    "pages": }\n\n'''Paul Angelo Vallone''' (June 2, 1967 – January 28, 2024) was an American politician and attorney from the state of New York. A , Vallone represented the  on the  from 2014 to 2021; the district was located in northeast . He later served as the Deputy Commissioner of External Affairs for the New York City Department of Veterans' Services.\n\n\nPaul Vallone was the son of New York City Council Speaker ; the grandson of Judge ; and the brother of , a politician and judge. Paul Vallone attended high school at . He then graduated from  with a  and from  with a .\n\nPrior to entering politics, Vallone served as the managing partner for the law firm of Vallone & Vallone, LLP. The firm was founded by his grandfather, Charles J. Vallone, in 1932. Both Vallone's father and his brother served on the New York City Council before he did.\n\n\nVallone first ran for the  in 2009, but came in third in the Democratic primary for the . In the 2013 Democratic primary election for the same seat, Vallone defeated Austin Shafran. He defeated  nominee Dennis Saffran in the general election. Vallone was re-elected in 2017.\n\nIn 2021, Vallone ran for a municipal judgeship, but was defeated by Republican Joseph Kasper.\n\nAfter his City Council tenure ended due to term limits, Vallone served as the Deputy Commissioner of External Affairs for the New York City Department of Veterans' Services.\n\n\n\n\n\nVallone and his wife, Anna-Marie, had three children. He had long-term  of the lungs, and tested positive for COVID-19 in April 2020 during .\n\nVallone died of a heart attack on January 28, 2024, at the age of 56.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Michael G. DenDekker''' (born July 11, 1961) is an American politician and former  for the  34th district, which included the neighborhoods of , , and , all in the Borough and County of .\n\n\nDenDekker was born in Jackson Heights, attending Our Lady of Fatima Grammar School and . He attended the , majoring in automotive technology.\n\nAfter college he worked as a banquet manager for a caterer and an account representative for . He joined the  in 1995, where he was promoted to supervisor in March 2001. Later that year he was assigned to the  as a public information officer and in 2003 he also became a special projects coordinator. He retired from the Sanitation Department and his assignment at OEM in 2006, after which he was a facilities manager for the .\n\nFrom 1998 to 2002, he worked as a part-time district representative for State Assembly member .  After longtime Assemblyman  decided not to run for reelection, DenDekker ran for the seat. He won uncontested s in 2008 and 2010.\n\n\nDenDekker attracted public attention with two bills he proposed in February 2011 that would have required all s in New York to be registered, inspected, and given s for a mandatory US $25 fee. DenDekker proposed the idea as an attempt to draw attention to bicyclists who violate existing state laws and to generate revenue for the state. After significant objections from his colleagues, constituents and local clerks, DenDekker withdrew the bill.\n\nIn May 2010, DenDekker introduced a bill to develop a  recycling program and require a minimum deposit of one cent per .\n\nIn 2020, he was defeated in the Democratic primary by  opponent .\n\n\nDenDekker and his wife Angela have four children: Michael, Linda, Elizabeth, and Jason. His step-daughter, Elizabeth Delaney, died on March 11, 2012. He has three grandchildren Jasen, Vincent, and Justin.  He occasionally works as an actor, has appeared in several movies and TV shows&mdash;including the first two seasons of , as a Detective&mdash;and is a member of the .\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Carolyn Jane Maloney''' (née '''Bosher''', February 19, 1946) is an American politician who served as the  for  from 2013 to 2023, and for  from 1993 to 2013. The district includes most of 's ,  and  in , , as well as . A member of the , Maloney ran for reelection in  but lost the primary to 10th district incumbent  after redistricting drew them both into the 12th district.\n\nMaloney was the first woman to represent New York City's 7th Council district (where she was the first woman to give birth while in office). Maloney was also the first woman to chair the . On October 17, 2019, she became the first woman to chair the  following the death of . On November 20, 2019, Maloney was formally chosen to succeed Cummings.\n\n\nCarolyn Jane Bosher was born in , on February 19, 1946. She attended . After graduating, she visited  in 1970, and decided to stay.\n\nFor several years, she worked as a teacher and an administrator for the . In 1977, she obtained a job working for the , and held senior staff positions in both the State Assembly and the State Senate. In 1976 she married , an .\n\n\nMaloney was elected to the  in 1982, defeating incumbent Robert Rodriguez in a heavily Spanish-speaking district based in  and parts of the . She served as a council member for 10 years. On the council, she served as the first chair of the Committee on Contracts, investigating contracts issued by New York City in sludge and other areas. She authored legislation creating the city's  program, which established computerized systems tracking information on city contracts and vendors doing business with the city. Maloney also introduced the first measure in New York to recognize s, including those of s. She was the first person to give birth while serving as a council member, and the first to offer a comprehensive package of legislation to make day care more available and affordable.\n\n\n\n\nIn 1992, Maloney ran for Congress in what was then the 14th district. The district had previously been the 15th, represented by 15-year incumbent , a progressive . She won with 51% of the vote. The district, nicknamed the \"silk stocking district\", had been one of the few in the city in which Republicans usually did well; in fact, they held the seat for all but eight of the 56 years between 1937 and Maloney's victory. But it had been made significantly friendlier to Democrats by redistricting. The old 15th had been more or less coextensive with the , but the new 14th included Long Island City, portions of the Upper West Side, and a sliver of Brooklyn. Maloney also benefited from 's strong showing in the district.\n\nThe core of Maloney's district was the Upper East Side, an area with a history of electing moderate Republicans. Their dominance waned throughout the 1990s, and by the early 2000s Democrats dominated every level of government. This was exemplified in 1994 (the year of the ), when a serious challenger to Maloney, Republican City Councilman , lost badly. No Republican has gotten more than 30% of the vote in the district since.\n\nIn 2004, Maloney faced a potential Democratic primary challenge from Robert Jereski, a former  political candidate and unsuccessful candidate for delegate to the  on the slate of . Jereski opposed the  while Maloney had initially voted for the resolution to authorize force; she later renounced the war, including at a town hall meeting in her district with antiwar Congressman , where her comments made headlines. Jereski failed to qualify for the ballot because his petition was found to have invalid signatures, leaving him four short of the 1,250 required.\n\nIn December 2008, Maloney hired a public-relations firm to help bolster her efforts to be named by Governor  as 's successor in the U.S. Senate. She toured parts of the state, but was overshadowed by 's promotional tour for the same seat. Maloney interviewed with Paterson for 55 minutes. Public opinion polls placed Maloney's support for the Senate seat in the single digits, trailing the front-runner, then-State Attorney General , although her bid was endorsed by the  Political Action Committee, the  Political Action Committee, '''' columnist , and other columnists and editorial boards.\n\nOn January 23, 2009, Paterson chose Representative . Since Gillibrand is from upstate, many in NYC's political circles urged Maloney to primary Gillibrand in 2010. Despite leading Gillibrand in the polls, she instead ran to retain her congressional seat. A decade later, Maloney was the sole member of Congress to endorse .\n \nIn the Democratic primary for Congress on September 14, 2010, Maloney defeated a well-funded opponent, , a 34-year-old   lawyer, by 62 percentage points. That night, Saujani said, \"I'm definitely running again\", but three months later announced publicly that she would not challenge Maloney again.\n\nIn 2012 Maloney's Republican challenger was Christopher Wright, who took a leave of absence from J. P. Morgan to campaign. Maloney won with 80.9% of the vote, a margin of over 120,000 votes.\n\nIn 2014, Maloney defeated Republican nominee Nicholas Di Iorio, a financial contractor with Pfizer, with 80% of the vote.\n\nIn the 2016 Democratic primary, Maloney defeated Pete Lindner with 90.1% of the vote. She defeated Republican  in the general election with 83.2% of the vote.\n\nIn the 2018 Democratic primary, Maloney defeated progressive candidate  with 59.6% of the vote. In the general election she defeated Republican nominee Eliot Rabin with 86.4% of the vote.\n\nIn the 2020 Democratic primary, Patel challenged Maloney again, as did progressive Democrat Lauren Ashcraft and housing activist Peter Harrison. Erica Vladimer, a co-founder of New York State's Sexual Harassment Working Group, withdrew from the race before the primary. By July 29, 2020, it was revealed that Maloney led Patel by about 4% and 3,700 votes. On August 4, 2020, local election officials declared Maloney the winner of the primary.\n\nThe redistricting process of 2022 consolidated parts of the 12th and  Congressional districts.  Maloney chose to face fellow incumbent  in the Democratic primary race for the newly combined seat, and in August of that year lost the primary to Nadler by thirty points.\n\n\n , , and  in 1999]]\n in 2001]]\nIn 2009, the ''National Journal'''s annual ranking placed Maloney as the 114th-most liberal (or 314th-most conservative) member of Congress, with more liberal scores on foreign policy than on economic and social policy. Her score of 75.5 ranked her as modestly more liberal than the New York Congressional delegation as a whole.\n\nIn 2011, a ''Daily News'' survey found that Maloney ranked first among New York's 28 representatives for activity with 36 proposed bills, resolutions, and amendments. In the 2013 legislative session, Govtrack.us scored her third among House Democrats for \"Leadership,\" third among all representatives for \"Powerful Co-sponsors,\" third-highest in the New York delegation for \"Working with the Senate,\" and fifth-highest among all representatives for \"Bills Sponsored.\" During the 2014 election cycle, the ''New York Daily News'' ran a story that said, \"Maloney has proposed more legislation than any other House member, according to records\", and called her \"James Zadroga 9/11 Health and Compensation Act, giving compensation to  workers who have fallen ill, as big a bill for the New York area as any in the last decade.\"\n\nFor the 2015 legislative session,  scored Maloney first for \"Leadership\" among House Democrats, based on sponsoring the most bills. It scored her second among all representatives for having the most co-sponsors, second for \"Working with the Senate\" and fourth among House Democrats for having powerful cosponsors. She was ranked in the top 10% of all representatives for bills introduced (\"Maloney introduced 26 bills and resolutions in 2015\").\n\nAs a U.S. Representative, Maloney was a superdelegate at presidential conventions. In the 2016 election cycle she was an early supporter of former Secretary of State and Senator . According to her 2018 GovTrack Report card Maloney ranked in the 80th percentile among House members for getting bicameral support for the bills she has introduced; she ranked sixth among House Democrats.\n\nIn 2019, Govtrack.us ranked Maloney as the top legislative leader in the House. This analysis ranked her second among all representatives for the most co-sponsors on her bills, in the top 5% for the number of bills introduced, and in the top 10% for getting her bills out of committee.\n\nFor her tenure as chair of the House Oversight and Reform Committee in the 116th Congress, Maloney earned an \"A\" grade from the nonpartisan Lugar Center's Congressional Oversight Hearing Index.\n\nIn 2021 the Center for Effective Lawmaking ranked Maloney the third-most effective lawmaker in the House.\n\n\n\nFollowing the , Maloney advocated for federal help for New York's recovery and security efforts. Her efforts prompted  of the '''' to write that Maloney was \"like a tiger in the House on every dollar due New York.\"\n\nOn February 25, 2019, she introduced her Never Forget the Heroes Act, HR1327 in the 116th Congressa bill to establish Permanent Authorization of the September 11 Victim Compensation Fund Act. The $10.2 billion authorization was signed into law, establishing that both the World Trade Center Health Program and September 11 Victim Compensation are effectively permanent, with the WTCHP authorized to operate until 2090 and the VCF until 2092.\n\n\nAfter the  published its findings, Maloney co-founded the bipartisan House 9/11 Commission Caucus and helped write and secure the enactment into law of many of its recommendations to reform the nation's intelligence agencies ''Congressional Quarterly'' wrote in its annual guide, 2006 Politics in America: \"In the 108th Congress, Maloney reached out beyond her usual roles as a liberal gadfly and persistent Bush administration critic, helping win enactment of a sweeping bill to reorganize U.S. intelligence operations.\"\n\nFollowing the , Maloney helped secure the passage and enactment of her bill to reform the system for vetting foreign investments in the United States. She has supported Scientology's \"\".\n and Nobel Peace Prize laureate  in September 2016]]\nOn October 1, 2020, Maloney co-signed a letter to Secretary of State  that condemned ’s offensive operations against the -populated enclave of , denounced ’s role in the , and criticized \"false equivalence between Armenia and Azerbaijan, even as the latter threatens war and refuses to agree to monitoring along the line of contact.\"\n\nMaloney, who chairs the , called on FBI Director  to open a probe into social media platform , writing, \"The company was founded by John Matze shortly after he traveled in Russia with his wife, who is  and whose family reportedly has ties to the Russian government.\"\n\n\nIn response to a number of high-profile incidents of gun violence, Maloney sponsored two bills to address the issue. The Gun Trafficking Prevention Act of 2013 would make gun trafficking a federal crime for the first time and substantially stiffen the penalties for \"straw buyers\" who knowingly help convicted felons, domestic abusers, the violently mentally ill and others, obtain guns.\n\nIn 2014, she joined Senator  in sending President  a letter asking him to insert $10 million into the budget for the  to resume research on gun violence and \"conduct scientific research on the causes and prevention of gun violence.\"\n\nIn 2022, as chair of the , Maloney held a hearing that examined leading gun manufacturers' marketing and sales practices.\n\n\nMaloney introduced a bill in October 2003 intended to enforce transparency in relation to military contracting in  and subject the  to . In 2008, after reports of corruption among military contractors in both Iraq and , she secured House passage of a further bill to create a database to better monitor all federal contracts, the key provisions of which were adopted into law as part of the defense budget.\n\nIn 2010, the , a government watchdog group, presented Maloney with its Good Government Award for her contributions to government transparency and oversight, including her investigations into corruption and mismanagement in the  and her support of a Federal Contractor Misconduct Database similar to POGO's.\n\nIn 2019, Maloney introduced a bill that would require corporate entities to disclose the identities of beneficial owners to , making it harder for them to hide assets and avoid taxes through a series of limited liability companies.\n\n\nMaloney has taken several actions on health care issues. Her measure to provide  coverage for annual s was included in the Fiscal Year 1998 federal budget. She advocated for providing federal support for medical monitoring and health care for rescue and recovery workers who were exposed to toxic smoke and dust at the  site after the 9/11 attacks. Maloney authored the James Zadroga 9/11 Health and Compensation Act and led the fight for years to push for its passage. In 2010 Obama signed the bill into law. It provides $4.3 billion in federal funds to provide 9/11 responders and survivors with treatment and compensation for their injuries. In June 2012, it was announced that the program would be expanded to cover care for a variety of cancers of the lung, trachea, stomach, colon, rectum, liver, bladder, kidney, thyroid and breast.\n\nIn 2015 when roughly 33,000 responders and survivors were battling an assortment of ailments, Maloney led the effort to extend the bill permanently. After a prolonged and very public push, a total of $8.5 billion in funding was included in the Omnibus Spending bill that passed in 2015 and extended the life of the monitoring and health insurance coverage for 75 years. In the 111th Congress, Maloney introduced The Breastfeeding Promotion Act to protect  in the workplace under  law and make it illegal for women to lose their jobs or otherwise be discriminated against for expressing milk during lunchtime or on breaks. She has advocated for international women's health and family planning programs supported by the .\n\nA co-founder and co-chair of the Congressional Working Group on , Maloney serves on the board of the Michael Stern Parkinson's Research Foundation and previously served as an honorary board member of the .\n\nMaloney has promoted scientifically discredited claims of a . On several occasions, she has introduced legislation that would direct the federal government to conduct studies into the alleged links between  and vaccines. In a 2012 congressional hearing, Maloney equated concerns over a link between autism and vaccines to concerns over a link between smoking and cancer. She said that it was \"common sense that [smoking] was bad for your health... The same thing seems to be here with the vaccinations.\"\n\nMaloney's views on vaccines changed, and she led efforts to bring COVID-19 vaccine sites to North Brooklyn and western Queens. She partnered with The Floating Hospital and the New York City Housing Authority to establish a modular site to provide COVID-19 testing and vaccination services at Astoria Houses in northwest Queens.\n\n\nMaloney serves on the  and the , and is the Ranking Democratic member of the Joint Economic Committee. She previously chaired the Democratic Task Force on Homeland Security. From 2009 to 2011, Maloney chaired the , the first woman to do so.\n\nMaloney was the author of the Credit Cardholders' Bill of Rights, or the , while serving as chair of the Subcommittee on Financial Institutions and Consumer Credit, in the 110th Congress. A 2014 Social Science Research Network study estimated that since its passage, the CARD Act has saved consumers $11.9 billion per year. Credit card companies fiercely opposed the measure, but it drew praise from editorial boards and consumer advocates. The bill was passed as the  by both houses of the 111th Congress, prompting  to dub Maloney the ''\"''best friend a credit card user ever had.''\"'' Obama signed the Credit Card Bill of Rights into law in a  ceremony Maloney attended on May 22, 2009.\n\nDays after voting against cancellation of a $1 billion, 10-year subsidy plan for U.S. sugar farmers within the , Maloney hosted a  event that netted $9,500 in contributions from sugar growers and refiners, according to  records. Her election attorney, Andrew Tulloch, called the timing of the July 31 fundraiser \"pure coincidence.\" The bill passed the House by a 282–144 vote. The  pointed out that among the 435 members of the House, Maloney has the ninth-highest amount of investment in oil stocks. She received a perfect 100 rating from the Defenders of Wildlife Action Fund in 2007, a perfect 100 rating from Environment America in 2008 and a perfect 100 from the League of Conservation Voters in 2008. And in 2008, Maloney introduced the Minerals Management Service Improvement Act (HR 7211) as a House companion to Integrity in Offshore Energy Resources Act (S. 3543). The legislation would impose dramatically tougher ethics rules for the Minerals Management Service, which was at the center of a major corruption scandal stemming from its employees' relationships with oil company representatives.\n\n\n, and  speak out on the need to keep birth control safe and legal in 2005]]\n  at the proclamation signing for Women's History Month in 2008]]\n\nMaloney has been active on many other issues involving women, children and families since the beginning of her career. A former co-chair of the House Caucus on Women's Issues, she authored and helped secure the enactment into law of a measure to provide federal funding to clear the backlog of  for which evidence had been collected, but never entered into law enforcement DNA databases. The Rape Abuse and Incest National Network called it \"the most important anti-rape legislation ever considered by Congress\". Maloney's bill, included in the Justice for All Act of 2005, was named the  in honor of Debbie Smith, a rape survivor. The effort to enact the bill was later the subject of a  movie, ''A Life Interrupted: The Debbie Smith Story'', in which Maloney was played by . Maloney also co-authored and helped secure passage of bipartisan legislation to curb the demand for sex trafficking.\n\nMaloney introduced the Child Care Affordability Act of 2007 to increase access to child care by providing tax credits. Her amendment to a foreign aid bill succeeded in securing $60 million in funding for programs for Afghan women and girls and to help establish an Afghan commission on human rights. She is the chief House sponsor of the . In 2008 and again in 2009, Maloney authored, and secured House passage of, a bill to provide four weeks of paid parental leave to federal employees.\n\nIn 2011, Maloney sponsored the Campus Sexual Violence Elimination Act, known as the Campus SaVE Act. It became part of the reauthorization of the Violence Against Women Act of 2013. The measure guarantees counseling, legal assistance, and medical care on campuses for victims of sexual assault, establishes minimum, national standards for schools to follow in responding to allegations of sexual assault and sexual violence, and makes explicit that schools must provide to both the alleged perpetrator and the alleged victim the same rights, including access to advisers, written notifications, as well as appeals processes during campus disciplinary proceedings.\n\nSaying that \"for too long, women's stories have been left out of the telling of our nation’s history\", Maloney began work in the 1990s on establishing a Smithsonian American Women’s History Museum on the National Mall. After years of effort, her bill passed and was signed into law in 2020.\n\nAfter Virginia became the 38th state to ratify the ERA, Maloney and  introduced a resolution to recognize that the ERA had met all legal requirements to be considered the 28th amendment to the . In March 2022, Maloney sent U.S. archivist David Ferriero a letter urging him to fulfill his statutory duty and publish the ERA.\n\n\nMaloney has helped secure funding for major  projects, resulting in the commitment of billions of federal dollars for New York State. She has been hailed as a champion of the .\n\nMaloney co-sponsored the 2009 reintroduction of the  (, originally introduced as  in 2008) and the  () introduced in 2011. Both bills aim to reverse the 's Public Access Policy, which   to -funded research. Some scientists criticized the -backed Research Works Act. In a ''New York Times'' op-ed, Michael Eisen said the bill would force the public to pay $15–$30 per paper to read the results of research they had already paid for as taxpayers. (Such results must now be published in  (PMC) after an embargo period of up to 12 months; this embargo period was imposed to minimize financial harm to publishers who were concerned that their readership would diminish if the results appeared concurrently in PMC, though authors of the paper are required to submit their papers to PMC as soon as their paper gets accepted for publication by a peer-review journal.) Some have suggested that Maloney supports the measure because she is the recipient of campaign contributions from , the largest scholarly publishing company. On February 27, 2012, following a , Maloney wrote to her constituents, \"it is important to be mindful of the impact of various industries on job creation and retention. New York State is home to more than 300 publishers that employ more than 12,000 New Yorkers, many of whom live in or around New York City in my district. New York City scientific publishers represent a significant subset of the total, and more than 20 are located in Manhattan, publishing thousands of scientific journals and employing thousands of New Yorkers.\" Elsevier withdrew its support for the legislation.\n\nIn 2021, Maloney protested the expansion of the , a nonprofit biomedical research facility, from a three-story-headquarters to a 16-story tower on Manhattan's Upper East Side.\n\n\n*\n**\n**\n* (chair)\n** As chair of the full committee, Maloney may serve as an ''ex officio'' member of all subcommittees.\n*\n* (Vice Chair)\n\n\n*House 9/11 Commission Caucus\n*House Caucus on Women's Issues\n*\n*\n*Americans Abroad Caucus (founder and co-chair)\n*\n*\n*Co-chair, Congressional Hellenic Caucus\n*\n*\n* \n*\n* House Pro-Choice Caucus\n* Congressional Skin Cancer Caucus (founder and co-chair)\n\n\nMaloney's ratings from various interest groups include the following:\n\n* The  (AAUW) gives her a 100.\n* NARAL Pro-Choice America gives her a 100.\n* Drug Policy Action gives her an A for 2015/2016.\n*  gives her a 100.\n* The Human Rights Campaign gives her a 100.\n* The Alliance for Retired Americans gives her a 100.\n* The League of Conservation Voters gives her a 96 for 2013 and 95 lifetime.\n* The  gives her a 90 for 2011.\n* The  gives her an A.\n* The  gives her a 100.\n* The  (AFSCME) gives her a 100.\n* The  gave her a 2019 core of 90%, and a lifetime score of 97%.\n* The  gave her a 100+ rating in 2013, and a 100 in 2020.\n* The Brady Campaign to Prevent Gun Violence gives her a 100.\n* The NRA gives her an F.\n* The  gave her an F in 2010.\n\n\n\n\nOn October 16, 2001, Maloney wore an   while giving a  in the  in support of Afghan women's rights and  against the . It was the first time an  had been worn on the House floor, and was technically not allowed under an unenforced .\n\nIn a 2018 '''' article, , a   author and journalist, called Maloney's display \"theatrical\" and an example of \", in which American womenintrepid and veil-freeare beacons of freedom with a duty to evangelize their particular brand of empowerment, even if it means using bombs.\" Muslim-American , while running in the Democratic primary against Maloney in 2021, criticized this event as feeding negative stereotypes about Muslims and of \"weapon[izing my identity] to justify American wars\". Maloney subsequently defended it as being necessary to make her point.\n\n\nOn July 20, 2009, Maloney apologized after saying the  \"\" while quoting a phone call she had received about   in an interview with ''City Hall News''. At the time, she was a week away from announcing an official campaign against Gillibrand in the . The quote, as reported by '''', was: \n\nCivil rights activist  criticized the remark and called Maloney's casual use of the word \"alarming\" but said he did not believe she was . She apologized and dropped out of the race on August 7, 2009, reportedly for different reasons.\n\n\nDuring the 2022 primary, Maloney campaigned on her work within the district, as well as her gender in the wake of ''''. Many of Maloney's activities were scrutinized, including her comments and legislation promoting . During a debate with Nadler, Maloney attracted attention for saying that she believed President  would not run for reelection in . She also told '''' that she thought he should not run in 2024. Maloney later apologized and said that Biden should run again, though she maintained her belief that he would not.\n\n\nIn 2022, the  was investigating Maloney for allegedly casting around for an invitation to the . Investigators alleged Maloney had sought an invitation for herself after being cut from the invite list in 2016. Maloney called former president of the , , to request an invitation, according to testimony Rafferty gave investigators. Investigators also found that Maloney might have requested an invitation to the 2020 Met Gala, citing an email thread with a staffer in which she asked whether she was invited and how to contact the Met's government affairs staffer. In a February 2022 report, the  said it found \"substantial reason to believe that Rep. Maloney may have solicited or accepted impermissible gifts associated with her attendance at the Met Gala.\"\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nMaloney and her husband, , raised two daughters.     "pages": }\n'''Bradford S. Lander''' (born July 8, 1969) is an American politician, urban planner, and community organizer who currently serves as the . A member of the , Lander is a  politician, and has been described as \"one of the most left-leaning politicians in the city.\"\n\nLander was first elected to the City Council in 2009, later serving as the Deputy Leader for Policy. His district included portions of Brooklyn.\n\nIn 2021, Lander was  as the 45th , and assumed office on January 1, 2022. He was notably endorsed by \"some of the nation's most prominent progressives, including Representative  of New York and Senator  of Massachusetts.\"\n\nIn July 2024, Lander announced he would challenge incumbent   in the .\n\n\nLander is a  native, and son of Carole Lander and David Lander, a bankruptcy attorney. He grew up in the  suburb of  in a  family. He earned a bachelor's degree from the  in 1991, where he received a , and master's degrees in anthropology from  on a  and in  from the .\n\n\nFrom 1993 to 2003, Lander was the executive director of the Fifth Avenue Committee (FAC), a  not-for-profit organization that develops and manages affordable housing. For his work he received the 2000 New York Magazine Civics Award, and FAC received the 2002 Leadership for a Changing World award (sponsored by the Washington, D.C.-based Institute for Sustainable Communities).\n\nFrom 2003 to 2009, Lander was a director of the university-based . In that position, he was a critic of the 's development policies. He has also been a critic of the  project. Lander's work in 2003–2005 on Greenpoint-Williamsburg rezoning led to the first New York City inclusionary housing program to create affordable housing in new development outside Manhattan. Lander served on a mayoral taskforce that recommended reforms to the  for luxury housing and required that new development in certain areas of the city set aside affordable housing units. He co-led the completion of the One City One Future platform, a progressive vision for economic development in New York City. He stepped down as head of the organization in 2009 to seek a seat on the . Lander teaches as an adjunct professor at .\n\n'''' described Lander as \"one of the most left-leaning politicians in the city.\"\n\n\n\n\nLander is a co-founder of the Progressive Caucus in the New York City Council, a group that was described by '''' as \"the City Council's most liberal members.\" For his first term, Lander shared the title of Co-Chair of the caucus with his Manhattan colleague Speaker .\n\nLander was one of four Council members who brought  to New York City, which allows citizens to propose, develop, and vote on items in the municipal budget. Over half of the 51 New York City Council Districts now engage in participatory budgeting.\n\n\nLander was first elected to New York City Council office on the  and  lines on November 4, 2009, with 70% of the vote. Lander had won a hotly contested Democratic primary on September 15, 2009 with 41% of the vote in a field of five. His district included portions of Brooklyn: , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , and .\n\nLander was reelected on the Democratic and Working Families Parties' lines in 2013 to serve for a second term.\n\nIn 2013, Lander played a key role in a campaign to pass paid sick leave over Mayor Bloomberg's veto, telling the Brooklyn Reporter the legislation would \"make our city a fairer, more compassionate place to live and work.\" Lander passed the Independent Expenditure Disclosure Act, giving NYC the most aggressive SuperPAC disclosure requirements in the country. In 2015, Lander passed legislation to ban discriminatory employment credit checks, ending the practice of companies discriminating against people because of their credit history.\nIn March 2015, Lander was arrested for blocking traffic in Park Slope to show support for eight striking car washers, outside a car wash that was closed at the time; it was his fourth arrest. '''' covered his arrest with an article entitled: \"Please Don't Arrest MeUntil the Cameras Are Here\". In November 2016 he announced his intention to get arrested, saying it was: \"part of a long tradition of civil disobedience, and it takes a little courage.\" In December 2017 he was arrested inside the  in Washington DC as he was protesting a tax bill and refusing the request of police to move the protest from public spaces; he tweeted \"Being arrested ... in the halls of Congress while ... fighting for a country where we provide health care for those who need it ... is something I'll remember for the rest of my life\". In June 2018 he was arrested for blocking traffic, disorderly conduct, and failing to disperse at a protest outside the office of State Senator .\n\nIn May 2016, Lander upset Asian community groups by calling supporters of Chinese-American Yungman Lee (a challenger of Representative ) \".\" Asian groups called his comment racist, and rallied at  to denounce it. Lee said Lander's comments were disrespectful, and his choice of words was especially distasteful, adding: \"In my view it's over the top of what should be part of our political discourse... we shouldn't have language like that in our politics.\" Lee demanded an apology, but Lander refused.\n\nLander opposed rezoning the site of  to include . As of July 2017, he was the primary sponsor of 20 local laws enacted by the City Council and signed by the . In addition, Lander played a role in helping shepherd the Community Safety Act to passage, with Council member . In 2017, Lander worked with advocates at the Association of Neighborhood and Housing Development and  to create a Certificate of No Harassment program that provides the strongest protections against tenant harassment & displacement of any law in the country. Lander also led the campaign that secured air-conditioning in all NYC school classrooms, shining a spotlight on the fact that 25 percent of classrooms previously did not have A/C, as part of the #TooHotToLearn campaign.\n\nLander has crafted a number of workers' rights policies. In 2017, Lander passed legislation to win a fair work week for fast-food and retail workers. He also worked with the Freelancers Union to create the \",\" the first legislation of its kind to ensure that freelancers and independent contractors are paid on time and in full. In 2018, Lander won the first rule in the country to guarantee a living wage for Uber, Lyft and other for-hire drivers. By April 2020, Lander had sponsored over 2,254 article of legislation. '''' ranked the performance of Lander in the lower half of NYC lawmakers, ranking him 30th out of the 51 councilmembers, on the criteria of the number of bills introduced, the number of bills signed into law, attendance, and responsiveness to questions from constituents and from the media.\n\n\nIn November 2018, Democratic Assemblymember  urged Lander to speak out against Lander's friend pro-Palestinian activist , for what Hikind described as her  views, criticisms of Israel, and reluctance to denounce  Minister , and \"Show us that the progressive movement is not a safe haven for haters.\" Lander had defended Sarsour the year prior when some urged that she not be allowed to be the commencement speaker at the City University of New York's Graduate School of Public Health. In 2020 he said he had: \"traveled to the  to get a glimpse of the horrors of life under occupation and the struggle against it.\"\n\nStarting in 2019, Lander has drawn criticism and, in his words, \"anger\" and \"suspicion\" for vocally supporting contracts for two s in particular. He did this despite multiple press reports that those contracts contain up to $89 million of unexplained cost compared to contracts for equivalent shelters, and that there is no apparent explanation for the increased cost, which neighbors said was $10,557 per unit per month. Lander acknowledged that the contracts will benefit developers accused of wrongdoing in the past.\n\nIn 2019 Lander admitted to an  for using his official government position to solicit monetary donations for a progressive non-profit he helped to create, and of which he was Chairman. Lander chairs the Council's Committee on Rules, Privileges and Ethics. In his second term on the Council, Lander served as the deputy leader for policy.\n\n\nIn March 2020, as the  began, Lander urged that the police suspend criminal arrests, summonses, warrant enforcement, and parole violations for low-level offenses, and release most of the over 900 people incarcerated at  who were over 50 years old.\n\nStarting in 2020, Lander has been a leading advocate of a program that has moved over 9,500  (Lander's goal is 30,000 homeless) to vacant hotel rooms across New York City to provide space for social distancing during the coronavirus pandemic, at an average cost of $174 per room per night (or $5,293 per person per month). The proposal drew intense criticism from New York Mayor Bill de Blasio's , which called it ham-fisted and reckless, self-defeatingly unilateral and ill-informed, and legally questionable and amateurish: insisting on using a one-size fits all approach for a system that is anything but, and forcing the involuntary rushed transfer of more than ten thousand people into hotels without appropriate services to match, putting individuals with higher service needs, including substance use challenges, at risk in the process. Lander called DSS's concerns \"cartoonish insults.\" The program has also drawn strong reactions from neighborhood residents, with some residents saying the program has led to significant increases in crime, nonstop open drug sales and drug use, public sex acts, and rampant street harassment of women and girls, and worrying about the risk of having s housed 1-block from a public school; other residents have been more open to the program.\n\nLander voiced support for  and limiting police powers by cutting their budget by $1 billion in 2020. In June 2020, Lander announced: \"It is time to \". In December he called for the disbandment of the  Vice Unit, and .\n\nLander said in December 2020 that it was a core ideal of his to \"comfort the afflicted, and afflict the comfortable.\"\n\nIn January 2021 he said: \"As a white man, [the work of racial justice] starts by listening as honestly as I can to Black people about the anger and pain they are feeling, and the system of  and systemic racism it reflects. That is not easy -- because it implicates me....\" He supports removing the  from  in Manhattan.\n\nIn March 2022, Comptroller Lander disagreed with Mayor ' new Medicare program for New York City employees and city retirees. Lander says the program is unnecessary and as comptroller he (Lander) can use his authority to prevent the contracts from being implemented. Sources close to Lander talking to the '''' and '''' say he is going to challenge to Adams for Mayorship in the . One source said that if that becomes improbable, he will revert to a reelection bid for his current job as Comptroller. The sources say he will not announce an , but instead make an announcement in July 2024; pundits speculate that the announcement would come after the .\n\n\n\n\n\n\nFacing term limits for his council seat after his third term, Lander announced his candidacy for the , an open race as the incumbent, , faced term limits. He ran in the Democratic primary against among others NY State Senator , entrepreneur and former US Marine , NY State Senator , former Public Advocate and former New York City Council Speaker  and NY Assemblymember .\n\nLander said that if elected he would expand the office to conduct equity audits to reduce disparities across race, gender, and ethnicity, including in how city agencies hire contractors. He said he would also use the office as an organizing vehicle for advocates, and produce audits, draft reports, and release data in partnership with organizers running campaigns centered on racial, social, and economic justice. Lander received endorsements from the , unions including  District 1, and various Democratic clubs and community organizations. He was endorsed by elected officials including NYC Public Advocate , Congresswoman , Congresswoman , and members of the New York City Council and New York State legislature.\n\nCandidates who raise at least $125,000 from at least 500 donors qualify for  from the , on an 8-to-1 match basis. As of February 16, 2021, he was one of three candidates who had qualified for matching funds, along with  and .\n Mural at  in Park Slope on May 8, 2021]]\n\nLander defeated  in the Democratic primary for comptroller and won the general election over Republican candidate Daby Carreras.\n\n\nIn 2022, Lander called for ending , a program that provided tax incentives for developers of market-rate apartments who also added below-market rentals. When the program was not renewed by the New York legislature, Lander said, \"It's good that it is not being renewed.\" Supporters of the tax incentive said it encouraged housing construction and alleviated the housing shortage in New York.\n\nLander is a member of the Vote Blue Coalition, a progressive group and  created to support Democrats in New York, New Jersey, and Pennsylvania through voter outreach and mobilization efforts.\n\n\n\n\n\nLander lives in Brooklyn with his wife, Meg Barnette, a former executive at , now president of Nonprofit New York. He also served as the Housing Chair of Brooklyn Community Board 6, served on the board of directors of the , and is a  coach in the 78th Precinct Youth Council.\n\nLander joined the  in 1987 when he was a student at the University of Chicago.\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Frank Charles Moore''' (March 23, 1896 &ndash; April 23, 1978) was a Canadian-born  lawyer and  who served as the 48th .\n\n\nMoore was born in , , in 1896. When he was 11 months old, his parents moved to , where he was raised. Moore attended  and earned a law degree from the .\n\n\nDuring , Moore served in the ,  and . He was discharged in 1917 for being underweight.\n\n\nMoore was a delegate to the s of 1938 and 1967. He was the  from 1943 to 1950, elected in  and .\n\nAt the , he was elected  and took office on January 1, 1951. He resigned on September 30, 1953, to become president of 's Government Affairs Foundation.\n\n\nMoore died on April 23, 1978, in . He was buried at Elmlawn Cemetery in .\n\n\n\n\n* at ''Political Graveyard''\n* His resignation announced, in ''Time'' magazine on May 4, 1953.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Judith Kennedy''' (October 25, 1944 &ndash; April 15, 2018) was an American politician and businesswoman. She was an , but was a member of the  until 2015. In 2011, Kennedy was elected Mayor of , serving in the office until her death in 2018.\n\nIn the 1990s, Kennedy worked for  in , before ultimately moving to Newburgh.\n\nDuring her tenure as mayor, Kennedy focused on Newburgh's reputation as one of the most dangerous places to live in the United States, through focus on reducing crime, bringing in business and revitalizing neighborhoods. She won a second term running as an independent after losing the Democratic nomination in 2015.\n\n\nKennedy was born in , on October 25, 1944, to alcoholic parents. At the age of ten, Kennedy was responsible for her family when necessity forced her mother to take on a full-time job as a store clerk, while her father worked two jobs day and night. Three years later, Kennedy and her family moved to .\n\nAfter graduating from high school, Kennedy married James Kennedy in 1964 and worked as a dental assistant. She filed for divorce in 1981 and took custody of her four children.\n\n\nKennedy taught homemaking crafts at her local church's women's organization in Baker City. She served as president of the church's youth group and co-chaired many of the church's fundraising efforts. Subsequently, Kennedy went on to become president of the Working Women's Conference.\n\nAfter her divorce, she studied at  and later transferred to , where she earned a  degree, majoring in business administration in 1982.\n\nIn the 1990s, Kennedy moved to , and worked for , including as a consultant for  and . In September 2006, she moved to  to help remodel her son's residence and to live closer with him.\n\n\nKennedy ran for Mayor of Newburgh in 2011 after she was outraged by a 71% tax rate increase. She started a grassroots group whose members collected signatures for a petition to be delivered to state legislators in . She replaced Nicholas J. Valentine, a . Kennedy was sworn in on January 1, 2012. Her platform included expanding the tax base to reduce everyone's taxes, increasing living-wage jobs and reforming government to make it more data-driven and focused on measurable outcomes.\n\nKennedy worked to change Newburgh's reputation as one of the most dangerous places to live in the United States, with focusing on reducing crime, bringing in business and revitalizing neighborhoods. She began her first term by announcing the formation of Community Action Teams with the goal of tackling issues ranging from beautification and job creation to public safety and a citywide arts and heritage festival. Three months into her first term, Kennedy oversaw the police shooting of Michael Lembhard which resulted in protests that included clashes between protesters and police. One of her main critics at that time, activist Omari Shakur, supported Kennedy's 2015 re-election campaign.\n\nKennedy won a second term in 2015 as the nominee of the Independence Party after beating Councilman  (who had defeated her in a Democratic primary) in the general election.\n\nIn May 2016, Kennedy was diagnosed with , but continued her council work. In April 2017, a celebration of her life was held in Newburgh with dozens of residents attending to honor her. Kennedy went to  that month for treatment.\n\nIn a March 2018 interview, Kennedy reflected on her future aspirations for Newburgh remarking that her greatest hope is that \"people lay down their sharp tongues and their weapons and decide to work together\". She also criticized New York state for not providing money to Newburgh and remarking that \"it is a slow progress. We don't have any money. We've been a cash-strapped city forever\", however, she remained optimistic in the city's crime improvement.\n\nIn the aftermath of her death, a special election was originally discussed which would have been held in November 2018 to determine her successor to the mayoral office. However, in May 2018, the city council appointed councilman Torrance Harvey as Kennedy's successor.\n\n\nKennedy died of ovarian cancer while under hospice care in Newburgh on April 15, 2018, at age 73.\n\nIn response to her death,   issued a statement on : \"Judy Kennedy and I shared a love for the City of Newburgh, and I saw her in action working every day to make Newburgh the City that its wonderful people deserve\".\n\nA memorial service was held on April 19 at the Newburgh Armory Unity Center with family and local politicians in attendance, including U.S. Representative Maloney.\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
          }

    "pages": }\n'''Mondaire Lamar Jones''' (born May 18, 1987) is an American lawyer and politician. A member of the , Jones was the U.S. representative for  from 2021 to 2023.\n\nBefore his 2022 defeat, Jones was described as a rising star on the  wing of the Democratic Party. He is an advocate for  and the . When first elected, he became one of the two first openly gay Black members of Congress. \n\nAfter the , he sought reelection in  in  losing the Democratic primary to attorney , who went on to win the seat in the general election. In July 2023, Jones announced that he would again seek election, this time in the 17th district, in 2024.\n\nJones was born in , and grew up in , where he was raised by a single mother, who worked multiple jobs to support him, and his grandparents. He graduated from public schools in the . \n\nJones earned his  from  in 2009. After graduating from Stanford, He worked in the  during the . He then earned his  from  in 2013.\n\nAfter law school, Jones worked as a law clerk for  of the . He also worked for  for four years, and one year with the  Law Department.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n results for the U.S. House of Representative for New York's ]]\nJones announced his candidacy for the   to represent the , including most of central and northwestern  and all of , against 16-term incumbent . Three months after he entered the race, Lowey announced that she would not seek reelection. He advocated for  and the . He also expressed support for defunding the police.\n\nIn a crowded eight-way Democratic primarythe real contest in this heavily Democratic districtJones defeated attorney Adam Schleifer, former Deputy Assistant Secretary of Defense ,  , and  , among others, winning 42% of the vote. The Associated Press called the race for Jones on July 14, 2020, three weeks after the June 23 primary, the vote tabulation having been delayed because of a large number of absentee ballots due to the .\n\nIn August, Jones filed a lawsuit against President  and Postmaster General  to reverse recent changes made to the  (USPS) that affected the agency's ability to deliver mail, including absentee ballots. Jones sued Trump and DeJoy \"for violating  in their attempts to undermine the United States Postal Service and thwart free and fair elections this November.\" In September, U.S. District Court Judge  granted an injunction against the USPS that required it to restore overtime and treat all mail-in ballots as .\n\nIn the November general election, Jones faced Republican nominee Maureen McArdle Schulman, a former  firefighter, as well as several third-party candidates. The Associated Press called the race for Jones the day after the election. Along with  from , Jones was one of the first gay African Americans elected to the .\n\n\n\nFollowing redistricting, the  included the residence of , the Democratic incumbent in the neighboring  and chair of the . Jones was no longer in the court drawn 17th district. According to '','' \"Maloney decided to run in New York's 17th congressional district rather than his longtime, more urban, 18th district, even though that meant booting out the newer Mondaire Jones, his fellow Democrat and the incumbent congressman in the 17th district\". According to '''', Maloney's decision \"infuriated Jones and his allies, particularly those in the , who accused Maloney of putting his own political survival over the interests of the party\".\n\nJones opted not to challenge Maloney in the redrawn 17th district; instead, on May 20, 2022, he announced that he would seek election in . He finished third in the Democratic primary in the 10th district, which was won by attorney . Jones received 18.2% of the vote.\n\n\n\nIn July 2023, Jones announced his candidacy to return to Congress, running in the  after relocating to , a village within the district's boundaries.\n\nAfter the  of Speaker , Jones tweeted a photo of McCarthy and  meeting with Jewish leaders in  captioned \"Well that was a waste of time.\" The post was condemned as antisemitic by Democrats  and . Jones took down the tweet and apologized for any misunderstanding. Following the removal Moskowitz and Gottheimer took down their response and Moskowitz accepted Jones's apology and emphasized his record of opposing antisemitism.\n\nJones's entry into the race solidified his position as the Democratic frontrunner, effectively clearing the primary field. By April 2024, he had raised over $3 million for his campaign.\n\n\n\nJones voted to certify the  and later voted to impeach during . He and  co-wrote a letter to the Attorney Grievance Committee of the New York State Supreme Court-Appellate Division asking for  to be disbarred due to his role in the .\n\nJones successfully lobbied  to halt the deportation of Paul Pierrilus, who was scheduled to be the last person to be deported during the Trump administration. Pierrilus, a constituent of Jones's, was to be deported to , a country he had never been to, before Jones intervened.\n\nJones, Senator , Representative , and  chair  pushed for an expansion of the  from 9 seats to 13. Around the same time, Jones called for a \"Third \" in a '''' opinion piece. He criticized President  for supporting the 9 member  system of the Supreme Court and opposing the court's expansion.\n\n\n*\n*\n**\n**\n* Representative Mondaire Jones|url=https://jones.house.gov/about/committees-and-caucuses|access-date=2021-02-02|website=jones.house.gov|date=January 3, 2021 }}\n**\n**\n*\n\n\n*\n*\n* (co-chair)\n\n\nIn 2023, Jones was appointed to the , a federal agency focused on investigating and reporting on civil rights issues. The same year, he joined  as an on-air contributor and began working with the nonprofit Future Forward USA Action, which supports progressive causes.\n\n\nJones publicly  as gay at the age of 24 and is a member of the First Baptist Church of Spring Valley. In 2020, marking the 50th anniversary of the first gay , '''' recognized Jones as one of 50 individuals \"leading the nation toward equality, acceptance, and dignity for all people.\"\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n| party = Democratic Party (United States)\n| votes = 11,777\n| percentage = 18.2\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n''|years=}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

His district included portions of ,  and  Counties.\n\nShortly after graduating law school, he joined the Monroe County District Attorney's Office, where he served as a felony trial prosecutor for six years.\n\nIn 1995, Hanna was elected to the Monroe County Legislature. He lost to   in the .\n\nHanna served as a lead trial attorney for Monroe County Executive Maggie Brooks' administration before his election to the New York State Assembly.     "pages": }\n'''Joseph Pinion III''' (born August 11, 1983) is an American former television host, businessman, and activist. A member of the , he was the nominee of the  and  parties in the , making him the first  to receive a major party's backing for the  in the state of . \n\n\nPinion was born on August 11, 1983, in . He attended  on an athletic grant, playing . He graduated in 2006 with a  in .\n\n\nPinion started his career as a youth development director at a  health center, where he worked for several years before becoming a , where he appeared on news networks such as . Later, Pinion became the host of \"Saturday Agenda\" on . He is also a  activist and has criticized  within the . He has worked with the organization RepublicEn, a right-leaning environmentalist advocacy organization, since 2017.\n\n\n\nPrior to running for office, Pinion served as the Chair of the Conservative Color Coalition and was the Outreach Director for the .\n\nIn 2018, Pinion announced his candidacy for New York's 90th assembly district, which was vacated after  won an open seat to the . He received the  and  party nominations, but lost the election to .\n\nIn 2022, on , Pinion announced that he was running for the  in a video highlighting  At the Republican convention in , he received the party designation. He unsuccessfully challenged  incumbent , the Senate Majority Leader, in the general election.\n\nPinion ultimately received 2.5 million votes statewide, winning 42.8% of the vote to Schumer's 56.8%. Despite a significant funding disparity (Pinion spent only $500,000 on campaign advertising, against Schumer's $38 million), Pinion performed better than any Republican candidate has in a New York US Senate race since  in , and lost to Schumer by a narrower margin than any Republican candidate has since Schumer beat Senator  in . Pinion's performance was part of a \"red wave\" in the , which saw an overperformance for Republicans in statewide and Congressional races.\n\n\n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Martin J. Golden''' (born September 22, 1950) is an American politician from , , one of the  of . A , Golden represented the  in the  from 1998 to 2002 and represented the  of the  from 2003 to 2018.\n\n\nGolden is the oldest of eight children born to  immigrants who settled in Bay Ridge. Golden attended St. Patrick's and Our Lady of Angels Grammar Schools, , and . He holds an  from . Golden and his wife, Colleen, have two children, Michael and P.J.\n\nGolden is a retired New York City police officer. He received 49 commendations during his seven years as an officer in the . He served from 1973 until 1976 in the 67th Precinct, whereupon he was laid off due to the . He was rehired in 1978. In 1978, Golden faced an Internal Affairs Investigation and a disciplinary proceeding for losing his service weapon, which he claimed was a result of his mother discarding the firearm along with an old train set while he was away \"on a vacation cruise\". According to Golden, he suffered a career-ending injury in 1981; while witnessing a suspected drug deal, he chased the suspect, was struck by a car, and suffered a broken arm and ligament damage to his legs. Golden has said that he retired the following year and received a three-quarters disability pension.\n\n\nFrom 1998 through 2002, Golden represented the  of the . Golden was first elected to represent Brooklyn's  in 2002. The 22nd State Senate district includes the neighborhoods of , , , , , , , and parts of ,  and .\n\nIn 2011, Golden voted against legalizing same-sex marriage in New York, stating that he considered it a \"destruction of the sacrament of marriage.\"\n\nGolden voted in favor of the gun control law known as the  in January 2013.\n\nIn 2013, Golden was a vocal opponent of traffic enforcement cameras. In 2017, he described plans to expand the number of speed cameras near public schools in New York City as \"non-starters\". While in May 2018, he stated support for legislation that would double the number of speed cameras in New York City, this concession came only after Republican members of the State Senate worked to reduce the number of speed cameras from the proposed 750 to just 290. In June 2018, Golden co-sponsored legislation to eliminate all speed cameras after six months.\n\nIn February 2015, the ''New York Post'' reported that Golden had \"proposed legislation requiring the state Health Department to inspect abortion clinics at least once every two years.\"\n\nFollowing the murder of NYPD Officer Randolph Holder in 2015, Golden proposed legislation that would prevent anyone with two or more felony convictions from entering a drug treatment program as an alternative to imprisonment. Tyrone Howard, the killer of Officer Holder, had a long history of arrests but was still allowed into a diversion program in early 2015. The bill passed the Senate in 2017.\n\nIn June 2017, approximately 150 protesters rallied outside Golden's office in support of the New York Health Act, an act to establish a single-payer healthcare system in New York.\nGolden and his staff reportedly declined the protesters' request for him to hold a healthcare townhall.\n\n\nGolden has been a vocal opponent of a proposed hotel that would sit directly across from a P.S. 104 in . Golden stated, \"We don't want to put a hotel where we so desperately need classrooms\". Since March 2018, Golden has attended three protests at the vacant lot. Golden started a petition online to help garner more support for the protest of the proposed hotel.\n\nIn September 2018, ''The New York Times'' described Golden as a \"popular figure\" in his district who has \"consistently won support from both Republicans and Democrats, who know him for his omnipresence at scholarship dinners and senior citizens' birthday parties\". He ran unopposed in four of his elections, even though Democrats hold a two-to-one voter registration advantage in the district.\n\nIn his 2018 re-election bid, Golden was defeated by Democratic challenger  by 1,100 votes.\n\n\nOn August 6, 2005, Golden struck a 74-year-old woman with his SUV when she attempted to cross the street against the light. Golden provided help to the woman, and witnesses said he \"was visibly shaken by the accident.\" Later that night, he \"went to the hospital to check on her condition.\" The NYPD determined Golden was not at fault and no charges were filed. The woman died six months later, and Golden paid her family $750,000 to settle a lawsuit.\n\nIn 2011, the '''' reported that Golden spent just under $40,000 in campaign funds at the Bay Ridge Manor, a catering hall in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn owned by Golden's brother. Golden sold the business to his brother in 2002. As of August 2011, Golden still owned the building that housed the Bay Ridge Manor and still received rent from his brother for the Manor. An investigation revealed that since Golden became Senator in 2002, he had paid $355,000 in campaign money to the Bay Ridge Manor. Golden denied nepotism, but was criticized by Michael Murphy, Susan Lerner, and other politicians. In 2014, Golden's campaign finances were the subject of an investigation by then-U.S. Attorney . In December 2017, the Albany  reported that Golden had spent more than $797,000 in campaign funds at the Bay Ridge Manor.\n\nIn 2012, Golden advertised an etiquette class for women to help them be successful in the workplace that included strategies such as \"walking up and down stairs elegantly\" and \"sitting, standing, and walking like a model\". This event, which was taxpayer-funded, was heavily criticized, and Golden eventually cancelled it.\n\nIn July 2015, Senator Golden made a controversial joke on his Facebook page regarding marijuana and same-sex marriage, stating \"It all makes sense now. Gay marriage and marijuana being legalized on the same day. Leviticus 20:13 – 'if a man lays with another man he should be stoned.' We've just been interpreting it wrong all these years,\" Golden has since deleted this comment.\n\nIn February 2017, Goldenspeaking in defense of President Donald Trump's inaccurately claimed that a number of the terrorists involved in the 9-11 attacks lived in Bay Ridge. Golden's spokesman, John Quaglione, later claimed that Golden had confused the 9-11 attacks with the 1993 attack on the World Trade Center; one of the 1993 attackers had, in fact, lived in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn.\n\nIn June 2017, while endorsing his staffer, John Quaglione, in a local City Council race, Golden was overheard referring derisively to one of Quaglione's Democratic challengers as \"Fat Boy\" in front of reporters, warning a reporter present who had taken note of the gaffe not to print it or \"[she] would never have a sit-down with [him] again.\"\n\nIn December 2017, Brian Howald, a bicyclist and member of 's transportation committee, alleged that Golden, while a passenger in a vehicle that was driving illegally in the bicycle lane, impersonated a police officer and threatened to arrest him if he did not yield to Golden's vehicle. The '''' reported that Golden's car's plate number was associated with \"more than 30 traffic violations over the last four years.\"\n\nFollowing the shooting at  in  in 2018, Golden fired a staffer named Anthony Testaverde who had shared Twitter posts comparing  to Hitler and .\n\n\n\n\n\n* Official website.\n*\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
          }

    "pages": }\n'''Shelley Mayer''' (born March 6, 1952) is an American politician serving as a  member of the  representing the , which includes portions of . Formerly a member of the , Mayer was first elected in a special election in 2018.\n\n\nBorn and raised in , Mayer went on to receive her B.A. at , and later her J.D. at the .\n\nPrior to her election to public office, Mayer was a  at the National State Attorney General Program at , where she focused on health care and labor law rights. From 2007 until early 2011, Shelley worked as Chief Counsel to the New York State Senate Conference in .\n\nFor over seven years, she served as Vice President of Government and Community Affairs at  in . From 1982 to 1994, Mayer served as an Assistant Attorney General in the office of New York Attorney General Bob Abrams. She served in the Civil Rights Bureau, as Chief of the Westchester Regional Office, as the legislative liaison for the  and ultimately as a senior advisor to the Attorney General.\n\nIn 2006, Mayer made her first run for public office, losing a bid for the  to incumbent Republican . Spano later went on to change parties, ran for Mayor of Yonkers in 2011 as a Democrat, and won.\n\nMayer was first elected to the  on March 20, 2012, in a  to succeed , and was re-elected three times.\n\nMayer lives in  with her husband, Lee Smith, with whom she has three adult children.\n\n\nMayer was elected to the  in a special election held on April 24, 2018 after the office was vacated by Westchester County Executive . Mayer appeared on the , , and  lines and won by a margin of 57% to 43%. Mayer attributed the win to a \"'big tent blue wave' that brought together progressives, Democrats, union groups and female activists.\"\n\nLater in 2018, despite the district being deemed competitive by pundits, Mayer was unopposed for a full-term.  With Democrats retaking the majority, Mayer is serving as Chair of Committee on Education.\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Farah N. Louis''' (born September 25, 1983) is an American politician. She is a member of the  and is a member of the  for the , which includes the  neighborhoods of , , , , and .\n\n\nBoth of Louis's parents immigrated from , her mother worked in the healthcare field and her father as a law enforcement professional and later a  driver.\n\nLouis attended ,  for a BA in English, and received an  from 's .\n\n\nLouis worked as a mental healthcare provider for eight years, then worked in '  office, first as director of community outreach, then as deputy chief of staff. She worked in Williams' office for six years and was still in that role when he was elected , creating the vacancy Louis would be then elected to. Williams did not endorse Louis, but another challenger for the District 45 seat who also worked in his Council office, Monique Chandler-Waterman.\n\nLouis won her Council seat in a special election on May 14, 2019, in a low-turnout election. She finished with 3,861 votes, a plurality of 41.81%, ahead of second-place Chandler-Waterman who finished with 2,790 votes cast (30.21%). She officially took office after being sworn in on June 13, 2019. As a result of New York laws, another special election was held to determine if she will serve the remainder of Williams' four-year term ending December 31, 2021. She won the June 25, 2019, Democratic primary 51.69% to Chandler-Waterman's 41.36%. On November 5, 2019, Louis won the general election gaining 93.1% to Anthony Beckford's 4.7%. On June 22, 2021, Louis won the Democratic Primary as the incumbent with 75.4% of the vote. Later in 2021 she ran unopposed in the general election on November 2 to win re-election.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n| partner            =  ( 2014)\n| children           = 3\n}}\n\n'''Curtis Sliwa''' (; born March 26, 1954) is an American activist, radio talk show host, and founder and chief executive officer of the , a nonprofit crime prevention organization. Sliwa was the  nominee for the , which he lost to  .\n\n\nCurtis Sliwa was born on March 26, 1954, into a Catholic family of Polish and Italian descent, in . He has two sisters. He attended , a  high school from which he was later expelled. He graduated from . In his youth, he worked as a delivery boy for the '''', where he was awarded the title of \"Newsboy of the Year\" and a trip to the  after he saved several people from a burning building while on a paper route.\n\nPrior to founding the , he was night manager of a  restaurant on  in .\n\n\n in , 2001]]\nIn May 1977, Sliwa created the \"Magnificent 13\", a civilian group dedicated to combating violence and crime on the . At the time, the city was experiencing a crime wave. The Magnificent 13 grew and was renamed the  in 1979. The group's actions drew strong reactions, both positive and negative. \n\nMost of the Guardian Angels members were either Black or Hispanic. Unarmed, the group required members to train in  and learn the legal requirements for  for all members before they were to be deployed. Sliwa's red  is a component of the Guardian Angels' uniform.\n\nIn 1981, then-Mayor , a critic of Sliwa and the organization, launched an investigation into the Guardian Angels, which, according to '''', proved \"so positive that the Guardian Angels will soon be awarded some sort of official status.\" Then-  was a rare early advocate of the organization, being quoted saying \"[t]hey are a better expression of morality than our city deserves\".\n\nIn 1992, Sliwa admitted that he and the Guardian Angels faked heroic subway rescues for publicity. He also admitted to having claimed falsely that three off-duty transit police officers had kidnapped him.\n\nIn the early 1980s, he expanded operations to  and was often critical of local police policies and practices. One incident involved Guardian Angels member Frank Melvin, who was fatally shot by a  police officer in December 1981 after an officer claimed they mistook his unzipping of his jacket – to display his Guardian Angels emblem – as a threat. Sliwa claimed that the killing of Melvin – an African American – was racially motivated, and had been done by a White officer who was being protected by the police department, rather than by the Hispanic officer identified as the shooter. An   cleared both officers of charges related to Melvin's death.\n\n\nOn June 19, 1992, Sliwa was kidnapped and shot by two gunmen after entering a stolen taxi in . The taxi picked up Sliwa near his home in the , and a gunman hiding in the front passenger seat jumped up and fired several shots, hitting him in the groin and legs. The kidnapping was foiled when Sliwa leaped from the front window of the moving cab and escaped. Sliwa underwent surgery for internal injuries and leg wounds.\n\n (middle) in an  surveillance photo]]\nFederal prosecutors eventually charged , the son of  leader , with attempted murder and a raft of other charges. Prosecutors claimed that Gotti was angered by remarks Sliwa had made about Gotti's father on his radio program. After three attempts to try him, on September 20, 2005, three separate juries could not agree to convict Gotti on any of the charges brought against him, and the charges were dropped. Jurors later told reporters they believed he had a role in Sliwa's shooting. Prosecutors declined to re-try Gotti and dismissed the charges against him. Sliwa said he would seek damages in .\n\nMichael Yannotti, a Gotti associate, was also charged with shooting Sliwa in the incident but was acquitted. \n\n\n\n\n with U.S. Representative  in 2005]]\nSliwa has been a radio broadcaster for three decades, most of that time on , where he began his career in 1990. In 1994, the then city-owned and operated  hired Sliwa, whom WABC had released. Some, including Sliwa, have suggested that he was given access to the station by newly elected Mayor , whom he had supported in the .\n\nSliwa has become a   host. Since 1996, he has hosted various radio programs on WABC, and in 2000, he became the co-host, with an attorney , of the long-running ''Curtis and Kuby in the Morning''. The show lasted eight years before  replaced the team with . His longtime broadcast partner was lawyer Ron Kuby, with whom he had multiple times hosted in the past \"Curtis & Kuby\" weekday radio show at noon, on  in New York City. Starting in June 2017, Sliwa's co-host was attorney and television commentator, . His most recent co-host was , who joined the show in February 2019.\n\nThe ''Curtis Sliwa LIVE'' program began national syndication on December 1, 2008. WABC retained Sliwa until November 2009, when his show was cancelled after a contract dispute. He hosted both the morning and evening \"drive time\" shows on -AM 970, but as of January 2, 2014, Sliwa returned to WABC, replacing  who moved to . After officially declaring his candidacy in March 2021, Sliwa's radio program went on hiatus.\n\n\nIn September 2016, Sliwa and Frank Morano launched a successful  of the . The Party lost its ballot access in the November 2018 elections.\n\nIn December 2019, Sliwa declared in an interview that he hated then-President of the United States , calling him a \"screwball and a crackpot\". In February 2021, weeks after Trump left office, Sliwa switched from the Reform Party to the Republican Party. \n\nSliwa changed parties and lost control over the Reform Party after losing the required votes to keep the Reform Party on the ballot. Bill C. Merrell regained control over the NYS Reform Party and is now again NYS Chair of the Reform Party. The official state Party is again affiliated with the National Reform Party.\n\n\n\nSliwa announced on March 8, 2020, that he would be  as a , seeking to become the 110th mayor of New York City.\n\nThe primary race turned Sliwa and , once friends, into bitter rivals.Emma G. Fitzsimmons, , ''New York Times'' (May 25, 2021). The Manhattan, Queens, and Bronx Republican parties endorsed Mateo while the Staten Island and Brooklyn Republican parties endorsed Sliwa. Sliwa criticized Mateo for donating to the 2017 re-election campaign of Mayor , a Democrat, and also accused Mateo of breaking the law; Mateo replied that Sliwa's accusations were bogus and shameful.\n\nDuring the campaign, Mateo and Sliwa clashed over loyalty to former president .Katie Honan, , ''Wall Street Journal'' (May 26, 2021).Dana Rubinstein, Jeffery C. Mays, Jazmine Hughes, Anne Barnard, Michael Gold and Mihir Zaveri, , ''The New York Times'' (June 7, 2021). Mateo voiced support for Trump's false claim that ; by contrast, Sliwa did not support Trump in either 2016 or 2020 and does not support Trump's . The unofficial results showed Sliwa winning by 72 to 28 percent.\n\nSliwa has run on a platform opposing the  movement, supporting a property tax overhaul so that working-class residents would not pay higher property taxes than wealthy citizens, keeping in place the  while increasing opportunities for vocational training in charter schools, and focusing on fiscal restraint. He also opposes the killing of unwanted animals and supports making all animal shelters s.\n\nSliwa campaigned on beginning a trial program, if elected, to test out the feasibility of  in New York City.\n\nSliwa lost to Brooklyn Borough President  in a landslide defeat in the general election on November 2, 2021, with Adams winning just over two-thirds of the votes. Sliwa conceded that same night, calling for unity in order to save New York City.\n\n\nIn late August 2023, Sliwa, along with four other organizers, were arrested after an anti- rally outside . Police issued a  on misdemeanor charges of resisting arrest and obstruction, but the  declined to prosecute. Sliwa had previously been arrested at several previous rallies.\n\n\n\n\nSliwa has been married four times. He wed his second wife, , in 1981. At the time, she was National Director of the Guardian Angels and co-hosted a WABC-AM radio show called ''Angels in the Morning''. She is also a  expert who briefly trained with the  in 1986.\n\nIn 2000, Sliwa married his third wife, Mary (nee Galda), a former WABC employee who also served as the Guardian Angels' national director. They have one son, Anthony, born circa 2004. In 2019, Mary became Mary Paterson, after marrying former New York State governor , who in turn is the step-father of Sliwa's son Anthony.\n\nCurtis Sliwa was diagnosed with  in 2010, which he announced publicly on April20, 2011.\n\nSliwa was in a relationship with , the , and separated from her in 2014; they have two children together, conceived  over the previous five years. In court documents, Sliwa's ex-wife, Mary, accused him of diverting money to Katz while still married to Mary, as part of a plan to build a \"nest egg\" with Katz prior to moving in with her.\n\nOn July5, 2018, Sliwa wed his longtime girlfriend, animal activist and attorney Nancy Regula, at the .\n\n\n\n\n\n*  (2020).
