    "pages": }\n\n'''John J. Bonacic''' (born June 14, 1942 in ) is a retired politician from New York. A Republican, Bonacic represented   (which includes all or parts of , , , and  Counties) from November 1998 to 2018. Prior to his Senate service, Bonacic served in the New York State Assembly.\n\n\nBonacic's grandparents were immigrants from .  Ratko Martinović: Loš PR u dijaspori - Koje su svjetski poznate osobe podrijetlom Hrvati, a da to niste ni znali, 28. listopada 2012. (Croatian) He received his  from  in 1964, majoring in . He received his  at  in 1968.\n\n\nOn February 20, 1990, Bonacic was elected to the , to fill the vacancy caused by the election of  as Orange County Executive. Bonacic was re-elected four times and remained in the Assembly until 1998, sitting in the , , ,  and s. In November 1998, he was elected to the .\n\nBonacic, a Republican, was the Chair of the Senate Racing, Gaming, and Wagering Committee. He sponsored a bill that would legalize online poker. He supported the opening of a casino in Sullivan County, New York.\n\nWhile Bonacic cast a procedural vote against a 2013 bill that would have expanded abortion rights, he expressed support for the Reproductive Health Act in 2016. At a January 25, 2016 gathering of abortion advocates in Albany, the Senator commented, \"'Both my daughter and my bride of 50 years believe in pro-choice and we should never deprive women of access of health care that they choose and their medical providers say is best for them.'\" In 2015, Bonacic introduced a bill to legalize physician-assisted suicide.\n\nIn 2011, Bonacic voted against allowing same-sex marriage in New York in a roll-call vote on the Marriage Equality Act, which passed in a close 33-29 vote.\n\nOn May 6, 2018, Bonacic announced that he would not seek re-election in November 2018.\n\n\n\n*\n*\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''John Chun Yah Liu''' (born January 8, 1967) is an American politician in . A member of the , he is a member of the  for the  in northeast . He previously served as the 43rd  from 2010 to 2013, and as a member of the  from 2002 to 2009, representing the  in northeast . He was the first  New York City Council member and Comptroller, and one of the first two Asian American New York State Senators, as well as the first elected to legislative or citywide office in New York. He was also a candidate in the .\n\nLiu currently teaches  and policy at  and  of the , and at .\n\n\nChun Liu was born in Taiwan, and moved to the United States at age five. His father, Chang Liu, was an  student and . In honor of  and the , Liu's father changed his sons' names to John, Robert, and Edward, and his own name to Joseph.\n\nLiu attended PS 20 in , and . He graduated from  in 1985, doing  and volunteer work in his spare time.\n\nDuring his years attending , he majored in  and rose to executive vice president of the university's Student Association. He worked as a manager at  and served as president of the North Flushing Civic Association before his election to the City Council.\n\n\n\n\n\nLiu was elected to the  in 2001, representing northeast Queens in the  as its first Asian American member. He also served as the Chairperson of the New York City Council's Transportation Committee, and served on the committees on Education, Consumer Affairs, Health, Land Use, Contracts, Oversight & Investigations as well as Lower Manhattan Redevelopment. Liu was known for his outspoken and confrontational demeanor.\n\n\nIn March 2009, Liu announced that he was running for the post of . Liu had raised $3 million for his political run.\n\nIn May, Liu picked up several endorsements from several different organizations: The Village Independent Democrats, The Queens County Democratic organization, the local  chapter and the , 1199 SEIU union local and the Uniformed Firefighters Association.\n\nLater, in September 2009, the  (UFT) began endorsing Liu. In the September 15 Democratic primary, Liu was the front-runner, ending up with 133,986 votes (38% of the vote), but because he did not manage to reach 40% of the vote, a run-off election was required between Liu and , who received 30 percent of the vote in the primary, but Liu later won the run-off by taking 55.6% of the vote.\n\nIn the general election on November 3, Liu won the comptroller election with a total of 696,330 votes (76% of votes). Republican candidate Joseph Mendola came in second with 19.3% of the vote.\n\nDuring his tenure as New York comptroller, Liu claimed to have saved New York City more than $3 billion by cracking down on wasteful expenditures and cutting inefficiencies. He spearheaded Checkbook 2.0, the initiative to upgrade the city's current online transparency system. ; accessed November 4, 2014.\n\nLiu is a leader of the Asian Political Leadership Fund, a federally designated 527 fund whose purpose is to promote political leadership from within the Asian American community.\n\n\nLiu ran as a candidate for  in the , losing in fourth place in the Democratic Party's .\n\n\nHis platform in the primary included:\n# Improving air quality and clean water by improving the city's transit system, pressuring the  to modernize their transit systems in order to reduce  and improve energy efficiency. \n# Greatly improve energy efficiency by supporting large-scale energy alternatives such as solar and wind energy as opposed to the usage of fossil fuels which would quickly deplete the Earth's natural resources as well as release about 10 billion tonnes of greenhouse gases every year.\n# Create opportunities to source food locally, which would improve New York's economy and further distribute capital throughout the City in an environmentally sound way. , comptroller.nyc.gov; accessed November 4, 2014. \n# Expanding safe streets for Senior Citizens by creating shorter crosswalks, implementing more countdown timers, and creating larger signs to reduce the risk of injury from careless drivers, inattentiveness, etc. \n# Support revitalizing , abandoned areas which were previously used as industrial centers for factories and mass production. \n# Advocating to increase minimum wage from $7.25/hour to $11.50/hour to increase the standard of living in New York City.\n# Legalizing, regulating and taxing the production and sale of recreational and medicinal  to adults of age 21 and older, and directing the tax revenues and savings to university education.\n\n\nInvestigations into Liu's election fundraising revealed that two of his former associates used s to contribute to his Comptroller campaign, a discovery that rattled his 2013 campaign.\n\nOn August 5, 2013, the  denied Liu  worth $3.53 million for his campaign. His supporters disagreed with the decision, saying they had legitimately donated funds to Liu's campaign, and were being denied their rights.\n\n\nOn November 17, 2011, Oliver Pan was arrested on charges of  from illegal donations. Pan was approached by an undercover  agent posing as someone who wanted to donate $16,000 to Liu, well over the city donation limit of $4,950 for individual contributions, and agreed to arranged for 20 fictitious donors.\n\nIn February 2012, campaign treasurer Jia \"Jenny\" Hou was arrested for using straw donors to circumvent campaign finance laws and gain more matching funds from taxpayers. In October 2013, she was sentenced to ten months in prison after her conviction for attempted ,  and making false statements. Pan's sentence was later reduced to four months in jail.\n\nLiu was never accused of any wrongdoing in connection with his staffers. On the eve of their 2013 trial, he expressed frustration with the  's office for what observers have described as an \"extraordinarily intrusive and exhaustive investigation,\" and was critical of the lengthy three-year long process and the interrogation of thousands of his supporters.\n\n\n\nIn September 2014, Liu ran in the Democratic primary race for   (which includes some of the same neighborhoods as City Council District 20), losing to incumbent  47-52%. Liu and Avella had previously served together in the City Council, representing neighboring districts, and the two had a strained relationship.\n\nLiu criticized Avella for joining the , a group of senate Democrats that allied themselves with the Senate Republican Conference, creating a coalition that controlled the Senate. At the time, Democrats held a numerical majority in the Senate, but the IDC-Republican coalition prevented Democrats from holding power, while allowing Avella and other IDC members to gain committee chairpersonships. Avella criticized Liu over the latter's campaign finance scandal, his failure to pay fines from his earlier campaign for Comptroller, and his record as Comptroller.\n\nLiu was initially supported by the , by the Queens County Democratic Party and by several unions, but these organizations largely dropped their support of Liu when , leader of the IDC, announced that its members would rejoin the mainline Democratic Conference after the 2014 elections. However, after Republicans gained an outright majority in the State Senate in the 2014 elections, the IDC continued to caucus with the Republicans.\n\nIn 2014, Liu rejoined  School of International and Public Affairs, where he has taught . He also began a teaching position at .\n\n\nLiu initially stated he had no plans to run for office after his 2014 loss to Avella and declined offers to do so, but was inspired after  upset victory over incumbent Congressman  in the . He was then convinced to run for state senate by activists looking to defeat former IDC members. Liu was initially doubtful that the grassroots campaigners that approached him could gather enough signatures to place him on the ballot so close to the July filing deadline, but he received more than three times the number of signatures needed. , which Crowley represented, partially overlaps with State Senate District 11.\n\nUnlike in 2014, the Queens County Democratic Party, which Crowley chaired at the time, endorsed Avella instead of Liu. In the , Liu once again challenged Avella. In a reversal of their 2014 race, Liu defeated Avella 53-47%, attributed to backlash against the former members of the Independent Democratic Conference, which had dissolved earlier in 2018.\n\nIn the November 2018 general election, Liu won a four-way race with 54% of the vote, defeating   with 24% of the vote, Avella, running on two third-party lines with 21% of the vote, and third-party candidate Simon Minching with 1% of the vote, becoming one of the two first Asian Americans in the New York Senate.\n\n\nLiu won reelection in 2022. In 2023, Liu's Senate district  from the  to the 16th.\n\n\n* \n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''John \"Jack\" McEneny''' (born August 30, 1943 in , New York) is an American politician of the . He was a member of the , representing about half of  in the 104th Assembly District, from 1993 through 2012.. Retrieved March 19, 2008.. Retrieved March 19, 2008.\n\n\nMcEneny went to the , graduating with fellow future assemblyman .  He graduated from  with a bachelor's degree in history, and attended  and the 's .  He served in the  in Colombia, South America, and worked as a er and for the  program in Albany. Long-time Mayor  appointed him to lead the  office of   from 1971 to 1984.  He directed the 1980  for the .  McEneny was married for many years to his wife, Barbara Leonard, and is ed; they have four children, John, Rachel, Daniel and Maeve and a granddaughter, Madeline Maeve, and a grandson, Owen Keats.\n\nMcEneny's daughter Rachel married John Spencer, Jr., the son of Republican politician , the former mayor of .  Rachel was the Communications Director for Congresswoman  from 2006 through her appointment to the United States Senate in January 2009, she then served as Senior Advisor for US Senator Gillibrand in Washington, DC. She now serves as the Commissioner of Administrative Services for the City of Albany.\n\nMcEneny's son John is an established playwright and Artistic Director of Piper Theatre Productions, a Summer Stock Theatre Company based in Brooklyn, NY.  It was co-founded with his sister Rachel.\n\n\nMcEneny has a degree in history, worked for over a decade as Albany County Historian, and remains involved in issues of archiving historical documents.  He is the author or co-author of several non-fiction books, including ''Albany: Capital City on the Hudson''.\n\n\nMcEneny served as the first director of the  \"Urban Cultural Parks\" program from 1985 to 1989.  He was the Deputy County Executive to Albany County Executive  from 1989 to 1991.\n\nIn his first election in 1991, McEneny won a write-in campaign for .\n\nAfter serving as  for state assemblyman  for two years, Conners retired and McEneny ran for the position himself in 1992.  He won a four-way primary for that seat in September 1992, and the general election that November.  He was re-elected in 1994 and 1996.\n\nIn the 1997 primary, McEneny unsuccessfully challenged incumbent Mayor  for the Democratic nomination for Mayor of the City of Albany.\n\nThe following year, Jennings supported the race of Albany County Legislator Gary Domalewicz in a  against McEneny.  In September 1998, McEneny won with 75% of the primary vote.  He has easily won re-election since, in 1998, 2000, 2002, 2004, and 2006.\n\nIn 2006, McEneny beat Jennings, this time in an election for New York State Democratic Committee. He was re-elected for a ninth term in November 2008, and a tenth in 2010, soundly defeating a \"Tea Party\" challenger.\n\nMcEneny has been criticized for collecting a pension in addition to his pay for being an Assembly member, but he defended it as legal and fair, based on his age of 66.\n\nMcEneny declined to run for an 11th term and retired at the end of 2012. He was succeeded by Pat Fahy, a fellow Democrat.\n\n\n* \n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Robin Schimminger''' (born September 17, 1947) is an American politician from the state of New York. A Democrat, Schimminger represented District 140 in the  from 1977 to 2020.\n\n\nSchimminger was born in  and resides in . He is a graduate of  and the .\n\n\nFirst elected to the Assembly in 1976, Schimminger previously served as a member of the  Legislature for two terms. During his tenure in the Erie County Legislature, he chaired the Public Health Committee.\n\nSchimminger was elected to the Assembly 22 times. As of 2019, Schimminger's district (Assembly District 140) included parts of North Buffalo, the Town of Tonawanda, the City of Tonawanda, and part of North Tonawanda.\n\nIn 1985, after having served for four years as chairman of the Assembly Subcommittee on Small Business, he was named as chairman of the newly created Assembly Standing Committee on Small Business. He has also served on the Ways and Means, Codes and Health Committees.\n\nSchimminger was a longtime chair of the Assembly Economic Development Committee, and was a frequent critic of the economic development policies of New York Governor .\n\nSome signature pieces of legislation authored or sponsored by Schimminger include the , Omnibus Procurement Act and the Linked Deposit Program.\n\nA Democrat, Schimminger is known for working across party lines. In 2019, the '''' reported that \"for about a quarter century, Schimminger ran with Conservative Party backing along a 'moderate Democrat' path. The last Western New York Democratic legislator to run on the Conservative line, he remains one of the few Assembly Democrats who opposes abortion and same-sex marriage\".\n\nSchimminger announced on November 19, 2019 that he would not seek re-election in 2020. At the time of his announcement, he was the dean of the Western New York delegation in the Assembly.\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Mario Matthew Cuomo''' ( , ; June 15, 1932&nbsp;– January 1, 2015) was an American lawyer and politician who served as the 52nd  for three terms, from 1983 to 1994. A member of the , Cuomo previously served as the  from 1979 to 1982 and the  from 1975 to 1978. He was the father of former New York governor  and   .\n\nCuomo was known for his  views and public speeches, particularly  at the  in which he sharply criticized the policies of the  administration, saying, \"Mr. President, you ought to know that this nation is more a '''' than it is just a shining '.'\" He was widely considered a potential front-runner for the Democratic nomination for president in both  and , though he declined to seek the nomination in both instances. His legacy as a reluctant standard-bearer for the Democrats in presidential elections led to his being dubbed \" on the \".\n\nCuomo was  for a fourth term as governor by  in the  of 1994. He subsequently retired from politics and joined the  law firm of .\n\n\nCuomo was born in the  section of the New York City borough of  to a family of  origin. His grandfather Donato came to the US in 1896. Mario Cuomo's father, Andrea Cuomo, was born in New York City in 1901 but in 1904, aged two or three, was taken back to a mountain village outside , , returning to the USA on his US passport more than two decades later. Andrea Cuomo was from , Campania, and his motherImmacolata Giordanowas from . The family ran Kessler's Grocery Store in .  Cuomo attended  and .\n\nCuomo was a baseball player and while attending  in 1952, he signed as an  with the  for a $2,000 , which he used to help purchase his wife 's engagement ring. Cuomo played for the  of the   where his teammates included future major leaguer ;  Cuomo attained a .244  and played center field until he was struck in the back of the head by a pitch. Batting helmets were not yet required equipment, and Cuomo's injury was severe enough that he was hospitalized for six days.\n\nAfter his recovery, Cuomo gave up baseball and returned to St. John's University, earning his bachelor's degree ''summa cum laude'' in 1953.''University convocation and inauguration of William R. Greiner: Thirteenth president of the University at Buffalo'', Buffalo, NY: University at Buffalo Inaugural Program, September 18, 1992. Deciding on a legal career, Cuomo attended  and graduated tied for first in his class in 1956. Cuomo clerked for Judge  of the . Despite having been a top student, the ethnic prejudice of the time led to his rejection by more than 50 law firms before he was hired by a small but established office in .\n\nDuring his tenure at the law firm of Comer, Weisbrod, Froeb and Charles, Cuomo represented . Cuomo eventually became a partner at the firm, but stepped down in 1974 to become New York Secretary of State. In 1989, he settled a longstanding lawsuit against his former firm regarding $4 million in legal fees. In addition to practicing law, Cuomo worked as an adjunct professor at .\n\n\n presenting Mario Cuomo and other New York leaders with a check for Westway Project Funds, September 1981]]\nCuomo first became widely known in New York City in the late 1960s when he represented \"The Corona Fighting 69\", a group of 69 home-owners from the Queens neighborhood of , who were threatened with displacement by the city's plan to build a new high school. He later represented another Queens residents group, the – Committee on Urban Scale, who opposed 's housing proposal adjacent to Willow Lake in Queens. In 1972, Cuomo became known beyond New York City when Mayor  appointed him to conduct an inquiry and mediate a dispute over low-income public housing slated for the upper-middle-class neighborhood of Forest Hills. Cuomo described his experience in that dispute in the book ''Forest Hills Diary'', and the story was retold by sociologist  in ''The Fall of Public Man''.\n\n\nIn 1974, he ran for  on a ticket headed by gubernatorial candidate , and both won the nomination of the Democratic State Committee at the party convention. But their entire ticket, including the nominees for  and  was defeated in the Democratic : Samuels by Rep.  of Brooklyn, and Cuomo by State Senator .\n\nGovernor-elect Carey chose to bring Cuomo into his new administration, naming him in December as his choice for . Cuomo was followed as Secretary of State by .\n\n\n\nTwo years later, Cuomo ran for  at Carey's urging. Incumbent Mayor  was very unpopular and Cuomo was one of five major challengers to Beame in the Democratic primary. In a close and highly fractured election, U.S. Representative  finished first with 19.81% of the vote and Cuomo came second with 18.74%. As no candidate cleared 40% of the vote, Koch and Cuomo advanced to a runoff. Koch emerged victorious with 54.94% of the vote to Cuomo's 45.06%. Cuomo had received the nomination of the  several months previously and was urged to drop out of the race but he contested the general election against Koch and token Republican opposition. New Republic, Washington, DC, 8 April 1985\n\nDuring the mayoral campaign, placards appeared saying: \"Vote for Cuomo, not the homo\" in reference to rumors about Koch's sexuality. Cuomo denied responsibility for this but Koch never forgave him \"as he made clear with a pointedly disparaging reference to Mr. Cuomo in a recorded interview with '''' that was not to be made public until Mr. Koch's death\". Cuomo ran on his opposition to the death penalty, which backfired among New Yorkers as crime was very high. Cuomo then went negative with ads that likened Koch to unpopular former mayor . Meanwhile, Koch backers accused Cuomo of  and pelted Cuomo campaign cars with eggs.Ladies and gentlemen, the Bronx is burning: 1977, baseball, politics, and the battle for the soul of a city, New York: Picador/Macmillan Publishers, 2006, Mahler, J. Cuomo was also defeated by Koch in the general election, taking 40.97% to Koch's 49.99%. The race is discussed in Jonathan Mahler's book ''''.\n\n\nIn 1978, incumbent Lieutenant Governor Krupsak declined to seek re-election. She withdrew from the ticket and unsuccessfully challenged Carey in the gubernatorial primary, accusing him of incompetence. Cuomo won the primary for lieutenant governor and was elected alongside Carey in .\n\n\n\n\n]]\n\nIn , Carey declined to run for re-election and Cuomo declared his candidacy. He once again faced Ed Koch in the Democratic primary. This time, Koch's support for the death penalty backfired and he alienated many voters from outside New York City when, in an interview with '''' magazine, he described the lifestyle of both suburbia and upstate New York as \"sterile\" and lamented the thought of having to live in \"the small town\" of  as governor, saying it was \"a city without a good Chinese restaurant\". Cuomo won the primary by ten points and faced Republican nominee businessman  in the general election. With  aiding Democratic candidates, Cuomo beat Lehrman 50.91% to 47.48%.\n\nCuomo actively campaigned for  in the , and was named on Mondale's list of .  was ultimately nominated as his running mate, but Cuomo was chosen to give the keynote speech at the  in San Francisco. He vigorously attacked 's record and policies in his  that brought him to national attention, most memorably saying: \"There is despair, Mr. President, in the faces that you don't see, in the places that you don't visit, in your shining city.\" He was immediately considered one of the frontrunners for the Democratic nomination for president in  and .\n\nCuomo was re-elected in  against Republican nominee  by 64.3% to 31.77%. He ruled out the possibility of running in the 1988 presidential election, announcing on February 19, 1987, that he would not run, and then going on to publicly decline  in the wake of 's withdrawal following the .\n\nIn the , Cuomo was re-elected with 53.17% of the vote to Republican 's 21.35% and Conservative 's 20.40%.\n\nWhen Cuomo was asked if he was planning to run for president in 1992, he said, \"I have no plans and no plans to make plans,\" but he refused to rule it out. In October 1991, news broke that he was interested in running and was taking advice from consultant . At the same time, he began working on a budget with the , and promised not to make any announcements about a presidential run until he had reached an agreement with the Republican-controlled  and the Democratic-controlled . Two polls taken in November of the  showed him leading the field by at least twenty points, and a poll in December showed him trailing President  48% to 43%, having been behind by twenty-eight points two months earlier.\n\nThe filing deadline for the New Hampshire primary was on December 20, 1991, and candidates were required to submit a ballot application in person. Cuomo was not able to negotiate a budget agreement with Republicans in the Legislature and on deadline day, time ran out. In a scene later fictionalized in 's '''','' |last=Fassin |first=Éric |author-link=Éric Fassin |date=1996 |journal= |volume=226 |issue=11 |pages=176–177 |issn=0014-0759 |jstor=24277975 |language=fr }} he kept an airplane idling on the tarmac as he pondered abandoning the budget talks in order to fly to New Hampshire and enter the race. Cuomo dashed the hopes of Democratic activists, salivating since his 1984 convention speech over the prospect of a presidential run by him, when he kept a New Hampshire-bound plane waiting on the tarmac&nbsp;.&nbsp;.&nbsp;. }} Democratic party leaders asked him to run and he prepared two statements, one in case he ran and one in case he did not. He tried to come to a final agreement over the budget, but as he could not, he made an announcement at 3:30&nbsp;p.m. that day:\n\n\n\nCuomo's supporters launched a draft movement and encouraged people to write in his name in the Democratic primary, which was held on February 18, 1992. Cuomo did not discourage it, which many saw as implicit endorsement of the campaign. Cuomo went on to receive 6,577 votes in the primary, 3.92% of the total cast and subsequently asked the draft committee to close down, saying, \"I am flattered by their support and impressed by their commitment, but I am also convinced that in fairness to themselves they ought now to end their effort.\" The group closed down, but Cuomo refused to rule out joining the primaries later in the year, stating, \"I have said more than once that the nomination should go to someone willing and able to campaign for it. I am willing, but because New York's budget has not been settled I am not able to campaign for it.\" Ultimately, Cuomo did not enter the race and  went on to win the Democratic nomination and the general election. Because of Cuomo's refusal to run for national office, despite his popularity, he was referred to as the \"Hamlet on the Hudson\".\n\nAfter Bill Clinton won the Democratic nomination for president in 1992, Cuomo was a candidate for vice president but he refused to be considered and did not make Clinton's final shortlist. He was also spoken of as a candidate for nomination to the , but when President Clinton was considering nominees during his first term to replace the retiring , Cuomo stated he was not interested in the office.  wrote in 1999 that Clinton came within 15 minutes of nominating Cuomo before the latter pre-emptively rejected the post.\n\nIn , Cuomo ran for a fourth term. In this election, Republicans attacked him for the weak economic recovery within the state since the early 1990s recession and the resulting high unemployment as well as his opposition to the death penalty by highlighting the case of , a multiple murderer convicted of manslaughter who was paroled by the state in 1987 and while on release became a serial killer. Republicans were able to associate Shawcross with Cuomo much like  with  six years earlier. Cuomo was defeated by  in the , taking 45.4% of the vote to Pataki's 48.8%. Cuomo lost mainly because his support outside of New York City all but vanished; he only carried one county outside the Five Boroughs, , while also failing to sweep the Five Boroughs unlike his previous three successful runs, losing .\n\nCuomo and fellow Democrat , the  who had been defeated in her re-election campaign by , appeared in a series of humorous  television advertisements for the snack food  shortly afterwards, in which they discussed the \"sweeping changes\" occurring. The changes they were discussing turned out to be the new Doritos packaging.\n\n\n\n of  in July 1986. From left to right:  owner , Governor Mario Cuomo and Buffalo Mayor .]]\n\nIn Cuomo's first term as Governor of New York State, he produced a balanced budget and earned the highest credit rating over the long term for the State in one decade. His philosophy in leading the State was one of \"progressive pragmatism\". Cuomo and the Democratic-controlled House of Representatives (Democrats had over a 3:2 margin in House) was successful in stopping U.S. President Ronald Reagan's administration from eliminating \"federal income tax deductibility of state, local and property taxes\".\n\nDuring his second term as governor, Cuomo successfully pushed for the enactment of sweeping fiscal reforms for the State. Comprehensive reform measures were also enacted in governmental ethics for New York State under Cuomo's leadership. Cuomo extended New York State's economic reach in business globally, contributing to both strengthening and developing it., Willkie Farr & Gallagher LLP (January 2, 2015).\n\nCuomo is also known for beginning the \"Decade of the Child\" initiative, an effort that included multiple health care and educational strategies to better the lives of children in New York State.  Further, in 1988, the \"Rebuild NY\" Transportation Bond Act was an initiative under Cuomo that was a continuance of efforts to rebuild bridges and roads throughout the State.  Cuomo increased assistance to local law enforcement agencies in order to help reduce or eliminate crime; and prison expansion in the State was continued which he is said to have regretted.  Under Cuomo, New York State was also the first in the nation to enact .\n\nCuomo established the  (OIG) in 1983, as an independent watchdog for the . The OIG provides oversight and monitors the activities of the MTA.\n\nGovernor Mario and his wife Matilda Cuomo presided over the First New York State Family Support Conference in 1988. His statewide initiatives in developing over 1,000  programs are today termed \"individual and family support\" nationwide and are cited by the National Council on Disability. He was the first governor to support an ecological approach to families which was represented by  and community development as the goal of deinstitutionalization.\n\nHealthcare was also an area that Cuomo improved as governor, implementing initiatives that succeeded in reducing costs of prescription medications.  This endeavor assisted senior citizens in making the medications more affordable.  Under Cuomo's leadership, a public health plan that tackled the AIDS epidemic was the most intense in the nation.\n\nOverseeing programs for environmental preservation and conservation, Cuomo implemented aggressive initiatives in these areas.  Under Cuomo's leadership, New York State was the first in the United States to integrate both environmental protection and energy conservation goals.\n\nCuomo's progressivism was also evident in his appointments of judges to the . Cuomo appointed all of the judges to the State Appeals Court, including the first two female judges, as well as both the first African-American and Hispanic judges.\n\nCuomo eliminated the New York State Regents Scholarship given to all students who ranked high on a statewide special examination.\n\n\n\nMaurizio Avola, a former  believed to have killed about 80 people, including journalists, lawyers, politicians and mobsters, before becoming a '''', or informer, and serving life in prison, told '''' in 2016 that the Sicilian Mafia had planned to assassinate Governor Cuomo on a visit to Italy in November 1992. The plan was for about a dozen gunmen armed with  and explosives to ambush Cuomo. Avola's , Aldo Ercolano, considered that Cuomo would be an \"excellent target\". Avola stated, \"The aim was to target politicians or members of institutions in order to send out a clear message... Killing a prominent American was a warning to law enforcement agencies that had allowed several prominent mafia informants to live in the US under assumed identities.\" This was several months after the mafia had already assassinated  judges  and . The attack was to be carried out in the main square of , Sicily during the day. However, after Cuomo arrived in  on November 19 with security consisting of many bodyguards and a bulletproof car, the attack was called off.\n\nCuomo's son Chris later denied the occurrence of said assassination attempt while guest starring on an episode of ''''.\n\n\nCuomo was notable for his  political views, particularly his steadfast opposition to the death penalty, an opinion that was unpopular in New York during the high-crime era of the 1980s and early 1990s. While governor, he vetoed several bills that would have re-established capital punishment in New York State. The death penalty was reinstated by Pataki the year after he defeated Cuomo in the 1994 election, although it was never put into effect and the statute was declared unconstitutional by the  in 2004.\n\nCuomo, a , was personally opposed to abortion, but he was  on the issue, believing that the State does not have the right to ban the procedure. In a speech at the  on September 13, 1984, he used the statements of the American Catholic hierarchy to make an argument: \"What is ideally desirable isn't always feasible,&nbsp;... there can be different political approaches to abortion besides unyielding adherence to an absolute prohibition.\" For this position, Cardinal  considered .\n\nCuomo was also outspoken on what he perceived to be the unfair stereotyping of Italian Americans as s by the media, including denying the existence of the , and urging the media to stop using the word \"mafia\". , an  agent widely known for his  as , wrote disparagingly of Cuomo in his book, ''Unfinished Business''.\n\nCuomo opposed the move of the 's  and  to the  in , New Jersey, choosing instead to attend the home games of the  while serving as governor, referring to the Bills as \"New York State's only team\".\n\n\n\n\n\nFrom 1995 until his death, Cuomo worked as counsel at the New York law firm, . In 1996, Cuomo joined the board of Medallion Financial Corp., a lender to purchasers of taxi medallions in leading cities across the U.S. He was named to the board through his personal and business relationship with , president of Medallion. Cuomo also sat on the advisory council of the .\n\n\n\nCuomo's first book, ''Forest Hills Diary: The Crisis of Low-income Housing'', became an influential text in the fields of political science and housing policy, and it helped make his name with the public outside New York.\n\nIn 1996, Cuomo wrote ''''. He also wrote a narrative essay titled \"Achieving the American Dream\" about his parents' struggles in coming to America and how they prospered. Cuomo was the author of '''', published in 2004, and he co-edited ''Lincoln on Democracy'', an anthology of 's speeches.\n\nCuomo also wrote and delivered numerous speeches and remarks.\n\n\n* Cuomo, M. Also in 1983,  awarded him an honorary Doctor of Laws degree.\n\nIn 2017, Governor Andrew Cuomo signed legislation officially naming the  the \"Governor Mario M. Cuomo Bridge\". This has been met with significant opposition. A petition and several pieces of proposed legislation have sought to restore the bridge's name to that of its .\n\n\nCuomo was married for 60 years to , from 1954 until his death in 2015. She is a graduate of St. John's University's Teachers College. They had five children, , , Maria, Madeline, and . In 2017, Matilda was inducted into the .\n\nCuomo's older son Andrew married , a daughter of  and , on June 9, 1990. They had three daughters, twins Cara Ethel and Mariah Matilda Cuomo, born on January 11, 1995; and Michaela Andrea Cuomo, born on August 26, 1997. The couple divorced in 2005. Andrew served as  under President  from 1997 to 2001. In his first attempt to succeed his father, he ran as , but withdrew before the . He withdrew after criticizing Republican incumbent 's leadership following the terrorist attacks on the city on  the previous year. In November 2006, Andrew was elected ; and on November 2, 2010, he was elected Governor of New York, inaugurated on January 1, 2011, and was re-elected two more times, serving until he resigned in August 2021 due to .\n\nCuomo's younger son Chris was a journalist on the   ''''. He anchored news segments and served as co-host on '''', before moving to CNN in 2013, where he co-hosted the morning news magazine ''''. He anchored his own prime time show '''' until he was suspended and ultimately fired in 2021 for assisting his brother Andrew in navigating a sexual harassment scandal which had previously led to Andrew's resignation as Governor of New York and after two accusations of sexual harassment against Chris were made. He was picked as one of '''' magazine's 50 Most Beautiful People in 1997.\n\nCuomo's daughter Maria is married to , the New York fashion designer. She is Chair of the Board of HELP USA, a charitable foundation that is also associated with the organization her mother founded, Mentoring USA.\n\nHis daughter Margaret is \"a board certified radiologist, teaching professional, and national advocate for the prevention of cancer, heart disease, and diabetes\"., ''LessCancer'', 2014, Retrieved January 29, 2014. She is the author of ''A World Without Cancer: The Making of a New World and the Real Promise of Prevention'' (2013), and she serves on the board of directors of the nonprofit organization, LessCancer.  She has been featured on such TV shows as '''', '''', '''', and ''''. In 2011, she was awarded the Commendation of the Order of the Star by the president and prime minister of Italy.\n\nCuomo remained a baseball fan after his athletic career ended, reportedly limiting his television watching to baseball games and . He was an avid player of , always with an Italian-American player on his team, regardless of how many Italian-American players were available or how well they were doing. In 1994, he was featured several times on the   series '''', where he shared memories of his life in baseball before he entered politics.\n\nCuomo was the first guest on the long-running  talk show '''' that began in 1985 and ended in 2010.\n\n described the man as both the most intelligent and wittiest politician he has ever interviewed.\n\n\nOn November 30, 2014, it was announced that Cuomo had been hospitalized for a heart condition; he was described as being \"in good spirits\".\n\nOn January 1, 2015, Andrew Cuomo was sworn in for his second term as governor. The elder Cuomo was not well enough to attend the inaugural ceremony, though his son remarked, \"He is in the heart and mind of every person who is here. He is here and his inspiration and his legacy and his experience is what has brought the state to this point.\" That afternoon Mario Cuomo died from heart failure at his home in Manhattan at 5:15&nbsp;p.m. EST, at the age of 82.\n\nCuomo's wake was held on January 5, 2015, and his funeral was held at  in Manhattan on January 6.  He is interred at , in .\n\n\nFile:Gov. Mario Cuomo Hearse at QMT (16221388421).jpg|Officers of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority and a state police honor guard saluting Cuomo's hearse as it passes through the Queens Midtown Tunnel, January 6, 2015\nFile:Governor Mario Cuomo Niche.jpg|The niche of Governor Mario Cuomo\n\n\n\nVarious elected officials praised Cuomo following his death. President  stated: \"An Italian Catholic kid from Queens, born to immigrant parents, Mario paired his faith in God and faith in America to live a life of public service – and we are all better for it.  He rose to be chief executive of the state he loved, a determined champion of progressive values, and an unflinching voice for tolerance, inclusiveness, fairness, dignity, and opportunity.  His own story taught him that as Americans, we are bound together as one people, and our country's success rests on the success of all of us, not just a fortunate few.\"\n\nPresident  described Cuomo as \"a forceful voice for civil rights, for equal rights, for economic opportunity and justice. He had the courage to stand by his convictions, even when it was unpopular.\" Former Governor of New York  called Cuomo \"a proud son of immigrants and a compassionate leader who possessed a soaring intellect\". Former Mayor of New York City  stated: \"Mario was a giant political influence of his generation. His ability to make riveting political speeches was only exceeded by his ability to logically argue and defend his position.\"\n\n\n\n\nCuomo and  are remembered as two New York politicians who dominated during the late 1970s and 1980s, as well for his public speaking ability.\n\nThe rebuilt Tappan Zee Bridge was renamed the  in his honor. However, this would be controversial as the old bridge was named after .\n\nHis legacy also ran in his family, with the election of his son  in 2010. Andrew Cuomo would serve as governor for ten years, from 2011 until his resignation in 2021.\n\n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n*  (2020). ''''.     "pages": }\n'''Chantel S. Jackson''' (born October 1, 1983) an American politician and social worker serving as a member of the  from the 79th district. Elected in November 2020, Jackson assumed office on January 1, 2021.\n\n\nJackson is a native of , the daughter of an American father and an immigrant mother from . Jackson earned a Bachelor of Arts degree in psychology from the  and a  from .\n\n\nAfter receiving her Master's degree, Jackson worked as a professor at the  from 2014 to 2019. Since March 2016, she has been a social worker at the Academy for Careers in Television & Film, a technical school in .\n\nIn 2020, after incumbent Assemblymember  announced his candidacy for , Jackson declared her candidacy for the 79th district of the . Jackson received Blake's endorsement and defeated the Bronx Democratic Party-endorsed candidate, Cynthia Cox, and four other candidates with 26% of the vote in the  primary. She won the November general election in the heavily Democratic district.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

Cook''' (born May 23, 1937) is an American politician currently representing District 32 in the , which comprises  neighborhoods of , , and .\n\nA native of , Cook has served as a District Leader in  for over 25 years. As of January 2019, Cook is the County Committee Chair of the Queens County  Committee.\n\nCook was first elected to the State Assembly in 1990. She was appointed Chairwoman of the Task Force on Food and the Farm and Nutrition Policy in 2000. As of June 2019, Cook serves as Chair of the Assembly Committee on Standing Committees. Cook ran uncontested in the 2008 and 2010 s.\n\nIn 2010, the New York Daily News reported that Cook was among the  that refused to disclose her outside income.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n*\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Andrew Cohen''' (born August 9, 1969) is a Justice of the Bronx branch of the . He is a . He was previously the councilmember for the  of the , resigning in 2020, with  winning the special election to succeed him. The district includes , , , , , , and  in . \n\n\nCohen was born on August 9, 1969, in .Jon Lentz, , '''' (January 28, 2014). He earned a B.A. in sociology from  and a J.D. from the , and is an attorney.\n\nPrior to joining the New York City Council, Cohen served as a member of  and legal advisor to Assemblyman . He was also an adjunct professor at the   and a court attorney to a justice of the Bronx .\n\n\nCouncilman  was term-limited in 2013 and unable to run for another term, and as a result, Cohen entered the race to succeed him.  After winning the primary, he was elected to a full term in November 2013. Cohen ran for Supreme Court Justice in the Bronx in November 2020, and resigned from the New York City Council, ending his term on December 31, 2020.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Stephanie Ann Miner''' (born April 30, 1970) is an American , , and former  of . Miner served as Mayor of Syracuse from 2010 to 2018, and is the first woman to have held that office. Prior to her mayoralty, she was a member of the Syracuse City Council. Miner co-chaired the New York State Democratic Party from 2012 to 2014. In 2018, Miner ran unsuccessfully for  on the newly created  line.\n\n\nOn April 30, 1970, Miner was born in  to Edward Miner, MD, a physician and an army officer, and Dianne Cooney, a nurse who later served as dean of the Wegmans School of Nursing at . Miner became involved in politics at an early age by stuffing envelopes for local candidates at her grandmother's kitchen table in the Eastwood neighborhood.\n\nMiner attended high school in , where she was senior class president and voted most likely to succeed. She received her , '''', in journalism and political science from  in 1992, and her  from the  in 1999.\n\nIn 1994, she served as a regional representative for then-governor of New York . Upon graduating from law school, Miner was hired at the Syracuse law firm Blitman and King LLP, where she worked until resigning in March 2009 to focus on her mayoral campaign.\n\n\nIn her first run for public office in 2001, Miner ran for one of two at-large Syracuse Common Council seats that were up for election. She won, placing first among four candidates. Her tough leadership on important city issues propelled her to re-election in 2005 when she again placed first among four candidates for the two seats. Miner received the most votes of any candidate on the ballot, including the incumbent mayor.\n\nAs a Common Councilor, Miner championed and helped pass legislation that gave $1 million in initial funding to , a program that provides necessary support services for Syracuse City School Districts students and promises free or reduced college tuition to students who graduate from City high schools.\n\n\nIn 2009, Minerrunning as a Democratdefeated  Steve Kimatian, 50%–39%, in the  and became the city's first female mayor. Miner was re-elected in 2013, winning 68% of the vote in defeating two third-party candidates.\n\nMiner was the 53rd Mayor of the City of Syracuse. She is the first woman elected Mayor of Syracuse and the first woman to lead one of New York's \"Big 5\" cities. Her second term concluded on January 1, 2018, and she did not seek re-election.\n\n\nMiner vetoed $2 million in amendments passed by the council to her $657 million budget. Miner stated that the council's sales tax estimates were \"phantom revenues\" which, if they materialized, should be saved.\n\nIn 2014, Miner announced that since she took office in 2010, the city had reversed the general funds deficit trend and achieved an $8.4 million budget surplus in the fiscal year ending in 2012.\n\nIn 2013, Miner was named one of the \"trailblazing women in public finance\" by Northeast Women in Public Finance and The Bond Buyer in recognition of her role in drawing attention to the fiscal plight of cities.\n\n\nIn 2012, Miner announced that  did not plan to build a promised future  expansion, including a hotel and more retail space. However, Miner added that Congel would not have to pay property taxes or PILOT payments on the Carousel Center expansion or the original mall for 30 years under the terms of a 2007 agreement forged by former mayor Matt Driscoll.\n\nIn 2014, Miner and County Executive  received a letter from Destiny signaling their intent to build a 252-room hotel. Destiny indicated it would be seeking new tax breaks from the Onondaga County Industrial Development Agency (OCIDA). Destiny officials were seeking an 18-year payment in lieu of taxes deal exempting the developer from County and City taxes on the new hotel. The new exemption would cost taxpayers approximately $20 million in tax revenue. Miner believed that any hotel construction to support the mall should be privately financed. Destiny received a 30-year break on local taxes after it promised to build a LEED Platinum, 39-story, 1,342- room \"Emerald 5 ShowTel and Conference Center.\" However, Destiny stated that they would not be building the hotel or the other amenities it promised, they were still legally entitled to its 30-year PILOT.\n\n\nMiner is a vocal opponent of Gov. 's policies on pensions and financially distressed cities. Mayor Miner publicized Gov. Cuomo was failing to take charge of the issue and had offered cities an \"accounting gimmick\" called pension smoothing instead.\nMiner publicly broke with Cuomo on his proposal to stabilize rising pension costs earlier that year.\n\n\nIn 2015, Miner established the first-ever Mayor's office of Innovation using a grant from Bloomberg Philanthropies.\n\nMiner was part of the Governing Institute Women in Government Leadership Program Class of 2015, a program that highlights the outstanding contributions of women currently in public office, and to encourage future generations of leaders.\n\n\nMiner attended the Clinton Global Initiative America Conference in both 2014 and 2015 to discuss infrastructure for cities and states. Miner also met with members of Congress and submitted testimony before the  and the New York State Legislature detailing the infrastructure needs of the City of Syracuse. Miner is a member of Rebuild New York Now, a coalition of construction trades, business owners, and elected officials.\n\n\nMiner revamped the Joint Schools Construction Board in an effort to rebuild and remodel Syracuse City School District buildings. Four schools were totally renovated, and the project was authorized to include $300 million of individual projects at up to 15 schools. Mayor Miner served as chair of the board.\n\n\nMiner spearheaded the effort to develop the Syracuse Regional Airport Authority. Miner also opened a $60 million renovation for the airport in 2013.\n\n\nMiner served as Co-Chair of the New York State Democratic Committee from 2012 to 2014.\n\n\nOn June 18, 2018, Miner announced that she intended to run for Governor of New York. According to '''', Miner, \"once an ally of Mr. Cuomo's, became something of an outlier in Democratic circles when she emerged as a vocal and persistent critic of the governor and his policies, beginning five years ago and culminating now in a direct challenge as he seeks a third term.\" Miner \"[planned] to run under the banner of an upstart new group, the , which calls itself SAM (coincidentally sharing Miner's initials), formed by people disaffected by the existing party structure after the 2016 elections. She will be the group’s first candidate.\" Miner circulated designating petitions to create a SAM Party in New York, and on August 21, her campaign announced that it had submitted over 40,000 petition signatures. On , Miner and running mate Michael Volpe received 55,441 votes (0.91%).\n\nIn 2021, Miner began writing a book about her two mayor terms.\n\n\nMiner was married to John F. X. Mannion from 2006 until his death in 2019.\n\nFollowing her mayoral tenure, Miner was awarded the Charles Evans Hughes Visiting Chair of Government and Jurisprudence in the Department of Political Science position at Colgate University.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''William D. Reilich''' (born March 17, 1957) is an American politician best known for having served as a man. He serves as Supervisor of the . Most recently re-elected in a landslide receiving over 67% of the vote. This is Reilich's 13th election.\n\nReilich is a businessman who founded Upstate Alarm systems, Upstate Patrol, Upstate Telecommunications answering service and Corporate Limo company in 1975 at age 18 which he eventually sold before entering politics full time.  He now owns Rochester Auto Design.\n\n\nReilich began his political career by serving on the  zoning and environment boards, eventually becoming the GOP chair for the Town of Greece.  In the early 1990s, he considered running for the  legislature, but his campaign failed to materialize when redistricting required by the 1990 census left him without a seat for which to run.  In 1997 he was picked by the Republican members of the county legislature, to succeed John T. Auberger who resigned to become Greece town supervisor.\n\nWhile in the legislature, Reilich served on the Planning and Economic Development Committee and rose to become the chairman of the Ways and Means Committee.  He also served on the board of the County of Monroe Industrial Development Agency (COMIDA).\n\nReilich successfully defended his county legislative seat in 1999 and ran unopposed in 2001.\n\n\nHe was elected to the New York State Assembly in 2002 and served six terms.\n\nIn July 2008 he was elected to Chairman of the Monroe County GOP and served for eleven years, the second longest Chair in County history. During that time he also was elected to Vice Chair of the New York State GOP. As Monroe County Chair, he was regarded as the most successful chair presiding over 1,000 races with a 93.5% win record in a county that has a Democrat enrolment advantage. At one point had 19 county legislative seats out of 29, and held 3 of the four County wide elected offices.\n\n\nIn November 2013,  Reilich was elected to serve as the Supervisor for the Town of Greece.\n\nIn , the United States Supreme Court ruled in favor of the practice of opening town meetings with a prayera practice Reilich continued from his predecessor.\n\nIn 2019, the  (IJC) announced that it had appointed Reilich to the International Lake Ontario-St. Lawrence River Board.\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Brad Madison Hoylman-Sigal''' (born October 27, 1965) is an American  politician. First elected in 2012, Hoylman-Sigal represents the  in the , covering much of the west side of  in New York City. He is chairman of the state senate Judiciary Committee.\n\n\nHoylman-Sigal was born in  and grew up in rural . He was the youngest of six children of Audrey Kennedy Hoylman, a public elementary school teacher, and James M. Hoylman, a  analytics analyst. He is a former  in Troop 70, Lewisburg, West Virginia. He attended  in West Virginia.\n\nHe attended  (WVU; BA in  and , 1989), where Hoylman-Sigal was elected president of student administration and graduated '''' with honors. At WVU he was a member of , and received a  and a .\n\nHoylman-Sigal then attended  () on a . He received a master's degree in political science (M.Phil., 1992).\n\nAfterward, he attended . He graduated with a JD in 1996.\n\n\nHoylman-Sigal was an associate at law firm  from 1996 to 1998. He was an associate at Frankfurt, Garbus, Klein & Selz from 1998 to 2000.\n\nFrom 2000 to 2012, Hoylman-Sigal served as executive vice president and general counsel of the , which represents New York City's business leadership and its largest private-sector employers.\n\nHoylman-Sigal was also the chairperson of , and the Democratic District Leader of the , Part A.  He is also Trustee of the , a former president of the , and a former board member of the , Tenants & Neighbors, Class Size Matters, and .\n\nIn 2001, Hoylman-Sigal ran for the  in the first district, which includes  and a portion of . He placed second in a seven-candidate race, losing to .\n\n\n\n]]\nOn June 11, 2012, Hoylman-Sigal declared his candidacy for the  of the , running for the seat of retiring state senator . He won Duane's endorsement, as well as the support of numerous local politicians and unions. In the Democratic primary election held on September 13, 2012, he won 68% of the vote in a three-candidate field. . DNAinfo.com, September 14, 2012.  activist and bar owner Tom Greco was his closest competition, winning 24% of the vote. In the general election in November he was unopposed.\n\nHoylman-Sigal won the Democratic primary and general election (with 80% of the vote) in 2014, 2016 (with 96% of the vote), and 2018 (with 99% of the vote). As of 2019, Hoylman-Sigal was the only openly gay member of the New York State Senate.\n\nIn December 2016, Hoylman-Sigal sponsored legislation known as the Tax Returns Uniformly Made Public (T.R.U.M.P.) Act, prohibiting New York State electors from voting for a presidential candidate who has not publicly released at least 5 years worth of tax returns no later than 50 days prior to a general election. Lawmakers in 25 other states followed suit in producing legislation to compel presidential candidates to release their tax returns. The idea was praised by the editorial board of ''''.\n\nAfter the , Hoylman-Sigal was appointed Chair of the Senate Judiciary Committee. In the majority, Hoylman-Sigal passed multiple pieces of legislation including the Child Victims Act, the Gender Expression Non-Discrimination Act (or GENDA), and a ban on so-called '.'  Hoylman-Sigal also sponsored the TRUST Act, which was passed by the state Senate. The bill would allow certain Congressional committees to perform oversight by reviewing the New York State tax returns of senior government officials; members of Congress suggested this could allow Congressional committees to review . '''', a New York-based political news organization, characterized Hoylman-Sigal as \"the person behind state Senate’s progressive bills.\"\n\nIn 2019, the Child Victims Act that Hoylman-Sigal sponsored was adopted. It extended New York's  for  and created a one-year lookback window within which survivors would be able to initiate claims against their abusers in cases where the statute of limitations had expired, and allowed them to bring a civil lawsuit against their abuser or institutions that enabled or protected their abuser by the age of 55 (up from the age of 23). Over 9,000 lawsuits have been filed under that law, including against the , the , and other groups that cared for children.\n\n\nIn early 2021, Governor Andrew Cuomo signed a bill, sponsored by Hoylman-Sigal, to repeal New York's ban on paid . Assemblywoman Amy Paulin introduced the bill in 2012.  As of the bill's passage, only two other states (Louisiana and Michigan) retained laws explicitly banning paid surrogacy.\n\nIn June 2021,  defeated Hoylman-Sigal in the Democratic  for . Levine won by 7.4 s. This was the first year that  was implemented for most New York City election and primary contests.\n\nIn June 2021, the New York Senate passed the  (ASA), which was sponsored by Hoylman-Sigal and Assemblymember . The bill failed to pass the Assembly in 2021. However, Rosenthal and Hoylman-Sigal introduced the ASA again the following year.Kate Lisa, ,  (May 2022). This time, the legislation was enacted: it unanimously passed the Senate in April 2022, passed the Assembly on a 140&ndash;3 vote in May 2022,Grace Ashford, , ''New York Times'' (May 23, 2022). and was signed into law by Governor . The bill established a one-year \"lookback period\" that allowed adult victims of sex abuse or sex crimes to bring civil lawsuits that were previously barred due to the .\n\nIn 2021, Hoylman-Sigal asked U.S. Senator , the chair of the , engage in oversight of the , and step in to ensure that SafeSport is adequately conducting investigations. He referred to what he called SafeSport's failure to carry out impartial and thorough investigations and ensure the safety of athletes it is charged with protecting. He highlighted serious outstanding allegations of , , and other violent behaviors by former friends, peers, and current teammates, and an ongoing investigation, and criticized SafeSport's decision to allow fencer  to Tokyo as an alternate for the .\n\nIn 2021, '''' ranked Hoylman-Sigal #11 on its annual list of the 100 most powerful people in Manhattan.\n\nIn 2021, Hoylman-Sigal proposed legislation to ban landlords convicted of criminal activity from doing business with state-chartered banks such as  and .  and  are not . , a landlord notorious for harassing his tenants in New York, was the inspiration for this bill.\n\nIn 2021, to address , Hoylman-Sigal proposed legislation to remove a number of zoning regulations in New York that he viewed as onerous. The legislation would eliminate parking requirements; prohibit localities from requiring large lot sizes for homes; and allow for the construction of up to four housing units on lots that were previously exclusively zoned for single-family housing.\n\nIn 2023, Hoylman-Sigal became the New York State Senator for the  district, which was redistricted from the  district. While Hoylman-Sigal's old district included , , and the , up to north of , the new and more compact 47th district excluded the East Side, and covered the , from  Chelsea through the .\n\nHoylman-Sigal is a member of the Vote Blue Coalition, a progressive group and  created to support Democrats in New York, New Jersey, and Pennsylvania through voter outreach and mobilization efforts.\n\n\nBrad Madison Hoylman married David Ivan Sigal, a filmmaker, at  in Manhattan, New York City, in February 2013. They live with their two daughters, Silvia and Lucy, in . Hoylman-Sigal is .\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* \n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n*\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Todd Kaminsky''' is an American attorney, lobbyist, and former politician from the  of . A , he was a member of the  representing the , which is based on the South Shore of . He was the Democratic nominee for Nassau County District Attorney in 2021 but lost the general election to Anne Donnelly by a landslide.\n\nKaminsky is the great-nephew of entertainer .\n\n\nKaminsky was born and raised in  on Long Island. He received his A.B. degree, , from the , and his  degree, magna cum laude, from .\n\n\nKaminsky worked as an assistant district attorney in the 's Office, prosecuting domestic violence cases, robberies, shootings and other violent crimes. He then joined the  in the Eastern District of New York as an , where he worked for six years. There he became acting deputy chief of the Public Integrity Section, successfully prosecuting elected officials including  Majority Leader ., Assemblyman , and U.S. Representative .\n\nGiving his closing remarks in the Espada, Jr. case, the ''New York Times'' wrote, \"Pacing before the jury and cuing up slides on a computer presentation, Mr. Kaminsky often brought the jury and others in the courtroom to laughter, throwing out one-liners and making fun of Mr. Espada’s excuses for spending the money.\" Kaminsky also successfully prosecuted former music mogul and drug dealer , securing an indictment after Rosemond was captured by DEA agents after remaining a fugitive for a month. For that prosecution, Kaminsky was awarded the True American Hero Award from the Federal Drug Agents Foundation.\n\nAs a community advocate, Kaminsky raised funds and held free legal clinics following . For his efforts, he was awarded the Community Service Award from the U.S. Attorney's Office for the ''Eastern District of New York'' and the Long Beach Martin Luther King Center’s Sandy Relief Service Award.\n\n\nKaminsky was elected to the  in November 2014, succeeding . As  noted in a profile, \"The rookie assemblyman has already delivered some tangible results for his district  speeding up the state’s reimbursement schedule for Sandy housing reconstruction, and pushing to open a new emergency room to compensate slightly for the storm-induced closure of Long Beach Hospital.\"\n\nIn 2015, Kaminsky was named one of 's 40 Under 40 Rising Stars. In his first legislative session, he set a record for recent years for most bills passed by a first-year Assemblymember, and tied him at fourth overall in the Assembly this session with 18 of his bills passing the Assembly and 16 of those also passing the Senate.\n\n\nFollowing the expulsion of  from the , the Democratic Party selected Kaminsky as their nominee for his seat in the  in April 2016. On May 2, two weeks after the election took place, Kaminsky was officially declared the winner after defeating Republican challenger Chris McGrath by 886 votes.  He was then sworn in the next day. Kaminsky and McGrath faced off again in the November 2016 general electionthis time for a full term. Kaminsky won that election by 6,422 votes, or approximately 5% of the electorate.\n\nHe resigned unexpectedly in July 2022 to work for lobbying firm .\n\n\n\nKaminsky's experience as a former federal prosecutor led to him becoming a leader on ethics reform in New York State politics and at the forefront of decision-making around recent corruption scandals. As ''The Wall Street Journal'' wrote, \"The confluence of federal prosecutors’ heightened interest in Albany and Mr. Kaminsky’s background has also vaulted him to prominence as Gov. Andrew Cuomo and the Legislature have grappled with whether and how to institute another package of ethics overhauls, which also happens to be the freshman lawmaker’s legislative priority.\" Kaminsky was appointed by Assembly Speaker  to a panel charged with finding an executive director for the Assembly's new ethics office. Kaminsky also played a role in helping put together the ethics reform package that was proposed in March by the Assembly and .\n\n\nKaminsky considers Hurricane Sandy one of the reasons for his decision to run for Assembly. Sandy hit the South Shore of Long Island particularly hard, destroying thousands of homes and other property. Like many residents in the area, Kaminsky was unsatisfied with the response from  and NY Rising. Since being elected, Kaminsky has pushed for reforms to the NY Rising system, licensing for mold removal companies, and helped implement an information-sharing database in Nassau County to help better track abandoned properties. Kaminsky also introduced a bill passed by the Legislature that would require quarterly reporting on unpaid claims and unresolved Sandy-related cases. Another bill Kaminsky introduced, which would provide tax relief for victims of Hurricane Sandy who withdrew from retirement accounts to cover emergency payments, passed the Assembly.\n\nUpon hearing that National Grid was going to reinstate fees for disconnecting and reconnecting gas lines – fees that had been eliminated after Sandy to provide some relief to homeowners affected – Kaminsky wrote a letter to National Grid on August 21 urging them to reverse the decision. On September 10, after weeks of talks, National Grid announced that it would continue its post-Sandy policy of not charging those fees, in a major victory for Sandy victims.\n\n\nDamage from Hurricane Sandy was so extensive that the  had to be permanently closed. Kaminsky lead the push to call on South Nassau Community Hospital, the new owner, to reopen a full-service hospital in the former hospital's place. In early August, Kaminsky announced that New York State had given approval for a 24/7 freestanding  to open. The emergency department opened on August 10, 2015.\n\n\nTodd and his wife Ellen, married since 2010, live in Long Beach with their children, Rafe and Rory.\n\nKaminsky is the great-nephew of entertainer .  During Kaminsky's 2016 run for a seat in the New York State Senate the famed comedian recorded a  which was then employed by his nephew's campaign.\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Major Robert Odell Owens''' (June 28, 1936 – October 21, 2013) was an American politician and  who served in the  from 1983 to 2007, representing the 's 11th and then 12th congressional district. He was first elected to replace retiring Representative . Owens shepherded the  through the House. He retired at the end of his term in January 2007 and was succeeded by .\n\n\nOwens was born on June 28, 1936, in , to Ezekiel and Edna Owens. He was raised in , and his father worked in a furniture factory as a laborer. He received a  in 1956 from , and a master's degree in library science in 1957 from , now known as Clark Atlanta.\n\n\n\n\nOwens began his career in . After obtaining his master's degree, Owens settled in , New York and began his career as a  at the  from 1958 through the late 1960s. At the same time, Owens became active in the  and other community groups. Owens, a community information librarian, became known for \"placing Brooklyn Public Library collections in public places such as laundromats, stores, bars, and anywhere people gathered.\" In 1969, Owens worked with a group of other New York librarians, including , Anne Littlejohn, Betty-Carol Sellen, Joan Marshall, , , Andrew Armitage, and , to establish the New York Social Responsibilities Round Table. This organization became part of the  and its mission was \"to create a central position for libraries and librarians in the battles for civil rights, social justice, peace, and ever-improved public access to education and information.\"\n\nAlthough having moved from his career in librarianship into his political career, in 1979 and 1991, Owens was a featured speaker at the White House Conference on Libraries sponsored by the . In 1987, Owens was awarded the , its highest honor.\n\n\nIn 1968, New York City Mayor  made Owens the commissioner of 's Community Development Agency. After serving in this position for approximately five years, he successfully ran for and was elected to the New York Senate. He was a member of the  from 1975 to 1982, sitting in the , ,  and s.\n\nIn 1982, he was elected to the , replacing the retiring , where he remained until his retirement in 2006. Owens became known as \"The Librarian In Congress.\" Owens's career in Congress is marked by his advocacy for and support of library funding and education issues; in particular public libraries, school libraries, and librarianship. In Congress, he worked closely with American Disability activist  who often was visiting his office in  and provided testimony before Owen's Subcommittee on Select Education in the House, during the late 1980s and early 1990s, prior to the passage of the ADA when it was being heatedly debated. Owens served as floor manager of the  (ADA) and aided in its enactment.\n\nOwens represented a diverse district located within , which included many African-Americans, Hispanic-Americans and Jewish Americans, including a large  Jewish community. His district included low income areas of , a large  area of , the heavily  areas of  and , and the now upscale neighborhood of . Although Owens won the 2004 Democratic  with just 45.44% of the vote, he was re-elected in the 2004 general election with 94% of the vote. In 2006, Owens decided to retire at the end of his term (January 2007). In the , , who had run against Owens in the 2004 primary, won the election and became Owens successor.\n\nOwens was one of 31 House Democrats who voted to not count the 20 s from  in the . Republican President  won Ohio by 118,457 votes. Without Ohio's electoral votes, the election would have been decided by the U.S. House of Representatives, with each state having one vote in accordance with the .\n\nHe was a member of the . He received an \"A\" on the 's 2005 Congressional Scorecard on middle-class issues.\n\n\nIn 2006, Owens decided to not pursue re-election and retired from Congress, thereby ending his political career. Owens indicated that he wanted to spend his time writing novels and poetry. In 2006 after Owens's retirement decision, the Librarian of Congress announced that Owens would be appointed as a distinguished visiting scholar at the John W. Kluge Center with the position to commence in January 2007. During his time at the John W. Kluge Center, Owens's work focused \"on a case study of the Congressional Black Caucus and its impact on national politics.\" Owens used his time at the Kluge Center to research and write his book ''The Peacock Elite: A Subjective Case Study of the Congressional Black Caucus and Its Impact on National Politics'', which was published in 2011. Owens served as a senior fellow for the DuBois-Bunche Center for Public Policy at .\n\n\nOwens was married twice. His first marriage to Ethel Werfel ended in divorce after twenty-five years. From his marriage to Ethel, Owens had three sons: Brooklyn politician Chris Owens, actor  (best known for playing \"Elvin\" on ''''), and Millard Owens. He then married Maria A. Cuprill (Maria Owens), and the couple had two children.\n\nOwens died October 21, 2013, in New York City of congestive heart failure. He was 77.\n\n\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* , ''Washington Post''\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
          }

    "pages": }\n\n'''Michael J. Cusick''' (born February 21, 1969) is a former   who represented the 's District 63, in . He is a , and served in the Assembly from 2003 to 2023.\n\n\nCusick is the son of the late  Justice Peter P. Cusick and Miriam \"Mimi\" Cusick.Tom Wrobleski, \"McMahon flexes his muscle and ally Titone gets the nod,\" '''', March 1, 2007.  In 1987, he graduated from , where he was on the cross-country and long-distance track teams.\n\nHe graduated from  in 1991.\n\n\nCusick began his career as a Special Assistant to former President of the City Council . He was the office representative for the Borough of Staten Island and worked on issues regarding incineration and waste management alternatives.\n\nPrior to his 2002 election, Cusick served as the Chief of Staff to former Staten Island Assemblyman , managing staff and overseeing the assemblyman's Albany and Staten Island offices. He researched and developed state legislation, including the law to close the . Cusick was also Vitaliano's representative to local and statewide civic, professional, and union organizations, on legislative and community issues.\n\nCusick later became Director of Constituent Services for U.S. Senator , as Schumer's liaison to New York State elected officials and to various federal agencies. He managed the day-to-day operation of the Senator's New York City office. He was elected to the New York State Assembly in the .\n\nAfter Rep. 's resignation, the  expressed interest in Cusick as the  nominee, but he declined.\n\nAs Assemblyman, Cusick wrote and sponsored several bills. In 2003, he wrote a law creating a moratorium on building in the area of the Mid-Island Blue Belt (Chapter 84 of 2003). He wrote legislation requiring notice to neighboring landowners of an application to build on  areas. In 2006, he helped pass a budget that increased school aid by $500 million over the previous year. The budget also included a down payment of $1.8 billion to renovate and expand city schools. In 2005, he sponsored legislation that allowed New York City to eliminate its share of the  on clothing and footwear (Chapter 285 of 2005). In 2006, he supported a budget that abolished the state tax. In 2008 Cusick introduced legislation that would make it a crime to protest or disturb in any way a funeral or memorial service.\n\nOn February 24, 2022, Cusick announced that he would not seek reelection to Assembly District 63. However, he announced his intention to continue to serve as Chairman of the Staten Island Democratic Party. Cusick later resigned as he took up his new role as the head of a local not-for-profit, the  and was succeeded by one of his vice-chairs, Laura Sword.\n\nDuring Senate Session 2023, Governor  appointed Cusick to the New York Power Authority Board of Trustees.\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Alicia L. Hyndman''' is the Assembly member for the 29th District of the . She is a . The district includes portions of , , , , ,  and  in .\n\n\nHyndman was born in  to parents who had immigrated from the , and moved at a very young age to , where her parents settled in the  neighborhoods of , and subsequently .  She would attend public schools, graduating from .\n\nShe received a  degree from  and later a  from  in . She worked in education policy at the , , and the .\n\nHyndman served as President of the Community District Education Council 29 - a group of volunteer parents that advise the NYC School Chancellor on dozens of schools in Southeast Queens. As President of CDEC 29, she organized opposition to co-location proposals throughout her school district including I.S.59Q and P.S.15Q Under her leadership, CDEC 29 also voted to approve 'middle school choice' which allows parents in the school district to select from any middle school in their area. She also helped to lobby for the construction of a new school in the heart of St. Albans after a local Catholic school closed.\n\nHyndman resides in  with her two daughters.\n\n\nIn 2015, Assemblyman  was convicted of a felony for the inappropriate use of state funds, and as a result was forced to relinquish his seat in the Assembly. With a special election called, Hyndman was nominated by the Queens Democratic Party to replace him. Facing nominal opposition, Hyndman went on to win the seat on 3 November 2015 with 91.35% of the vote.\n\nShe was sworn into office on 10 January 2016. She won re-election in 2016 unopposed. Since her re-election she has partnered with several other local elected officials and the PTA to prevent the co-location of I.S.109Q with a high school.\n\nDuring negotiations for the FY2017-2018 State Budget, Hyndman was a part of group of Assembly Members of color who successfully pushed Assembly Speaker  and Governor  to include legislation to raise the age of criminal prosecution from age 16 to 18 for non-violent felonies. This reform made New York State the last state to prosecute 16 and 17 year olds in Criminal Court instead of Family Court.\n\nSince her election to the , Hyndman has worked closely with NYS Senator , NYS Senator , and Council Member  to develop a \"Freedom Ticket\" pilot program in Southeast Queens to address the transit desert. Local residents would be allowed a reduced fare to ride the  to  with free transfer to the buses and subways. Hyndman has also passed state legislation that allows  to give out as much as $150,000 to Minority & Women-owned Business Enterprises (MWBE) without a competitive bidding process in an attempt to promote minority businesses.\n\n\n\n\n\n* official site\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Edward P. Ra''' (born November 4, 1981) is a member of the , representing the 19th district, which includes portions of the towns of ,  and  in  on . A , Ra was first elected in 2010.\n\nRa was born in  and raised in , where he still resides with his wife Laura. He earned a  in computer science from  in 2004. He received his  from  in 2007 and  in Intellectual Property Law from  in 2008. Prior to entering elected office, Ra served as the deputy town attorney for the , where the Town Attorney is his father, Joseph Ra. He was also a legal aide in the Office of the .\n\nIn 2010, Assemblyman  decided not to seek reelection, and Ra entered the race to succeed him. Ra defeated Democrat Patrick Nicolosi. Since his initial election, he has never faced serious opposition. In 2018, Ra defeated Democrat Bill Carr 55% to 45%, his closest race since the 2010 election.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
