    "pages": }\n\n'''Mark J. F. Schroeder''' (born December 13, 1955) is an American politician who currently serves as the Commissioner of the .\n\n\nSchroeder was raised in , where he attended Public School #72, St. Thomas Aquinas School, and . He received an  degree from  in 1976, and a  degree from  in 1982.\n\n\n\n\nIn 2001, Schroeder ran for an open seat in the  Legislature against conservative Joe Kelly of South Buffalo. As a County Legislator, he started the Greater South Buffalo Chamber of Commerce, which currently has more than 200 members and holds several community events every year. That same year, Schroeder founded the South Buffalo Education Center, which offers G.E.D. classes and computer and vocational training, helping more than 500 students receive their GEDs since 2002.\n\n\nSchroeder was first elected to the Assembly in November 2004 and he was re-elected in November 2006. He won the November 2008 general election with 75 percent of the vote and ran uncontested in the November 2010 general election.\n\nIn 2010, Schroeder indicated he would not vote for  as , although both are Democrats.\n\n\nIn June 2011, he expressed interest in running for the position of Buffalo City Comptroller, which had been recently vacated by  when he was appointed New York State Deputy Comptroller. He was expected to face opposition in a Democratic primary from Erie County Legislature Majority Leader Maria Whyte, but she withdrew from the race to instead run in a special election for Erie County Clerk. In November 2011, Schroeder was elected Buffalo City Comptroller, he was unopposed.\n\n\nOn December 30, 2018, Schroeder announced he will be resigning from the City Comptroller's office to become the Commissioner of the .\n\n\nSchroeder resides in South Buffalo, with his wife, Kathleen (née Horan), and their three children.\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Randolph Brody''' '''Altschuler''' (born December 8, 1970) is an American businessman and politician. He was the Republican and Conservative Party candidate for Congress in New York's 1st Congressional District in 2010 and 2012. He is the co-founder and chief executive officer (CEO) of , Inc.\n\n\nAltschuler was born and raised in New York City by a single mother, Sheila Brody, and graduated from  in 1989. He attended , working his way through school as a short order cook and campus security guard. He graduated in 1993 with a Bachelor of Arts (B.A.) in German Studies and Literature, earning High Honors. In 1994, Altschuler studied at the  as a . In 1998, Altschuler graduated from  earning a  (MBA) degree with Distinction.\n\n\nAltschuler worked as an investment banker at  and served as an assistant to the CEO of  North America, focusing on strategic and management issues. After getting his MBA, Altschuler worked in private equity at .. CloudBlue. Retrieved 11 November 2010. As an entrepreneur, Altschuler has co-founded three successful companies, including Office Tiger in 1999, CloudBlue in 2001, and  in 2013, where he is CEO. Xometry became a public company on June 30, 2021, trading on  under the ticker symbol XMTR.\n\n\nIn 1999, Altschuler and Princeton classmate  started OfficeTiger, a  (BPO) company that performs back-office support services for American companies., ''CNN in the Money'', February 28, 2004. In July 2005,  magazine reported that OfficeTiger was the only successful startup in India's outsourcing industry owned and managed by U.S. entrepreneurs.\n\nAltschuler claims that OfficeTiger is not a traditional outsourcing company, but rather one whose overseas employees \"enhance the services and jobs that Americans are doing here domestically,\" and contends, \"You want the professionals here doing different kinds of things than he or she is doing today. Office Tiger allows them to take some of the more traditional tasks and outsource that offshore.\"\n\nOfficeTiger was acquired by  in April 2006 for $250&nbsp;million, and through combination with another Donnelley acquisition, Astron BPO, by September 2006 OfficeTiger had expanded to 29 offices and 42 client locations across nine countries and employed 4,000 people in India, 4,000 in Europe, 1,000 in Sri Lanka, 750 in the United States, and 300 in the Philippines.\n\n\nIn 2001 Altschuler co-founded an  (e-waste) recycling company CloudBlue Technologies based in , having moved there in 2011 from . He served as the company's executive chairman and worked out of their Port Jefferson, NY offices. On September 30, 2013, ClouldBlue was acquired by Ingram Micro, a large wholesale technology distributor.\n\n\n, 2024]]\nAltschuler's most recent business venture is , Inc., an advanced manufacturing company with investors including Dell Technologies Capital and Highland Capital Partners, that he co-founded with Laurence Zuriff in 2013.\n\n\n]]\n\nOn August 11, 2009, Altschuler filed to run for U.S. Congress from New York's 1st congressional district against four-term incumbent  . Altschuler won the September 14, 2010, Republican primary over , a former  prosecutor, and , a grandson of , receiving 45.07% of the vote. Demos received 30.32%, while Cox received 24.61%.\n\nIn the general election, Altschuler was endorsed by former New York City Mayor , Suffolk County Executive Steve Levy, Former Massachusetts Governor and 2008 presidential contender , Former New York Governor , House Republican Whip , former House Speaker , The U.S. Chamber of Commerce, the National Federation of Independent Business, Long Island Congressman Peter T. King, , , The Conservative Party of New York State, the , , and numerous other local elected officials. In the days leading up to the primary, Conservative radio host  commented on the race calling Altschuler \"a guy who was a Green Party pro-choice Republican in New Jersey before they shipped him out to Suffolk County to run.\"\n\nAltschuler faced incumbent Tim Bishop in the November 2, 2010 general election. On Election Day Bishop was reported to have a 3,400 vote lead but after the electronic voting machines were reread at the board of elections, Altschulter was reported with a 392-vote lead, with approximately 11,000 absentee ballots left to be counted. After most absentee ballots were tabulated, Bishop had a 263-vote lead, at which point Altschuler conceded defeat to Bishop and ended his campaign on December 8 – 36 days after the election.  It was the last Congressional race decided in the United States. Altschuler lost the election by 593 votes.\n \nAltschuler invested $2.2&nbsp;million of his own money in the campaign.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nEnding speculation that he would run for the Suffolk  position to succeed , he announced in May 2011 that he would run for Congress again in 2012.  He faced  in the primary. The National Republican Congressional Committee named Altschuler to their \"Young Guns\" list of the top Republican candidates in the country. Altschuler secured the nomination of the Independence Party, which had delivered Bishop 7,370 votes in 2010.\n\nAltschuler's campaign collected well over 6,000 signatures to nominate him as the Republican, Conservative and Independence Party candidate in 2012, vastly surpassing the 938 required by law.\nAltschuler's only rival for the nomination left the race in May 2012.\nIn the election, Altschuler was again defeated by Bishop, this time by around 11,000 votes.\n\n\nAltschuler was awarded membership in the exclusive GOP \"Young Guns\", a select group of young candidates chosen by Majority Leader Eric Cantor and Majority Whip Kevin McCarthy.\n\n\nRandy Altschuler is married to Cheryl Sladkin, a professional ballet dancer turned pediatrician. She was a classmate from Princeton, where they met. Cheryl was born in Thailand. They have two sons, Noah and Matthew, and a daughter Sasha.  The family lives in .\n\n\n\n\n\n* ''official business site''\n* ''official campaign site''\n* \n* at \n*  at eBusinessForum, March 22, 2006\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Clarence Henry \"Du\" Burns''' (September 13, 1918 – January 12, 2003) was a  politician and the first  mayor of , Maryland in 1987.\n\n\nBurns was born in Baltimore on September 13, 1918. One of his first jobs was locker room attendant at Dunbar High School, one of the others being picking up newspapers. He got the nickname \"Du\" for what he would \"do\" for his community.\n\n\nDu Burns was first elected to the  in 1971. He was later elected City Council President in 1983, defeating  in the election. In January 1987, the then-Mayor  resigned after being elected . As City Council president, Burns was elevated to mayor, becoming the first black mayor in the city's history.\n\nIn , Burns ran for a full term but was defeated in the Democratic primary by . He ran again , once more falling second to Schmoke for the primary.\n\nIn 1991,  on the waterfront near the neighborhood of  and  was named in Burns's honor. In 2014, the field received a renovation deal of 20 years, worth up to $1.5 million.\n\n\nBurns was Catholic, an active member of .\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Joseph Louis Bruno''' (April 8, 1929 – October 6, 2020) was an American businessman and  politician from . Bruno served in the  from 1977 to 2008 and was Senate Majority Leader from 1994 to 2008. Bruno was convicted of federal corruption charges in 2009, but his conviction was overturned on appeal and a subsequent retrial resulted in an acquittal.\n\n\nBruno was born in  and grew up in a six-room . Bruno graduated from  and earned a  in  from . He served in the  as an  . Bruno was president of the New York State ; in 1964, he was named by them as one of the five \"Outstanding Young Men of the State.\" He “became a millionaire after founding and then selling the Coradian Corporation, a company that sold telephone systems to private businesses and government agencies”.\n\n\nIn 1966, Bruno was on the campaign staff of Governor , and from 1969 to 1974 he served as Special Assistant to Speaker of the Assembly . From 1968 to 1969, he was President of the New York State Association of . He also served as Chairman of the Rensselaer County Republican Committee from 1974 to 1977.\n\n\n in  on November 15, 1997]]\n , , and  during a tour of the 7 World Trade Center disaster site on September 14, 2001, following the ]]\nBruno was a member of the  from 1977 to 2008, sitting in the , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , and s. He was elected  on November 25, 1994, ousting the incumbent .\n\nBruno, along with Governor  and Assembly Speaker , was instrumental in passing a  law in New York State in 1995.  The  (the highest state court in New York) later found the law to be unconstitutional because it gave jurors deadlocked between life without parole and execution no choice but to give eligibility for parole after 25 years; the Court of Appeals feared that jurors faced with this choice would unfairly lean toward a death sentence.  In the 10 years after the law was passed, New York's crime rate plummeted without ever seeing an execution, perhaps weakening public support for the death penalty.  Silver let the law die in 2005 without much debate.\n\nDuring the budget process in 1995, Bruno (who was new to the Majority Leader role at the time) made a comment about Blacks and Hispanics who \"got their hands out\" pressuring the legislature to avoid cuts to social services.  According to the '''', \"Bruno said he was referring to the Black and  Caucus, which is a major force in the Democratic majority in the Assembly.\"  Bruno's defense was that he was referring to political caucuses, not all blacks and Hispanics; he offered a blanket apology for offending some people, but refused to take his words back.\n\nAccording to an editorial in '''', Bruno pushed a bill through the Senate on June 27, 1995, that would have required girls under 16 years of age to obtain consent from both parents for an abortion. The bill never passed the New York State Assembly.\n\nAfter , a  bill, languished in the state Senate for many years as a result of Bruno's opposition, Bruno and his caucus were put on the spot for their support of a socially conservative agenda.  people and groups pushed very hard for SONDA, and in late 2002, Bruno finally gave in; the bill passed the Senate and was signed into law by Governor Pataki.\n\nIn 2005, Bruno proposed research into  in New York State as part of a plan to boost Upstate New York's economy.\n\nIn December 2006, Bruno disclosed that the  had been looking into business associates  of Bruno's who had received state grants.  The FBI investigation appeared to lead Bruno to end one of his long-time consulting jobs in 2007.\n\nInitially,   supported Bruno's agenda as Senate Majority Leader. In later years, they expressed concern over Bruno's willingness to cooperate with Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver on budgets deemed to be excessive, over endorsements Bruno received from state employee s (including  union ), and over Bruno's recruitment of former Democrats to run as Republicans for swing Senate districts in  and .\n\nAs of 2009, all 16 municipalities (two cities and 14 towns) in  had at least one building named for Bruno. In addition, the a short-season minor-league affiliate of the play in  situated on the Troy-North Greenbush border.\n\n\nEntering 2007, Bruno's hold on Senate control appeared more precarious than in prior years, as the Republicans lost the seat formerly held by , failed to regain a Republican-leaning seat in Syracuse andwith a caucus diminished to 33 membershad to defend the open seat of  in ; the latter seat was lost to Democrat , a Nassau County Legislator in a February 6, 2007 special election.  The electoral reverses and the ongoing FBI investigation led some Republicans to suggest Bruno might step down as Majority Leader. There were also rumors some Republican senators might cross the aisle to throw control of the Senate to the Democrats.\n\nIn April 2007, Bruno also appeared to hold  over two other Spitzer initiatives:  and .  Bruno challenged New York State Governor  to restore the state's  law.  Bruno also criticized the Governor's plan to issue driver licenses to , claiming it was aimed at stuffing the ballot box with Democratic voters.\n\nBruno's position became more tenuous in February 2008 after the special election loss of the heavily Republican 48th District in , which had formerly been held by Sen. . This loss diminished the Republican Senate majority to a single seat, and press speculation centered on whether the remaining GOP senate caucus would cause Bruno to step down.\n\n\n\nOn July 23, 2007,   admonished Governor Eliot Spitzer's administration for ordering the  to track Bruno's travel records, particularly his use of a state helicopter. At the direction of top officials of the Spitzer administration, the New York State Police created documents meant to cause political damage to Bruno.  The governor's staff stated they were responding to a  (FOIA or FOIL) request from the Albany '''' in late June.\n\nA lengthy report issued by the Attorney General's office concluded that Spitzer aides attempted to create negative media coverage concerning Bruno's travel before any Freedom of Information Act request was made. Not available, March 17, 2008. The investigation looked into both Bruno's travel and the senate leader's allegation that Spitzer used State Police to spy on him. The ''Times Union's'' requests sought documents on use of state aircraft by seven officials, including Spitzer, Bruno and Lieutenant Governor , yet Spitzer's office released only Bruno's itinerary. The Spitzer administration and the State Police provided far more details about Bruno than about other officials to the ''Times Union''. No other officials were subject to the same scrutiny as Bruno. In some cases, the reports created by State Police were pieced together long after the trips and based on the memories of the police escorts involved. Not available, March 17, 2008. The report stated that the ''Times Union'' request came after the story about Bruno's travels was published, and was \"not consistent\" with Spitzer administration claims that all it did was respond to a FOIL request.Kugler, Sara. \" \", '' '', July 24, 2007. Retrieved July 28, 2007. Cuomo concluded: \"These e-mails show that persons in the governor's office did not merely produce records under a , but were instead engaged in planning and producing media coverage concerning Senator Bruno's travel on state aircraft before any FOIL request was made.\"Faiola, Anthony. \"\", '''', p. A06, July 25, 2007. Retrieved on July 28, 2007. The report cleared Bruno of any legal violations in his use of the state's air fleet. Not available, March 17, 2008. The report criticized Spitzer's office for using State Police resources to gather information about Bruno's travel and releasing the information to the media. On July 23, 2007, Spitzer stated that his administration had \"grossly mishandled\" the situation regarding Bruno's use of state aircraft and added that he had personally apologized to Bruno.\n\nOn March 29, 2008, '''' reported that \"former Gov. Eliot L. Spitzer lied to prosecutors\" about his role in , but added that \"the Albany County District Attorney said he will not pursue any criminal charges against the already disgraced ex-governor.\"\n\n\nOn June 23, 2008, Bruno confirmed that he would not seek re-election in the fall of 2008. On June 24, 2008, Bruno stepped down as \"temporary president of the senate\" and as Senate Majority Leader. On July 18, 2008, Bruno resigned his  seat.  On November 4, 2008, he was replaced by his \"hand-picked\" successor, , in the .Kenneth C. Crowe II, \"McDonald tops Russo in 43rd Senate race: Incumbents Farley, Seward, Breslin also lead in their Senate races\", '''', found at .  Retrieved November 6, 2008.\n\n\nOn January 23, 2009, Bruno was indicted on eight federal corruption charges, including  and . The indictment alleged that between 1993 and 2006, Bruno was paid $3.2 million in consulting fees to use his position to do favors for entities with business before the state.\n\nOn December 7, 2009, Bruno was convicted of two counts of mail and wire fraud. He was acquitted of five felony charges, and the jury  on the eighth and final count of the indictment. On May 6, 2010, he was sentenced to two years in jail.\n\nIn November 2011, Bruno's convictions were overturned on appeal. In May 2013, Bruno's lawyers urged an appeals court to halt the planned retrial, claiming it would violate Bruno's right against double jeopardy. In August 2013, the  denied Bruno's appeal and held that he could be retried. On May 16, 2014, Bruno was acquitted on both remaining corruption charges.Lovett, Ken (May 16, 2014). . ''New York Daily News''. Retrieved June 2, 2014.\n\n\nAlmost one year after stepping down from being Senate Majority Leader, Bruno announced that he supported same-sex marriagea position that in the past he had never taken publicly. In 2009, Bruno was asked by Governor  to speak out for same-sex marriage in . Bruno also admitted in 2009 that he personally favored same-sex marriage but never brought it to the floor of the State Senate because the majority of his conference was against it, stating \"[this] is America, and we have ... Life is short, and we should all be afforded the same opportunities and rights to enjoy it.\"  was passed in New York in 2011.\n\nIn October 2015, Bruno announced that he was contributing $1.4 million in unspent campaign funds to the New York State Senate Republican Campaign Committee, and donating $100,000 to a scholarship fund.  At the same time, he announced that he was closing his legal defense fund and donating the $70,000 balance to several nonprofit organizations.\n\nBruno's , ''Keep Swinging: A Memoir of Politics and Justice'', was published by  in November 2016. In the memoir, Bruno reportedly made \"a spirited defense\" of Albany's \"system of transactional politics and backroom dealing that he says generally worked\".\n\n\nBruno and his wife, Barbara, had four children: Joseph, Susan, Kenneth, and Catherine. Barbara Bruno died in 2008 after suffering from . As of 2014, Bruno's partner was Kay Stafford, President and CEO of CMA Consulting Services and widow of the late Republican State Senator . Bruno lived in  in , .\n\nIn September 2013, Bruno had successful surgery to remove a cancerous tumor from his kidney.\n\nIn late July 2006, Bruno's 20-year-old granddaughter Rachel Bruno disappeared and her family alerted the authorities. In early August, Rachel was recovered by police in  when they traced her cellphone calls. 30-year-old John Savage, who Rachel had met on the internet, was arrested by police at the same spot.\n\nOn October 6, 2020, Bruno died at his home in  after a lengthy battle with . He was 91.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Jeffrey David Klein''' (born July 10, 1960) is an American politician and a member of the . He represented the 's , serving parts of  and  from 2005 to 2018. Klein also served as Deputy Democratic Conference Leader.\n\nKlein served in the  from 1994 until 2004, when he was elected to the New York State Senate. From January 2011 to April 2018, Klein led the  (IDC), a group of Democratic state senators who formed a separate conference and allied themselves with Senate Republicans. Klein and his IDC colleagues rejoined the Senate Democratic Conference in April 2018.\n\nIn the September 2018 Democratic primary election, Klein was defeated by lawyer and first-time candidate  in what amounted to a major upset for Klein and his former IDC colleagues. Klein remained on the general election ballot on a minor party line and was defeated by Biaggi again.\n\n\nA lifelong resident of the northeast , son of Howard and Marilyn Klein, he was educated in Bronx public schools. Klein received his undergraduate degree from , an  from 's School of International and Public Affairs, and a  from the , where he was a member of the .\n\n\nA former chief of staff to Congressman , Klein served as a  State Committeeman and District Leader before being elected to the  in 1994. During his ten years representing the 80th Assembly District in the state legislature, Klein served as Chairman of the Subcommittee on Crime and the Elderly, the Committee on State-Federal Relations, and the Committee on Oversight, Analysis and Investigations.\n\n\nIn 2004, after former State Senator  was convicted on corruption charges, Klein declined to seek reelection to the Assembly in order to run for Velella's seat in the New York Senate. In the Democratic Senate primary, Klein defeated then-Assemblyman . Prior to running for the Senate, Klein was reported to be considering a race for  in 2006, but did not do so because  and  were competing for that position. After two years in the Senate, he abandoned plans to run for the Majority Leader position, instead opting for the Deputy Minority Leader spot.\n\nAfter considering a race for New York Attorney General, Klein opted to run for re-election. In 2010, he was easily re-elected, defeating Republican Frank Vernuccio, a community activist in the Bronx.\n\n\n\nIn January 2011, Klein announced that he would lead the newly formed  (IDC), a group of breakaway New York State Senate Democrats.\n\nFollowing the 2010 census, New York redistricted the Senate, expanding it from 62 to 63 seats as of January 2013. The 34th district of  where Klein was elected was  to combine a majority white district in the Bronx with Jewish neighborhoods in  and in the . When all election night results were tabulated on November 6, 2012, it appeared that Democrats would hold 33 seats for a three-seat majority, their third Senate majority since World War II. Yet not long after the Senate Democrats' momentous victory, on December 4, 2012, Klein and the Republican Leadership announced a power-sharing agreement between the IDC and the G.O.P. in order to govern the Senate in a bipartisan coalition. Under their power-sharing arrangement, the IDC and the Senate Republicans jointly controlled the Senate legislative calendar (determining what bills would reach the Senate floor), made assignments to Senate committees, decided appointments to government boards, and negotiated the state budget. Sens. Klein and Skelos also agreed that the title of Senate President would shift back and forth between the two of them every two weeks.\n\nKlein was a prime sponsor of the 2013 New York Secure Ammunition and Firearms Enforcement Act (), which enacted new comprehensive  measures statewide in the wake of the  in , and in response to .\n\nKlein was the primary sponsor of proposed \"At Rest\" legislation, which would require liquor sold in New York State to be stored in warehouses located in New York State. Wine retailers, New York wine producers, and smaller wine wholesalers argue that the legislation would drive up the cost of wine and spirits in New York State and significantly benefit large New York State liquor wholesalers such as Empire Merchants, which donated over $53,000 to Klein's campaign between 2009 and 2014.\n\nPrior to the 2013 state budget negotiations, Klein publicly demanded that New York increase its minimum wage as part of a final agreement. Klein's support was seen as critical to the measure's success, which will increase New York's minimum wage to $9 per hour by the end of 2015.\n\nLiberal activists working with the Democratic Party and the  targeted Klein in 2014, with  challenging Klein in a Democratic primary. Due to pressure from   and , Klein indicated in June 2014 that the IDC would rejoin the Democratic caucus after the . Klein defeated Koppell.\n\nIn the 2014 general election, Republicans won back the Senate majority. The election results meant that Klein lost his position as Senate co-leader. Though Klein had previously stated that the IDC would rejoin the Senate Democrats, the IDC decided to remain allied with the Republicans in the 2015 legislative session despite their conference's diminished role.\n\nKlein was a partner in the  Klein, Calderoni & Santucci, LLP, but divested from the law practice in 2015 and continued to call for lawmakers to give up their outside income.\n\nKlein and his IDC colleagues rejoined the Senate Democratic Conference in April 2018 at the request of Gov. . At that time, Klein was appointed to his former role as Deputy Democratic Conference Leader.\n\n\nIn January 2018, Klein was accused by a female former staffer of forcibly kissing her in 2015. Klein denied the accusation. Despite the allegations, Klein took part in high-level negotiations regarding sexual harassment legislation in 2018. The New York Joint Commission on Public Ethics (JCOPE) opened an investigation into the allegation, though by the time it went to an administrative hearing, Klein was no longer in the  State Senate, having lost his campaign for reelection.Anna Gronewold, , ''Politico'' (December 5, 2019).\n\nKlein later petitioned to shut down the investigation, pointing to findings by the assigned hearing officer that encouraged the commission to drop the investigation in June 2020. The findings concluded that the Public Officers Law under which Klein was charged did not apply because the alleged incident appeared to be isolated and did not affect government decision-making. In August 2020, the JCOPE voted 9–2 to proceed with the investigative hearing.\nKlein's lawyers attempted to have the lawsuit dismissed in January 2021. In March 2023, Klein failed to have the  (or probe) into the allegations closed by investigators. The Appellate Division Third Department in Albany ruled against dimissal on March 9, 2023. Klein did not appeal the ruling. He originally requested the investigation into the accusations against himself while he was still a New York State Senator.\n\n\nLawyer and first-time candidate , 32 years old, challenged Klein, who had held the seat for 14 years, in the 2018 Democratic Primary election. Klein outspent Biaggi by a rate of 9-to-1, spending $2 million to her $200,000. Biaggi defeated Klein in the primary in a major upset, 54%-46%. His upset loss was attributed by some to anger with the former members of the Independent Democratic Conference.\n\nAs New York's  laws allow candidates to appear on multiple ballot lines in an election, Klein still appeared in the November 6, 2018, general election on the third-party  ballot line. Biaggi defeated Klein again in the general election.\n\n\nAfter leaving the state Senate, Klein became a lobbyist for Mercury Public Affairs, based in New York City.\n\n\nAs of February 2018, Klein was romantically involved with , a fellow Democratic State Senator. Klein and Savino had been dating since 2008. Like Klein, Savino is a former member of the IDC.\n\n\n* \n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
          }
        ]
      }

    "pages": }\n'''Peter Lawrence''' is an American politician who served as a member of the  from 2015 to 2021. A , he represented  ,  and  in .\n\n\nA native of , Lawrence formerly served as an officer with the  before retiring to accept a nomination from President  as a , in which he would serve from 2002 to 2010. Lawrence also has served as a wrestling coach for , and as a board member for various other organizations.\n\nIn 2014, Assemblyman  opted not to seek re-election, and Lawrence was nominated by Republicans to replace him. He easily won election with nearly 68% of the vote.\n\nFor more than 30 years, Lawrence has served as a board member for the . He has also been the assistant coach for the  wrestling team.\n\n\n\n\n\n* ''official site''\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Christopher S. \"Chris\" Friend''' (born December 21, 1972) is an   and  who represents the 124th Assembly District of the . He is a  and represents parts of  and  Counties, and all of Tioga County. Friend is known to submit less bills than other Members of the Assembly. As of March 2020, Friend has sponsored 47 bills. This compares to neighboring assemblyman  sponsoring 137 bills in the same time.\n\nA native of  and a 1991 graduate of , he completed a  in chemistry at the  before earning  and  degrees in chemistry at the . He was named a   Fellow and has published more than 20 scientific papers and symposia.\n\nIn 2006, he was elected to the Chemung County Legislature. In 2010, he won election to the State Assembly after winning Republican and  party primaries against   George Richter, the endorsed candidate, who later endorsed Friend. The seat had become vacant after former Assemblyman  ran successfully for the .\n\nOn June 3, 2020 Friend, along with , were the only two assemblymen to voted against the Digital Fair Repair Act.\n\nFriend resides in Big Flats with his wife Renée and their four children: Brianna, Joshua, Ashley, and Elijah.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Rafael L. Espinal Jr.''' (born June 30, 1984) is an American politician and non-profit executive. A , he represented the  of the , which includes portions of , , , , , and  in .\n\nOn January 26, 2020, he resigned from the City Council in favor of leading the  as its President and Executive Director.\n\n\nEspinal has lived in Brooklyn all his life, while his parents are from the . He was born in 1984, and is the third of six children. He was raised in , attending and graduating from New York City public schools, P.S. 108, I.S. 302, and Franklin K. Lane High School. Espinal attended  and graduated with a bachelor's degree in English.\n\nIn 2017 - 2018, Espinal was selected for a MIT CoLab Fellowship. A two year program within the MIT Department of Urban Studies and Planning focused on prospective models for community-driven economic development tied to shared wealth and ownership.\n\n\nEspinal first worked as an  teacher.\nEspinal entered public service as an aide to City Councilmember , ultimately serving as his chief of staff.\n\nIn the , he was the only New York City Councilmember to endorse . He endorsed him again for the , the first City Councilmember to do so.\n\nIn 2017, Espinal was named one of '''''s \"New Yorkers of the Year\", largely in recognition of his advocacy in repealing the , enforcement of which disproportionately targeted LGBTQ and ethnic minority venues and creating the city's Office of Nightlife, dedicated to supporting DIY art spaces, music venues, bars and restaurants.\n\nIn 2019, Espinal ran in the  for , following 's victory in her race for . He came in 7th place in a crowded field of 17 candidates, won by fellow Brooklyn City Councilmember . The New York Times endorsed Jumaane Williams, but noted on Espinal's career as a City Council Member, \"In a 51-member body, Mr. Espinal has been a standout.\"\n\nEspinal, facing term limits to another term in the City Council, announced plans to run for  in the 2021 election, as , then Brooklyn Borough President, faced term limits. Espinal dropped out of the race in January 2020, and subsequently resigned from the Council entirely.\n\n\nIn his first campaign, Espinal won the open 54th district seat in the  in a  held on September 13, 2011. The seat was left vacant after  resigned from the post in order to take a position with Governor 's administration. The assembly district represents parts of , , , , and  in .\n\nEspinal had endorsements from the , the  and the . In a tight race, Espinal (46%) defeated Jesus Gonzalez (35%) running on the  line and Deidra Towns (19%) running on her party platform, \"Community First\".\n\nIn 2012, Espinal was named one of City & State's \"New York City Rising Stars: 40 Under 40\" for his work as New York State Assemblyman.\n\n\nIn 2013, Espinal opted to leave the state Assembly to run for the  to succeed , and won the primary and general to take the seat in 2014.\n\nIn 2014 Mayor  announced an affordable housing plan that would create over 3,000 units of affordable housing in the , , and  portions of his district. Espinal used the opportunity to advocate for funding to address all of the social and infrastructure issues his community had experienced for decades. While facing opposition from a citywide advocacy group, Espinal was able to secure what some have called the most comprehensive rezoning plan in the City of New York, over a quarter of a billion dollars to address unemployment, crumbling infrastructure, and affordable housing issues. '''' endorsed Espinal's move and stated that \"Espinal did right by his constituents.\"\n\nIn 2017 Espinal introduced and passed a bill calling for the full repeal of the , a regulation introduced in 1926 and often called racist, homophobic and authoritarian by its opponents. He soon after passed legislation creating the nation's first Office of Nightlife, a city agency dedicated to supporting the city's nightlife economy.\n\nIn 2019 Espinal passed legislation requiring all New York City buildings to install solar panels or green roofs as part of New York City's \"Green New Deal\" to decrease carbon emissions and build green infrastructure. Espinal also lead on many  green initiatives like banning singles use plastics, securing funding for New York City's first electric school buses and passing the city's first Urban Agriculture policy, creating a comprehensive Urban Ag plan, website and Office.\n\nOn January 26, 2020, he resigned from the City Council to become the Executive Director and President of .\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Jonathan G. Jacobson''' (born June 20, 1953) is an American politician and attorney who has served in the  since 2018. A , Jacobson represents the 104th district, covering  and .\n\n\nAfter graduating from  with a B.A. degree and then  in June 1977 with a J.D. degree, Jacobson held a number of positions in New York state government, including Assistant Counsel to the , Assistant Attorney General, and Workers' Compensation Law Judge. He also operates his own law firm.\n\nJacobson chaired the  Charter Review Commission in the early 1990s, and is a former Newburgh city council member.\n\nJacobson ran for mayor of Newburgh in 2015 against incumbent Democrat . Although Jacobson defeated Kennedy in the Democratic primary, Kennedy won in the general election on the  line.\n\nIn , Jacobson announced his campaign for the 104th Assembly district, which had been held by Democrat  until his death in April 2018. Jacobson defeated four candidates in the September primary election with 28% of the vote, and went on to defeat  nominee Scott Manley that November with 60% of the vote.\n\nBecause the seat was vacant following Skartados' death, Jacobson assumed office immediately, rather than waiting until January 2019 to be sworn in.\n\nJacobson was re-elected in 2020, receiving 61.74% of the vote against Republican challenger Andrew Gauzza IV. He ran unopposed in 2022.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Herman Carl McCall''' (born October 17, 1935) is an American politician of the . A former  and New York State Senator, McCall was the  candidate for  . McCall was the first  to be elected New York State Comptroller. He is an ordained minister in the , and is on the board of directors of several corporations. From October 17, 2011, until his retirement on June 30, 2019, McCall was chairman of the  Board of Trustees.\n\n\nMcCall was born in the  section of Boston, Massachusetts. He is the oldest of six children of Herman McCall and Caroleasa Ray. Herman McCall moved to Boston from Georgia and worked as a railroad porter; he abandoned the family when Carl was 11 years of age. Thereafter, the family was supported primarily by welfare and by relatives due to Carl's mother's infirmity. McCall graduated from  in Boston, where he was president of his class. He attended  on private and  scholarships, graduating in 1958 with a bachelor's degree in government. McCall was also educated at the  and received a Master of Divinity (M.Div.) Degree from .\n\n\nDuring the 1960s, McCall worked as a high school teacher and a bank manager. He taught for six months at  on  in Boston, and then joined the Army. He opened a church in the  neighborhood. By the late 1960s, McCall had moved to New York City. He was appointed by New York Mayor  to head the Commission Against Poverty.\n\n\nDuring the 1970s, McCall, as a member of the , backed by the Harlem political power of , was elected to three terms as a State Senator representing Harlem and the Upper West Side of Manhattan. He was a member of the  from 1975 to 1980, sitting in the ,  and s. He left the Senate to accept an appointment from President  as a member of the U.S. delegation to the United Nations with the rank of .\n\nIn 1982, McCall was an unsuccessful candidate for the Democratic nomination for . Governor  then appointed McCall to serve as the state's Commissioner of Human Rights (1983–84). While in the private sector as a vice president for governmental relations with  (1985–93), McCall accepted an appointment to the New York City Board of Education, where he was President of the Board from 1991 to 1993.\n\n\nIn 1993, McCall was selected by the  to fill the unexpired term of   as . As comptroller, McCall was responsible for serving as the state's chief fiscal officer, conducting audits of state and local entities, serving as the state's bookkeeper, investing the state's funds, overseeing the state's debt issuances, and serving as the sole trustee of the state pension fund.\n\nMcCall was elected to a full term as comptroller in  (defeating Conservative ) and was re-elected in  (defeating Republican ). In 1998, he announced that he would not seek election to the , helping to pave the way for the successful candidacy of .\n\n was quoted as saying that \"if  has a cold in the black community, Carl McCall has \", and it has been said that McCall was a \"stiff, bourgeois figure\" who generally did not excite the black electorate.\n\n\nIn 2002, McCall officially announced his campaign against  incumbent . After his primary opponent, former US Housing Secretary , withdrew from the race, McCall entered the general election as the uncontested Democratic candidate, but lost to Pataki. McCall remains New York state's highest-ranking black elected official and first black major party gubernatorial candidate.\n\nMcCall was the favorite of the Democratic establishment, but he faced a tough challenge from Cuomo which almost split the party. Cuomo proved to be a better fundraiser, and McCall's own campaign war chest was heavily depleted in the primary battle. Although McCall himself did not make any negative attacks, his close supporter, US Congressman , stated that the McCall camp would not necessarily endorse Cuomo in the general election should the latter win. This backfired as some Italian-Americans interpreted that as racism, and many of Cuomo's supporters refused to unite behind McCall after McCall won the nomination. McCall was endorsed by Senator . While Senator  did not officially take sides during the primary, she loaned a staffer and a fundraiser to McCall's campaign and she marched by McCall's side at the West Indian American Day parade in New York City, as the Clinton wanted to retain strong African-American support in case she made a president run in the future. Cuomo withdrew from the primary race after McCall moved to a double-digit lead in polls.\n\nMoney would prove to be a handicap in the general election, as  Chairman  stated that he would not channel large sums of money to McCall's campaign unless the gap could be closed with Pataki, which McCall never managed to do. In an unusual show of support, conservative radio host  urged his listeners to donate to McCall's campaign. Limbaugh said the refusal to give the McCall campaign money was a show of racism on the part of the DNC.\n\nCharles Rangel suggested that 's gubernatorial run in 2010 would undo years of work that Cuomo spent rebuilding his standing in the state Democratic Party after his bruising 2002 gubernatorial primary contest against Carl McCall. Rangel said \"it would be immoral for the white attorney general to challenge New York's first black governor in a primary\" with the \"inclination for racial polarization in a primary in the state of New York. Since we have most African-Americans registered as Democrats, and since you would be making an appeal for Democrats, it would be devastating in my opinion\". , the incumbent and first African-American governor of New York, whom Rangel staunchly supported, fared poorly in polls due to several scandals and later abandoned his campaign re-election.\n\n\nIn October 2002, McCall released 61 letters he had written on state letterhead to heads of companies in which the state pension fund owned large blocks of stock, asking them to review enclosed resumes of his relatives and other job-seekers.\n\nSome of the letters referred to the size of the state's ownership interest in the corporation targeted, which critics claimed amounted to a veiled threat to punish companies that didn't hire his relatives. A Quinnipiac poll released October 16 showed that two-thirds of likely voters were aware of the letters and of those more than a fifth were less likely to vote for McCall as a result.\n\nMcCall defended the letters. Although he did issue a statement regretting the \"appearance\" and \"impression\" of the letters he wrote on government stationery, he maintained that he \"never sought to leverage my public position nor mix my government role with my personal and professional relationship\" in the letters. McCall's daughter, Marci, was hired by Verizon, which received such a letter, but was subsequently fired for using her company credit card to pay for substantial personal expenditures. Charges of larceny against her were dropped after some reimbursement to Verizon, and she was then hired as a marketer by McCall's running mate, Dennis Mehiel.\n\n\nMcCall was defeated in the election for governor by the Republican incumbent, . McCall received 33% of the vote, a low percentage for a Democratic nominee for statewide office in a state where the Democratic Party is by far the dominant party based on voter registrations. Some observers felt that this seemingly poor showing was in part due to the revelation of the above-referenced letters; others insinuated that McCall's showing was related to racism, especially in upstate New York. However, others point out that Pataki was able to make crucial inroads into traditional areas of Democratic support, such as unions and even African-American congregations. The three-way vote-split efforts of , who primarily ran against Pataki on , also diverted much of the anti-Pataki vote away from McCall.\n\nOther political commentators attribute McCall's defeat to the growing popularity of the  after the  of September 11, 2001, along with Governor Pataki's successful administration of the state.\n\n\nMcCall was a recent member of the Board of the  (1999–2003), as well as the Apollo Theater Foundation, Inc. Currently, he is a member of the Fiscal Control Board for  as well as the SUNY Board of Trustees. He also is on the Boards of Directors for TYCO International, New Plan Realty, TAG Entertainment Corporation, Ariel Mutual Fund, and as Chair of the New York State Public Higher Education Conference Board. He spoke at his alma mater 's annual  celebration in 2006 about modern civil rights and the legacy of Dr. King. He operates his own financial services fund called Convent Capital, LLC.\n\nIn January 2007, McCall was appointed to a panel, along with former New York State Comptroller  and former New York City Comptroller , to interview and recommend up to five candidates to the State Legislature to replace , who resigned as state comptroller due to scandal.\n\nIn May 2009, Convent Capital, the financial services firm run by McCall, was subpoenaed, along with other unregistered placement agents, by state Attorney General Andrew Cuomo's office as part of an inquiry into possible corruption involved in deals brokered between investment firms and the state pension fund.\n\nMcCall joined the  Board of Trustees on October 22, 2007. He was appointed to the Board by Governor . McCall was appointed chairman on October 17, 2011, by Governor . He announced his retirement in April 2019, effective at the end of June. He was succeeded as chair by vice chair .\n\n\nMcCall's first marriageto Cecilia McCall, the mother of his daughter Marcella (Marci)--ended in divorce. In 1983, McCall married his second wife, ; Brown is a former psychology professor, was a Deputy Mayor of New York City under Mayor David Dinkins, and is president of SUNY's  in New York City. They have no children.\n\nMcCall is a member of the  fraternity.\n\n\nMcCall is the recipient of nine honorary degrees. In 2003, he was awarded the  Distinguished Public Service Award from the Rockefeller College of Public Affairs and Policy at the .\n\nOn February 14, 2020, the  administrative building was renamed to the H. Carl McCall SUNY Building in honor of McCall's \"long standing contributions to SUNY and New York State.\"\n\n\n\n\n\n* ''\".\"''Skyhorse Publishing. New York, New York, 2020\n*John C. Walker, ''The Harlem Fox:  and Tammany, 1920–1970'', New York: State University New York Press, 1989.\n*, ''A Mayor's Life: Governing New York's Gorgeous Mosaic'', New York, PublicAffairs Books, 2013.\n*\n\n\n*\n*\n* at The National Visionary Leadership Project\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''William Morris Perkins''' (April 18, 1949 – May 16, 2023) was an American politician from the state of New York. A , he served in the  from the  from 2017 to 2021. The district includes portions of  in . Perkins formerly represented the same seat from 1998 to 2005, and was a member of the  for the  from 2007 to 2017.\n\n\nPerkins was born and raised in , a neighborhood in . He attended  on a scholarship before receiving a scholarship to . He graduated from Brown in 1972.\n\n\n\nIn 1997, Perkins was first elected to the , winning the seat easily after losing the Democratic nomination for the Council three times previously. On the Council, Perkins served as Deputy Majority Leader, and championed the  laws that required New York City residences to be tested for hazardous conditions. He also ran for Manhattan Borough President in 2005, and lost the primary to .\n\n\nTerm-limited from the Council in 2005, Perkins opted to seek election to the  in 2006, where he won. Bill Perkins endorsed United States Senator Barack Obama over U.S. Senator Hillary Clinton during the 2008 Democratic Party presidential primaries.\n\nHe was re-elected five times and served for more ten years before resigning to retake his seat on the New York City Council. Perkins also ran briefly to succeed  in the  in 2016, but later dropped out.\n\nIn 2015 Perkins, was one of a number of Black activists who met with Venezuelan president, , in Harlem. He was quoted as saying, “We recognize that in the person of Nicolás Maduro, the president of Venezuela, we have an exceptional leader!”\n\nPerkins was one of the few New York lawmakers who endorsed  and not , in the .\n\n\n\n\nIn 2016, Councilmember , who had succeeded Perkins on the New York City Council, announced that she would forgo her last year on the Council to run for a vacant seat in the . After Dickens won the Assembly seat,   called a February 14, 2017, special election to fill her vacated seat on the City Council. Perkins announced that he would be a candidate and won the election with over 33% of the vote. He was sworn into office on March 1, 2017.\n\nPerkins won a full four-year term in the November 2017 general election.\n\nOn January 31, 2019, Perkins was transported to a hospital by authorities \"after neighbors called the police on him for acting erratically in his  home\". At the time, the '''' reported that Perkins was receiving treatment for  and that various constituents and colleagues had expressed concern about his health and his continued fitness to hold public office. In June 2021, '''' published a piece on Perkins entitled \"As Worries Persist Over Harlem Lawmaker's Health, Elected Leaders Stay Mum\".\n\nPerkins sought re-election to the City Council in 2021. The June 22, 2021, Democratic primary in Council District 9 was so close that a recount was held. On August 9, 2021, Perkins conceded the primary election to , a , and announced that he would retire at the end of the year.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nPerkins died in New York City on May 16, 2023, at the age of 74.\n\n\n* \n\n\n* ''\".\"'' New York, New York, 2020\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Michael Benedetto''' (born June 2, 1947) is a Member of the  representing the 82nd Assembly District, which covers the , , , , , and  sections of the . After a 35-year teaching career at the elementary and secondary school level, he was first elected to the State Assembly in 2004. He is a member of the .\n\n\nBenedetto was born in the Bronx in 1947. He holds a  in History/Education from  and a  in Social Studies/Education. In 1981, Benedetto co-founded the '''', a weekly newspaper, with John Collazzi.\n\n\n\n\nBenedetto first ran for office in 1976, losing to Republican Assemblyman . Two years later, Benedetto ran against Republican State Senator  and lost by 1,121 votes.\n\nIn 1980, Benedetto attempted to run again against Calandra. Bronx Democratic leaders, who maintained a non-aggression pact with Calandra, allowed him to run in the Democratic primary. Calandra defeated Benedetto to win the Democratic nomination, and in the general election as the candidate of both the Republican and Democratic parties, Calandra easily defeated Benedetto, who ran on the Liberal Party ticket.\n\n\nBenedetto was elected to the State Assembly in 2004.Assembly Member Directory  New York State Assembly |url=https://nyassembly.gov/mem/Michael-Benedetto/bio/ |access-date=2024-06-18 |website=nyassembly.gov}} Since 2019, he has served as chair of the Education Committee.  ranked him 8th on \"The most powerful education leaders in New York\" and 18th on \"The 2021 Bronx Power 100\" in 2021.\n\nMany of his legislative priorities relate to children and education. With the support of teachers' unions, he has opposed the expansion of charter schools in New York State.\n\nHe has introduced laws aimed at protecting young children from concussion-related developmental problems. Since 2013, he has worked to prohibit tackle football for children. The proposed law is named the  Youth Football Protection Act after the former  star who developed dementia. He has also sponsored a bill that would require youth baseball players to wear helmets with chin straps.\n\nBenedetto supports the repeal of the Hecht-Calandra Act, a state law which established the  as the only admissions criteria for the city's specialized high schools. He believes that the state should have less control over the city's educational policies.\n\nIn 2022, Benedetto negotiated with fellow legislators to pass bills extending  and reducing class sizes in New York City. The class size reduction bill was opposed by Mayor  as being too costly and by some parents who believed that it would disproportionately benefit schools in richer neighborhoods and reduce access to popular schools.\n\n\nSince 2010, Benedetto has faced several primary challenges, including two challenges from former  staffer Jonathan Soto.\n\nIn the 2024 Democratic primary, Soto critiqued Benedetto's role in the Education Committee, saying that there is a lack of accountability, while Benedetto said: \"We have allocated and sent more money to the schools of the state of New York more than any other time in the history of this state\". '''' reported that Benedetto received support from Solidarity PAC, a Pro-Israel group that \"resembles\" . Additionally, he received support from two pro-charter school groups, New Yorkers for a Balanced Albany and Moving New York Families Forward, that are supported by . Benedetto won the 2024 Democratic primary with 62% of the vote.\n\n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Shahana K. Hanif''' (born February 5, 1991) is an American politician who is a member of the  for the , which covers  and other neighborhoods in central .\n\n\nHanif was born and raised in , New York, to immigrant parents from . She graduated from  and went on to receive her  from .\n\nAt age 17, Hanif was diagnosed with , an incurable and potentially fatal autoimmune disease. Hanif has cited her experience with the chronic illness, which forced her to navigate the healthcare system for years despite having inadequate health insurance, as her first window into disability justice and community organizing.\n\n\nHanif began working for Councilman  in 2017, first as his liaison to the Bangladeshi community and eventually as his director of organizing and community engagement. During her time working for Lander, Hanif helped a Bangladeshi woman escape a forced marriage, which she cited as an important factor in her eventual decision to run for the  herself.\n\n\nIn late 2019, with her boss Lander facing term limits, Hanif announced her intention to run for the City Council's  in . The district, which had previously been represented by Mayor  and which was soon to promote Lander to the 's office, was described as a \"political launching pad\" by ''''.\n\nHanif faced six other candidates in the June 2021 Democratic primary, most notable among them activist Brandon West. Hanif and West both ran on similar left-wing policy platforms, but West received the support of the  and other socialist elected officials, while Hanif was backed by the  and other more traditional progressive organizations; Congresswoman , meanwhile, issued an unusual dual endorsement of both candidates.\n\nOn election night, Hanif held a 32-23% advantage over West. When absentee ballots and ranked-choice votes were counted two weeks later, Hanif emerged with a 57-43% lead, and declared victory on July 3. She faced minimal opposition in the November general election, and handily won the race, making her the first Muslim woman and the first  elected to the New York City Council and the first woman to represent the 39th district. The final tally showed that she had 89% of the vote.\n\nIn 2022, Hanif pushed to reduce the number of housing units that could be built on a rezoned block in Gowanus, Brooklyn. The original plan proposed to allow the construction of buildings that were 95 feet and nine stories, but after Hanif's intervention, the lot only allowed for 55 feet and five stories. The lower height limit was likely to reduce the number of affordable housing units in the buildings, in part because developers are required to include affordable units when they exceed a certain size.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
          }

    "pages": }\n\n'''William R. Nojay''' (born '''Nogaj'''; November 24, 1956 – September 9, 2016) was an American politician and member of the . He represented the 133rd Assembly District, which includes parts of  and  counties and all of .\n\n\nNojay was born and raised in , where his father worked at . His surname was originally \"Nogaj\", but he changed the spelling to match the pronunciation. He earned a  from  and graduated from  with degrees from their law school and business school.\n\n\nIn 1996, Nojay was appointed by Governor  as commissioner of the Rochester Genesee Regional Transportation Authority. He also served on the Executive Committee of the Genesee Transportation Council and as chairman of the Regional Trails Initiative Steering Committee for the Rochester region, and as chief operating officer of Detroit's transportation system under Mayor .\n\nNojay supported several international democratic movements, working in , , , and . He also worked extensively in  on behalf of the , a right-wing opposition party to the  regime. He was the director and secretary treasurer of the .\n\nAfter redistricting, Nojay challenged and defeated Steuben County Legislator Randy Weaver, winning a vacant seat in the newly created 133rd Assembly District. He also hosted a regionally syndicated  show, which predated his election to the state legislature. The program originated from .\n\nNojay supported 's , and he served as co-chair of its New York campaign committee. He had asked Trump to run for governor of New York in 2013.\n\n\nOn September 9, 2016, Nojay died from  near his family's plot at  in Rochester, New York. He was due in court that day to face  charges related to his legal work, which were subsequently .\n\nNojay was already running for re-election as assemblyman, and the following Tuesday, September 14, 2016, he posthumously defeated Richard Milne, his challenger in the primary election for the Republican nomination. As a result, a Republican party committee selected former Assemblyman  to replace Nojay in the general election, which Errigo won.\n\n\n*Committee on Cities\n*Committee on Consumer Affairs and Protection\n*Committee on Election Law\n*Committee on Tourism, Parks, Arts and Sports Development\n*Committee on Transportation\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Michael Gianaris''' (born April 23, 1970) is an  politician and attorney from . He represented District 36 in the New York State Assembly from 2001 to 2010, and he has represented District 12 in the New York State Senate since 2011. A Democrat, Gianaris was appointed as Deputy Majority Leader of the New York State Senate in 2019.\n\n\nGianaris was born in Astoria and is the son of  Nicholas and Magdalene Gianaris. He graduated from  (NYC) public schools P.S. 84, Junior High School 141 and . He received a  ''summa cum laude'' in economics and political science from  and earned a  degree from .\n\n\nGianaris has served as Associate Counsel to the Committee on Consumer Affairs and Protection, Governmental Operations, Veterans Affairs, and Agriculture and Markets of the Assembly, and also served as an aide to former   , an aide to former Governor 's Queens County Regional Representative, and as a member of Queens Community Planning Board 1 and Legal Counsel to the United Community Civic Association.\n\n\nIn 2000, Gianaris was elected to the  in District 36. He is a Democrat.\n\nIn September 2007, he was named one of '''''s \"40 under 40\".\n\n\nIn 2010, Senator  decided not to seek re-election, and Gianaris was nominated to replace him. Gianaris easily prevailed in the District 12 election.\n\nIn 2019, following Senate Democrats' ascent to the majority, Gianaris was named Deputy Majority Leader of the Senate.\n\nAccording to ''The Guardian'', Gianaris was principally responsible for scuttling a proposal to locate  in New York City. Gianaris has been noted for his support for antitrust enforcement, having introduced the \"21st Century Antitrust Act\" in the  and written in support of the federal  proposal.\n\n\nGianaris ran for  in 2018, but ended his campaign in May 2018 and endorsed fellow Democrat .\n\n\n\n\nIn May 2024, Gianaris and  secured $70 million for school safety equipment in religious and independent schools in the 2024-2025 state budget, they initially lobbied for $90 million but negotiated to $70 million. Gianaris cited this as their commitment to advocating for additional resources to schools amidst concerns about increases in anti semitic attacks from the .\n\n\nIn 2018, he introduced legislation to automatically register eligible voters otherwise interacting with state government.\n\nIn September 2023, governor  signed his senate bill to expand early mail-in voting for all New Yorkers. Republican groups, including republican congresswoman , attempted to challenge this expansion but a state appellate rejected it and affirmed the law.\n\n\nIn the 2023-2024 legislative session, Gianaris sponsored a bill to prohibit openly carrying a rifle or shotgun. Gianaris consponsored other bills such as S4818 which establishes a 10-day waiting period to buy a firearm.\n\n\nGianaris alongside  lobbied for $90 million in additional bus funding before congestion pricing took place to split half of it to fund more  and the other half for increasing bus reliability. In response to governor  reversal on her support and implementation of congestion pricing, Gianaris opposed a payroll tax that was floated to replace the funding not generated by congestion pricing. He stated their reaction of her reversal \"This whole thing was just dropped on us just yesterday and to expect us to have serious, substantive, deliberative discussion on such an important issue in 24 hours is unrealistic\" and that \"We put the burden on New York City to bail out the MTA just last year with this exact tax and I don’t think many of us who represent the city support doing it again\".\n\n\nGianaris has supported  and the elimination of cash bail. In response to the , Gianaris called for the repeal of Citizen's arrest law in New York as a local prosecutor initially declined to bring charges because they thought the killer of  was acting in accordance with Citizen's arrest law in .\n\n\nDuring COVID-19, Gianaris fought for $1 billion for a small business recovery grant program in the 2021-2022 state budget.\n\n\nGianaris is married and resides in Astoria.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n*\n\n\n*\n*\n*\n*\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''James Nicholas Tedisco''' (born July 15, 1950) is an American politician. Since 2023, he has been the  for .\n\nA Republican, Tedisco served in the  from 1983 to 2017. He was the Assembly  from November 2005 until his resignation from that post in April 2009. In 2009, Tedisco was the Republican nominee in a  to fill the seat vacated by  following Gillibrand's appointment to the ; he was defeated by Democrat .\n\n\nJim Tedisco graduated from  in 1968, and received his B.A. in Psychology from . While at Union, he played varsity basketball for three years where he set 15 scoring and assist records, and left as Union's all-time leading scorer with 1,632 points. Tedisco earned multiple athletic awards during his college career, and was inducted into the Union Athletics Hall of Fame in 2002. In 1997, he was given the  from the .\n\nTedisco got a graduate degree in Special Education from the . From 1973 to 1982, Tedisco worked in education; he served as a guidance counselor, basketball coach, and athletic director at  in Schenectady, and later worked as a special education teacher, resource room instructor and varsity basketball coach at  in .\n\nTedisco entered public service in 1977 when, at the age of 27, he was elected to the  City Council.\n\nTedisco is a resident of , where he lives with his wife and stepson.\n\n\n\nIn 1982, Assemblyman Clark Wemple retired from the State Assembly, leaving an opening in the district. Tedisco won a four-way race in Republican primary, and then won the general election.\n\nDue to redistricting, Tedisco represented the 107th District from 1983 to 1993, the 103rd District from 1993 to 2003, the 110th District from 2003 to 2012, and most recently represented the 112th District since from 2012 to 2017. The 112th District consists of portions of  and , including the towns of Greenfield, Providence, Milton, Galway, Ballston, Charlton, Clifton Park, Halfmoon, and Glenville.\n\nTedisco ran uncontested in the 2008 general election and won the 2010 general election with 64 percent of the vote.\n\n\nTedisco introduced \"Charlotte's Law\" to permanently terminate driver's license privileges for drunk and dangerous drivers. While Tedisco's bill was not passed, the  similar to what was proposed in the bill.\n\nIn 1999, Tedisco worked to pass Buster's Law, which protected pets by making animal cruelty a felony, and in 2011 advocated for New York State Animal Advocacy Day.\n\nIn 2014, Tedisco sponsored a successful constitutional amendment, Proposition 2, that would replace bill printouts with digital copies of bills.\n\n\nTedisco served as Assembly Minority Leader from November 2005 to April 2009.\n\nAccording to '''', Tedisco \"clashed loudly and publicly\" with Democratic Governor . In January 2007, Spitzer reportedly told Tedisco, \"'I am a fucking steamroller and I’ll roll over you or anybody else'\".\n\nTedisco was noted for his opposition to Spitzer's September 2007 executive order directing that state offices allow undocumented immigrants to be issued . Tedisco threatened a lawsuit if the plan was implemented. On November 14, 2007, Spitzer announced he would withdraw the driver license plan, acknowledging that it would never be implemented.\n\n\nTedisco later accused Spitzer of cutting $300,000 of state funding for health care and education grants in the  area as retaliation for Tedisco's opposition to the Spitzer driver license plan. Tedisco accused the Governor of \"dirty tricks\" and \"bullying\".\n\nFollowing reports of Spitzer's involvement in a prostitution scandal, Tedisco called for his resignation and announced that he would initiate  proceedings in the  if Spitzer did not resign. Spitzer resigned his post effective March 17, 2008.\n\nTedisco stepped down as Minority Leader in April 2009 amid reports that other Republican Members of the Assembly were concerned about his congressional campaign distracting him from his leadership role.\n\n\n\nOn January 23, 2009, after Governor  announced that he had selected Representative  to fill the United States Senate seat vacated by , Tedisco stated his intention to run for Congress to replace Gillibrand in New York's 20th Congressional District. Though not a resident of the district, Tedisco became its Republican nominee on January 27, 2009, and ran against Democrat . The initial count from the election had Murphy leading by 59 votes, out of over 155,000 cast on March 31, 2009. This tally reportedly did not include any of the 10,000 requested absentee ballots, which needed only to have been postmarked by that date and could have been returned as late as April 7 (domestically) or April 13 (internationally). Eventually, about 7,000 absentee ballots were received; the vote count as of April 24 had Murphy ahead by 399 votes. On April 24, Tedisco conceded the election to Murphy.\n\n\n\nIn 2016, Senator  announced that he would not seek re-election to the Senate. Farley's retirement left an opening in the 49th State Senate District. After Tedisco handily won the Republican primary, he went on to defeat General Election opponent Chad Putman. Tedisco won the election with 69% of the vote on November 8, 2016.\n\nTedisco won reelection in 2018 and 2020.\n\n\n\nTedisco opposes abortion and only supports it in cases of rape, incest, or if a woman's life (not health) is in danger. In 2018, the  endorsed Tedisco for re-election to the State Senate. The Times Union stated that Tedisco had informed the paper's editorial board that he would support a proposed abortion rights bill known as the Reproductive Health Act. After Tedisco publicly contradicted this assertion and affirmed his opposition to the bill, the Times Union rescinded its endorsement. Tedisco voted against the Reproductive Health Act in January 2019.\n\n\nTedisco holds a broad interpretation of the Second Amendment. He voted against the NY SAFE Act, a gun control measure that became law in 2013. He voted against a bill that prohibits individuals convicted of domestic abuse from purchasing guns. He also believes that a safety or childproof mechanism does not need to be incorporated into the design of firearms.\n\n\nTedisco voted against paid family leave (February 2, 2016), equal pay regardless of gender (January 27, 2014), freelance wage protection (June 20, 2011), and the Wage Theft Prevention Act (July 1, 2010). He also repeatedly voted against an increase in the minimum wage (May 4, 2015; March 5, 2013).\n\n\nTedisco repeatedly voted against bills to legalize same-sex marriage. He also voted against bills to prohibit discrimination based on gender identity. On June 16, 2014, Tedisco voted against a bill that would have prohibited sexual orientation  on minors.\n\n\nTedisco opposes legalizing recreational marijuana.\n\n\n\n\n\n* ''New York State Senate Official Member Website''\n* ''Jim Tedisco's campaign site''\n* ''Jim Tedisco's Blog''\n\n\n\n \n \n\n \n \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n \n \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
