    "pages": }\n| honorific_prefix    = \n| module              = \n}}\n\n'''Kathleen Hochul''' ( ; née '''Courtney'''; born August 27, 1958) is an American politician and lawyer who has served since August 2021 as the 57th . A member of the , she is New York's  governor and the first governor from  since  in 1922.\n\nBorn in , Hochul graduated from  in 1980 and received a  from the   in  in 1984. After serving on the   board and as deputy  clerk, Hochul was appointed Erie County clerk in 2007. She was elected to a full term as Erie County clerk in 2007 and reelected in 2010. In May 2011, Hochul won a four-candidate  for New York's 26th congressional district to fill the vacancy created by the resignation of then-Representative , becoming the first  to represent the district in 40 years. She served as a  from 2011 to 2013. Hochul was defeated for reelection in  by  after the district's boundaries and demographics were changed in the . Hochul later worked as a government relations executive for the Buffalo-based .\n\nIn the ,  selected Hochul as his running mate; after they won the election, Hochul was inaugurated as lieutenant governor. Cuomo and Hochul were reelected in . Hochul took office as governor of New York on August 24, 2021, after Cuomo resigned amid . She won a full term in  against Republican U.S. Representative  in the narrowest New York gubernatorial election since .\n\nAs governor, Hochul entered into an agreement with the  to fund their new stadium with at least $850 million of taxpayer money. In June 2024, just weeks before it was to go into effect, she abruptly halted a  that had been in the works since 2019, already cost hundreds of millions of dollars, and was expected to become the 's largest funding source.\n\n\nHochul was born Kathleen Courtney in , the second of the six children of John P. \"Jack\" Courtney, then a college student and clerical worker, and Patricia Ann \"Pat\" (Rochford) Courtney, a . The family struggled financially during Hochul's early years and for a time lived in a trailer near a steel plant. By the time Hochul was in college, however, her father was working for the  company he later headed. Her family is .\n\nHochul became politically active during her college years at , leading a boycott of the student bookstore over high prices and an unsuccessful effort to name the university stadium after alumnus , a star running back who died of cancer before he could join the . Hochul successfully lobbied the university to . In the spring of 1979, the student newspaper '''' awarded her an \"A\", citing the campus changes as evidence for the grade. She received a  with a major in  from the  of Syracuse University in 1980 and a  from the   in , in 1984.\n\n\nAfter graduation from law school, Hochul began working for a Washington, D.C., law firm, but she found the work unsatisfying. She then worked as legal counsel and legislative assistant to U.S. Representative  and U.S. Senator , and also for the , before seeking elected office.\n\nHochul became involved in local issues as a supporter of small businesses facing competition from  stores and, in the process, caught the attention of local Democratic leaders. On January 3, 1994, the  voted to appoint her to the vacant seat on the board caused by Patrick H. Hoak's resignation to become town supervisor. She was elected to a full term in November 1994, on the Democratic and  lines, and was reelected in 1998, 2002, and 2006. She resigned on April 10, 2007, and was succeeded by former state assemblymember Richard A. Smith. While on the board, she led efforts to remove s on parts of the  system.\n\nIn May 2003,  Clerk  appointed Hochul as his deputy. Governor  named Swarts to his administration in January 2007 and appointed Hochul to succeed Swarts as county clerk in April 2007. In an intervention that raised her statewide profile, she opposed Spitzer's proposal to allow undocumented immigrants to apply for a driver's license without producing a social security card, and said that if the proposal went into effect she would seek to have any such applicants arrested. She was elected later in 2007 to fill the remainder of Swarts's term. She ran for reelection on four : , ,  and , defeating Republican Clifton Bergfeld in November 2010 with 80 percent of the vote.\n\nFollowing Hochul's departure as county clerk, a backlog of mail was discovered by newly elected County Clerk Chris Jacobs, who later said that $792,571 in checks were found in the backlogged mail.Gee, Denise Jewell (May 4, 2012). \"\". ''''. buffalonews.com. Retrieved September 10, 2018. As county clerk, Hochul had been in the process of implementing a new system for handling real estate documents when she left after being elected to Congress. Jacobs said that $9,000 were spent in overtime to deposit checks and file unopened documents that had accumulated in the interim period after Hochul's departure, while the office was adjusting to the new system.\n\n\n\n\n\n, following her 2011 election to represent New York's 26th district]]\nHochul ran in the May 24, 2011,  to fill the seat in  left vacant by the resignation of . She was the  and  nominee. Hochul's residence in , just outside the 26th district, became an issue during her campaign, though it did not disqualify her from seeking the seat. One month after her victory, she moved into the district.\n\nThe  and  nominee,  , was at first strongly favored to win in the  district, which had sent a Republican to Congress for the previous four decades. A late April poll had Corwin leading Hochul by 36% to 31%;  candidate  trailed at 23%. An early May poll gave Hochul a lead of 35% to 31%, and shortly thereafter the nonpartisan '''' called the race a toss-up. Additional polling in the days immediately before the election had Hochul leading by four- and six-point margins.\n\nA '''' article noted that in the face of a possible Hochul victory, there was already a \"full blown spin war\" about the meaning of the result. The article said that Democrats viewed the close race as a result of Republicans' budget proposal '''', and, in particular, their proposal for  reform. Republicans viewed it as the result of Davis's third-party candidacy.\n\nThe campaign featured a number of negative television ads, with  accusing both sides of \"taking liberties with the facts\". In particular, FactCheck criticized the Democrats' ads for claiming that Corwin would \"essentially end Medicare\", even though the plan left Medicare intact for current beneficiaries. The organization also faulted the Republicans for ads portraying Hochul as a puppet of former  , and for claiming that Hochul planned to cut  and  benefits.\n\nHochul was endorsed by , a  that supports Democratic women candidates who support . She was the fifth largest recipient of EMILY's List funds in 2011, receiving more than $27,000 in bundled donations. The  endorsed Hochul \"for her tenacity and independence\", while '''' endorsed her for her positions on preserving Medicare and her record of streamlining government.\n\nHochul defeated Corwin 47% to 42%, with Davis receiving 9% and  candidate  1%.\n\n\n\nBefore the 2012 election, Hochul's district was renumbered the 27th during the redistricting process. The district was redrawn in a manner that caused it to be more heavily Republican. Hochul was endorsed by the . She lost to Republican , 51% to 49%.\n\n\n, 2011]]\n\nIn Hochul's first few weeks in office, she co-sponsored bills with  to streamline the passport acquisition process. She also met with   about the economy and job creation and introduced a motion to restore the Republican cuts to the . She looked for ways to reduce the federal budget deficit and expressed support for reducing  spending as long as the reductions would not be achieved in the form of s offered to states, as proposed in the Republican budget blueprint. She also spoke with Obama about ending tax breaks for oil companies and protecting small businesses.\n\nWhile campaigning for Congress, Hochul called herself an \" \". In an interview with the '''', she cited as examples of her independence her opposition to then-Governor 's driver's license program for undocumented immigrants and her opposition to then-Governor 's 2010 proposal to raise revenue by requiring all vehicle owners to buy new license plates.\n\nHochul was one of 17 Democrats to join Republicans in supporting a resolution finding   in contempt of Congress relating to the , a vote on which the NRA, which supported the resolution, announced it would be scoring lawmakers. Later in 2012, Hochul \"trumpeted\" her endorsement by the NRA and noted that she was just one of two   to receive its support.\n\n\n* \n* \n** \n** \n\n\n\n\n\n at the 2014 Labor Day parade in ]]\nAfter her departure from Congress, Hochul worked as a government relations executive for the Buffalo-based .\n\nIn 2014,  announced that he would not run  as lieutenant governor. Incumbent Governor Cuomo was running for a second term. After Duffy's announcement, Cuomo named Hochul as his choice for lieutenant governor. On May 22, 2014, the delegates to the state Democratic convention formally endorsed Hochul for lieutenant governor.\n\nIn September, Cuomo and Hochul won their Democratic primary elections, with Hochul defeating Timothy Wu. They were also the Working Families Party nominees. (In New York, candidates for governor and lieutenant governor are nominated separately, but run as a ticket in the general election.) In November, the Cuomo/Hochul ticket won the general election. Hochul was sworn in as lieutenant governor on January 1, 2015.\n\n\n\n\nIn the 2018 Democratic primary for lieutenant governor of New York, Hochul defeated , a member of the , 53.3%–46.7%. In the November 6 general election, the Cuomo-Hochul ticket defeated the Republican ticket of  and Julie Killian, 59.6%–36.2%.\n\n\nCuomo tasked Hochul with chairing the 10 regional economic development councils that are the centerpiece of the administration's economic development plan. The councils' goal is to build upon the strengths of each region to develop individualized long-term strategic plans.\n\nCuomo appointed Hochul to chair the Task Force on Heroin and Opioid Abuse and Addiction. In this capacity, she convened eight outreach sessions across New York State to hear from experts and community members in search of answers to the heroin crisis and works to develop a comprehensive strategy for New York.\n\nHochul spearheaded Cuomo's \"Enough is Enough\" campaign to combat sexual assault on college campuses beginning in 2015, hosting and attending more than 25 events. In March 2016, Cuomo named her to the New York State Women's Suffrage 100th Anniversary Commemoration Commission.\n\nIn 2018, Hochul supported legislation to provide driver's licenses to undocumented immigrants, which she had opposed as Erie County Clerk in 2007. While Hochul had said in 2007 that she would seek to have any such applicants arrested if the proposal was implemented, in 2018 she said circumstances had changed.\n\nOn May 30, 2018, State Senate Democrats hoped to force a vote on an abortion rights bill known as the . Hochul was prepared to cast a tie-breaking vote on a hostile amendment; with one Republican senator away from Albany on military duty, the Senate Republican Conference and the Senate Democratic conference each had 31 members in the chamber. But Senate Republicans \"abruptly shut down business and pulled all the bills for the day\" when Hochul entered the Senate chamber. She called the GOP's actions \"reprehensible\" and \"cowardly\", adding, \"The governor and I are offended by the actions taken here today in the Senate.\"\n\nHochul presided over the Senate chamber on June 5, 2018, when Senate Republicans called for the override of Cuomo's veto of a bill relating to full-day kindergarten classes. The override passed by a large margin, and was the first veto override to occur during Cuomo's gubernatorial tenure.\n\nAt a July 2018 rally with Planned Parenthood, Hochul called upon the Republican-led State Senate to reconvene in Albany to pass the Reproductive Health Act. She asserted that the potential confirmation of then-Supreme Court nominee  made this necessary. The Act was reintroduced in January 2019 and passed the same month with wide margins in the state House and Senate.\n\n\n on August 24, 2021]]\nIn a press briefing on August 10, 2021, Andrew Cuomo announced his resignation as , effective August 24. Cuomo was accused of multiple instances of . Hochul said that New York attorney general 's report on Cuomo documented \"repulsive and unlawful behavior\" and praised his decision to resign. Of her time as lieutenant governor and relationship with Cuomo, Hochul has said: \"I think it's very clear that the governor and I have not been close.\"\n\nHochul was sworn in as governor at 12:00 AM  on August 24 by   in a private ceremony. A public ceremonial event was held later that morning at the  Red Room. Hochul is the state's first female governor. She is also the first New York governor from outside  and its  since 1932 (when  left office). Hochul also became the first governor from north of  since  in 1922, in addition to being the first governor from  since  in 1910 and the first governor from Buffalo since  in 1885. On August 12, Hochul confirmed that she planned to run for a full term as governor in . She was the first Democrat to announce a 2022 gubernatorial candidacy after Cuomo said he would resign.\n \nIn August 2021, '''' and '''' reported on a potential  between Hochul's role as governor and the high-level executive position held by her husband, , at , a Buffalo-based casino and hospitality company. Delaware North has stated that William Hochul will be prohibited from working on any matter that involves state business, oversight, or regulation. A spokesman for Kathy Hochul has said that she had a  process as lieutenant governor and would maintain that process as governor.\n\nOn August 26, 2021, Hochul appointed State Senator  to the position of . Benjamin was sworn in on September 9, 2021.\n\n in October 2021]]\nIn November 2021, Hochul pushed to end remote work during the  and to return workers to offices. That same month, Hochul offered her plans to redevelop Manhattan's  and the surrounding neighborhood. In her plans, she called for reducing density in the area.\n\nIn December 2021, Hochul announced the reinstatement of an indoor  amid the spread of the .\n\nIn January 2022, she expanded an existing vaccine mandate for healthcare workers to include a  requirement. Also in January 2022, Hochul confirmed that New York's eviction  would expire on January 15. She announced that she would sign on to a letter with other governors to the federal government asking for more rent assistance, after New York received only $27.2 million of its nearly $1 billion request. Tenant advocates and other politicians have pushed her and state lawmakers to pass the Good Cause eviction bill, which would give tenants the right to a lease renewal in most cases, , and require landlords to obtain a judge's order to evict tenants.\n\nIn March 2022, Hochul reached an agreement with the  to have taxpayers pay $850 million for the construction of a , as well as commit to maintain and repair the stadium. It was set to be the largest taxpayer contribution ever for a  facility. The agreement was released four days before the state budget was due to be passed, making it hard for lawmakers to scrutinize it. Critics of the agreement characterized it as . Part of the funding for the stadium came from a payment from the , whose bank accounts had been recently frozen as part of a long-running dispute between the Seneca Nation and the State of New York over the Seneca Nation's refusal to pay certain fees related to casino gaming despite being ordered to do so by multiple judicial bodies.\n and New York City Mayor  in February 2022]]\nOn April 12, 2022, Brian Benjamin resigned as lieutenant governor after having been indicted earlier that day on federal charges of ,  to commit wire fraud, , and falsification of records. The crimes of which Benjamin is accused were allegedly committed during his State Senate tenure. He has pleaded not guilty to all charges.\n\nOn May 3, 2022, Hochul selected U.S. Representative  to serve as  of New York. Delgado was sworn in on May 25.\n\nOn June 22, 2022, Hochul announced a $300 million plan to rebuild infrastructure in western New York communities with public and private funding.\n\nIn 2022, a citizens' group called Uniting NYS and a group of state legislators sued Hochul in the  in ''George M. Borrello et al. v. Kathleen C. Hochul et al.'' to prevent implementation of a recently created state department of health policy enabling health practitioners to refer even asymptomatic patients suspected of having been exposed to a contagious illness for possible involuntary detention backed by law enforcement, with the option of holding detainees incommunicado. The policy had been created without consulting the state legislature and did not require an emergency to be implemented. New York Supreme Court Justice Ronald Ploetz ruled against Hochul on the grounds of unconstitutionality under the  doctrine of both the state and federal constitutions, as well as on the grounds that the policy was cruel and lacked . The New York state attorney general and Hochul are filing an appeal to retain the regulations, and the appeal is being challenged.\n\nIn late 2022, Hochul delayed the signing of the Digital Fair Repair Act, a bill that received rare bipartisan support. The delay was allegedly due to major equipment manufacturers' lobbying efforts. On December 28, 2022, Hochul signed the Digital Fair Repair Act (Senate bill 4104-A) into law, but not before adding an amendment that equipment manufacturers \"may provide assemblies of parts rather than individual components\". Independent repair analysts such as  have claimed these amendments undermine the bill's purpose, and allege codification into law of \"unethical practices\".\n\n\n\nOn February 17, 2022, the New York State Democratic Convention endorsed Hochul for governor. As of that month, she had raised $21 million in campaign funds. Hochul won a full term in office, defeating  nominee  in the closest New York gubernatorial election since  and the closest Democratic victory since . Hochul's election marked the first time a woman was elected governor of New York.\n\n\nHochul was inaugurated to her first full term as governor on January 1, 2023. One of her first actions was to nominate  for the vacant position of chief judge of the . LaSalle's nomination drew opposition from a wide variety of Democratic groups and constituencies, including numerous unions and trade groups, criminal justice advocates, elected officeholders, and local party affiliates, who raised concerns about his track record on issues relating to abortion, criminal justice, corporate interests, and the environment. Many also suggested that he would do little to stem, or could even accelerate, the Court of Appeals's rightward drift under the previous chief judge, . Despite an extensive lobbying campaign by Hochul's allies, including support from  , the Senate Judiciary Committee rejected LaSalle's nomination by a 10–9 vote. Hochul subsequently sued to demand a full floor vote. Democratic leadership then held a full Senate floor vote, which overwhelmingly rejected LaSalle's nomination. Hochul proceeded to nominate associate judge  as chief judge and  as the replacement associate judge for Wilson. The  confirmed the nominations on April 19, 2023.\n\nHochul has employed consulting firms  and  in preparing her State of the State address, an arrangement the ''New York Times'' in April 2023 called \"unusual, and possibly novel\".\n\nIn December 2023, Hochul vetoed legislation to ban . Business interests lobbied her to veto it while labor supported it, arguing that non-compete agreements harm workers' interests.\n\nIn February 2024, during the , Hochul was keynote speaker at a -Federation of New York event. During her speech, she made remarks implying that  had a right to destroy  in response to the October 7, 2023, : \"If  someday ever attacked Buffalo, I'm sorry, my friends, there would be no Canada the next day.\" February 16, 2024, '','' February 16, 2024 February 17, 2024, , retrieved February 19m 2024 Following angry responses from a wide range of partiesincluding public officials and the Buffalo chapter of Hochul apologized for her \"inappropriate analogy\".\n\nIn March 2024, Hochul instituted a policy in coordination with  to deploy 750 National Guard soldiers to the NYC subway system and empower them to conduct random bag checks on subway-goers. She also put forth legislation to allow judges to ban criminals from riding the subway.\n\nIn May 2024, Hochul was criticized for saying at a business conference that minority children growing up in the  \"don't even know what the word 'computer' is.\" She later apologized, saying she misspoke and regretted her remark.\n\nIn June 2024, Hochul indefinitely halted implementation of a  plan in the most congested parts of Manhattan just weeks before it was to go into effect. The plan was approved in 2019 and was expected to bring in $1 billion in revenue per year, making it the MTA's largest source of funding. At the time of the cancellation, the MTA had already purchased $500 million for equipment needed for congestion pricing and earmarked $15 billion for projects it expected to fund with the revenue. Hochul proposed raising the city's  for business owners to cover the lost revenue from the cancellation of the congestion pricing, which New York lawmakers declined to consider. Her decision received widespread backlash, especially among state lawmakers, business leaders, and climate activists.\n\nHochul defended her sudden decision to block the congestion pricing plan based in part on conversations with New Yorkers, particularly from a Manhattan diner, and claimed that the plan would \"suck the vitality out of this city when we’re still fighting for our comeback\". Lawmakers said her plan to raise payroll taxes to cover the lost revenue ran contrary to her reason for halting the program, and that the sudden tax hike would incapacitate the city's post-COVID-19 economic recovery. Democratic Senate Deputy Leader  condemned how the agreed-upon program was derailed \"at the last possible moment\" before giving lawmakers less than 48 hours to create an alternative funding plan, calling it \"irresponsible\" and \"inconsistent with principles of good governance\". Senator  called it \"incomprehensible\" that Hochul could claim to care about cost of living while proposing a tax hike.\n\nIn June 2024, Hochul proposed banning face masks on the  in response to groups of protesters she said were conducting antisemitic acts and confronting people while covering their faces. Organizations such as the  criticized the proposal as a means to target protesters who hide their identities to avoid legal or professional repercussions, saying it would be selectively used to \"arrest, doxx, surveil, and silence people of color and protesters the police disagree with\".\n\nIn July 2024, Hochul said that she intends to run for reelection as governor in 2026.\n\n\n\nOn September 17, 2011,  noted that Hochul and her election opponent  agreed on their opposition to . \"We saw what happened with NAFTA; the promises never materialized,\" she said of the . \"If I have to stand up to my own party on this, I'm willing to do so.\"\n\n\nDuring her congressional campaign, Hochul favored offering incentives to develop .\n\nIn June 2011, Hochul opposed legislation that would cut funding for the  by 44%, on the grounds that the CFTC curbs speculation in oil and the resulting layoffs of CFTC personnel would \"make it easier for Big Oil companies and speculators to take advantage of ... consumers\".\n\n\nWhile running for Congress, Hochul supported raising taxes on those making more than $500,000 per year. She opposed new free trade agreements then under consideration, saying, \"We don't need to look any further than Western New York to see that these policies do not work.\" She believes that free trade agreements such as  and  have suppressed U.S. wages and benefits and caused job loss in the U.S.\n\nHochul acknowledged during her campaign that substantial cuts must be made in the federal budget, and said she would consider cuts in all entitlement programs. But she expressed opposition to the Republican plan that would turn  into a voucher system, saying it \"would end Medicare as we know it\". She said money could be saved in the Medicare program by eliminating waste and purchasing prescription drugs in bulk, and that the creation of more jobs would alleviate Medicare and  budget shortfalls due to increased collections of payroll taxes.\n\nOn November 19, 2011, Brian Tumulty of  reported that Hochul had voted for a , which she called \"a bipartisan solution\".\n\nIn July 2023, in response to a statewide workforce shortage, Hochul waived exam application fees for all New York State civil service exams through the end of 2025 to make it easier to join the state workforce.\n\n\nHochul expressed support for the  passed by the  and said during her campaign that she would not vote to repeal it. In response to a constituent's question during a  in February 2012, she was booed for saying that the federal government was \"not looking to the Constitution\" under the Obama administration requirement that employers provide their workers with insurance coverage for birth control. A spokesman later said she had misspoken, but did not clarify her answer.\n\nHochul has said she is pro-choice and called the overturning of '''' a \"grave injustice\".\n\n\nIn 2023, Hochul advocated that the federal government expedite work permits to migrants to address a surge of immigration to New York, writing to President , \"For me, the answer to these two crisesa humanitarian crisis and our workforce crisisis so crystal clear and common sense. Let them get the work authorizations; let them work; legally, let them work.\"\n\n\n and Vice President  in September 2023]]\nHochul is married to , the former , who is also the senior vice president, general counsel, and secretary to , a hospitality and gambling company. They have two children. Hochul is Catholic.\n\nHochul is a founder of Kathleen Mary House, a transitional home for women and children who are victims of domestic violence. She has served on the organization's board. She also co-founded the Village Action Coalition, and, as of 2011, was a member of the board of trustees of  in .\n\nIn 2024, Hochul was diagnosed with , a common form of skin cancer.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n}}\n}}\n\n\n\n}}\n\n| party = New York State Democratic Committee\n| votes = 2,879,092\n| percentage = 48.77%\n| change = -7.39%\n}}\n\n| party = Working Families Party\n| votes = 261,323\n| percentage = 4.33%\n| change = +2.45%\n}}\n'''\n| party = '''Total'''\n| votes = '''3,140,415'''\n| percentage = '''53.20%'''\n| change = '''-6.42%'''\n}}\n\n| party = New York Republican State Committee\n| votes = 2,449,394\n| percentage = 41.49%\n| change = +9.89%\n}}\n\n| party = Conservative Party of New York State\n| votes = 313,187\n| percentage = 5.31%\n| change = +1.15%\n}}\n\n| party = Total\n| votes = 2,762,581\n| percentage = 46.80%\n| change = +10.59%\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* \n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n*  official government website\n*  campaign website\n*  U.S. House website (archived)\n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n|-\n\n|as=}}\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Crystal R. Hudson''' (born April 14, 1983) is an  politician from . A , she represents the  of the , which covers parts of central .\n\n\nBorn and raised in , , Hudson graduated from  with a degree in economics and later received a Master's degree in  from .\n\n\nHudson began her career working for the , a  team based in  In 2011, she joined  as a marketing executive.\n\nAfter moving back to  to care for her mother, Carole Kay, Hudson switched to public policy work, joining   and later working for Councilwoman  as her chief of operations. Hudson was chosen in 2019 to be a Deputy Public Advocate under  , a position she held until the beginning of her campaign for .\n\n\nIn 2020, Hudson announced  to succeed the term-limited Cumbo in the City Council's . She was quickly regarded as a frontrunner in the race, raising the most money of any candidate in the field and receiving influential endorsements from Congressmembers  and , neighboring Councilman , and most of the city's major unions.\n\nHudson's main competition came from tenant organizer Michael Hollingsworth, who was backed by the New York City  and politicians from the city's leftmost flank. The race was characterized by '''' as \"split[ting] the city's left,\" as Hudson similarly claimed \"progressive\" policy positions and endorsements, but was put on the defensive about her establishment ties and work for the controversial Cumbo. Hudson worked to distance herself from Cumbo during the campaign, writing an  for  calling one of Cumbo's key policy achievements a \"disgrace.\"\n\nOn election night on June 22, Hudson led Hollingsworth 38–34% in first-place votes, with minor candidates taking the remainder; when s and ranked-choice votes were counted, Hudson expanded her lead to 54–46%. She declared victory, and Hollingsworth conceded defeat, on July 6. Hudson faced minimal opposition in the November general election, and won.\n\n\nIn February 2024, Hudson led an effort to block the construction of a 150-unit apartment building in her district. She has said that she will not support new rental housing unless somewhere between 20-80% of the units are set aside for income-restricted housing.\n\n\nHudson is openly , and lives in  with her partner,  . Hudson served as the primary caregiver for her mother, who suffered from , until she died in April 2021.\n\n\n* \n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Jamie Romeo''' is an American politician from the state of . A , Romeo has served as  since 2020. She previously represented the 136th district in the , covering parts of  and its inner suburbs, from 2019 until 2020.\n\n\nWhile still obtaining her  at , Romeo began her political career working for the Democratic legislative office in . Afterwards, she held positions as chief of staff for   and executive director of the Monroe County Democratic Committee.\n\n\nIn 2018, after the death of U.S. Congresswoman , Assemblymen  announced a run for her  opening up the  seat in the 136th district that he occupied for the first time since 1990. Romeo ran for the seat, defeating two other candidates in the primary election and facing no opposition in the . She took office on January 9, 2019.\n\nAfter Monroe County Clerk Adam Bello was elected Monroe County Executive in , Romeo announced her candidacy for his former office. On February 6, 2020,   appointed her to the position in advance of the 2020 election.\n\n\nRomeo was born and raised in , where she continues to live with her son, Dominic.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Michael Joseph Spano''' (born April 22, 1964) is an American politician who is the 42nd  of . He is a member of the . A former , he served as a member of the .\n\n\nBorn and raised in , Spano is the ninth of sixteen children born to Josephine and Leonard Spano (1930–2019). Spano was first elected to the  in 1992 as the assembly's youngest member. Due to the state's reapportionment plan, his seat was eliminated later that same year. However, he ran again in 1994 and continued to serve in the  for nearly a decade until he chose not to run for re-election.\n\nWithin the , Spano worked for a New York governmental relations firm and served on the Board of Directors for . After his children became school-aged, he decided to return to public service and ran successfully once again for the State Assembly where he represented the people of Yonkers in the 93rd Assembly District.\n\nOn November 8, 2011, Spano was elected as mayor of the City of . During his tenure, Spano has passed two consecutive bipartisan budgets that included historic investment in education and kept taxes within the New York State property tax cap.\n\nHe was reelected to a second term as mayor in 2015.\n\nIn 2019, Spano was reelected to a third term as mayor following a revision in the city charter which overturned term limits by the . Spano had previously said he would not seek a third term, stating, \"even if they did overturn term limits, as much as I love being mayor, I wouldn’t seek a third term.\"\n\nIn 2022, the Yonkers City Council voted to extend term limits for the second time for Mayor Spano. Citizens of Yonkers challenged the extension in New York State court, but the change in local law was upheld.\n\nIn May 2023, the Westchester County District Attorney's Office received a letter calling for an ethics investigation into alleged \"nepotism, abuse of taxpayer dollars, corruption and abuse of power\" under Spano's administration. The letter was prompted by media reports regarding Spano family members employed by the City of Yonkers. As of April 27, 2023, it was reported that at least 15 members of the Spano family were employed by the City of Yonkers, with the family collectively earning \"at least $2 million annually\" from the City.  Spano has denied the allegations.\n\nSpano is also a member of numerous community organizations such as the Yonkers Chamber of Commerce, Access Westchester, Exchange Club of Yonkers, Sons of Italy, and an Honorary Member (non-veteran) of the Armando Rauso AMVETS Post. He is also a former member of the board of directors of Westchester School for Special Children and donor to the Luis Pani foundation.\n\nSpano appeared on the TV show '''' during Murr's punishment that took place at Yonkers City Hall in the episode \"Speech Impediment\".\n\nA lifelong Yonkers resident, Spano has been married to  newscaster  since 1996 and has three children.\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* http://www.yonkersny.gov/\n*https://www.facebook.com/MayorMikeSpano/\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
          }
        ]

    "pages": }\n'''Jabari Brisport''' (born August 9, 1987) is an American politician, activist, and former public school teacher. He is the state senator for  in , and the first openly gay person of color to be elected to the .\n\n\nBrisport was raised in , by a Caribbean immigrant father and a second-generation Brooklynite mother.  During Brisport's childhood, his father worked at a  factory, and his mother was an office manager.\n\nHe graduated from , a private high school in . He attended  and the .\n\n\n\nBrisport taught math to 6th and 7th graders at Medgar Evers College Preparatory School, a public school in . He is a member of the  (UFT).\n\n\nAt age 22, Brisport began organizing efforts in support of a bill to legalize  in New York. The bill was defeated in 2009, but Brisport continued organizing around the issue and same-sex marriage was legalized in New York two years later.\n\nA few years after that, Brisport got involved in the burgeoning  movement and began organizing rallies and protests, as well as training protesters on what to do if stopped or harassed by the police. In 2017, he traveled to , to march in the counter-protest of a .\n\nBrisport joined the  (DSA) shortly after 's election as president, and got involved in their work on access to . He quickly became a leader in the fight against the private development of the  in Crown Heights.\n\n\nIn 2017, Brisport ran against incumbent  in the 35th  District. In a rare  primary, he defeated Scott Hutchinson, 32 votes to 4. Brisport was partially inspired to run for office by  and . He was endorsed by , , and the New York Chapter of . He lost the election, receiving 29% of the vote. Brisport earned more independent votes than any council candidate since 2003.\n\n\n\n\nIn 2019, Brisport announced a run for the  seat being vacated by . On September 29, 2019, he was endorsed by the . His campaign did not accept any donations from the real estate industry or any for-profit corporations. Instead, it received donations from over 7,000 individuals, breaking the record for most donors to a New York State-level campaign. According to the campaign, it also had the support of over 1,000 volunteers. His campaign was also endorsed by , , , , and the .\n\nOn election night of the Democratic primary on June 23, 2020, Brisport led the race with 52.25% of the vote against sitting Assemblywoman  and former Montgomery staffer Jason Salmon. But there were more  than usual due to the , and on election night there were still 26,000 absentee ballots to be counted. Brisport declared victory on July 23, once the absentee ballots had been counted and his lead over Wright had grown to 10,000 votes. He won the November general election, becoming the first openly gay person of color ever elected to the New York legislature.\n\n\n\nIn 2022, Brisport faced  in the State Senate district 25 race. Brisport was backed by the  and by unions including 1199SEIU and District Council 37. Tillard was endorsed by , State Senator , and former New York City Councilman . Tillard ran as a more moderate and centrist candidate than Brisport, and was critical of his support of . Brisport won re-nomination in the three-way race, with 70% of the vote to Tillard's 16%.\n\n\nBrisport came to identify as a  through 's presidential campaign, for which he volunteered as a canvasser and phone-banker. He is a member of the  (DSA).\n\nBrisport was arrested while protesting the re-development of the vacant  in . He argued that the development should be 100% affordable housing. He has advocated for a vacancy tax and a '''' tax.\n\nBrisport, who is vegan, supports a ban on the commercial sale of cats, dogs, and rabbits, as well as on the  clothing. He defends outlawing cruel  practices and redirecting  into programs for dairy farmers to exit the industry.\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Pierina Ana Sanchez''' (born June 10, 1988) is an American politician from , . Since 2022, Sanchez has represented the  on the , encompassing , , , and . A , Sanchez formerly served in the mayoral office of  as a policy advisor. \n\n\nSanchez was born in University Heights and grew up in the Kingsbridge neighborhood of the Bronx. She is the daughter of  immigrants who immigrated to the United States in the 1970s. She has a son, born in August of 2022.\n\nAfter enrolling in the Upward Bound  provided by , Sanchez attended . She later received a  (M.P.A.) degree from 's .\n\n\nWhile at Harvard, Sanchez worked for an immigration non-profit organization and tutored incarcerated  students. After receiving her undergraduate degree, she worked in constituency services for councilman . While at Princeton, Sanchez interned at the  in the summer of 2012 during the .\n\nIn 2015, Sanchez was elected to serve on the board of the Bronx Young Democrats. She also worked under   as senior advisor for housing, economic development and labor.\n\n\n\nIn the , Sanchez ran to replace Cabrera, her former boss. Sanchez's campaign received the support of the  (RWDSU) and the .\n\nAs a candidate, Sanchez advocated for universal  for college preparation and vocational training, and endorsed the creation of more s. On housing, Sanchez endorsed the creation of a , rent cancellation, and direct funding for repairing  (NYCHA) units. Sanchez endorsed the  movement in 2020.\n\nIn the final count, Sanchez received 62.4 percent of the vote in the Democratic primary against runner-up , who received 37.6 percent. Sanchez won the general election against  opponent Shemeen Chappell. As of 2024, she serves as the City Council's chair of the housing and buildings committee.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Jamaal T. Bailey''' (born August 26, 1982) is an American attorney and politician serving as a member of the  from the . A , he represents portions of , , , Edenwald, , , and  in  as well as  in .\n\n\nBailey was born and raised in , where he attended , including P.S. 83 in  and M.S 181 in . He later attended the . He earned a Bachelor of Arts degree from the  and a  from the .\n\n\nA protege of   , Bailey began his political career as an intern in Heastie's office.\n\n\nIn mid 2016, state Senator  resigned from her seat to take a position with  , and Bailey ran in the state primary to replace her. Against four other Democratic candidates, Bailey would win an outright majority of the vote with over 55%. Much of his success was attributed to both his roots in the district, as well as the strong support given by Assembly Speaker , who Bailey formerly worked for. Heastie's district covers a portion of the same area of the .\n\nBailey won a second term unopposed in 2018. With Democrats taking the majority in the Senate, Bailey became chair of the Senate Committee on Codes.\n\n\nBailey is married and has two daughters.\n\n\n\n\n\n* ''official site''\n\n\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }, ''Project Vote Smart'', Philipsburg, MT, 2013, Retrieved 14 December 2013.\n| birth_place = , \n| party = \n| spouse = Constance \"Connie\" (Gallivan) Hoyt, ''NYDailyNews.com'', New York, NY: NYDailyNews.com, 30 June 2011, Katz, C., Retrieved 5 December 2013., ''New York State Commission on Local Government'', 2001, Retrieved 13 December 2013.\n| children = two\n| residence = \n| alma_mater = \n| profession =  Economic developmentalist\n| website = \n| footnotes = \n}}\n\n\n\n'''William Ballard''' \"'''Sam'''\" '''Hoyt III''' (born January 9, 1962) is an American politician from . A Democrat, Hoyt is an economic development professional and was a member of the  from 1992 to 2011. He represented the 144th Assembly district, consisting of part of , and all of ,, ''Buffalo News'', Buffalo, NY: Berkshire Hathaway, 27 January 1993, McNeil, H., Retrieved 15 January 2014. from 1992 to 2011.  Hoyt was first elected to succeed his late father, . He resigned from office in 2011 after a sexual harassment suit and he previously was the subject of an ethics investigation in 2008 concerning a two-year sexual relationship with a 23-year-old assembly intern, named Lori Gradwell.\n\nHe was then appointed to an  position as Regional President of the  in  Governor 's administration., ''New York State Governor Andrew Cuomo'', Albany, NY, 1 July 2011, Retrieved 13 December 2013., ''The Buffalo News'', Buffalo, NY: Berkshire Hathaway, 7 November 2013, Besecker, A., Retrieved 13 December 2013., ''McClatchy - Tribune Business News'', Washington, DC: McClatchy - Tribune Business News, 13 May 2012, McCarthy, R.J., Retrieved 15 January 2014. He was also Interim Chairman of the Erie Canal Harbor Development Corporation,, ''Bloomberg Businessweek'', New York, NY, 2013, Retrieved 13 December 2013. and Vice Chairman of the .\n\nHoyt is founder and president of , a full-service PR, lobbying, and government relations firm based in Buffalo, NY\n\n\nHoyt grew up on Buffalo's west side and attended area schools, graduating from , and receiving a Bachelor of Arts degree in  from  in 1992.  He also attended .\n\n\nPrior to entering elected office, Hoyt served as Western New York regional director for  , and was marketing and promotions director for the  minor league baseball team.  He represented the 144th Assembly District, encompassing part of Buffalo, New York, and all of  from 1992 to 2011.\n\n\n\n\nHoyt was first elected in a 1992 special election following the death of his father, William B. Hoyt, who held the office prior to him.  From 1992 to 2010, Hoyt won all elections for his assembly seat with voting percentages between 51% and 79% in his favor.\n\n\n\nHoyt's complete electoral history has been tracked, online, at ''Our Campaigns'', and a portion of it is reflected here.\n\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n*There were also 31 write-in votes in this election, accounting for 0.10%.\n*Hoyt also received votes on both the Independent and Working Family lines in this election.\n\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n*Hoyt also ran on the Liberal ticket in this election.\n\n\n\nIn the Assembly, Hoyt served as Majority Whip.  As a senior member of the Assembly, he chaired several Assembly committees.  In 2007, Assembly Speaker  appointed Hoyt as the Chairman of the Assembly Local Governments Committee. Prior to becoming chairman of this committee, Hoyt was the Chairman of the Assembly Oversight, Analysis and Investigations Committee. He is also both a former Chairman of the Assembly Task Force on Demographics and Reapportionment, and the Assembly  and  Committee., ''New York State Office of Alcoholism and Substance Abuse Services'', Albany, NY, Undated, Hoyt, S., Retrieved 14 December 2013.  He also co-chaired both the Anti-Flipping and High Speed Rail Task Forces., ''Buffalo News'', Buffalo, NY: Berkshire Hathaway, 18 February 1993, Retrieved 15 January 2014.  Hoyt was also a member of the following committees: Ways and Means;, ''Legislative Gazette.com'', Albany, NY, 24 October 2011, Krieg, F., Retrieved 15 December 2013. Local Governments; Children and Families; Transportation; Energy; Tourism; Arts and Sports Development; Cities; Government Operations; Women's Issues Task Force; and the Puerto Rican/Hispanic Task Force.\n\n\nSome of Hoyt's political interests have included making state and local governments more efficient and accountable to taxpayers; revitalizing neighborhoods; increasing economic opportunity; and developing the Buffalo waterfront.\n\n\nHoyt concentrated on the redevelopment of Upstate New York cities. The passage of the Smart Growth Public Infrastructure Policy Act; Land Bank Program; and State Historic Preservation Tax Credit , ''Preservation League of New York State'', Albany, NY, 5 May 2010, Ryan, C.M., Retrieved 15 December 2013. are among his legislative accomplishments.\n\nIn 2009, Hoyt sponsored legislation that was passed to allow the  to start the fourth phase of its Joint Schools reconstruction project. As a lifelong environmentalist, in 2008, Hoyt passed a new law to protect old growth forests. The same year, Hoyt sponsored a new law that passed to fund bike paths across New York State, and has worked for their protection.\n\nAn advocate of marriage equality, Hoyt supported the , which was passed in June 2011. This Act granted same-sex couples in New York State the freedom to marry under the law, as well as hundreds of rights, benefits, and protections that had been limited to married couples of the opposite sex.\n\nIn 2006, Hoyt proposed that a land-locked area between the  to  and Porter Avenue be transformed into a park., ''McClatchy - Tribune Business News'', Washington, DC: McClatchy - Tribune Business News, 9 October 2006, Linstedt, S., Retrieved 15 January 2014.  The strip of land was owned by the New York State Thruway Authority, and its scenic value had been lost due to the development of both the Peace Bridge toll plaza and Interstate-190.  That area of land had previously been part of Front Park, designed by .\n\n\n\nHoyt proposed in 2004 that a community-based group be created regarding the restoration of the , historic buildings that are part of the , for use as a center for cultural and educational activities., ''Buffalo News'', Buffalo, NY: Berkshire Hathaway, 22 January 2004, Sommer, M., Retrieved 15 January 2014.  Hoyt proposed that $100&nbsp;million be put toward the restoration, which was supported by New York State Governor .  In 2009, in relation to interests of Buffalo State College in desiring land use expansion of the psychiatric center grounds and vacant buildings, Hoyt stated that Buffalo was famous for its historic architecture., ''Buffalo News'', Buffalo, NY: Berkshire Hathaway, 19 May 1999, Collison, K., Retrieved 6 February 2014.\n\nIn 2000, Hoyt, who is an advocate of college students, urged  (UB) leaders  (1934–2009) and Dennis Black to work with staff of the student newspaper, ''The Spectrum'', after students were twice-arrested by campus police for remaining in the newspaper offices after hours to work., ''Buffalo News'', Buffalo, NY: Berkshire Hathaway, 4 April 2000, Brady, K., Retrieved 21 December 2013.  The involvement of Hoyt and UB English Department Chairwoman Barbara Bono succeeded in opening communications between UB leadership and the students.\n\nAlso active in the area of social justice, Hoyt joined other urban legislators in declaring a state of emergency in the fight against HIV/AIDS in minority communities.\n\nHoyt introduced legislation that went into effect in 1998 that guaranteed a tax-free week for college students in New York State for the purchase of their college textbooks., ''Buffalo News'', Buffalo, NY: Berkshire Hathaway, 19 August 1998, Brady, K., Retrieved 5 February 2014.\n\nIn 1997, Hoyt worked with other legislators on a project aimed at expanding high speed rail in New York State, particularly to Buffalo.\n\nThroughout his tenure, Hoyt was a strong supporter of his alma mater, Buffalo State College, as well as , the president of the college from 1996 to 2009., ''Buffalo News'', Buffalo, NY: Berkshire Hathaway, 12 December 1995, Brady, K., Retrieved 21 December 2013., ''McClatchy - Tribune Business News'', Washington, DC: McClatchy-Tribune Business News,  1 April 2009, Rey, J., Retrieved 5 February 2014.  When Howard took on the role as president of the college, Hoyt stated that she was an excellent choice.  When Howard announced that she would be departing from the college, Hoyt stated that she would be difficult to replace and would be sorely missed.\n\n\nIn 2000, Hoyt was involved in an attempted political coup, led by Former Majority Leader , of Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver, in order to oust him from his position., ''Buffalo News'', Buffalo, NY: Berkshire Hathaway, 22 September 2004, Esmonde, D., Retrieved 15 January 2014.  Following the coup, it was stated that Hoyt was unable to enter the circle of inner leadership in the Assembly, though he salvaged his political access to Silver when it was clear that the coup would be unsuccessful.\n\n\n from Buffalo State College, 2000]]\nHoyt received numerous awards, including the 2011 Lifetime Achievement Award by the New York League of Conservation Voters; Elected Official of the Year in 2008 by both the State Historic Preservation Office and American Institute of Architects; the 1992 SUNY Chancellor's Recognition Award; and the 2001 William B. Hoyt Environmental Award from the National Audubon Society that was named in honor of his late father.  Hoyt has been a proponent of preserving historical architecture, including the  and its  administration building.\n\nHoyt has been recognized by the Western New York Chemical Dependency Consortium and New York Council on Problem Gambling for his efforts into creating awareness and funding for drug and gambling addiction treatment and prevention programs.\n\nHoyt has received \"Public Citizen of the Year\" aware by the New York State Chapter of the  and the \"Creating a Greener New York Award\" from the  (2001), as well as the National Family Planning and Reproductive Health Association's Distinguished Public Service Award (2000); the National Association for Mental Illness Public Service Award (2000); and the New York State Public Employees Federation (PEF) Quality Service Award in (1999).\n\n\n\nIn September 2008, Hoyt was disciplined by   for an inappropriate relationship involving a participant in the Assembly Intern Program based on a report completed by the New York State Assembly Standing Committee on Ethics and Guidance., ''New York State Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver Press Release'', Albany, NY, 26 September 2008, Silver, S., Retrieved 13 December 2013., ''New York State Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver'', Albany, NY, 26 September 2008, Silver, S., Retrieved 13 December 2013., ''McClatchy - Tribune Business News'', Washington, DC: McClatchy - Tribune Business News, 27 September 2008, Precious, T., Retrieved 15 January 2014., ''New York Daily News'', New York, NY: NY Daily News, 26 September 2008, Lovett, K., Retrieved 15 January 2014. Silver announced that Hoyt had an \"inappropriate personal relationship\" with an Assembly intern,, ''McClatchy - Tribune Business News'', Washington, DC: McClatchy - Tribune Business News, 10 September 2008, Fairbanks, P., Retrieved 15 January 2014., ''Buffalo News'', Buffalo, NY: Berkshire Hathaway, 5 September 2008, Beebe, M., Retrieved 15 January 2014. and issued a new \"policy prohibiting fraternization with student interns.\"  Hoyt was prohibited from future participation in \"any student internship program.\"\n\n''The Buffalo News'' reported that the woman was 23 (Hoyt was 41 at the time) and had graduated from the .  Hoyt did not break any law or Assembly rules, because prior to 2004 there no policy prohibiting relationships with interns  (The affair occurred in 2003.) Hoyt said in a statement: \"I am a public figure, but I've reconciled with my family, and I'm pleased to report I am happily married. No rules were broken; no laws were broken. I broke my marriage vows.\"\n\nInformation initially investigated by the Ethics Committee included e-mails by two women regarding personal information shared with them by Hoyt., ''Buffalo News'', Buffalo, NY: Berkshire Hathaway, 21 August 2008, Precious, T., McCarthy, R.J., & Becker, M., Retrieved 15 January 2014.\n\nThe second woman whose e-mails were provided to the Ethics Committee was a student assistant for two years, and later, was part of a federal student work program, though there was no evidence that definitively reflected that the two engaged in an affair.\n\n\n\nIn 2011, New York State Governor Andrew M. Cuomo announced Hoyt's appointment as Regional President for the Empire State Development Corporation,\n\nIn this position, Hoyt oversaw economic development efforts in the , , , and  regions of New York State.\n\nIn 2012, Hoyt was named Interim Chairman of the Erie Canal Harbor Development Corporation.  He also served as chair of the Buffalo and Fort Erie Peace Bridge Authority.\n\n\nHoyt abruptly resigned in October 2017 amid a state investigation into an extramarital affair with a woman who was a fellow state employee. Hoyt had paid the woman $50,000 in exchange for her agreement to conceal the relationship. A spokesman for the governor said that \"With the investigation still pending, Mr. Hoyt separated from state service.\"Joseph Spector, ,  (Oct. 31, 2017). Hoyt issued a statement expressing regret for what he termed a \"short term, consensual and inappropriate relationship\" and stated that: \"When I attempted to end the relationship, she threatened me. At that point, over a year ago, my wife and I agreed to a settlement to avoid public embarrassment to our family.\"\n\nIn November 2017, Lisa Marie Cater, a former State Department of Motor Vehicles employee, filed a federal lawsuit against Hoyt alleging . Cater alleges that Hoyt sexually harassed her starting in 2015, shortly after helping her gain employment.Charlie Specht, , ''The Buffalo News'' (November 20, 2017). Hoyt denies wrongdoing.\n\n\n\nOn June 11, 2018, the New York State Joint Commission on Public Ethics cleared Hoyt on charges of sexual harassment and assault. The Committee said it reviewed hundreds of pages of records, including emails, employment records, and information from multiple witnesses, and stated that the Cater was uncooperative during the investigation.\n\n\nHoyt is married to wife, Connie, and has two sons, Clayton and Griffin.\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Letitia Ann James''' (born October 18, 1958) is an American lawyer and politician serving since 2019 as the  (NYAG), having won the  to succeed . A member of the , James is the first  and first woman to be elected New York Attorney General.\n\nBorn and raised in , James graduated from  in  before obtaining her  degree at  in  She worked as a , then on staff in the , and later as a New York State Assistant Attorney General in the Brooklyn regional office.\n\nJames served as a member of the  from 2004 to 2013. She represented the , which includes the Brooklyn neighborhoods of , , parts of , , and . James chaired the committees on economic development and sanitation and served on several others. From 2013 to 2018, she was the , making her the first African-American woman to be elected to and hold citywide office in New York City.\n\nJames was briefly a candidate in the , but suspended her campaign in December 2021, opting to instead run for reelection as Attorney General.\n\n\nLetitia Ann James was born on October 18, 1958, in , New York. She is one of eight children born to Nellie James (b. 1919, ) and Robert James. She attended New York City . Raised in , she attended  in nearby . She received her  from the 's  in 1981, majoring in  with an emphasis in .\n\nJames received her  degree from  in  in 1987, and was admitted to practice law in New York State in 1989. As of 2013, James was enrolled at 's  (SIPA) in the  section of Manhattan, where she was working towards a  degree.\n\n\nJames served as a  for the  and established the Urban Network, a coalition of  professional organizations aimed at providing scholarships for inner city youth.\n\nShe served on former New York Governor 's Task Force on  in the Judiciary. She served as  for ,  for  in the , and in the administration of  . She was appointed the first Assistant Attorney General in charge of the Brooklyn regional office in 1999. While working in that position, James worked in many capacities but notably focused on consumer complaints involving  and other unlawful business practices.\n\n\nJames' first run for the  was in November 2001. In a close race, James received 42% of the vote on the  line but lost to , a . In July 2003, just months before the next election, Davis was assassinated by , a former political rival. Following Davis's death, his brother Geoffrey ran for his vacant council seat on the Democratic Party ticket, but on election day, November 4, 2003, Geoffrey A. Davis lost by a large margin to James as the Working Families Party nominee. In that 2003 race, James officially became a member of the Working Families Party, and was the first citywide office-holder to run solely on the WFP line.\n\n\n, 2008]]\nJames is the first member of the Working Families Party to win office in New York State, and the first  member to be elected to the city council since 1977. She has since changed back to the Democratic party.\n\nJames again won the Working Families and the Democratic parties' nominations by a large margin over Samuel Eric Blackwell, an urban planner at  and pro-stadium advocate. She was re-elected on the Democratic line on November 8, 2005, with 88.11% of the vote, compared to 6.80% for  Anthony Herbert, and 5.08% for  candidate Charles B. Billups.\n\nOn October 10, 2006, there was a devastating fire at the , an architectural icon in . The fire attracted attention from the , which resulted in citations being issued for numerous building code violations. James represented Broken Angel's owner, Arthur Wood,  in his negotiations to keep his home. The agency decided to allow Wood to re-occupy Broken Angel provided the upper levels were taken down and the central stairwell reconstructed.\n\n in 2009]]\nShe was the first to question cost overruns and irregularities in the subcontracting work of the new CityTime payroll system much touted by Bloomberg which eventually led to several indictments, Bloomberg asking a tech giant for $600 million back, and two consultants fleeing the country in 2011.\n\nJames originally advocated for the demolition of the  houses on  in order to build a parking lot for a proposed supermarket to serve residents in nearby housing developments, but later supported preserving some of the historic housing. In 2008, James, with , advocated against Mayor 's attempts to seek a third term without a voter referendum.\n\nJames won the Democratic  in September 2009 against her opponents, community organizer Delia Hunley-Adossa, who received more than $200,000 from Forest City Ratner and Medhanie Estiphanos, a financial consultant. James went on to win re-election for a second term.\n\nIn May 2013, with a group that included construction unions, community groups and other elected officials, she was a part of an Article 78 lawsuit against the  and Acadia Realty Trust seeking the shut-down of the City Point real estate project and a reassessment of its environmental impact.\n\nIn June 2016, James attempted to pressure six s, including , Berkshire Bank, , ,  and , into ending its practice of providing  to gun manufacturers.  was specifically requested to drop the accounts of  of , but denied the request.\n\n\n*Committee on Economic Development (chair)\n*Committee on Sanitation (chair)\n*Committee on Parks & Recreation\n*Committee on Small Business\n*Committee on Technology in Government\n*Committee on Veteran Affairs\n*Committee on Women's Issues\n\n\n\n\n rally]]\nIn 2013, James ran for  and received 36% of the vote in the first Democratic primary, under the 40% threshold that would have avoided a . James won the runoff election on October 1, 2013, against , 59.4%–40.6%, becoming the party's nominee for the city's elected watchdog position in November.\n\nIn the 2013 election campaign for Public Advocate, James was endorsed by many of the city's important labor unions, , , Democracy for NYC, , '''' and ''.'' On October 1, 2013, James achieved a Democratic primary win in spite of her campaign fundraising trailing 's and , to become the Democratic Party's nominee for New York City's elected watchdog position. She was endorsed by third-place finisher Saujani in September James won the Democratic . Without a Republican opponent, she won the general election with over 83% of the vote.\n\nIn 2017, James won the Democratic primary for her position with 77% of the vote, over closest competitor David Eisenbach's 23%.\n\n\n\n\nIn May 2018, James, who initially planned to run for  in , declared her candidacy for  and won the Democratic primary on September 13, 2018, with 40.6% of the vote; she defeated  (31%) and two other candidates. On November 6, 2018, she was elected Attorney General, defeating Republican . She made history by becoming the first woman and African American to be elected as attorney general in New York and serve in that role. During her campaign, James vowed to pursue , who she said was an “illegitimate president” and an “embarrassment.”\n\n\n]]\nJames was sworn in as attorney general on January 1, 2019, succeeding , who was first appointed after the resignation of .\n\n\nIn September 2019, James filed suit against the officials of 's , alleging financial misconduct.\n\n\nIn August 2020, James filed a civil lawsuit in  against the  (NRA), accusing the organization of corruption and financial misconduct, and calling for its dissolution. The NRA filed a countersuit against James, citing statements she made during her 2018 campaign. In February 2024, a lawsuit brought by the New York Attorney General’s Office under James found that the NRA mismanaged charitable funds when it failed to stop top executives, including CEO Wayne LaPierre, from diverting millions of dollars for lavish personal trips, no-show contracts and other questionable expenditures. A jury found that LaPierre should pay the gun rights group $4.3 million in damages for mismanagement and misspending of charitable funds, having violated his fiduciary duties from 2014 to 2022. The panel also found the NRA’s former CFO Wilson Phillips should pay back $2 million for breaching his fiduciary duties as an executive. \n\n\nIn early March 2020, the attorney general's office began to preliminarily \"investigate allegations of -related neglect of residents in nursing homes.\" The office solicited and subsequently received 953 complaints from patients' families regarding neglect of patients through November 16. The probe released its first report on both the nursing homes and the state  (DOH) on January 28, 2021, where it concluded that the department's public data under-counted nursing home deaths by up to 50 percent. The methodology of the Office of the Attorney General (OAG) was to compare deaths from COVID reported to the DOH and such deaths reported to OAG. The OAG press release makes no mention of medical analysis of the cases. James said investigations into 20 separate nursing homes \"whose reported conduct during the first wave of the pandemic presented particular concern\" would continue for the foreseeable future. The report was heralded by some in Albany as a \"declaration of independence\" from New York State Governor  after a two-year alliance in opposition to President .\n\nThree weeks after the report, the '''' revealed an ongoing joint investigation by the FBI and the , examining how Governor Cuomo's coronavirus task force played a role in nursing homes' COVID-19 response. On March 18, 2021, '''' found that the FBI's scope included a last-minute addition to the state's 2020 budget that provided greater immunity to long-term care organizations. The head of the Greater New York Hospital Association said in an August 2020  hearing that the lobbying group had provided a \"draft\" of \"some ideas to be included\" to the governor's office.\n\n\n\nOn August 3, 2021, James' office released a report finding that Cuomo engaged in multiple acts of sexual harassment.\n\n\nOn October 29, 2021, James stated her intention to run for the office of  in the 2022 Democratic primary but withdrew from the race in December,  after consistently polling behind incumbent Governor , with James instead choosing to seek reelection as Attorney General.\n\n\n\n\nAfter James launched her reelection bid, all previous Democratic candidates withdrew their candidacies and endorsed her. On November 8, 2022, James was reelected Attorney General, defeating Republican Michael Henry in the general election.\n\n\nOn May 4, 2023, James and her California counterpart  announced they would jointly investigate the  over employment practices at its offices in  and , citing a report by '''' detailing complaints of harassment and discrimination made by former female staffers.\n\n\n\n\nIn 2022, in her capacity as New York Attorney General, James filed a civil lawsuit against  and worked alongside the 's office in its . Trump argued that previous comments by James, including referring to him as an 'illegitimate president' during her campaign for attorney general, prove that she has a political  against him. On February 16, 2024, the fraud case against the former president, , proved successful. Judge 's 92-page ruling barred Trump from operating any business in New York for three years and fined him more than $355 million.\n\n\nJames lives in the  neighborhood of Brooklyn and is a member of . She has never married.\n\nAt a May 2022 rally, James stated that she had received an abortion early in her tenure as a member of the New York City Council. James said, \"'I was just elected and I was faced with the decision of whether to have an abortion or not, and I chose to have an abortion. I walked proudly into Planned Parenthood, and I make no apologies to anyone'\".\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}} \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* \n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n}}\n|-\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Phillip Michael Boyle''' (born July 21, 1961) is an American politician who served as the Senator for the  of the  from 2013 to 2022. He is a . The district he served includes the villages of , , , ,  in  on .\n\n\nBoyle was born in , and grew up in . He attended the , and transferred to  where he graduated with a  in Political Science. He attended  where he got his  degree, and also received a  in Public Administration from the  at the . Boyle was a founding partner in the law firm of Steinberg & Boyle, LLP, located in .\n\nBoyle and his wife, Victoria Ryan, reside in Bay Shore. Boyle is the stepfather to Patrick and Sarah Ryan.\n\n\nBoyle served several years on Capitol Hill as a . He was the legislative director to   (R-Rochester) and a campaign manager and chief of staff for  (R-Brightwaters).\n\nIn 1994, Boyle was elected to the  as a representative of the 8th Assembly District, which encompassed portions of the Suffolk County towns of Islip and Babylon. He did not seek reelection in 2002 after redistricting divided his district between a strongly Democratic district and a district represented by fellow Republican .\n\nHowever, when Barraga ran for the Suffolk County legislature and won, Boyle won a special election to replace him in the Assembly. In 2012, Boyle decided to run for election to the New York Senate, winning a tough race against County Legislator  52% to 48%.\n\nIn 2017, Boyle ran for Suffolk County Sheriff, but lost the Republican primary to Lawrence M. Zacarese. He then ran for the , and lost.\n\n\nIn 2013, Boyle voted in favor of the , to enact an assault weapons ban, to limit the number of rounds allowed in a magazine to seven, and to raise the legal age to own a rifle or shotgun. In 2020, the National Rifle Association gave Boyle a 42 percent rating.\n\nIn 2017, Boyle introduced legislation to ban minors from purchasing machetes. The bill passed the Senate, but was not voted on in the Assembly. This followed several machete attacks associated with the gang  in Suffolk County.\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n*\n*\n*  at Egan & Golden\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n| residence           = , U.S. Assembly Member Directory  New York State Assembly |url=https://www.nyassembly.gov/mem/Jennifer-Lunsford/bio/ |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210326071432/https://www.nyassembly.gov/mem/Jennifer-Lunsford/bio/ |archive-date=26 March 2021 |access-date=2021-03-26 |website=www.nyassembly.gov}}\n}}\n\n'''Jennifer Lunsford''' is an   politician, lawyer, and community volunteer who currently represents  , which includes parts of .\n\n\n\nLunsford was born on . Her mother was a  and sales manager, while her father was a . After graduating from , she earned an undergraduate degree in  and  at . She worked as a paralegal before attending the , where she focused on . She then moved to , where she works as a litigator, primarily representing plaintiffs in , , and .\n\nLunsford has worked as a community volunteer and activist, campaigning for , , and  with groups including .\n\n\n\nIn 2018, Lunsford unsuccessfully ran for the  seat in the , losing narrowly to  state senator . She campaigned again in 2020, but dropped out to run for the assembly.\n\nLunsford narrowly defeated incumbent Republican  during the elections of 2020. In the close race, Johns held the lead before  and s were counted.\n\nLunsford co-sponsored legislation to outlaw use of  and  on minors in February 2021, after an incident the previous month in which a suicidal 9-year-old girl was sprayed in the face.\n\nAlong with other  area lawmakers, Lunsford supported an independent investigation of the  that developed in February 2021.\n\nIn early March 2021, Lunsford was among a bipartisan group of legislators from the Rochester area to support revoking the  that Governor  had been granted in order to fight the , citing the progress that had been made up until that time and allegations that his administration had mishandled death numbers in the .\n\nOn March 23, 2021, the assembly passed legislation expanding  eligibility to cover those who had to leave work due to  obligations. Lunsford noted that the  had worsened the child care situation in New York. Lunsford sponsored the bill, which clarified that child care constitutes good cause, a matter which had been decided inconsistently by courts and the  appeal board at the .\n\n\n\n\n\n*  \n*  \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
