    "pages": }\n'''Joseph Crowley''' (born March 16, 1962) is a former American politician and consultant who served as  from  from 1999 to 2019. He was  by Democratic primary challenger  in what was viewed as one of the biggest  of the .\n\nDuring his tenure, Crowley served as  from 2017 to 2019, as well as the local chairman of the  Democratic Party from 2006 to 2019. He previously served in the  from 1987 to 1998. After leaving Congress, he joined the  lobbying and law firm . He left that firm in 2022 and joined the rival law firm .\n\n\nCrowley was born in , , to Joseph F. Crowley Sr., an , and Eileen Crowley, who emigrated from , . Crowley Sr. served in the United States Army during the , later becoming a lawyer and a  detective. Crowley Jr. is the second of four siblings. Crowley Jr.'s paternal uncle Walter H. Crowley was a New York City councilman, and is the namesake of Crowley Playground in .\n\nCrowley attended private Roman Catholic schools in the city, graduating from  in Manhattan in 1981. He graduated from  in 1985 with a degree in political science and communications. Crowley was inducted into the  Hall of Fame in 2011.\n\n\n\n\nHe was a member of the  from 1987 to 1998, sitting in the , , , ,  and s. Because of his Irish roots, he quickly became involved in  politics throughout New York.\n\n\n in 1999]]\n in 1999]]\nDemocratic Congressman  announced his retirement from Congress in 1998, having already filed for and circulated petitions for reelection. He withdrew on the last day it was legally possible to do so and arranged for Crowley, his chosen successor, to replace him on the ballot. Crowley was not aware of this until Manton phoned him to tell him his name would be on the general election ballot.\n\nPrior to  for the 2012 election, Crowley represented the 7th District, which encompassed portions of Queens and the Bronx. It included neighborhoods such as Woodside, Jackson Heights, East Elmhurst, and College Point, in Queens as well as the neighborhoods of , , Parkchester, Throgs Neck, Morris Park, , Pelham Bay, , and City Island in the eastern Bronx.\n\nAfter 2013, Crowley represented , which includes the eastern  and part of north-central . The Queens portion includes the neighborhoods of , , , , ,  and . The Bronx portion of the district includes the neighborhoods of , , , and  as well as .\n\nOn June 26, 2018, Crowley was defeated in the  by .\n\n\n\n* ''''''\n** \n** \n\n\n\n* Ad Hoc Committee on Irish Affairs, Co-Chair\n* Rare Disease Congressional Caucus, Co-Chair\n* Congressional Musicians Caucus, Founder and Chair\n* Bangladesh Caucus, Founder and Chair\n* Congressional Caucus on India and Indian-Americans, former co-chair\n* Animal Protection Caucus\n* Congressional Arts Caucus\n* Congressional Historic Preservation Caucus\n* Congressional LGBT Equality Caucus\n* Congressional Pro-Choice Caucus\n* National Service Caucus\n* \n\n\nCrowley served as , the fourth highest leadership position in the .\n\nCrowley's cousin,  John Michael Moran, was killed as a result of the . Crowley authored a bill that provided the  to all emergency workers who died as a result of the terrorist acts. He also created the Urban Area Security Initiative, which directs money to prevent terrorism toward regions that are seen as the most threatened.\n\nCrowley, who has spent much time in India, created a Bangladesh caucus and was formerly the chair of the India Caucus.\n\n's leader  in September 2016]]\nOn October 10, 2002, Crowley was among the 81 House Democrats who voted in favor of authorizing the .\n\nCrowley joined Bronx Representative  in 2008 in proposing legislation to help clean up -contaminated schools.\n\nIn April 2011, Crowley received media attention for an angry \"speech\" he gave without actually speaking. Crowley ripped pieces of paper with words to deliver his message.\n\nCrowley was first elected to the U.S. House of Representatives in 1998. The seat was considered open after incumbent  retired.\n\nIn 2017, Crowley was the commencement speaker at and received an honorary degree from .\n\nIn the June 26, 2018, Democratic primary for New York's 14th congressional district, Crowley was defeated by challenger , who received 57% of the vote, in what was seen as a massive upset. Crowley remained on the general election ballot under the  line. Ocasio-Cortez called on Crowley to take his name off the ballot, but he responded that he could not unless he moved, died, was convicted of a felony, or filed to run for another office in November as a  (which he claimed would be a form of electoral fraud). Ocasio-Cortez defeated Crowley and Republican Anthony Pappas in the , with Crowley receiving 7% of the vote.\n\nIn February 2019, Crowley resigned as Chair of the Queens Democratic Party and signed on to the lobbying firm ., 02/19/2019,  June Bunch was selected to serve as Chair on an interim basis. Crowley also became honorary co-chair of the Pass USMCA Coalition, an umbrella organization working to pass , the 's replacement for the .\n\nIn May 2019, Crowley joined the board of Northern Swan Holdings Inc., an investment firm focused on  and  cultivation in , along with former  .\n\n\n\n\nSince 2005, Crowley consistently received ratings of 0% from the  and 100% from the NARAL. In 2011, he opposed a bill that would have banned taxpayer funding for abortions, and in the 2010 election, he was endorsed by Planned Parenthood. In 2018, Crowley received a voting record of 100% from Planned Parenthood.\n\n\nSince 2007, he received a rating of 100% from the , the , and the .\n\nCrowley fought against the practice of  (FGM), both abroad and in the United States. In 2010, he introduced the Girls Protection Act of 2010, which would criminalize the transport of a girl under the age of 18 years old to undergo FGM.\n\nIn 2015, he proposed a bill with Representative  encouraging the collection of data on the prevalence of FGM, and to create a plan to better prevent the practice, which is illegal in the United States.\n\nCrowley was a consistent supporter of the 2010  (known as \"Obamacare\", or \"ACA\"). On March 22, 2010, he said: \"I... support the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act, a historic measure that will put families first when it comes to accessing health care coverage.\" He opposed repealing the act, and voted against a repeal on January 19, 2011. Also in 2011, he held an event to celebrate the one-year anniversary of the bill's passage.\n\nIn 2017, Crowley signed on to H.R. 676, the Expanded and Improved Medicare for All Act. This bill was introduced by former Michigan Congressman John Conyers in January 2017.\n\n\nCrowley has been a heavy critic of President Trump's plan to build a wall on the U.S.–Mexico border and his decision to end  and Temporary Protected Status protection for qualifying immigrants in 2017. In 2017, Crowley introduced a bill that would grant green cards to undocumented workers who helped to recover and clean up New York City after the terrorist attacks on September 11.\n\n\n]]\nCrowley holds the view \"that reducing barriers to investment, creating opportunities for small businesses, and providing equitable working conditions for all Americans can and should be part of our national economic policy\". He supported federal spending as a way to increase economic growth. In 2008, he endorsed the Financial Asset Purchase Authority and Tax Law Amendments, which established the Troubled Assets Relief Program (TARP) and allowed the Secretary of the Treasury to buy assets from troubled financial institutions.\n\nCrowley advocated tax increases on the highest tax brackets, tax cuts for the middle class, and reduced defense spending. When serving on the Ways and Means Committee, he stated: \"I really don't see how it's justifiable or sensible to give a tax cut to the wealthiest among us, but at the same time increase taxes on U.S. soldiers.\" He also applauded the 2009 Budget for ending the Alternative Minimum Tax, and ensuring tax cuts for 23 million middle-class Americans. In 2011, he opposed a bill that appropriated funds to the defense budget.\n\nIn 2017, Crowley opposed the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act of 2017, saying its only goal was to give more tax cuts to America's top 1% than the working class. In December 2017, Crowley said in a floor speech: \"It's a scam, and the American people know it. Is this a bill that helps people who are living paycheck to paycheck? Hell, no.\"\n\n\n, and  meeting with Indian Prime Minister , New Delhi, January 26, 2015]]\nCrowley proposed legislation to improve conditions for renters in his district. In September 2017, he introduced the Rent Relief Act, which would give refundable tax credits to renters.\n\nCrowley had a 2016 score of 95% from the .\n\nCrowley's Irish roots influenced his policy decisions in Congress as a member of the Friends of Ireland Caucus. He worked on peace efforts for the conflict in Northern Ireland and securing refuge for those affected by it. Crowley spoke out against President Trump's effort to eliminate the position of . Trump eventually reversed this decision. Crowley was named \"Irish-American of the year\" by the Irish Echo in 2018.\n\nCrowley voted in favor of the .\n\nIn January 2017, Crowley voted for a House resolution condemning the , which called  in the occupied  a flagrant violation of international law and a major obstacle to peace.\n\n\nAfter leaving Congress in 2019, he joined the  lobbying and law firm . In 2022, he left Squire Patton Boggs to move to the Dentons’ Law Firm, also based in Washington, D.C. Crowley was named a fellow at the . Crowley is a member of the U.S. Semiquincentennial Commission, which is charged with planning and executing the 250th anniversary of the signing of the Declaration of Independence. Crowley sits on the board of directors of  in the Bronx, New York.\n\n\nCrowley is married to Kasey Crowley, a registered nurse. They have three children: Cullen, Kenzie, and Liam. He is the cousin of former woman .\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n \n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n \n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* \n* \n* \n* \n* \n* \n* \n* \n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n}}\n|-\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n|-\n\n\n''|years=}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Margaret M. Markey''' (born November 4, 1941) is an American politician who formerly represented District 30 in the , which is made up of  and , as well as portions of , ,  and . She is a .\n\n\nA graduate of Berkeley Business School, Markey began in public service as the assistant director of economic development for former Queens Borough President , later becoming the borough's director of marketing and tourism. She was first elected to the New York State Assembly in 1998. She is the current chairwoman of the Tourism, Parks, Arts and Sports Development; as well as previously holding the position of president of the Irish American Legislators Society.\n\nIn 2009, a controversial bill presented by Markey sought to tackle sex abuse cases in private schools. Critics have argued that the legislation is unfair because it appears to target Catholic schools, while the vast majority of sexual abuse has occurred in public schools under the state's control.\n\nIn March 2010, Markey co-sponsored, along with assembly members  and , a bill that would prohibit the use of all forms of  in the preparation and cooking of all restaurant food, with customers having the option to add salt once served.\n\nMarkey lost re-election to the Assembly in 2016, defeated in the Democratic primary for District 30 to Woodside attorney , aged 30. Markey saw her political fortunes change for the worse when she failed to show up at community events and protests in relation to a proposed homeless shelter in the neighborhood of Maspeth, in a somewhat similar fashion to her Assembly predecessor 's loss in his  primary two years later.\n\n\nMarkey resides in Maspeth with her husband, State Supreme Court Judge Charles Markey. They have three children: Charles, John, and Margaret.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Matthew Joseph Troy, Jr.''' (September 23, 1929 – December 4, 2004) was an American lawyer and politician. He was a member of the  from the  borough of  from 1964 to 1977 and the leader of the Queens  from 1971 to 1974. He pleaded guilty to federal tax charges in 1976 and was convicted of grand larceny in 1979.\n\n\nTroy was born September 23, 1929, in , New York, to Matthew Troy, a lawyer and political figure who served as a municipal judge. He graduated from  and received his law degree from .\n\n\nIn January 1964, the New York City Council elected Troy as an interim 5th district councilman to replace Seymour Boyers, who had been elected as the at-large council member for Queens. As this was an interim appointment, he would have to run in the 1964 general election to secure the seat for the remainder of Boyers’ term. Troy actively opposed , a hot-button issue in eastern Queens, where an anti-integration organization, Parents and Taxpayers, had a strong following. In the general election, he defeated  Robert McMillan.\n\nIn 1970, Troy briefly ran for the Democratic nomination for . He withdrew from the race in favor of . He later became the Democratic Party leader in Queens in 1971, succeeding Frank Smith.\n\nAs a councilman and party leader, Troy clashed with Mayors  and  throughout his career. He was a critic of Lindsay’s policies, especially with regard to a planned low-income housing development in Forest Hills. Troy also was an early backer of Senator  in the race for the  over Mayor Lindsay.\n\nIn the , Troy supported the conservative Democratic Representative  in the Democratic primary. His support for Biaggi came after making an initial promise of an endorsement to Beame. After Beame's victory, Troy began to clash with the new mayor over his austere budgets. In 1974, Beame worked with , the Borough President Of Queens, and a friend of Troy, to arrange Troy’s ouster as Democratic leader. Troy had angered Manes when he switched support to  in the 1974 race for Governor of New York.\n\n\nIn 1976, Troy faced federal income tax charges for failing to report income on funds that he had stolen from his clients’ estates. Troy pleaded guilty to one charge of filing a false tax return and served 55 days in prison. Although he pleaded guilty to a felony, under state law, the crime was a misdemeanor which allowed him to hold on to his council seat. He was disbarred after the plea.\n\nHe ran for re-election in 1977 but lost the Democratic nomination to  in the wake of his conviction. Leffler, coincidentally, was eventually convicted of campaign fraud in 2013.\n\nThe State of New York indicted him on larceny and perjury charges as a result of the federal investigation in 1977. A judge dismissed the perjury charge but let the remaining larceny charges go to trial. At his trial, Troy stated that he took the money because he overdrew his checking account. A judge turned aside his argument that the charges constituted  and that his agreement with federal prosecutors to face no further charges did not permit the conviction. In 1979, Troy consented to a guilty verdict and was sentenced to 26 weekends in prison.\n\n\nTroy was the executive director of the Long Island Gasoline Retailers Association but did not enter politics again. He practiced law after the restoration of his law license for the remainder of his life. He died on December 4, 2004, from .\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
          }
        ]
      }
    }
  }

    "pages": }\n\n'''Nily Rozic''' (born March 15, 1986) is a legislator from  and a member of the .\n\nRozic represents , which spans the northeast portions of Queens, including the communities of Flushing, Queensboro Hill, Hillcrest, Fresh Meadows, Oakland Gardens, Bayside, and Douglaston.\n\n\nRozic was born in Jerusalem and raised in the United States. She is a graduate of , ’s , and . Nily Rozic|website=nyassembly.gov|access-date=2017-05-05}}\n\n\nPrior to her election, Rozic had been chief of staff to Assemblyman .\n\n\nIn 2012, , the former Democratic representative of the 25th District, decided to vacate his assembly seat. Rozic defeated Jerry Iannece from Bayside in the Democratic Party primary. Rozic received 55.6 percent of the vote to Iannece's 44.4. In the 2012 general election, Rozic went on to defeat Conservative Party nominee William N. Garifal Jr., and Republican candidate Abe Fuchs in the November general.\n\n\nIn the 2014 Assembly race, Rozic was unopposed in the Democratic primary. Rozic ran as the candidate of the Working Families Party and Independence Party. She was uncontested in the 2014 general election of the 25th Assembly District.\n\n\nRozic, running for a third term in 2016, was unopposed in the Democratic primary. \nRozic was challenged by Republican candidate Usman Ali Chohan in 2016. In the general election, Rozic won her third term with 76.36 percent of the vote (about 22,000 voters).\n\n\nShe was appointed to serve on the Assembly's Children and Families, Corporations, Authorities and Commissions, Correction, Environmental Conservation, and Labor Committees.\n\nShe was also a member of the Black, Puerto Rican, Hispanic & Asian Legislative Caucus and the Puerto Rican/Hispanic Task Force.\n\nShe serves on the Assembly's Ways & Means, Labor, Environmental Conservation, Correction, and Corporations, Authorities and Commissions Committees. In 2017, Nily was named as chair of the Task Force on Women's Issues.\n\n\nIn 2013, Rozic was named as a Rising Star on City & State's annual list of the Next Generation of Political Leaders for becoming an influential force in New York State politics as a young elected official.\n\n\nRozic lives in , .\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
          }

    "pages": }\n\n'''Sarahana Shrestha''' is a Nepalese-American democratic socialist politician and activist who is a member of the , representing the . She was first elected in November 2022.\n\n\nShrestha was born in , , and moved to the United States in 2001 to study computer science at the . She became an American citizen in 2019. Shrestha became interested in socialist politics as a college student.\n\n\n\nShrestha is affiliated with Public Power NY, a coalition of clean energy advocacy organizations. She has also worked as a graphic designer and is the co-chair of the 's Ulster County chapter. Shrestha focused her campaign on climate and renewable energy policy. She was endorsed by the Democratic Socialists of America, , and Congresswoman . Shrestha was elected in November 2022 and assumed office on January 1, 2023.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Christine Callaghan Quinn''' (born July 25, 1966) is an American politician. A member of the , she formerly served as the  of the . The third person to hold this office, she was the first female and first openly  speaker.Chibbaro, Jr., Lou.  , '''', January 20, 2006. Retrieved on 04-11-2007. She ran to succeed  as the city's mayor in the , but lost the Democratic primary. Quinn is a political contributor on  and .\n\n\nQuinn was born in , one of two daughters of Mary (née Callaghan) and Lawrence Quinn. Her mother died of breast cancer in 1982. She attended School of the Holy Child in the village of  on  in , and graduated from  in  in 1988. Her maternal grandmother, Ellen (née Shine) Callaghan, was a survivor of the sinking of the .\n\nShe served as head of the Housing Justice Campaign for the Association of Neighborhood and Housing Development. Quinn entered politics to manage the City Council campaign of  in 1991, after which she served as Duane's chief of staff for five years. She later became the executive director of the , and was appointed a member of the /Community Relations Task Force by then- .\n\n\n\nIn a 1999 special election, Quinn ran for  in the . The 3rd district covers the Manhattan neighborhoods of , , and , as well as parts of ,   and . Quinn became the Democratic nominee and defeated Republican Joseph Mauriello, 89%-11%.\n\nIn 2001 Quinn won a full term on the City Council, defeating Republican Michelle Bouchard 75%-25%. Because the district lines were redrawn after the 2000 census, her term lasted only two years. She was reelected in 2003 after the districts were redrawn according to population shifts (all council districts must have an equal number of residents). In 2005 she was reelected to a four-year term unopposed. In 2009 she was reelected to a third term with 81% of the vote.\n\n\n\nWhile on the City Council, Quinn served as Chair of the Health Committee. She sponsored the Equal Benefits Bill and the Health Care Security Act, which requires that city contractors provide parity in benefits between married spouses and registered s. This bill (along with the Health Care Security Act, which ensures health care for grocery workers) passed over Mayor 's veto. Quinn also \"shepherded\" a ban on indoor smoking at commercial establishments through the City Council; the bill passed 42–7.\n\n\n\nQuinn was elected Speaker of the New York City Council in January 2006 and reelected in 2010. She was the first female and first openly  person to hold this position.\n\n\nPreceding the controversial lecture by Iranian President  at  in 2007, Quinn wrote to the school requesting that his invitation to speak be withdrawn due to his support of  and hate speech, the latter particularly with regard to the . Her request was denied.\n\n\nUnder New York City law, the City Council Speaker has authority over the yearly City Council funds, worth almost $400 million (in 2012), to distribute among 51 members. This discretionary funding system, sometimes called the \"slush fund\", has been criticized, with some councilmembers alleging Quinn to have cut funding to their districts as a form of political retaliation. She repeatedly denied these allegations.\n\nIn April 2008 the '''' reported that Quinn's office had appropriated millions of dollars to organizations that did not exist, and that the money was then secretly routed to organizations favored by individual councilmembers. In a news conference that followed Quinn said, \"I had no knowledge of it; I did not know this was the practice\". She said she had found out about it only a few months earlier, alerted authorities, and ordered staffers to stop the practice, but that they did not listen. Quinn hired a criminal defense lawyer to represent her in the federal and city investigations. Records showed that nearly 25% of those \"secret slush\" funds went to organizations in Quinn's district and that two of the biggest recipients had contributed to Quinn's 2009 mayoral run. In September 2011 one of the city council's lawyers reported that the federal \"investigation has been closed without taking up any action,\" but only after two councilmen were indicted at the cost of $100,000 to the city.\n\n\nUnder Quinn's leadership, the  Council led efforts to make Greenmarkets accept food stamps. She also opposed requiring applicants for food stamps to be electronically fingerprinted.  stopped fingerprinting food-stamp recipients in 2007, but the practice continued in New York City under the Bloomberg administration.\n\n\nOn December 26, 2012, Quinn wrote a letter to President Obama formally requesting that he commute 's lifetime sentence for providing classified information to Israel. She wrote, \"I know I share similar views with many past and current American elected officials,\" and asked Obama to \"use [his] constitutional power to treat Mr. Pollard the way others have been treated by our nation's justice system.\"\n\n\nQuinn was a vigorous LGBT advocate during her tenure on the City Council. In 2006 she boycotted the annual  Parade in New York due to the policy of the parade's sponsor, the , against gays marching openly. The same year she tried unsuccessfully to broker a deal with the organizers to allow her to wear a  pin. Subsequently, she was named 2008 Irish-American of the Year by the New York-based '''' and has boycotted the parade every year since, marching instead in St. Patrick's Day parades in other cities around the world.\n\nIn November 2009 Quinn urged the New York Senate to pass same-sex marriage legislation, saying that \"she and her partner, lawyer Kim Catullo, [would] not get married until they [could do so] in New York. Near tears, she added: 'This is literally a moment when people can stand up and say that everybody's family matters, that everybody's home is a blessed place and that everybody has the same rights.'\"\n\nOn July 28, 2012, Quinn sent a letter demanding that the president of  end its relationship with , because of the stance of the company's CEO, Dan Cathy, against same-sex marriage.\n\n\nAccording to '''', \"[for] years, Quinn opposed term limits, a position that helped her get elected speaker by fellow Council members in 2005. Once in the job, though, she commissioned a poll, and it showed that the public opposed tinkering with them. In December 2007, Quinn declared that repealing term limits would be 'anti-democratic,' a position she called 'firm and final.'\" But in 2008 Quinn backed Mayor 's effort to overturn the two-term limit for New York City elected officials, saying she had changed her position due to concern about the impact a change in leadership could have on the city's economic recovery. In 2008 the Council voted to extend term limits to allow the mayor, City Council members, and borough presidents to run for third terms, reversing the results of the two previous public referenda. Bloomberg was subsequently elected to a third term as mayor, and Quinn to a third term on the City Council.\n\nPublic Advocate , among others, denounced this move. In June 2009 the City Council approved a 40% cut in the budget of the Public Advocate's Office. Gotbaum declared herself a victim of \"political payback\" because of her opposition to the changes in the term limits law, a notion Quinn claimed was \"ridiculous\". All five candidates for Public Advocate showed up at City Hall in June to protest the move, and in 2010 New Yorkers again voted overwhelmingly to limit politicians to two consecutive terms.\n\n\n\nOn March 10, 2013, after much speculation, Quinn announced that she was running for . (, the incumbent, was term-limited and could not run again.)\n\nWidely viewed as Bloomberg's heir apparent, Quinn was considered the early frontrunner in the nine-candidate race for the Democratic nomination. During her mayoral campaign, multiple media outlets reported on Quinn's temper; ''''  reported that her staff had her City Council office soundproofed due to her outbursts. Quinn's rivals attacked her for reversing her position on mayoral term limits and supporting Bloomberg's bid for a third term in 2009. In August 2013 '''' opined that Quinn's primary chances were damaged by Bloomberg's \"tacit endorsement\" of her campaign, and in September '''' asserted that her change in position on term limits had also harmed her chances. Quinn's campaign faded as time went on, and she finished third in the primary. She received 15.5% of the vote, while winner  received 40.3% and  26.2%.\n\n\nIn 2013 Quinn's memoir, ''With Patience and Fortitude A Memoir'', was published by . It sold poorly, with ''The New York Times'' reporting only 100 copies sold its first week.\n\nIn October 2014 Quinn stumped for the Women's Equality Party established by New York Governor  in July 2014. When asked about the 's criticism of the creation of a competing progressive party, she said, \"Change is hard.\" In January 2015 Cuomo hired Quinn as a special advisor.\n\nIn 2015, Quinn became president and CEO of Women in Need (WIN), a nonprofit organization that is one of New York City's largest providers of services to homeless women and children. Her annual salary is $350,000. Since Quinn's first job was as a housing organizer for poor and homeless people, she noted that she had come full circle with her new job. Quinn said she was hoping to continue the good work of WIN's previous longtime leader, Bonnie Stone, and use a holistic approach to help women facing domestic violence, eviction, and other issues. Before accepting the position at WIN, Quinn fought against a homeless shelter planned for her own neighborhood of Chelsea.\n\nQuinn made headlines in 2018 for her comments about 's campaign for the Democratic gubernatorial nomination. Referring to her own 2013 mayoral candidacy, Quinn said, \"Cynthia Nixon was opposed to having a qualified lesbian become mayor of New York City\", and added, \"Now she wants to be an unqualified lesbian to be the governor of New York. [Being] an actress and celebrity doesn’t make you qualified for public office\".\n\nIn 2019, Quinn and WIN drew criticism from the press (including a masthead editorial in ''The New York Daily News'') for two contracts to operate homeless shelters in South Park Slope, Brooklyn. The allegations, verified by multiple journalists, included that the contracts contained up to $89 million of unexplained and apparently inflated costs. WIN and Quinn repeatedly declined to comment when asked for an explanation of the cost. One of the shelters opened in 2020.\n\nThough Quinn was designated an  in the , Manhattan Borough President  served as her alternate.\n\n\nQuinn resides in , with her wife, Kim Catullo, a lawyer. They married on May 19, 2012, and spend their summer weekends at a home they bought in 2004 in . Her former partner, Laura Morrison, was chief of staff to former State Senator .\n\nQuinn joined the board of , an organization fighting  in sports, in February 2014. She is Catholic.\n\n\n* \n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n* \n*\n*\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
          }

    "pages": }\n'''Lester Chang''' (Chinese: 鄭永佳) is an American businessman, naval reservist, and politician who represents the  of the , which comprises part of . A , he defeated longtime  incumbent  in .\n\n\nLester Chang was born in the  neighborhood of  to parents from . When he was 8 years old, his father died of  and the family moved to  before moving to . Chang graduated from , then  with a  in  and the  with a  in international transportation.\n\n\nChang previously worked in banking as well as international shipping logistics.\n\n\n\nChang is a retired member of the  and current member of the . In the aftermath of , he was assigned to  and was deployed to ,  as a military analyst.\n\n\nChang first ran for office in the  for the  to succeed  following his resignation due to a corruption scandal. He was on the ballot for the Republican, , , and 'Clean Up This Mess' party lines. He placed third behind Democrat  and -endorsed  respectively.\n\nIn 2020, he ran in the , losing to incumbent Democrat .\n\nIn 2022, Chang announced he would run against longtime Democratic incumbent  in the . The redrawn district is majority Asian-American and includes parts of the Southern Brooklyn communities of , ,  and . In an upset attributed to Republican organizing in the traditionally Democratic-leaning , Chang defeated Abatte.\n\n\nFollowing his election to the State Assembly, the  attempted to block Chang from being seated. Proponents claimed that Chang had been living in  and was therefore ineligible to have been elected under New York's one-year residency requirement for candidates. Chang claimed to have lived in Manhattan until 2019, when his late wife passed away, before moving back to Brooklyn; but records show he had voted in Manhattan in 2021 and previously ran for office there in 2016 and 2020. Critics of the move pointed out that his ballot petitions could have been challenged in court before the election, but Democrats waited until after he had already won.\n\nAn investigation organized by   concluded that Chang did own an apartment in Manhattan, but he fulfilled the residency requirements to run in the district.\n\nThe '''' editorial board published an article in support of Chang taking his Assembly seat, noting hypocrisy from Brooklyn Democratic Party Chair  and Heastie.\n\n\nChang lives in his childhood home in . He has spoken about receiving mental health treatment for , the death of his wife from cancer in 2019, and aiding his 95-year-old mother who suffers from .\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n*  at the \n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Nelson Castro''' (born January 25, 1972) is an American politician from the state of . A , he was first elected to the New York State Assembly in  in 2008. Castro resigned from office in 2013 after pleading guilty to perjury charges. He is notable for having worn a wire as an FBI informant while serving in elected office; in so doing, he assisted the federal government in prosecuting other corrupt elected officials.\n\n\n\nIn 2008, Castro was first elected to the  in District 86; the district includes the , , and  sections of the Bronx.  He succeeded  and became the first Dominican to represent the Bronx in the State Assembly. In July 2009, the  charged Castro with perjury. The charges were kept secret, and Castro agreed to cooperate with the Bronx County District Attorney and later with the FBI. Castro proceeded to win re-election in 2010 and 2012, but was living a \"double life\" as an FBI informant during that time. Information obtained by Castro was used to prosecute six other corrupt elected officials. While Castro's original deal did not involve jail time, he was charged in 2013 with lying to investigators. In 2013, Castro's role as an FBI informant became public knowledge during the scandal affecting his Assembly colleague, . Castro resigned his Assembly seat on April 8, 2013. He later pleaded guilty to the 2009 state charges and the 2013 federal charge against him. In September 2014, Castro received a sentence of two years' probation and 500 hours of community service for his federal crimes. On November 17, 2014, Castro was given a three-year conditional discharge for his state crimes.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
          }
        ]

    "pages": }\n'''Nicholas A. Langworthy''' (born February 27, 1981) is an American politician serving as the  for  since 2023. He was formerly the chair of the . Langworthy was named chair of the committee in July 2019 after having chaired the   since 2010. He was the youngest state chair in party history.\n\n\nLangworthy was born in .  He attended the Pine Valley Central School in his hometown of  and graduated in 1999. After graduation, he attended , where he established the university's branch of the . He graduated from Niagara with a  in  and chaired the .\n\n\n\nAfter ing at Governor  office and running a congressional campaign for Brett Sommer in 2000, Langworthy became a staffer for  . He managed Reynolds's successful reelection campaigns in 2004 and 2006. While working for Reynolds, Langworthy met his future wife, Erin Baker, who also worked on Reynolds's staff. Langworthy later managed the successful 2008 campaign of Representative  and served as Lee's district office director until May 2010.\n\nLangworthy is the founder and president of a  firm, Liberty Opinion Research.\n\n\nErie County Republican Committee Chair James P. Domagalski resigned his chairmanship in 2010 to run for the . An early front-runner for the county chairship, Langworthy made himself as visible as possible on the county and state Republican scenes. Langworthy unanimously won a special election for the chairship, becoming the youngest chair of either political party in Erie County's history. He was the only Republican county chair to endorse  in the ; he emerged as a political powerhouse when Paladino won the primary.  Paladino's primary upset, together with the Republicans' successful effort to take control of the Erie County legislature, led '''' chief political columnist Bob McCarthy to call Langworthy the \"GOP's Young Elder\".\n\nIn 2016,   announced that Langworthy would serve on the executive committee of his . Langworthy had been a vocal supporter of Trump's presidential campaign.\n\nIn September 2019, it was announced that Langworthy would be succeeded as Erie County chair by  Republican chair Karl J. Simmeth Jr.\n\n\n\nIn 2018, Langworthy began campaigning for the chairship of the  against incumbent state chairman . On May 20, 2019, after Monroe County Republican Chair Bill Reilich announced his support for Langworthy, Cox announced that he was withdrawing his candidacy for a new term as chair; the '''' reported that Langworthy was \"poised to become\" the next chair of the Republican Committee. On July 1, 2019, Langworthy was named chair of the New York State Republican Committee. He is the youngest state chair in party history.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nIn June 2022, U.S. Representative , who was running in , announced that he would withdraw from the race and not seek reelection. Langworthy subsequently announced his candidacy for the seat, which represents part of  and most of the . He won the August 24 Republican primary, defeating . In the general election, Langworthy defeated Democratic nominee Max Della Pia.\n\n\n\n* \n\n\n\nOn June 11, 2024, Langworthy  (at 6:36 in video) against including H.R.1282 -  in the FY 25 NDAA.  This despite the fact that he is listed as a co-sponsor of the .\n\n\nLangworthy's wife, Erin Baker Langworthy, ran unsuccessfully for  Town Board in 2017. She served as finance chair of the Erie County Republican Committee.\n\n\n\n\n\n*  official U.S. House website\n* \n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Annette Robinson''' (born 1940) formerly represented the 56th district of the , which includes most of ,  and , from 2002 to 2016.\n\n\nAnnette Marie Robinson was born in  and raised in Bedford-Stuyvesant,  where she was active in the local  church and the community. She studied dance and performed at the  at age 8. Oral History|website=oralhistory.brooklynhistory.org|access-date=2019-05-09}} She holds B.S. and master's degrees from New Hampshire College (now ).\n\n\nRobinson's career in politics began in 1977 when she was elected as a Community School Board District 16 member. She went on to work for N.Y.C. Comptroller  serving three terms-as Coordinator and Liaison, and District Director for U.S. Congressman  and in 1991, was elected to the  representing Bedford-Stuyvesant.\n\nShe was term limited from her City Council position in 2000 and was chosen in a  held in 2002. Robinson garnered over 90% of the vote in the special election and served as the District Leader/State Committeewoman for the 56th Assembly District. Her office was at Restoration Plaza, in  former space.\n\nRobinson announced that she would be retiring in 2016. On Saturday April 16, 2016, Robinson officially endorsed Brooklyn Community Board 3 chairperson  to succeed her in the 56th assembly district. The endorsement took place at the campaign announcement for Tremaine Wright. Robinson stated that she was very proud to pass the torch to candidate Wright.\n\nAfter her retirement, she continued to serve as the female Democratic District leader of the 56th Assembly district, and the Vice Chair of the , making her the second in command behind  .\n\n\nIn addition to her work in the New York Assembly, Robinson is the Vice-Chairwoman of the '''New York State Council of Black Elected Democrats'''.\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Emily E. Gallagher''' (born March 23, 1984) is an American politician. She is the  representative serving District 50 in the , which comprises parts of ,  and , among other neighborhoods located in the northern portion of the   of .\n\n\n\nGallagher grew up in , and moved to  shortly after graduating from  in 2006.\n\n\nGallagher became involved in politics while attending Ithaca College in 2002.  After moving to Brooklyn in 2006, she became deeply involved in neighborhood organizing especially around social and environmental justice organizing, and eventually came to know many local players and issues in the community over a decade of grassroots participation.  At the time, Gallagher was uninspired by local politics because she did not see used to advance social justice.  However, she did see the value of politicians who were willing to \"stick their neck out\" in office, and began to reconsider her position, becoming involved with the Brooklyn political organization New Kings Democrats. \nIn 2016, New Kings Democrats approached Gallagher to consider a run for District Leader.   \nGallagher ran for Democratic leader of New York's 50th State Assembly district against 32-year incumbent Linda Minucci. She was endorsed by Congresswoman  and New York City Council Member , but ultimately lost with 44.9% of the vote.\n\nGallagher was soon after appointed to , where she worked on transportation issues, the environment, and uncovering community board abuses. As a community board member, Gallagher learned that the City had provided grant funding for community engagement.  After several months trying to trace the money, the Board Chair Gerald Esposito admitted that the $26,000 had been spent to buy a RAV-4 SUV to “To go different places,”   She was then removed from the board the following year by Brooklyn Borough President Eric Adams. \n\n\nOn September 23, 2019, Gallagher launched a campaign against incumbent  for the Democratic primary to represent District 50 in the . Gallagher ran on a platform of , housing justice, and transit improvement, and received endorsements from New Kings Democrats, New York Communities for Change and the Brooklyn Young Democrats. A member of the Brooklyn , she sought their endorsement but did not receive it due to Brooklyn DSA's limited capacity and desire to focus on building power in working-class communities of color.\n\nGallagher's team had to quickly pivot in March 2020 when the COVID 19 epidemic necessitated a universal shut down.  Their campaign pivoted to completely rely on phone banking, text banking, events on the video chat platform Zoom, and holding virtual fundraisers.  Their campaign was run with 25-30 core volunteers. \n\nOn primary election night, June 23, 2020, Gallagher trailed Lentol by 1,763 votes based on in-person totals.  were more significant than usual, however, due to the , and once they were counted, Gallagher was determined to have won by between 400-600 votes. In the final certified result, Gallagher won by 1,151 votes. On June 28, 2022, Gallagher won the Democratic primary with 79.5% of the votes over Paddy O'Sullivan.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
          }
        ]
      }

    "pages": }\n\n'''Peter D. Lopez''' (born April 10, 1961) is a politician who served in the  from the 102nd Assembly District (established in 2012), which includes all of  and portions of , , , , ,  counties from 2007 to 2017. He is a .\n\nOn October 1, 2017, Lopez became the regional administrator for the 's region 2, based in New York City.\n\n\nLopez was born in ; his family moved to , where he was raised. He graduated from Schoharie Central School, the , and the , where he received a  degree in 1988.\n\n\nLopez became interested in public service as a young man, joining the  and running for the Schoharie Village Board at the age of 20. He lost to a candidate endorsed by the mayor. Lopez later won a seat on the Village Board and later was elected as Supervisor.\n\nLopez worked as staff to the New York State Legislature for 21 years, collaborating with a broad range of public and private interests at the federal, state and local levels. Among his position was as associate director of the Senate Agriculture Committee (Senator John R. Kuhl, Jr., chairman), and assistant director of the Legislative Commission on Rural Resources (Senator Charles D. Cook, chairman). He also served as the District Office Director for Assembly Minority Leader , who ran for Governor of New York in 2006, and managed constituent services, including helping seniors and veterans access benefits.\n\nIn 2004, Lopez was elected County Clerk with about 70 percent of the vote; he served until 2006.\n\n\nLopez was first elected to the State Assembly in November 2006, when he defeated  professor Scott Trees. He won a total of 58 percent of the vote on the Republican, , and  party lines.  Lopez ran uncontested in the November 2008 and November 2010 s. In 2012 he won from the newly defined 102nd Assembly district.\n\nLopez supported energy conservation and the development of alternative energy sources in the Mohawk Valley, including ., ''Daily Freeman'', 24 October 2012 In 2007 he and his staff organized a tour of the , , and  wind farms in New York state. Lopez also supports biodiesel research and development in the state, as well as tourism, family farms, and manufacturing.\n\nLopez has fought against the opioid epidemic, sponsoring Laree's Law, which holds drug dealers accountable for the deaths caused by the sale of opioids and other narcotics. Lopez has also been vocal about Albany's culture of corruption, and called on fellow lawmakers to strip the pensions of  and , who were (in Silver's case, initially) convicted of corruption charges. Silver's conviction was overturned by the  on July 13, 2017.\n\n\nOn September 28, 2017, , administrator of the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, named Lopez to be regional administrator for region 2. The region 2 office is based in , and its area of responsibility is , ,  and the .\n\nLopez is due to begin his position at the EPA on Oct. 1, at which point he will resign his assembly seat. New York Governor  has the responsibility to call a special election for the 102nd district.\n\n\nLopez is a member of the SUNY Cobleskill Foundation Board as well as the Bassett Hospital Board. He is a black belt in .\n\nHe has been a member of an advisory committee on runaway and troubled youth, and Chairman of the Schoharie Main Street Committee. He was a founding member of  of Schoharie County., Hispanic Coalition of New York, Inc., 2011, accessed 30 December 2014\n\n\n* He received the Distinguished Alumni Award from both SUNY Cobleskill and SUNY Albany, the State University of New York's Golden Anniversary Chancellor's Recognition award, the New York State Masons' General Douglas MacArthur Award for Service to Youth, and the Schoharie County Chamber of Commerce's Leader of the Year Award.\n*In 2012, he received the ''Times Journal'' Star of the Year Award for his dedicated efforts in helping communities recover from the devastation of  in 2011 and .\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''George Onorato''' (November 5, 1928 – February 21, 2015) was an American politician from .\n\n\nOnorato was born on November 5, 1928, in , . He graduated from . He served in the  of the  from 1950 to 1952. He married Athena Georgakakos, and they had three children.\n\nHe was Secretary and Treasurer of Local 41 of the  for 15 years, and entered politics as a .\n\nOn June 28, 1983, he was elected to the , to fill the vacancy caused by the appointment of  as Chairman of the New York State Liquor Authority. Onorato was re-elected several times, and remained in the State Senate until 2010, sitting in the , , , , , , , , , , , ,  and s. He was Vice Chair of the Minority Conference, Co-chair of the New York State Armed Forces Legislative Caucus, and Co-Chairman of the New York State Senate Democratic Task Force on Energy & Conservation. He generally opposes same-sex marriage legislation. He is a member of New York State Senate Democratic Puerto Rican and Hispanic Task Force, the Senate Minority Task Force on Vietnam Veterans, and the Senate Minority Task Force on Waterfront Development.\n\nOn December 2, 2009, Onorato voted against  legislation, which failed to pass the Senate.\n\nOnorato announced on January 11, 2010, that he would not be a candidate for re-election.\n\nHe died on February 21, 2015, in .\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Diane J. Savino''' (born September 28, 1963) is an American  politician who represented the  in the , in northern  and parts of southern , including , , , , and . She currently serves as a senior advisor to  .\n\nFrom January 2011 to April 2018, Savino was a founding member of the , a group of eight Democratic state senators who formed a separate conference and allied themselves with Senate Republicans. Savino and her IDC colleagues rejoined the Senate Democratic Conference in April 2018. Savino was one of only two former members of the IDC that survived primary challenges in the s.\n\n\nSavino was born in  and went on to graduate from .  She has a psychology degree from  as well as a degree in Industrial and Labor Relations from .\n\nPrior to elected office, Savino began her career in public service as a caseworker for , providing direct assistance to abused and neglected children. She was an active member of her local labor union, the Social Service Employees Union, Local 371, DC 37 of AFSCME, and became the Vice President for Political Action & Legislative Affairs.\n\n\n.]]\nIn 2004, Savino was elected to represent the . She succeeded longtime Senator , who had retired.\n\nOn December 2, 2009, Savino voted for  legislation, which failed to pass the Senate. Her speech on same-sex marriage became popular on the Internet. Subsequently, in 2011, the  passed the Senate and became law; Savino voted for this bill as well.\n\nIn 2011, Savinotogether with Democratic Sens. , , and formed the  (IDC). The IDC caucused separately from the other State Senate Democrats; eventually, in December 2012, it entered into a power-sharing arrangement with Senate Republicans. When the Republican Conference won enough seats for outright control of the Senate in 2014, Savino and the rest of the IDC chose to remain aligned with them.\n\nAs a member of the IDC, Savino was provided with a , known as a \"lulu\", worth $13,500 per year that is designated by Legislative Law 5-1 for the Chair of the Senate Codes Committee. Senate Republicans named her Vice Chair of that committee, reserving the chairmanship for a Republican; in order to provide the stipend to Savino, payroll officials falsified state documents.\n\nIn 2014,  was legalized in New York; Savino was the lead sponsor of that legislation. Savino has also sponsored proposed legislation that would legalize physician-assisted suicide.\n\nSavino and her IDC colleagues rejoined the Senate Democratic Conference in April 2018. In the 2018 Democratic Primary, Savino defeated Jasmine Robinson, a legal secretary who had been endorsed by the progressive groups Citizen Action of New York and , by a 67-21% margin. Savino was one of only two former IDC members (along with ) to win their primary races. In the 2018 general election, Savino defeated her Republican opponent, David Krainert, by a 69-28% margin.\n\nIn early 2022, Savino stated that she supported the creation of a new congressional district in Brooklyn which consists of Asian-American voting residential majority. As of January 2023, the new New York State Senate district that she represented includes the neighborhood of . Other sections of her district in Brooklyn were removed.\n\nSavino has announced that she will not be running for reelection to the state senate in .\n\n\n* In 2004, Savino was first elected to the State Senate with 39,833 votes; her Republican opponent, Al Curtis, received 23,361 votes.\n* In 2008, Savino was re-elected with 46,386 votes. Her Republican opponent, Richard Thomas, received 12,621 votes.\n* In 2010, Savino was unopposed in the general election.\n* In 2012, Savino was re-elected with 50,553 votes; her Republican opponent, Lisa Grey, received 15,131 votes., New York State Senate. 29 January 2014. Accessed 2 May 2015.\n* In 2014, Savino was unopposed in the general election.\n* In 2016, Savino was unopposed in the primary and general election.\n* In 2018, Savino won the Democratic nomination with 67% of the votes cast defeating Democrat Jasmine Robinson.  She won the general election with 69% of the votes cast.\nIn the 2018 general election, Savino defeated her Republican opponent, David Krainert, by a 69-28% margin.[23]\n\n\n\n\n\nAs of 2018, Savino was in a long-term relationship with then-State Senator . The Italian-American politician is known for her early to bed, early to rise lifestyle.Elizabeth A. Harris, \"Cleanliness Is Next to Politics,\" ''New York Times'', March 27, 2011, WE section p. 2. She lives by herself in .  She is a self-admitted \"neurotic cleaner\". New York politician  once tricked her into cleaning his apartment.\n\n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* \n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }'''John Mikulin''' (born April 7, 1988) is a member of the  representing the 17th district, which includes portions of the towns of  and  in  on . A , Mikulin was first elected in a 2018 special election.\n\nMikulin was born and raised in . An attorney, he attended  where he attained a B.A., a M.A. and his J.D at . Prior to serving in the legislature, Mikulin was President of the Island Trees Library Board and served as the Deputy Town Attorney in the Town of Hempstead.\n\nIn 2017, Assemblyman  opted to run for the , and won. Required to vacate his seat, a special election was called for April 24, 2018. Mikulin soon after was nominated by local Republicans to run for the seat. A safely Republican seat, Mikulin went on to defeat Democrat Matthew W. Malin with 63% of the vote.  He was easily reelected to a full term in 2018.\n\nMikulin and his wife, Corinne, reside in Bethpage.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''David J. DiPietro''' (born June 22, 1960) is a  member of the  representing Assembly District 147, which comprises the southern halves of  and .\n\n\nDiPietro was born in .  His parents moved the family to the Village of East Aurora where he subsequently attended Immaculate Conception Elementary and .  He earned a degree in Business Administration from Wittenberg University in 1985.\n\nDiPietro began his career at  in Buffalo but left after a few years to work as a consultant to small businesses.  In 1991 he assumed control of his parents' dry cleaning business in .\n\n\nHe was elected a trustee of the Village of East Aurora in 1999 and mayor in 2002.  After serving as mayor for six years, he set his sights on higher office, running in the Republican primary for the 59th New York State Senate District against incumbent  in 2008 and challenger  in 2010.  He ran unsuccessfully as the  candidate in the 2010 general election for the senate seat.\n\nIn 2012, he won a seat in the New York State Assembly, where he demonstrated conservative views. In 2013, he introduced legislation to repeal the .\nHe voted against proposed medical marijuana legislation, the Compassionate Care Act (Bill A6357), and motions dated June 3, 2013 (94-41) and May 27, 2014 (94-63). DiPietro was one of 13 nay votes when the bill passed on June 20, 2014 (117-13). He voted against emergency access to medical marijuana (Bill A07060) on June 9, 2015; the bill passed, 130-18. However, DiPietro voted for adding  to the list of conditions treatable by medical marijuana (Bill A09016) on June 6, 2018 (108-28). In 2019 Assemblyman DiPietro became the Assembly sponsor of Bill# A05498 which proposes a constitutional amendment to .\nDiPietro voted against key votes related to policies concerning affirmative action, paid family leave, increasing the minimum wage and prohibiting workplace discrimination based on reproductive health decisions. He voted against state-funded projects  and a three-year prohibition of .\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

Steck''' (born July 8, 1959) is a  member of the  representing , which comprises the eastern portions of  and northern portions of .\n\n\nSteck is the son of Ernest, a high school athletic director, and Roselyn, a middle school teacher. He played varsity football and graduated the valedictorian of his class from  in 1977. He earned a degree in Government from  in 1981 and a law degree from the  in 1984. In college, he interned on the staff of Congressman . For several years after college, he worked as an assistant district attorney in  and  Counties. He then entered private practice for the  law firm of  where he has worked ever since.\n\n\n\nSteck's political career began in 1999 when he was elected to the Albany County Legislature; he served three terms there.\n\nIn 2008, he ran for Congress in , but lost in the Democratic primary.\n\nIn 2012, Steck won a seat in the .\n\nHe endorsed  for the .\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n*\n*\n*\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''James F. Gaughran''' (born January 5, 1957) is an American attorney and politician from , , who served as a member of the  from . The district is located around the border of  and , encompassing the town of  and the northern part of the town of . Gaughran is a member of the .\n\nGaughran served as the chair of the Suffolk County Water Authority from 2010 to 2018. He previously served as a member of the  from 1988 to 1993, and as a member of the  Town Board from 1984 to 1987.\n\nIn , Gaughran was elected to the  from , defeating the long-time  incumbent, . He took office on January 1, 2019.\n\n\n\nGaughran was raised in , and attended . He earned a  degree from , where he majored in . Subsequently, he earned a  degree from  .\n\n\n\n\nGaughran was elected to the  Town Board in 1983, at the age of 26. He became the youngest member of the Town Board in the history of the town.\n\nDuring his tenure, Gaughran was the lone Democrat on the Town Board. He authored bills creating municipal solid waste districts and enacting environmental protections.\n\n\nIn 1987, Gaughran was elected to the  from the 17th legislative district.\n\nGaughran authored a charter amendment which reduced the Legislature's authority to increase spending by adding \"pet projects\" to the budget; the amendment was approved by voters in a referendum. He also cosponsored a water protection bill preserving numerous critical areas in the county, a \"\" law targeting drug dealers, as well as reforms to the .\n\n\nGaughran was confirmed by the  to the Suffolk County Water Authority (SCWA) for a five-year term in March 2008. He was reappointed by the Legislature in March 2013 and March 2018.\n\nFollowing the retirement of SCWA chair (and former interim )  in May 2010, Gaughran was appointed as the new SCWA chair. As chair, he implemented reforms emphasizing accountability and transparency. He also reduced the payroll of the SCWA by 6% over four years.\n\nAfter his election to the  in 2018, Gaughran resigned as SCWA chair. He was succeeded by fellow SCWA board member (and former Suffolk County Executive) .\n\n\nGaughran ran for comptroller of Suffolk County in 2014, losing the general election to county legislator  by 6 percentage points.\n\n\n\n\n\n\nGaughran first ran for the  from  in 1992; his opponent in the general election was the long-time  incumbent, .\n\nThe 5th district \"straddles the - border\", and includes the town of  and the northern part of the town of . Thus, the district includes all or parts of the  of , , , , , , , and .\n\nIn December 1991, Marino, who was the senate majority leader at the time, became known for his \"budget-wrangling\" which led to the infamous \"Hamlet on the Hudson\" incident, in which   kept a plane bound for New Hampshire idling on a tarmac on the last day to file for the 1992 first-in-the-nation presidential primary in that state, while he tried to negotiate a state budget with the Republican-controlled senate. Although he had been perceived as a frontrunner for the , Cuomo declined to run for president, saying that he was \"willing\" but not \"able\" to campaign due to the unresolved state budget crisis.\n\nThe 1992 campaign was extremely bitter, with Marino accusing Gaughran of improperly conspiring with a fiscally conservative group called Pack-Up (an acronym for \"Political Action Committee to Kick out Unproductive Politicians\"), and Gaughran accusing Marino of using state funds to finance the distribution of his campaign mailings. The campaign was the most expensive state senate campaign up to that point, eclipsing the previous record of $910,000 set in 1990, and took place concurrently with a similarly rancorous  between the  incumbent,  , and the  challenger,  .\n\nIn the campaign, Gaughran drew a surprising contrast between himself and Marino: he charged that Marino symbolized \"clubhouse politics\" and big government in Albany, and that Marino \"voted for every state tax increase and every mandate on localities passed by the Legislature\", while Gaughran himself signed a pledge to vote against any tax increase. Gaughran also chose environmental protection as a signature issue of his campaign, highlighting Marino's opposition to a state environmental trust fund and saying that Marino was \"selling Long Island out on the environment\".\n\nUltimately, Marino defeated Gaughran with a larger-than-expected margin of over 20 percentage points.\n\n\nGaughran ran against Marino's successor, , in 2016.\n\nMarino had resigned from the state senate in February 1995 following his defeat in a senate caucus vote for another term as senate majority leader by , an ally of Marino's intraparty rival  . Marcellino had won the special election on March 14, 1995, to replace Marino, and had been reelected to ten full two-year terms, remaining in office since then.\n\nGaughran was unopposed in the Democratic primary. The general election was closer than expected, but Marcellino defeated Gaughran by 1,761 votes out of almost 160,000 votes, or about one percentage point.\n\n\n\n\nGaughran announced in February 2018 that he would seek a re-match with Marcellino, who was seeking his 12th full two-year term. Gaughran was again unopposed in the Democratic primary.\n\nAn analysis conducted by '''' found that, before 2018, the last Democratic candidate to win a state senate election on  in a midterm year was  in 1982; Berman defeated  to win a third term before losing to Skelos in a rematch in 1984.\n\nGaughran was endorsed by '''', '''', and numerous local labor unions and activist groups. Campaign spending on behalf of both Gaughran and Marcellino was unusually prolific, reaching at least $2.8 million. Outside spending on behalf of Gaughran included $494,000 from the , $136,000 from the , and $15,000 from the New York State Nurses Association. An advisory from the political blog '''' to left-leaning small donors included Gaughran among eight state legislature candidates in key races across the country; according to Gaughran's campaign, this \"shout-out\" attracted more than $47,000 in individual contributions from about 4,000 donors.\n\nGaughran won the 2018 election, defeating Marcellino by almost 10,000 votes out of about 118,000 votes, or about 8.5 percentage points. Gaughran's victory formed part of the successful campaign by the  to retake the majority in the  for the first time in a decade, and just the fourth time in 80 years.\n\n\n\n\nGaughran ran for a second term in 2020. The Republican nominee was Huntington town board member Edmund Smyth.\n\nA  law passed in 2019 became a major campaign issue for Gaughran and other Long Island Democrats facing a difficult reelection. Smyth was endorsed by 23  angered by the bail reform law, as well as by police reforms enacted in response to the  in May 2020; the reforms included the repeal of a state statute that had allowed departments to conceal records of police misconduct. The police unions, alongside separate  groups including Safe Together New York (which received $1.7 million from businessman ) and the Long Island Law Enforcement Foundation, spent millions of dollars in advertisements targeting Democratic state senators including Gaughran.\n\nBy October, attack ads against Gaughran claimed that he \"voted to release violent criminals\" and that \"New York's crime wave is no accident &mdash; state senator Jim Gaughran voted for it\". Even as some observers noted that the claim that the bail reform law caused the increase in crime in 2020 contradicted official crime data, an internal Democratic poll showed that the ads were successful in damaging Gaughran's standing among voters. Gaughran responded with ads featuring him speaking directly to the camera: \"If the attacks they are throwing at me seem crazy, well, that's because they are\". According to Gaughran, the massive spending against him ultimately backfired: \"To be honest with you, it was very effective in generating volunteers [for Gaughran]\".\n\nAfter endorsing Gaughran in both his 2016 and 2018 campaigns, '''' endorsed Smyth in 2020. Assessing Gaughran's performance in his first term, the editorial board praised his successful efforts on the  cap and the bail reform law, but criticized his proposed bill to resolve local tax negotiations with the  (LIPA), calling it \"unworkable\".\n\nVoting in  was impacted by the ; many more voters  than in previous elections, which delayed the reporting of results. In New York, in-person votes were tabulated before postal votes, so a phenomenon known as a \"\" occurred. On November 4, the results showed Gaughran trailing Smyth, 55,132 votes to 69,015, a margin of over 11 percentage points. Election analysts estimated that Gaughran would have to win about 70% of the absentee ballots in order to make up the difference, but acknowledged that this was possible because the Democratic Party had encouraged postal voting while the Republican Party generally discouraged it. Indeed, on November 18, Gaughran overtook Smyth in the vote count, and Smyth conceded the election.\n\nThe final results showed Gaughran defeating Smyth by 3,135 votes out of about 167,000, or about 2 percentage points. Gaughran's victory in a competitive district helped the Democratic Party win a two-thirds  in the state senate in 2020.\n\n\n*Committee on Alcoholism and Substance Abuse (2019&ndash;2020)\n*Committee on Commerce, Economic Development, and Small Business (2019&ndash;2020)\n*Committee on Corporations, Authorities, and Commissions (2021&ndash;2022)\n*'Committee on Energy and Telecommunications (2021&ndash;2022)\n*Committee on Higher Education (2019&ndash;2022)\n*Committee on Investigations and Government Operations (2021&ndash;2022)\n*Committee on Local Government (''Chair'', 2019&ndash;2022)\n*Committee on Racing, Gaming, and Wagering (2019&ndash;2022)\n*Committee on Women's Issues (2019&ndash;2020)\n\n\nGaughran took office on January 1, 2019. On January 6, 2019, Gaughran held an in-district inauguration ceremony.\n\n the bill is nicknamed \"Ryan's Law\" after twelve-year-old Ryan Weiss, who died in July 2017 during a boating lesson, in an accident that would likely not have been fatal had propeller guards been in place. The bill is simultaneously sponsored in the  by , who  in September 2017. -->\n\nOn January 17, 2019, Gaughran introduced  to make permanent the property tax cap of 2% enacted in 2011. Gaughran said the following about his rationale for introducing the bill:\nToday I took the first step and introduced vital legislation to make the property tax cap permanent. No more temporary extensions....\nWe're beginning to feel the devastating effects of the federal limit on state and local tax deductions.... It is critical that New York State takes steps to providing real tax relief to Long Islanders, while the federal government continues its attack on New York taxpayers. The Democratic senate majority is going to provide local municipalities and school districts with mandate reform and increase state aid to our region to help lower local tax levies....\nGaughran's bill was passed by the senate almost unanimously on January 23, 2019;  and , both Democrats, were the only two votes against Gaughran's bill.\n\nIn March 2021, Gaughran joined the other four Democratic state senators from Long Island in calling for |Gov. Andrew Cuomo to resign amid . After an investigation by  , Cuomo resigned in August 2021 facing a likely impeachment and removal by the state legislature.\n\nIn May 2021, Gaughran introduced  to establish a public water authority in  to replace New York American Water, the private supplier which charges residents the highest prices in the region. The bill was passed by the legislature in June 2021, and was signed by   on November 3, 2021.\n\n\n\nIn his 2018 endorsement by '''', which is the largest newspaper on  by circulation and , Gaughran is described as a \"moderate and suburbanite ... who would protect Long Island against a New York City-centric agenda\".\n\n\nGaughran supports \"simple remedies\" which would reduce corruption in , such as:\n*prohibiting outside income for legislators,\n*closing a loophole that allows large political donors to hide their identities and to legally exceed campaign finance limits via s,\n*requiring legislators to reveal conflicts of interest,\n*banning the personal use of campaign funds,\n*allowing for the recall of elected officials via public petition.\n\n\nGaughran touts his experience with environmental policy as the chair of the Suffolk County Water Authority. He supports a ban on , and a reduction in  usage by 40% by the year 2030. He also favors measures targeting , for its effects both on food-insecure households and on the environment.\n\n\nGaughran believes that the  should be expanded; he favors banning s and extending the background check waiting period from three to ten days.\n Following the successful passage of the legislation through the state senate, Gaughran praised the efforts of activist movements such as  and other  which raised awareness of , saying:\nToday I have the great honor of hosting Linda Beigel Schulman and Michael Schulman, parents of the late Scott Beigel, who was tragically gunned down in  last year while heroically saving the lives of his students. I thank them for their tremendous bravery and courage in turning their tragedy into advocacy. It shouldn't take a tragedy to spur action. Never again.\nThe legislation was passed by the state legislature on January 29, 2019, and was signed by Gov. Andrew Cuomo shortly thereafter. -->\n\n\nIn 2018, Gaughran expressed his intention to vote for the , which will establish a . However, after he was elected, he reneged on his promise to support the bill. In 2019, the New York Health Act was cosponsored by 31 senators, which was one short of a majority, and Gaughran and  were identified as two senators who had previously expressed support for the bill but declined to cosponsor it. In 2020, Gaughran's campaign website did not mention the New York Health Act.\n\n\nGaughran supports classifying  and expression as \"protected classes\", meaning that existing state laws prohibiting discrimination would then apply (''viz.'' forbid discrimination on the basis of gender identity and expression). Gaughran also supports a state-wide ban on .\n\nIn January 2019, each of the 39 members of the Democratic caucus in the state senate, including Gaughran, cosponsored the  , alongside . The bills were passed by the state legislature on January 15, 2019, and were signed by Gov. Andrew Cuomo on January 25, 2019.\n\n\"Years of dysfunction in Albany have blocked the passage of critical legislation like GENDA. This week we broke the logjam and passed historic protections to root out discrimination with the passage of GENDA and end cruel, barbaric practices like conversion therapy. As a conference, we've promised one of the most productive sessions in decades; we're just getting started.\"\nWhereas the Democratic-controlled  had consistently passed GENDA in every legislative session since 2013, the 2019 bills became the first significant LGBT bills passed by the senate since the passage of the  in June 2011. -->\n\nGaughran is  and supports codifying a woman's right to an  into state law, citing the conservative majority on the  as a threat to  established in the landmark '''' case in 1973.  In response to his vote in favor of the Reproductive Health Act in 2019, which expanded late term abortion and codified abortion rights statewide, the Huntington chapter of  asked Gaughran to resign as a member and barred him from participating in the  parade.\n\n\nGaughran favors overhauling the , which New York has formally adopted, saying \"this time we need to listen to our teachers, our parents, and our children about what works\". He opposes funding private for-profit charter schools with the public education budget. He cosponsored a bill to repeal the 2015 law establishing \"Annual Professional Performance Reviews\" (APPRs), which measured the effectiveness of teachers via the performance of their students on standardized tests; the bill was passed by the legislature on January 23, 2019, and was signed by Gov. Andrew Cuomo on April 12, 2019.\n In a statement issued following the successful passage of the legislation, Gaughran said:\n\"Public school teachers are the cornerstone of New York's excellent public school system. Teachers and students deserve fully funded public schools, not over-testing or the arbitrary linkage of test scores to teacher performance. We don't need annual tests to know how our students are progressing, we need to maintain local control. Our teachers are already evaluating student achievements every day in their classrooms, and perpetually modifying their lesson plans to provide the best education possible. I am proud to cast my vote to repeal the ineffective APPR evaluation system and look forward to fighting for increased education aid to Long Island public schools.\"\nThe bill was passed by the state legislature on January 23, 2019, and was signed by Gov. Andrew Cuomo on April 12, 2019. -->\n\nGaughran advocates for legalizing, regulating, and taxing , and using the tax revenue to help fund s in order to alleviate the trend of rising property taxes.\n\n\nGaughran opposes the  passed by the  and signed by   in late 2017, due to its cap on the , known as the SALT deduction. This cap raises the  on many Long Island residents (300,000 households by Gaughran's estimation) since state and local taxes are higher on Long Island than they are on average nationwide.\n\n\nGaughran supports expanding  and facilitating . He opposes requiring a reason to request an absentee ballot. He supports appointing an independent re-districting commission to prevent ,\n\n\n\nIn 1987, Gaughran married his wife, Carol, who works as a library media specialist. They reside in , and have two children, Kaitlin and Michael.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n*\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Costa Constantinides''' (born January 7, 1975) is an American politician and attorney who served as a member of the  from the . The district includes , , part of ,  and part of  in . \n\nIn April 2021, Constantinides resigned before his term in office officially ended to become the Chief Executive Officer of the Variety Boys and Girls Club of Queens.\n\n\n\nConstantinides was born and raised in . He attended local public schools P.S. 84 and P.S. 122, Constantinides graduated cum laude from  with a bachelor's degree in political science and history. He then earned a  from the .\n\n\nHe was admitted to the  in 2014.\n\nPreviously, Constantinides served as Deputy Chief of Staff to New York City Council Member  of District 24. Constantinides is the first Greek-Cypriot American to hold elected office. Constantinides serves as the Chair of the Committee on Environmental Protection in the New York City Council.\n\nIn 2013, Councilman  was barred from seeking re-election due to term limits. Constantinides won the Democratic primary to succeed him and easily won the general election later that year to take the seat. He served as chair of the Environmental Protection Committee.\n\nConstantinides was not able to seek re-election to the city council in 2020 due to term limits. After  was elected to serve as , she was succeeded as Queens Borough President by . Constantinides announced his candidacy for the special election to succeed Katz. Along with fellow council member , Constantinides was defeated in the Democratic primary by .\n\nCosta resigned from the New York City Council on April 9, 2021, to head Variety Boys Girls Club.\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Archie Spigner''' (August 27, 1928 – October 29, 2020) was an African-American politician who served in the  from 1974 to 2001. He was born in .\n\nOn the city council, he represented south-east . He was also influential in races for other positions. He was called the \"godfather of politics in southeastern Queens\" by  due to his ability to control who got elected from that area.\n\nHe died on October 29, 2020, in Queens, ,  at age 92. The cause was cancer.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Diana Ayala''' (born September 24, 1973) is an American politician, serving as a member and the deputy speaker of the . Ayala represents the , succeeding former Council Speaker  in 2017. The district includes , , , , , , and . She is a member of the .\n\n\nBorn in , she and her family moved to New York City when she was a child. They lived in  after living in . She received an associate degree in Human Services from .\n\n\nAyala worked as a Senior Center Director in  for seven years. She then served as Constituent Services Director and Deputy Chief of Staff for her predecessor, .\n\n\nAyala ran against three other candidates in the Democratic primary for the open 8th city council district. Ayala had the support of , the term-limited incumbent and Speaker. Ayala's main primary opponent was , an assemblyman. Ayala won the primary narrowly with 43.5% of the vote (4,012 votes) to Rodriguez's 42.23% (3,895 votes). In the general election, Ayala won 91.07% of the vote (13,617 votes), while her Republican opponent, , won 5.26% (787 votes) and her Conservative opponent, Linda Ortiz, won 3.30% of the vote (494 votes).\n\n\n\n\nAyala and her long-time partner live in East Harlem. She has four children and three grandchildren.\n\n\n\n\n\n* Councilwoman Diana Ayala (official site)\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
