    "pages": }\n'''Richard Ernest Jackson Jr.''' (born July 18, 1945) is an American , civil servant, and educator from New York. A , Jackson has served as New York State Commissioner of Motor Vehicles, Mayor of , and as a member of the Peekskill City Council. \n\nHe is the first African-American to serve as mayor of a city in the history of New York.\n\n\nJackson was born in Peekskill on July 18, 1945.\n\n\nJackson began his career as a mathematics teacher at .\nJackson later taught calculus at Averill Park High School.\n\nA three-term Peekskill City Councilmember, Jackson was appointed Mayor of Peekskill in December 1984 by a unanimous vote of the City Council when the previous mayor, , stepped down to serve in the . Upon assuming office, he became the first  Mayor of Peekskill. According to '''', Jackson was also the first African-American mayor of a city in the State of New York. Everett T. Holmes, also an African-American, served as Mayor of the   from 1974 to 1976 and from 1978 until 1982. Also, Ronald Blackwood, an African-American man from , became Acting Mayor of that city in 1976. According to The New York History Blog and the Cleveland Historical Society, the   elected an African-American man named Edward \"Ned\" Sherman to the position of village president in May 1878.}} A Republican, Jackson won a full term as mayor in 1985; he later won re-election to two successive terms with the largest pluralities in the city's 51-year history. He continued to teach mathematics at Peekskill High School while serving in his part-time mayoral post. Jackson stepped down on April 24, 1991.\n\nIn 1995, then-Governor Pataki appointed Jackson to the post of . Jackson served as Commissioner from 1995 to 2000.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
          }
        ]

    "pages": }\n\n'''Rebecca Seawright''' is the Assembly member for the 76th District of the . The district includes portions of the ,  and  in .\n\n\nSeawright formerly served as the New York State Director of the National Women's Political Caucus and a staffer in the . She also worked in , including for  .\n\nSeawright serves on the boards of  and the  Board of Visitors.\n\n\n\nAssemblyman  decided not to seek re-election in 2014, and Seawright entered the race to succeed him. She defeated three other candidates to receive the Democratic nomination. Seawright would go on to win the general election with nearly 67% of the vote.\n\nSeawright was sworn into office on January 1, 2015. She is a member of the Banking, Consumer Affairs and Protection, Corporations, Authorities and Commissions, Judiciary, and Tourism, Parks, Arts, and Sports Development Committees. She is the Chair of the Subcommittee on Consumer Fraud Protection and also sits on the Assembly's Work group on operations. Rebecca A. Seawright |url=http://nyassembly.gov/mem/Rebecca-A-Seawright/bio/ |access-date=2016-06-07 |website=nyassembly.gov}} She is a member of the Legislative Women's Caucus and Bipartisan Pro-Choice Legislative Caucus.\n\n\nIn August 2020, Seawright's electoral office was vandalized with paint and an  note. Seawright is not Jewish, but was targeted for supposedly mentioning a synagogue in a fundraising letter. The suspect was later caught. The incident led to a collaboration with Speaker of the New York State Assembly  to create the  in New York City.\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Rich Funke''' (born January 30, 1949) is an American journalist and politician who represented the  of the  from 2015 until 2020.\n\nFunke is a  who was elected in November 2014 when he defeated  incumbent . Prior to his election, Funke had for almost 40 years been a news anchor and sports director for , the  affiliate station in .\n\n\nFunke is a former radio disk jockey, radio and television journalist and television sports reporter and news anchor in . He began his career in broadcasting at  in . From there he worked as a news reader and reporter at  in Rochester before moving in 1972 to WAXC a top 40 station as its news director. After WAXC he was brought on as a sports director at  in 1974. After a stint at  in  from 1980 to 1981 he returned to Rochester and his previous position at WHEC-TV.\n\nIn 2005, Funke became the primary anchor of the evening news at 5, 6, 7 and 11 p.m. at WHEC-TV before retiring in 2012 as one of the main faces of the station.\n\n\nIn March 2014, Funke announced his candidacy for the New York State Senate in Senate District 55 against incumbent Democrat Ted O'Brien. Funke defeated O'Brien, 54,874 votes to 38,624.\n\nFunke ran for re-election unopposed in 2016. In 2018, however, he was a top Democratic target, ultimately defeating Democrat Jen Lunsford by a margin of 52%-48%.\n\nIn December 2019, Funke announced that he would not seek re-election the following year.\n\n\nFunke received the  for his coverage of the  in 1977 and 1986.\n\nFunke was inducted into the New York State Broadcasters Hall of Fame in December, 2012 shortly after his retirement.\n\nOn December 27, 2014, the  of the  inducted Funke into the Rochester Lancers Wall of Fame as one of Rochester's \"soccer pioneers\". Funke was the television play-by-play announcer for the original  of the .\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Pedro Espada Jr.''' (born October 20, 1953) is an American former politician. A Democrat, Espada served multiple nonconsecutive terms in the .\n\nEspada was at the center of  in the State Senate. He was one of two Democratic senators who voted to appoint Republican  as Majority Leader. After his return to the Democratic caucus on July 9, 2009, Espada was chosen as Senate Majority Leader; he is the first Hispanic to have held that post. Dogged by scandals, he was defeated by  in a September 2010 primary election.\n\nOn December 14, 2010, Espada was indicted on six federal counts of embezzlement and theft; he was stripped of his leadership position in the State Senate the same day and left office in January 2011. Espada was convicted on federal corruption charges in May 2012 and was sentenced to five years in prison.\n\n\nEspada was born in  in 1953 and moved with his family to  at the age of five. His family settled in the  section of , where he attended the . He attended , and graduated in 1975 with a  degree. Espada subsequently took graduate level coursework at the  School of Social Work, received graduate training certificates from  programs at the  and from the , and received certification in 1990 from the Real Estate Institute at ., . Accessed June 8, 2009.\n\nIn the late 1970s, Espada was a  and educator in  and the  in , and in the . He established and served as president of the Comprehensive Community Development Corporation and was the executive director of the Soundview Health Center.\n\nEspada had become head of the tenant's association at Stevenson Commons and led the effort in 1978 to open what became the Soundview Health Center after the city's economic problems led to a decision to not establish a promised clinic in the complex. The empty building that was to have been the clinic was leased by the group and $50,000 in federal grants was obtained, with the first patient taken in October 1981. By 1992, Soundview was offering medical and preventive care to 45,000 patients annually, and was also running a computer literacy program, serving lunch to hundreds of seniors daily and distributing surplus food. '''' noted that the health center featured Espada's name and image throughout the facility, describing it as having \"elements of a cult of personality\"; Espada explained, \"the community has to know you\" so that \"in the end, they will trust you\".\n\n\nIn 1988, Espada ran in the Democratic primary for the nomination in , which at the time covered the largely  and  heart of the South Bronx, against incumbent .Staff. , '''', September 6, 1988. Accessed June 9, 2009. Espada, mounting a challenge against what would normally be a  for renomination, made an issue of García's involvement in the , which resulted in the loss of 1,500 jobs in the economically challenged district. In the primary, Espada was endorsed by '''', which called him \"articulate, focused and knowledgeable about health and poverty\" based on his experience with the Soundview Health Center and encouraged voters to \"send a powerful message by supporting candidates who have been neither burned nor singed\". Espada was also endorsed by '''' and '''', but received few endorsements from political figures. García won renomination with 60 percent of the vote to Espada's 27 percent.\n\nEspada was elected to represent the 32nd Senate District in the Southeast Bronx, which included the neighborhoods of Soundview, Hunts Point, Mott Haven and Parkchester. He served in office from 1993 to 1996 and again from 2001 to 2002, with  holding office in the intervening years.\n\nIn July 1996, the ''New York Observer'' reported that Espada did not live in the district when he ran for office and since he had been elected to the state legislature, in violation of New York State residency laws. He had moved to a house overlooking the Long Island Sound, \"located on a cul-de-sac in a lushly green and exclusive neighborhood, only 16 miles from the South Bronx,\" in Mamaroneck, in Westchester County, the year before he ran for the State Senate, in 1991, according to Westchester County real estate records, reported the Manhattan-based weekly. When a reporter visited the house listed as the address for a car leased by the Medicaid-funded Comprehensive Community Development Corporation for the use of his wife, Connie, \"Mr. Espada could be found lounging by the pool, dressed in a white tank-top and baby-blue shorts with a matching baseball cap.\"\n\nAlso in 1996, Espada was indicted for using $70,000 from a city-financed HMO to fund his unsuccessful reelection campaign.\n\nWhen Espada's son, Pedro Gautier Espada, was elected to the  in 1996, the two became the first father and son in the  to represent different districts in the Bronx.\n\nIn the 1996 primary, the Bronx Democratic Party ran a candidate against Espada and successfully challenged his petitions in court. Espada ran on the Liberal Party line, and lost to David Rosado, 78% to 21%. In their 2000 rematch, Espada wrested the Democratic nomination from Rosado, who was forced to defend his seat in the Senate on the Liberal and Working Families Party lines. Espada, having the Democratic line, won the election handily.\n\nIn 2000, Espada was acquitted on charges of using $200,000 from a Soundview Health Management Organization to pay off campaign debts from 1996. He was found not guilty by arguing that the HMO was allowed to do as it wished with federal money. Four employees were found guilty of using taxpayer funds to help the campaigns of Espada and his son.\n\nIn 2001, Espada ran for , but was defeated by  in the Democratic primary election. Carrion received 48,913 votes, Espada received 44,124 votes, and June Margolin Eislan received 26,815 votes.\n\nThe State of New York pulled funding for some of Espada's nonprofits in 2002 due to \"administrative deficiencies and apparent misuse of funds.\"\n\nIn 2002, Espada was defeated in a Democratic primary for his Senate seat. Incumbent City Councilmember  won that primary by 97 votes. Espada sought a new primary in court, but was denied.  He then ran unsuccessfully for his old seat on the Republican and Independence lines while remaining registered as a Democrat.\n\nEspada was elected to the Senate in 2008 for a seat in the 33rd District, succeeding . The 33rd District is in the Northwest Bronx, including the neighborhoods of Bedford Park, Fordham, Norwood, and Kingsbridge Heights. At that time, he owed in excess of $60,000 in fines to the  related to races as far back as his 2001 run for Bronx . The campaign for his 2008 State Senate run had not registered with the  and fines were assessed against Espada's 2000 Senate campaign for required reports that had not been filed. Espada acknowledged that mistakes had been made but insisted that some of the accusations were unfair.\n\nEspada voted in favor of same-sex marriage legislation on December 2, 2009, but the bill was defeated.\n\n\n during the Senate leadership crisis.]]\n\nThough there were 32 Democrats and 30 Republicans in the Senate, on June 8, 2009, Espada and  (D-Queens) were part of what was described by the '''' as a \"parliamentary coup\" and voted with the 30 Republican members to install Senator  (R-Nassau) as the new majority leader of the Senate, replacing Senator  (D-Queens). In a press release posted to his Senate web page, Espada emphasized that \"I remain a staunch, reform Democrat. I have not switched parties,\" and that his actions were intended to help end the \"gridlock, paralysis, secretiveness, threats and partisan politics\" that the Senate had experienced in the previous months and that he was not part of \"a power grab or a coup\" but was working to build a coalition to serve the needs of all New Yorkers with open and transparent government. However, when pressed by  on June 11, 2009, as to whether he felt allegiance to the Democratic party, the Senator claimed he owed nothing to a political party that spent \"hundreds of thousands\" to defeat his past elections.\n\nThe switch was preceded by several weeks of private talks brokered by upstate billionaire .\n\nIn the early evening of July 9, 2009, Espada switched his allegiance back with the Democratic Party, and was then selected the Senate Majority Leader of the New York State Senate. He is the first Hispanic to have held that post.\n\n\nEspada claimed a  in  as his district residence. Several residents of the Bronx co-op said they never saw him there. The  opened an investigation in 2009.\n\nIn 2009,   investigated Espada's use of the Soundview Health Clinic for personal political reasons. Clinic offices also advertised Espada's name on the front canopy, displayed campaign posters on clinic grounds, and displayed posters of Espada surrounded by smiling children.\n\nIn 2010, Espada was investigated by federal investigators and the  for his ties with a consulting firm called \"A-1 Multi-Service LLC\" over suspicions that the firm, which appeared to not have a valid office, might be a  for  and .\n\nOn April 20, 2010, Cuomo sued Espada for siphoning $14&nbsp;million from the Soundview Health Clinic for personal expenses. The lawsuit covered five years of spending, which included $80,000 in restaurant bills (which included $20,000 in  delivered to Espada's  home), personal trips including to  and , and renting a residence required to establish residency in the district for his Senate race in 2008. Central New York - Syracuse, Oswego, Auburn, Ithaca, Oneida  LocalSYR  NewsChannel 9 WSYR|publisher=9wsyr.com|access-date=September 10, 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120305233614/http://www.9wsyr.com/news/local/story/Attorney-General-says-senator-looted-own-not-for/asKJH-JTZ0iWI39XcSejwA.cspx|archive-date=March 5, 2012|url-status=dead}} New York State Attorney General|publisher=ag.ny.gov|access-date=September 10, 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120225045108/http://www.ag.ny.gov/media_center/2010/apr/apr20a_10.html|archive-date=February 25, 2012|url-status=dead|df=mdy-all}} The lawsuit also sought to remove Espada from the board of directors of Soundview and replace the board, which Cuomo characterized as being \"packed with family and friends that Mr. Espada could control directly and indirectly.\"\n\nFederal and IRS agents raided two of Espada's offices in the Bronx on April 21, 2010  and his office records were ed the following day.\n\nOn April 24, 2010, Espada walked out of the taping of an interview with reporter  of  after issues of his actual residence was revisited. Espada got testy when Kramer reminded him that when she approached him last year outside his Mamaroneck home, he donned an orange ski cap and held a baby in front of his face to hide from the camera before speeding off in a car driven by his wife Connie Espada.\n\nOn April 29, 2010, Espada was hit with a civil lawsuit for allegedly pocketing $1.35&nbsp;million in a sham job training program. The suit focused on \"Espada Management Company\", a company run by Espada's son and the company that was hired to provide janitorial services for Espada's Soundview Health Clinics. According to the suit, Espada paid the trainees below   as little as $1.70/hr  to mop floors and scrub toilets.\n\nDuring a later interview conducted by  on , Espada's defense was characterized as turning personal against Andrew Cuomo. Espada repeatedly called Attorney General Cuomo the \"Prince of Darkness\" and claimed Cuomo's success to be because of the success of his father, former New York governor . abc7ny.com|publisher=abclocal.go.com|access-date=September 10, 2015}} WNYW|author=FOX|publisher=myfoxny.com|access-date=September 10, 2015}}\n\nSeveral state senatorsincluding fellow Democrats , , and called for Espada to step down from his Senate leadership positions. syracuse.com|date=23 April 2010|publisher=syracuse.com|access-date=September 10, 2015}} State Senator  of Brooklyn also introduced an amendment to force Espada from his majority leader position. NCPR News|publisher=northcountrypublicradio.org|date=2010-04-22|access-date=September 10, 2015}}  District Attorney  said that Espada could not lead anymore amid the investigations against him. State Senator  also called for Espada to not only step down from his senate position, but also forfeit his stipend.\n\nOn June 9, 2010, residents from the 33rd Bronx Senate district, which Espada represented, descended upon Espada's out-of-district Mamaroneck home in Westchester County to protest for his ousting.\n\n\nDespite being under investigation by the Bronx District Attorney, the FBI, the IRS, and the New York State Attorney General, Espada ran for re-election to his 33rd State Senate District seat. He was challenged by a number of candidates, including . The New Roosevelt Initiative, an  group led by , pledged to donate $250,000 to a candidate who sought to defeat Espada.\n\nThe  launched efforts to oust Espada from the party. The week of July 5, the Committee sent a letter to Bronx party leaders calling for the cancellation of Espada's membership. They said Espada did not support party goals because he had joined with Republicans the previous summer in the power play that ground Senate business to a halt for a month. In response, on July 12, 2010, Espada claimed that the charges against him were filed due to racism. Espada said, \"If you look brown and you're an immigrant, you're not supposed to have power\". Furthermore, Espada proclaimed, \"I have God on my side!\"\n\nOn August 9, 2010, two major labor unions  the 1199  and 32BJ  endorsed Espada's opponent for the 33rd district seat.\n\nEspada lost the primary election to Gustavo Rivera on September 14, 2010, 32.66% to 62.21%. In his concession speech, Espada blamed unions, outside influence, and the media for his defeat. Espada also refused to call primary winner Rivera personally.\n\n\nOn December 14, 2010, Espada and his son, Pedro Gautier Espada, were indicted on six federal counts of embezzlement and theft. The indictment was by U.S. Attorney , and also announced by New York State Attorney General and Governor-elect Andrew Cuomo. According to Cuomo, the Espadas embezzled public money for personal use, including purchases of food, Broadway show tickets, and a down payment for a Bentley car. They faced up to 55 years in prison if convicted of all charges.\n\nThe same day Espada was indicted, he was stripped of his title and position as Senate Majority Leader. He left office in January 2011.\n\nOn May 14, 2012, after 11 days of deliberation, a federal jury found Espada guilty of embezzling money from federally funded healthcare clinics. Espada was sentenced to five years in prison.\n\nEspada served his prison sentence in the Metropolitan Detention Center in Brooklyn, New York, and complained about the conditions at the facility while incarcerated. Espada's prisoner number was 78764-053 and he was released on October 30, 2017.\n\n\n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''David G. Greenfield''' (born September 26, 1978) is an American , law professor, and  executive. He served as a  in the  from the  from 2010 to 2017. In 2018, he became CEO of the , a Jewish charity in New York City.\n\n\nGreenfield is the founding director and counsel of TEACH NYS, and prior to his election served as the executive vice president of the Sephardic Community Federation.\n\nAs Director and Counsel of TEACH NYS, Greenfield organized statewide advocacy campaigns that resulted in private and public school parents receiving tax breaks and private schools receiving more government assistance. Greenfield served as deputy director of finance in Senator 's 2004 presidential campaign. Prior to that, he had a stint as chief of staff to Assemblyman .\n\n\nOn January 7, 2010 Greenfield announced his candidacy on the  radio show to replace  in the , which included , , , , , and  in . Felder announced his resignation after accepting the post as the new deputy comptroller for accounting and budget under . Greenfield received endorsements from U.S. Senator , then-Mayor , former Mayor , and State Senators , . He received the support of council members , , , and , as well as the backing of the Kings County Conservative Party, Democratic county leader , and .\n\nHe was elected in his first term by his  colleagues to co-chair the Brooklyn delegation and serve as their representative on the Budget Negotiating Team of the . He later became the chair of the Land Use Committee of the .\n\nGreenfield is a frequent political commentator in '''' and ''''.\n\nGreenfield was considered a political moderate in a liberal New York City Council. Greenfield authored a law that banned the Department of Sanitation from placing hard-to-remove stickers on vehicles that were parked on the wrong-side of the street. He co-authored a law that requires the Department of Education to notify parents and teachers about potentially harmful  (PCB) in classrooms. Greenfield also introduced a law that would stop New York City from towing cars for unpaid parking tickets and instead boot the car. Greenfield's proposed legislation was adopted by the New York City Council Department of Finance as a pilot program in June 2012. Greenfield was also the author of the  legislation that lowers the default speed-limit in New York City to 25 miles per hour. This legislation is the lynchpin of Vision Zero and is widely considered to be the key strategy behind saving lives by reducing traffic accidents in New York City.\n\nGreenfield voted against a year 2010 bill requiring the  office to post on its website and distribute at its office information on where in the world (countries, , and US States) same-sex gay couples are able to get married.\n\nGreenfield is a long-time advocate for increased government funding for public and non-public (including religious) schools.\n\nGreenfield was ranked as the 51st most powerful New Yorker in '''''s Power 100 list in 2014. In 2021 he rose to the 14th spot on the list.\n\n\nIn July 2017, he announced that he would not be seeking a third term on the city council, and would instead be taking over as CEO of the . He began his tenure as CEO on January 1, 2018.\n\n\n\n\n\nGreenfield is  and is a member of the R' Landau's Synagogue in . He is married with three children.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
          }

    "pages": }\n\n'''Cesar Augusto Perales''' (born November 12, 1940) is an American attorney, civil servant and was the previous  in the Cabinet of Governor . Perales was appointed by Cuomo on March 31, 2011, and unanimously confirmed by the New York State Senate on June 7.\n\n\nThe son of a  father and a  mother, Perales grew up in . He has said he first considered becoming a lawyer as a child, after his father's business went bankrupt.\n\n\"It really cost us a lot. I'm talking about losing furniture in the house, having it repossessed and things of that nature. It was a very terrible period for our family. And my father once told me that if he had had good legal help this wouldn't have happened.\"\n\nPerales went on to earn a bachelor's degree from  in 1962 and graduated from  in 1965.\n\nUpon graduating from Fordham, Perales worked at the legal unit for a -funded program on the  of New York called Mobilization for Youth. In 1968, when the federal government began to open neighbourhood legal services programs as part of the , Perales was selected to establish the first  Legal Services Office. His experiences working in New York's Puerto Rican neighborhoods allowed him to also assume the role of legal advocate for New York's Latino community. In April 1969, he represented the students who took over his alma mater, the City College of New York to demand the admission of more minority students.\n\nIn January 1970, he represented the  when they took control of a church to provide community services to poor community in . Perales negotiated the early morning non-violent arrest of over 100 members the Young Lords who refused to leave the church. \"The Young Lords were seen as a radical young Puerto Rican group that, actually in that situation had taken over that church and were offering breakfast to the kids,\" Perales said. \"These young people had a right to have a lawyer. I was doing my job as a lawyer for a group that I thought was doing good things.\"\n\n\n\nPerales has spent more than four decades in public service, including serving as the regional director of the  (HEW) in New York and later as Assistant Secretary of HEW during the administration of President .\n\nPerales served as Commissioner of the New York State Department of Social Services under Governor  and as  under Mayor .\n\n\n\nPerales is a co-founder of LatinoJustice PRLDEF and established the first Brooklyn Legal Services Office. In 1972, Perales, along with two other young Puerto Rican attorneysJorge Batista and raised enough seed money to open the Puerto Rican Legal Defense and Education Fund, a legal organization modeled on the . Perales served as the first executive director and Marrero was chairman of the board. In its early days, the fund, known by the acronym PRLDEF (pronounced pearl-deaf), brought many important civil rights lawsuits on behalf of Latinos living in New York City and across the U.S.\n\nIn 1974, the consent decree issued in PRLDEF's suit '' v. '' became central to the United States’ establishment of  programs in schools across the country. And, in several lawsuits against the New York Civil Service Commission, New York Police Department and New York Sanitation Commission, PRLDEF was able to get the courts to strike down numerous civil service requirements that kept Latinos from public employment and eliminated barriers to government benefits for non-English speaking applicants.\n\nIn the mid-1970s, a number of PRLDEF lawsuits, beginning with ''Lopez v. Dinkins'' on the local level and culminating with ''Ortiz v. New York State Board of Elections'' on the statewide level, forced election officials in New York to provide bilingual assistance. The litigation had national impact in 1975 when Congress amended the  to include the right to bilingual voting procedures.\n\nIn 1981, Perales returned to PRLDEF after another stint in government. Within six months, PRLDEF was at the forefront of litigation to get the  to block the election of the  until district lines were redrawn in a nondiscriminatory manner. The subsequent court order halting the elections was perhaps the most dramatic application of the Voting Rights Act in the North.\n\nPerales left government in 1994 to assume the position of senior vice president at . During his tenure at the hospital, he developed a Community Health Care system that received national recognition.\n\nIn 2003, Perales returned to the organization he had founded. PRLDEF quickly gained new prominence as an advocate and defender of the rights of immigrants. The fund's attorneys won a major victory against the Town of Brookhaven, New York in 2005 when a judge ruled that the town had to halt its policy of selectively enforcing its housing code laws against Latino households and its practice of evicting tenants without prior notice.\n\nThe group's case against 's anti-immigrant ordinance in 2007 was the first of its kind to go to a full trial, and ended with a federal judge issuing the precedent-setting ruling that immigration legislation is a matter reserved to the federal government.\n\nUnder Perales's leadership, the group was also among the first to challenge violent early morning raids of private homes by federal  agents. The organization has also filed a unique petition with the , arguing that the United States' aggressive immigration enforcement policies create a climate that fosters bias crimes.\n\nIn 2008, PRLDEF's board of directors voted to change the name of the group to more accurately reflect changes in its mission, its client base, and the make-up of its board. The Puerto Rican Legal Defense and Education Fund changed its name to LatinoJustice PRLDEF. \"Latinos are beginning to see themselves as a group, as a community,\" said Perales. \"There is a coming together of identification in a common struggle.\"\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n*\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
          }
        ]
      }
    }
  }

    "pages": }\n'''Katherine M. Sheehan''' (born December 5, 1963) is an American politician and attorney serving as the 75th  of . Prior to being elected Mayor, Sheehan served as City Treasurer from 2010 to 2013. On September 10, 2013, she defeated Corey Ellis in the Democratic primary for mayor of Albany. She later won the general election, becoming the first female mayor in Albany's history. She was re-elected in  and .\n\n\nSheehan was born outside  and grew up in the Midwest. She is one of six children. Sheehan earned a bachelor of science degree in journalism from  in 1985. In 1994, she earned a  from the .\n\n\nAfter graduating from law school, she began working in the Albany office of . In 1996, Sheehan took a position at Intermagnetics General Corporation in . She helped negotiate the sale of the company to .\n\nIn 2009, Sheehan was elected City Treasurer of Albany, New York.\n\n\n\nOn November 17, 2012, Sheehan announced herself as a 2013 candidate for mayor. In May 2013, longtime Albany Mayor  announced that he would not seek a sixth term in the fall elections. Sheehan defeated former Common Councilor Corey Ellis in a Democratic mayoral primary on September 10, 2013. Sheehan won the Democratic nomination with 7,468 votes (65.72%) to Ellis's 3,294 votes (29%). On November 5, 2013, Sheehan won the general election with over 83% of the total vote. When she took office on January 1, 2014, she became the first female mayor in the history of the city.\n\nDuring Sheehan's tenure, the city's total debt decreased from $140.1 million in 2014 to $106.8 million in 2018. The city installed s at various intersections in 2015. In 2017, Sheehan announced a $1 million vacant building grant program.\n\nIn February 2017, Sheehanalong with Assemblywoman  and Congressman was criticized by Bishop  for supporting and attending a rally for  despite being a Roman Catholic politician.\n\nIn her 2017 re-election bid, Sheehan faced opposition from Common Council President Carolyn McLaughlin and Common Councilor Frank Commisso Jr. in the Democratic primary. Sheehan won the primary with 51 percent of the vote. Sheehan was re-elected Mayor on November 7, 2017, winning 70 percent of the vote; Commisso received 22 percent of the vote as an independent candidate.\n\n\nSheehan and her husband, Bob, were married in 1992. The Sheehans have an adopted son named Jay. In January 2018, the Sheehans purchased a house in the  section of the  neighborhood.\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Charles J. Fuschillo Jr.''' (born July 1, 1960) is a former  member of the  from .  From 1998 to 2013, he represented the , which spans several  communities in both Nassau and Suffolk Counties.  The district currently includes the communities of , , ,  , , , , , and , as well as parts of , , , , , , and .  Senator Fuschillo resigned from the New York State Senate on December 31, 2013 to serve as the President and CEO of the .\n\n\n\nFuschillo was born in , and graduated from . He then attended . In 1982, he earned a  degree from , majoring in Finance.\n\nPrior to being elected to the New York State Senate, Fuschillo served as the Chief Operating Officer of a private, not-for-profit family service agency where he managed over four hundred employees and forty human service programs throughout Long Island and the five boroughs of New York City.\n\nFuschillo currently serves as the President & CEO of the Alzheimer's Foundation of America (AFA).\n\n\nFuschillo has been a campaigner against drunk driving in New York State. He sponsored \"Leandra's Law,\" which makes it a felony to drive drunk with a child in the car and requires all convicted drunk drivers to use ignition interlocks to prevent them from drinking and driving again. He sponsored laws which lowered New York State's legal  (BAC) level from .10 to .08; enacted tougher penalties for repeat offenders and those who drive with an elevated BAC; and expanded the use of ignition interlock devices to keep convicted DWI offenders from drinking and driving again.\n\nFuschillo helped create the Broad Hollow Bioscience Park at Farmingdale State College, which serves as a home to established and startup biotechnology companies and provides high-tech jobs for Long Islanders. In April 2011, he authored a law to expand Broad Hollow Bioscience Park to create new jobs and promote economic development.\n\nFuschillo sponsored complete streets legislation which would require all state, county, and local transportation agencies in New York State to consider complete streets design principles on all projects which receive both federal and state funding.  Complete streets design principles are roadway design features that accommodate and facilitate safe travel by pedestrians, bicyclists, and motorists of all ages and abilities. The legislation was approved by the New York State Legislature in June 2011 and signed into law two months later. The New York League of Conservation Voters named him a 2011 Eco-Star for his efforts in getting the law passed.\n\nFuschillo also sponsored a statewide ban on over-the-counter products containing the dangerous dietary supplement ephedra. Fuschillo has authored child safety laws, and helped secure new educational technology for local school districts. Additionally, he sponsored a statewide ban on dangerous drop-side cribs, which have been linked to numerous child deaths and injuries.\n\nFuschillo authored a law, signed on November 1, 2011, to prevent insurance companies from denying treatments and therapies for autism. Autism Speaks, a national autism advocacy organization, named Fuschillo a \"legislative champion\" in 2012 for authoring the law.\n\n\nFuschillo and his wife, Ellen, reside in Merrick with their 3 children, Daniel, Chad, and Catie.\n\n\nFuschillo is involved with local organizations, including Kiwanis, the Chamber of Commerce, the Community Wellness Council, Italian Americans in Government, and Order Sons of Italy in America. He  served as a coach for the Police Athletic League.\n\n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''David R. Koon''' (born March 18, 1947) Facts For All |url=http://votesmart.org/ |access-date=2023-11-17 |website=Vote Smart}} is a former American  politician who represented District 135 in the , which includes the towns and villages of ,  and , and , neighboring communities located in  in the eastern suburbs of  from 1996 to 2010.\n\n\nKoon studied at , , earning a  in 1969. He worked at  in  from 1970–82, and joined  in 1982 as an . He was transferred and moved to Fairport in 1989., accessed September 16, 2008.\n\n\nKoon and his wife, Suzanne, have had two children, Jason Koon and Jennifer Patterson Koon. In 1993, Jennifer, then 18 years old, was abducted from a suburban mall parking lot, beaten, raped and murdered. (The assailant was convicted and is serving a sentence of 37½ years to life.) David Koon asked a local official to have security cameras installed in such parking lots, but received no response. Thus began his political activism. He ran against the county legislator, losing a close election. Jason Koon was elected to a four-year term as the Mayor of East Rochester in 2007. He did not seek re-election in 2011.\n\n\nKoon successfully ran for the 135th Assembly District seat in a special election held in February 1996 (to replace , who had been elected to the state senate). He was elected to a full term in November of that year. Koon serves as a member of the Alcoholism and Drug Abuse; Economic Development, Job Creation, Commerce and Industry; Local Governments; Small Business; and Library and Education Technology Committees. He is also Vice Chair of the Legislative Commission on Rural Resources and Vice Chair of the Legislative Commission on Toxic Substances and Hazardous Waste.\n\nIn 1998, through , Koon and his wife Suzanne were instrumental in creating and managing the Jennifer Patterson Koon Peacemaking Foundation, in honor of their daughter. The Foundation \"recognize(s) and honor persons who have made a significant contribution to peacemaking and who foster and stimulate a commitment to peacemaking in our society.\" One of Koon's legislative priorities has been full funding for , a system of automatically locating those who've called 911, in New York State. His daughter had called 911 during her abduction ordeal, but although the call lasted 20 minutes, 911 dispatchers were not able to locate her. Although E911 had received some funding in the state since 1991, it had not been fully implemented as late as 2003. Koon pressed his case in 2003, against opposition from then-governor .\n\n\nWhile serving, Koon was s in favor of state presence in providing child care and job training for displaced workers, national standards for education and state-funded vouchers for private school education, and increased penalties for violent crime (including capital punishment and elimination of the statute of limitation for criminal sex cases).\n\n\nOn March 28, 2008, Assemblyman Koon announced the passage of a bill he authored which allows for the New York State Thruway Authority to issue annual short-distance commuter permits on the Thruway in the Rochester area at no charge between interchanges and barriers in the permit area. This bill would allow those citizens who travel for work in the Rochester area to use the Thruway at reduced rates or free of charge (A7094).\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Antonio Ramon Delgado''' (born January 28, 1977) is an American attorney and politician serving as the  since 2022. A member of the , Delgado served as the  from  from 2019 to 2022. He is the first person of either  or  descent to be elected to  from , and the first Latino person to hold statewide office in New York.\n\nOn May 3, 2022, Governor  announced that she had appointed Delgado to serve as lieutenant governor, after  resigned; Delgado was sworn in on May 25, 2022. On November 8, 2022, Delgado won a full term as lieutenant governor, on Hochul's ticket.\n\n\nDelgado was born on January 28, 1977, in , to Tony Delgado and Thelma P. Hill. He is of , an, , , and  ancestry. Delgado has three younger brothers: Kito, Kendall, and Julian. He grew up in the Hamilton Hill neighborhood of Schenectady.\n\nDelgado attended  and played for the school's  team as a . In his senior year, '''' named Delgado to its all-area second team. He then enrolled at  and played for the  team alongside future  player . Delgado graduated from Colgate in 1999 and earned a  to study at , from which he received a Master of Arts in 2001. In 2005, Delgado graduated from .\n\nAfter law school, Delgado moved to Los Angeles in 2005 and worked in the music industry. In 2007, he released a  album under the stage name \"AD the Voice\". He was sworn into office on January 3, 2019.\n\n\n\nDelgado ran for reelection to a second term in 2020.     "pages": }\n'''Barbara Patton''' (born March 28, 1944) is an American lawyer and politician from .\n\n\nShe was born on March 28, 1944, in . She was confirmed by the State Senate in January 1988, and remained in office until 1994.\n\nAfterwards she was a Vice President of , and took part in the company's merger with  in 1997.\n\nShe was the Democratic Co-Commissioner of Elections for Nassau County from April 1999 to July 2002. She resigned this post to become an assistant professor of accounting, Taxation and Legal Studies in Business at Hofstra University's .\n\nIn May 2003, she announced that she would run for Supervisor of the , but withdrew from the race in August.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Nantasha M. Williams''' (born March 29, 1988) is an  politician from . A , Williams represents the  in the , which covers parts of southeastern .\n\n\nWilliams was born in , and was raised by a single mother who worked as a social worker. She received a  from  and an  from , and is currently enrolled in a  program at the .\n\n\nPrior to seeking elected office herself, Williams held a number of staff roles in the office of Assemblywoman , eventually rising to become Richardson's chief of staff. Williams was also appointed as the executive director of New York State's Black, Puerto Rican, Hispanic and Asian Legislative Caucus, which represents state assemblymembers and senators of color.\n\n\nIn , after the death of Assemblywoman , Williams announced she would run for the 33rd district of the  in southeastern . She faced , who had run for the seat twice before, and three other candidates in the  primary. Vanel ultimately defeated Williams by a narrow margin, 32-28%, and went on to win the seat in the general election.\n\n\nFour years after her Assembly campaign, with incumbent City Councilman  term-limited, Williams launched her campaign for the  of the , a heavily overlapping constituency. Williams received endorsements from Assemblywoman  and nearly all of the city's major unions, but many other power players remained neutral among the crowded race's twelve contenders.\n\nOn primary election night on June 22, Williams emerged with a strong lead, earning 36 percent of the vote while her nearest competitor was far behind with 11 percent; she officially won two weeks later, after ranked-choice votes and absentee ballots were counted. She ran uncontested in the November general election, and was elected. She assumed office on January 1, 2022.\n\n\nShortly after being elected, Council Member Williams was appointed to Chair of the NYC Council's Committee on Civil and Human Rights, and sit on the following committees: Economic Development, General Welfare, Mental Health, Disabilities, and Addictions, Oversight and Investigations, Sanitation and Solid Waste Management, Transportation and Infrastructure, and Youth Services. Council Member Williams would transition out of the Economic Development Committee, Sanitation and Solid Waste Management Committee, and Youth Services Committee to the powerful Finance Committee overseeing the NYC budget.\n\nDuring her first year in the City Council, Council Member Williams helped pass historic legislation requiring many ads for jobs in the nation’s most populous city to include salary ranges, in the name of giving job applicants  particularly women and people of color  a better shot at fair pay.  During this same year, following a horrendous fire that claimed the lives of 17 people in the , the City Council passed her legislation requiring inspections for self-closing doors in residential buildings which was a major factor in this loss of life.\n\nCouncil Member Williams also championed a resolution calling for the NYS Legislature to pass the Clean Slate Act - New Yorkers would be eligible to have their records automatically sealed 3 years from sentencing  and 7 years for . To be eligible for this relief, individuals must have completed probation, parole, or post-release supervision. They cannot have incurred any new convictions during the three- or seven-year waiting period. The Clean Slate Act would ultimately pass and be signed into law by Governor  the following year.\n\nDuring her second year in office, Council Member Williams passed two resolutions in honor of the 50th Anniversary of Hip-Hop including a resolution recognizing August as the Hip-Hop Recognition Month and December as Hip-Hop History Month, and a second resolution recognizing  for their contributions to the genre. Council Member Williams was also able to secure major investments in the New York City budget for her district including $3.8 million to redesign a local park neighboring PS.176Q, $2.8 million for crucial resilience upgrades in the  Library, and $2.755 million for the reconstruction and revitalization of the playground that was heavily damaged during .\n\nCouncil Member also launched the Jamaica Neighborhood Plan, in partnership with , Queens Borough President  and Speaker , to create a grassroots vision for the future of the Downtown Jamaica and Hollis area that includes more affordable housing and investments to improve the quality of life. The Jamaica Neighborhood Plan aims to create a vision driven by the local community for Jamaica’s future where the community has more people able to live, work and play in the area. The Plan focuses on the downtown Jamaica area, around a 300-block radius and includes transportation corridors, manufacturing districts, institutions and community parks and transportation.\n\n\nNantasha Williams is a homeowner, who lives in , .\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Sheldon Silver''' (February 13, 1944 – January 24, 2022) was an American  politician and attorney from New York City who served as  from 1994 to 2015. A native of 's , Silver served in the New York State Assembly from 1977 to 2015. In 1994, he was selected as the Speaker of the Assembly; he held that position for two decades. During this period, Silver was known as one of the most powerful politicians in the state.\n\nSilver was arrested on federal corruption charges in early 2015, and resigned as Speaker of the Assembly shortly afterward. At his trial that November, he was convicted of all charges; the felony convictions triggered his automatic expulsion from the Assembly. Silver's conviction was overturned on appeal, but in May 2018, following a , he was found guilty on the same charges. After another appeal, the Second Circuit Court dismissed the guilty verdicts for three of the charges, but upheld them for four others. Silver was resentenced in July 2020 to  years in prison and a $1&nbsp;million fine. He was incarcerated in the federal prison at , New York. Silver was released on May 4, 2021, under a provision of the , which allows prison bureaus to release those deemed vulnerable to COVID-19, but was recalled to a medical-care specialized federal prison at , Massachusetts two days later on May 6. He died at a hospital in nearby , on January 24, 2022, while still serving his sentence.\n\n\nAn  whose parents were Russian immigrants, Silver was a native of 's . He graduated from the  on , where he was captain of the basketball team. Silver graduated from  with a Bachelor of Arts degree in 1965, and earned his  from  in 1968.\n\n\nSilver practiced law with the firm of Schecter and Schwartz from 1968 until 1971, and then served as law secretary for  Judge Francis N. Pecora from 1971 to 1976. In addition to Silver's duties in the  from 1977 to 2015, he was \"\" at , one of 's largest personal injury litigation firms.\n\nFor years, Weitz & Luxenberg insisted that Silver's ties with the firm were negligible. In 2007, the '''' charged that Silver's refusal to disclose the terms of his employment or the income he received raised suspicions of a . The income Silver received from Weitz & Luxenberg and the manner in which Silver obtained it ultimately led to his 2015 arrest on federal corruption charges.\n\n\n, and  announce federal funds for construction of the , December 2001]]\n, and  at the Israel Day Parade in New York, May 2004]]\n\n\nSilver was first elected to the Assembly in 1976. Silver advanced to the chairmanship of the Assembly Ways and Means Committee in 1991 and became speaker of the Assembly in 1994.\n\nDuring the election years of his speakership, 1994–2014, Silver's district typically re-elected him with 80 to 90 percent of the vote. In 2008, he had his first Democratic primary challenge in over two decades, winning 69 percent, or 7,037 votes, to defeat his challengers, Paul Newell, who earned 22 percent (2,401 votes), and Luke Henry with 9 percent (891). Silver was re-elected on November 4 with 27,632 votes. His Republican challenger, Danniel Maio, received 7,387 votes.\n\n\nOn February 11, 1994, after  died from a stroke, Silver became the . Silver served as Assembly Speaker until November 30, 2015.\n\n\nAs Speaker, Silver was instrumental in the reinstatement of the death penalty in New York State in 1995. New York's death penalty law was eventually ruled unconstitutional by the  in '''' (2004). The law provided that juries in capital cases would be instructed that if they deadlocked between sentencing a defendant to life imprisonment without parole and sentencing a defendant to death, the judge would sentence the defendant to life imprisonment with parole eligibility after 20 to 25 years. The Court found this provision unconstitutional, reasoning that this instruction would make execution seem preferable to juries because they would wish to avoid a defendant's potential future release on parole. Although no executions were carried out under the 1995 law, New York's crime rate dropped significantly in the decade since the law was passed. Silver let the law expire without much debate.\n\nIn December 2005, after two New York City police officers were killed in as many months, Governor  called for reinstatement of the death penalty. '''' quoted Silver's spokesman Charles Carrier as saying, \"He no longer supports it because Assembly hearings have shown it is not the most effective way to improve public safety.\"\n\n\nIn 1997 and throughout his Assembly career, Silver was a key advocate of state-administered  of New York apartments. This complex and highly politicized system made the Speaker a central figure, continually courted by major participants in the real-estate industry.\n\nIn 1967, New York City leveled the   Urban Renewal Area in Silver's neighborhood, and removed more than 1,800 low-income largely  families, with a promise that they could return to new low-income apartments when they were built. However, the site was kept undeveloped for decades afterward, as Silver and key allies, for example, the  strove to maintain the area's Jewish identity and opposed affordable housing, which would have brought more Hispanic and  residents. Finally in 2012, the site was approved for the  mixed-use development project. Construction is scheduled to be completed in 2024, some 57 years after the site was cleared.\n\n\nIn 1999, Silver was instrumental in the repeal of New York City's  on non-resident earners. The repeal was a benefit to those commuting to work in the city from surrounding areas, but came at a substantial cost to New York City residents. Silver was criticized by city leaders for removing the tax, and although he suggested he would support reinstating it after the terrorist attacks of September 11, 2001, he took no steps to do so.\n\n\nIn 2000, Silver faced an attempted \"coup\" in the Assembly as members, primarily from  and dissatisfied with his leadership style, tried to overthrow him as Speaker. , the leader of the backlash, lost his position as majority leader. An editorial in '''', written in response, criticized Silver for having too much power:\nThe problemwhich also exists in the State Senatecan be boiled down to a single overarching issue: The Assembly speaker has too much power. He controls everything, from the legislation that can be voted on to how his normally docile members vote on it. He decides what the Assembly will accept in a state budget. He negotiates secretly with the other two leaders to hammer out important, expensive and far-reaching laws. And he ignores the wishes of less-exalted lawmakers.\n\n\nIn July 2007, Silver was skeptical about  's  program. When a meeting of the Democratic Assembly Conference indicated the proposal lacked sufficient support, Silver declined to schedule a vote on the measure, and it died. Although he stated that he \"probably would have voted for the bill,\" a majority of his conference opposed the proposed plan.\n\n\nSilver, in his role as Speaker, was widely blamed for the delay in passing legislation allowing professional  in New York State. New York became the last of the 50 states to allow the sport in early 2016, after Silver had been expelled from the Assembly.\n\n\nA former top aide to Silver, chief counsel J. Michael Boxley, was accused of raping two legislative aides while he was working for the Speaker, and Boxley eventually pleaded guilty to . Silver was sued for failing to investigate the accusations properly and for tolerating a culture of sexual harassment in the Assembly. In 2006, Silver and the Assembly leadership agreed to pay $500,000 to settle the lawsuit. Similar settlements in 2012 and 2015 resulted from multiple harassment charges against former Assemblyman , and Silver was accused of not acting forcefully to prevent Lopez's behavior. Silver apologized for not reporting cases to the Assembly's Ethics Committee as required, and said that since then he \"put in place new policies to ensure these incidents are dealt with swiftly and transparently.\"\n\n\n\nOn January 7, 2015, Silver was re-elected Speaker of the New York State Assembly for the 11th time, with almost unanimous support from the Democratic majority despite an ongoing federal probe into his outside income.\n\nTwo weeks later, on January 22, Silver was arrested on federal corruption charges resulting from that probe. He was charged with , , and . The federal inquiry, which followed the state's abrupt disbandment of its , focused on large payments that Silver received for years from Goldberg & Iryami, a law firm that specialized in seeking reductions of New York City real estate taxes for real estate developers. Silver was alleged to have persuaded developers who had business with the state to use the firm, which in turn generated $700,000 in referral fees to Silver. Investigators led by U.S. Attorney for the   charged that Silver did not properly disclose the payments from the firm on his annual financial disclosure filings with the state. Goldberg & Iryami's major client was the state's single-largest political donor. One of the firm's founding partners, Jay Goldberg, was Silver's former Assembly counsel.  Goldberg's partner at the firm, Dara Iryami, agreed to testify under immunity.\n\nSimilar charges were also filed involving millions of dollars in referral fees that Silver received from the law firm Weitz & Luxenberg. In this scheme, Silver was alleged to have directed about $500,000 in state grants to Dr. Robert Taub, a researcher in diseases caused by  and the director of the   Center. Taub then referred asbestos claimants to Weitz & Luxenberg, which paid Silver $1.4&nbsp;million in salary and another $3.9&nbsp;million in referral fees, although he did no work for them. After the charges were announced, Weitz & Luxenberg promptly placed Silver on leave. Both Taub and another of Silver's longtime associates, Brian Meara, provided key information to investigators in exchange for non-prosecution agreements.\n\nOn January 30, after a week of intense political pressure and dwindling support, Silver submitted his resignation as Speaker, effective February 2, while retaining his seat as a member of the Assembly and vowing to fight the charges against him. On February 3, the Assembly elected  as their new Speaker.\n\nOn April 25, 2015, Silver was indicted on additional charges of making illegal investments through private vehicles, netting a profit of $750,000. He pleaded not guilty to those charges three days later, on April 28.\n\n\nSilver's trial on seven corruption charges lasted for much of November 2015. On November 30, 2015, a unanimous jury found Silver guilty on all seven counts, triggering his automatic expulsion from the Assembly. The , which handles judicial and attorney misconduct, affirmed his automatic disbarment for the felony convictions.\n\nOn May 3, 2016, federal judge  of the , who presided over the trial, sentenced Silver to 12 years in prison, and ordered him to pay $5.3&nbsp;million in ill-gotten gains and $1.75&nbsp;million in additional fines. Silver received two prison terms: 12 years for six criminal counts against him and 10 years on the seventh, to run concurrently.\n\n\nAfter the conviction, Silver remained free on bail as a panel of judges considered his appeal based on the 's decision in '''' that reversed the corruption conviction of former  .\n\nThe Supreme Court decision in the McDonnell case narrowed the kinds of activities that could constitute corruption, and Silver's conviction was overturned by the  in Manhattan on July 13, 2017.\n\n\nAfter his conviction was overturned, Silver was retried on the same charges. On May 11, 2018, he was again found guilty on all counts.  On July 27, 2018, Judge Caproni sentenced him to seven years in prison, five years less than the sentence she gave him for his first conviction, citing his advancing age.\n\nSilver was due to report to prison on October 5, 2018, but this was stayed as he again appealed his conviction to the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit. While his case was under continued appeal, he remained free on $200,000 bail.\n\nOn January 21, 2020, the panel unanimously dismissed the three charges stemming from Silver's involvement in the asbestos exposure cases but upheld the four charges related to the kickbacks from Goldberg & Iryami and , sending the case back to Judge Caproni for resentencing. Silver was resentenced by Judge Caproni on July 20, this time to  years in prison and a fine of $1&nbsp;million. He reported to , on August 26, 2020. After being furloughed briefly, Silver was transferred to  in May 2021.\n\n\nA number of commentators reflected on Silver's political career in the aftermath of his criminal convictions. Sara Foss, writing for the ''Daily Gazette'', said that during his speakership, \"he wielded an enormous amount of power, while also using his office for personal gain.\" She attributed to Silver an \"opaque and autocratic style of governance\". Joseph Spector and Jon Campbell in the ''Observer Dispatch'' said that, \"for more than two decades\" Silver \"was one of the most powerful and feared politicians in New York\". In 2018, Daniel Leddy of the '''' wrote \"As speaker of the New York State Assembly, Sheldon Silver was corruption personified, an iron-fisted dictator who turned that legislative body into his own personal, profit-making enterprise. The full extent of Silver's sleaziness will never be known, nor will the identity of those irreparably harmed by it\".\n\n\nSilver and his wife Rosa, a former  schoolteacher, had four children. According to court papers unsealed during the sentencing phase of his first trial, Silver was alleged to have had two extramarital affairs, both of which were connected to his Albany position. Both Silver and the two women who were the subject of the allegations have denied the affairs.\n\nBy the time he became Speaker of the Assembly, he was known to play basketball with other high-ranking officials, including former Governor  and former New York State Comptroller .\n\nTwo weeks after Silver's first criminal conviction, his son-in-law Marcello Trebitsch was sentenced to prison for a separate multimillion-dollar crime, also prosecuted by Bharara's office.\n\nAt the time of his death, Silver was imprisoned at the Devens Federal Medical Center in . He died at  in nearby , on January 24, 2022, less than a month before his 78th birthday.\n\n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n* Paterson, David (2020). ''Black, Blind, & in Charge: A Story of Visionary Leadership and Overcoming Adversity''. New York: Skyhorse Publishing.\n\n\n\n* \n*  \n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Carl Edward Heastie''' (; born September 25, 1967) is an American politician from New York. Heastie has served in the New York State Assembly since January 2001, and was elected  on February 3, 2015.\n\n\n\nBorn in New York City, Heastie earned a Bachelor of Science degree in Applied Mathematics and Statistics from  in , and a M.B.A. in Finance from  in New York City.\n\n\nBefore his election to the Assembly, Heastie worked as a budget analyst for the . Heastie has also worked as an adjunct professor at .\n\n\nHeastie was first elected to the New York State Assembly in 2000 and represents the 83rd District, which covers the , , , , and  sections of the Northeast .\n\nSince joining the Assembly, Heastie became one of the lead negotiators for the construction of a new  in his district. He has also sponsored legislation to require mandatory reporting of alleged child abuse of students in New York City. He became Chair of the Assembly Labor Committee in 2013.\n\nHeastie became Chair of the Bronx  in 2008, a post that he relinquished after becoming Assembly Speaker in 2015.\n\n\nIn January 2015, Heastie's Assembly colleagues considered him a frontrunner to be elected Speaker, following the arrest of  on federal corruption charges led by  . On February 2, Assembly Democrats voted unanimously for Heastie to become the new Speaker. The full Assembly elected him Speaker of the Assembly the next day.\n\nHeastie is the first African-American to serve the position. One of his first New York City appearances after becoming speaker was at 's rally in Harlem, where he told the crowd, \"This is a tremendous opportunity for our community, for the first time, to have one of us sit at the table,\" and added \"All of you are going to be sitting at that table with me for the first time\".\n\nIn April 2015, it was reported that, contrary to a judge's instructions, Heastie had neglected to sell a home that his mother, Helene Heastie, according to s bought with money d from a nonprofit charity. After his mother's death, Heastie ceased attempts to sell the home, having been advised by his lawyer that he was no longer obligated to do so, and later sold it for a profit of $200,000. An independent  expert consulted by the '''' agreed, explaining that the judge's order was \"probably legally unenforceable without a formal forfeiture agreement,\" which prosecutors had not obtained. In addition, prosecutors did not follow the judge's instructions to file a civil judgement against Heastie's mother. When asked in 2015 why no civil judgement was sought, the District Attorney's office was unable to explain why this routine filing had not occurred. In 2015, Heastie's office issued a statement about the incident, saying that \"the lessons imparted to the speaker [Heastie]... included owning up to mistakes and taking responsibility.\"\n\n\nHeastie has a daughter from a previous marriage.\n\nAs of 2024, he is in a relationship with disability advocate Rebecca Lamorte, who is 24 years his junior.\n\n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n*\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Joann Ariola-Shanks''' (born June 14, 1958) is a councilwoman of the , representing  which includes , , , , , and the western half of the .  She previously served as the chairwoman of the Queens Republican Party.\n\n\nAriola is a lifelong resident of the 32nd Council District.  Born on  June 14, 1958, Joann is the eldest child of a prominent Ozone Park family. During her childhood, the family - including her younger sister and brother - relocated to a new home in Howard Beach. She attended P.S. 63 (Old South), P.S. 207 (Rockwood Park), Our Lady of Grace Catholic School,  on the Rockaway Peninsula and Adelphi Business School.\n\n\nAriola entered into the political arena in 1993 as chief of staff for New York City Councilmember . In 1996, Ariola unsuccessfully ran against  for a seat in the New York State Assembly.\n\nLater, Ariola served as communications director for Councilmember , before unsuccessfully running against  in 2001 for the City Council seat left vacant by Stabile.\n\nFollowing the unsuccessful 2001 race, Ariola worked under the  as an Assistant Commissioner with the Community Assistance Unit until 2006, when she entered into the private sector as Director of Intergovernmental Relations for Medisys. \n\n\nIn 2020, Ariola ran for  against .\n\n\nAriola was elected to the NYC City Council in 2021 over Democrat Felicia Singh.     "pages": }\n'''Jenifer Rajkumar''' (born September 1, 1982) is an American politician. A , she is a member of the  from the , representing  neighborhoods of , , , , and .\n\n\nRajkumar was born and raised in  in . Her parents are doctors who immigrated from  and first settled in . She is a graduate of . Rajkumar earned a Bachelor of Arts degree from the  and a  from .\n\n\nJenifer Rajkumar is currently a member of the  from the , representing  neighborhoods of , , , , and . In 2020, Rajkumar became the first  woman ever elected to the New York State Legislature.\n\nPreviously, she practiced law as a civil rights attorney, served as the Director of Immigration Affairs for New York State, and worked as an  of political science at CUNY's  in the Bronx.\n\n\n\n\nRajkumar was appointed by the Speaker of the Assembly as the Chair of the Subcommittee on Diversity in Law. She also serves on the following Assembly Committees: Judiciary, Veterans' Affairs, Committee on Aging, Consumer Affairs, and Small Business.\n\nIn her first term, Rajkumar passed a legislative package for domestic workers, securing them the full protections of the state human rights law, and expanding their paid family leave benefits. Governor Hochul signed Rajkumar's legislative package into law in December 2021. Rajkumar also passed a bill expanding benefits for victims of crime, which the Governor signed into law in June 2022.\n\nIn December 2021, Mayor-Elect Eric Adams appointed Rajkumar as a Senior Advisor on his Transition Team.\n\n\nOn February 6, 2017, Governor  appointed Rajkumar as the Director of Immigration Affairs and Special Counsel for the .\n\n\nIn 2011, Rajkumar became the first  elected as the District Leader of the  of the , defeating a 28-year incumbent with over 70% of the vote. She was re-elected to that office two more times, in 2013 and 2015. As district leader, Rajkumar led the effort to bring  back to  in  and has worked closely with Democracy for Battery Park City, an organization which seeks representation for residents of the neighborhood on the board of the .\n\n\nIn 2013, Rajkumar ran for the  in the Democratic primary in New York City's first Council district, losing to incumbent . Rajkumar won 41.5% of the vote. Rajkumar's campaign championed affordable housing and community-friendly development. She was endorsed by various organizations and unions, such as The , and local Allied ers and s groups.\n\n\nShe ran for the  in the 65th District, as the seat was occupied by , the winner of a special election on April 19, 2016, to replace , who was convicted of corruption and expelled from the Assembly in 2015.\n\nRajkumar finished second in a six-way Democratic primary; the winner, , went on to win in the general election in November.\n\n\nRajkumar ran in the primary for the   district in Queens, which includes portions of the Glendale, Ozone Park, Richmond Hill, Ridgewood, and Woodhaven neighborhoods, against incumbent Democrat  and challenger . Rajkumar was endorsed by California Congressman  in February 2020. In May 2020, '' ''criticized Rajkumar alongside a slate of other candidates for  across multiple primaries and elections.\n\nRajkumar defeated Miller and De Jesus in the June 2020 Democratic primary and won over Giovanni Perna in the November general election. Along with , Rajkumar was one of the first members of Indian ancestry elected to the Assembly, and the first American woman of Indian ancestry.\n\n'''New York City Comptroller'''\n\nOn August 12, 2024, Rajkumar announced her intention to run to become New York City's 46th .Assembly Member Directory  New York State Assembly |url=https://nyassembly.gov/mem/Jenifer-Rajkumar |access-date=August 6, 2022 |website=nyassembly.gov}}\n\n\n'''2022'''\n\n'''2020'''\n\n\n\n\nRajkumar is a \n\n\n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Thomas Peter DiNapoli''' (born February 10, 1954) is an American politician serving as the 54th and current  since 2007. A member of the , he was appointed by a bipartisan majority of the  to the position of comptroller on February 7, 2007. He was then elected Comptroller by New York's voters in 2010, 2014, 2018 and 2022. In his 2014 victory, he led the statewide ticket with the most votes. He was easily reelected to a third term in November 2018, receiving 64.9% of the vote. In 2022, he secured his fourth term in office, receiving 57% of the vote. He is the second longest-serving comptroller in New York State History.\n\nDiNapoli previously served as a man for the 16th district in northwestern Nassau County, first elected in 1986. He served 20 years in the Assembly. During his tenure, he chaired the Environmental Conservation Committee, the Local Governments Committee, and the Governmental Operations Committee.\n\nHe is a resident of the village of . Long Island Press  www.longislandpress.com |date=5 November 2014 |url=https://www.longislandpress.com/2014/11/05/ny-comptroller-tom-dinapoli-beats-gop-rival/}}\n\n\nDiNapoli was born to Nicholas Peter DiNapoli and Adeline (Abbondandelo) DiNapoli, named after his paternal grandfather Thomas Peter DiNapoli. DiNapoli, raised in , has been active in politics since he was a teenager, when he ran for and won a position as a trustee on the  .Danny Hakim, \"Man in the News: Thomas P. DiNapoli, a Nice Guy Who Wound Up Finishing First,\" '''', February 8, 2007. Found at  . Accessed March 29, 2010. At the age of 18 in 1972, he was the youngest person in New York State history elected to public office. He served on the  for 10 years.\n\nIn 1976, DiNapoli graduated  from  with a  in history. After college he worked for  and . In 1988, he received a  in human resources management from 's Graduate School of Management and Urban Professions.\n\n\n\nDiNapoli worked as an aide for Assemblyman . He also served as a district representative for Congressman . DiNapoli was a member of the  from 1987 to 2007, sitting in the , , , , , , , , ,  and  New York state legislatures. He represented the 16th district, located in Northwest . DiNapoli was later also elected as Chairman of the Nassau County  Committee. In 2001, he lost the Democratic nomination for Nassau County Executive to , who later won the election. In 2006, DiNapoli was a candidate for , but dropped out of the race after Attorney General , the party's frontrunner for , chose Senate Minority Leader  as his running mate.\n\n\n\n\n\n resigned in December 2006. On February 7, 2007, in a joint session of the , DiNapoli was elected as New York State Comptroller in a vote of 150–56.\n\n\nIn lieu of a transition committee, DiNapoli established a commission to review the Comptroller's office. The commission was headed by former   and financial expert . Also included in this commission were Nassau  , Chancellor of  University , and  . In March 2007, as one of DiNapoli's first public statements as Comptroller, he warned Governor  that his proposed budget had levels of spending were at an \"unsustainable rate\". DiNapoli stated that, at the rate proposed by Spitzer's budget, there would be a $13 billion deficit in three years' time.\n\nAs Comptroller, DiNapoli makes periodic, public reports on a variety of issues affecting state, local, and charitable agencies. In March 2010, he reported that non-profits had been hurt by the recession as well as by delays in state contracts. The following month, he gained a reputation as a critic of the State's budget deficit.\"DiNapoli wants to alter budget process\", ''Business First of Buffalo'' and ''The Albany Business Review'', March 9, 2010. Found at , accessed April 5, 2010. He \"has proposed major reforms in the state budget process\". He unveiled a package of proposed reforms to the budget process in March 2010. Key parts of his plans are for \"governors to identify plans to erase budget deficits in future years\", to cap state debt, and to require excess surplusses to be deposited into the \"\".\n\n\n\nDiNapoli ran for election in November 2010. On May 1, 2010, he won the Democratic Rural Conference's Straw Poll by acclamation. On May 26, 2010, DiNapoli received the designation of the . \"I'm grateful for your support and I salute your commitment to moving our great state forward. It's a commitment I share with each of you,\" said DiNapoli on the occasion. He received the nomination of the  for comptroller.\n\nIn November 2010, he narrowly won reelection. DiNapoli claimed victory early the morning of November 3, and  conceded later in the morning.\n\n\n\nDiNapoli ran for reelection in November 2014. On May 21, 2014, he received the nomination of the New York Democratic Party. \"This office has an important compelling and independent role to play in moving our state forward. As New York State Comptroller, I'll continue to go to work every day striving to do right by New Yorkers,\" said DiNapoli at the Democratic Convention. He also received the nomination of the Independence, Working Families and Women's Equality parties for State Comptroller.\n\nIn November 2014, he won reelection, defeating Republican candidate . DiNapoli received the most votes of any statewide candidate with 2,077,293 votes.\n\n\n\nDiNapoli ran for reelection for a third full term. On May 23, 2018, he received the nomination of the New York Democratic Party. \"This office has a lot more work to do for a safer, fairer New York. As New York State Comptroller, I'll continue to go to work every day striving to do right by New Yorkers,\" said DiNapoli at the Democratic Convention. He also received the nomination of the Independence, Working Families and Women's Equality and Reform parties for State Comptroller.\n\nIn November 2018, he won reelection, defeating Republican candidate Jonathan Trichter, a former Democrat who switched to the GOP. DiNapoli once again received the most votes of any statewide candidate with 4,027,886 votes.\n\n\n\nDiNapoli won reelection to a fourth term. He ran unopposed in the primary.\n\n\nDiNapoli is single and has no children. He lives in .\n\nBoth of his parents are the children of immigrants. His father, Nick, served in , and after the war worked as a cable splicer for New York Telephone. For a time he was a shop steward for his union, the Communications Workers of America. DiNapoli's mother, Adeline, was a records clerk for the county police department. On September 1, 2013, he received the honorary citizenship in the small town of Paduli, in the province of Benevento - Italy, the birthplace of his paternal grandfather. He has been awarded an honorary degree from Hofstra University and Ulster University.\n\n\n\n*DiNapoli also appeared on the Independence Party and Liberal Party lines; Zampino also appeared on the Conservative Party line.\n\n*DiNapoli also appeared on the Independence Party, Liberal Party, and Working Families Party lines; Galluscio also appeared on the Conservative Party and Right to Life Party lines.\n\n*DiNapoli also appeared on the Independence Party, Liberal Party, and Working Families Party lines.\n\n*DiNapoli also appeared on the Independence Party, Liberal Party, and Working Families Party lines; McGillicuddy also appeared on the Conservative Party line.\n\n*DiNapoli also appeared on the Working Families Party line; Wilson also appeared on the Independence Party and Conservative Party lines.\n\n*DiNapoli also appeared on the Working Families Party, Independence Party, and Women's Equality Party lines; Antonacci also appeared on the Conservative Party and Stop Common Core Party lines.\n\n*DiNapoli also appeared on the Working Families Party, Independence Party, Women's Equality Party, and Reform Party lines; Trichter also appeared on the Conservative Party line.\n\n*DiNapoli also appeared on the Working Families Party line; Rodriguez also appeared on the Conservative Party line.\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n*\n*\n* ''''.     "pages": }\n'''Jaime R. Williams''' (born August 24, 1979) is the Assembly member for the 59th district of the . She is a . The district includes portions of , , , , and  in .\n\n\nWilliams was born and raised in  before immigrating to  in 1999, where she has been a resident of  ever since. Williams graduated from  with a master's degree in  before going to work in the community, including for  prevention.\n\nFollowing , Williams worked for Catholic Social Services of Brooklyn and Queens to help with relief efforts.  She joined the staff of Assemblywoman  following her election in 2014 as her .\n\n\n\nAssemblywoman  was elected to the  in a special election in November 2015 following  losing his Senate seat due to a felony conviction. As a result, she resigned from the Assembly to take her seat in the Senate.  Brooklyn Democrats soon after chose Williams to run in the special election to serve out the remainder of Persaud's term.  She went on to win the special election against Republican Jeffrey Feretti with 82.47% of the vote.\n\nWilliams was seated in the Assembly on May 10, 2016.\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
