    "pages": }\n'''Christopher John Lee''' (born April 1, 1964) is a former American politician and former  member of the  for . He served from January 2009 until he resigned on February 9, 2011, after it was revealed that he had solicited a woman on .\n\n\nLee was raised in  in a politically-active family. His sister ran regional affairs in western New York for former  , and his father was the finance chairman on several campaigns for former U.S. Rep. .\n\nLee earned a Bachelor of Arts degree in  and  from the  and a  from  in . At Rochester, he was a member of the  fraternity.\n\n\nDuring his campaign for Congress, it emerged that Lee was fired from a sales job in Buffalo at  (now in ) when he was 25 years old. He had obtained his supervisor's password and accessed customer accounts to change their credit limits with the company; as a result, Lee and another employee were fired.\n\nLee moved to California, where he worked for  as director of sales before returning to New York in 1995 to work for Enidine, Inc., a company founded by his father and based in . He worked at Enidine in various roles including Pacific Rim sales manager, director of international sales and marketing, and then general manager. Under Lee's direction, the business was transformed \"from a small machine shop in western New York to a global enterprise,\" according to ''The New York Times''.\n\nIn 2003, Lee became automation group president of  (IMC) of , another company founded by his father. He oversaw the group's acquisition of the  firm Evolutionary Concepts Inc., and worked at IMC until it was sold to the  for nearly $400&nbsp;million in 2007.\n\nLee's father established the Patrick P. Lee Foundation, where Chris Lee served as director. The foundation promotes cancer and mental illness awareness, education, prevention, and research in .\n\n\n\nLee announced his candidacy for the  nomination for the  in  in April 2008. He was endorsed by the incumbent Rep. , who was retiring; ultimately, Lee was supported by all seven of the district's Republican county chairmen, who met in May 2008 to announce that he would obtain the party's official endorsement. His candidacy garnered the support of  Chairman  in an election year in which the Republican party was looking for self-financed candidates. Lee won reelection in 2010 with 76 percent of the vote in a district that consistently votes Republican, according to ''The Weekly Standard''.\n\n\n\n\n\nIn Congress, Lee was a conservative who voted with the Republican party 93% of the time during his first term. He voted \"no\" on the repeal of , and \"no\" on the  and the health care reform bills. He voted with the Democrats to expand the State Children's Health Insurance Program, provide compensation to the 9/11 responders, overhaul the nation's food safety system, and reauthorize the America Competes Act. In 2009, Lee supported the proposed Student Internet Safety Act, which was aimed at protecting children from internet predators.\n\nAlthough Lee was a fiscally conservative budget hawk, he obtained $29.7&nbsp;million in federal funds (known as ) for his districtmore than any of the Democratic members of Congress in neighboring districts. Lee explained that earmarks can be helpful in promoting job growth and said it is better to have earmarks than to have spending decisions made by unelected bureaucrats. He obtained earmarks for a small arms practice range for an Air Reserve station, high-speed rail, and local defense contractors. Lee was a member of the House Republican Economic Group, as well as the House Ways and Means Committee. This group sought to reduce individual tax rates, allow small businesses to reduce their tax liabilities, and provide assistance for the unemployed. As stated in his 2008 campaign, he believed that \"taxes were too high, too burdensome and too complex\".\n\nHe was criticized for liberal use of the  privilege to send constituents glossy newsletters, some of which were described as promotional whereas others only gave constituents information on new legislation and proposals. In August 2010, Lee proposed a plan to bring manufacturing jobs back to the United States. The plan involved lowering the corporate tax rate, student loan forgiveness for students who enter fields related to manufacturing, and trade reform to open up new markets.\n\nIn December 2010, he met with representatives of online travel agencies to pressure them into complying with a law that requires websites to show when regional airlines are operating any part of a flight.\n\n\nIn the wake of the , Lee said \"I think what we need to look at is ensuring there are sufficient background checks to make sure that those who are unstable don't have access to weapons of that nature.\" He also spent the beginning of his first term working with the House Ways and Means Committee.\n\n\nOn February 9, 2011, Lee was found to have been soliciting a trans woman on . He used a  account to send a woman a shirtless photo taken with his  phone. The woman searched his name, discovered he was a married congressman, and turned over her email correspondence to news blog , which published an exposé on February 9, 2011. Lee resigned from office the same day. He issued a statement of apology, saying, \"I regret the harm that my actions have caused my family, my staff and my constituents.... I have made profound mistakes and I promise to work as hard as I can to seek their forgiveness.\" Lee did not return to Western New York after his resignation. Democratic Erie County clerk  filled his seat after winning the  on May 24 set by Governor .\n\n\nAfter his resignation, Lee dedicated more of his time to philanthropic work. He is currently on the board of the Patrick P. Lee Foundation and serves as the Treasurer of the Osprey Cove Master Association.\n\n\nLee and his wife, Michele, have one child.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* at \n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n''|years=}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
          }
        ]
      }
    }

    "pages": }\n'''Eliot Lance Engel''' (; born February 18, 1947) is an American politician who served as a  from  from 1989 to 2021. A member of the , he represented a district covering portions of the north  and southern .\n\nIn 2019, following Democratic gains in the , he took over as Chairman of the ; he previously was its ranking member from 2013, following 's reelection defeat in .\n\nHe had won his first congressional election in 1989 by defeating , who did not campaign though his name was on the ballot. In , after 16 terms in office, Engel was defeated in the Democratic primary by middle school principal .\n\n\nEngel was born in , the son of Sylvia (née Bleend) and Philip Engel, an . His grandparents, of  background, were immigrants from the . He grew up in a city housing project, Eastchester Gardens, and attended  public schools.\n\nIn 1969, Engel graduated from the Bronx campus of  with a  in . He subsequently received a  in guidance and counseling in 1973 from the same institution, by now renamed  following the severance of its relationship with Hunter College. In February 1987, he earned a  from .\n\n\nHe began his political career in local Democratic clubs. He taught in the  and was a school counselor. He taught at Intermediate School 52 from 1969 to 1976, and then at Intermediate School 174.\n\n\nIn 1977, Engel entered the special election for a seat in the  after the incumbent Democrat  was forced to resign. He was the  nominee in the special election, and on March 1, 1977, he won by 103 votes, defeating Democratic nominee Ted Weinstein and Republican nominee Arlene Siegel.\n\nEngel was a member of the  from 1977 to 1988, sitting in the , , , , , and s. He chaired the Committee on Alcoholism and Substance Abuse, and the Subcommittee on the .\n\n\n\nIn 1988, Engel ran for the  in . His state assembly district covered much of the congressional district's southeastern corner. He defeated ten-term incumbent Democrat  in the  with 48% of the vote, as Biaggi had resigned his seat and did not campaign for office, though his name remained on the ballot since election petitions were already filed. Biaggi had been charged by  with  in the , and was eventually jailed. Biaggi was unopposed for the Republican nomination (he had run on both the Republican and Democratic lines since 1972), which Engel won with 56% of the vote.\n\nEngel's district, which became the 17th in 1993 and has been the 16th since 2013, had historically been one of the more conservative districts in New York City. Republicans represented much of its territory at the state level as late as 2004. However, reflecting the increasing Democratic trend in the Bronx at the federal level, Engel would never face another general election contest nearly as close as his first one. He was re-elected 14 more times with at least 61 percent of the vote, and only dropped below 70 percent of the vote twice. As a measure of the district's growing Democratic trend, Biaggi is the last candidate running on the Republican line to clear the 40 percent mark.\n\nBy the 1990s, as in much of the rest of New York City, the Democratic primary had become the real contest in this district. From 1990 to 2018, Engel only faced two competitive primary contests (getting less than 70%). In 1994, he defeated musician  62%-38%. In 2000, Engel defeated State Senator , who had the support of Bronx County Democratic Party Chairman Roberto Ramirez, 50%-41%.\n\nIn , Engel was challenged in the primary by Yonkers school principal , who ran well to Engel's left. Engel initially received an endorsement from New York State Senator , Mario Biaggi's granddaughter. However, in early June, after a hot mic gaffe by Engel, where he insisted on speaking at a press conference and said, \"If I didn't have a primary, I wouldn't care,\" Biaggi withdrew her support of Engel and instead endorsed Bowman.\n\nIn a mid-June poll, Engel trailed Bowman by ten percentage points and, after the election, with early and election day votes counted, Bowman led Engel by almost 12,000 votes, 61.8% to 34.9%. Absentee ballots were scheduled to be counted on June 30, 2020, though some sources called the race for Bowman before the counting of absentee ballots. After the absentee ballots were counted, Bowman's lead was 55.4%-40.6%, or 13,218 votes. The race was called for Bowman on July 17, 2020, with the  certifying the results on August 6, 2020.\n\n\n* ''''''\n** \n** \n* '''''' (Chair, 116th Congress) (Ranking Member, 113th, 114th, 115th Congress)\n\n;Party leadership\n* Vice Chair of the Democratic Task Force on Homeland Security\n* Assistant Democratic Whip\n\n;Caucus memberships\n* Arab-Israeli Peace Accord Monitoring Group\n* Congressional Albanian Caucus\n* \n* Congressional Hellenic-Israeli Alliance\n* Ad Hoc Congressional Committee for Irish Affairs\n* \n* Democratic Task Force on Health\n* House Oil and National Security Caucus (Founder and Co-Chair)\n* \n* \n* House Caucus on Human Rights\n* House Caucus on the Hudson Valley\n*\n* \n* \n* Congressional  (Founding Member) \n* Congressional LGBT Equality Caucus \n*\n*\n* Congressional Argentina Caucus (Founder)\n\n\n\nEngel could be seen shaking hands with the President at a number of televised es during his time in Congress. Along with other Members of Congress, Engel showed up at the  early in order to guarantee that he would get an aisle seat. Engel managed to shake hands with the President at every address, and be seen by his constituents on live television, starting when he arrived in Congress in 1989. He expressed that, \"It's an honor to shake the hand of the president of the United States no matter who it is.\"\n\nThis tradition ended in 2017 when Engel decided not to shake then President 's hand.\n\n\n\n\nA strong supporter of , Engel supported quality access to , and referred to himself as  \"all the way\". Engel was a co-sponsor of the , which would implement a single-payer health care system in the United States. In 2010 he was a strong supporter of the landmark  once he secured provisions that  would not be penalized for providing more generous benefits than other states.\n\nIn 2008, Engel authored the  (P.L. 110–373), which established a national registry for the collection and storage of data on those suffering from ALS. He also authored the   (P.L. 110–361), which promoted research at Centers of Excellence for Muscular Dystrophy.\n\nIn 2010, Engel wrote the  to improve maternity care for mothers and newborns, and to do so in partnership with doctors, advocates, payers, and purchasers. In 2010 he also wrote the , which passed the House, but didn't come to a vote in the Senate. In 2018, he reintroduced the legislation in the  for consideration. It was not voted on. The legislation would provide for better tracking and research into gestational diabetes, which, if untreated, could lead to  for both mother and child.\n\n\nEngel supported an improved re-authorization of the  (PEPFAR). Within the PEPFAR bill, Engel included his bill, the Stop Tuberculosis Now Act. This measure would provide increased U.S. support for international  activities, and promotes research to develop new drugs, diagnostics, and vaccines.\n\n\nIn 2005, Engel, along with Congressman  (R-GA), introduced the Fuel Choices for American Security Act (H.R. 4409), later modified and re-introduced in 2007 as the DRIVE Act (H.R. 670) - the Dependence Reduction through Innovation in Vehicles and Energy Act - with more than 80 bi-partisan co-sponsors. It was designed to promote America's  and economic stability by reducing dependence on foreign oil through the use of clean  and advanced vehicle technologies. It also called for increased tire efficiency - to increase a vehicle's gas miles.\n\nMany provisions of the DRIVE Act were included in the , which was signed into law on December 19, 2007, and became Public Law No. 110-140. This law mandates increased fuel efficiency standards from 25 miles per gallon to 35 miles per gallon by 2020. The law also requires improved energy efficiency standards for appliances, lighting and buildings, and the development of American-grown s like , , and .\n\nEngel introduced the Open Fuel Standards Act, alongside Congressmen Kingston,  (D-NY) and  (R-SC). This bill would have required 50 percent of new cars sold in the  by 2012 (and 80 percent of new cars sold by 2015) to be s capable of running on any combination of , , or . Flex fuel vehicles cost about $100 more than the same vehicle in a gasoline-only version.\n\nEngel on the  and Subcommittee on Energy and the Environment. He played a key role in negotiating the American Clean Energy and Security Act, HR 2454, which passed the House on June 26, 2009. That legislation was intended to revitalize the economy by creating millions of new jobs, increase American national security by reducing dependence on foreign oil, and preserve the planet by reducing . It passed the House in 2009, but was not voted on by the Senate in the .\n\n\nA supporter of , Engel in Congress \"worked to , s and armor-piercing bullets, institute s, adopt s, and restore funding for gun violence research.\" Engel received an \"F\" grade from the  and 100 percent ratings from the  and . He voted against a  that immunized firearm manufacturers and dealers from civil liability for gun misuse, supports \"\" technology to prevent guns from being used by unauthorized persons, and voted against a bill to reduce the waiting period to purchase a gun at a gun show. In 2009, Engel was one of 53 members of Congress who signed a letter to President , urging the new president to resume enforcement of a ban on the import of foreign  (authorized by the  and enforced during the administrations of  and ). In 2011, after 400,000 defective s were recalled from the market, Engel introduced a bill intended to protect parents and children from faulty gun locks by instructing the  (CPSC) to set a national quality standard for all child safety devices used on firearms.\n\n\nOn December 22, 2010, President Barack Obama signed into law the . The legislation was introduced by  in the Senate, passed the House on December 15, and is virtually identical to Engel's bill. The new law cracks down on the use of , often used by criminals to trick their victims into giving out personal information. The legislation will help law enforcement combat .\n\nEngel originally introduced the Securing our Borders and Our Data Act in July 2008, HR 6702. That bill would ensure that when a traveler enters the United States, a border agent cannot search or seize the traveler's data or equipment without cause. The legislation was re-introduced in the 111th Congress as HR 239. The  altered their rules to prevent agents from searching and seizing without cause. This encompassed much of Engel's legislation.\n\nIn the 109th Congress, Engel introduced the Calling Card Consumer Protection Act, HR 3402. The bill was intended to stop some of the massive fraud in the prepaid calling card industry. The legislation passed the House unanimously, but the Senate did not act on it. In 2011, Engel introduced the , which would prohibit products to be sold that enable cheating on drug tests.\n\nIn 2010, Engel urged the  to stop their plan to ban private transfer fees on  sales. Some developers and investors had been  by imposing transfer fees that would have provided them with percentages on all future sales of the property over many decades. The transfer fee, when used correctly, can help owners and developers fund projects and remain affordable. The FHFA decided not to pursue this plan in 2011.\n\nIn 2012, Engel introduced , the Social Network Online Protection Act. It would guarantee online privacy and ensure that employers and educational institutions cannot use personal data as a bargaining chip for employment or education. Employers/schools would be barred from requesting or requiring usernames or passwords to  sites as part of the hiring, employment, or enrollment process. The bill was re-introduced in the , with Rep.  as the Republican lead, and Rep.  as an original co-sponsor.\n\n\n]]\nEngel is a supporter of recognizing  as the capital of , and has also been an advocate for the causes of  and ethnic  in . In 2003, he authored the , which was signed into law by President  on December 12, 2003. In this Law, Congress authorized penalties and restrictions on US relations with  for its  of , and for its relationship with terrorist groups. Syria withdrew all forces from Lebanon in 2005 after the .\n\nIn September 2020, Engel stated that \"the influence of external actors such as  recklessly meddling\" in the  is \"troubling\".\n\n\nAs Chairman of the House of Representatives  Subcommittee on the , Engel called for stronger U.S. relations with  and the . His Subcommittee held hearings on issues such as the crisis in , poverty, and inequality in Latin America.\n\nEngel pushed for increased funding for emergency relief in Haiti, and for Temporary Protective Status (TPS) of Haitian nationals in the U.S. Engel is also supportive of the \"\", in which the U.S. is cooperating with , , the , and Haiti to counter  and related violence in the region. In the , he introduced the Social Investment and Economic Development Act for the Americas of 2007 (re-introduced in 2009, where it also died in committee) and sponsored the Western Hemisphere Energy Compact Act to develop partnerships to strengthen diplomatic relations with the Government of Brazil, and the governments of other countries in the Western Hemisphere (died in committee).\n\nThe bi-partisan Western Hemisphere Drug Policy Commission Act of 2009 (sponsored by Engel) was passed by the House on December 8, 2009; it would have taken a fresh look at the United States' counter-narcotics efforts, both at home and abroad. The bill did not pass the Senate.\n\n\n, in ,  in January 2015]]\nEngel was one of the leading congressional supporters of . Although he supported resolutions critical of both Israelis and Palestinians, his criticisms of Israeli policies were usually couched as warnings of their harm to Israel itself. In 2008, he was the lead Democrat on a resolution condemning  rocket attacks on Israeli civilians by  and other Palestinian militant organizations. Shortly after entering Congress, he sponsored a resolution declaring  the undivided capital of Israel. A very pro-Israel position, this was contrary to official American policy until President  adopted it in December 2019. He also wrote the , which was signed into law by President  on December 12, 2003. This law authorized restrictions on American relations with , and penalties for its occupation of , and for its relationship with terrorist groups.\n\nIn 2016 Engel was one of only 16 Democrats to join with 200 Republicans and defeat a measure that would have banned the sale of cluster bombs to  who is at war with . In November 2018 the CIA determined that Saudi Crown Prince  had ordered the brutal murder of  columnist . Engel told NPR that he did not want to see  Salman “punished.”\n\nIn January 2017, Engel introduced a House resolution condemning the , which condemned  in the occupied  as a violation of international law.\n\n\nThe , an   group in , added Engel to its lobby lineup of prominent politicians in the early 1990s. In 1996, '''' wrote, \"The  cause has been kept alive in  by a small group of congressmen led by Rep. Eliot L. Engel (D-N.Y.)\"  While a member of the Subcommittee on Europe and Chair of the Congressional Albanian Issues Caucus, Engel fought  in the 1999  and voiced support in Congress for the unilateral  from Serbia. A street has been named after him in , and he was the first foreign dignitary to address the .\n\n\nEngel called for the withdrawal of  troops from , and authored a resolution in 1996 calling for its . His 1994 law allowed the  to conduct an investigation of five Americans who disappeared during the , and found the remains of one. Engel received the  Award on May 17, 2007, given to those who have utilized ancient  values to contribute to the nations and people of Cyprus and America and to the Hellenics in the modern world.\n\n\nIn 2002, although 133 members of the House of Representatives voted against it, Engel voted for the resolution granting President Bush the authority to use force in Iraq, as did the two  from ,  and , and almost 300 members of the ., . After revelations that intelligence provided to Congress was partially unreliable, and the subsequent problems faced after  was deposed, Engel has come to regret his decision to support the , and consistently votes in favor of gradual withdrawal. He has met with anti-war activists, and in 2008, he publicly called for the closing of the . Engel received an \"A\" grade from the Iraq and Afghanistan War Veterans in 2008.\n\n\nIn 2007, Engel became a Co-Chair of the Congressional Ad Hoc Committee on Irish Affairs. He supported the 1998 , and aided Irish nationals facing deportation from the United States. He has been a friend of , former leader of , and was the author of legislation that prohibits employers in  and  from receiving U.S. funds from the , unless they comply with fair employment and non-discrimination principles called the \"\". In 2010, Engel was instrumental in helping Joe Byrne return to the , after a bureaucratic problem left him detained in Ireland and separated from his family in .\n\n\n]]\nAs a member of the , Engel supported  and ethnic . He is co-author of the , along with Senator  (D-IA), which addresses  in the cocoa fields of .\n\nIn early 2001, he wrote the House resolution condemning the  for forcing  citizens to wear distinguishing marks as reminiscent of the  forcing Jews to wear a yellow . In 2008, he wrote a resolution commending the U.S.-Brazil Joint Action Plan to Promote Racial and Ethnic Equality.\n\nEngel sponsored a bill to support the , during which students vow to remain silent to bring attention to the harassment and discrimination faced by  people in schools. That bill has been re-submitted in the . He also voted against the  (DOMA), which allowed for states not to be required to recognize s in other states. In 2010, he voted in 2010 to repeal the \"\" policy, enabling homosexuals to serve  in the U.S. military.\n\nIn 2018, Engel condemned the  of the  minority in  and called for a stronger response to the crisis.\n\nEngel urged the Trump administration to take a tougher line on China by imposing sanctions on Chinese officials who are responsible for  against the   minority in China's northwestern  region. In March 2019, the group of lawmakers led by Engel wrote a letter to Secretary of State  that read in part, \"This issue is bigger than just China. It is about demonstrating to strongmen globally that the world will hold them accountable for their actions.\"\n\nIn June 2020, Engel stated that Polish President  and Poland's nationalist  (PiS) party \"promote horrifying  and anti-LGBTQ stereotypes and policies that run counter to the human rights and values that America should strive to uphold\".\n\n\nIn August 2015, Engel announced that he would oppose the  in congress, saying that, \"The answers I've received simply don't convince me that this deal will keep a nuclear weapon out of Iran's hands, and may in fact strengthen Iran's position as a destabilizing and destructive influence across the Middle East.\"\n\n\n\nIn March 2009, the  reported that Engel had been taking an annual  on his , residence for at least 10 years (cumulatively receiving thousands of dollars in tax credits), despite the fact that the credit is reserved for people who declare Maryland their primary residence. Maryland officials revoked the tax credit. The matter was reviewed by the , which also looked into similar tax credits claimed by three other members of the House. The OCE eventually ended its review on Engel and two of the other members of Congress ( and ) without recommending further investigation by the .\n\nIn 1988, publisher Christopher Hagedorn began targeting Engel with criticism in his Bronx weekly newspapers (the ''Bronx News'', the ''Parkchester News'', and the ''Co-op City News''), when he alleged that Engel, when he was still an assemblyman, was behind a failed effort to evict the Co-op City News from its offices. In addition, Hagedorn later reprinted articles from other newspapers that contained criticism of Engel. Hagedorn also endorsed Engel's Democratic opponents, including  in 2000; however, this did not prevent Engel's re-election to Congress.\n\nEngel mostly ignored Hagedorn's criticism and accusations. In 1995, however, his communications director, Greg Howard, told the ''Bronx Beat'' newspaper \"We don't consider Mr. Hagedorn a legitimate journalist. He uses the paper as his own personal platform for whatever agenda he has. He chooses the paper to malign people with whom he has philosophical differences.\" In the last decade, Hagedorn's newspapers have been mostly silent in regard to Engel.\n\nIn January 2020, he revealed that in a call after he was fired as Trump's ,  \"suggested to [Engel]  unprompted  that the [Foreign Affairs Committee] look into the recall of Ambassador .\"\n\nIn April 2020, Engel claimed he had visited his district and taken part in COVID-19 and healthcare related events, before confirming when challenged that he had not returned to New York since March.\n\nIn June 2020, Engel appeared at a press conference to address the  resulting from the . When Bronx Borough President  indicated there was not enough time for Engel to address the press, Engel responded, \"If I didn't have a primary, I wouldn't care.\" Diaz immediately rebuked Engel, saying, \"We're not politicizing. Everybody's got a primary, you know?\"\n\n\nEngel received an A on the 's 2005 Congressional Scorecard on middle-class issues. Engel has received positive marks from major environmental groups such as the  and the .\n\nEngel received the National Association of Public Hospitals Safety Net Award in 2007 primarily for the introduction of The Public and Teaching Hospital Preservation Act. He also earned the 100% Perfection in the Pursuit of Equality in 2002 from the . Engel was presented with The AIDS Institute National HIV/AIDS Care and Treatment Award in 2007 and is the 2008 Distinguished Community Health Superhero as deemed by the National Association of Community Health Centers.\n\nHe was honored in 2008 by the  and the New York Farm Bureau as a Friend of the Farm Bureau for his support of farm issues during the . He received an A on the 's Congressional Scorecards in 2005 and 2008 for supporting middle-class issues. Engel has had a nearly 100% rating from the  over his entire legislative career. On November 11, 2011, the Municipality of , , gave Engel the title of Honorary Citizen of Peje.\n\nIn July 2019, the highway section M9.1 between ,  and SH22 ,  passing through ,  was named Eliot Engel Drive by local authorities.\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n allbusiness.com \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nhttp://bulk.resource.org/gpo.gov/record/1997/1997_H03615.pdf \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n* \n* \n*  at BrainyQuote.com\n\n\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n''|years=}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Joseph Charles Borelli''' (born July 27, 1982) is an American politician and the  member for the  and Minority Leader of the . He is a  and a former media surrogate of the Donald Trump campaign. The district encompasses much of 's .\n\n\n\nJoseph was born on Staten Island and adopted at birth by the Borelli family. He attended Public School 4, Our Lady Star of the Sea Grammar School, and , starring on the football and swimming team, from which he graduated in 2000. He earned the rank of Eagle Scout in 1997.\n\nAfter graduating from , he worked on the campaign of , who was elected to the  from the 62nd District. He became Chief-of-Staff to the then-Assemblyman, and continued in that role when Ignizio was elected to the  in February 2007.\n\n\nBorelli was elected on November 6, 2012, to the State Assembly to succeed the retiring . He was one of only two  in 's State Assembly delegation.\n\nOn November 3, 2015, Borelli won election to replace fellow Republican  on the City Council. Ignizio left in July to work for a nonprofit. He was sworn into office on November 30, 2015, and was chosen to be the Council's Minority Whip. Borelli served as the chair of the Council's Committee on Fire and Emergency Management, where he oversaw the FDNY.\n\nIn 2016, Borelli frequently appeared on national cable TV news shows where he supported  as the  presidential nominee. Borelli also co-chaired Trump's campaign during the 2016 . Borelli was re-elected in the , winning 80% of the vote.\n\nIn 2019, Borelli was the Republican and Conservative Party nominee for NYC  running against Democratic incumbent . Williams won the race garnering 77.9 percent of the vote to Borelli's 20%. In 2019,  Chairman  named Borelli as a spokesman to help spread the New York GOP's message during the 2020 election cycle.\n\nOn November 17, 2021, Borelli was elected as Minority Leader of the City Council's Republican delegation, replacing outgoing Council Member Steven Matteo. During his tenure, he grew the conference to six members and founded and co-chaired the Common Sense Caucus, which consists of nine moderate bipartisan members. \n\nIn 2022, Borelli successfully opposed the implementation of congestion pricing to areas of Manhattan because it would add costs, congestion and pollution for Staten Islanders.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Sandra Galef''' (née '''Risk'''; born May 7, 1940) is an American politician who served as a member of the  for 30 years.\n\n\nGalef was born Sandra Risk in  on May 7, 1940. In 1944, she moved with her family to  in New York. She received a B.A. from  and an M.A. in education from the , and began her career as a teacher in a rural schoolhouse near . Then, Galef moved back to New York, where she worked as a teacher in . In 1963, she married Steven Galef, a former Westchester County legislator and attorney, with whom she had two children; she remained married to Steven until his death in 1998.\n\n\nIn 1980, Galef was elected to the , where she represented the 2nd and 9th Districts and served as the minority leader from 1984 until 1992, when she was elected to the Assembly.\n\nGalef was elected to the 90th Assembly District and began her term in 1993. During her time in the Assembly, Galef chaired the Real Property Tax Committee, the Libraries and Education Technology Committee, and the Subcommittee for Rural Health, and was a member of the Corporations, Authorities, and Commissions Committee, the Election Law Committee, the Governmental Operations Committee, and the Health Committee.\n\nIn 1997, Galef introduced an amendment to make the language of the  . Galef argued that the  of the Constitution was \"old-fashioned\" and that a change to gender neutral language was \"symbolically ... important\". New York voters adopted the amendment in November 2001. In 1999, Galef was an early supporter of  in New York. Galef also supported several  causes, including measures to build consensus with  members of the assembly, campaign finance reform, and staff budget parity between the majority and the minority in the Assembly.\n\nIn December 2022, Governor  signed a bill introduced by Galef that allows  to issue a one-day permit to a non-ordained individual to officiate a specific wedding in New York.\n\nThroughout her legislative career, Galef hosted two television shows, \"Dear Sandy\" and \"Speakout with Sandy Galef\", on .\n\n\n}}\n\n}}\n\n}}\n\n}}\n\n}}\n\n}}\n\n}}\n\n}}\n\n .}}\n\n .}}\n\n .}}\n\n .}}\n\n .}}\n\n}}\n\n}}\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Matthew Scott Murphy''' (born January 26, 1970) is an American  and politician. He represented parts of New York state's  (excluding the city of ) in the  for a portion of one term from April 2009 until January 2011. He was defeated for election to a full term on November 2, 2010.\n\nHe is a member of the  and was a member of the  in Congress.\n\n\nThe son of a  and , Murphy graduated from the  in , in 1988, He later graduated  from .\n\nMurphy worked for  for two and a half years in the early 1990s before becoming an entrepreneur. In 1994, he co-founded an interactive media company, Small World Software. In 1998 the company, which had grown to 25 employees, was purchased by the internet-consulting company iXL. He then served as one of the heads of the purchased entity, rebranded \"iXL New York\". iXL later went bankrupt in 2002 during the end of the . In 2001 Murphy joined Advantage Capital Partners, an Impact Investing Company that attempts to bring businesses, technologies and jobs to communities that have historically lacked access to investment capital.\n\nHe is a past-President of the Board of Directors of Upstate Capital Association, (fka Upstate Venture Association of New York, Inc.) He worked as an aide, Deputy , and  for former   and .\n\n\n\n\n  at a campaign stop on March 29, 2009.]]\n\n\nOn January 22, 2009,  , a Democrat representing , was appointed by   to fill the  seat vacated by , who assumed the office of  in the .\n\nOn February 1, 2009, Murphy was chosen by a unanimous vote of ten Democratic   to be their party's nominee for  to fill Gillibrand's seat in the House.\n\nMurphy ran against  nominee  from , who, until April 2009, was the  of the . Murphy was endorsed by   and Senator Gillibrand.\n\nThe initial count from the election had Murphy leading by approximately 60 votes out of more than 150,000 cast. However, by April 24, after re-tallies and absentee ballot counting, Murphy was ahead by 399 votes, and Tedisco conceded the election. Murphy was sworn in on April 29.\n\n\nOn November 7, 2009, Murphy voted against the . Murphy opposed the , which proposed to restrict federal funding and subsidies for plans that cover elective abortion.\n\nIn March 2010, Murphy supported the , known today as Obamacare.\n\nIn December 2010, Murphy voted for the Protecting Students from Sexual and Violent Predators Act, which require criminal background checks for school employees and prohibits the employment of school employees who refuse to consent to a criminal background check, make false statements in connection with one, or have been convicted of one of a list of felonies or any other crime that is a violent or sexual crime against a child. The felonies included are homicide, child abuse or neglect, rape or sexual assault, crimes against children, spousal abuse, kidnapping, arson, and physical assault, battery, or drug-related offenses, committed within the past five years.\n\n\nRep. Murphy served on the same two committees as his predecessor, now-Senator Kirsten Gillibrand:\n*''''''\n**\n**\n**\n*''''''\n**\n**\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nMurphy is married to Jennifer Hogan, a native of . They have three children, Simone, Lux and Duke. All three attend school in New York City while living part time in Glens Falls.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n''|years=}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n|birth_date    = \n|birth_place   = \n|death_date    = \n|death_place   = \n|party         = \n|spouse        = Alan Tung\n|children      = 1\n|alma_mater    = \n|website       = \n|religion      =\n|module        = \n}}\n\n'''Margaret S. Chin''' (born May 26, 1953) is a  politician who served as a council member for the  of the .  A , she and  Council member  comprised the Asian American delegation of the city council.\n\nHer district included all or parts of , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , and the . Chin controversially retained the right to run a third term despite its unpopularity in 2010. Seven years later, she ran for re-election and won her primary with 46% of the vote against a newcomer, , who received 44%.\n\n\nBorn on May 26, 1954, in  as the third of five children and the only daughter in the family, Chin immigrated to the United States in 1963. Her father, who arrived in the U.S. before his family, was an , working as a waiter in the ; his experiences inspired his daughter to advocate for  during her political tenure.\n\nChin grew up in  in New York City and graduated from the  and the  with a degree in . She worked for 14 years at 's Division of Adult and Continuing Education.\n\nShe has been a member of several public service groups and organizations. In 1974, she was a founding member of , a group dedicated to \"empowering Asian Americans and others in need\", and she served as the board's president from 1982 to 1986. She was the chairperson of the New York Immigration Coalition, a policy and advocacy organization which works on issues concerning immigrants and refugees. She was a board member of the Association for Neighborhood and Housing Development, an  non-profit organization. Chin was also a founding member of the Chinatown Partnership Local Development Corporation, a group that was formed in 2006 to \"rebuild Chinatown following , and to preserve the neighborhood's unique culture while ensuring its vitality in the future.\"\n\nIn local and state politics, Chin was a member of  and , and was elected to the  for two terms from 1986 to 1990.\n\nChin has stated that her ethnicity helped her win the district that includes Chinatown. In her words, many new immigrants and seniors do not speak English, and appreciated that they could speak to her directly and \"talk to a City Council member without having to go through an interpreter.\"  professor and sociologist , who has written books on Chinese Americans, said that Chin's election victory at the time was a \"milestone in an increasingly active Asian American community\" and a \"special moment in Chinatown history\". Margaret Fung, head of , a national Asian American civil rights group, described her win as a \"significant step forward for Asian American political representation\".\n\n\nPrior to winning the 2009 city council election, Chin had run and lost in the Democratic Party  for the District 1 seat in 1991, 1993, and 2001.\n\nIn a primary with low , she won the Democratic nomination with 39% of the vote, ousting two-term incumbent . Chin earned 4,541 votes to Gerson's 3,520; the other three candidates, PJ Kim, Pete Gleason, and Arthur Gregory won 1,927 votes, 1,293 votes, and 235 votes, respectively. Campaigning on the issues of , improving infrastructure, immigration reform, and better services for senior citizens, Chin won the  held on November 3, 2009, against Republican candidate Irene Horvath in a landslide, carrying 86% of the vote.\n\nIn 2013, Chin ran for reelection. She received an endorsement from the Stonewall Democratic Club of New York prior to that year's September Democratic Party primary and received funding from  for mailings. She was challenged in the primary by Democrat , a  District Leader, in a widely publicized race. Chin won with 58.5% of the vote.\n\nThe councilwoman retained the right to run a third term despite New Yorkers voting against the concept in 2010. In 2017, Chin ran for re-election and won her primary with 46% of the vote against her main challenger, Christopher Marte, a newcomer, who received 44%. Marte ran against her again in the general election on the Independence party line, and Chin won the general election with 49.8% of the vote.\n\n\n\n\n\nIn September 2017 '''' endorsed her opponent Christopher Marte, saying \n\nCritics in October 2019 also opposed her lack of clarity before the vote to expand the current jail in her district; more than 1,000 marched to get her attention on the matter.\n\nOn 8 November 2021, during the lame-duck period of her final term on the city council, Chin introduced a bill specifically targeting over 1600 housing units in her district designated as JLWQA (joint living-work quarters for artists) for fines and flip-taxes in the hundreds of thousands of dollars per unit. The legislation was introduced one day before a vote on rezoning the SoHo and NoHo neighborhoods in her district and was opposed by her elected successor, . Chin nevertheless tabled and voted for the bill, triggering years of legal action after her retirement.\n\nChin is married to Alan Tung, a public school teacher, and has retired to . Their son, Kevin, also graduated from the . He completed his studies at , and is now studying photography in .\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Maritza Davila''' (born November 16, 1963) is an American politician from the state of . A member of the , she represents the 53rd district in the .\n\nAccording to her self-described biography, Davila was born in , . She has served as the President of the Community School Board of Education in District 32, founded the North Brooklyn Residents Association, and is a member on the , which was founded by her predecessor, former Assemblymember .  She received an AA in Political Science from Long Island University in 2013. She has represented the 53rd District in the New York State Assembly since 2013, and is currently in her 6th term.\n\nIn the Assembly, Davila chairs the Committee on Social Services and is a member of the Committees on Housing, Rules, Alcoholism and Drug Abuse, and Children and Families. She is also a member of the , the Legislative Women's Caucus, the Task Force on Women's Issues, and the Puerto Rican/Hispanic Task Force, which she formerly chaired.\n\nShe also serves as the female  from the 53rd District, where she has challenged current  Chair .\n\n\n\nDavila is the lead sponsor of A02305, often known as the Elder Parole Bill, to allow incarcerated people who have served more than 15 years in prison and are over 55 years old be evaluated by the .\n\nIn 2022 Davila received a 94% vote score from the New York League of Conservation Voters. In 2021 she received a 93% score. The New York Conservative Party gave Davila a 12% vote score in 2021 and a 8% in 2021. She has been characterized as being on the left flank of New York State Assembly Democrats.\n\n\n\nDavila has frequently found herself leading a group of Brooklyn politicians calling for reform in the , criticizing the leadership of Chair and Assemblymember . In 2021, Davila led calls for Bichotte Hermelyn to resign. In 2022, Davila challenged Bichotte Hermelyn with support from the reformist organization . Bichotte Hermelyn won, receiving votes from 23 district leaders. 12 voted for Davila, six abstained and four were absent.\n\n\n\nIn 2009, Davila ran for  in the 34th District and lost to  in the Democratic Primary. Reyna received 45.57% of the vote to Davila's 43.15%. Gerald A. Esposito received 11.28%.\n\nDavila first won her State Assembly seat, District 53, in a special election in 2013. She received 51.91% of the vote, Jason Otano received 31.61%, and Charveys Gonzalez received 16.49%. Since then Davila has been re-elected five times, without a competitive election.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Ritchie John Torres''' (born March 12, 1988) is an American politician from . A member of the , Torres is the  for . The district covers most of the  and is by one measure the poorest congressional district in the United States, as well as one of the smallest districts by area in the country, covering only a few square miles.\n\nTorres served as the  member for the  from 2013 to 2020. He was the first  candidate to be elected to legislative office in the Bronx, and the council's youngest member. Torres chaired the Committee on Public Housing and was a deputy . As chair of the Oversight and Investigations Committee he focused on  associated with  procurement and the city's . In 2016, Torres was a delegate for the .\n\nIn July 2019, Torres announced his bid for  to succeed Representative . The district is one of the most Democratic-leaning congressional districts in the country. Torres won the November 2020 general election and assumed office on January 3, 2021.  This made him and  the first openly gay Black men elected to Congress. It also made Torres the first openly gay  elected to Congress. Torres was one of nine co-chairs of the  in the .\n\n\nRitchie Torres was born on March 12, 1988, in . He is ; his father is Afro-Puerto Rican and his mother was born in the Bronx to white Puerto Rican parents. Torres was raised  but says he is not practicing while still believing in God.\n\nTorres was raised by his mother in Throggs Neck Houses, a  project in the  neighborhood of the , where he was frequently hospitalized for  as a result of the mold in their apartment. Of growing up economically disadvantaged in \"slum conditions\", Torres has said, \"I was raised by a single mother who had to raise three children on  and I lived in conditions of mold and vermin, lead and leaks.\" His mother raised him, his twin brother, and their sister. (Torres was upset by the $269 million city-subsidized  built \"across the street\" in  rather than housing for struggling New Yorkers; the course was built on a landfill, took 14 years to be developed, and opened in 2015. He vowed then to fight for their well-being.) In junior high, Torres realized he was  but did not , fearing . He has described being \"brutally assaulted\" by a bully in the third grade.\n\nTorres attended , served in the inaugural class of the  New York Exploring Leadership Program, and later worked as an intern in the offices of the mayor and the . He  while a  \"during a schoolwide forum on \".\n\nTorres is one of a small minority of congressmen who does not hold a college degree. He enrolled at , but dropped out at the beginning of his sophomore year, as he was suffering from severe . He struggled with . As he recovered, Torres resumed working for council member , eventually becoming Vacca's housing director. In that role, Torres conducted site inspections and documented conditions, ensuring housing issues were promptly and adequately addressed.\n\n\nAt 25 years old, Torres ran to succeed  as the councilmember for the  of the . The district includes , , , Claremont Village, , , , , , , , ,  and  in .\n\n\nWhen he won the Democratic nomination for New York city council, Torres became one of the first  political candidates in  to win a Democratic nomination, and upon victory in the general election became the first openly gay public official in the Bronx. Torres also served as a deputy leader of the city council.\n\n\nUpon his election, Torres requested the chairmanship of the council's committee on public housing, tasked with overseeing the  (NYCHA); as of July 2019, it is the \"nation's largest public housing system\", which \"provides housing to more than 400,000 low-income residents\" in \"176,000 apartments across 325 complexes\". He made \"the living conditions of the city's most underserved residents a signature priority\". In this role he helped secure $3 million for Concourse Village, Inc., a nearly 1,900-unit housing cooperative in the . According to  data the South Bronx is among the poorest districts in the nation. The cooperative is subsidized by the , offering \"income-restricted rentals and below-market value buy-in for co-ops\". He also secured nearly $1 million to  Dennis Lane Apartments, a Mitchell-Lama co-op in the heart of his district, and \"played a crucial role in exposing the city's failures to address .\"\n\nIn August 2019, along with fellow council member , Torres announced ''Right To Counsel 2.0'', an expansion of legal aid to NYCHA tenants facing . Since the original law passed in 2017, providing legal help throughout the entire eviction case, the council has found 84% of tenants were able to stay in their homes. The council members \"say this will help keep families together and prevent displacement.\" Torres said, \"NYCHA is one of the worst evictees in the city ... Not just one of the worst landlords, but one of the worst evictors. In 2018 alone, 838 families lost their homes in the hands of the NYCHA.\"\n\n\nIn April 2019, Torres worked on legislation aimed to compel companies that employ ers to be transparent if the worker's  are diverted to pay base salary.  delivery companies, like which has freelance workers pickup and deliver meals from restaurants, and , usually allow customers to add a gratuity, but the companies were counting the tips toward regular payment. Torres characterized the practice as exploiting \"an underclass of independent contractors\", and hopes the city council can ban the practice altogether.  noted the gig economy is in need of regulation for the estimated 57 million workers (in the U.S.) who have little protection, and few if any benefits. Torres's bill would compel these companies to be  about the practice \"by explicitly stating it in their  or by sending a notification as a transaction is being approved\".\n\n\nAs chair of the oversight and investigations committee, newly empowered in January 2018 by city council speaker , Torres said he had documentation that as early as 2010 the  was \"aware that medallion prices could crumple\", a year before  pioneer  started . Medallion prices dropped considerably in 2014, likely due to competition from ride-share companies. Medallion owners sued the city and Uber in November 2015. By 2017, 60,000 ride-share vehicles outnumbered medallion vehicles by almost 4 to 1, and many medallion owners faced the prospect of  or severe debt because of the low medallion prices, which few were willing to pay. Torres said the \"medallion market collapse is a \" and \"one of the greatest government scandals in the history of New York City\".\n\nIn July 2019, the city council considered how to address the  with the 's concerns that the  knowingly sold  at inflated prices, bringing in $1 billion in revenue to city government, while saddling \"thousands of drivers with impossible debt loads\", leading to s. \n\n\nIn July 2019, Torres proposed legislation to address the movement in New York toward  at stores and restaurants. He did so to preserve access for those who rely on cash for their purchases. The businesses accept only s and  rather than , in part for higher efficiency, possibly streamlining both cashiering, and accounting; and for security reasons, as having cash risks robbery. According to the , in 2017 16.9% of African-American households \"and 14% of Latino households did not have a bank account\"; 6.5% of all households did not have a bank account; and 18.7% with accounts also used non-insured institutions for financial transactions. In New York City, 12% did not have bank accounts in 2013, including \" who don't wish to be traced and undocumented immigrants as some of those who may face significant challenges when opening bank accounts\". They instead often use  and . Torres's proposal would fine noncompliant businesses, while allowing them to refuse currency higher than . It also prohibits charging more for using cash.\n\n\nIn July 2019, Torres, as chair of the oversight and investigation committee, and , chair of the committees on housing and buildings, released a report from the joint committee that conducted a city council  investigation into the city's  (TPT) program. The TPT was started in 1996 under  to let the  (HPD) transfer \"derelict, tax-delinquent buildings to nonprofits that could rehabilitate and manage them\", ostensibly for working-class people, freeing the city from ownership, or responsibility for tenants. HPD followed a rule selecting \"every other building in the same tax block with a lieneven for a few hundred dollars\"if even one was picked for TPT. 's administration characterized the TPT as a tool for taking over \"distressed properties\" in \"blighted\" areas\". The report, however, holds that characterization is in tension with its findings, which implicate  by both NYC's HPD and the  (DOF), detailing how the agencies were \"targeting and taking of numerous black and brown owned properties, and thus stripping these communities of millions of dollars of generational wealth\". According to Torres, \"TPT is quite different from and far harsher than a typical foreclosure from the perspective of a property owner. If you are the target of a foreclosure, you get a share of the proceeds from the sale of your property. Under TPT, the city can completely strip you of all the equity in your property\". The TPT process strips the minority owner of the property and its value, and mitigates the  and resources investedall with no compensation.\n\n\n\nTorres helped open the first homeless shelter for LGBT youth in the Bronx. He also secured funds for senior centers to serve LGBT people in all .\n\n\nIn August 2019, Torres announced the city council was awarding $36.2 million for gun violence prevention and reduction. He said shooting incidents in New York City were up from 413 in the first half of 2018 to 551 in the same period of 2019.\n\n\n\n\n\nTorres has said that he is \"intent on advancing politically\", and has been floated as a future candidate for . His \"goal is to be a national champion for the .\"\n\nIn July 2019, Torres announced his candidacy for the  for . In his announcement, Torres shared his history of . Torres said he was seeking the office to pursue \"his legislative passions of overhauling public housing and focusing on the issues of concentrated poverty\". The 15th congressional district is the nation's poorest in terms of . Torres said, \"If you are on a mission to fight  ... then you have to be a policymaker on the national stage\". He favors maximizing  in the nation, including the ending of land-use bans of apartments, which he says will result in the , as well as increase affordable housing. Torres came under criticism for his willingness to take real estate cash donations during his campaign.\n\nTorres's main opponent as he started campaigning in the Democratic primary was , a  and , who does not believe in, and openly stood in opposition to, . Media outlets contextualized the contest between the two, noting their age difference; contrasting levels of experience; and Torres's open homosexuality versus Díaz's track record of . Torres said he saw Díaz as \"temperamentally and ideologically indistinguishable\" from . According to '''', Díaz had \"a decades-long history of making  remarks\"; '''' said his anti-LGBT rhetoric started in the early 1990s, right after his start in city politics, when he claimed the city's hosting the  \"would spread  and \". In February 2019, Díaz said that the City Council was \"controlled by homosexuals\"; in response, the council dissolved a subcommittee he chaired. , Torres had raised $500,000 and Díaz $80,000. Torres was endorsed by the  and the  (Equality PAC).\n\nThe Democratic primary was held on June 23. Although an official winner had not yet been declared, Torres declared victory in the primary on July 22. As the seat for which he was running is one of the safest Democratic seats in the country, he was expected to win the general election, after which he would become one of the first openly gay black Congressmen in U.S. history, along with  in the 17th district. On August 4, local election officials declared Torres the winner of the primary. This all but assured him of being the next congressman from this heavily Democratic, Latino-majority district. The 15th and its predecessors have been in Democratic hands for all but 11 months since 1927, the lone break in this tradition being  member  from February 1948 to January 1949. It has been held by Latino congressmen since 1971.\n\n\n\nTorres won the November general election. He took office on January 3, 2021. Upon his swearing-in, he became the first openly gay  member of Congress.\n\nOn August 6, 2021, Torres introduced H.R. 4980, which would \"ensure that any individual traveling on a flight that departs from or arrives to an airport inside the United States or a territory of the United States is fully vaccinated against COVID-19.\"\n\nTorres voted with President 's stated position 100% of the time in the , according to a '''' analysis.\n\nTorres was among the 46 Democrats who voted against final passage of the  in the House. He said his vote was motivated by the new  requirements included in the deal, which raised the work requirements from able-bodied adults under age 50 who do not live with any dependent children to adults under age 54, and the diversion of $20 billion in funding for the .\n\n\nTorres says that he is a loyal Democrat and \"generally in agreement with the planks of the Democratic platform.\"\n\n\nTorres has voiced support for a  and was endorsed by the  in 2020. He suggested that public housing should be \"a model for green and energy efficient buildings to help combat climate change while addressing its capital needs.\" Torres has called the  \"a structure of environmental racism\" and supports a plan to cover the highway with .\n\n\n in 2024]]\nTorres has called himself \"the embodiment of a pro- progressive\". After winning election in 2020, he announced that he would not join , a group of left-wing Democratic representatives, due to their support of the  (BDS) movement. Torres has described his \"revulsion\" to the \"extremism\" of the BDS movement that he says questions the legitimacy and existence of Israel as a Jewish state. He has contrasted BDS's stagnancy with what he called the \"path to peace\" presented by the . He supports a  for Israel and Palestine. Torres has said his first visit to Israel, led by the  in 2015, was a \"life-changing experience\".\n\nIn 2023, Torres was among 56 Democrats to vote in favor of H.Con.Res. 21, which directed President  to remove U.S. troops from  within 180 days.\n\nIn July 2023, Torres was among 49 Democrats to break with President , by voting for a ban on  to .\n\nIn November 2023, Torres rejected calls for a ceasefire in the . He called claims that Israel is committing  in the  a \"blood libel\".\n\nOn November 7, 2023, Torres was one of 22 House Democrats who voted successfully to  , passing a resolution that accused her of, \"...promoting false narratives regarding the October 7, 2023, Hamas attack,\" as well as criticized, in particular, her use of the slogan \"\". In explaining why he voted for the censure, Torres wrote on , “Congress has a right to take a principled stand against hate speech calling for the destruction of the world’s only Jewish nation-state.”\n\nTorres voted in favor of three military aid package supplementals for , , and  respectively in April 2024, along with most Democrats. In a statement after the vote, he said \"The US has a singular obligation to help freedom fighters fight for their freedom, and nowhere more so than in Ukraine, whose self-defense against Putin’s aggression must prevail.\"\n\n\nTorres is viewed as an ally of the  industry. He is a member of the  and has been a prominent critic of  chair 's \"regulation by enforcement\" strategy towards cryptocurrencies.\n\n\n* \n* \n* \n\n\n* '''''' (2021–February 2024)\n* '''''' (Co-chair)\n* \n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* \n* \n* \n* \n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n* official U.S. House website\n*\n*\n\n\n\n\n\nfrom the |years=2014–2020}}\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n|- \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''David F. Gantt Jr.''' (September 12, 1941July 1, 2020) was an American politician who served as a member of the  from 1983 to 2020 as a member of the . Prior to his Assembly tenure, he was a member of the  Legislature. He was the first and, until the election of  in 2020, only black person to represent Monroe County in the New York Assembly.\n\nGantt was born in Alabama and his family moved to New York during the 1950s. He attended two colleges after graduating from high school, but dropped out of both after a few years. In 1973, he was elected to the Monroe County Legislature and served until his election to the Assembly in 1982. During his tenure in the Assembly, he served on the Aging, Commerce, Election Laws, Steering, Transportation, and Ways and Means committees.\n\n\n\nDavid F. Gantt Jr. was born on September 12, 1941, in , to Lena Mae Gantt and David Gantt Sr., who died during David's youth. During the 1950s his family moved to New York, as the social services system was better in New York than in the South. In 1960, he graduated from Franklin High School, and later he attended the  and . Gantt attended Roberts Wesleyan College for two years using a partial basketball scholarship, but dropped out due to the financial constraints on his family.\n\nAfter dropping out of college, he worked for Case-Hoyt Corp. printing company and as a manager at the Anthony Jordan Health Center. During the  he volunteered for Massachusetts Senator 's . In 1965, he campaigned for Ronald Good's successful campaign for the Monroe County Legislature.\n\n\n\n\n\nIn 1973, Gantt ran to succeed Good in the Monroe County Legislature from the 22nd district, defeating Republican nominee Leonard M. Lofton. He won reelection to the county legislature in 1975, 1977, and 1979.\n\nIn 1979, Gantt faced a primary challenge from Joseph Flores, a Hispanic Republican with the endorsement of the Hispanic Political Action Coalition and the Hispanic Women's Caucus, but defeated him in the Democratic primary. In the general election he defeated Flores, now the Republican nominee.\n\nIn 1981, Gantt faced a primary challenge from Marlene Tisdale. In the Democratic primary he defeated Tisdale, and was the only one of seven incumbent county legislators to receive the support of the Monroe County Democratic Party that won in the primary election. In the general election he defeated Republican nominee Willie C. Anderson.\n\n\n\nIn 1977, the Democratic minority in the county legislature attempted to place him onto the Ways and Means Committee, but the Republican majority rejected Gantt in favor of Anthony Reed. After the Democratic Party gained a majority in the county legislature in the 1977 elections Gantt and Michael Ormsby were selected to serve as assistant majority leaders.\n\nIn 1980, Gantt was elected as a member of the  state committee alongside Marlene Tisdale.\n\n\n\n\nOn July 15, 1982, Gantt announced that he would seek the Democratic nomination in the New York Assembly's 133rd district to replace Assemblymember Dale Rath. In the Democratic primary, he defeated Anthony Reed and James George. In the general election, Gantt defeated Republican nominee John H. Dixon,  nominee Patricia Brennan, and  nominee James J. Downs. Gantt became the first and only black person to represent Monroe County in the Assembly. He was reelected in 1984, and 1986.\n\nIn 1988, Gantt faced a primary challenge from Melody Long, one of multiple  supporters who challenged incumbent Democratic members of the Assembly and  in the primaries, but defeated Long in the primary. In the general election he defeated Republican nominee Michael Keller, Conservative nominee Mario Mazzullo, and Right to Life nominee Cheryl Battles.\n\nGantt won reelection from the 133rd district with opposition in 1990, 1992, 1996, 1998, 2000, 2002, and 2006. In 1994, 2004, 2008, and 2010, he won reelection from the 133rd district without opposition. He was redistricted into the 137th district and won reelection in 2012, 2014, 2016, and 2018.\n\nIn June 2020, Gantt announced that he would not seek reelection to the Assembly. He endorsed Ernest Flagler-Mitchell, a member of the Monroe County legislature, to succeed him, but Flagler-Mitchell was defeated by Demond Meeks.\n\n\n\nDuring the 1983–1985 session of the Assembly Gantt served on the Aging, Commerce, and Election Laws committees. During the 1993–1995 session of the Assembly he served on the Ways and Means, and Steering committees.\n\nDuring the  he supported  and ran as a Mondale delegate from the . He was later selected to serve as a delegate-at-large for Mondale alongside Nancy Padilla. During the  he supported  and petitioned to serve as a Jackson delegate from the 29th congressional district.\n\nIn 1989, he was selected to serve as the chairman of the state Legislative Commission on the Development of Rural Resources by Speaker . In 1990, he was selected by Miller to replace , who was appointed as Chairman of the Education committee, as co-chairman of the joint Legislative Task Force on Demographic Research and Reapportionment committee, which would  districts based upon the . In 1994, he was selected to replace  as chairman of the Transportation committee.\n\nIn January 1990, Gantt swore in  for his second term as mayor of Rochester, New York. In 1991, he became the senior member of Monroe County's delegation following the death of .\n\nDuring the  he endorsed Massachusetts Senator . Gantt stated that Kerry was \"an American war hero and willing to stick his head out for education\". During the  he endorsed New York Senator  and served as a delegate for her to the . During the  he supported President , served as a delegate to the , and attended the Obama's . During the  he endorsed Hillary Clinton.\n\n\nOn July 1, 2020, Gantt died from kidney failure. Following his death, he was praised by Governor , Attorney General , United States Representative , Assembly Speaker , Assembly Minority Leader , and Rochester Mayor .\n\n\n\n\nIn 1994, Gantt voted in favor of legislation that would prohibit discrimination based upon sexual orientation in jobs, schools, public establishments, and housing. The Assembly later voted unanimously to support legislation prohibit discrimination against people with disabilities. In 1997, he voted in favor of legislation that prohibited . In 1999, he voted in favor a constitutional amendment that would require  for men and women.\n\nIn 2001, Gantt co-sponsored a resolution by  that called for President  to pardon the 50 black sailors who were convicted for refusing to load munitions onto ships following the .\n\nIn 2007, Gantt voted in favor of legislation that made the  of violent or indecent video games to minors a , and would require consoles to have equipment that would prevent the display of those games. He later voted in favor of legislation that would  the medicinal usage of marijuana.\n\nIn 2009, he chose to abstain on legislation that would  same-sex marriages in New York. In 2011, he voted against legislation that would legalize same-sex marriages.\n\n\n\nIn 1983, Gantt introduced legislation that would make the possession of a knife, dagger, or imitation pistol on school grounds a Class A misdemeanor punished with up to one year in prison and a $1,000 fine. He created the legislation in response to the stabbing death of Peter Castle, a school tutor. In 1993, he sponsored legislation that would make the possession of a loaded gun in a school building, playground, athletic field, or within 1,000 feet of schoolyards a felony punishable with six to twenty five years in prison. In 1995, he voted in favor of legislation that would ban the ownership of s. In 2000, he voted in favor of legislation that raised the age requirement for obtaining a handgun permit from 18 to 21 years old.\n\nIn 1990, he voted against legislation that would have reinstituted  in New York. In 1993, the Assembly voted 61 to 49, with Gantt voting against, in favor of an amendment to the  that would reinstitute capital punishment, but fell below the 2/3rds requirement. In 1995, he voted against legislation that would reinstitute capital punishment, but it was approved by the Assembly and Senate before being signed into law by Governor .\n\nIn 1994, the Assembly voted 57 to 56, with Gantt voting against, against legislation that would create a central  of convicted sex offenders and would allow DNA evidence to be used in court. On June 28, 1995, the Assembly voted 149 to 9, with Gantt voting against, in favor of legislation similar to  which would require sex offenders to register their location with the state.\n\n\n\nIn 1993, Gantt proposed using $10&nbsp;million to renovate the  to meet  facility standards and transfer ownership from the  to Monroe County. Following the demolition of the stadium he proposed building a new $44&nbsp;million stadium, with $15&nbsp;million coming from the state, $6&nbsp;million from Monroe County, $1&nbsp;million from Rochester, and the remainder coming from the .\n\nIn 2004, the documentary ''July '64'' was released and received two Emmy award nominations, after being produced in Rochester, New York, and receiving funding from the New York state legislature due to Gantt. The documentary was based on the  which Gantt had experienced.\n\n\n\nIn 1983, Gantt voted in favor of legislation that raised the minimum wage for farm workers from $2.75 to $3.35 per hour. In 1996, he voted in favor of legislation that would raise New York's minimum wage from $4.25 to $5.05 per hour. In 1997, he voted in favor of legislation that would raise New York's minimum wage from $4.25 to $5.15 per hour. In 2001 and 2002, he voted in favor of legislation that would raise the minimum wage from $5.15 to $6.75 per hour.\n\nIn 1992, he opposed a sales tax increase from 7% to 8% that was proposed by Monroe County Executive Robert L. King and approved by the Monroe County Legislature. However, Gantt later supported another proposed sales tax increase to 7.5%.\n\n\n\nIn 1989, Gantt was given an 85% rating from the New York Environmental Planning Lobby. In 1990, he was given a 92% rating from the . He was given a 20% rating from the Conservative Party of New York State in 1991. In 1992, he was given a 0% rating from the Conservative Party.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
