    "pages": }\n'''Kristen Prata Browde''' (born 1950) is an American attorney, politician, and former journalist. She has been involved in local politics in New York and Florida and has advocated for the  since leaving journalism in 2013.\n\nBrowde worked in television and radio journalism, with a stint at the recently established  in the 1980s and 30 years as a reporter at  and  in New York. She began concurrently working as an attorney after graduating from law school in 2000.\n\nSince leaving news media, Browde has continued to practice law and has been active in local politics as a member of the . She has held various positions in , and countywide positions in . She was narrowly defeated in the 2017 election for  of New Castle (a position equivalent to mayor) and the 2020 Democratic primary election for . Her candidacy for town supervisor made her the first transgender person to run for office on a major party  in New York.\n\n\nKristen Prata Browde is one of three children of Anatole Browde () and Frances Buchman Browde (). Anatole Browde, of , was vice president of  Electronic Systems and Micro-Electronic CTR, and he later taught at  in Missouri.\n\nKristen Browde attended Country Day high school in St. Louis in the late 1960s. She graduated from  in New York in 1972. At Cornell, she was a radio presenter on the university's radio station, , and she played  hockey.\n\n\n\nBrowde joined the New York station  after graduating from college. She worked for the Independent Television News Association (ITNA), a satellite news cooperative, and then joined the fledgling  as a Washington and Pentagon correspondent by 1980. She was also the network's first  correspondent.\n\nBrowde later joined  (then known as WNEW-TV when owned by ). In 1984, she was reporting for the station when she recorded remarks by vice-presidential candidate  at a  rally boasting about his performance in the  earlier that week, not aware that he was being recorded by a television crew. In 1986, Browde and two other reporters were summoned by police to a Bronx building that  was holding out in. In a six-hour telephone exchange with the police, Davis negotiated that news reporters be present at the scene so he would not be shot. Davis surrendered to police after he was assured of the presence of his girlfriend and given the  of the reporters. Browde left WNYW three years later, in 1989, and later that year joined the   '''' in the role of segment producer. In 1993, Browde and three colleagues won the \"Single Breaking News Story\" award at the  for the news story \"Watermain Break, Grand Central\" for the CBS-owned station . She worked as a freelance reporter for NBC 4 News (WNBC) for 8 months in 1993 before she was appointed to a full reporter position there.\n\nIn 1996, while working at WNBC, Browde started attending the night school program at , initially motivated by the desire to become a better reporter. Executives at NBC decided not to renew Browde's contract because they felt she could not handle the stresses of working as a journalist while attending law school. She left WNBC in late 1996, after three years at the station. She later began freelance work for CBS News, where she was a weekend news anchor and a correspondent. She graduated from Fordham Law in 2000, just before she turned 50 years old. She chose to continue working as a journalist, while personally selecting what legal cases she would work on as an attorney: \"I knew that I could truly have my cake and eat it toowithout taking a big pay cut by becoming a first-year associate. Thus, it wasn't a really tough call.\"\n\n\nBrowde was a member of the national board of the  (AFTRA) from 1983 to 2012 (when the union was merged with the ).\n\nIn 2006, Browde was elected as a trustee to the AFTRA Health & Retirement Funds. In 2010, '''' and '''' reported that several Screen Actors Guild (SAG) members had accused Browde of running a union news website, SAGWatch, and abusing her access to SAG's confidential information as an AFTRA trustee. Browde told ''The Hollywood Reporter'' that the allegations were false. A two-month investigation by AFTRA led the union to conclude that there was \"no evidence suggesting any infractions took place\". In 1999 and 2003, Browde publicly expressed her opposition to the merger of SAG and AFTRA. When the unions were merged in 2012 to create , she was appointed one of the 24 members of the initial SAG-AFTRA national executive committee.\n\n\nBy 2013, Browde was practicing as a divorce attorney in , a hamlet in New Castle. Browde left CBS News around that time; in an interview, she said that by that time her law practice had been \"going strong, completely blossomed\". She  as a  woman to the public at the 's gala of New York journalists in April 2016. The ''''s gossip section, , ran a print article on Browde's announcement with the headline \"Journo Says He's a She\". Browde said her practice was unaffected after she came out.\n\nBrowde has served on the board of the LGBT Bar Association of New York (LeGaL), a  serving the , and she was elected president of its board in 2019. She is the first transgender person to hold the position. She is also a founding member of the National Trans Bar Association, and she was elected a co-chair of the organization in 2019. In 2019, she was among at least a dozen transgender attorneys present for s before the Supreme Court for '''', a landmark case for the rights of transgender people.\n\n\n\nBrowde became active in politics after she left the news industry in 2013 with the desire to \"break free from the restraint of public neutrality.\" She served as secretary of the ethics board of , from 2014 until she resigned in 2017 to run for . She also served on the Financial Advisory Committee for the  starting in 2013, and she was appointed to the town diversity committee in 2016.\n\nBrowde supported the , and campaigned in North Carolina in support of the Clinton campaign and in opposition to the  (House Bill 2), a . Browde participated in the  in Washington, D.C. after the , during which she marched with the .\n\n\nIn April 2017, Browde announced she would be running as a  candidate for town supervisor of New Castle, making her the first transgender person in New York to run for office on a major party . Browde and the other Democratic Party candidates for New Castle Town Board were members of Up2Us, a group which rose from the Chappaqua Friends of Hillary (a group supporting presidential candidate and Chappaqua resident ). Hillary Clinton herself endorsed the Democratic Party town board candidates, including Browde. Robert Greenstein, the incumbent town supervisor and the  candidate, led by a 300-vote margin over Browde in unofficial vote counts late in the November election and narrowly defeated Browde.\n\nFrom 2017 to 2018, Browde served on the  of  of , . In 2018, she was one of 15 nominations to the Westchester Women's Advisory Board, a board which advises the government of Westchester County on women's issues, with her term lasting through 2019. Also in 2018, state governor  appointed her to the steering committee of New York State Council on Women and Girls. In 2019, she sat alongside the governor at an event during which the governor signaled his support for the  and for changes to the state's  laws.\n\n\nIn the , Browde was one of five candidates in the Democratic Party primary for , a seat held by . Browde said that frustration around issues such as  motivated her to run for the assembly. Bedford town supervisor  narrowly defeated Browde in the primary; unofficial tallies counted 4,879 votes for Burdick compared to 4,532 votes for Browde (a difference of 347 votes). Later that year, Browde was appointed as one of 12 vice chairs of the Westchester County Democratic Party.\n\n'''' of New York City named Browde one of their 2020 Impact Award Honorees, describing her as \"a change-maker who has made a difference on numerous fronts.\"\n\n\nIn 2023, Browde was reported to be vice president of the  LGBTQ+ Caucus. Early that year, Browde began to publish weekly videos on  highlighting people who have been arrested on charges of  that week in an effort to prove that s are not threats to children (a notion associated with the ongoing ). Browde's videos have been featured by LGBT media outlets '''' and ''''. Her inspiration for the video series came from a speech by the outgoing president of the caucus, during which he read a list of people arrested or charged for child sexual abuse in the past week. By March 2023, Browde's first video on the subject had been viewed 1.4 million times, and her TikTok account had amassed more than 300,000 followers.\n\n\nIn 1980, Browde was engaged to Bettina Gregory, an  correspondent. They were married by the following year. In 1988, Browde was engaged to Elizabeth J. Hellawell. Their marriage later ended in a divorce. In 1999, Browde married film director Elizabeth Schub in Long Island, New York. The couple was living on the east side of  in New York City when the nearby  was destroyed in the  in 2001. They told ''Cornell Alumni Magazine'' that they were \"lucky to be alive.\" Browde moved to  in 2004.\n\nBrowde has two sons. Her son Maximilian Browde and Maximilian's mother, Elizabeth Schub Kamir, were living in Paris at the time of the . Maximilian wrote about his experience in an article published by '''' (LoHud.com).\n\nBrowde took the middle name Prata after her friend and coach, Monica Prata, a feminine  based in .\n\n\n* \n* \n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Michael Alexander Blake''' (born December 25, 1982) is an American politician and member of the . He formerly served as a New York Assemblyman from the 79th district and was the Vice Chair of the  from 2017 to 2021.\n\n\nBlake was born on December 25, 1982, in  to parents who had immigrated from . He was named after  and . After graduating from New York City public schools, Blake went on to attend and graduate from  with a degree in . While at Northwestern, he served as student council president and was close friends with , who later became the first black president of a  team upon his hiring by the  in 2020.\n\n\nBlake began his career working in the  and for Illinois State Senator .\n\nBlake served as the Iowa deputy political director for  in the , and following his election to the presidency, Blake became associate director of public engagement and the deputy associate director of the . He served as the national deputy director of Operation Vote for President, Obama’s 2012 re-election. Blake was noted in  as one of nine black politicos behind President Obama’s re-election.\n\nIn 2013, he served as the  for  for . He helped to found the Atlas Strategy Group, which focuses on policy issues for communities of color.\n\n\nIn 2014, Assemblyman  was found guilty on  charges and was required to  his seat. Blake entered the race to replace him. His own candidacy was not without controversy, and the Bronx Democratic Party, who did not support his candidacy, claimed he was not actually a resident of the Bronx. Despite these setbacks, Blake won the Democratic primary over five other candidates. He easily won the general election with nearly 92% of the vote.\n\nBlake was sworn in for his first term on December 15, 2014. He was the Chair of the Subcommittee on Mitchell-Lama and is a member of the Corrections, Housing, Banks, Veterans, Election Law and Governmental Operations committees.\n\nBlake did not seek re-election in 2020; instead, he ran for U.S. House of Representatives.\n\n\nIn 2018, Blake announced his candidacy for . He lost to City Councilmember  in a crowded race with 17 other candidates.\n\n\n\nIn 2019, Blake announced his campaign for ; the then-current Representative, , had announced his retirement from Congress. He lost, finishing in second place behind winner  in the Democratic primary.\n\n\nBlake is close friends with , a classmate of his at Northwestern who later became the first black president of a  (NFL) franchise upon his hiring by the  in 2020.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* government website\n* campaign website\n\n\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n\n'''Robert J. Castelli''' (December 16, 1949 – May 21, 2024) was an American security consultant, academic, and media personality from . He served two terms as a member of the , representing northeastern .\n\nDuring the , he served with the  in the . Upon his separation from the military, he became a member of the , where he served with the elite Special Investigations Unit and the New York State Organized Crime Task Force for over two decades.\n\nA graduate of , Castelli became an educator in 1996 and went on to serve as Chair of the  Department at . After holding elective office in local government, Castelli ran for and was elected to the State Assembly in a  in February 2010. He was also a columnist for the website '''' and served as the shooting instructor at the .\n\nCastelli died on May 21, 2024, at the age of 74.\n\n\nCastelli was born in . He dropped out of high school in 1967 and volunteered to join the , and was assigned to the  as an infantryman. He served in combat operations in the  from 1968 to 1969. He received an honorable discharge in 1973.\n\nUpon his return from his Army service, he worked as a Constable in South Carolina before returning to New York and beginning a 21-year career in the New York State Police, during which he worked as an intelligence officer with elite Special Investigations Unit and the New York State Organized Crime Task Force.\".\" ''''. Retrieved December 17, 2010. Castelli held the ranks of trooper, sergeant, investigator, and eventually was promoted to station commander. He was involved in numerous high-profile arrests during his tenure with the State Police.Markon, Jerry. \".\" ''''. January 20, 2011.\n\nCastelli had two sons, Christian, a retired Army Special Forces Colonel  in , and Paul, an ordained Minister in Florida.\n\nCastelli was a graduate of , the  and Harvard Kennedy School, where he was named a  in Criminal Justice Policy and Management by the  in recognition of his contributions to the law enforcement community. He was also once a nationally ranked competitive , and was a life member of the , and the , where he served as a shooting instructor.\n\nAfter retiring from the State Police, he began a career as an educator, teaching at Iona College for thirteen years and rising to become Chairman of the Criminal Justice Department. He also worked as an adjunct professor at   and  from 1996 to 2010, where he lectured on a wide variety of criminal justice and security-related subjects including criminal investigation, organized crime, white collar crime, terrorism, security management and police procedures.\".\" ''''. Retrieved December 17, 2010.\n\nThese credentials made him a popular guest as an expert commentator in print, radio, and television media programs throughout the . Prior to his transition from public service to politics, Castelli was a regular contributor on network television including , , , ,  and .Bailey, John. \".\" ''''. September 4, 2004. Castelli owned a professional security consulting business, and held certifications as a , Crime Prevention Specialist, , , Certified Police and Security Officer Instructor, Certified Firearms Instructor and licensed and bonded .\n\n\n from the neighboring 99th Assembly District to call for a moratorium on '' for natural gas in the , which covers both their districts.]]\nA , Castelli was elected as a town councilman in his hometown of Lewisboro from 2000 to 2004. He made his first run for the State Assembly in 2004.McManus, James. \".\" ''''. January 3, 2011.\n\nFrom February 2010 to January 2013, he represented  in the , which included the towns of , , , , , ,  and portions of the City of  in , .\n\n\nCastelli was elected to the  in a special election on February 9, 2010, defeating   in an upset victory. The previous incumbent, Democratic Assemblyman , had resigned after he was elected Mayor of  in 2009. Castelli previously ran for the seat in 2004, but was defeated by Bradley.\n\nPolitical prognosticators viewed the suburban contest as a sign of a Republican resurgence and a , where Republicans would eventually go on to make large gains in the , , and retake the . Castelli described his victory as \"an expression of voter discontent with the state capitol\" and the corruption prevalent in New York's State Government.\n\n\n  signs Chapter 294 of the laws of 2010 in the Red Room of the  in , the first law authored by Castelli, then a freshman legislator.]]After serving for only eight months, the freshman legislator had to run for a full term. In the 2010 general election, Castelli held the seat by defeating White Plains City Council President . Winning with a slim 112 vote margin, a month-long recount was necessary before Castelli could be declared the winner, thus earning him a full two-year term representing the 89th District. The 89th Assembly District has over 10,000 more registered Democrats than Republicans, and Castelli was the first Republican to hold the seat in seventeen years.\n\nHis 2010 election and subsequent reelection were considered significant, as the 89th Assembly District seat to which he was elected was  to be a Democratic district, and was home to prominent Democratic political figures, including former  ,  ,  , attorney  and , billionaire financier of numerous  causes.Pillifant, Reid. \".\" ''''. December 3, 2010. Castelli was also outspent by his opponents, although he attempted to overcome these disadvantages by running what he called a \"grassroots, front-porch campaign.\"\n\n\nAs a Republican representing a heavily  district, Castelli placed a large emphasis on . He decried the 2012  process as partisan gerrymandering, for which he was named a \"Hero of Reform\" by former   . Castelli voted against the final redistricting bill, which further gerrymandered and renumbered his district from the 89th to the 93rd Assembly District, added the town of , and significantly reoriented the portion of the City of White Plains contained within the district, which packed more Democratic-leaning voters into the already heavily Democratic district which Castelli, a member of the , represented.Gonzalez, Carlos. \".\" ''''. February 23, 2012.\n\nCastelli sought to earn a reputation as a reformer and frequently challenged   in his campaign rhetoric. The press frequently said he is known for his independence from both parties. In an editorial endorsing Castelli, '''' called him \"the kind out outsider Albany needs.\"\n\nSensing political opportunity following the redistricting process, White Plains City Councilman  launched a challenge to Castelli, citing the district's overwhelming Democratic enrollment advantage. Castelli received endorsements from every newspaper in the district and aired television and radio ads featuring Democratic Governor Andrew Cuomo saying, \"Assemblyman Castelli, I'll tell you how tough Assemblyman Castelli's job is. He is MY Assemblyman ... He's doing a great job representing me and this entire district.\"\n\n\n\nDespite running a spirited campaign where he was again outspent, Castelli could not overcome party-line voting in the high turnout for incumbent President , although he still managed to garner 47% of the vote in the overwhelmingly Democratic district.\n\nCastelli ran for the  for the  district in 2014, but lost the Republican primary to .\n\n\n  (left) and   (right) walk with Assemblyman Castelli (center), who represents their hometown of  in the Assembly.]] Castelli was known as a staunch fiscal conservative and held strong pro-business, anti-tax and limited government positions.Oliva, Zach. \".\" ''''. April 23, 2010. Yet he also held environmentalist views considered atypical for most Republican politicians, and his pro-conservation ideals garnered him support and endorsements from organizations such as the  and  during all of his campaigns. For instance, he was a cosponsor and vocal proponent of a ban on  in the  region of upstate New York, a process for natural gas exploration which is known as \".\"\n\nCastelli received a perfect score on the environment from the statewide group EPL/Environmental Advocates in 2011 and 2012, on the only scorecard that grades New York State lawmakers according to their votes on the environment. His score led all Republican lawmakers in both houses in each of his three years in office.\n\nA self-described conservationist, Castelli also received top marks from the  for what they described as \"his actions in defense of our civil rights,\" as well as from the , which named him to their prestigious \"Circle of Friends.\"\n\nAccording to , a regional outlet covering the 89th Assembly District, he \"earned a reputation for being an independent voice in the Legislature, especially on tax policies that he says unfairly penalize Westchester County residents and business owners.\"\n\nAs one of only three combat veterans in the State Assembly, he placed a large part of his legislative focus on veterans' issues. He was credited with building the coalition that saved the five  from elimination in the 2011 New York State budget.\n\n\nIn his first 120 days in office, Castelli passed two pieces of legislation, the first of which was signed into law by   as Chapter 294 of the Laws of 2010. Castelli showed an uncanny ability to pass his own prime-sponsored legislation despite being a member of the 's , which has a reputation for legislative powerlessness amid the control of  .\n\nIn 2011, Castelli became the first member of the Minority since 2007 to pass a \"statewide\" bill, a veterans protection measure which prohibited public employers from abolishing positions of persons absent on military duty. Six other Castelli bills have been signed into law, making him one of the more productive junior lawmakers in Albany. As of 2024, no other member of the Assembly Minority has passed a statewide bill since.\n\nDuring the legislative session in 2012, Castelli authored and passed a bill to extend the  for s to bring claims arising from exposure to  and other s, which was signed into law by Governor Cuomo. He also cosponsored and passed a bill to increase funding for the state's Environmental Protection Fund (EPF), and conduct a  of hydrofracking before the state considers whether or not to allow the controversial process to go forward.\n\nCastelli also authored a bill to eliminate the  Urban Renewal Agency, a moribund , which was called an \"unnecessary mandate\" for the village, that successfully passed both houses of the legislature in 2012. He also authored and passed legislation to rename portions of  in  and  for Staff Sergeant Kyu Hyuk Chay, and Specialist Anthony Kalladeen, soldiers from those communities who were killed in action during the wars in , and , respectively.\n\n\n*'''February 2010 , NYS Assembly, 89th AD'''\n:\n\n*'''November 2010 , NYS Assembly, 89th AD'''\n:\n\n*'''November 2012 , NYS Assembly, 93rd AD'''\n:\n\n\n\n\n\n*Neubaer, David W. & Meinhold, Stephen S.     "pages": }\n'''Kalman Yeger''' (born April 26, 1974) is an American politician who serves in the  for the . He is a member of the . The district includes all or parts of the , , , , and  neighborhoods in . On Nov 5, 2024, Yeger won an uncontested election for New York State's 41st Assembly District.\n\n\nYeger, who has lived in  his entire life, is a graduate of  with a B.A. degree and  with a J.D. degree in 2011.\n\n\nYeger began his career as a community liaison and assistant to New York City Councilman . He then went on to work as a top advisor to Bronx Borough President , including as the Executive Director of Ferrer’s 2001 & 2005 campaigns for NYC Mayor. In 2010, he began working as senior advisor and counsel to New York City Councilman . In 2012, Yeger worked as a senior advisor for 's successful New York State Senate campaign.\n\nYeger has been a member of  since 2000. He has advised a slew of public officials, including former Borough President and current NYC Mayor , former Borough President and current Queens District Attorney , as well as former NYC Councilmembers , , , and .\n\n\nIn 2017, outgoing councilmember  encouraged Yeger to run for his council seat, as Greenfield decided not to run for re-election, instead taking over the helm of New York's largest Jewish charity, the . Opposing Yeger, was Yoni Hikind, the son of former man, , whose district covered much of the same constituency. Yeger received endorsements from the four unions representing the , which are the , the , the Lieutenants Benevolent Association (LBA), and the Captains Endowment Association (CEA), as well as The United Federation of Teachers. Yeger also received the endorsement of the then four Democratic NYC Borough Presidents including NYC Mayor , as well as , , and .\n\nIn 2021, Yeger won re-election after running unopposed in the general election.  Yeger, who ran on the Democrat, Republican, and Conservative lines garnered 97.8% of the vote.\n\nIn 2023, Yeger won the Democratic Primary unopposed while also defeating Heshy Tischler in the Republican Primary 52%-48%. In the general election, Yeger who again ran on the Democrat, Republican, and Conservative lines, received 80% of the vote, trouncing Tischler again, who this time ran under the Boro Park Flatbush Party line. Yeger received the endorsement of The New York City Correction Officers’ Benevolent Association.\n\n\nIn 2024, Yeger ran for , which was held by longtime Assembly Member  who was retiring after a record-breaking 44 years. Yeger won the primary with 70.7% of the vote, defeating Adam Dweck. Yeger was endorsed by Weinstein, NYS Senator , NYS Assembly Member , former Councilman , and Solidarity PAC. Although Yeger ran unopposed in the general election, he was endorsed by The Jewish Press.\n\nAs of 2024, Yeger was serving on the following New York City Council committees:\n\n* Health\n* Public Safety\n* Sanitation and Solid Waste Management\n* Oversight and Investigation\n* Fire and Emergency Management\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nOn March 26, 2019, Yeger accused Democratic Minnesota Congresswoman  of being an  due to her criticism of  and then claimed that \" does not exist\". This resulted in protests outside Yeger's office in . He was later removed from the New York City Council's immigration committee. \n\nOn October 30, 2022, Yeger tweeted a video of a swarm of bikers taking over a New York City street, Yeger compared these bikers to cockroaches saying, \"Like cockroaches, there's never just one\". Yeger received major backlash as a result with many calling the tweet racist pointing out that a majority of the bikers were black and brown. He subsequently deleted the tweet that same day.\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Linda B. Rosenthal''' (born November 12, 1957) represents  as a  in the , which includes parts of 's  and / neighborhoods. Linda B. Rosenthal|website=nyassembly.gov|access-date=2019-05-09}}\n\n\nLinda Rosenthal was born in 1957 to parents who fled the Nazis in the 1930s. Rosenthal earned a  degree in history from the  in 1980.\n\n\nIn 1993, Rosenthal began working for US Congressman (for )  and served as Manhattan District Director and Director of Special Projects. Prior to this, she worked in publishing.\n\n\nRosenthal was elected to the New York State Assembly in a February 2006  for  between four candidates to replace , who left the Assembly to become .  Rosenthal won the November 2008  with 84.7 percent of the vote, and ran uncontested in the November 2010 general election.\n\nIn May 2015, fellow Manhattan Democrat  tried to curb a bill introduced by Rosenthal that would allow customers to bring their dogs to outdoor restaurants, because Gottfried was afraid larger breeds would be able to grab food from tabletops. Gottfried said: \"Some dogs are tall enough that all they would have to do is turn their heads and they would be eating off people's plates.\" A similar bill that passed in California has not resulted in any problems, and the practice is also legal in Israel and some European countries, and common in Europe and in Los Angeles. The bill passed the Senate in May 2015 by a 60-0 vote.  In March 2016, follows the State Legislature's passage of her bill, the  issued an advisory allowing dogs to accompany human diners at restaurants that have outdoor seating, joining s which were already allowed in virtually all situations.\n\nIn March 2019, she introduced a bill, A5040, that will ban a sale of fur in New York, by 2021. New York would follow California, which is in the process of legislating the ban.\n\nAlso in 2019, New York passed Rosenthal's bill A1303B, the first statewide law to ban cat declawing in the United States. She worked closely with the nonprofit animal advocacy organization, , to pass the bill.\n\nIn 2022, Rosenthal was the Assembly sponsor of the  (the Senate sponsor was ).Kate Lisa, ,  (May 2022). The bill established a one-year \"lookback period\" that allowed adult victims of sex abuse to bring civil suits that were previously barred due to the . It unanimously passed the Senate in April 2022, passed the Assembly on a 140&ndash;3 vote in May 2022, and was signed into law by Governor .\n\nIn the Assembly, Rosenthal is the chair of the Housing Committee, and sits on the Codes, Health, and Agriculture committees. In 2023, she said of , \"I’m really not worried about the supply of market-rate housing.\"\n\nRosenthal is a member of the Vote Blue Coalition, a progressive group and  created to support Democrats in New York, New Jersey, and Pennsylvania through voter outreach and mobilization efforts.\n\nIn 2024, Linda Rosenthal introduced a bill to ban e-cigarettes with video games installed in them.\n\n\nRosenthal resides in a  apartment on the  of . Although she shares a last name with former City Council member  who represented an overlapping district, they are not related.\n\n\n* '''February 2006 , NYS Assembly, 67th AD'''\n:\n\n* '''November 2006 , NYS Assembly, 67th AD'''\n:\n\n* '''November 2008 , NYS Assembly, 67th AD'''\n:\n\n* '''November 2010 , NYS Assembly, 67th AD'''\n:\n\n* '''November 2012 , NYS Assembly, 67th AD'''\n:\n\n* '''November 2014 , NYS Assembly, 67th AD'''\n:\n\n* '''September 2016 , NYS Assembly, 67th AD'''\n:\n\n* '''November 2016 , NYS Assembly, 67th AD'''\n:\n\n* '''November 2018 , NYS Assembly, 67th AD'''\n:\n\n* '''November 2020 , NYS Assembly, 67th AD'''\n:\n\n* '''November 2022 , NYS Assembly, 67th AD'''\n:\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n* Official website.\n*\n* Biography.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

Elected in November 2020, he assumed office on January 6, 2021.\n\n\nDurso was born in  and raised in the town of . Growing up, Durso's parents worked multiple jobs to support the family. After graduating from high school, Durso became a sanitation worker.\n\n\nPrior to entering politics, Durso has worked as a sanitation supervisor. He is a member of CSEA Local 881. He previously worked as a public safety officer at .     "pages": }\n\n'''Basil Alexander Paterson''' (April 27, 1926 – April 16, 2014) was an American labor lawyer and politician. He served in the  from 1966 to 1971 and as  under Governor  from 1979 to 1983. In , Paterson was the Democratic nominee for  on the  ticket. Paterson's son  served as governor from 2008 to 2011.\n\n\n\nPaterson was born in  on April 27, 1926,|website=The History Makers|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180820050752/http://www.thehistorymakers.org:80/biography/honorable-basil-paterson |archive-date=August 20, 2018 }} the son of Leonard James and Evangeline Alicia (Rondon) Paterson. His father was born on the island of  in the  and arrived in  aboard the S.S. Vestris on May 16, 1917.\n\n\n His mother was born in  and arrived in  on September 9, 1919, aboard the S.S. Vestnorge (with a final destination of New York City). A stenographer by profession, the former Miss Rondon once served as a secretary for .\n\nIn 1942, at the age of 16, Paterson graduated from  in the .  He was shaped by his experiences with racism early on.  \"I got out of high school when I was 16,\" Paterson told '''' columnist , \"and the first real job I had was with a wholesale house in the old Port Authority building, down on 18th Street. We'd pack and load these trucks that went up and down in huge elevators. Every year there would be a Christmas party for the employees at some local hotel. Those of us who worked in the shipping department were black. We got paid not to go to the party.\"\n\n\n\n\nPaterson attended college at , but his studies were interrupted by a two-year stint in the U.S. Army during . After serving honorably, he returned to St. John's to complete his undergraduate studies. While there, he was active in social and community service organizations including the  fraternitywhere he joined the ranks of the Omicron chapter of New York (now at ) in 1947. Paterson graduated with a  degree in  in 1948. He was later admitted to , where he received a  degree in 1951.\n\n\n\n\n\nPaterson became involved in Democratic politics in Harlem in the 1950s.  Along with former Mayor , Manhattan Borough President , and Congressman , he was a leader of the influential  (also known as the \"Harlem Clubhouse\").\n\n\nPaterson was elected to the  in 1966 and represented the  and  in the ,  and s. While in office, he played a key role in preventing  from building a gym in .\n\n\nIn , Paterson vacated his senate seat to run for  alongside former U.S. Supreme Court Justice .  In the primary, Paterson received the most 100,000 more than votes than his ticket mate, who ran a close race against Howard Samuels. During the election, Albany machine boss  stated \"He's the only white man on the ticket.\"\n\nThe Goldberg/Paterson ticket ultimately lost to Republican incumbents Gov.  and Lt. Gov. . Paterson was passed over for the  even though he was the highest vote-getter in . His son, , would go on to become Lt. Governor in January 2007.\n\n\nIn 1972, Paterson was the first elected African American Vice Chairman of the Democratic National Committee.\n\nIn 1978, Paterson was appointed  by . He stepped down from that post in 1979 to become  in Governor  administration.  Paterson was the first African-American to hold the post, and he served until 1983.\n\nAs Koch prepared to seek a third term in 1985, Paterson explored a mayoral candidacy of his own but ultimately chose not to run.\n\n appointed Paterson to the board of the  in 1989. Paterson served from 1989 to 1995.\n\n appointed Paterson to the Board of the  in 2013.\n\nPaterson chaired the New York City Mayor's Judiciary Committee for four years and the New York State Governor's\nJudicial Screening Panel for the Second Department for eight years. He ended his tenure at the Commission on Judicial\nNominations after serving for twelve years. Paterson was appointed by Mario Cuomo to the State Committee's and  to the city's Judiciary Committee.\n\n\nPaterson was . Outside of public service, he was a member of Meyer, Suozzi, English & Klein, P.C. and co-chaired the firm's labor law practice.\n\nPaterson was the father of 55th Governor of New York . David, prior to his tenure as Governor, served in the state Senate from 1985 to 2006. David ran at the behest of , after the death of . David rose to the post of state senate minority leader from 2003 to 2006. He was subsequently elected lieutenant governor in  on a ticket with Gov. . David Paterson succeeded to the governor's office upon Spitzer's resignation on March 17, 2008. Basil was present at his son's swearing in and was recognized by his son during his speech.\n\nPaterson died at  in Manhattan on April 16, 2014, at the age of 87.\n\n\n* \"''''.\" New York, New York, 2020\n*, ''A Mayor's Life: Governing New York's Gorgeous Mosaic'', PublicAffairs Books, 2013\n*.; Wynter, Leon (2007) ''And I Haven't Had a Bad Day Since: From the Streets of Harlem to the Halls of Congress'' New York: St. Martin's Press. \n*Walker, John C.''The Harlem Fox:  at Tammany 1920:1970'', New York: State University New York Press, 1989.\n*Howell, Ron ''Boss of Black Brooklyn: The Life and Times of '' Fordham University Press Bronx, New York 2018\n\n\n*\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Dan Quart''' (born May 29, 1972)  is an American lawyer and politician. He was a member of the  representing District 73 which includes parts of the  and  areas in the , , .  He was originally elected in a  in 2011 following the resignation of . On December 23, 2021 he announced his plan to step down at the end of his current term.\n\n\nQuart was born in the  neighborhood of Manhattan. He grew up in Mitchell-Lama Housing. His father was a teacher for 41 years and a member of the .\n\n\nAfter being admitted to the bar, Quart worked as a volunteer lawyer for 's Housing Division. In 2003, he was awarded the Pro Bono Publico Award by New York State Chief Judge  for his commitment to providing legal services to the poor.\n\nBefore his election to the State Assembly, Quart served on  for eight years, where he was co-chair of the Transportation Committee and the chair of the board's Second Ave Subway Task force. When the project stalled, he helped secure $1 billion in funding.\n\nIn 2005, he finished second in the Democratic primary for  to .\n\nQuart was elected to the New York State Assembly in 2011. He has introduced legislation to end cash , reform campaign finance laws for District Attorneys races, and hold reckless drivers accountable. He was part of a 7-year effort to repeal New York's  ban, a state law found unconstitutional by a Manhattan federal court judge.\n\nIn 2012, he was named one of '''''s \"40 under 40\" people who are young and influential in New York City politics.Pehme, Morgan (May 21, 2012). .  ''''.\n\nIn 2021, he ran for Manhattan District Attorney, losing in the Democratic primary to .\n\nHe continues to do criminal defense work while serving in the assembly.\n\n\nQuart resides on the Upper East Side with his wife Miriam, and their two children.\n\n\n\n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n* , his official website with the \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

Millman''' (born June 20, 1940) represented District 52 in the , which consists of the  neighborhoods of , , , , , , ,  and .\n\nChosen in a  held in 1997, Millman served as the Chairwoman of the Assembly Commission on Government Administration and the Assembly Task Force on Women's Issues, as well as sitting on the Assembly committees on Aging, Alcoholism and Drug Abuse, Corporations, among several other standing committee assignments.\n\nPrior to her election to the assembly, from 1985 to 1996, Millman served as an educational consultant in several capacities, including as a consultant to former NY City Council president  and Senator , as well as facilitator for Comprehensive School Development and Planning.     "pages": }\n\n'''Miriam Friedlander''' (April 8, 1914, ,  – October 4, 2009, ) was an American politician from the  who represented New York City's  and  in the  from 1974 to 1991.\n\n\nFriedlander was born to a  family in , , in 1914. Her father, David Sigel (Sigelovytch), was an office worker, insurance salesman, and political activist in the immigrant foreign language clubs. Her mother Hannah Lipman (Goldotsky) was fluent in Russian, Hebrew, Yiddish, and English. Miriam moved with her family to  as at the age of five in 1919. She graduated from  in 1931 and 's College of Education in 1935. In 1939, she married Mark Friedlander, and their son Paul was born in New York City in 1943. The marriage ended in divorce in 1954. Her brother Paul died in 1938 , according to a 2008 profile published in ''The Villager'', a community newspaper in the . In 1962, Friedlander was one of ten U.S.  officials told by Attorney General  to register with the . Friedlander was identified as a member of the New York party committee.\n\nIn 1973, Friedlander won the Democratic primary for the  of the City Council, which then included SoHo, Chinatown, the East Village and the Lower East Side, by a mere 48 votes, defeating four opponents. She had to defend her seat the following year, due to a court-ordered legislative reapportionment. In the  primary election she defeated a then-little known lawyer named , by just 95 votes.\n\nIn 1985, she ran against another Chinatown candidate, .\n\n\nWilliam K. Dobbs, a longtime gay activist who got to know Ms. Friedlander in the 1970s and 1980s, described her as a strong, and early, advocate of gay rights.\n\n\"When she made a point, it was a physical action,\" he said in a phone interview. \"She'd pull her arm back and crook her elbow. She was a real brawler as a politician, and she fought fiercely in what she believed in.\"\n\n\nFriedlander died on October 4, 2009, aged 95. Prior to her death, Friedlander supported the candidacies of  and .\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

O'Brien''' (born 1957) is an American politician who served in the  in 2013 and 2014, representing .\n\n\nO'Brien was raised in , and graduated from  in 1975,  in 1979, and  in 1982.\n\nHe was admitted to the  in 1983 and the U.S. Bankruptcy Court, Western District of New York in 1985. Early in his career he moved to , where he still resides.\n\nHe briefly practiced in his family's firm before moving to a series of other law firms. He entered into partnership with other attorneys to form Harris, Chesworth, O'Brien, Johnstone & Welch, LLP in 1991.\n\n\n\nFile:TedOBrienIndependenceDayParade2014.JPG\n\nO'Brien began his political career as the chair of the Monroe County Democratic Committee. In 2004, he was appointed to fill the vacancy left by Jay Ricci in the Monroe County Legislature. He served two years as the minority leader there, starting in 2010.\n\nIn November 2012, he bested  for the state Senate seat left open by the retiring .\n\nO'Brien lost his Senate seat to the Republican and former  anchor  in the 2014 general election.\n\nIn July 2015, O'Brien was appointed Assistant Attorney General In Charge of the Rochester Office of the New York State Attorney General.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Abraham David Beame''' ('''' '''Birnbaum'''; March 20, 1906February 10, 2001) was an American accountant, investor, and  politician who was the 104th , in office from 1974 to 1977. As mayor, he presided over the city during the , when the city was almost forced to declare bankruptcy.\n\n\nBeame was born Abraham David Birnbaum in London. His parents were Esther (née Goldfarb) and Philip Birnbaum, Jewish immigrants from Poland who fled . Beame and his family left England when he was three months old. He was raised on New York City's .\n\nHe graduated from P.S. 160 and the High School of Commerce before enrolling at the 's School of Business and Civic Administration (spun off as  in 1968), where he received his undergraduate degree in business with honors in 1928.\n\n\n\n\nWhile in college, Beame co-founded an accounting firm, Beame & Greidinger. He was an accounting teacher at  in  from 1929 to 1946 and also taught accounting and commercial law at  from 1944 to 1945.\n\nFrom 1952 to 1961, Beame served as New York City's director of the budget, having also served as assistant director from 1946 to 1952. In this capacity, he \"negotiated all city labor contracts without a strike and kept books on city spending and borrowing; he also set up management programs that saved the city $40 million.\"\n\n\nBeame was a \"clubhouse\" or , a product of the  wing of the patronage-oriented \"regular\"  organization, the borough's equivalent of Manhattan's  and the locus of New York patronage politics following the ascent of , as opposed to the policy-oriented \"reform\" Democrats who entered New York City politics, most effectively in Manhattan and the Bronx in the 1950s.\n\nBefore being elected to two nonconsecutive terms as city comptroller in 1961 and 1969, he was a longstanding member of 's influential Madison Democratic Club and served as  's personal accountant. Members of the Madison Club, including attorney/fundraiser Abraham \"Bunny\" Lindenbaum and Steingut's son, , frequently liaised with real estate developer . The club also played a decisive role in the political ascent of –based attorney , whose tenure as  coincided with Beame's administration, though Carey eventually broke with the organization by endorsing 's 1977 primary bid to unseat Beame.\n\nIn 1965, Beame was the Democratic nominee for mayor of New York City.  was his campaign manager and  his campaign chair. Despite having Senator 's strong support, Beame lost to the Republican nominee, .\n\n\n with President  and   in 1977]]\n\nBeame won the  with 34% of the vote, ahead of  (29%),  (24%), and  (16%). He defeated State Senator , Blumenthal, and Biaggi in the , becoming the 104th mayor of New York City. Beame was the city's first Jewish mayor.}}\n\n\n\nHe entered office facing the  in the city's history and spent most of his term attempting to ward off bankruptcy. Soon after being sworn in as mayor, Beame slashed the city workforce, froze salaries, and reconfigured the budget, which proved unsatisfactory until reinforced by actions from newly created state-sponsored entities and the granting of federal funds.\n\nIn October 1975, the city of New York was in debt of $453 million. Beame made a statement on October 17 that the city had insufficient cash on hand to meet its debt obligations for that day. He added that New York City citizens needed to take immediate steps to protect the city's essential life support systems and to preserve their well-being. President  at first turned down New York's request for a loan, inspiring the legendary '''' headline \"Ford to City: Drop Dead\", but Ford later approved federal support for New York.\n\n\nOn the evening of July 13, 1977, a  hit the city. With temperatures in the mid-nineties Fahrenheit and the humidity high, New Yorkers sweltered. By the time power was restored at 10:39&nbsp;p.m. the next night, the city had been without power for 25 hours. Beame set up a Blackout Action Center at the New York City Police Department headquarters. The blackout resulted in raw sewage washing up on beaches and spoiled food in hundreds or thousands of restaurants around the city.\n\nAfter a chaotic four years as mayor, Beame ran for a second term in 1977, and finished third in the Democratic , behind Representative  and  , and ahead of former Representative , Representative  and Manhattan Borough President . He was succeeded by Koch, who won the .\n\nWhen Beame left office on January 1, 1978, the city budget had a surplus of $200 million. There was a $1.5 billion deficit when Beame took office.\n\nA 1993 survey of historians, political scientists and urban experts by Melvin G. Holli of the  ranked Beame as the 14th-worst American big-city mayor to serve between 1820 and 1993.\n\n\nBeame worked in investment advising after leaving office.\n\n\nBeame was married to his childhood sweetheart, Mary (née Ingerman), for 67 years. They met when Beame was 15, playing checkers at the . They raised two sons, Edmond and Bernard (Buddy), and lived in Brooklyn, first in Crown Heights and later in a \"modest\" apartment on Plaza Street West in Park Slope. Throughout his life, Beame summered in the  neighborhood of .\n\nBeame received the Townsend Harris medal in 1957, and awards from numerous charitable, religious and civic organizations.\n\nBeame experienced heart problems in his later years. He had heart attacks in 1991 and 2000. After the second, he was admitted to , where he remained for the last months of his life. He underwent open-heart surgery in August and December 2000, and died from surgical complications on February 10, 2001, at the age of 94.\n\n\n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* Shelton, Jon. \"Dropping Dead: Teachers, the New York City Fiscal Crisis, and Austerity\" in Shelton, ''Teacher Strike! Public Education and the Making of a New American Political Order'' (U of Illinois Press, 2017) pp 114-142.\n\n\n* \n*  (archived)\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
          }
        ]
      }
    }

    "pages": }\n'''Julia Salazar''' (born December 30, 1990) is an American politician and activist. She is the  for the , which covers much of northern , centered on . She won the seat as a first-time candidate after unseating incumbent Senator  in the  primary in 2018. She attracted national media attention for her support for  and other views. A member of the , she became the first member of the organization to serve in New York's state legislature.\n\n\nSalazar was born in Miami on December 30, 1990. Her mother is an American citizen by birth, and her father a  American citizen from . Her parents divorced during her childhood. Salazar was raised in a secular conservative home and at 18 registered as a . In March 2010, she registered with the , believing it meant she was an .\n\nSalazar attended , but did not earn a degree. While there, Salazar was  and a member of pro-Israel Christian student groups, but after a trip to Israel with , her political views began to shift and she became involved in campus Jewish life and tenant organizing. After college, she became a  and campaigned extensively for legislation around .\n\n\n\nWhile attending college, Salazar worked as a nanny for four years on the  and as a housecleaner, and in combination with her study of Middle Eastern history this led her to become more class-conscious. She began as an activist by organizing a tenant group with which she launched a rent strike against poor conditions in her housing block. She then worked at a social justice non-profit,  (JFREJ) as an organizer.\n\n\nIn April 2018, Salazar announced her candidacy for the  of the  in the Democratic primary against incumbent Senator , who had held his position since 2002.\n\nShe ran as a . Her campaign gained significant attention after the primary victory of  in . She was endorsed by , the , , and Ocasio-Cortez herself.  initially endorsed her but later revoked their endorsement, citing discrepancies in information she provided about her academic credentials.\n\nOn September 13, 2018 Salazar defeated Dilan for the Democratic Party nomination. She was elected unopposed at the November 6 general election.\n\nSalazar handily won re-election in 2020, with 86.7% of the votes in the Democratic primary, and 97.5% in the general election.\n\n\n\nSalazar is a self-described , a member of the , and a staff organizer for Jews for Racial and Economic Justice. She supports universal rent control in New York City, , , the abolition of , and . She also states that she supports the  movement which advocates boycotting Israel. She also supported the .\n\nSalazar characterizes democratic socialists as those who recognize  to be an inherently oppressive and  system and who actively work to dismantle it in favor of a socialist . Contrasting  from democratic socialists, she identifies the former as those offering palliative solutions within capitalism (without advocating for changing the system); however, she highlights the overlap between the two groups in regard to short-term policy goals.\n\nShe endorsed  for the . For the , she endorsed , the candidate of the .\n\n\nArmin Rosen of '''' has questioned Salazar's Jewish identity. Salazar describes herself as Jewish, has said that she has some  ancestry through her father, including a Sephardic surname, and that she started to explore Judaism while attending college. According to Rosen, her brother claimed their father \"never mentioned\" any Sephardic heritage before his death, though Salazar's mother stated that her husband's family had a Sephardic background, and Salazar's former classmates attested to her Jewish faith in college. Salazar accused Rosen of engaging in \"\" and claimed he had threatened to publish her mother’s personal information if she didn't cooperate.\n\n\nOn September 11, 2018, Salazar accused , a spokesperson for then Israeli Prime Minister , of sexual assault, stating she was preempting being outed in a story about to be published by ''''. Keyes denied assaulting her in a statement to Israeli newspaper ''''. Eleven additional women subsequently alleged similar instances of harassment or assault by him. Keyes resigned from his position in December 2018.\n\n\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Timothy Howard Bishop''' (born June 1, 1950) is an American politician who served as a  for  from 2003 to 2015. He is a member of the .\n\nThe district includes most of Central and Eastern , including most of , as well as the entirety of the towns of , , , , , and . The district encompasses wealthy enclaves such as , middle-class suburban towns such as ,  and , working-class neighborhoods such as  and , and rural farming communities such as  and  on the .\n\n\nBishop is a twelfth-generation resident of , where he was born on June 1, 1950. He is the son of Catherine (Roesel) and Howard Cortland Bishop. He is the great-grandson of Benjamin H. Bishop, a mayor of Southampton, and has English, Irish, and German ancestry. He received a bachelor's degree in history from the  and a master's degree in public administration from .  Bishop served as  of  for 16 years, where he began working in 1973 as an admissions counselor. He served as the college's director of financial aid, assistant director of admissions, registrar, director of institutional research and planning, dean for enrollment services, and dean for administrative and student services.\n\nDuring his tenure, several academic programs were improved.   Southampton College of Long Island University produced 36 Fulbright Scholars. Four new graduate programs were added to the curriculum, and a new academic center, Chancellors Hall, was built.\n\nAlong with the Southampton College Chancellor, , Bishop developed the most successful single fund-raising event in the college's history, the All for the Sea rock concerts which grossed as much as $1 million annually.\n\n\n\n\nBishop supported and voted for the  and the Health Care and Education Reconciliation Act of 2010.\n\nBishop also voted for the Housing and Economic Recovery Act of 2008, the Emergency Economic Stabilization Act (TARP), and the  (also known as the \"stimulus bill\"), and for further measures in 2009 and 2010.  He also voted for the Budget Control Act of 2011, which provided for further gradual increments in the .\n\nBishop participated in the bipartisan coalition of elected officials and community advocates that saved the 106th Air Rescue Wing located at Gabreski Airport from being shut down by the Pentagon's base closure commission.\n\nIn opposition to a plan that would have dumped more than twenty million cubic yards of contaminated dredge waste in the Long Island Sound, Bishop sponsored legislation to block the plan. In January 2007, he voted for a reduction of interest rates on future federal student loans.\n\nBishop supported the  tribe's successful attempts at gaining formal federal recognition. Bishop supported a $160,000 line-item for the Shinnecock Nation in President Obama's 2013 budget proposal.\n\n\n*''''''\n**\n**\n*''''''\n**\n**\n** (Ranking Member)\n**\n\n\n*    National Archives Caucus, Co-chair\n*    Democratic Budget Group, Co-chair\n*    Coalition for Autism Research and Education (CARE)\n*    Community College Caucus\n*    Congressional Caucus on Armenian Issues\n*    Congressional Arts Caucus\n*    Congressional Caucus on Addiction, Treatment and Recovery\n*    Congressional Civility Caucus\n*    Congressional Humanities Caucus\n*    Congressional Labor and Working Families Caucus\n*    Congressional Long Island Sound Caucus\n*    Congressional Military Family Caucus\n*    Congressional Shipbuilding Caucus\n*    Congressional Sri Lanka Caucus\n*    Congressional Wine Caucus\n*    House Cancer Caucus\n*    House Democratic Caucus\n*    House Renewable Energy and Energy Efficiency Caucus\n*    House National Service Caucus\n*    Sudan Caucus\n*    Sustainable Energy and Environment Coalition\n*   United Services Organization (USO) Congressional Caucus\n\n\n\nIn September 2013, the  recommended further review of an August 2012 incident in which Bishop was accused of soliciting a campaign contribution from hedge fund magnate Eric Semler in exchange for acting in an official capacity to obtain a fireworks permit for Semler's son's bar mitzvah on Long Island. Bishop denied the allegations as \"outrageous, unfounded attacks on my character and my family\". After the incident was picked up by the media, Semler called the allegations a \"nonstory\".\n \t\nThe  investigated the incident. In September 2014, the Justice Department closed its investigation without filing charges, although the ethics probe remained open until Bishop left office in January 2015. The falling out from the incident, along with the 2013 redistricting which made the 1st more favorable to Republicans, was cited as a factor in Bishop's failed re-election in 2014.\n\n\n\n;2002\n\nIn his first political race, Bishop ran as a  against  incumbent  During the campaign, Grucci ran  ads accusing Bishop of falsifying rape statistics at  Southampton College, but his claims were based on articles from a college newspaper that contained numerous inaccuracies. Grucci refused to repudiate the ads, and was defeated by Bishop.\n\n;2004\n\nIncumbent Bishop beat Republican  56.2%-43.8%\n\n;2006\n\nIncumbent Bishop beat Republican  62.2%-37.8%\n\n;2008\n\nIncumbent Bishop defeated Republican  58%-42% and was re-elected.\n\n;2010\n\nBishop narrowly defeated Republican  by a margin of 50.2% to 49.8% after Altschuler conceded the race when trailing by 263 votes.\n\n;2012\n\nBishop again defeated Republican Randy Altschuler by a 52.2%-47.8% margin. Although Bishop received the Independence Party endorsement in most of his previous elections, in 2012 the endorsement went instead to his opponent.\n\n;2014\n\nBishop ran unopposed for the Democratic,  and Independence Party nominations. He was a member of the 's Frontline Program, a program designed to help protect vulnerable Democratic incumbents heading into the 2014 election. He faced Republican nominee , whom he had defeated in 2008, in the general election.\nOn November 4, 2014, Bishop lost his re-election bid to Zeldin 55% to 45%.\n\n\nAfter leaving Congress, Bishop joined St. Joseph's University as a distinguished professor of Civic Engagement and Public Service.  Among Bishop's many responsibilities at the University he will be afforded the opportunity to continue his lifelong work of providing access to Higher Education to traditional underserved populations.\n\nBishop is a senior advisor to a -based government relations firm.\n\nBishop has accepted positions on the Board of Directors of Social Accountability International and The Sergeant Sullivan Center. Both commitments allow Bishop to continue on two of his top priorities in the Congress  working to ensure workplace protections and services to U.S. veterans, particularly in the area of post deployment health.\n\nOn March 20, 2018, Bishop was confirmed by the  to a five-year term on the Suffolk County Water Authority (SCWA).\n\n\nBishop is married to Kathryn, founder and director of The Children's School Early Childhood program at Southampton College, and has two daughters, Molly and Meghan. He is a .\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n*  at \n*\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n''|years=}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

He represents the , which includes the  neighborhoods of , , , ,  and parts of .\n\n\nSanders was born at the Hammel Houses in Far Rockaway. He attended public schools throughout the Rockaways then attended . Sanders served as a .\n\n\nIn 2001, Sanders won election to the  of the  in an  win against powerful candidates James Blake and Charlotte Jefferson. Blake had received the support of  councilwoman Juanita Watkins. On the council, Sanders was the first African-American to sit as Chair of the '. In July 2009, Sanders was reported to have shown up for only 61% of City Council meetings for fiscal year 2009, the second-fewest on the list. However, he has attributed this to the near fatal car crash that he had in the fall of 2008 which also injured his staffers,  and Mike Duvall.\n\nIn 2009, he was challenged for reelection from candidates Michael Duncan, Jacques Leandre, and Frederick Lewis. He was re-elected with 40% of the vote, with his next leading opponent, Jacques Leandre, receiving 19%. His council seat is now held by his former District Manager .\n\nIn early 2007, Sanders endorsed then-Senator  for  and traveled to , , and  to campaign for him. He became an Obama  and represented his district at the  in . In 2015, Sanders endorsed Senator  for  and the 2016 general election. He endorsed Bernie Sanders again for the .\n\n\nIn 2012, Sanders, who would have been term-limited in the City Council and unable to run again in 2013, opted to primary Senator , who was facing corruption charges. He would go on to win with 56% of the vote, winning the general election unopposed.  He has been unopposed in the general election ever since.\n\nIn December 2015, Sanders filed papers to challenge Congressman  in the Democratic primary for . However, he dropped out of the race in March 2016, accusing Meeks of leaking information to the '''' about a  probe into Sanders' use of s and alleged  of a $250,000  from a non-profit. Sanders was never charged with any wrongdoing, and he successfully ran for reelection to his Senate seat despite the  backing an opponent, .\n\nWhen Democrats took control of the state senate in 2019, Sanders was named chairman on the Committee on Banks.\n\nIn 2019, Sanders introduced a resolution to recognize October 1, the , as \"China Day\" in New York State. The resolution in the state senate was attended by China's counsel general for New York State, Huang Ping, who praised it.\n\n\nIn 2005, he married his former . He has two children from a previous marriage.\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Marcos A. Crespo''' (born July 29, 1980) is a former  member of the  representing the 85th Assembly District, which includes the , , , and  sections of the .\n\nBorn in , Crespo and his family moved to  when he was a young child. Crespo also spent some time in , in his young years, thus shaping Crespo's views about the conditions of other countries.\n\nHe enrolled in  in 1996, pursuing a degree in government studies. In 2003, he participated in the State Assembly's internship program, where he was assigned to work with Assemblyman  Crespo earned his  degree in 2004, after which he got a position as assistant to New York State Senator \n\nCrespo was first elected to the  in a June 2009 special election to replace Rubén Díaz Jr., who became   in 2009.\n\n\nCrespo was born in , on July 29, 1980, one of four children of Ivette Fontanez and Alberto Crespo. At a young age, Crespo moved with his family to New York City, where he attended New York City public schools. Crespo also spent three years living in Lima, Perú, where he completed fourth and fifth grades while attending Santa Tersesita. He returned to Puerto Rico with his younger sister and his mother and completed  at Carmen Bozello de Huyke High School, but soon thereafter, returned to New York to live with his father.\n\nMarcos is a graduate of  of Criminal Justice, is married and has two young daughters.\n\n\nCrespo was one of the youngest members of the  when first elected in 2009. His proposal to create an emergency energy backup system for the State’s health and safety infrastructure during a natural disaster was included in the 2013-2014 State Budget.\n\nIn April 2013, Crespo was appointed to the Chairmanship of the Assembly Task Force on New Americans, and in March 2015, he was appointed by Assembly Speaker  to the Chairmanship of the Assembly Puerto Rican/Hispanic Task Force and the Task Force on Demographic Research and Reapportionment. In the Assembly, Crespo authored an anti-fraud bill to protect immigrants that passed both houses of the legislature and worked to expand legal services to underserved communities outside New York City. In , Crespo has pushed for  service that will cut commuting time into  by an hour and worked on improving traffic congestion and air quality for the neighborhoods near  Terminal Market by building an additional ramp to the Bruckner Expressway, thereby removing hundreds of trucks from local roads. He has fought to secure the remaining funding needed to finish the last phase of the Starlight Park trail.\n\nCrespo has also fought to remove tons of garbage trucked into the Bronx each day from Manhattan, which pollutes Bronx neighborhoods and sickens its residents with severe respiratory diseases. He has called for the building of the Ganesvoort Recycling Facility in Manhattan in order to make Manhattan residents responsible for their own garbage.\n\nIn 2015, Crespo was unanimously elected Chair of the Bronx County Democratic Committee, replacing , who gave up the role when elected . Crespo was nominated for the post by his Assembly colleague, , and the nomination was seconded by woman .\n\nIn 2020 after 11 years as a member of the New York State Assembly Marcos Crespo joined  in The Bronx where he was named Senior Vice President, Community Affairs.\n\n\nCrespo belongs to these committees.\n* Chair, Puerto Rican/Hispanic Task Force\n* Member, Committee on Alcoholism and Drug Abuse\n* Member, Committee on Cities\n* Member, Committee on Energy\n* Member, Committee on Environmental Conservation\n* Member, Committee on Insurance\n* Member, Committee on Transportation\n* Member, Black, Puerto Rican, Hispanic & Asian Legislative Caucus\n* Co-Chair, Legislative Task Force on Demographic Research and Reapportionment\n\n\n* '''November 2018 , NYS Assembly, 85th AD'''\n:\n\n* '''November 2016 , NYS Assembly, 85th AD'''\n:\n\n* '''September 2016  , NYS Assembly, 85th AD'''\n: \n\n* '''November 2014 , NYS Assembly, 85th AD'''\n: \n\n* '''September 2014  , NYS Assembly, 85th AD'''\n: \n\n* '''November 2012 , NYS Assembly, 85th AD'''\n:\n\n* '''November 2010 , NYS Assembly, 85th AD'''\n:\n\n* '''June 2009 , NYS Assembly, 85th AD'''\n:\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

She attended  in . She graduated  in economics from the , and later earned a master's degree from 's Graduate School of Business. After receiving her degree, she worked on  as an industry analyst for .\n\n\nShe entered politics as a , and was President of the Mamaroneck , and President of the PTA of the Central School in Mamaroneck. Her district was numbered the 36th from January 1985 to 2002, and the 37th from 2003 to 2012. The district comprised a part of . \n\nShe was a pivotal political supporter of the efforts of the Jay Coalition (today's non-profit ) to preserve the historic  in Rye.\n\nOn Monday, December 6, 2010, Bob Cohen conceded to Oppenheimer after a lengthy ballot recount.     "pages": }\n'''Frederick J. Akshar II''' is an American  politician from the State of New York. Akshar represented  in the New York State Senate from 2015 to 2022. Since January 1, 2023, Akshar has served as the  .\n\n\nAkshar grew up in Afton in the  region of . He graduated from  as well as the .\n\nA law enforcement officer, Akshar worked at the  and the . His work in law enforcement spanned 15 years, and he served as Captain of the Law Enforcement Division at the Broome County Sheriff's Office. Akshar was named undersheriff of Broome County in June 2015. Prior to his election to the New York State Senate, he also served on the Crime Victims Assistance Center Board and the Broome Opioid Abuse Council.\n\n\nIn 2015, long-serving State Senator  forfeited his Senate seat after being found guilty of lying to the federal authorities. As a result, a special election was called in Senate District 52, and the Republican Party nominated Akshar to replace Libous. While Democrats targeted the seat and ran former Broome County Executive Barbara Fiala against him, Akshar received nearly 78% of the vote and defeated Fiala. He was re-elected in 2016 and 2018.\n\nIn July 2018, Akshar's staff confirmed that Akshar was \"in a relationship with Jessica Williams, who until last week was on Akshar's payroll as his director of administration.\" A report indicated that Williams had \"received eight salary increases and three promotions during her roughly 2½ years on Akshar's payroll, rising from a part-timer making $32,600 in 2015 to a full-timer making $85,000 today\".\n\nAkshar was appointed chair of the Senate Republican Campaign Committee in December 2018, replacing Sen. . Young had attempted to oust Senate Republican Leader  from his leadership position in November 2018, and Akshar had supported Flanagan.\n\nIn January 2019, ''The New York Times'' noted Akshar's frustration with the continuing push for transgender rights; when \"State Senator Jessica Ramos...said lawmakers should go even further to help transgender New Yorkers,\" Akshar responded, \"Jesus Christ! Further?\"\n\nOn January 23, 2019, Akshar voted against the NY DREAM Act, which passed both houses of the State Legislature. The bill would extend state financial aid to undocumented immigrant students who were brought to the United States as children.\n\nOn March 30, 2021, After NYS voted and passed S.854 to Legalize Recreational Marijuana, Akshar released a message claiming that traffic accidents are going up in other states. Shortly after he announced his run for Broome County Sheriff. \"We know that in states that have legalized recreational marijuana, fatal accidents have shot up - a nearly 50% increase in Colorado and double in Washington. Across the board in states that have legalized recreational marijuana, we’ve seen substantial increases in vehicle accidents vs. neighboring states where it is not legal. We know that unemployment has risen, marijuana hospitalizations and teen suicide have risen as well as mental health rates.\"\n\nOn June 3, 2021, Akshar announced his intention not to run for reelection for his seat in the New York State Senate, instead opting to run for Broome County Sheriff in 2022.\n\n\nDuring his 2015 campaign for New York State Senate, Akshar's opponent accused him of unethical behavior in connection with a 2009 motor vehicle accident involving the nephew of his then-girlfriend, Kate Newcomb. Akshar denied wrongdoing, and no charges were filed following an investigation.\n\nIn November 2016, PressConnects.com described Kate Newcomb, a captain in the Broome County Sheriff's Office, as Akshar's longtime girlfriend.\n\nAs of July 2018, Akshar was dating former staffer Jessica Williams. He announced his engagement to Jessica Fiacco (also known as Jessica Williams) in December 2018.\n\nIn April 2019, Akshar was accused of engaging in an inappropriate relationship with the mother of a murder victim. At that time, Akshar acknowledged having had a \"brief, consensual relationship\" with Mirella Masciarelli some years earlier. Masciarelli was the mother of Mario Masciarelli, whose 2013 murder Akshar had helped to investigate; Akshar also testified at a pretrial hearing in the case. Masciarelli described Akshar as a \"predator\" who \"'interjected himself into [her] life in a way that...was not professional as a captain in the Broome County Sheriff's Office'\" and took advantage of her grief over the loss of her son. Akshar denied any wrongdoing and accused Masciarelli of engaging in an \"attempted smear campaign\".\n\nAs of January 2019, Akshar resides in .\n\n\n\n\n\n* ''official site''\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
          }

  "query":
