    "pages": }\n| image_size = 220px\n| term_start = January 2010\n| term_end = January 2018\n}}\n'''George Maragos''' (born March 17, 1949) was the 13th Comptroller of , USA. He was first elected in 2009 for a four-year term and was re-elected in 2013 for a second four-year term.\n\n\nMaragos received an  in finance in 1983 from  in . As an undergraduate, he studied  at  in , Canada, earning a  in electrical engineering in 1973.\n\n\nMaragos started his career at  where he was one of the youngest managers in the global technology organization. In 1978, he joined  in New York to work on  Defense Command and Control Systems, requiring security clearances from the . He later became an associate in charge of developing information technology solutions for major multi-national commercial clients.\n\nIn 1981, he joined , leading a team charged with building the organization's international data and money transfer network. He was later promoted to vice president. In 1986, he joined  as vice president and director of North American Treasury and Telecommunications Systems.\n\nIn 1989, Maragos founded his own business, SDS Financial Technologies, and was its president and CEO for over 20 years until his election as Nassau County Comptroller in 2009.\n\n\nMaragos was elected as Nassau County comptroller in November 2009, and was sworn in in January 2010. He was re-elected to a second term beginning in January 2014. The comptroller and his staff oversee the county's budget and financial operations; in 2017, the annual budget was $2.6 billion. The comptroller's office audits government agencies, reviews all county contracts and claims and reports on all matters that significantly affect Nassau County's financial health and operations. The office is also in charge of administering the county payroll and employee health benefits, and preparing Nassau County's Comprehensive Annual Financial Report. In general, Maragos and his staff \"work with the administration and legislature to help Nassau County overcome its fiscal challenges\".\n\n\nMaragos released an audit of the Nassau County Police Department which revealed $96.28 million in higher-than-budgeted overtime costs and $382.27 million in savings from attrition from 2009 to 2014. These figures were compounded on $247.58 million in estimated future savings as a result of the new collective bargaining agreement. Maragos gave credit to the Nassau County Police for keeping crime low and protecting Nassau County residents but also proposed that the police department's management practices needed to be revised so that more resources could be directed to improve public safety.\n\n\nMaragos released a study in 2014 into the changing demographics of Nassau County. The study proposed a new economic vision for the county which, if implemented, it was claimed would revitalize the economy by drawing on the county's natural advantages to become the health and wellness center of the world. Maragos proposed that Nassau County should become a place where people would \"want to come to receive the best medical treatments and where the next generation of miracle medicines would be discovered\". He urged greater focused investments in innovation, research and development, transportation infrastructure and IT to achieve this economic vision.\n\n\nAt the request of the Nassau County Police Department, the Nassau County Comptroller's Office conducted an audit which revealed that Verizon underpaid the county over $466,919, an amount that may have increased as investigations continued. From 2001 to 2014, Verizon implemented an Enhanced 911 system throughout Nassau County. During this time, Verizon deducted 1-3% beyond the permitted administrative fee from residents' monthly phone bills. The comptroller's office recommended a collaboration with the offices of the Nassau County Police to obtain the total unpaid amount from Verizon while the police department reviewed the previous months that Verizon was working with Nassau County on the E911 system to determine whether or not there was even more withheld during that time.\n\n\nIn a letter dated December 4, 2014, the Hempstead Industrial Development Agency (\"IDA\") proposed a Payment In Lieu Of Taxes (\"PILOT\") which was described to assist with the purchase of 71.87 acres of land and improvements to the Green Acres Commons (formerly known as the Green Acres Mall). It was not until December 12, 2014, that a cost-benefit analysis for the project was released. The approval of the IDA's PILOT on December 17, 2014, directly contributed to a rise in school property taxes from 4.6% to 12.2% while reducing the taxes paid by the Green Acre Commons by $2.7 million. Maragos review of the documents concerned the PILOTs' unusually expedited process of approval, as well as the PILOT's four-page cost-benefit analysis which contained only calculation tables without any explanations. On October 24, 2016, the Nassau County Comptroller's Office commenced a formal audit of the Town of Hempstead IDA regarding the PILOT granted to the Green Acres Mall.\n\n\nMaragos conducted and released an audit of a county contract totaling $385,478 in order to monitor the removal of debris caused by . The contract was performed by Gibbons, Esposito and Boyce (GEB), an engineering firm based in Uniondale, New York. Eight field monitors, who constituted 50% of the employees who were working on the debris removal monitoring project, were underpaid. According to the audit, GEB failed to provide proof that all of its field monitors had the proper FEMA protocol training which was a minimum requirement stated in the contract. Paid time off was not awarded, which is contrary to Living Wave Law. Various time sheets that GEB submitted to the county for reimbursement did not contain the appropriate signatures for approval. GEB and its legal counsel maintained that they were exempt from the county's Living Wage Law. The auditors disagreed. GEB offered to pay the employees the Living Wave underpayment. The audit was sent to Nassau's County and District Attorneys for further review.\n\n\n testimony on the privatization of Island Bus in November 2010]]\nMaragos released a study concerning the proposed privatization of Long Island Bus after over 35 years. The report recommended that the best option for Nassau County was to negotiate with the MTA to continue with the current service, with a more equitable subsidy. The MTA should first decrease the LIBS operating expense by about 4%, so that no increase in subsidies would be required for 2011 by either the MTA or the county. If an increase was necessary, then both the county and the MTA should proportionately increase their subsidies in order to keep the LIBS running. However, if negotiations failed and Nassau County was forced to contribute the full subsidy demanded by the MTA of over $36 million for 2011, then Maragos ultimately recommended that privatization should be pursued.\n\n\nIn early 2011, Maragos released an audit of the Nassau County Traffic and Parking Violations Agency, which showed that on December 31, 2010, the agency had $44 million in uncollected traffic violation fines dating back ten years and $26 million in uncollected parking violations in the previous six years with red light camera passed due tickets estimated at over $10 million alone on December 31, 2011.\n\n\nMaragos released an audit of the Nassau County Office of Consumer Affairs. The audit, conducted from January 1, 2013, to December 31, 2015, revealed that poor internal controls led to a loss of $2.9 million in county revenue. Missed violations from a lack of Item Pricing Waiver inspections resulted in approximately $1.5 million in uncollected fees. Maragos went on to say that a complete overhaul was needed to restore the confidence of the public and to improve efficiency.\n\n\nIn January 2014, Maragos posted all vendor names, contract amounts and brief summaries of public contracts to social media via ''Facebook''. This is considered to be the first time nationwide that public contracts had been released to the public in such a manner.\n\n\nIn 2010, Maragos and his staff were awarded a Certificate of Achievement for Excellence in Financial Reporting from the  of the United States and Canada, for the county's 2009 Comprehensive Annual Financial Report. The Comptroller's office was similarly recognized by the professional association in the next five years (2011-2015).\n\nOther honors and awards include:\n* Sergeant-at-Arms of the  Republican Club\n* Public Service Award of the Hempstead Coordinating Council of Civic Associations, October 2013\n* Hispanic Heritage Community Service Leadership Award, of the Theodore Roosevelt Council, Boy Scouts of America, October 2013\n* Superstorm Sandy Leadership Award of the Long Island Contractors' Association (LICA), 2012\n\n\nMaragos announced on September 29, 2016, that he would seek the Democratic nomination for Nassau County Executive in 2017. He stated that he had been at odds with County Republican leaders \"for years\" but, up until May 2016, he had still been donating heavily to Republicans and the County Republican Committee.\n\nHe was criticised by both Republicans and Democrats after his switch of party affiliation to run for County Executive. Brian Nevin, the spokesman for Republican , called him an opportunist with Conservative values that he trumpeted during his two failed Senate campaigns. Robert Zimmerman, the Democratic National Committeeman from , called Maragos's switch \"an affront to the principles and standards of the Democratic Party\".\n\n\n\n\nMaragos faced Congressman  and attorney  in a primary election to face  Senator . The 2012 New York State Republican Convention split the endorsement between the three candidates, with enough support for each candidate to automatically appear on the ballot. The primary was held on June 26, 2012, and the general election coincided with the presidential election on November 2.\n\t\nMaragos was unable to win name recognition outside Nassau County and ultimately was defeated and came in last place.\n\nMaragos also attempted to run for the US Senate in 2010.\n\n\nMaragos said during an interview, \"Some people would even like to marry with their pets,\" worried that the legalization of gay marriage could also lead to the legalization of polygamy. At the time, he was against abortion, except to preserve the life of the mother or in cases of rape or incest. Maragos later explained that his views had \"evolved\", believing in the right of a woman to choose and that same-sex marriage is the law and should be respected.\n\n\nMaragos has been married to Angela since 1973, and has two sons, Peter and Angelo, and two grandchildren.\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
          }
        ]

    "pages": }\n\n'''Thomas P. Morahan''' (October 11, 1931 &ndash; July 12, 2010) was a member of the , for the  covering all of  and parts of . He was first elected in a special election in 1999.\n\nMorahan, after winning the November 4th elections, was serving his sixth term at the time of his death in 2010, though he had announced his retirement at the end of the term due to age and leukemia (which ultimately caused his death).\n\n\nThomas Morahan was born in the Bronx.  After graduating from high school, he attended .  The state senator began his government service as a member of the Clarkstown Zoning Board of Appeals. In 1977, he was elected as a  Legislator. He was a member of the  (96th D.) in . He returned to the Rockland County Legislature in 1984. In 1996, he was elected unanimously to serve as Chairman of the Rockland County Legislature. In 1999, he campaigned for position as New York State Senator for the 38th senatorial district.  After winning, served five terms, and won reelection for a sixth term in 2008.  While in political office, Morahan served on the Orange and Rockland Utilities Board as a Community Relations Manager, from 1990 to 1996.\n\nMorahan was identified as a 'very liberal' Republican, within the 2% most liberal Republicans in the New York State Legislature.\n\n\nMorahan was an active member in promoting avocations for citizens with . He was member of the American Organization for Retarded Citizens, which raises funds for solutions for  and other issues. The state senator was also actively involved in Big Brothers, Big Sisters, as well as the New City Rotary Club. He served on the agricultural, educational, homeland security, and mental health committees. Morahan visited and supported veterans' organizations, specifically those of the   and the .\n\n\nOn May 25, 1999, Morahan was elected to fill a vacancy in the State Senate.\nMorahan sponsored and co-sponsored several pieces of  involving promoting awareness for citizens with special needs. He helped pass the Veterans' Buyback Law, which allowed veterans to easily deal with mortgages and retirement issues. He sponsored and voted for strengthening  Laws, which increase the sentences for those charged with . He co-sponsored , which entitles parents and legal guardians access to all child abuse investigation files and medical history records.  Public Safety programs were specifically of Morahan's interest, of which he seeks to pass more laws to solve important issues. He supports donating money to   for its  Center, as well as Emergency Preparedness Training at . Morahan voted against same-sex marriage legislation on December 2, 2009, and the bill was defeated.\n\n\nMorahan died on July 12, 2010, at the age of 78. Prior to his death, he had fought a six-month battle with .\n\n\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Anthony Howard Palumbo''' (born September 14, 1970) is an American  politician who currently represents the  of the . He previously served as a member of the .\n\nPalumbo attended high school at  where he starred as a baseball player earning an athletic scholarship to . In 1992, Palumbo was named to the All-Patriot League baseball team. In 1994 Palumbo graduated with a bachelor's degree in Government and Law from Lafayette College.\n\nHe attended the  and after his graduation in 1998 immediately began his career in public service as an assistant district attorney. He was eventually promoted to the position of trial supervisor to the five eastern Suffolk County towns under District Attorney . He left the District Attorney's office in 2004 to open a small law practice in .\n\nPalumbo resides in  with his wife Tracy and two children.\n\n\n\n\nIn 2013, in his first political campaign, Palumbo defeated Democrat John McManmon with 57% of the vote for the open 2nd Assembly District seat. In 2014 he ran for re-election against Democratic challenger Thomas Schirilo and won with 63% of the vote. He was re-elected again in 2016 and 2018.\n\n\nIn 2020, after Senator  announced he would not be running for reelection after 44 years in the New York State Senate, Palumbo entered the race and won against Democratic challenger Laura Ahearn.\n\nPalumbo introduced a bill that would allow the towns of , , , , and  to establish community housing funds that would help provide financial assistance to first-time home purchasers in the form of a grant or loan. The bill was signed by the governor.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n*\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Rossana Rosado''' (born August 20, 1961) is the 13th Commissioner of the  appointed by Governor  in November 2021. She is also an American newspaper editor, publisher and producer who served as the . On February 3, 2016, Governor  appointed Rosado as the Secretary of State. She then was publisher and CEO of the newspaper company in 1999. In 1992, Rosado was appointed vice president for public affairs at the  for the City of New York by Mayors  and .     "pages": }\n\n'''Andrew Reed Garbarino''' ( ; born September 27, 1984) is an American attorney and politician serving as the  for  since 2021. A member of the , he served as the man for the 7th district from 2013 to 2020.\n\n\nGarbarino was born and raised in . He graduated from  and earned a Bachelor of Arts degree in history and classical humanities from . He then earned a  from .\n\n\nAfter graduating from law school, Garbarino worked at his family law firm in Sayville. His family also owns numerous small businesses in communities from  to .\n\n\nIn 2012,  vacated his  seat to run for the . The  nominated Garbarino to replace him, and he was elected with 56% of the vote. He was reelected three times, in 2014, 2016, and 2018. Garbarino was a member of the New York Conference of Italian-American State Legislators as an assemblyman.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nFollowing the announcement that 14-term incumbent Representative  would not run for reelection in 2020, Garbarino announced his candidacy for Congress in . He ran in the June 23 Republican Party primary, and was endorsed by King, as well as the Nassau County and Suffolk County Republican Parties. He defeated Assemblyman Mike LiPetri, 65% to 35%.\n\nIn the general election, Garbarino was the candidate of the , , and  parties, and the . He defeated Suffolk County legislator Jackie Gordon, the nominee of the , , and  parties, 53% to 46%.\n\n\n\n\nGarbarino won the Republican primary with 53.7% of the vote against primary challengers Robert Cornicelli and Mike Rakebrandt. In a rematch against 2020 Democratic nominee Jackie Gordon, Garbarino again defeated Gordon, 60.7% to 39.3%.\n\n\nGarbarino was sworn in on January 3, 2021.\n\nOn January 6, 2021, Garbarino did not object to the Electoral College results, saying:The role of Congress is not to overturn the election or to take actions that silence voters. The Constitution is clear, the votes must be counted and certified by the states and Congress has the constitutional obligation to accept those electors and certify each states’ elections. All 50 states have certified their elections and the majority of electors have cast their votes for President-Elect Joe Biden. While I join many Long Islanders in wishing the results were different, Congress does not have the constitutional authority to overturn the election.In March 2021, Garbarino was one of eight House Republicans to vote for the .\n\nGarbarino voted against the , as did every congressional Republican.\n\nOn May 19, 2021, Garbarino was one of 35 Republicans who joined all Democrats in voting to approve legislation to establish the  meant to investigate the . On November 5, 2021, Garbarino was one of 13 House Republicans who voted with a majority of Democrats in favor of the . Trump excoriated House Republicans who voted for the bill.\n\nIn October 2023, Garbarino was one of 18 Republicans who  Jim Jordan's nomination for Speaker of the House all three times.\n\n\nIn 2021, Garbarino co-sponsored the Fairness for All Act, the Republican alternative to the Equality Act. The bill would prohibit discrimination on the basis of sex, sexual orientation, and gender identity, and protect the free exercise of religion.\n\nOn July 19, 2022, Garbarino and 46 other Republican representatives voted for the , which would codify the right to same-sex marriage in federal law.\n\n\nFor the :\n* \n* \n** \n** \n* \n**  (Chair)\n\n\n* \n*  Representative Andrew Garbarino|url=https://garbarino.house.gov/about/committees-and-caucuses|access-date=February 1, 2021|website=garbarino.house.gov|date=January 3, 2021}}\n*\n* \n\n\nGarbarino is . He resides in .\n\n\n\n\n\n\n*  official U.S. House website\n* \n* \n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n\n'''Michael Rubens Bloomberg''' (born February 14, 1942) is an American businessman and politician. He is the majority owner and co-founder of , and was its CEO from 1981 to 2001 and again from 2014 to 2023. He served as the  for three terms from 2002 to 2013 and was a candidate for the  for . In 2024, Bloomberg received the  from President . He has served as chair of the , an independent advisory board that provides recommendations on , software, data and digital modernization to the , since June 2022.\n\nBloomberg grew up in , and graduated from  and . He began his career at the securities brokerage firm  before forming his own company in 1981. That company, , is a financial information, software and media firm that is known for its . Bloomberg spent the next twenty years as its chairman and CEO. As of April 2024, '''' ranked him as , with an estimated net worth of US$106.2&nbsp;billion. Bloomberg, who has signed ,  has given away $17.4&nbsp;billion to philanthropic causes in his lifetime.\n\nBloomberg was elected the  mayor of New York City in . He held office for three consecutive terms, winning re-election in  and . Pursuing , Bloomberg developed a .\n\nAs the mayor of New York, Bloomberg established public s, rebuilt urban infrastructure, and supported ,  initiatives, and . He also led a rezoning of large areas of the city, which facilitated massive and widespread new commercial and residential construction after the . Bloomberg is considered to have had far-reaching influence on , , and  during his three terms as mayor. He has also faced significant criticism for the city's  program, support for which he reversed with an apology before his 2020 presidential run.\n\nAfter a brief stint as a full-time philanthropist, he re-assumed the position of CEO at Bloomberg L.P. by the end of 2014. In November 2019, four months before Super Tuesday, Bloomberg officially launched  for the Democratic nomination for president of the United States in the . He ended his campaign in March 2020, after having won only 61 delegates. Bloomberg self-funded $935 million for his candidacy, which set the record for the most expensive U.S. presidential primary campaign.\n\n\nBloomberg was born on February 14, 1942, at , in the  neighborhood of , to William Henry Bloomberg (1906–1963), a bookkeeper for a dairy company, and Charlotte (née Rubens) Bloomberg (1909–2011). His father never earned more than $6,000 a year. William Henry Bloomberg died suddenly when his son was in college. The  at the  was named in William Henry's honor. Bloomberg's family is , and he is a member of the  in Manhattan. Bloomberg's paternal grandfather, Rabbi Alexander \"Elick\" Bloomberg, was a . Bloomberg's maternal grandfather, Max Rubens, was a  immigrant from present-day , and his maternal grandmother was born in New York to Lithuanian Jewish parents.\n\nThe family lived in  until Bloomberg was two years old, followed by , for two years, finally settling in the Boston suburb of , where he lived until after he graduated from college.\n\nBloomberg became an  when he was twelve years old. He graduated from  in 1960. He went on to attend , where he joined the fraternity . While there, he constructed the  costume for the university's . He graduated in 1964 with a  degree in . In 1966, he graduated from  with a  (MBA) degree.\n\nFile:Michael Bloomberg in 1964 Hullabaloo.jpg|\nFile:Michael Bloomberg in 1960 Blue and White.jpg|\n\nBloomberg is a member of  and . He wrote an autobiography, ''Bloomberg by Bloomberg'', with help from  editor-in-chief .\n\n\n with a multi-monitor set-up composed of six screens]]\n\nIn 1966, Bloomberg was hired for a job earning $9,000 per year at , a large  . Salomon Brothers later promoted him to the equities desk. Bloomberg became a  at Salomon Brothers in 1972; he headed  and, later, .  bought Salomon Brothers in 1981, and the new management fired Bloomberg, paying him $10&nbsp;million for his equity in the firm.\n\nUsing the money he received from Phibro, Bloomberghaving designed in-house computerized financial systems for Salomonset up a data services company named Innovative Market Systems (IMS) based on his belief that Wall Street would pay a premium for high-quality business information, delivered instantaneously on computer terminals in a variety of usable formats. The company sold customized s that delivered real-time market data, financial calculations and other analytics to Wall Street firms. The terminal, first called the Market Master terminal, was released to market in December 1982.\n\nIn 1986, IMS renamed itself Bloomberg L.P. Over the years, ancillary products including , , Bloomberg Message, and Bloomberg Tradebook were launched. Bloomberg, L.P. had revenues of approximately $10&nbsp;billion in 2018. As of 2019, the company has more than 325,000 terminal subscribers worldwide and employs 20,000 people in dozens of locations.\n\nThe culture of the company in the 1980s and 1990s has been compared to a fraternity, with employees bragging in the company's office about their sexual exploits. The company was  for , including one incident in which a victim claimed to have been raped. To celebrate Bloomberg's 48th birthday, colleagues published a pamphlet entitled ''''. Among various sayings that were attributed to him, several have subsequently been criticized as sexist or misogynistic.\n\nWhen he left the position of CEO to pursue a political career as the mayor of New York City, Bloomberg was replaced by Lex Fenwick and later by , after his initial service as deputy mayor under Bloomberg. After completing his final term as the mayor of New York City, Bloomberg spent his first eight months out of office as a full-time philanthropist. In fall 2014, he announced that he would return to Bloomberg L.P. as CEO at the end of 2014, succeeding Doctoroff, who had led the company since February 2008. Bloomberg resigned as CEO of Bloomberg L.P. to run for president in 2019.\n\nIn January 2024,  reached a $1.725 billion deal to sell the  to a group led by . The group included Bloomberg, former Baltimore Mayor , , New York investment manager Michael Arougheti and NBA legend .\n\n\nIn March 2009, '''' reported Bloomberg's wealth at $16&nbsp;billion, a gain of $4.5&nbsp;billion over the previous year, the world's biggest increase in wealth from 2008 to 2009. Bloomberg moved from 142nd to 17th in the ''Forbes'' list of the world's billionaires in only two years. In the 2019 ''Forbes'' list of the world's billionaires, he was ; his net worth was estimated at $55.5&nbsp;billion. Currently, Bloomberg's net worth is estimated at $106&nbsp;billion, ranking him 12th on ''Forbes''' list of billionaires.\n\n\n\n\n in 2003]]\n\nBloomberg assumed office as the 108th  on January 1, 2002. He won re-election in 2005 and again in 2009. As mayor, he initially struggled with approval ratings as low as 24 percent; however, he subsequently developed and maintained high approval ratings. Bloomberg joined , , and  as re-elected Republican mayors in the mostly Democratic city.\n\nBloomberg stated that he wanted  reform to be the legacy of his first term and addressing poverty to be the legacy of his second.\n\n in 2012]]\n\nBloomberg chose to apply a statistical, metrics-based management approach to city government, and granted departmental commissioners' broad autonomy in their decision-making. Breaking with 190 years of tradition, he implemented what ''New York Times'' political reporter  called a \"bullpen\"  plan, similar to a  trading floor, in which dozens of aides and managerial staff are seated together in a large chamber. The design is intended to promote accountability and accessibility.\n\nBloomberg accepted a  in lieu of the mayoral salary.\n\n, ,  and  in 2014]]\n\nAs mayor, Bloomberg turned the city's $6&nbsp;billion budget deficit into a $3&nbsp;billion surplus, largely by raising property taxes. Bloomberg increased city funding for the new development of affordable housing through a plan that created and preserved an estimated 160,000 affordable homes in the city. In 2003, he implemented a successful  in all indoor workplaces, including bars and restaurants, and many other cities and states followed suit. On December 5, 2006, New York City became the first city in the United States to  from all restaurants. This went into effect in July 2008 and has since been adopted in many other cities and countries. Bloomberg created , required chain restaurants to post , and  much of . In 2011, Bloomberg launched the NYC Young Men's Initiative, a $127&nbsp;million initiative to support programs and policies designed to address disparities between young Black and Latino men and their peers, and personally donated $30&nbsp;million to the project. In 2010, Bloomberg supported the then-controversial .\n\nUnder the Bloomberg Administration, the  greatly expanded its  program, with a sixfold increase in documented stops. The policy was challenged in , which ruled that the city's implementation of the policy violated citizens' rights under the  and encouraged racial profiling. Bloomberg's administration appealed the ruling; however, his successor, Mayor Bill de Blasio, dropped the appeal and allowed the ruling to take effect. After the , with assistance from the Central Intelligence Agency, Bloomberg's administration oversaw a controversial program that surveilled Muslim communities on the basis of their religion, ethnicity, and language. The program was discontinued in 2014.\n\nIn a January 2014  poll, 64 percent of voters called Bloomberg's 12 years as mayor \"mainly a success\".\n\n\n\n\n\nIn 2001, New York's Republican mayor , was ineligible for re-election due to the city's limit of two consecutive terms. Bloomberg, who had been a lifelong member of the , decided to run for mayor on the  ticket. Voting in the primary began on the morning of September 11, 2001. The primary was postponed later that day, due to the . In the rescheduled primary, Bloomberg defeated , a former Democratic , to become the Republican nominee. After a , the Democratic nomination went to  .\n\nBloomberg received Giuliani's endorsement to succeed him in the 2001 election. He also had a huge campaign spending advantage. Although New York City's  law restricts the total amount of contributions that a candidate can accept, Bloomberg chose not to use public funds and therefore his campaign was not subject to these restrictions. He spent $73&nbsp;million of his own money on his campaign, outspending Green by a ratio of five to one.\n\nIn the wake of the September 11 attacks, Bloomberg's administration made a successful bid to host the . The , among them New Yorkers against  and the Bush administration's pursuit of the .\n\n\n\n\nBloomberg was re-elected mayor in November 2005 by a margin of 20 percent, the widest margin ever for a Republican mayor of New York City. He spent almost $78&nbsp;million on his campaign, exceeding the record of $74&nbsp;million he spent on the previous election. In late 2004 or early 2005, Bloomberg gave the  $250,000 to fund a phone bank seeking to recruit volunteers for his re-election campaign.\n\nFormer Bronx Borough President  won the Democratic nomination to oppose Bloomberg in the general election.  sought to run against Bloomberg in the Republican Party's primary election. The Bloomberg campaign successfully challenged the signatures Ognibene submitted to the Board of Elections to prevent Ognibene from appearing on ballots for the Republican primary. Instead, Ognibene ran on only the  ticket. Ognibene accused Bloomberg of betraying Republican Party ideals, a feeling echoed by others.\n\nBloomberg opposed the confirmation of  as . Bloomberg is a staunch supporter of  and did not believe that Roberts was committed to maintaining ''''. In addition to Republican support, Bloomberg obtained the endorsements of several prominent Democrats: former Democratic mayor ; former Democratic governor ; former Democratic City Council Speaker , and his son, Councilman ; former Democratic Congressman  (who had previously endorsed Bloomberg in 2001), and   .\n\n\n\n\n\nOn October 2, 2008, Bloomberg announced he would seek to extend the  and run for a third mayoral term in 2009. Bloomberg said, \"Handling this financial crisis while strengthening essential services&nbsp;... is a challenge I want to take on,\" Bloomberg said at a news conference. \"So should the City Council vote to amend term limits, I plan to ask New Yorkers to look at my record of independent leadership and then decide if I have earned another term.\"\n\n, who campaigned for New York City's term limits in 1993 and spent over 4&nbsp;million dollars of his own money to limit the maximum years a mayor could serve to eight years, sided with Bloomberg and agreed to stay out of future legality issues. In exchange, he was promised a seat on an influential city board by Bloomberg.\n\nSome people and organizations objected and  filed a complaint with the City Conflict of Interest Board. On October 23, 2008, the city council voted 29–22 in favor of extending the term limit to three consecutive four-year terms.Aye' And Mighty: Bloomberg's Wish Is Granted |website= |date=October 23, 2008 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081025085132/http://wcbstv.com/breakingnewsalerts/bloomberg.third.term.2.847239.html |first=Marcia |last=Kramer |archive-date=October 25, 2008}} After two days of public hearings, Bloomberg signed the bill into law on November 3.\n\nBloomberg's bid for a third term generated some controversy. Civil libertarians such as former  Director  and New York Civil Rights Coalition Executive Director Michael Meyers joined with local politicians to protest the process as undermining the democratic process.\n\nBloomberg's opponent was  and  nominee , who had been  for the past eight years and before that, president of the . Bloomberg defeated Thompson by a vote of 51 percent to 46 percent. Bloomberg spent $109.2&nbsp;million on his 2009 campaign, outspending Thompson by a margin of more than 11 to one.\n\nAfter the release of Independence Party campaign filings in January 2010, it was reported that Bloomberg had made two $600,000 contributions from his personal account to the Independence Party on October 30 and November 2, 2009. The Independence Party then paid $750,000 of that money to Republican Party political operative John Haggerty Jr.\n\nThis prompted an investigation beginning in February 2010 by the office of   into possible improprieties. The Independence Party later questioned how Haggerty spent the money, which was to go to poll-watchers. Former New York State Senator  contended that because the Bloomberg donations were made to an Independence Party housekeeping account rather than to an account meant for current campaigns, this was a violation of campaign finance laws. Haggerty also spent money from a separate $200,000 donation from Bloomberg on office space.\n\n\n\n\nOn September 13, 2013, Bloomberg announced that he would not endorse any of the candidates to succeed him. On his radio show, he stated, \"I don't want to do anything that complicates it for the next mayor. And that's one of the reasons I've decided I'm just not going to make an endorsement in the race.\" He added, \"I want to make sure that person is ready to succeed, to take what we've done and build on that.\"\n\n in 2015]]\nBloomberg praised '''' for its endorsement of  and  as their favorite candidates in the Democratic and Republican primaries, respectively. Quinn came in third in the Democratic primary and Lhota won the Republican primary. Bloomberg criticized Democratic mayoral candidate 's campaign methods, which he initially called \"racist\"; Bloomberg later downplayed and partially retracted those remarks.\n\nOn January 1, 2014, de Blasio became New York City's new mayor, succeeding Bloomberg.\n\n\n\n\nBloomberg was frequently mentioned as a possible  candidate for the presidential elections in  and , as well as for governor of New York  or vice-president in 2008. He eventually declined to seek all of these offices.\n\nIn the immediate aftermath of  in November 2012, Bloomberg penned an op-ed officially endorsing  for president, citing Obama's policies on climate change.\n\n\n]]\n\nOn January 23, 2016, it was reported that Bloomberg was again considering a presidential run, as an independent candidate in the , if Bernie Sanders got the Democratic party nomination. This was the first time he had officially confirmed he was considering a run. Bloomberg supporters believed that Bloomberg could run as a centrist and capture many voters who were dissatisfied with the likely Democratic and Republican nominees. However, on March 7, Bloomberg announced he would not be running for president.\n\nIn July 2016, Bloomberg delivered a speech at the  in which he called Hillary Clinton \"the right choice\". Bloomberg warned of the dangers a Donald Trump presidency would pose. He said Trump \"wants you to believe that we can solve our biggest problems by deporting Mexicans and shutting out Muslims. He wants you to believe that erecting trade barriers will bring back good jobs. He's wrong on both counts.\" Bloomberg also said Trump's economic plans \"would make it harder for small businesses to compete\" and would \"erode our influence in the world\". Trump responded to the speech by condemning Bloomberg in a series of tweets.\n\n\nIn June 2018, Bloomberg pledged $80&nbsp;million to support Democratic congressional candidates in the , with the goal of flipping control of the Republican-controlled House to Democrats. In a statement, Bloomberg said that Republican House leadership were \"absolutely feckless\" and had failed to govern responsibly. Bloomberg advisor  was chosen to lead the effort, which was to target mainly suburban districts. By early October, Bloomberg had committed more than $100&nbsp;million to returning the House and Senate to Democratic power, fueling speculation about a presidential run in . On October 10, 2018, Bloomberg announced that he had returned to the Democratic party.\n\n\n\n logo]]\n, in February 2020]]\nOn March 5, 2019, Bloomberg had announced that he would not run for president in 2020. Instead, he encouraged the Democratic Party to \"nominate a Democrat who will be in the strongest position to defeat .\" However, due to his dissatisfaction with the Democratic field, Bloomberg reconsidered. He officially launched his campaign for the 2020 Democratic nomination on November 24, 2019.\n\nBloomberg self-funded his campaign from his personal fortune and did not accept campaign contributions.\n\nBloomberg's campaign suffered from his lackluster performance in two televised debates.Patricia Mazzei, Rebecca R. Ruiz & Jeremy W. Peters, , ''New York Times'' (March 4, 2020). When Bloomberg participated in his first presidential debate,  challenged him to release women from non-disclosure agreements relating to their  Two days later, Bloomberg announced that there were three women who had made complaints concerning him, and added that he would release any of the three if they request him to do so. Warren continued her attack in the second debate the next week. Others criticized Bloomberg for his wealth and campaign spending, as well as his former affiliation with the Republican Party.\n\nAs a late entrant to the race, Bloomberg skipped the first four state primaries and caucuses. He spent $676&nbsp;million of his personal fortune on the primary campaign, breaking a record for the most money ever spent on a presidential primary campaign. His campaign blanketed the country with campaign advertisements on broadcast and cable television, the Internet, and radio, as well as . Bloomberg also spent heavily on campaign operations that grew to 200 field offices and more than 2,400 paid campaign staffers. His support in  never exceeded 15 percent but stagnated or dropped before , while former vice president  had become the frontrunner after receiving the support of major candidates  and  shortly before Super Tuesday. Bloomberg suspended his campaign on March 4, 2020, after a disappointing Super Tuesday in which he , and subsequently endorsed Biden. Bloomberg donated $18 million to the Democratic National Committee and publicly planned a \"massive spending blitz\" to support Biden's campaign.\n\n\n\nWhen a '''' correspondent remarked on March 1 that Bloomberg had spent twice what President Trump had raised, he was asked how much he would spend. Bloomberg replied, \"I'm making an investment in this country. My investment is I'm going to remove President Trump from 1600 Pennsylvania Avenue or at least try as hard as I can.\"\n\nSpeaking on the final night of the 2020 Democratic National Convention, Bloomberg took aim at Trump's handling of the COVID-19 pandemic and the American economy: \"Would you rehire or work for someone who ran your business into the ground? Who always does what's best for him or her, even when it hurts the company, and whose reckless decisions put you in danger, and who spends more time tweeting than working? If the answer is no, why the hell would we ever rehire Donald Trump for another four years?\"\n\n\nIn February 2022, Bloomberg was nominated to chair the , being sworn in on June 22, 2022.\n\n\n\n\n\nBloomberg was a  until 2001, when he switched to the  to run for mayor. He switched to an  in 2007 and registered again as a Democrat in October 2018. In 2004, he endorsed the re-election of  and spoke at the . He endorsed 's re-election in 2012, endorsed  in the , and spoke at the . In 2008, he did not make a presidential election endorsement, but he voted for Obama, according to a 2020 statement by \"Stu Loeser, a Bloomberg [2020] campaign spokesman.\"\n\nAs Mayor of New York, Bloomberg supported government initiatives in public health and welfare.Tami Luhby, , CNN (February 25, 2020). This included  efforts (including an increase in the legal age to purchase tobacco products, a ban on smoking in indoor workplaces, and an increase in the cigarette tax); the elimination of the use of artificial  in restaurants; and bans on all flavored tobacco and e-cigarette products including menthol flavors. Bloomberg also launched an unsuccessful effort to  at restaurants and food service establishments in the city. These initiatives were supported by public health advocates but were criticized by some as \"\" policies.\n\nOver his career, Bloomberg has \"mingled support for progressive causes with more conservative positions on law enforcement, business regulation and .\" Bloomberg supports gun-control measures, abortion rights, same-sex marriage, and a pathway to citizenship for illegal immigrants. He advocates for a  that he has called \"Medicare for all for people that are uncovered\" rather than a universal  system. He is concerned about  and has touted his mayoral efforts to reduce . Bloomberg supported the  and opposed creating a timeline for withdrawing troops. Bloomberg has sometimes embraced the use of  in efforts to deter crime and protect against terrorism.\n\nDuring and after his tenure, he was a staunch supporter of . In November 2019, Bloomberg apologized for supporting it. He advocates reversing many of the . His own tax plan includes implementing a 5 percent surtax on incomes above $5&nbsp;million a year and would raise federal revenue by $5&nbsp;trillion over a decade. He opposes a , saying that it would likely be found unconstitutional. He has also proposed more stringent financial regulations that include tougher oversight for big banks, a , and stronger consumer protections. He supported decreasing estate-tax threshold to collect more estate taxes and close tax avoidance schemes. According to  investigation he set up multiple  thus shielding parts of his fortune for his heirs.\n\nBloomberg stated that running as a Democratnot an independentwas the only path he saw to defeating , saying: \"In 2020, the great likelihood is that an independent would just split the anti-Trump vote and end up re-electing the President. That's a risk I refused to run in 2016 and we can't afford to run it now.\"\n\nIn the , Bloomberg invested $115 million in  in key states like , , and , contributed millions to various Democrats in local races, and raised over $16 million to clear court fines for nearly 32,000 Black and Hispanic Florida voters with felony convictions. Bloomberg contributed $19&nbsp;million to a pro-Biden super PAC in support of  in 2024. In October 2024, Bloomberg contributed $50 million to support  .\n\n\n\n\n\nIn August 2010, Bloomberg signed , whereby the wealthy pledge to give away at least half of their wealth. In his lifetime, he has given away $17.4 billion overall including $3 billion in 2023, when he was America's highest giving philanthropist, according to Chronicle of Philanthropy. He has been in the top ten on the publication's list of America's biggest donors since 2004.\n\nHis  foundation focuses on public health, the arts, government innovation, the environment, and education. Through the foundation, he donated or pledged $767&nbsp;million in 2018, and more than $1 billion in 2019.\n\nIn 2011, recipients included the ; ; ;  and the . According to ''The New York Times'', Bloomberg was an \"anonymous donor\" to the  from 2001 to 2010, with gifts ranging from $5&nbsp;million to $20&nbsp;million each year. The  distributed these contributions to hundreds of New York City organizations ranging from the  to , a non-profit organization that provides support to people and families living with cancer. He continues to support the arts through his foundation.\n\nBloomberg gave $254&nbsp;million in 2009 to almost 1,400 nonprofit organizations, saying, \"I am a big believer in giving it all away and have always said that the best financial planning ends with bouncing the check to the undertaker.\"\n\n\nDuring the 2020  pandemic and its aftermath, Bloomberg through his foundation committed to a wide range of urgent causes including researching treatments and vaccines, leading contact tracing to root out the virus, supporting the World Health Organization, and funding global efforts to fight the spread of the disease and protect vulnerable populations. Action included:\n\n* Cofounding a $75&nbsp;million fund for nonprofits impacted by COVID-19 in New York City\n* Donating $6&nbsp;million to  to serve meals to health care workers in New York City\n* Partnering with Johns Hopkins University to train COVID-19 contact tracers through its school of public health and search for a treatment of the virus.\n* Convening mayors through a partnership with Harvard College to learn and discuss their pandemic response, featuring a bipartisan roster of speakers and attendees.\n* Leading New York's contact tracing effort\n* Launching an information and action sharing network for cities through the \n* Supporting international efforts to combat the spread of COVID-19 and prepare regional leaders through the , the , Vital Strategies and other partners\n\n\nBloomberg is an environmentalist and has advocated policy to fight climate change at least since he became the mayor of New York City. In September 2023, the  called Bloomberg \"perhaps the world's single largest funder of climate activism.\" At the national level, Bloomberg has consistently pushed for transitioning the United States' energy mix from fossil fuels to clean energy. In July 2011, Bloomberg Philanthropies donated $50 million to 's  campaign, allowing the campaign to expand its efforts to shut down s from 15 states to 45 states. In 2015, Bloomberg announced an additional $30 million contribution to the Beyond Coal initiative, matched with another $30&nbsp;million by other donors, to help secure the retirement of half of America's fleet of coal plants by 2017. In July 2017, Europe Beyond Coal was established to phase out use of coal on the continent by 2030. Austria closed its final coal-fired plant in April 2020. In early June 2019, Bloomberg pledged $500 million to reduce climate impacts and shut remaining coal-fired power plants by 2030 via the new Beyond Carbon initiative. In September 2023, Bloomberg committed another $500 million to Beyond Carbon to \"finish the job on coal.\"\n\nBloomberg Philanthropies awarded a $6 million grant to the  in support of strict regulations on  in the 14 states with the heaviest natural gas production.\n\nIn 2013, Bloomberg and Bloomberg Philanthropies launched the Risky Business initiative with former Treasury Secretary  and hedge-fund billionaire . The joint effort worked to convince the business community of the need for more sustainable energy and development policies, by quantifying and publicizing the economic risks the United States faces from the . In January 2015, Bloomberg led Bloomberg Philanthropies in a $48-million partnership with the Heising-Simons family to launch the Clean Energy Initiative. The initiative supports state-based solutions aimed at ensuring America has a clean, reliable, and affordable energy system.\n\nSince 2010, Bloomberg has taken an increasingly global role on environmental issues. From 2010 to 2013, he served as the chairman of the , a network of the world's biggest cities working together to reduce . During his tenure, Bloomberg worked with President Bill Clinton to merge C40 with the , with the goal of amplifying their efforts in the global fight against climate change worldwide. He serves as the president of the board of C40 Cities. In January 2014, Bloomberg began a five-year commitment totaling $53&nbsp;million through Bloomberg Philanthropies to the Vibrant Oceans Initiative. The initiative partners Bloomberg Philanthropies with , , and Encourage Capital to help reform fisheries and increase sustainable populations worldwide. In 2018, Bloomberg joined  in announcing a commitment of $185&nbsp;million towards protecting the oceans.\n\nIn 2014,   appointed Bloomberg as his first Special Envoy for Cities and Climate Change to help the United Nations work with cities to prevent climate change. In September 2014, Bloomberg convened with Ban and global leaders at the UN Climate Summit to announce definite action to fight climate change in 2015. In 2018, Ban's successor  appointed Bloomberg as UN envoy for climate action. He resigned in November 2019, in the run-up to his presidential campaign. On 5 February 2021, however, he was re-appointed by Guterres as his Special Envoy on Climate Ambition and Solutions in the lead-up to the climate conference in  scheduled for November 2021.\n\nIn late 2014, Bloomberg, Ban Ki-moon, and global city networks -Local Governments for Sustainability (ICLEI),  (C40) and  (UCLG), with support from UN-Habitat, launched the , a global coalition of mayors and city officials pledging to reduce local greenhouse gas emissions, enhance , and track their progress transparently. To date, over 250 cities representing more than 300&nbsp;million people worldwide and 4.1 percent of the total global population, have committed to the Compact of Mayors, which was merged with the  in June 2016.\n\nIn 2015, Bloomberg and   created the Climate Summit for Local Leaders. which convened assembled hundreds of city leaders from around the world at  to discuss fighting climate change. The Summit concluded with the presentation of the Paris Declaration, a pledge by leaders from assembled global cities to cut carbon emissions by 3.7 gigatons annually by 2030.\n\nDuring the  in Paris, ,  and chair of the , announced that Bloomberg would lead a new global task force designed to help industry and financial markets understand the growing .\n\nFollowing President 's announcement that the , Bloomberg outlined a coalition of cities, states, universities and businesses that had come together to honor America's commitment under the agreement through 'America's Pledge'. Bloomberg offered up to $15&nbsp;million to the , the UN body that assists countries with climate change efforts. About a month later, Bloomberg and California Governor  announced that the America's Pledge coalition would work to \"quantify the actions taken by U.S. states, cities and business to drive down greenhouse gas emissions consistent with the goals of the Paris Agreement.\" In announcing the initiative, Bloomberg said \"the American government may have pulled out of the Paris agreement, but American society remains committed to it.\" Two s,  and the , will work with America's Pledge to analyze the work cities, states and businesses do to meet the U.S. commitment to the Paris agreement.\n\nIn May 2019, Bloomberg announced a 2020 Midwestern Collegiate Climate Summit in  with the aim to bring together leaders from Midwestern universities, local government and the private sector to reduce climate impacts in the region.\n\nExpanding on the work of Beyond Coal and Beyond Carbon, Bloomberg launched Beyond Petrochemicals in September 2022. The campaign takes aim at the rapid expansion of U.S. petrochemicals and . The $85 million campaign aims to block the construction of 120 proposed petrochemical projects in Louisiana, Texas and the .\n\nBloomberg serves as global adviser to the winners of the . His foundation Bloomberg Philanthropies is a founding partner of the Prize which awards 1,000,000 to each of five winners each year whose work will achieve ambitious climate and sustainability goals by 2030. The 2023 finalists were announced at the Earthshot Prize Innovation Summit in September 2023 in New York, and the five winners were announced in November 2023 in Singapore.\n\n\nAs of 2024, Bloomberg has given more than $4.55&nbsp;billion to , his alma mater, making him \"the most generous living donor to any education institution in the United States.\" His first contribution, in 1965, had been $5. He made his first $1&nbsp;million commitment to JHU in 1984, and subsequently became the first individual to exceed $1&nbsp;billion in lifetime donations to a single U.S. institution of higher education.\n\nBloomberg's contributions to Johns Hopkins \"fueled major improvements in the university's reputation and rankings, its competitiveness for faculty and students, and the appearance of its campus,\" and included construction of a  (the , named after Bloomberg's mother); a  building, a school of public health (the ), libraries, and biomedical research facilities, including the Institute for Cell Engineering, a  institute within the , and the Malaria Research Institute within the School of Public Health. In 2013, Bloomberg committed $350&nbsp;million to Johns Hopkins, five-sevenths of which were allocated to the . In 2016, Bloomberg Philanthropies contributed $300&nbsp;million to establish the Bloomberg American Health Initiative. Bloomberg also funded the launch of the  within the Johns Hopkins School of Medicine in East Baltimore, with a $50&nbsp;million gift; an additional $50&nbsp;million was given by philanthropist , and $25&nbsp;million by other donors. It will support cancer therapy research, technology and infrastructure development, and private sector partnerships. In 2016, Bloomberg joined   for the institute's formal launch, embracing Biden's \"\" initiative, which seeks to find a cure for cancer through national coordination of government and private sector resources. In 2018, Bloomberg contributed a further gift of $1.8&nbsp;billion to Johns Hopkins, allowing the university to practice  and meet the full financial need of admitted students.\n\nIn 2024, Bloomberg announced a $1 billion gift to Johns Hopkins University to make tuition free for all medical school students whose families make under $300,000 a year, beginning in the fall of 2024. The donation also increases financial aid for students enrolled in nursing, public health and other graduate programs.\n\n\nIn 1996, Bloomberg endowed the William Henry Bloomberg Professorship at  with a $3&nbsp;million gift in honor of his father, who died in 1963, saying, \"throughout his life, he recognized the importance of reaching out to the nonprofit sector to help better the welfare of the entire community.\"\n\nIn 2015, Bloomberg donated $100&nbsp;million to , the applied sciences graduate school of  on the school's Roosevelt Island campus. Through Bloomberg Philanthropies, Bloomberg established the American Talent Initiative in 2016 which is committed to increasing the number of lower-income high-achieving students attending elite colleges. Bloomberg Philanthropies also supports CollegePoint which has provided advising to lower- and moderate-income high school students since 2014. In 2016, the  announced a $50&nbsp;million gift from Bloomberg. Bloomberg credited the museum with sparking his intellectual curiosity as a patron and student during his youth in . It is the largest donation in the museum's 186-year history.\n\nBloomberg donated $100 million to America's four Historically Black Medical Schools in 2020 as part of Bloomberg Philanthropies' Greenwood Initiative, which tackles the racial wealth gap and addresses decades of underinvestment in Black communities. The gift to , ,  and  provided grants to reduce debt for students, meaning many medical students enrolled at the time and for the four years to follow would graduate free of debt.\n\nIn 2024, Bloomberg again made a donation to the nation's Historically Black Medical Schools  this time gifting $600 million to the four schools to support their endowments. These endowments are 'significantly underfunded' due to entrenched discrimination. For three of the schools, the gift will more than double the size of their endowments. The donation also includes $5 million to help  to establish a new medical school. Despite underfunding, the four Historically Black Medical Schools graduate nearly half of the nation's Black doctors.\n\n\nIn July 2011, Bloomberg launched a $24&nbsp;million initiative to fund \"Innovation Delivery Teams\" in five cities. The teams are one of Bloomberg Philanthropies' key goals: advancing government innovation. In December 2011, Bloomberg Philanthropies launched a partnership with online ticket search engine  to connect artists with new audiences. Called the Discover New York Arts Project, the project includes organizations HERE, , and the .\n\nIn 2013, Bloomberg announced the Mayors Challenge competition to drive innovation in American cities. The program was later expanded to competitions in Latin America and Europe.\n\nIn 2016, Bloomberg gave Harvard $32&nbsp;million to create the Bloomberg Harvard City Leadership Initiative within 's ; the initiative provides training to mayors and their aides on innovative municipal leadership and challenges facing cities. Since its founding, 275 mayors and more than 400 top city aides have gone through the program, prompting Time Magazine to call Bloomberg 'the nation's mayoral tutor.'\n\nIn March 2021, Bloomberg gave Harvard $150&nbsp;million to create the ''Bloomberg Center for Cities'' to support mayors.\n\n\n\n\nBloomberg has been a longtime donor to global  efforts. Bloomberg has donated close to $1&nbsp;billion to the  (WHO) to promote anti-smoking efforts, including $125&nbsp;million in 2006, $250&nbsp;million in 2008, and $360&nbsp;million, making Bloomberg Philanthropies the 's biggest funder of tobacco-control initiatives. In 2013, it was reported that Bloomberg had donated $109.24&nbsp;million in 556 grants and 61 countries to campaigns against tobacco. Bloomberg's contributions are aimed at \"getting countries to monitor tobacco use, introduce strong tobacco-control laws, and create mass media campaigns to educate the public about the .\" Bloomberg Philanthropies and the  jointly launched a $160 million, three-year campaign against youth  (vaping).\n\nBloomberg is the co-founder of  (formerly Mayors Against Illegal Guns), a  advocacy group.\n\nIn 2016, the  appointed Bloomberg as its Global Ambassador for Noncommunicable Diseases.\n\n\nThrough Bloomberg Philanthropies, Bloomberg supported the Fresh Air Fund's creation of 'Open Spaces in the City' in summer 2020 to provide socially-distant areas for kids to play during the COVID-19 pandemic, as well as jobs for local teens. He donated $3 million to the construction of a new public library in his hometown of Medford and $75&nbsp;million for , a new arts and  in , Manhattan.\n\nIn September 2023, the  opened with $130 million of support from Bloomberg, who serves as its chair. The $500 million art center is the final major piece of the redevelopment of the site where the  once stood.\n\nFollowing the  attack on Israel in October 2023, Bloomberg committed to matching donations to the Israeli Red Cross, known as . By October 19, 2023, Bloomberg had matched $25 million in donations to the ambulance and Medivac service.\n\nBloomberg also endowed his hometown synagogue, Temple Shalom, which was renamed for his parents as the William and Charlotte Bloomberg Jewish Community Center of Medford.\n\nBloomberg hosted the  in 2017, during the annual meeting of the ; the gathering featured international CEOs, heads of state, and other prominent speakers.\n\nIn 2009 Bloomberg met with other billionaires such as Warren Buffett, Bill Gates, Ted Turner and Oprah Winfrey to address issues ranging from the ,  and concerns over . Although no formal organization was established, the effort was understood to be designed to help bring various philanthropic projects of the mega-donors into a more unified effort to address various problems on our planet.\n\n\n\n\n\n\nIn 1975, Bloomberg married Susan Elizabeth Barbara Brown, a British national from , United Kingdom. They have two daughters: Emma Beth (born c. 1979) and  (born 1983), who were featured on '''', a 2003 documentary film about the children of the extremely wealthy. Bloomberg divorced Brown in 1993, but he has said she remains his \"best friend.\" Since 2000, Bloomberg has lived with former  . Emma Bloomberg was married to Chris Frissora, son of , and they had a daughter with a hybrid surname Frissberg.\n\nBloomberg's younger sister, Marjorie Tiven, has been commissioner of the New York City Commission for the United Nations, Consular Corps and Protocol, since February 2002.\n\n\nDuring the ,   son of a co-founder of the company, , and a member of its board, met with Bloomberg to \"seek his help and guidance on the current issues we are facing\". Purdue's head of communications, Josephine Martin, added \"Any positive news or ability to get our side out is through Bloomberg. We have given them exclusives and they have treated us very well.\" Bloomberg also advised Mortimer Sackler to consult  to help manage communications.\n\n\nAlthough he attended , had a , and his family kept a  kitchen, Bloomberg today lives a mostly secular religious life, attending synagogue mainly during the  and a  with his sister, Marjorie Tiven. Neither of his daughters had bat mitzvahs, nor does either daughter follow a religiously Jewish lifestyle, such as abiding kosher dietary restrictions or keeping the Jewish sabbath.\n\n\nThroughout his business career, Bloomberg has made numerous statements which have been considered by some to be insulting, derogatory, sexist or misogynistic. When working on Wall Street in the 1960s and 1970s, Bloomberg claimed in his 1997 autobiography, he had \"a girlfriend in every city\". On various occasions, Bloomberg allegedly commented \"I'd do her\", regarding certain women, some of whom were coworkers or employees. Bloomberg later said that by \"do\", he meant that he would have a personal relationship with the woman. Further, the  acquired a booklet of Bloomberg quotes, which included: \"If women wanted to be appreciated for their brains, they'd go to the library instead of to Bloomingdale's.\" Bloomberg's staff told the ''New York Times'' that he now regrets having made \"disrespectful\" remarks concerning women.\n\nDuring his term as mayor, he lived at his own home on the  of  instead of , the official mayoral residence. In 2013, he owned 13 properties in various countries around the world, including a $20&nbsp;million  mansion in . In 2015, he acquired , a historical property in , , which once belonged to writer . Bloomberg and his daughters own houses in  and stay there frequently.\n\nBloomberg stated that during his mayoralty, he rode the  on a daily basis, particularly in the commute from his 79th Street home to his office at . An August 2007 story in '''' stated that he was often seen chauffeured by two -owned SUVs to an express train station to avoid having to change from the local to the express trains on the . He supported the construction of the  and the ; in December 2013, Bloomberg took a ceremonial ride on a train to the new  station to celebrate a part of his legacy as mayor.\n\nDuring his tenure as mayor, Bloomberg made cameos playing himself in the films '''' and '''', as well as in episodes of '''', '''', '''', and two episodes of ''''.\n\nBloomberg is a private pilot. He owns six airplanes: three s, a , a , and a . Bloomberg also owns two helicopters: an  and an  and as of 2012 was near the top of the waiting list for an  tiltrotor aircraft. In his youth he was a licensed , was proficient in , and built s.\n\nBloomberg's fortune is managed by , an investment firm that serves as his .\n\n\nIn 2024, President  awarded Bloomberg the , the Nation's highest civilian honor.\n\nBloomberg has received s from  (2007),  (2007),  (2007), the  (2008),  (2009),  (2014),  (2014), the  (2016),  (2017)  and  (2019). Bloomberg was the speaker for 's 2011 .\n\nOn May 27, 2010, Bloomberg delivered the commencement speech at his alma mater, . In addition, he was invited to and delivered guest remarks for the Johns Hopkins Class of 2020. Other notable guest speakers during the virtual ceremony included Reddit co-founder and Commencement speaker ; , director of the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases and a leading member of the White House Coronavirus Task Force; and senior class president Pavan Patel\n\nBloomberg has received the 's Award for Distinguished Leadership in Global Capital Markets (2003); Golden Plate Award of the  presented by  (2004); 's Barnard Medal of Distinction (2008); the  ' Healthy Communities Leadership Award (2009); and the 's U.S. Senator John Heinz Award for Greatest Public Service by an Elected or Appointed Official (2010). He was the inaugural laureate of the annual  for Jewish values in 2013, and donated the $1&nbsp;million prize money to a global competition, the Genesis Generation Challenge, to identify young adults' big ideas to better the world.\n\nBloomberg was named the 39th most influential person in the world in the 2007 and 2008 . In 2010, '''' ranked him #7 in its \"Vanity Fair 100\" list of influential figures.\n\nIn 2014, Queen  appointed Bloomberg an  for his \"prodigious entrepreneurial and philanthropic endeavors, and the many ways in which they have benefited the United Kingdom and the U.K.-U.S. special relationship.\"\n\n\nBloomberg, with , wrote an autobiography, ''Bloomberg by Bloomberg'', published in 1997 by . A second edition was released in 2019, ahead of Bloomberg's presidential run. Bloomberg and former Sierra Club Executive Director  co-authored '': How Cities, Businesses, and Citizens Can Save the Planet'' (2017), published by ; the book appeared on the . Bloomberg has written a number of s in ''The New York Times'' about various issues, including an op-ed supporting state and local efforts to fight  (2017), an op-ed about his donation of $1.8&nbsp;billion in financial aid for college students and support for  policies (2018); an op-ed supporting a ban on flavored s (2019); and an op-ed supporting policies to reduce  (2020).\n\n\n\n* \n* \n* \n* \n* \n* , 2000s–2010s\n\n\n\n\n\n*  Uses anthropology and geography to examine the mayor's corporate-style governance, with particular attention to the Hudson Yards plan, which aims to transform the far West Side into a high-end district.\n* Brash, Julian. \"The ghost in the machine: the neoliberal urban visions of Michael Bloomberg.\" ''Journal of Cultural Geography'' 29.2 (2012): 135–153.\n* \n* \n* \n* McNickle, Chris.     "pages": }\n'''Charles Malcolm Wilson''' (February 26, 1914 – March 13, 2000) was an American politician who served as the 50th  from December 18, 1973, to December 31, 1974. He was a member of the  from 1939 to 1958. He also served in the  during World War II. In , he was elected the  on the gubernatorial ticket with , and when they won he served as lieutenant governor until succeeding to the governorship after Rockefeller resigned. Wilson lost the  to .\n\nIn 1994, the  was renamed in Wilson's honor. There is also a park in  named for him.\n\n\nWilson was born in New York City, one of four children born to patent attorney Charles H. Wilson and Agnes (Egan) Wilson. The Wilsons were a Roman Catholic family of  and  extraction. Charles H. Wilson, was an unsuccessful Republican candidate for the  in 1912. Agnes Wilson was a Republican activist and local party leader. The family moved to , when Wilson was eight, and Wilson continued to reside there after he began his career.\n\n\nWilson attended Manhattan's St. Thomas Academy and the Elizabeth Seton Academy in . He then attended , from which he graduated in 1929 at age 15. Wilson earned a  degree from  in 1933 at age 19 and a  from  in 1936 at age 22. He was admitted to the bar and joined the White Plains firm that eventually became known as Kent, Hazzard, Jaeger, Greer, Wilson, and Fay. Wilson practiced law at this firm for his entire career, and became a partner in 1946.\n\n\nAt age 24, just two years after graduating from Fordham Law, Wilson was elected to the  where he represented the 5th district of  from 1939 to 1945, and after re-districting the 1st district from 1945 to 1959. He sat in the , , , , , , , ,  and s. During his tenure as a legislator, Wilson sponsored a large number of bills that became law. Among his bills that came into law was the , which prevented candidates from running in a party primary if they were not members of that party.\n\nWilson's political and legal careers were interrupted by the outbreak of . He joined the  as an  in June 1943 and trained at the  Armed Guard School. He served as a gun crew commander on s, including duty in the British Isles and the Mediterranean, and also took part in the  invasion of Normandy. He was promoted to  in December 1944 and transferred to the inactive reserve in October 1945. While he was at war, in 1944 Wilson won reelection to the Assembly ''''.\n\n\n\n\nIn , Wilson decided to support Rockefeller for Governor despite the fact that Rockefeller was new to state politics and had never run for office before. Wilson took pains to introduce Rockefeller to many politically powerful people in the state. They would frequently travel in Wilson's personal car in order to play down the candidate's wealth. Rockefeller was nominated for governor, and Wilson for lieutenant governor.\n\nThe Rockefeller-Wilson ticket defeated the incumbent Democrats  and . Wilson served as lieutenant governor for nearly 15 years, the entirety of Rockefeller's governorship. The Rockefeller-Wilson ticket was reelected in ,  and . Throughout his tenure, he tended to agree with Rockefeller's liberal Republicanism, with the notable exception of abortion, the legalization of which Wilson opposed. Wilson defined himself as \"an economic conservative and a human-rights liberal\".\n\n\nIn December 1973, Rockefeller resigned as governor to run the , and Wilson assumed the governorship.  He completed the remaining year of Rockefeller's term. While governor, Wilson worked to improve passenger rail service in the state and under his leadership, New York City-Albany-Montréal and New York City-Buffalo-Detroit service were revived.  Concerned that city governments, especially New York City, were financing their budgets with financial sleight-of-hand, Wilson warned New York State's mayors that there would be a reckoning unless they got their fiscal houses in order.  His warning turned out to be prescient when New York City was found to be nearly bankrupt, and had to resort to federal assistance to regain a sound footing.  But Wilson's concern over government finances turned into a campaign issue for Carey in the 1974 election, when an agency under Wilson's purview, the state's Urban Development Corporation, was discovered to be near bankruptcy.  After taking office, Carey accused Wilson of hiding the severity of the crisis, and complained that the Wilson administration had not been helpful or engaged during the transition between governors.\n\nWilson ran for election to a full term . The period was a difficult one for the nation, both in terms of economic and foreign policy and for the Republican Party, which was weakened by the . Democrats swept to power across the nation in the 1974 general election, with Wilson losing the governorship to , who won with 57% of the vote. to Wilson's 42%\n\n\nAfter losing the election, Wilson returned to his legal practice and served as Chairman of the Board and CEO of the  from 1977 until 1986.\n\nWilson's wife, Katherine, (née McCloskey) died in 1980. In 1991 Wilson's health deteriorated and he retired to .\n\nWilson died in New Rochelle on March 13, 2000. His memorial service was held at Holy Family Church in New Rochelle. He was buried at  in .\n\n\n\n\nWilson had two daughters, Katharine, an attorney, and Anne, and six grandsons. Wilson was a Catholic and attended the St. Denis Catholic Church in Yonkers, New York.\n\n\n\n\n\n*Wolfgang Saxon, ''Former Gov. Malcolm Wilson, 86, Is Dead'', , March 14, 2000, at C31, ''''\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
          }
        ]

    "pages": }\n\n'''Karl A. Brabenec''' (born July 12, 1979) is the man from the 98th District. A Republican, he has served in the Assembly since 2014, when he won a special election. The 98th District contains portions of  and  Counties in the . In January 2023, Brabenec ascended to the role of Assembly  after previously serving as the Deputy Minority Whip since 2019.\n\n\n\nBrabenec was born in  and lived in  before moving with his family to  when he was 8 years old. He went to , and graduated from  in 2000. In 2005, he received his Masters of Public Administration from . His father, Rainer K. Brabenec, was a police officer with the ; Brabenec's mother, Emilie (Popule) Brabenec, was a police dispatcher, also with the NYPD. Both of Brabenec's parents are  refugees from the former  who fled from Soviet communist oppression in the late 1940s.\n\nAt age 18, while attending , Brabenec was appointed as events coordinator for the City of . He was later appointed as executive director of the  Planning Committee.\n\nBrabenec served as a staff assistant to Orange County Executive  in the early 2000s.\n\nIn early 2007, Brabenec was appointed by the Deerpark Town Board to serve as a member of the Zoning Board of Appeals. Later that year in November, he was elected to serve as a Deerpark Town councilman.\n\nIn 2009, with the town facing fiscal difficulties brought on by previous administrations, Brabenec announced he would run for town supervisor and recruited a team of individuals with legal and business expertise to run for town board positions. All of those candidates, including Brabenec, were elected that November.\n\nFrom 2010 to 2014, Brabenec served as town supervisor for the . He became an assistant professor at  in 2010.\n\nBrabenec resides in , and has two children (Karl and Kimberlee) with his ex-wife, Jessica Ebbecke, to whom he was married from 2005 to 2009.\n\n\n\nBrabenec was chosen in a special election held November 2014 to fill the remaining term of Assemblywoman , who had resigned to become  Clerk. Brabenec was concurrently elected to serve a full two-year term starting January 2015. He won re-election to a second term in 2016 with 59% of the vote, to a third term in 2018 with 63% of the vote, ran unopposed for a fourth term in 2020, and to a fifth term in 2022 with 64% of the vote.\n\nBrabenec currently serves as the '''ranking minority member of the Labor Committee''', and is a member of the committees on '''Ways and Means, Rules and Election Law.'''\n\nOn January 1, 2019, Brabenec was appointed '''assistant minority ''', a leadership position within the Assembly Republican Minority Conference, by then-Minority Leader .\n\nOn January 1, 2021, Brabenec was appointed '''deputy minority whip''', a leadership position within the Assembly Republican Minority Conference, by Minority Leader .\n\nOn January 1, 2023, Brabenec was appointed '''minority whip''', a leadership position within the Assembly Republican Minority Conference, by Minority Leader .\n\n\nOn April 27, 2018, Brabenec confirmed he was considering running to replace retiring New York   in the November 2018 election. The race was expected to be one of the most competitive in New York State and could easily determine whether Republicans maintained their slim majority in the . After careful consideration, Brabenec opted to continue his campaign for re-election to the 98th Assembly District for a third term and he won the general election on November 6, 2018.\n\n\nBrabenec's community involvement includes being a former member of the board of directors for the Regional Economic Community Action Program, Inc., an associate member of the Orange County Shields, member of the Greenwood Lake  Lodge #2067, , Town of Deerpark , , the  - Monroe Post #488, and the . He is also an honorary major with the United States Air Force Auxiliary .\n\n\nBrabenec has been involved in the Republican Party since the age of 14.\n\nHe served as '''president of the Orange County (NY) Young Republicans''' from 1997 to 2003 and then again in 2005.\n\nAdditionally, he served as '''1st vice chairman of the New York State Young Republicans''' and '''Northeast Regional (Region 1) vice chairman of the ''' from 1999 to 2001.\n\nBrabenec served as '''vice chairman''' for the '''Town of Wawayanda''' and '''Town of Wallkill Republican Committees''' in the late 1990s and early 2000s.\n\nBrabenec is currently '''chairman of the Town of Deerpark Republican Committee''' and '''1st vice chairman of the Orange County (NY) Republican Committee'''.\n\n\n\n*2010 Rising Star, Orange County Chamber of Commerce\n*2015 Rising Star, New York State Republican Committee \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

Stevenson''' (born September 1966) is a former  member of the  who represented the 79th Assembly District serving the  and  sections of .\n\n\nRaised in , Stevenson followed in the footsteps of his father (former District Leader Edward Stevenson, Jr.) and his grandfather (Assemblyman ) by serving  under the administrations of Bronx borough presidents  and  After several failed attempts to win the 79th Assembly seat against both  and , Stevenson was successful in 2010 when Benjamin decided to step down from after flirting with challenging  for the US Congress.\n\nOn April 4, 2013, federal prosecutors announced that Assemblyman Stevenson had been charged with bribery, conspiracy, and other related charges. Federal Prosecutors said Stevenson took bribes in exchange for drafting, proposing, and agreeing to enact legislation to aid his co-defendants' businesses. Authorities said that a second, unidentified assemblyman who had cooperated in the corruption probe had been charged in a sealed indictment and would resign to avoid prosecution. That member was later identified by the media as Assemblyman .\n\nOn January 13, 2014, Stevenson was convicted of  and , and was thus required to vacate his Assembly seat. On May 21, 2014, he was sentenced to three years in prison.\n\nIn June 2019, Stevensondespite his prior felony convictionlaunched an  into running for .\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
