    "pages": }\n\n'''Donna Janele Hyer-Spencer''' (born October 24, 1964) is an American attorney and former politician. Hyer-Spencer represented New York's 60th Assembly District, which covers parts of  and , from 2007 to 2010. She is a .\n\n\nHyer-Spencer attended high school in , where she ran track and cross country and played .\n\nHyer-Spencer earned a bachelor's degree from . She played basketball in college. She graduated from  with a  and also graduated from  with a  degree in .\n\n\nHyer-Spencer became a litigation attorney for the , specializing in child abuse and neglect. Hyer-Spencer practiced in all five boroughs of the City of New York and the Integrated Domestic Violence Courts. She later joined the ACS legal Counsel unit, where she was responsible for negotiating and resolving class actions and civil lawsuits.\n\nHyer-Spencer served as the Legal Director of My Sister's Place, a -based  which helps victims of domestic violence.\n\n\nHyer-Spencer was first elected to the  in November 2006, narrowly defeating her Republican opponent to win a seat vacated by Republican . In 2010, Hyer-Spencer was defeated by Republican  with 55% of the vote. Following her 2010 defeat, Hyer-Spencer packed up her district office and failed to pass constituent files on to Malliotakis.\n\n\nUpon taking office, Hyer-Spencer vowed to be a voice for victims of violence and abuse. Speaking on the floor of the New York State Assembly in her first term, she advocated for stronger penalties for child sex abusers. During her tenure, several domestic violence-related bills sponsored by Hyer-Spencer became law. Hyer-Spencer sponsored a bill to eliminate fees on Orders of Protection to remove financial roadblocks from victims seeking protections; the bill became law.\n\n\nIn 2008, Hyer-Spencer told voters that she would advocate for education and health care that is \"a right not a privilege\". In 2010, she voted against a budget extender bill that included education spending cuts. She also developed the Hyer Hopes Awards honoring students from selected elementary, intermediate, and high schools throughout Staten Island and Bay Ridge who demonstrated significant improvement in academic achievement, or succeeded by overcoming adverse conditions.\n\n\nHyer-Spencer used her role on the State's Energy Committee to partner with Josh Fox, an Oscar-nominated film director, to educate the public and advocate a ban on natural gas drilling within New York City's watershed.\n\n\nHyer-Spencer was awarded the Verrazano Narrows award from the  for her work promoting economic development, where she drafted and sponsored legislation to create the first ever \"Green Zone\" to attract and encourage environmentally green businesses to Staten Island. She was also recognized for her efforts to motivate, mentor, and inspire Staten Island business women by founding and funding the Women's Leadership Council. Her local awards also include recognition by the Alzheimer's Foundation of Staten Island for her commitment and advocacy on behalf of those combating the brain disorder.\n\n\nHyer-Spencer was chosen by the  to present a public service announcement highlighting her father's battle with cancer and struggle with maintaining . She was recognized for her commitment to the Dress for Success campaign where she sponsored a yearly drive to benefit women re-entering the work force.\n\n\nIn September 2011, Hyer-Spencer was hired by the New York State Education Department as a federal legislative liaison. A former state employee alleged that Sheldon Silver concocted a scheme to fire her from her job so that Hyer-Spencer could be hired.\n\n\nDuring her Assembly tenure, Hyer-Spencer resided in Staten Island with her husband, Douglas Spencer. As of 2009, she had run in three s, with a best time of 4 hours and 20 minutes. In a  interview, she stated she runs 5 days a week, and over 25 hours a week.\n\nWhile in the State Assembly, she was noted for commuting to  via motorcycle, riding a  with the custom license plate JANELE.\n\nIn court papers unsealed during the sentencing phase of the criminal trial of former Assembly Speaker , the federal government stated that it had evidence that Silver had engaged in extramarital affairs with two people; the names were redacted, but other sources identified one of the people as Hyer-Spencer. Hyer-Spencer's attorney denied the allegations.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
          }

    "pages": }\n\n'''Amy Paulin''' (born November 29, 1955) was elected to the  in November 2000. She represents the 88th Assembly District. Paulin chairs the Assembly Committee on Corporations, Authorities and Commissions, and serves on the Committees on Rules, Education, and Health. She previously chaired the Assembly Committee on Energy and before that chaired the Committee on Libraries and Education Technology and the Task Force on People with Disabilities.\n\nIn 2021, Governor Andrew Cuomo signed Assemblywoman Paulin's bill into law.  The law repeals the ban on paid .  She first introduced the bill in 2012.\n\nPaulin resides in Scarsdale with her husband, Ira Schuman. They have three children; Beth, Sarah, and Joseph.\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Matthew J. Titone''' (born January 24, 1961) is an  and lawyer from . A , he served as a member of the  from the 61st District, on  from April 1, 2007 to January 1, 2019. Titone currently serves as a surrogate court judge of Richmond County.\n\n\nTitone was born on Staten Island, the son of , a former judge of the . Titone was raised in the  and  neighborhoods. He went on to attend , while working full-time as a law clerk for the late John S. Zachary.\n\nAfter being admitted to the  in 1992, Titone worked  for the Staten Island AIDS Task Force and Project Hospitality. In 1993, he joined the  law firm of Morgan, Melhuish, Monahan, Arvidson, Abrutyn & Lisowski, where he was a senior trial associate and managed the firm's labor law litigation department. In 1998, he established a private law practice on Staten Island.\n\nTitone garnered national attention when he took on the New York State adoption industry representing a family who adopted a baby boy. The family was never informed by the adoption agency that the child was born with the AIDS virus and resulted in the child being untreated for his illness for eleven years after the adoption was completed. Not only did Titone provide legal support and guidance for the family, he also helped the young man establish the Justin LiGreci HIV/AIDS Foundation for Children and Teens, a not for profit organization that provides educational services to the youth of Staten Island and New York metropolitan area.\n\n\nTitone was the Democratic nominee for the  in 2006, losing the 24th District race to Republican .\n\nFollowing the death of Assemblyman  in January 2007, Titone was selected as the Democratic nominee for the special election held to fill the vacancy.Wrobleski, Tom. \"Dems select Titone as Assembly candidate\". ''''. February 28, 2007.  On the third ballot of Democratic committeemembers, Daniel Lavelle, son of the late Assemblymember, dropped out and Titone was unopposed. Titone was backed by City Councilman , whose support was crucial.Wrobleski, Tom. \"McMahon flexes his muscle and ally Titone gets the nod\". ''''. March 1, 2007. Mimi Cusick, mother of assembly member  and \"mother of the party\", also endorsed Titone's candidacy.\n\nIn the election held on March 27, 2007, Titone received 49% of the vote in a three-way contest to succeed Lavelle, comfortably defeating his Republican and Independence party opponents who won 32% and 19% respectively. \n\n\nIn March 2018, Titone announced that he would vacate his Assembly seat that fall to seek election as Richmond County (Staten Island) Surrogate.  Titone’s announcement was quickly followed by endorsements from , , , and former  Staten Island Borough President .\n\n\nTitone is openly gay and married his partner of 18 years, Giosue Pugliese, in a ceremony at  in September 2011, shortly after same-sex marriage was legalized in New York State. He was one of five  members of the , alongside Assemblymembers , , and , as well as Senator . His Assembly campaigns have won the support of the , which provides financial and strategic assistance. He is the first openly gay man elected to higher office on Staten Island.\n\n\n* '''November 2006 , NYS Senate, 24th SD'''\n:\n\n* '''March 2007 , NYS Assembly, 61st AD'''\n:\n\n* '''November 2008 , NYS Assembly, 61st AD'''\n:\n\n* '''November 2010 , NYS Assembly, 61st AD'''\n:\n\n* '''November 2012 , NYS Assembly, 61st AD'''\n:\n\n* '''November 2014 , NYS Assembly, 61st AD'''\n:\n\n\n* \n* \n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Phara Souffrant Forrest''' (born February 5, 1989) is an American politician, nurse, and tenant activist. A member of the , she is the assembly member for the  of the . After defeating incumbent Assembly Member  in the  primary in June 2020, Forrest won the general election in November of that year. She defeated former District Manager of Community Board 2 Olanike Alabi in the primary to defend her seat in 2022. She was unopposed in the general election.\n\n\nForrest was born in  to  . In 2011, she graduated from  with a  in . Forrest pursued a career in nursing, attending the  and the  to receive an  and  in Registered Nursing, respectively.\n\n\nIn 2017, Forrest joined the  as part of her efforts to fight against the  and displacement of her rent-stabilized apartment building. Then in June 2019 she worked with the Housing Justice for All campaign to fortify tenant protective rights.\n\nIn August 2019, Forrest launched a campaign against incumbent Democrat  in the primary for the heavily  . Souffrant's campaign emphasized support for , investment in , and  . During her campaign, she was endorsed by the  and  . Her campaign was funded entirely by the community, with no outside funding from corporations or businesses.\n\nForrest trailed Mosley by 588 votes on election night June 23, 2020, but  were more significant than usual due to the . Once absentee ballots were counted on July 22, 2020, Forrest led Mosley by over 2,500 votes and was declared the winner. While Mosley remained on the general election ballot under the  line, Forrest won the November race with about 74% of the vote over Mosley's 26%.\n\nIn 2022, Forrest was challenged by former  and Community Board District Manager Olanike \"Ola\" Alabi in the Democratic primary. Alabi was supported by the  and Congressman , among others. Forrest won with 67.24% of the vote while Alabi received 32.43% of the vote. Forrest was uncontested in the general election.\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Kristin Richardson Jordan''' (born January 3, 1987) is an American politician who was the Council member for  from 2022 to 2024. Jordan identifies as a  and . In her 2021 race for the , she campaigned on a platform of \"radical love.\"\n\nDuring her tenure on the New York City Council, she blocked a 1000 unit housing development (half of which were ) in her Harlem district, arguing it would cause . Instead, a large truck depot opened on the lot.\n\n\nJordan was born in , , in 1987 to physicians  and Desmond Jordan. Her parents were both raised in , and the family returned after her father's internship at , where she grew up. She graduated from the  and then from  in 2009, double-majoring in  and literary arts.\n\nJordan is a published poet, a reform activist, and a lesbian.\n\n\nJordan ran for  in  against incumbent Council member , narrowly defeating him in the Democratic primary, virtually assuring her election in the overwhelmingly Democratic district.\n\nJordan was a member of the  (DSA), but was not endorsed by that organization, as it wanted to focus support on other candidates in that year's elections. Jordan had previously been a member of the  prior to joining DSA.\n\nJordan served one term as a New York City Councillor and her term was marked by intense controversy over many of her comments. On May 16, 2023, Jordan announced that she will not run for reelection to the New York City Council.\n\n\nJordan was criticized in the aftermath of a fatal shooting in her district where two   police officers, Jason Rivera and Wilbert Mora were shot and killed in a domestic disturbance call; choosing instead to issue tweets about a local community garden. After criticism by residents, she stated she was told not to tweet about the slain officers. Several days later, she publicly sent condolences to the family of Lashawn McNeil, the alleged killer who was shot and killed by a third officer, alongside the families of the fallen cops. Explaining her motivation, Jordan stated \"I mourn the loss of literally all human life. I don’t see it as contradictory to mourn the life lost of Lashawn as well as the lives of Officer Rivera and Officer Mora.\"\n\nIn February 2022, Jordan received criticism for justifying the  by claiming that the  was a coup led by the United States, European Union, and . She said, \"In 2014, the U.S. helped overthrow Ukraine’s democratically elected leader in an illegal coup, helped install a fascist government and empowered a far right military all with the goal of destabilizing Russia.\"\n\nOn housing, Jordan has said that she \"would rather have lots sit empty than have them filled with further .\" In summer 2022, Jordan helped block a 1000 unit housing development which would have consisted of 50% affordable housing and a civil rights museum. Jordan's rationale was that said \"what they're calling affordable is [not] actually affordable to the community,\" as only 12% of the units were earmarked for individuals earning 30% of the area median income. Jordan said she would only support projects where more than half of all units were earmarked for individuals earning less than 30% of New York median income. After the developer, Bruce Teitelbaum, agreed to make half the units affordable, Jordan asked for 100% affordable units, which was refused. Instead, a large truck depot was built and opened in December 2022.\n\n\n* \n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Patricia A. Ritchie''' (born February 22, 1962) was a  member of the  who represented the  from 2011-2022. Her district encompassed portions of the  abutting .\n\n\nRitchie is a lifelong resident of . The daughter of Rita A. and Kenneth H. Hilborne, she was born and raised in . At 15, she moved with her parents and brother to town of . She graduated from  Central High School in 1980.\n\nShe received an  in social work from  of  in 1985. She briefly attended , then transferred to . She was married in 1982 and continued her education part-time while raising her family and working. Ritchie earned her  in psychology in 1991.\n\n\nRitchie worked for the  from 1986 to 1999. She was then elected as the  Clerk, a position she held from 2000 through 2010. In 2002, she was the unsuccessful Republican candidate for  District 116, losing to Democrat . In November 2010 she defeated Aubertine, this time for his seat in the State Senate. She was handily reelected in 2012, defeating a little known county legislator from Oswego County. She has run unopposed for reelection three times, in 2014, 2016 and 2018.\n\nIn 2011, Ritchie was named Chair of the Senate's Agriculture Committee, where she has been recognized as an outstanding champion of the state's 35,000 farm families and sponsored such initiatives as the Young Farmers Grant and loan forgiveness program. In 2016, Ritchie was named co-chair of the bi-cameral Legislative Commission on Rural Resources, and in 2017, was named Deputy Vice Chair of the important Health Committee, in recognition of her work to improve public health, especially in rural counties, like those she represents.\n\n\nShe and her husband Tom live in Oswegatchie. They have three grown children.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Rachel May''' is an American academic, university administrator, and politician. She is a member of the , representing the  since 2023, and the  from 2019-2022.  The district comprises  and surrounding communities. A , May defeated incumbent  in a 2018 primary election and was first elected to the State Senate in November 2018.\n\n\nMay graduated with an A.B. in Slavic languages and literature from  in 1978 after completing a 99-page long senior thesis titled \"Leisure Time and Its Functions in the Upbringing of New Soviet Men.\" She was awarded a  and graduated from the  with a  in 1981 before graduating from  with a  in  and  in 1990. She taught at  in  and  in  as a  professor of Russian language and literature. In 2001, she and her husband moved to , when her husband became a professor of philosophy at .\n\nAfter May and her family settled in , she graduated from the  with a  in environmental communications. She worked as an administrator at  for fifteen years, first as the Director of the Office of Environment and Society and later as the Coordinator of Sustainability Education until her election to the .\n\nPrior to her election to the Senate, May served on the Onondaga County Board of Zoning Appeals and the Democratic County Committee. She is married with a daughter.\n\n\nFollowing the election of , voters became more aware of the , where state Senators elected as Democrats formed an alliance with Republicans to provide them with the Senate majority in return for better committee assignments and larger office budgets, among other benefits. Among the members of the IDC was , who had represented the district since 2005.\n\nIn the , May ran for  against Valesky in the Democratic primary. The election was the first serious challenge to Valesky since he took office. In a year with strong anti-IDC sentiment, May narrowly defeated Valesky. With the district leaning Democratic, she defeated Republican Janet Burman in the general election.\n\nThe Democrats took the Senate majority in the 2018 general election, and May was named Chair of Committee on Aging.\n\nMay and Senator  received criticism in March 2022 after attending a rally organized by NY Renews, where they posed with a sign that compared  to the . The sign used imagery that depicted a plane flying into the , with \"climate change\" captioned over the plane. May apologized for the incident, though others (including  and ) argued her apology did not go far enough, and called on her to resign.\n\n\n*''The Translator in the Text: On Reading Russian Literature in English'' (1994)\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Robert C. Carroll''' (born October 26, 1986) is an American politician and attorney. He is a  member of the , representing the . The district includes portions of the neighborhoods of , , , , , ,  and , as well as the entirety of .\n\n\nCarroll is a lifelong resident of  and was raised in the Windsor Terrace and Kensington neighborhoods. He attended P.S. 230 and  before graduating from  and receiving his  from . Robert C. Carroll|url=https://nyassembly.gov/mem/Robert-C-Carroll/bio/|access-date=2020-10-07|website=nyassembly.gov}}\n\nHe currently resides in Park Slope with his wife Virginia and their son Teddy.\n\n\nCarroll was a practicing attorney at a firm in  and the Development Director of a non-profit theatrical organization.\n\nCarroll became the youngest president of the Central Brooklyn Independent Democrats. He also served as a member of .\n\n\nRetiring Assemblyman  stepped down in 2016, creating the first vacancy in 32 years.\n\nCarroll easily secured the Democratic nomination. He also won the nomination of the .\n\nCarroll is the Chair of the Subcommittee on Museums and Cultural Institutions as well as the Commission on Government Administration.\n\nCarroll has written and co-sponsored several bills designed to help children with . In 2020, Carroll wrote a bill that would enforce tests in schools that would help to screen young students for dyslexia. The Yale Center for Dyslexia and Creativity praised Carroll and the bill, calling the bill \"groundbreaking news for all who care about [d]yslexia and the future of children who are [d]yslexic.\"\n\nIn 2019 Carroll worked with the Brooklyn Irish  Organization (BILO) and the Irish American Parade Committee to allow for BILO to walk in the Brooklyn  Day Parade. This marked the first time an openly LGBTQ+ organization marched in the parade. Carroll's grandfather co-founded the parade in 1976. On the committee's decision, Carroll stated, \"I am so glad that everyone was able to come together to honor Irish heritage and culture and make this the first fully inclusive St. Patrick's Day parade in Brooklyn.\"\n\nCarroll has spoken in favor of building more affordable housing, but has opposed increases in housing supply in his own district. In 2024, he opposed a plan to build two 13-story residential buildings on the lot of a vacant factory building on Prospect Ave. The proposed buildings would provide 244 units (of which 20-30% were set aside for affordable housing) for more than 1,000 residents. Carroll has argued that more housing would lead to gentrification and displacement.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* official site\n* Twitter\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

She is also a founding chairwoman of Girls Incorporated of NYC, and a former board member of  Pro-Choice New York. She is a trustee emeritus of the .\n\nIn November 2012, Barrett won re-election in the newly created 106th district seat with 54.3% of the vote. She was re-elected with 50.8% of the vote in November 2014, 55.85% of the vote in November 2016, and 55.4% of the vote in November 2018, and she once again won reelection in 2020.\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Robert Gary Ortt II''' (born May 23, 1979) is an American military veteran, treasurer, and politician who is a member of the . Ortt represents the , which covers  and . First elected in 2014, Ortt is a .\n\nPrior to serving in the State Senate, Ortt served as mayor of  from 2010 to 2014 and as city treasurer from 2007 to 2010. On June 19, 2020, Ortt was named Senate Minority Leader.\n\n\nOrtt was born on May 23, 1979. He attended  in Buffalo and graduated from , with a degree in international relations and political science. Ortt and his wife, Meghan, live in North Tonawanda.\n\n\nIn October 2001, Ortt enlisted in the  in response to the . From March 2008 until December 2008, he served in the  where his mission was to serve as a combat mentor/advisor to the  in , the second-largest city in Afghanistan. In recognition of his service, he was awarded the , , , and the . He achieved the rank of .\n\n\nOn April 3, 2007, Ortt was appointed to the post of City Treasurer by the Common Council of .  A few months later on November 6, 2007, he was elected to serve a four-year term, which began on January 1, 2008.  On November 4, 2008, the town voted to eliminate the position of City Clerk and combined the offices of the City Clerk and City Treasurer to form one position of Clerk-Treasurer, making Ortt the first to hold that title.\n\nFrom January 1, 2010 to December 31, 2014, Ortt served as mayor of North Tonawanda, taking over from Lawrence V. Soos, a Democrat.  He was succeeded as mayor by Arthur G. Pappas.\n\n\nIn 2014, when  opted not to run for reelection, Ortt ran for his seat, which Maziarz had held since 1995.  The 62nd District covers all of  and  counties, as well as the towns of  and  in .  Ortt was elected to the , defeating Johnny G. Destino, a  attorney from .\n\nIn the Senate, he was named chairman of the Standing Committee on Mental Health and Developmental Disabilities as well as the co-chair the Senate's Joint Task Force on Heroin and Opioid Addiction.\n\nIn May 2015, Ortt, along with  and , called for , who was serving as Republican majority leader of the State Senate, to step down. Ortt also expressed support for a motion to replace Skelos as majority leader. (On May 4, Skelos had been arrested on federal corruption charges.)\n\nIn July 2016, Ortt and New York Assemblyman  asked , , to objectively investigate the state contracting process. Ortt and Walter requested that DiNapoli pay special attention to the , a large state investment into job creation in and around Buffalo, New York.\n\n\nAs a candidate for the Senate in 2014, Ortt indicated that he opposes abortion, except in cases of rape or incest. He stated that he \"strongly supports\" the other nine pieces of Governor Cuomo's women's equality bills including \"tougher equal-pay laws and laws to combat sexual harassment, domestic violence, and human trafficking.\"\n\nIn 2017, Ortt introduced legislation that would cause the 2013 gun control law known as the NY SAFE Act to be repealed in all areas of New York other than New York City.\n\nOn the EPL/Environmental Advocate's Environmental Scorecard in 2018, Ortt scored a 68, up from a score of 53 points in 2017. In 2018, Ortt helped pass legislation he sponsored that added geothermal heating systems to the list of financeable heating systems in New York State.\n\nAlso in 2019, Ortt voted against the following bills that became law:\n\n* The Reproductive Health Act, an abortion rights bill; \n* The New York State Climate Leadership and Community Protection Act;\n* The Driver's License Access and Privacy Act (also known as the Green Light Bill), which made driver licenses available to undocumented immigrants; and\n* The Jose Peralta New York State DREAM Act, which gave undocumented students the opportunity to receive state-funded financial aid for college.\n\n\nOn March 22, 2017, Ortt, along with his predecessor , was indicted by a grand jury on corruption charges. Ortt was charged with three counts of offering a false instrument for filing; he pleaded not guilty. Prosecutors alleged that Republican officials had approached Ortt about running for mayor of North Tonawanda in 2009. However, taking that position would have reportedly involved a $5,000 pay cut for Ortt. According to prosecutors, Synor Marketing, a public relations firm, created a no-show job for Ortt's wife, Meghan; the Niagara County Republican Committee allegedly paid $21,500 to Synor that was to be paid to Meghan Ortt.\n\n\n\nOn June 27, 2017, all charges against Ortt were dismissed by Judge Peter A. Lynch. Judge Lynch ruled that there was no evidence that Ortt had known that the Niagara County Republican Committee was the source of the payments made to Meghan Ortt. Lynch did not rule that then-New York State Attorney General  had prosecuted Ortt in bad faith or presented inaccurate evidence to the court.\n\n\nOrtt was named Minority Leader of the  on June 19, 2020 after incumbent  announced his resignation.\n\n\nOn August 17, 2019, Ortt announced that he would seek the Republican nomination for the  in . The  representative in the district, Republican , was arrested on federal insider trading charges in 2018. Ortt did not receive the Republican nomination, and he ended his congressional campaign on February 11, 2020.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
          }
        ]
      }
    }

    "pages": }\n| birth_place         = , , U.S.\n| death_date          = \n| death_place         = \n| party               = \n| spouse              = Simone-Marie Meeks\n| children            = 3\n| education           =  () ()\n| website             = \n| module              = \n}}\n'''Gregory Weldon Meeks''' (born September 25, 1953) is an American lawyer and politician who has been a  from  since 1998. He is a member of the  and chaired the  from 2021 to 2023. He still sits on the committee as ranking member.\n\nIn the last Congress, Meeks's district included most of southeastern , including , , , , , , , and the . It was made up largely of economically diverse  and  communities, but also included a small part of  and part of  known as , both of which are predominantly middle-class  communities. He also represented much of  and northern , as well as the largely  western part of .\n\n\nMeeks was born in , New York City and raised in a housing project. He received his  degree from  and his  degree from . He is a member of  fraternity. He worked as an Assistant District Attorney and for the  before joining the Investigations Commission on official misconduct and . He then was Supervising Judge for the New York State Workers Compensation System. Meeks was a member of the  (31st D.) from 1993 to 1998.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nMeeks was criticized for initially supporting  over  for president. His House primary election challenger was to be , a former chief of staff for State Senator  and an organizer for Obama. Wills said, \"I was on board with Obama from Day 1; Meeks had to be dragged across the line.\" Some suggested that a young black political class was seeking to assert the neighborhood's power against what it saw as an older establishment, based in Harlem, that had long exercised disproportionate influence in . Wills did not qualify for the ballot, so no primary election took place.\n\n\n\n\n (CREW) named Meeks one of the most corrupt members of Congress in 2011. It was subsequently reported that his continuing ethical and criminal probes would cause his premature exit from Congress, but Meeks has denied this. In October 2011,  artist and law school graduate Mike Scala announced his candidacy in the Democratic primary. Meeks won the primary and was reelected in the November general election with 90% of the vote.\n\n\n in Israel, November 12, 2023]]\nOn March 3, 2015, Meeks participated with fellow Democrats in a boycott of the speech delivered by Israeli prime minister  to Congress. \n\nIn July 2020, after the primary defeat of  chair , Meeks declared his candidacy for chair. On December 3, 2020, Meeks defeated  148-78 in a  vote.\n\nMeeks voted with President Joe Biden's stated position 100% of the time in the , according to a '''' analysis.\n\n\nIn November 2021, Meeks called for increasing the cap on SALT deductions.\n\n\nOn August 25, 2007, , chair of the Permanent Select Committee on Intelligence and the , and four other representatives visited American troops deployed in the southern  to overview the US-Philippines relationship. Reyes headed the bipartisan delegation, which included , member of the Appropriations Committee and the select intelligence oversight panel;  of the Committee on Energy and the Intelligence Committee; Meeks; and  of the Appropriations and Intelligence Committees. They drove to the base of the Joint Special Operation Task Force Philippines (JSOTFP), a US-led body that trains Filipino soldiers against terror in Barangay Upper Calarian.\n\n\nOn the day of the , Meeks said in a statement that the  victory was \"inevitable\". He also said, \"It is abundantly clear that the Taliban's advance was ultimately inevitable, at least without a commitment to surge tens of thousands of U.S. troops for an unknown span of time. That is a commitment the American public has made clear it does not support.\"\n\n\nIn 2013,  named Meeks as one of the most corrupt politicians in Washington. This was as a result of claims that he purchased a home for over $150,000 less than it was worth, met with former Venezuelan president  on behalf of a donor, and failure to disclose a private loan on congressional financial statements.\n\n\n''The New York Times'' reported that Meeks utilizes the option to use tax dollars to lease a car for use as a member of Congress. This option does not exist for Senate members. The lease is forgone by many members of Congress, but Meeks has held the most-expensive lease among all members. He has used tax dollars to lease a 2007  460 for $998 per month. Meeks was unwilling to provide further comment when questioned by the ''Times'' about the lease arrangement, saying, \"These are never lighthearted stories.\"\n\n\nIn August 2022, Meeks traveled to Malaysia with House Speaker  and other members of Congress as part of Pelosi's Asia tour. Malaysia was their second stop after Singapore. They discussed security challenges, economic opportunities and governance priorities between Malaysia and the U.S.\n  before Blinken testifies before the  on March 10, 2021.]]\n\n\nOn October 6, 2022,  stated that Meeks represented Pelosi and would deliver the keynote address at the 's plenary session on \"Effective Parliament, Dynamic Democracy\". His speech discussed the importance of defending democratic values, combating climate change, strengthening food and energy security, advancing sustainable development and recovery from COVID-19, and deepening inter-parliamentary coordination to address these challenges.\n\n\n* \n** \n*  (Ranking Member)\n\n\n* Co-chair of the Dialogue Caucus\n* Co-chair of the Malaysia Caucus\n* Co-chair of the Middle East Economic Partnership Caucus\n* Co-chair of the Services Caucus\n* Co-chair of the Caucus on US Russian Trade and Economic Relations\n* \n* \n*\n*\n*, \n*\n* \n*.\n\n\nMeeks has  heritage, and according to DNA analysis, he descends mainly from people of . His great-grandparents lived in  when slavery was abolished.\n\n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n*  official U.S. House website\n* \n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Jesse Hamilton''' is an American lawyer and politician in . A member of the , he represented the  , including parts of the  neighborhoods of ,  and  from 2015 to 2018. Hamilton is a former member of the  (IDC), a group of Democratic senators who allied themselves with Senate Republicans. Hamilton is the Secretary of the , the official organization of the  for . He was defeated in the September 2018 Democratic primary election by lawyer .\n\n\nHamilton was born and raised in the . He later moved to , and served on the , as president of his block association and as president of the Rosa Parks Democratic Club. He was the Democratic District Leader in the 43rd Assembly District for nearly a decade. He also served as  for then-Senator  of District 20.\n\n\nIn November 2013,  was elected to the office of Brooklyn , leaving District 20's State Senate seat vacant. On September 9, 2014, Hamilton won the   to represent . There was no  opponent, Hamilton won the November 2014 general election without opposition.\n\nOn Monday, November 7, 2016, Hamilton announced that he would join the , a group of Democratic senators who caucused with the Senate Republican Conference, allowing the Republicans to control the chamber. In January 2017, after joining the IDC, Hamilton was named Chair of the Senate Standing Committee on Banking - which '''' notes earned him a $5,500 raise.\n\nIn 2017, Hamilton played a key role in passage of legislation to raise the age of juvenile jurisdiction for 16- and 17-year-olds, ensuring that they will not be treated as adults under the criminal justice system for misdemeanors and many felonies. The legislation also removes 16- and 17-year-olds from Rikers Island by April 1, 2018, to the extent practicable, and by no later than October 1, 2018. The IDC-backed legislation was criticized as a \"watered down\" version of legislation proposed by Democrats, and because \"it still pushes the majority of juveniles through the criminal justice system.  \"As of 2017, there were 150 minors in Rikers Island.\n\nHamilton has advocated for an end to broken windows policing and has proposed legislation to decriminalize fare evasion on subways, buses and railroads, which would make fare evasion a civil penalty instead of a criminal penalty.\n\nIn 2017, Hamilton and Assemblyman  passed legislation named \"Briana's Law\", after 11-year-old Briana Ojeda, that requires New York City police officers and state troopers to be retrained in CPR every two years. The legislation was introduced after the death of Briana Ojeda when she suffered a severe asthma attack. A police officer stopped her mother driving the wrong way on a one-way street but the police officer did not know how to perform CPR to save Briana's life.\n\nHamilton and his IDC colleagues rejoined the Senate Democratic Conference in April 2018. Subsequently, the Republican conference stripped Hamilton of his position as Chair of the Banks Committee.\n\nIn the September 13, 2018 Democratic primary, Hamilton was defeated by lawyer . Hamilton's loss was attributed to long-simmering anger with the former members of the IDC. Due to New York State's  laws allowing candidates to run on multiple ballot lines in an election, Hamilton still appeared in the November 6, 2018, general election as the third-party candidate for the  and the . Myrie won the general election.\n\nIn the 2020 elections, Hamilton ran against incumbent  in the Democratic primary for the 's 43rd district. Hamilton lost to Richardson in a landslide.\n\nIn August 2022, Mayor  hired Hamilton as a legal counsel at the .\n\nOn October 11, 2024, Manhattan District Attorney Alvin Bragg's agents seized Jesse Hamilton's mobile phone as he was exiting Kennedy Airport after returning from a trip to Japan. He was with Eric Adam's chief advisor  at the time, who also had her phone seized from her possession. Cushman and Wakefield Vice-Chair  was also on the trip. The week prior, Hamilton's boss (Mayor Eric L. Adams) was indicted on bribery and other Federal charges relating to obtaining campaign donations from Turkish nationals illegally. Hamilton is the mayor's Deputy Commissioner for Real Estate Services.\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Nita Sue Lowey''' ( ;  '''Melnikoff'''; born July 5, 1937) is an American politician who formerly served as a  from  from 1989 until 2021. She is a member of the . Lowey also served as co-Dean of the New York Congressional Delegation, along with former U.S. Representative . Lowey's district was numbered as the 20th from 1989 to 1993, as the 18th from 1993 to 2013, and as the  beginning in 2013. The district includes many of New York City's inner northern suburbs, such as , , , , and . She was succeeded by fellow Democrat .\n\nIn 2018, Lowey became the first woman to chair the . She announced on October 10, 2019, that she would retire and not run for re-election to  in .\n\n\nLowey was born in  in New York City to Beatrice (Fleisher) and Jack Melnikoff. She graduated from the  as valedictorian of the class of 1955, and then from  with a bachelor's degree in liberal studies.\n\nLowey worked for 's 1974 campaign for . She then served as the assistant secretary of state of  for 13 years.\n\n\n\n\n\nLowey ran for the  from  in the  against  . She defeated DioGuardi. Her district was renumbered as the  after the 1990 census and became the  after the 2010 census. For her entire tenure, Lowey represented a large slice of New York City's northern suburbs, including most of  and all of . She used to represent some of the far northern portions of  and the  until redistricting after the  removed the New York City portion of her district.\n\nLowey considered , but stepped aside when   announced her candidacy. Lowey was considered a top contender for appointment to Clinton's Senate seat after Clinton was nominated to be , but in a December 1, 2008, phone interview with the , she stated that she was not interested in giving up her senior seat on the House Appropriations Committee.\n\nIn 2004, Lowey received 69% of the vote against political newcomer Richard A. Hoffman, a Wall Street investor and largely self-funded candidate who ran on a platform of opposing special interests and cutting federal taxes. Lowey emphasized her track record on homeland security issues, notably her work to reform the formula for distributing  grants to states. In 2006, also against Hoffman, Lowey won with 70%. Lowey was re-elected to an eleventh term in 2008, with 68% of the vote against James C. Russell.\n\n\nLowey received an \"A\" on the liberal 's 2005 scorecard. She received 12% on the 's 2007 congressional scorecard. According to the conservative , Lowey consistently votes in support of the policies of the Democratic Party, and is seen as a strong and effective progressive voice in that legislative body.\n\nHer voting record on  earned her a \"D\" on the , which was created by a coalition of organizations and individuals from across the political spectrum advocating for transparency and an end to mass surveillance.\n\nEarly in her Congressional career, Lowey sponsored an  for the purpose of \"dredging the  Harbor.\"Carney, Timothy (March 16, 2011) . ''.'' According to the local newspaper, '''', the dredging was proposed because \"the harbor was becoming too shallow 'to accommodate the larger yachts.'\"\n\nIn 2001–2002, Lowey served as the first female chair of the .\n\nOne of the notable causes she supports is the , in support of which she appeared at a congressional hearing accompanied  by '''' characters Bert and Ernie.\n\nLowey has been a vocal advocate for a Security Council Resolution on the . She is responsible for the $500 million in the Emergency Spending Bill for Aid in Darfur.\n\nLowey voted for HR 2454, the \"Cap and Trade\" legislation.\n\n Director  and Senator , during 2007 floods in New York.]]In early 2009, Lowey introduced the Transportation Security Workforce Enhancement Act, which calls for collective bargaining rights for federal workers at the TSA and Department of Homeland Security. However, some statements from the TSA dispute the necessity of collective bargaining.\n\nShe was strongly critical of the , which places limits on taxpayer-funded abortions in the context of the November 2009, . Because of the rancor and disruptions which marked many of the town hall meetings held in the summer of 2009 to discuss Health Care Reform, Lowey chose to present her point of view on Health Care Reform in a telephone conference call, the effectiveness of which was questioned by some of her constituents.\n\nIn 2018, the Democrats won the majority in the U.S House of Representatives and subsequently Congresswoman Lowey became the first Chairwoman of the House Committee on Appropriations. After she became chair, she negotiated a border security bill with Senator  that funded the government through 2020.\n\nOn October 10, 2019, two months after Democrat  announced his intention to challenge her in a 2020 primary, Lowey announced she would not run for reelection in 2020.\n\nFor her tenure as the chairwoman of the House Appropriations Committee in the 116th Congress, Lowey earned an \"A\" grade from the non-partisan Lugar Center's Congressional Oversight Hearing Index.\n\n\nLowey announced her opposition to the , stating that\n\nIn my judgment, sufficient safeguards are not in place to address the risks associated with the agreement. Relieving UN sanctions on conventional arms and ballistic missiles and releasing billions of dollars to the Iranian regime could lead to a dangerous regional weapons race and enable Iran to bolster its funding of terrorists. The deal does not explicitly require Iran to fully disclose its previous military work to the IAEA's satisfaction before sanctions relief is provided, and inspectors will not have immediate access to the most suspicious facilities. There are no clear accountability measures regarding punishment for minor violations, which could encourage Iran to cheat.\n\n\nLike all Democratic members of Congress, Lowey was a  to the , pledged to support . Lowey's chief of staff, when asked by the '''' whether Lowey might switch her support to candidate  if Sanders were to win the New York State Democratic presidential primary, said \"absolutely not... Hillary Clinton is Congresswoman Lowey's friend, colleague and her constituent, and she is behind her 100%.\"\n\n\n* '''''' (Chairwoman)\n**  (Chairwoman)\n** As Chairwoman of the full committee, Lowey may serve as an ''ex officio'' member of all subcommittees.\n\n\n* Congressional Women's Caucus\n* House Pro-Choice Caucus\n* Hudson River Caucus\n*\n* \n* \n* National Eating Disorders Awareness Caucus\n* Congressional Crohn's and Colitis Caucus\n* \n\n\nLowey is married to Stephen Lowey, a named partner in the  of Lowey Dannenberg Cohen & Hart, P.C., which is located in . According to the , his practice areas include securities law,  law, and consumer protection. They have three children and eight grandchildren, including '''' cast member Ilan Luttway. The estimate of Lowey's personal assets, based on financial disclosures members of Congress are required to provide (aside from that of personal residences and non-interest-bearing bank accounts), put her wealth at $41.2 million in 2010, based largely on her husband's investments. This figure is derived from a special investigative series of asset wealth of all U.S. Congressional Representatives conducted by ''''.\n\nLowey is Jewish.\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n''|years=}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Ro Ann Maggiolino Destito''' (born January 15, 1956) was appointed Commissioner of the New York State Office of General Services overseeing all state contracts, by Governor  in 2011. She resigned from this position in October 2021 and was succeeded by Jeanette M. Moy who was appointed by Governor Hochul in October 2021 (https://ogs.ny.gov/commissioner-jeanette-m-moy). Prior to becoming Commissioner she was a member of the  for the 116th district (which includes  and ) from 1993 to 2011 when she resigned. She is a .\n\n\nHer tenure included a seat on the New York State Liquor Authority Board. While she was on the SLA, her husband's liquor wholesale client the 's  was granted the legal right to have alcohol served at the casino. In 2009, Oneida County Legislator Michael Hennessy spoke out against issuing the permit and requested an investigation. To comply with this deal approximately 1,200 employees were switched from working for Turning Stone to now being employed by CD Food & Beverage.\n\nIn September 2011, Destito proclaimed a curfew of 7pm to help Albany State Park Police break up a demonstration. Protesters argued that by sleeping in a public park they were expressing a protected  right to free speech and were not subject to curfews. Albany police did not make any arrests.\n\nIn 2013, she was accused of ethics violations by lobbying for the casino's gaming deal.\n\n\nShe is the widow of Chris Destito, former President of the Rome Chamber of Commerce and owner of the Beeches Restaurant and Convention Center; and the mother of one son.\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Patrick B. Burke''' (born June 22, 1984) is an American politician who serves in the  from the 142nd district, which represents , the City of , and the towns of  and . Burke is a South Buffalo native.\n\n\nBurke was first elected to the 7th District of the  in 2013.\n\nIn August 2015, Burke sponsored a bill that became the first  in the state of New York. It bans the sale and distribution of all plastic microbeads (including biodegradable ones) including from personal care products. , its prohibition on sales is decent.  It was enacted on August 12, 2015 and took effect in February, 2016. In November 2015, four other NY counties followed suit.\n\nIn 2015, Burke released a plan to create a regional municipal broadband network as co-chair of the Erie County Municipal Broadband Project Committee. The report argued that affordable, high-speed municipal broadband internet service in Erie County would create faster job and business growth, while raising property values.\n\nBurke introduced the Prevention of Emotional Neglect and Childhood Endangerment Act, named for Vice President Mike Pence. The law , and went into effect upon filing with the New York Department of State on March 7, 2018.\n\n\nBurke won the  for the 142nd district of the .\n\nDuring the , Burke co-sponsored laws that allow , no-excuse , and regulate political donations by .\n\nIn 2018, Burke called on  Bishop  to resign over accusations of negligence concerning investigations into . On January 28, 2019, Burke co-sponsored the  that allows prosecutors to bring criminal charges until a victim turns 28, and permits victims to sue until age 55.\n\nBurke cosponsored ''Assembly Bill A576'', which passed the  on January 15, 2019 by a vote of 141-7, and passed the  that same day by a vote of 57-4. The bill expanded the Erie County conversion therapy ban to cover the entire state, and was signed by Governor  on January 25, 2019, taking effect immediately upon receiving his signature. Since 2016, conversion therapy has been banned in New York from coverage by insurers and Medicaid, or from being practiced by any state-licensed or operated mental health facility per executive order.\n\nIn February 2019, Burke joined his fellow  elected officials in condemning Governor Cuomo's budget that cut state Aid and Incentives Municipalities funding for nearly all towns and villages.\n\nIn April 2019, Burke introduced and passed legislation that permits the New York Office of Victim Services to provide compensation and funding to a broader classification of child victims, for uses such as mental health counseling and transportation to court appearances.\nIn March 2021, Burke called on then-Governor  to resign over .\n\nIn November 2020, Burke won the November 3, 2020 election for the 142nd Assembly District. Burke, the incumbent, was uncontested in the Democratic Primary and challenged by Republican Matthew Szalkowski in the general election.\n\nIn November 2021, Assembly Bill A7564, which was introduced by Burke,  was signed by the Governor. This bill, which passed in both the Assembly and Senate, encourages the elimination of certain single-use plastics in both the SUNY and CUNY systems.\n\nIn December 2021, Assembly Bill A6057, which was introduced by Burke, passed by both the Assembly and the Senate, and signed by the Governor. This bill mandated that the Commissioner of Health is to establish and implement an infection inspection audit and checklist on nursing homes.\n\nIn July 2022, Burke announced funding that he secured for the public libraries in his district. The funding was used to update the exterior of libraries, update reading materials, and purchase new technology, such as a 3D printer and projector screen.\n\nIn July 2022, Burke announced $1 million in funding that he secured for the West Seneca and Orchard Park School Districts. This money is to be used to improve the schools overall safety.\n\nIn August 2022, Burke was named chair of the Great Lakes Watershed Task Force. This task force was created by Assembly Speaker Carl E. Heastie.\n\nIn September 2022, Burke announced funds secured in the amount of $160,000 for the Lackawanna Fire Department. Announced at Lackawanna Fire Station #3, this funding is to be used to purchase a second set of gear, commonly referred to as turnout gear for all Lackawanna Firefighters.\n\n\nIn November 2021, Burke announced that he was drafting a bill that would give health insurance companies the option to deny healthcare coverage to unvaccinated people for any -related treatments.The bill was deemed highly controversial by multiple elected officials.\n\nIn May 2022, former Burke staffers came out against him, saying that they were fired after calling on Burke to speak out against the . Burke's former director of community relations said that Burke had stated \"I'm not giving up my seat for this issue\". Burke called the comments \"bizarre, offensive, and completely off base\".\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
          }

    "pages": }\n'''Linda Lee''' (born July 3, 1979) is an American politician from  who is the  of , representing the .\n\nLee grew up in . She received her B.A. from  of  and her Master's of Social Work from Columbia. Before running in the council elections aged 42, she had never previously sought office and served as the President and CEO of Korean Community Services of Metropolitan New York, Inc.  She campaigned for election on a platform of increasing services for , improving the accountability of police to citizens, and workforce training to help recover the economy in the aftermath of the .\n\nAfter winning the November 2021 general election, she became the first Asian American woman to represent the district, along with a wave of previously unrepresented minorities on the City Council. She succeeded fellow Democrat ; her term is intended to run for two years instead of the usual four because of planned . Her district office is located in Oakland Gardens, Queens. \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Alessandra Rose Biaggi''' (born May 20, 1986) is an American politician who served as a member of the  from 2019 to 2022, representing the , which includes portions of  and . She was the chair of the New York State Senate Committee on Ethics and Internal Governance. She is the granddaughter of former U.S. Congressman .\n\nIn February 2022, Biaggi  for  after the incumbent representative  announced his run for New York Governor. After court ordered redistricting removed Westchester County and the Bronx from the 3rd congressional district, Biaggi announced her candidacy for , where she unsuccessfully ran against , who decided to run in the 17th congressional district that was represented by , into which his home was drawn, rather than the  Maloney previously represented.\n\n\nBiaggi was born in , and is . Her great-grandparents had immigrated to the United States from Italy, and she is the fourth generation of her family to live in her district. She grew up first in , and when she was eight years old she moved with her family to . When she was a child, she was  for over a year.\n\nShe graduated from  ('04), where Biaggi was a cheerleader. After attending , Biaggi transferred to and ultimately graduated from  with a Bachelor of Arts degree in 2008.\n\nShe then first attended . She subsequently transferred to and graduated from  in 2012, where she was a member of the ''''. She was the first woman from her family to graduate from law school. In 2014, she attended the Women's Campaign School at .\n\n\n\nBiaggi  in the office of U.S. Congressman  after college, and while in law school with the  Rackets Bureau and the  Public Corruption and Appellate Bureaus. She then worked from 2014 to 2015 at her first job as a lawyer, as Assistant General Counsel for New York State Governor ’s .\n\nFrom May 2015 to December 2016, during the campaign for the , Biaggi served as Deputy National Operations Director for the . She oversaw a staff of 200, and a budget of $500 million. She said: \"Everything was urgent in the moment. It was total chaos and I loved it. We played very hard, and it was very hard to lose.\"\n\nFollowing the election, she worked on various advocacy and voter engagement measures. In April to December 2017, Biaggi served as counsel in Governor Cuomo's Counsel's Office, and as a member of the governor's  team. She also created the ''Take Action Guide for Activism''.\n\n\nBiaggi served as chair of the Senate Committee on Ethics and Internal Governance.\n\nCombating sexual abuse is one of Biaggi's policy issues. She has led the first public hearings in the New York State Senate on  in 27 years, and fought for tougher  laws. Susan Kang, Associate Professor of political science at , said: \"She is definitely making a name for herself as someone who is an advocate for victims of sexual violence.\"\n\nBiaggi is also focused on institutional reform of Congress, of the Supreme Court, and institutions. Specifically, Biaggi is also focused on banning trading stocks among members.\n\n\n|source= Biaggi}}\nBiaggi ran in 2018 in the primary for the Democratic nomination for  in . While only 32 years old, she ran against powerful longtime incumbent , the number 2 Democrat in the NY Senate and the leader of the , who had held the seat for 14 years. Klein outspent Biaggi by a rate of 9-to-1, spending $2.7 million to her $333,000. Biaggi said: \"The more people told me I couldn’t win, the more obsessed I became.\"\n\nIn a major upset, Biaggi defeated Klein in the primary, 54%–46%. She remarked: \"It was a tough fight. And, I should also say, we should thank [Senator Klein] for his service. But his time is up.\"\n\nSubsequently, on November 6, 2018, she , and was elected to the New York State Senate.Claire Wasserman (2021).  At 32 years of age, she became one of the youngest women ever elected to the New York State Senate.\n\n\nIn June 2019, the New York legislature passed sweeping anti-sexual-harassment legislation that Biaggi had sponsored. Among other things, the bills reduced employers' ability to avoid liability for their employees' behavior, provided for attorney fees and punitive damages, and lengthened the time frame within which to file complaints. In her first six months in office, Biaggi introduced 80 bills, 17 of which were passed.\n\nIn 2020, Biaggi won the Democratic primary with 88% of the vote. She then won the general election with 74% of the vote.\n\nIn February 2021, Biaggi wrote on Twitter: \"@NYGovCuomo, you are a monster, and it is time for you to go. Now.\" At the time, her call for his resignation was what ''The New York Times'' described as: \"something of an outlier in the Democrat-controlled Legislature.\" On August 10, 2021, Governor  announced his resignation.\n\nIn May 2021 journalist Matthew Kassel opined: \"Biaggi ... has gained a reputation, on her own merits, as an upstate force  an influential lawmaker with a growing list of legislative accomplishments who has carved out a space for herself as an outspoken and independent voice in Albany’s cutthroat political sphere.\"\n\nOn September 24, 2021, Biaggi co-wrote a letter to US Senator  with eight other New York State Senators, requesting that the  engage in oversight of the , and step in to ensure that SafeSport is adequately conducting investigations. They referred to what they called SafeSport's failure to carry out impartial and thorough investigations, and ensure the safety of athletes it is charged with protecting. They highlighted the fact that despite serious outstanding allegations of , , and other violent behaviors by former friends, peers, and current teammates, and an ongoing investigation, fencer  was allowed to travel to Tokyo as an alternate for the 2021 Team USA Olympic fencing team.\n\nBiaggi has been a vocal advocate for defunding the police.\n\nShe has received a rating of 100% from  Empire State (2019 and 2020), from New York  (2019), and from EPL/Environmental Advocates (2019 and 2020).\n\nIn 2022, Biaggi received criticism over her treatment of her staff.\n\n\nOn June 7, 2022, Biaggi announced that she would be running for  in a primary challenge against  chair . Upon her announcement, she was endorsed by . On August 23, 2022, Biaggi lost to Maloney in the primary election.\n\n\nIn 2019, '''' named her to its annual \"40 Under 40\" list.\n\nIn June 2021, she was named to the  New York City Food Policy Center annual 40 Under 40: The Rising Stars in NYC Food Policy. She was noted for working \"to transform and improve the .\" In November 2021, Biaggi was named to the '''' \"Women 100\", as one of the prominent women wielding power in New York State. She was noted especially for having long pushed for legislation addressing  and .\n\n\nBiaggi's grandfather  served as a Democratic member of the  from New York from 1969 to 1988.\n\nOn July 22, 2019, in , Biaggi married Nathaniel Koloc. He is a management consultant whom she met in 2015, and who also worked on the .\n\n\n\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n*\n\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Andrew D. Hevesi''' (born November 19, 1973) is a  member of the  representing the 28th Assembly District, which includes , , , , , , and .\n\n\nHevesi is the son of former  , and the brother of former  .\n\nAndrew Hevesi held several public service positions before being elected to the New York State Assembly, including a period in both the 's office and as Director of Community Affairs for  . Hevesi also served as Chief of Staff for former  .\n\nHevesi has a BA degree in political science from . He married Rachel Ross in 2007. The couple has a daughter,\n\n\n\nOn May 10, 2005, Hevesi won a  to fill a seat left vacant by the resignation of former Assemblyman , serving for the remainder of his term. In 2007, New York State and Albany County investigators examined whether Hevesi and his brother improperly reaped benefits from their disgraced father's control of the state's $154 billion pension fund. At the time, more than a tenth of Hevesi's contributions had come from investment firms that managed state pension fund assets or their executives, including Los Angeles–based Republican fundraiser . Hevesi was re-elected in November 2006 and has been re-elected in all subsequent elections.\n\nFrom June 2011 to February 2015 Assemblyman Hevesi served as Chairman of the Committee on Oversight, Analysis, and Investigation, a position previously held by both   and   . As Chair, Assemblyman Hevesi held hearings on numerous topics including healthcare, human trafficking, and technology infrastructure in New York State.\n\nHevesi has secured a total of $6&nbsp;million for freight locomotive engine upgrades in the 2013–2014 and 2014–2015 New York State Budgets. The initiative was prompted by a constituency in his district that suffered from constant locomotive idling and emissions from outdated locomotive engines.\n\nIn February 2015, Assemblyman Hevesi was appointed Chairman of the Committee on Social Services.\n\n\n* '''May 2005 , NYS Assembly, 28th AD'''\n\n:\n\n* '''November 2006 general election, NYS Assembly, 28th AD'''\n:\n\n* '''November 2008 general election, NYS Assembly, 28th AD'''\n:\n\n* '''November 2010 general election, NYS Assembly, 28th AD'''\n:\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n*, nydailynews.com; March 1, 2011.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Brian Patrick Kavanagh''' (born January 18, 1967) is an American politician who represents the  in the , representing  since December 2017. Before the redrawing of legislative districts in January 2023, Kavanagh represented the west part of Brooklyn. He previously served in the  representing the . Kavanagh is a .\n\n\nKavanagh is a lifelong resident of . He was born and raised on  and graduated from  in Manhattan. Kavanagh tutored students at the . He graduated with a B.A. in politics from  in 1989. He then received a  from . He worked as an attorney at the New York law firms  and .\n\nWhile living in Manhattan, Kavanagh lived in many different neighborhoods: the Lower East Side, Murray Hill, , and Turtle Bay.\n\nHe was an aide to former New York City Mayors  and . He served as chief of staff to  member .\n\nKavanagh began government service as an aide to Mayor  and has served in three mayoral administrations. After the  fire claimed the lives of 87 people in 1990, Kavanagh helped coordinate the city's response to the tragedy on behalf of Mayor , co-designing a task force that shut down the most grievous fire code offenders. At the Mayor's Office, Brian also played a key role in launching the  and he then served as the agency's first Policy Director.\n\nAs Chief-of-Staff for then-New York City Council member , Kavanagh negotiated enactment of the  Protection Act, promoting the rights of housekeepers and caregivers. With then-Councilmember , Councilmember Brewer, and dozens of their colleagues on the Council, Kavanagh helped to draft and secure passage of Council Resolution 549, opposing the imminent invasion of Iraq.\n\nKavanagh has served as a counselor, volunteer, and board member at the Lower East Side's Nativity Middle School and community center, and as a board member of the . He is a member of the  and has served on the Association's Election Law Committee.\n\nFollowing an unsuccessful bid for the  in 2005, Kavanagh was first elected to the  in November 2006. He is a member of the  and has been endorsed by the . He is on the board of the , and serves as the President of the American-Irish Legislators Society.\n\nKavanagh has been awarded the  Eco-Star Award, the highest rating of any legislator in 2010 from Environmental Advocates of New York, the  Legislator of the Year Award, and a perfect rating from the League of Humane Voters. Kavanagh teaches a course at .\n\n\nIn 2017, Kavanagh announced that he would run in the special election to succeed Senator , who was resigning to found a non-profit. Not without criticism, Kavanagh was nominated as the Democratic candidate, despite representing very little of the same territory in the state Assembly that the Senate district encompassed. Despite this, Kavanagh easily won election. He was easily re-elected to a full first term in 2018.\n\nKavanagh has been a proponent of election reform. Stating New Yorkers \"have some of the worst election laws in the country,\" Kavanagh introduced a bill \"that would allow voters to cast ballots before Election Day\". Until New York enacted early voting in 2019, it was the largest state with no advance voting regime.\n\nWith Democrats taking the majority in the Senate in 2019, Kavanagh was named Chair of the Committee on Housing, Construction and Community Development. In his first year as Chair, Kavanagh led the effort to pass the  (HSTPA), which became law. Early into the , Kavanagh advocated to stop evictions and foreclosures, extending the statewide eviction and foreclosure moratorium for almost two years. He enacted New York's Emergency Rental Assistance Program and Homeowner Assistance Fund. In 2024, New York State adopted  legislation, which had been a priority of Kavanagh's since 2019.\n\nKavanagh was a co-sponsor of the  (CLCPA), enacted in 2019, and has served on the Environmental Conservation Committee in each of his years in the legislature. One of Kavanagh's priorities has been the introduction of extended producer responsibility legislation, which would required producers to be responsible for products from the beginning to end of life. He has introduced legislation in this area for rechargeable batteries, lamps, mattresses, and textiles, among others.\n\nKavanagh authored the \"All-Electric Building Act,\" which became law in 2023, requiring the state energy construction code to halt the use of fossil fuels in new construction in the state.\n\nKavanagh has pursued legislation that would curb gun violence in New York. As the founder and chair of the American State Legislators for Gun Violence Prevention, Kavanagh prioritized working across the aisle to curb access to illegal guns. He is the sponsor of New York's red flag law, which would prevent those who may be a threat to themselves or others from purchasing or possessing a firearm.\n\n* '''September 2006 Democratic , NYS Assembly, 74th AD'''\n:\n\n* '''November 2006 , NYS Assembly, 74th AD'''\n:\n\n* '''November 2008 , NYS Assembly, 74th AD'''\n:\n\n* '''November 2010 , NYS Assembly, 74th AD'''\n:\n* '''September 2012 Democratic , NYS Assembly, 74th AD'''\n:\n* '''November 2012 , NYS Assembly, 74th AD'''\n:\n* '''November 2014 , NYS Assembly, 74th AD'''\n:\n* '''November 2016 , NYS Assembly, 74th AD'''\n:\n* '''November 2017 , NYS Senate, 26th SD'''\n:\n*'''November 2022 , New York State Senate'''\n:\n\n\nKavanagh is one of six children of an Irish-immigrant police officer and a community leader in Staten Island who worked at a . Kavanagh currently lives in his district in the East Side of Manhattan.\n\n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n* ''\".\"'' New York, New York, 2020\n\n\n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Laura Curran''' (born December 31, 1967) is a Canadian-born American politician who served as the county executive of  from 2018 to 2021. She was the ninth county executive in Nassau County history and the first woman to hold the office. Curran worked as a reporter before serving in the .\n\n\nCurran was born in , , . She moved frequently as a child, and before turning 18, lived in , , , New York City, Los Angeles, and Washington, D.C.\n\nIn 1989, Curran earned a  in Liberal Arts from .\n\n\nCurran previously served in the  from 2014 to 2017 and as a local  member in her hometown of . Prior to holding elective office, Curran worked as a reporter for the '''' and ''''.\n\n\n\n\nIn 2017, Curran won a September 12 primary against Nassau County Comptroller George Maragos, who switched parties from  to .\n\nIn the general election, Curran won a contentious campaign against former  and  Village Mayor . The then sitting Nassau County Executive, , had decided not to run for re-election following an indictment on federal corruption charges.\n\nThe campaign between Curran and Martins touched on gang violence () and runaway property taxes, but ultimately centered on ethics. When polls closed on election night Curran, an underdog in the historically Republican Nassau County, had won 52 percent to 48 percent. She is the third Democrat to hold the position in 80 years.\n\nCurran was sworn into office on January 1, 2018, by then-  on the steps of the Theodore Roosevelt Executive and Legislative Building.\n\nOn November 16, 2021, Laura Curran conceded the race for Nassau County Executive to Republican challenger  and left office on December 31, 2021. She attributed her loss to her name being on the same ballot as  , Democrat of Long Beach, for  . He was the author of the  law that disgruntled many Long Islanders.\n\n\nAmong Curran's first hires were former  President Helena Williams and former New York City Budget Director under Mayor  Mark Page. Williams was the railroad's longest-serving president in several decades, president of the nation's busiest commuter railroad, and the first woman to run any  agency. Page, as director of the city's Office of Management and Budget under NYC Mayor Michael Bloomberg, oversaw the city's finances through the  terror attacks, the , and .\n\nOther early hires included an assistant state attorney general and former special counsel to the New York State Attorney General Public Integrity Bureau to enforce new ethics and procurement reform policies. Curran also appointed the first permanent commissioner of the Nassau County Police Department in more than four years. Curran's appointment, Patrick Ryder, previously served as commanding officer of the Asset Forfeiture and Intelligence Unit. Within the department, Ryder was largely credited with widespread adoption of new advances in technology to assist in crime reduction. Examples include Nassau's successful use of gunfire locator technology to reduce gun crime.\n  ]]\n\n\nUnder Curran's predecessor, Nassau County froze the tax rolls in 2011. The rolls would remain frozen for nearly seven years. According to an exposè, the policy resulted in a $1.7 billion shift in the property tax burden that largely benefited wealthy residents over low-income, middle-class and elderly residents. In effect, the policy created a \"separate and unequal\" tax assessment and challenge system that benefited those who frequently challenged their annual property tax assessment over others who did not or were unable to do so.\n\nTo address the issue Curran issued an executive order unfreezing the tax rolls in March 2018 and signed legislation that would allow for the reassessment of all county properties by 2019. Additionally, Curran introduced a proposal providing tax relief to the homeowners who shouldered the majority of the tax burden shift under the 2011 freeze. The proposal called for a five-year, partial tax exemption that would be granted to owner of homes built before the freeze began in 2010, are assessed at a high level, and are worth $1&nbsp;million or less. The resulting exemption would primarily benefit middle-income property owners who have not challenged their assessments successfully since the 2011 freeze and resultant tax shift.\n\n\nUpon taking office Curran confronted the growing opioid epidemic which saw the drug claiming a record number of lives in the region. Curran, and Commissioner Ryder, quickly established a tech and intel-driven response to the opioid and heroin crises by working in conjunction with the U.S.   program. Through the HIDTA program Curran and Ryder were able to fund and roll out the Overdose Detection Mapping Application Program (OD Map). Through ODMap police track overdoses reported to hospitals, fire and police officials and are able to predict waves of overdoses and try to prevent them as well as the crimes that often follow drug use. Curran, Ryder, and the program gained national attention when early results showed a precipitous drop in both fatal and non-fatal overdoses; 32 and 34 percent respectively.\n\n\nCurran signed an executive order barring appointees from holding leadership positions in political parties or donating to her campaign. At the time the measure was considered to be the first in New York State history. Shortly after, Curran issued a \"zero-tolerance\" executive order banning gift-giving among vendors and employees involved with procurement or contracting procedures. Previously county employees could not accept gifts worth $75 or more.\n\n\nDuring the campaign Curran pledged that if elected she would remove the county executive's name from the county's parks and welcome signs. The pledge was a sharp break with tradition and an unusual measure by political standards. Of the pledge, ''The New York Times'' wrote, \"Across the county's many parks, large signs welcome visitors with the county executive's name in giant letters, with the park's name in a smaller typeface. Ms. Curran has asked the county's public works department to simply remove the county executive's name altogether.\" Curran criticized the signs as self-promotional and a waster of taxpayer dollars.\n\n\nIn opposition to rising public opinion of her electorate and popular sentiment within the New York State Legislature, controlled by the Democratic Party in all three chambers at the time, Curran took a hardline stance against the legalization of recreational marijuana and announced that she intended to have Nassau County opt-out of the clause which would legalize marijuana that was included in an early version of the 2019 New York State Budget.\n\n\nFollowing a measure that eliminated cash bail passed by the New York State Legislature as part of the 2019 budget and was hailed as a landmark progressive legislation by supporters, Curran vigorously spoke out against the legislation to numerous media outlets, appeared on  to oppose bail reform, and continued on efforts to form a coalition against the legislation.\n\n\nCurran lives in , Nassau County, New York, in the town of . She is married and has three daughters.\n\n\n\n\n\n*  at Nassau County Government\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
          }
        ]
      }
    }

    "pages": }\n\n'''Ruth Hassell-Thompson''' (\nHassell; born November 6, 1942) of , is a former  who represented the  of New York, which includes the Bronx neighborhoods of , , , ,  and  and City of .\n\n\n\nBorn November 6, 1942 in New York City to Branon Hassell and Thelma Crump Hassell, Hassell-Thompson worked as a pediatric nurse and substance abuse counselor for Mount Vernon Hospital from 1963 to 1998. From January 1980 to June 1987, she was executive director of the Westchester Minority Contractor's Association (WMCA). Prior to leading the WMCA, she worked for the Westchester Community Opportunity Program for 10 years in a number of management positions.\n\nShe served as president/CEO of Whart Development Company Inc., a real estate development company and a consultant to small and developing businesses before being elected to  City Council in 1993. She would later serve as council president and acting mayor.\n\nIn 2000, she was elected to the . She is the chairwoman of the Crime Victims, Crime and Corrections Committee and is a former ranking minority member on the Consumer Protection and Judiciary committees.\n\nHassell-Thompson announced on April 22, 2016, that she would be leaving the Senate to work for Governor . She worked as special adviser for policy and community affairs of New York State Homes and Community Renewal.\n\n\n*\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n* ''\".\"'' Skyhorse Publishing.
