    "pages": }\n\n'''Jerrold Lewis Nadler''' (; born June 13, 1947) is an American lawyer and politician who since 2023 has served as the  for , which includes central . A member of the , he was first elected to Congress in 1992 to represent the state's , which was renumbered as the  from 1993 to 2013 and as the  from 2013 to 2023. Nadler chaired the  from 2019 to 2023. In his 17th term in Congress, Nadler is the dean of New York's U.S. House delegation. Before his election to Congress, he served eight terms as a man.\n\n\n\nNadler was born into a  family in , the son of Miriam () and Emanuel \"Max\" Nadler. Nadler described his father as a \"dyed-in-the-wool Democrat\" who lost his poultry farm in  when the younger Nadler was seven. In his youth, he attended  ; he is the only member of Congress with a yeshiva education. He graduated from  in 1965 (where his debate team partner was the future philosopher of science , and  managed his successful campaign for student government president).\n\nNadler received his  in 1969 from , where he became a brother of . After graduating from Columbia, Nadler worked as a legal assistant and clerk, first with  in 1970, then the Morris, Levin and Shein law firm in 1971. In 1972, Nadler was a legislative assistant in the  before becoming shift manager at the New York City , a position he held until becoming a law clerk with Morgan, Finnegan, Pine, Foley and Lee in 1976.\n\nWhile attending evening courses at the , Nadler was elected to the  in 1976. He completed his  at Fordham in 1978.\n\n\n\nNadler was a member of the  from 1977 to 1992, sitting in the , , , , , ,  and s.\n\nIn 1985, Nadler ran for . He lost the Democratic primary to . In the general election, he ran as the  nominee, and again lost to Dinkins.\n\nIn 1989, he ran for , but lost to  and former U.S. representative  in the Democratic primary.\n\nNadler founded and chaired the Assembly Subcommittee on Mass Transit and Rail Freight.\n\n\n\n\n\nIn 1992, Democratic representative  was expected to run for reelection in the 8th district, which had been renumbered from the 17th after the . However, Weiss died a day before the , and Nadler was nominated to replace Weiss. He ran in two elections on Election Day– a special election to serve the rest of Weiss's eighth term in the old 17th district, and a regular election for a full two-year term in the new 8th district. He won both handily, and has been reelected 15 times with very little opposition. In 2020, Nadler faced a primary challenge from activist Lindsey Boylan; the election was the first time in his tenure that Nadler received less than 75% of the vote. The district was renumbered the 10th district after the 2010 Census. A  has not represented this district or its predecessors in over a century.\n\nFrom 2013 to 2023, Nadler's 10th district included Manhattan's west side from the  down to , including the ; the Manhattan neighborhoods of ,  and ; and parts of Brooklyn, such as , , , and . It includes many of New York City's most popular tourist attractions, including the , ,  and .\n\nIn 2022, Nadler defeated his longtime House colleague  in a three-way Democratic primary with 56% of the vote after he and Maloney were both drawn into the  during .\n\n\n  in 2009]]\n at the ]]\n\nNadler is the ranking member of the , and is a member of the  committees.\n\nDespite earlier  and more recent requests from fellow representatives, he did not schedule hearings on  for Bush or , saying in 2007 that doing so would be pointless and would distract from the presidential election. In an interview in '''' on July 15, 2008, Nadler reiterated the timing argument and endorsed  in the , saying that electing an honest candidate would create a greater chance of prosecuting those in the Bush administration who had committed war crimes. Ten days later, after Representative  submitted , the full House Judiciary Committee held hearings regarding the process covered solely by . A top  Justice Department official, , was among those testifying for impeachment.\n\nOn a similar note, referring to hypothetical impeachment proceedings against President  that would begin in the newly elected Democrat-controlled House, he suggested a \"three-pronged test\" that \"would make for a legitimate impeachment proceeding\". Such a test would include \"the offenses in question must be so grave\", and \"the evidence so clear\", that \"even some supporters of the president concede that impeachment is necessary\". If it was determined that the president committed an impeachable offense, lawmakers must consider if such an offense would \"rise to the gravity where it's worth putting the country through the trauma of an impeachment proceeding,\" Nadler said.\n\nOn September 24, 2019, Representative  proposed a resolution to remove Nadler from his position as chair of the House Judiciary committee, accusing him of unlawfully beginning impeachment proceedings before the House had given the committee authorization.\n\nNadler served as an  (prosecutor) during the .\n\nFor his tenure as chair of the House Judiciary Committee in the 116th Congress, Nadler earned an \"A\" grade from the non-partisan 's Congressional Oversight Hearing Index.\n\n criticized Nadler for incorrectly claiming following the  that  had taken a gun across state lines and might thus be subject to a federal  review, when in fact he had not.\n\nNadler is a member of the Vote Blue Coalition, a progressive group and  created to support Democrats in New York, New Jersey, and Pennsylvania through voter outreach and mobilization efforts.\n\n\n\n*  (Ranking member)\n\n\n* \n** \n** \n\n\n* \n* \n* \n* \n* House Pro-Choice Caucus\n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\nNadler was unhappy with the passage of the surveillance-reform compromise bill, the , saying it \"abandons the Constitution's protections and insulates lawless behavior from legal scrutiny\".\n\n\n\nNadler compared Obama's acceptance of Republican demands to extend Bush-era tax cuts at the highest income levels to someone's being roughed up by the mob, asserting that the Republicans would allow the middle class tax cut only if millionaires and billionaires receive a long-term tax cut as well.\n\nNadler has proposed changing the income tax brackets to reflect different regions and their costs of living, which would have lowered the tax rate for New Yorkers. He has opposed tax breaks for high-income earners, saying that the country cannot afford it.\n\n\n\nNadler has a 100% rating from NARAL Pro-Choice America.\n\nNadler sponsored the  in 2004 and 2007. In 2009, he said he might soon re-introduce the bill.\n\n\n in 2004]]\nNadler supports , and  on the basis of  and .\n\nOn September 15, 2009, Nadler and two other representatives introduced the , a proposed bill that would have repealed the  and required the federal government to recognize the validity of same-sex marriages.\n\nIn 2019, Nadler supported the , a bill that would expand the federal  to ban discrimination based on sexual orientation and gender identity.\n\n\n\nIn March 2019, as the House debated President Trump's veto of a measure unwinding his declaration of a national emergency at the southern border, Nadler said: \"I'm convinced that the president's actions are unlawful and deeply irresponsible. A core foundation of our system of government and of democracies across the world, going back hundreds of years, is that the executive cannot unilaterally spend taxpayer money without the legislature's consent.\"\n\n\n\nIn 2015, Nadler voted to support an agreement to lift economic sanctions against Iran in exchange for Iran's compliance with the terms of the agreement which called for substantial dismantling and scaling back of their nuclear program.\n\n\n\nOf Trump's decision to  as the capital of  in December 2017, Nadler said, \"I have long recognized Jerusalem as the historic capital of Israel, and have called for the eventual relocation of the United States Embassy to Jerusalem, the seat of the Israeli government. While President Trump's announcement earlier today rightly acknowledged the unique attachment of the Jewish people to Jerusalem, the timing and circumstances surrounding this decision are deeply worrying.\"\n\n\nIn 2020, Nadler praised a judge for a ruling that could lead to the removal of 20 or more stories in an already-constructed 52-story luxury high-rise building in the Upper West Side of New York City. The developer had received a permit to construct the building, but the judge said the permit should not have been given.\n\n\nIn April 2023, Nadler was one of the 95 co-sponsors of H.Res.319, which calls for the creation of a .\n\n\n in 2024]]\nNadler introduced the  in July 2019 to  at the federal level by removing it from the . He said: \"It's past time to right this wrong nationwide and work to view marijuana use as an issue of personal choice and public health, not criminal behavior.\" In November 2019, the bill passed the House Judiciary Committee by a 24–10 vote, marking the first time that a bill to end cannabis prohibition had ever passed a congressional committee. In April 2022, it passed the full House of Representatives by a 228–164 vote.\n\n\nNadler was among the 46 Democrats who voted against final passage of the  in the House.\n\n\nOn July 7, 2024, it was reported that Nadler had expressed interest in Biden dropping out. This was during a call that  held with the committee leaders.\n\nBut on July 9, 2024, after a huddle with all the Democrats, Nadler said \"he is \"enthusiastically\" supporting Biden.\"\n\n\n\nNadler has had a  voting record in the House. He gained national prominence during the , when he described the process as a \"partisan railroad job\".\n\nHis Medicare proposal includes a section that provides for a consortium of organization to study Ground Zero illness.\n\n\nNadler and Josephine Langsdorr \"Joyce\" Miller wed in 1976. As of 2013, they lived in .\n\nIn 2002 and 2003, Nadler had   surgery, helping him lose more than .\n\n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n*  official U.S. House website\n* \n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''D. Billy Jones''' is the Assembly member for the 115th District of the . He is a . The district includes  and  counties as well as a portion of .\n\n\nJones is a lifelong resident of the , growing up on a dairy farm.  Following high school, Jones began work as a corrections officer with the New York Department of Corrections, where he worked for nearly twenty years. Jones has one daughter.\n\nFirst elected to public office in 2009, Jones first served as Mayor of  for four years and was elected to the Franklin County Legislature in 2010. He served as the Chairman of the legislature in from 2013 to 2016.\n\n\nIn 2016, Republican Assemblymember  announced that she would not seek re-election, opening up a possibly competitive seat.  Jones was recruited by the Democratic caucus, and decided ultimately to jump into the race. Facing Republican Kevin A. Mulverhill in the general election, Jones won by a 52% to 48% margin. He was the first Democrat to represent Clinton County in the state legislature in over half a century.\n\nJones was sworn in for his first term on January 1, 2017. With no opponent in the race, he ran unopposed and was reelected in 2018 for a second term.\n\n\n\n\n\n* official site\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Victor M. Pichardo''' (born August 27, 1984) is a former  member of the  representing 86th New York State Assembly District, which includes the university and Morris Heights, Mount Eden, Kingsbridge, Tremont, and Fordham sections of the .\n\n\nHe attended the  where he earned a Bachelor of Arts degree in communications.\n\nPichardo went on to work for U.S. Senator  as a staff assistant and was eventually promoted to Community Outreach Coordinator. During his time with Senator Schumer, Pichardo worked on such important issues such as Comprehensive , the  and the .\n\nAfter serving for 4 years in Senator Schumer's office, Pichardo became an associate director of Public Relations at . In 2012, Pichardo left Mercy to join New York State Senator 's staff as Director of Community Affairs.\n\n\nPichardo was elected to the New York State Assembly in a November 2013 special election. In the special election, Pichardo was endorsed by U.S. Senator , State Senator , and then-Bronx Democratic Party Chairman .\n\nIn 2014, Pichardo was re-elected to a full term in the  with 95 percent of the vote. He defeated challengers Rene Santos and Jose Marte.\n\nIn 2016, Pichardo was re-elected to a full term in the New York State Assembly with the highest  percentage of the vote.\n\nIn August 2021, Victor Pichardo announced that he will quit being a member of the New York State Assembly after serving 8 years (4 terms) representing his assembly district in the Bronx before the redistricting process begins.  He cited a need to spend more time with his wife and two children.\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n*\n*\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Anna Kaplan''' (née '''Monahemi''') (born August 23, 1965) is an Iranian-American politician from . A , she was a member of the , representing , which runs from the North Shore to roughly the central part of Western  on . She was a member of the so-called \"Long Island Six,\" a group of six Democrats who represent Long Island in the  and often vote as a block. She was elected in 2018 as part of a wave of Democrats who defeated  incumbents and brought control of the New York Senate to the Democrats for only the third time since World War II. She lost re-election in  to .\n\nKaplan is the first Iranian-American to be elected to either of New York state's legislative chambers and she is the first former political refugee to serve in the New York Senate.\n\n\nKaplan was born to an ish family in , , and raised in , where her father was a carpet dealer. When the  swept the country, Anna's parents sent her to the United States for safety at age 13. Arriving as an unaccompanied child refugee in , Anna was sent to live with a foster family in , until her parents were able to legally enter the United States. After her family reunited in Chicago, they moved to , and then to .\n\nKaplan attended the  at , and received her J.D. from  in New York City.\n\n\n\nKaplan started her political career as a member of the  Town Board in 2011, and served until her election to the state senate. She had previously served as a trustee of the Great Neck Public Library and was also a member of the North Hempstead Board of Zoning Appeals.\n\n\nOn January 11, 2016, Kaplan announced that she would run for the seat in the  for  being vacated by retiring congressman . Kaplan was defeated in the 2016 New York Congressional Democratic Primary by former Nassau County Executive . Suozzi won the general election.\n\n\nOn April 27, 2018, flanked by Nassau County Democratic Party Chairman Jay Jacobs and New York Governor , Kaplan announced her candidacy for the 's  to a large gathering of supporters and state and local Democratic elected officials at the \"Yes We Can Community Center\" in . On August 1, 2018, Kaplan became the first candidate for New York State office to be endorsed by former President .\n\nOn November 6, 2018, Kaplan defeated incumbent Senator  and won election to the New York State Senate with 55 percent of the vote.\n\n\nKaplan was Chairperson of the Senate Committee on Commerce, Economic Development and Small Business, and was a member of the Senate Committees on Children and Families, Internet and Technology, Judiciary, Mental Health and Developmental Disabilities, Transportation and Women's Issues. She was also a member of the Legislative Women's Caucus.\n\nIn January 2019, Kaplan was one of four new state senators spotlighted by the  in a piece on first-time New York senators.\n\n\nIn May 2023, Kaplan announced she would run for Congress in , seeking to succeed  in either the  or a special election if Santos were to resign or be expelled from the House.\n\n\nKaplan and her husband, Darren, live in , and have two college-age daughters.\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Stacey Pheffer Amato''' (born March 19, 1966) is a member of the , representing the 23rd district, which includes portions of . A conservative , Pheffer Amato was first elected in 2016.\n\n\nPheffer Amato was born in . Prior to holding office, she worked as an education paraprofessional for the  and as a procurement analyst for the  and the . She holds a bachelor's degree in business economics from the . She has been an active member of the Rockaway Beach Civic Association for years and is a committee member of the NY Rising Community Reconstruction Program, which is tasked with overseeing the state's recovery efforts from .\n\n\nIn 2016, Assemblymember  announced abruptly that he would retire. Pheffer Amato soon after announced that she would seek the Democratic nomination. With support from the Queens County Democratic Party, she was unopposed in the primary. She defeated Republican Alan N. Zwirn in the 2016 general election, 68% to 32%, to take the seat. She was easily re-elected in 2018.\n\nIn 2022, Pheffer Amato defeated her Republican opponents by just 15 votes. She was not declared the winner until January 2023, two months after the election.\n\n\nIn the Assembly, she is the Chair on the Subcommittee on Child Product Safety. Her mother, Queens County Clerk , previously held this Assembly seat. Upon Pheffer Amato's election, they became the first mother-daughter team to hold the same seat in the New York State Legislature.\n\n\nPheffer Amato and her husband, Frank, live in Rockaway Beach with their two children.\n\n\n\n\n\n* official site\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Christopher \"Chris\" Tague''' is an American politician, farmer, and businessman from the state of . A , Tague has represented the 102nd district of the , covering parts of the , since 2018.\n\n\nAfter graduating from high school in 1987, Tague ran a dairy business, selling it in 1992. From 1992 until 2017, Tague worked at Cobleskill Stone Products, eventually becoming the company's general manager. While Tague was the general manager, Cobleskill Stone was involved in a lawsuit filed by Mark Galasso that alleges financial malfeasance and also complains that one of the shareholders and Tague co-worker Mike Galasso, posted pro-Hitler tweets and co-ran a company with \"Eric Feight, the man recently sentenced to more than eight years in prison for supporting a plot to build an X-ray weapon to kill Muslims.\"\n\nHe also served as Schoharie Town Supervisor between 2016 and 2018.\n\n\nIn April 2018, upon the resignation of Republican Assemblyman  to become a regional administrator for the , a special election was held in the Assembly's 102nd district. After a closely fought campaign, Tague defeated  Aidan O'Connor 46-44%, with  candidate Wesley Laraway taking the remainder.\n\nBoth Tague and O'Connor ran for a full term . In a much higher turnout election, Tague defeated O'Connor by a wide margin, 56-44%.\n\nAfter   announced he wouldn't seek re-election to the  in 2020, Tague was mentioned as a potential candidate, but he declined.\n\nDuring the COVID pandemic of 2020, he voted against extending unemployment benefits and against temporarily halting evictions and utility shutoffs.  His other votes in 2020 include permitting the declawing of cats and biometric tracking of children in schools.  He also served as a delegate for Donald Trump at the 2020 Republican National Convention.\n  In 2022, he voted against a billthat was successfully passed into lawprotecting patients from hospitals and doctors who seek to garnish people's wages and place liens on their homes while collecting medical debt.\n\n\nTague was born and raised in , , along with 2 siblings. He continues to live in Schoharie.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Zach Iscol''' (born August 18, 1978) is an American , non-profit executive, politician, and  veteran who serves as Commissioner of . Iscol is a  veteran and was a  candidate in the .\n\n\nIscol was born in  and grew up in , in an affluent family. He is Jewish. His father is a cellphone technology entrepreneur, and his mother is an educator.\n\nHe graduated from  in 1997. In 2001, after competing for the school in  , he graduated from  with a major in government.\n\n\n\nIscol served two tours and served in  from 2001 to 2007 as a Captain in the , . During his service in Iraq in the , he fought on the front lines in the , as commander of a  composed of 30 U.S. Marines and 250 Iraqi soldiers.  He was awarded the  for bravery in combat in that battle, with , and the . After returning from Iraq, he successfully lobbied to bring his threatened Iraqi translator to the United States.\n\nHe returned to Iraq to make a film, '''', which was shown at the 2010 , and explored in what ways the US changed its tactics in Iraq over time. Iscol served as screenwriter, cast, director, and producer.\n\n\nIscol launched the Headstrong Project in 2012. It is a New York City-based  that provides veterans and their families in 25 cities with free  care.\n\nIscol co-founded '''' in 2014. It is a military-focused  company. Its parent company is Grid North Group. In 2018  Adam Weinstein resigned after CEO Iscol requested that he change the title of a  investigation into undue influence over the  featured on the site,  which Weinstein felt was undue influence on the publication's .\n\nIn 2014 Iscol also founded and became CEO of Hirepurpose, a hiring platform job website for military veterans and relatives.\n\n\nIscol served as a Deputy Director of a  during the  in the spring of 2020.\n\n\nIscol was one of a number of candidates looking to succeed  . He launched his campaign in the  on October 21, 2020, and was initially entered in the June 22, 2021,  primary. Iscol's campaign staff included , a national political strategist. As of mid-January 2021, he had raised more than $746,000 from donors, spent just over $261,000 on his campaign, and had about $485,000 left.\n\n\nOn January 26, 2021, Iscol filed paperwork to drop out of the mayor's race, and run instead in the . As of the end of January, he was the second-biggest fundraiser in the race. Iscol said his goal was to help the city recover economically from the pandemic, focusing on the performance of city agencies. He also said he would require companies that contract with New York City to describe their commitment to the five boroughs and that he would push to reinvest some pension fund monies in local job creation. Candidates who raised at least $125,000 from at least 500 donors qualified for  from the , on an 8-to-1 match basis.  As of February 16, 2021, he was one of three candidates who had qualified for , along with  and .\n\n\nOn February 17, 2022, Iscol was appointed commissioner of  by Mayor .\n\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n* '''', October 21, 2020.\n* '''', , January 19, 2021 (video)\n* '''', February 1, 2021  (video)\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Marcus James Molinaro''' ( ; born October 8, 1975) is an American politician serving as the  for  since 2023. A member of the , Molinaro was a member of the Dutchess County Legislature and the  before being elected county executive of  in 2011. He was reelected county executive in 2015 and 2019. Molinaro is also a former mayor of ; when he became mayor at age 19, he was the youngest mayor in the United States at that time. Molinaro was the Republican nominee for  in , losing to  incumbent .\n\nOn September 21, 2021, Molinaro announced that he would run for  in the  in . In the  held on August 23, 2022, Molinaro lost to Democratic nominee , the  executive, 51.2% to 48.8%. Molinaro was the Republican nominee for the same seat in the , this time defeating Democratic nominee  under new district lines. Ryan, who defeated Molinaro in August, was also elected to a full term simultaneously in a neighboring district. Riley defeated Molinaro in 2024.\n\n\nMolinaro was born in , to Anthony Molinaro and Dona Vananden. After his parents' divorce, he and his mother moved to , in 1980, and to , in 1989. Molinaro's mother struggled financially, and the family received . Molinaro graduated from  with an  degree in  and s.\n\n\nMolinaro was first elected to public office at the age of 18 in 1994, when he was elected to the Village of Tivoli's Board of Trustees. In 1995, he became the youngest mayor in the U.S. when he was elected mayor of Tivoli. He was reelected five times, and also served in the Dutchess County Legislature.\n\n\nIn 2006, Molinaro was elected to represent the 103rd District in the . He served in the Assembly until 2011. In January 2011, at the recommendation of Assembly Minority Leader , Governor  appointed Molinaro to serve on the Governor's Mandate Relief Redesign Team.\n\n\nMolinaro announced his bid to succeed 20-year  Executive William Steinhaus in May 2011. The campaign was endorsed by the county's Republican, Conservative, and Independence parties. On June 3, Beekman supervisor  won the Democratic nomination. Molinaro won the November 8, 2011, election with 62% of the vote. He was sworn into office on January 1, 2012. In 2015, Molinaro was reelected, defeating Democratic nominee Diane Jablonski, 30,181 votes to 17,539. Molinaro won a third term in 2019, defeating Democratic nominee Joseph Ruggiero, 41,285 votes to 29,293.\n\nIn 2014, Molinaro was awarded the Pace University Land Use Law Center's Groundbreaker's Award. As county executive, he spearheaded a 2015 initiative called \"Think Differently\" for people with disabilities; he also appointed a Deputy Commissioner of Special Needs in 2016. In 2015, Molinaro was elected second vice president of the New York State Association of Counties.\n\n\n\nIn March 2018, Molinaro informed Republican leaders that he would run for  in the . He announced his candidacy on April 2, 2018, and was endorsed by the  on April 13. On May 23, the Republican Party unanimously nominated Molinaro for governor at its state convention, three days after the  endorsed Molinaro for its gubernatorial ticket. Molinaro's running mate was Julie Killian, a former Rye City councilwoman and state senate candidate. While he was described as a moderate during the campaign, Molinaro said in a March 2018 interview that he considered himself a , explaining that he believed leaders need to bring together community members of different perspectives to solve the problems they face.\n\nMolinaro lost to incumbent governor  in the 2018 election, garnering 36% of the vote.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nOn September 21, 2021, Molinaro announced his candidacy for Congress in . Ten days after this announcement, his campaign reported raising at least $350,000. A special election to fill the 19th congressional district seat was held in August 2022. The seat was left vacant following 's appointment as . Molinaro lost the special election to Democrat .\n\n\n\n\nMolinaro was also the Republican nominee in the November 2022 general election in the 19th district. In that election, he faced Democratic nominee . He narrowly won the House seat with 50.8% of the vote.\n\n\n\n\nMolinaro sought reelection in 2024. He faced Riley in a rematch of their 2022 race. Riley defeated Molinaro.\n\n\nMolinaro was among a group of New York congressman calling for the ultimately successful expulsion of  from Congress.\n\n\n\n* \n* \n\n\nIn 2024, Molinaro was rated as the second most bipartisan member of the U.S. House during the  in the Bipartisan Index created by  and the . He has sponsored several bipartisan bills to help children and adults with disabilities.\n\nMolinaro supports . He said that he would have voted for the  had he been in office during the .\n\nIn 2022, Molinaro stated \"Like it or not, the  has determined in the  decision that this is a states rights issue. As such, I do not believe that Congress has any role to play in a woman’s right to access.\"\n\nDuring the 118th Congress, Molinaro voted for the Parents Bill of Rights in Education, a bill that would require public schools to disclose information including budget, curriculum, and school performance to parents.\n\n\nMolinaro and his wife, Corinne Adams, reside in . Molinaro had two children with his first wife and he has two children with Adams. One of his children is on the  spectrum.\n\nMolinaro is .\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n*  official U.S. House website\n*\n\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Gale Arnot Brewer''' (born September 6, 1951) is an American  politician from the state of  who has represented the 6th  district since January 2022, a position she previously held from 2002 to 2013. From January 2014 to December 2021, she served as the 27th  of the   of .\n\n\nBrewer graduated from the  in Boston in 1969, and then obtained a bachelor's from  in 1973 and a  from 's  in 1990. She then earned a second bachelor's from the  in 1997.\n\n\nFrom 1975 to 1978, Brewer served as director of scheduling for , the former . From 1978 to 1990, she was chief of staff to then- member . From 1990 to 1994, Brewer was director of the New York City Office of Federal Relations in New York in the administration of . From 1994 to 1998, she was Deputy Public Advocate for Intergovernmental Affairs under .\n\nBrewer then served as Project Manager for the NYC Nonprofits Project and worked with the , a private firm that builds affordable housing. She was a member of Manhattan's  and Chair of the New York State chapter of the . In 2000, she was cited by the '''' as #20 of \"50 New Yorkers to Watch\".\n\n\n\n\nBrewer began serving on the New York City Council in 2002. She represented the 6th district. In each re-election vote in 2003, 2005, and 2009, she received over 80% of the votes cast.\n\nBrewer has helped to pass legislation protecting s, establishing the , establishing an electronic death registration system and requiring New York City publications to be made available via the Internet, as well as two bills aimed at eliminating graffiti and unwanted stickers.\n\nBrewer chaired the Select Committee on Technology in Government (now the Committee on Technology) from 2002 to 2009 In June 2004, in conjunction with a graduate student Digital Opportunities Team at  departments of Urban Affairs and Planning supervised by Professor Lisa Tolliver, the committee published a study and recommendations titled ''Expanding Digital Opportunity in New York City Public Schools: Profiles of Innovators and Leaders Who Make a Difference''. The report was one of numerous initiatives and events implemented by the Select Committee, which included roundtables, conferences, hearings, and .\n\n\nIneligible to run for re-election to the City Council in 2013 because of term limits, in February 2013, Brewer announced she would run for . On September 10, 2013, Brewer won the Democratic primary, taking nearly 40% of the vote in a four-way race. Brewer won the general election on Tuesday, November 5, 2013, and assumed office in January 2014.\n\nBrewer was re-elected Manhattan Borough President in 2017. Due to term limits for borough presidents, she was ineligible to seek re-election in 2021.\n\nIn the , Brewer served as an alternate , replacing .\n\n\nIn December 2020, Brewer announced her candidacy for her former City Council seat in the . She lost the  endorsement to another Democrat Sara Lind and requested a second endorsement vote from the organization prior to the June Democratic Primary in 2021. On November 2, 2021, Brewer defeated Republican  (wife of ) with over 82% of the vote. Brewer's main progressive Democratic primary challenger in 2021, Sara Lind, was not reappointed to Manhattan Community Board 7 when her position came up for renewal in 2023.\n\nBrewer chairs the . She is a member of the Committees on Consumer and Worker Protection, Finance, Governmental Operations, Higher Education, and Rules, Privileges, and Elections. In addition, she is a member of the Manhattan Delegation, the Women's Caucus, and sits on the Budget Negotiating Team.\n\nBrewer is running for the City Council's new  in 2023.\n\nBrewer is a member of the Vote Blue Coalition, a progressive group and  created to support Democrats in New York, New Jersey, and Pennsylvania through voter outreach and mobilization efforts.\n\n\n\nIn 2018, the  awarded Gale Brewer an honorary doctorate citing her \"long career on critical issues facing New York City from affordable housing and land use to health care and workers rights\". \n\n\nBrewer is married to Cal Snyder. Their son, Mo Sumbundu, works for . In 2023, Sumbundu was appointed by Governor  to the  Council. Brewer has had several .\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Harry B. Bronson''' (born May 22, 1959) is an attorney and politician from  who serves as a member of the . A former member of the  legislature, he was elected to the Assembly in 2010. He is a .\n\nBronson represents the 138th district, which encompasses parts of the city of Rochester as well as the towns and villages of  and .\n\n\nBronson grew up on a 200-acre farm outside  and became a Rochester resident in 1991. He holds a B.A. from  and a  from . He runs a private law practice in Rochester and served as counsel to the state Assembly Labor Committee from 2004 to 2010. From 2001 to 2004, he was a member of the Rochester City Planning Commission and served as Vice Chair in 2004. He also co-owns Equal=Grounds coffee house and serves as an adjunct professor at  in .\n\n\nBronson was first elected to the county legislature in 2005, running on the Democratic,  and  ballot lines in the 24th district. He outpolled his Republican opponent (also running on the  line) by 67 percent to 33 percent. Upon taking office, he was immediately elected assistant minority leader by the legislature's Democratic caucus, assuming the post of minority leader in October 2007. He sought re-election in 2009 and, running on the Democratic and Working Families lines, won with 65% of the vote.\n\n\nWithin a week of Susan John announcing in January 2010 that she would not seek an eleventh term in the assembly, Bronson declared his candidacy for the newly open 131st district seat. He won the endorsement of the Monroe County Democratic party as well as organized labor. He faced two primary opponents, both members of the Rochester school board. In the primary election held on September 14, 2010, he gained 40 percent of the vote and won by a margin of 244 votes (6.0%).\n\nIn the general election held on November 2, Bronson (also running on the Working Families Party line) polled 16,318 votes, defeating his Republican opponent by 55% to 45%.\n\n\nBronson is openly gay. He is the first openly  member of the  from .\n\nBronson was the co-owner of Equal=Grounds, a coffeehouse in the South Wedge neighborhood of , before selling the business in December 2023.\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Michael J. Norris''' (born April 12, 1976) is the Assembly member for the  of the . He is a . The district includes portions of  and  counties in .\n\n\nNorris was born and raised in  and attended . He is a graduate of  and . He was admitted to the New York State Bar in 2006. As an attorney, Norris has focused on real estate, contracts and estate planning. He has served as the attorney for numerous towns in Niagara County, as well as a town prosecutor.\n\nA former aide for both the  and the , he has also been politically engaged as an elections commissioner.\n\n\nIn 2016, Assemblywoman  announced that she would not seek re-election after four terms. The , a reliably Republican district, had its three counties, Erie, Niagara and Orleans choosing Norris to replace her through their county Republican organizations.  He was unopposed for the Republican nomination, as well as for the general election.\n\nNorris was sworn into office on January 1, 2017.\n\nIn 2024, Norris announced on social media that he would not be seeking re-election to the New York State Assembly. He instead would be pursuing a seat for the New York State Supreme Court. He was endorsed on the Republican, Democratic, and Conservative lines.\n\nHis term ends on December 31, 2024.\n\n\nhttp://niagarafallsreporter.com/indicted.html Norris Granted Immunity\n\n\n* official site\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Fernando Cabrera''' (born April 18, 1964) is an American politician in . A , he formerly represented the  in the , including the neighborhoods of Claremont Village, , , , , Mount Eden, , and .\n\nCabrera is a  Democrat. He is an opponent of  and opposes .\n\n\nCabrera was born in  to a  father and  mother. He received a B.A. in Religion from , a M.A. in Counseling from , and a Doctorate in Education from .\n\n\nIn 2009, Cabrera challenged  to a  for the  nomination for  in the Bronx. With the backing of The Bronx Democratic Committee and the endorsement of key unions, Cabrera was able to defeat the incumbent by just over 1% difference in three-way race that included . Cabrera followed that by winning the general election against  Yessenia A. Duran and  Lisa Marie Campbell. He won reelection in 2013.\n\nIn 2014, Cabrera challenged Senator  in the Democratic primary, but lost 59% to 41%. During his primary bid against Rivera, Cabrera attracted ire for his opposition to abortion & gay marriage, as well as his apparent praise of an anti-gay Ugandan law. In a video posted on Youtube and later deleted, Cabrera, speaking from Uganda, said, \"Gay marriage is not accepted in this country. Why? Because the Christians have assumed the place of decision-making for the nation.\"\n\nCabrera challenged Rivera again in 2016, but lost by a larger margin, 63% to 37%.\n\nOn September 12, 2017, Cabrera won 55% of the vote in the , to 35% for challenger Randy Abreu and 10% for Felix Perdomo.\n\nOn January 11, 2018, Cabrera was elected Majority Whip and Chairman of the Committee on Governmental Operations.\n\nIn 2019, Cabrera announced that he was going to challenge  in the Democratic primary for , while criticizing her embracing of . On March 1, 2020, Cabrera announced that he was ending his primary bid against Ocasio-Cortez and that he would instead be running for the position of Bronx  in 2021.\n\nCabrera lost this borough president race to , the then-chair of the council's Committee on Public Safety. She is the first woman to hold the position of Bronx borough president.\n\nIn February 2022, after New York City mayor  named Cabrera a senior advisor in the city's  Office of Faith-Based and Community Partnerships, LGBT groups objected to the appointment, citing Cabrera's history of opposing same-sex marriage.\n\n\n\n\nCabrera is the senior pastor of New Life Outreach International in the  area of the Bronx. He is a former program director for the Mental Health and Counseling program at .\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Selvena N. Brooks-Powers''' (born March 1, 1983) is an American politician and community organizer serving as a member of the  from the . She assumed office on March 19, 2021.\n\n\nBrooks-Powers was raised in , . She earned a Bachelor of Arts degree in sociology from  and a Master of Science in global affairs from .\n\n\nBrooks-Powers began her career as a staffer to Democratic members of the . She later worked on 's campaign for . In 2012 and 2013, she worked as a communications specialist for the . She also worked as a press officer in the office of the . Brooks-Powers has since worked as an independent political consultant. She was elected to the  on March 19, 2021.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''David S. Carlucci''' ( ; born April 3, 1981) is an American politician in . A member of the , he was the state senator for the , which includes most of  and parts of  until December 2020. Carlucci was one of the youngest senators elected to the  in 2010 at just 29 years old.[3] Carlucci served as the chair of the Committee on Mental Health and Developmental Disabilities.\n\nIn October 2019, Carlucci announced his bid for the  for . to replace retiring Representative . He lost to attorney  of Rockland County in the Democratic Primary.\n\n\nCarlucci was born in , and raised in Rockland County. He attended  and ran track. He graduated from  in 2000. He went on to attend  and graduated with a Bachelor of Science degree in industrial and labor relations in 2002.\n\n\nCarlucci worked as a financial planner for  from 2002 to 2003 and worked in 's office as a staff assistant from 2004 to 2005.\n\nIn 2003, Carlucci made his first political run for the office of  in the . Carlucci lost to the 28-year incumbent, Republican Patricia Sheridan. In 2006, he defeated Sheridan by 294 votes at the age of 24.\n\n\n\n\nFollowing the Monsey Hanukkah stabbing in December 2019 which came amid a state-wide and national increase in anti-Semitic crimes and incidents, Senator Carlucci collaborated with former Governor Andrew Cuomo to draft a bill to create a formal state statute against domestic terrorism. Together, they passed the \"Josef Neumann Hate Crimes Domestic Terrorism Act of 2020\" named after one of the victims of the stabbing. The bill was implemented into New York State law through the 2020 budget and exists as the first domestic terrorism law in the nation. The assailant of the 2022 Buffalo shooting, who shot and killed 10 Black people in a supermarket, was the first individual to be charged under the domestic terrorism statute.\n\n\nIn May 2010, Carlucci announced his candidacy for the Democratic nomination for  in District 38. That same month incumbent,  announced he would not be seeking re-election. Morahan who was 78-years-old was seeking treatment for Leukemia. In June 2010, Rockland republicans nominated then Rockland County Executive C.  over Rockland County Legislator Ed Day, as the Republican nominee. Carlucci defeated Vanderhoef and won 53 percent of the vote, picking up a seat that had not been held by a Democrat since 1984. He was one of the youngest senators elected to the  at just 29-years-old.\n\nCarlucci went on to win four more general elections. He also defeated a primary challenger, Julie Goldberg, in 2018. All of his former IDC colleagues faced similar primary challenges and most were defeated.\n\n\nCarlucci has passed more than 130 bills that were signed into law since 2011. He supported the SAFE Act, raise the age of criminal responsibility, a $15/hr minimum wage plan, and paid family leave policy.\n\nIn 2014, Carlucci's bill to create a relapse prevention program to combat heroin addiction in New York State would be signed into law by Governor Cuomo. David Carlucci secured funding for the Nyack Skate Park “Working with my colleagues in the Senate, we were able to secure a grant that will finally [let Nyack] complete this project,” said Carlucci. “It makes it easier when it comes from the ground up…when the community really comes together and sees that vision.” \n\nDavid Carlucci Co-sponsored legislation to redesign the handicap logo after 45 years. Carlucci explained “New York is again leading the way by being the first state in the Nation to update our outdated ‘handicap’ signs with a more active, engaging symbol. Working together we will continue to be a shining example for disability rights throughout the country,” \n\nIn 2015, Carlucci proposed legislation to create the Mental Illness Anti-Stigma Fund which would later be signed into law by Governor Cuomo. The Mental Illness Anti-Stigma Fund will support critical programs to eliminate the stigma surrounding mental health issues and received funding from a tax check-off box which appeared on state income tax forms. Carlucci declared “The signing of this bill into law is the first step to eliminating the stigma of mental illness from our society, New Yorkers can now directly help end the stigma by making a donation that will fund mental health public awareness campaigns across the state.\"\n\nDavid Carlucci sponsored legislation making the heroin - overdose antidote Naloxone available over the counter. Carlucci stated In a letter to state Health Commissioner Howard Zucker,  \"As the number of overdoses increases, so should the amount of people who have access to naloxone, By issuing a standing order, you will make naloxone, which has not been shown to be a dangerous drug, more accessible, and in turn save more lives.\"\n\nDavid Carlucci proposed an arrangement where Marydell whose views overlooks the Hudson and is contiguous with 1,831 acres of state parkland would become public land. David stated \"This is an excellent opportunity to expand Hook Mountain State Park,\" \n\nIn 2016, Carlucci sponsored a bill to review the precautions at rail crossings after deadly accidents which would later be signed into law by Governor Cuomo. Carlucci illustrated in a statement \"We need to seriously examine why the number of crossing accidents has increased in New York, and what we can do to fix them as soon as possible.\"\n\nDavid Carlucci called for renewed investment to restore the Vanderbilt-Budke House & adjacent Farmhouse on the Traphagen property in Clarkstown.\n\nIn 2017, David Carlucci sponsored legislation banning tobacco discounts coupons in New York State. \"Time and time again, we've seen that as prices go up for tobacco products, the usage declines,\" Carlucci said Monday. \"(Coupons and discounts) are a way for big tobacco companies to get around the high prices of cigarettes.\"\n\nDavid secured funding for Grace VanderWaal's show choir in the East Ramapo district elementary school. Carlucci stated \"East Ramapo students are lucky to have Grace VanderWaal as a role model for them and helping make this new choir a reality,\"\n\nIn 2019, Carlucci sponsored legislation requiring the State Office of Mental Health to regularly review suicide prevention programs and recommend changes to be meet the needs of at risk individuals and address risk factors for minority and underrepresented populations. Carlucci also sponsored legislation to establish a Black Youth Suicide Task Force to address an increasing rate of suicide among black children ages 5-years to 18-years-old. The task force would be made up of mental health professionals with knowledge of the black community who can examine, evaluate and determine remedies to tailor youth suicide prevention efforts in the back community.\n\nDavid Carlucci championed the Heatstroke Elimination Awareness Technology (HEAT) Act, which would require cars in the state to have detection systems installed. The intent was to force automakers to make the change on a national level similar to how California lawmakers have set nationwide emissions standards. Carlucci explained “Unless they're required to make these safety features, they don't do them, This is not some scientific theory, This is being done in other places.”\n\nCarlucci co-sponsored the Climate Leadership and Community Protection Act (CLCPA); the law aims to have New York's electricity entirely from emission-free sources by 2040 and reduce greenhouse gas emissions by 85% by 2050. Carlucci also sponsored the Green Amendment, a constitutional amendment to the New York State Constitution which guarantees “each person shall have the right to clean air and water, and a healthful environment.” \n\nCarlucci sponsored legislation allowing 16-year-olds to pre-register to vote. David Stated “When young people are engaged from any early age they stay engaged, By eliminating barriers to register and increasing education, we are strengthening our democracy.\"\n\nDavid Carlucci sponsored several pieces of key legislation which requires an independent, comprehensive, forensic audit of the MTA. An audit would show how, and where, the MTA gets and spends its money, ensure that drivers facing cashless-tolling fines would not have their credit scores adversely affected by late payment of bills. Drivers who live in Westchester and Rockland counties could see their toll reduced by 60% when crossing the Gov. Mario M. Cuomo Bridge. However drivers who intentionally skip out on paying a toll can be charged with a Class “A” misdemeanor, which can carry a maximum of one year in jail or three years of probation. Additionally, a judge may impose a fine up to $1,000 additionally drivers who previously incurred fees and fines on any MTA crossing could have the penalties waived, under a six-month amnesty program, similar to the one used by the Thruway Authority.\n\nCarlucci sponsored legislation in 2019 banning employers from asking job applicants their salary history as a requirement for a job interview, job application, job offer, or promotion. Carlucci sponsored legislation signed into law, allowing survivors of domestic violence to report the incident of abuse to any law enforcement agency in New York State, regardless of where it happened.\n\nIn 2020, Carlucci's amended version of Dream's Law was signed by Governor Cuomo. The bill requires hospitals to have a discharge plan in place before a person can leave. Carlucci sponsored Lauren's Law, which requires individuals who apply for a driver's license to complete the organ donor registry section of the application by selecting either “yes” or “skip this question.”  Carlucci helped expand the Elderly Pharmaceutical Insurance Coverage (EPIC), which provides discount drugs for senior citizens.\n\nCarlucci sponsored the Pension Poaching Prevention Act. The will crackdown on scammers trying to profit off a veteran's service by selling them financial products they don't need or charging them to apply for benefits they do not quality for. In 2013, Carlucci sponsored a bill that was signed into law called Jobs for Heroes, which gives a tax credit to businesses for hiring returning veterans.\n\nCarlucci sponsored Legislation Banning Crib Bumper Pads. “As a parent, it's our job to protect our children, and I simply cannot imagine how the families are coping who have lost a newborn due to crib bumper pads,” said Former Senator David Carlucci. “We know these accessories are not safe due to the risk of suffocation or strangulation of a baby and yet they are still marketed to parents as a matching nursery accessory. It's time we ban their sale in New York State and prevent further tragedies.”  In 2019 Senate Bill S3788A was signed into law by the NYS governor.\n\nIn 2020, Carlucci proposed legislation which would later be signed into law by Governor Cuomo.  Before Carlucci's legislation New York State law required all front seat passengers to wear seat belts, while people under the age of 16 wear seat belts whether they're seated in the front or back seats. Carlucci's legislation requires everyone to wear seat belts in the backseat of a vehicle, no matter the age of the passenger.  Carlucci stated while on the chamber floor “The simple fact is that you're not any safer in the back seat, So we have to make that message loud and clear by passing this legislation.” \n\nDavid Carlucci sponsored legislation to rename a portion of Route 45 \"The Sandra L. Wilson Memorial Highway \"“Sandra Wilson was attacked for no reason. She was at the library simply doing her job,\" Carlucci said Wednesday. \"She was known to patrons for her warm smile and friendly demeanor. This roadway will serve as a reminder of her kindness and ensure her legacy is remembered in Spring Valley and the entire State of New York.” \n\nCarlucci sponsored legislation which made it illegal for employers to ask about applicants salary history. David stated “Now, New Yorkers can talk about their qualifications and not their past wages in an interview, For too long, the salary history question was used by some employers to justify low pay and low raises for women and women of color. We are now working to close the gender wage gap and ensure equal pay for equal work.” \n\nDavid Carlucci championed legislation which shortened New York States suicide hotline to 988 \n\nDuring the Covid-19 Pandemic, Carlucci sponsored legislation which would be signed into law by Governor Cuomo which guarantees schools will not lose state funding due to COVID-19 closures. Carlucci explained \"Our School districts need every penny as potential cuts could be devastating, Schools should not be penalized for making necessary decisions in the wake of the COVID-19 pandemic.\"\n\n\nOn January 5, 2011, David Carlucci entered into the Senate and formed the  (IDC), with three other Democratic senators, , , and . The formation of the IDC created a third legislative conference in the State Senate. The senators said the IDC would \"push for commonsense solutions to the problems facing New York State, break the hyper-partisan gridlock that has gripped the Senate and work to restore the public's trust in its public officials.\" In 2013, the IDC and the Senate Republicans announced a majority coalition agreement. Their Democratic colleagues called the move a power grab and liberal Democrats blamed the group for enabling a Republican agenda.\n\nIn April 2018, the IDC was dissolved and Carlucci joined the Senate Democratic Conference. In the 2018 Democratic Primary, Carlucci defeated challenger Julie Goldberg by a 54% to 46% margin, becoming one of only two former IDC members, along with , to defeat primary challengers.\n\n\n\nIn October 2019, Carlucci announced his bid for . Previously, Congresswoman , who represents the district, had announced she would not be seeking another term and would be retiring after 30+ years in office. After Carlucci announced his run, he told the Journal News that he has \"the experience, work ethic, energy to get the job done. For me, public service isn't just a job or career: it's my life.\" The focuses of his campaign include education, climate change, gun reforms, women's rights, and comprehensive immigration reform. He lost the primary to .\n\nHis campaign was endorsed by various organizations including Laborers local 754, IOUE local 825.\n\n\nIn June 2017, several members of the IDC, including Carlucci, sent a pro-choice mailer to their constituents that, according to , “misleads constituents by implying electoral support from Planned Parenthood.” The mailer used the Planned Parenthood logo and read \"Supported by Planned Parenthood\" on the front. In a letter to the IDC, Planned Parenthood stated that they had not made any endorsements and misuse of their logo \"undermines confidence and integrity in this endorsement process.\" The mailer also touted Carlucci's support of two major pieces of pro-choice legislation, the  and the Comprehensive Contraception Coverage Act, while referring to both bills by the wrong names. A spokesperson for the IDC said in a statement: \"Constituents have a right to know where their senators stand on women's health issues and this is what the IDC communicated to voters. Every member of the IDC supports women's health rights and universally stand at the ready to pass these vital issues.\"\n\n\nIn 2021, Carlucci was recognized on The City & State New York Mental Health Power 50 list. \"Serving in the state Senate between 2011 and 2020, David Carlucci focused on mental health care and substance abuse policy, including as chair of the Mental Health and Developmental Disabilities Committee beginning in 2013 and as co-chair of a joint task force on opioid addiction and overdose prevention. Since he left office at the start of the year, he has continued to use his expertise as a consultant for organizations navigating local and state mental health care bureaucracy.\"\n\n\nOn January 15, 2011, Carlucci married his high school sweetheart and longtime girlfriend, Lauren Grossberg. Grossberg is a Rockland County native and an elementary school teacher. The pair met in high school on the track team. They have two children. They live in the town of .\n\n\n }}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n }}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n*\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Walter Ward''' (January 1, 1911 – November 8, 1994) was a member of the  for a quarter of a century, serving 13 terms from 1968 until 1993. Ward, who took courses at the , was the owner of the Ward Advertising Company, which specialized in outdoor signs. Ward sold the business in 1971 to devote himself solely to representing the  of the City Council, which incorporated , , , , and the . Towards the end of his tenure, Ward was the oldest member of the legislative body, and had earned the unofficial title \"Dean of the Council.\"\n\nThroughout his 25 years in office, Ward worked ardently for clean beaches and against airplane noise, issues at the heart of his constituency near the coast and around . Ward became chairman of the City Council Committee of Parks, Recreation and Cultural Affairs, and a member of the Council's General Welfare Committee. Ward also cast one of the deciding electoral votes for President  (1917-1963) after being named a  for  in the . Ward continued to be involved in Democratic politics until his death, serving as Democratic District Leader in  after being defeated in the 1993 City Council election.\n\nIn addition to his political activities, Ward served on various community boards and organizations, such as the 101st Precinct Community and Youth Council, the Ozone Howard Little League, and the Wyckoff Heights Hospital Advisory Board. Ward died of cancer on November 8, 1994, at the age of 83.\n\nPS 232 in  and the playground for PS 207 in  have been named in his honor.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Carl Andrews''' was a member of the  from  from 2002 to 2006.  A , he represented , , , , and .\n\nA graduate of  – with an MA in  from SUNY-Albany – Andrews' first stint in public office came in 1981, when he sat on a community school board in the 17th District, . He's also served as a member of Community Board 8.\n\nAndrews has taught as an adjunct professor at both The College of New Rochelle and at his alma mater, Medgar Evers College. In addition, he has served as Attorney General Eliot Spitzer's Director of Intergovernmental Relations.\n\nIn February 2002, Andrews ran for an open seat in the  and won a special election to fill the vacancy left when Marty Markowitz won the race for Brooklyn Borough President in November 2001.\n\n\n\nAndrews was one of four Democratic candidates vying to represent the 11th Congressional district of  in a hotly contested, volatile race.\n\nEven though he was endorsed by influential New York politicians, including Attorney General , State Senator , New York City Comptroller , he was also subjected to criticism for his decision to remain in this race-thus potentially splintering the African-American vote in a divided primary-especially after another African-American candidate, Assemblyman Nick Perry, withdrew from the race in May.\n\nCarl Andrews was also the subject of criticism from some quarters for his close association with former chairman of the  , and Assemblyman, Clarence Norman, who was forced to resign from his official positions as a result of his indictment and conviction on multiple felony counts of violating election law in late 2005.\n\nOn August 14, 2006, Andrews received the endorsement of the New York State . In order to receive the endorsement Andrews need the support of over two-thirds of the union membership, which union president Dennis Hughes stated Andrews had achieved.\n\n\nOn September 12, 2006, Andrews was defeated in a four-way Democratic primary, garnering nearly 23% of the vote, and coming in third.\n\n\n\nAndrews participated in a debate broadcast by  on August 24, 2006, stating that former Kings County Democratic Leader Clarence Norman \"did some good things as county leader and some bad things as county leader\". He also took highlighted several high-profile endorsements from leading members of the New York State Democratic Party, such as state  , and state Attorney General and gubernatorial candidate Eliot Spitzer.\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n*\n*\n*\n* \n*\n*\n*\n*\n*\n*\n*\n* Endorsement by The Jewish Press.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Judy Griffin''' is an American author and politician, and former member of the , representing the 21st district which includes portions of the town of  in  on . A , Griffin was first elected in 2018.\n\nBorn and raised on , Griffin holds a Bachelor of Science in Business Economics with minors in Political Science and Communication from the . She later worked in the financial industry, including at . An integrative health coach, Griffin founded a health coaching business and co-founded a corporate wellness business. She also authored the book ''Flourish Beyond 50''. For many years, she advocated for the betterment of public education on Long Island. Griffin previously served as Director of Community Outreach for state Senator .\n\nIn 2018, she decided to run for the  in District 21 against incumbent Republican  of  who had held the seat since 2010. In the  on November 6, 2018, Griffin unseated Curran, 51% to 46%. It is the first time a Democrat has held the seat in 42 years. In the s on November 8, 2022, Griffin narrowly lost her seat back to Curran in a rematch, 50.1% to 49.9%, a margin of 138 votes.\n\nGriffin and her family have resided in  for nearly 30 years.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''B. John Tutuska''' (December 4, 1911 &ndash; July 30, 1993)  was the second  in , serving from 1969 to 1971. The -born  Tutuska succeeded  in 1969 after Rath died in office. Prior to being appointed county executive, Tutuska served as Erie County Sheriff from 1959 to 1969. \n\n\nTutuska defeated then Common Council member , future mayor of  in a special election held on November 4, 1969, 55% - 45%. During that election, a major campaign issue was the claim by Makowski that Tutuska was responsible for the failed  domed stadium project. Tutuska was the endorsed GOP candidate for reelection in 1971 when he suffered a heart attack. While he was recuperating from his heart attack he was challenged to a primary election by . Rather than run in the primary, he withdrew from the race and the GOP nomination went to Regan, who subsequently defeated , mayor of Buffalo, in the general election. \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Justin Lee Brannan''' (born October 14, 1978) is an American politician and musician. A , he is the current member for the , based in . A former musician, he was a founding member of the  bands  and .\n\n\nBrannan is an outspoken  and animal welfare advocate. A Third Degree Master , Brannan founded the Bay Ridge Democrats, an active Democratic political club based in southwest Brooklyn. In 2012 he was named one of the \"New York City Rising Stars: 40 Under 40\" by ''City & State'' newspaper for his work as Director of Communications and Legislative Affairs for man .\n\nBrannan is married to artist and educator Leigh Jewel Holliday. The couple were married in the lobby of  where they met as employees. Brannan and Holliday opened a fine art school for children in Bay Ridge called The Art Room.\n\nBrannan attended  in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn. He studied journalism and mass media at  and . He has worked for  and . He later worked as a commercial announcer for , where he was the de facto  for the American Federation of Television and Radio Artists. While at WNEW, Brannan represented and defended the interests of his fellow employees and advocated to get all union employees retroactively paid for decades of overtime work on weekends and overnights.\n\n\n\n\nBefore entering politics, Justin Brannan was a  guitarist for the bands  from 1993 to 2000 and  from 2000 onwards. Both bands were known for their outspoken commitment to social justice and . The band’s messages focused on social justice, human rights, , relationships, individuality and espousing  views against drugs, alcohol and promiscuous sex.\n\nIndecision is widely known for their song \"Hallowed be Thy Name\". The song features a lyric (\"For Those I Love I Will Sacrifice\") wrote by Brannan when he was sixteen years old that fans across the world have turned into a . Most famously, an image of the tattoo was seen on the ribs of a 19-year-old US Army infantryman named Kyle Hockenberry being treated in a medevac helicopter following an explosion that cost him both of his legs and one arm. The photo was taken for a military newspaper and won photographer Laura Rauch an award from the . Brannan also works closely with the 9/11 Stephen Siller Tunnel to Towers Foundation commemorating the heroes of 9/11 and \"Building for America’s Bravest\", a program that constructs Smart Homes for military returning home with devastating injuries.\n\nBrannan also founded the  band , known for using two dogs as vocalists.\n\n\nBrannan was a touring punk rock musician before he landed at , working his way up as a clerk in their wealth management division, and working as a financier in the  space raising money for start-up  companies based in . He later worked as a fundraising consultant for a number of non-profit humanitarian organizations in New York City.\n\n\nBrannan served as the Director of Communications and Legislative Affairs for Council member , representing the  which includes , ,  and portions of .\n\n\nIn 2017, Brannan won the Democratic primary to replace Gentile in the 43rd district. Brannan won 39% of the vote in a five-way race, narrowly beating , who garnered 31% of the vote, by 682 votes.\n\nBrannan drew criticism during the campaign for taking money from real estate interests. Contributors to Brannan's campaign include Sal Raziano of the real estate firm Casandra Properties and Anthony Constantinople of Constantinople & Vallone, a lobbying firm currently under investigation for conflicts of interest and payroll discrepancies surrounding its Sports & Arts program at a Lower East Side public school.\n\nDuring the campaign, several concerned citizens filed a complaint with the  in which they accused Brannan of neglecting to disclose campaign expenses when he failed to alert election regulators that Gentile’s campaign for Brooklyn DA paid the rent for Brannan’s campaign office.\n\nIn the general election, Brannan won with 51% of the vote to the Republican candidate, John Quaglione's 47%. Brannan won by a slightly smaller margin in the .\n\n\n\nFollowing the decision by New York City Comptroller  to challenge incumbent  in the 2025 Democratic primary for mayor, Brannan opened a campaign account for Comptroller.\n\n\n\nIn May 2021, a former aide to ex-City Councilman , Michael Bistreich, settled a lawsuit with New York City for $850,000 where he alleged Justin Brannan bullied him. Judge Verna Saunders ultimately found Bistreich had established a strong case for discrimination. \n\nIn June 2023, 72-year-old Democratic District Leader Charles Ragusa filed an ethics complaint with the New York City Council alleging that Justin Brannan threatened him. A representative for Justin Brannan confirmed the councilman threatened to oust Ragusa from his party leadership position (but disputed the use of expletives, as had been alleged by Ragusa).\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
          }

    "pages": }\n'''Crystal Davis Peoples-Stokes''' (born December 22, 1951) is an American politician representing Assembly District 141, which includes the city of  within . She is currently the Majority Leader of the .\n\n\nPeoples-Stokes attended , where she earned her  degree in elementary education and  in student personnel administration.\n\n\nShe worked as a member of the  Legislature representing the 7th District from 1993 to 2002.\n\nIn 2000, Peoples-Stokes, a member of  and the majority leader of the Erie County Legislature, ran against incumbent Assemblyman . The race was described by '''' as the toughest election contest of Eve's political career.  Peoples-Stokes's Democratic  challenge was almost successful, and it was credited with energizing minority voters to elect  as a .\n\nPeoples-Stokes was elected to the State Assembly in November 2002, after Eve's retirement. She ran uncontested in the November 2008 and November 2010 s.\n\nOn December 17, 2018, Peoples-Stokes was appointed Majority Leader of the New York State Assembly, becoming the first woman and first African American to serve in the role.\n\nIn the , People-Stokes served as an alternate , replacing .\n\n\nPeoples-Stokes lives in , with her daughter Rashaun and grandson Kaleb Malik.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Velmanette Montgomery''' (born December 22, 1942) is an American  politician who represented the  of the  from 1984 until 2020. The district comprised , , , , , , and , among other neighborhoods located within the borough of .\n\n\nMontgomery was born in , but relocated to New York City to attain a  in  from . She later became a Revson Fellow at .\n\nPrior to elected office, Montgomery worked as a , , and  director as well as the cofounder of the Day Care Forum of . She has also served as president of Community School Board 13.\n\nIn 1991, Montgomery was awarded an   from .\n\n\nMontgomery was first elected in 1984, succeeding , who did not run for re-election that year. She has been re-elected seventeen times, never facing serious opposition.  Montgomery has never lost an election.\n\nIn the Senate, Montgomery is the Chair of the Senate Committee on Children and Families. She is a  advocate, sponsoring legislation on the topic, and a longtime nurse practitioner advocate. She was an original sponsor of legislation to legalize s to stop the spread of , wrote the law banning , and sponsored a current law that prohibits the  in the granting of funeral or bereavement leave to workers in committed s.\n\nIn 2013 Montgomery was secretly recorded at the home of then-Senator , as revealed in a federal corruption probe of Huntley. The probe centered around former Senator Huntley who pled guilty to embezzling over $87,000 in taxpayer money. Montgomery was never accused of wrongdoing in the probe.\n\nIn 2019, Montgomery was elected Majority Conference Secretary.\n\nOn January 11, 2020, Montgomery announced that she would be retiring from the State Senate and not seeking reelection in 2020. She endorsed Assemblywoman  in her retirement announcement.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n*\n*\n*\n*\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Patrick Kevin Ryan''' (born March 28, 1982) is an American businessman,  politician, and veteran serving as the  for  since 2023. He served as the representative for  from 2022 to 2023 after being elected in a . He previously served as the  of .\n\n\nRyan was born and raised in , the son of Patricia L. and Kevin M. Ryan. He earned a  in international politics from the  in 2004 and a Master of Arts in security studies from . Two of his West Point classmates are fellow Congressmen  and . \n\nRyan served in the  as a military  from 2004 to 2009, including two tours in Iraq. From 2009 to 2011, he worked as the deputy director of Berico Technologies, as a subcontractor for  in Afghanistan. He co-founded Praescient Analytics, a software company, in 2011. From 2015 to 2017, he was a senior vice president of , an  platform. In 2018 and 2019, Ryan was a senior adviser at New Politics.\n\n\nIn February 2019,  Executive  resigned to take a position in  's administration. On April 30, Ryan defeated Republican nominee Jack Hayes in the special election to succeed Hein; he took office on June 7, 2019. He became the second executive of Ulster County since it adopted a county charter in 2008. In November 2019, he defeated Hayes in a rematch to win a full four-year term as county executive.\n\nAs county executive, Ryan piloted a  program, wherein 100 families in the county received $500 per month. He also enacted several environmental protections in Ulster County, committing to fully transition the operations of the county government to renewable energy by 2030 and partnering with  to promote green energy jobs.\n\nOn January 14, 2020, Ryan endorsed  in the . In a statement, Ryan cited Buttigieg's military service, his \"bold progressive vision\", and his \"moral leadership\" as his reasons for support.\n\nOn September 9, 2022, Ryan stepped down as Ulster County Executive. The deputy county executive, , was sworn in as acting county executive that day.\n\n\n\n\n\nRyan first ran for the  in 2018. In the Democratic primary in , he received 18% of the vote to 's 22%. Delgado defeated incumbent Republican representative  in the general election.\n\n\n\nAfter Delgado resigned from Congress on May 25, 2022, to become , Ryan announced that he would run in the special election to succeed Delgado. Ryan was chosen as the Democratic nominee on June 9 at a meeting of Democratic county party chairs.\n\nIn the August 23 special election, Ryan faced the Republican nominee and  Executive . Ryan was seen as the underdog as every poll had him trailing Molinaro, and many believed that President 's unpopularity would hinder Democrats in the swing district. Ryan narrowly defeated Molinaro by 2,858 votes, 51.1%–48.8%, which was considered an upset. He outperformed Biden's  margin in the district by 0.8%. In explaining his victory, political observers noted that Ryan campaigned strongly in favor of protecting  in the wake of the  ruling in '''', which overturned ''''. His victory was attributed to college-educated voters', particularly women's, support for abortion rights.\n\nMolinaro and Ryan both ran for Congress again in the  for the newly redrawn  and , respectively. Each won in his respective district.\n\n\n\nIn November 2022, Ryan contested the state's , which was changed from its previous configuration after redistricting. On the same day as his special election victory in the 19th district, Ryan won the Democratic nomination for the regular election in the 18th district. He defeated Republican nominee  in the general election.\n\n\n, after the ]]\nOn February 1, 2023, Ryan was among twelve Democrats to vote for a resolution to end  national emergency.\n\nRyan is a staunch opponent of  in the most congested parts of Manhattan.\n\nOn July 10, 2024, Ryan called for  to withdraw from the .\n\n\n*\n*\n\n\n*\n* \n* Pro-Choice Caucus\n\n\n\n\nRyan was born and raised in , where he lives with his wife and two children. His grandfather served on the Kingston City Council.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n* official U.S. House website\n* campaign website\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Andrew P. Raia''' (born May 8, 1968) is an American politician from Long Island, New York. A Republican, Raia became the clerk of the town of Huntington, New York on January 6, 2020. Raia previously served in the New York State Assembly representing the 9th and 12th districts, respectively.\n\n\n\nAndrew P. Raia was born and raised in . He holds a  in political science from the , from which he graduated in 1991. Prior to his election to the Assembly, he was a staffer in legislative offices in both houses of the New York state legislature, as well as the .\n\nIn 2002, Assemblyman  announced that he would run for the , leaving his district open. Soon afterward, Raia announced that he would run for the seat. The Democratic candidate, Mark Cuthbertson, was favored to win. However, Raia took the seat that fall, 50% to 47%. He won his re-election campaigns easily. Raia represented Assembly District 9 from 2003 to 2013. Following redistricting, he represented Assembly District 12 beginning in 2013. Raia served as Assistant Minority Leader in the Assembly.\n\nRaia was elected Huntington Town Clerk on November 5, 2019, defeating Simon Saks of Dix Hills. Thereafter, he resigned his Assembly seat. Raia was sworn in as Huntington Town Clerk on January 6, 2020; he succeeded his mother, Jo-Ann Raia, who had held the post for 38 years.\n\nRaia resides in .\n\n\n\n\n\n\n-->\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n\n'''J. Kemp Hannon''' (born January 10, 1946) is an American politician. A , Hannon was a member of the  from the  in  between 1989 and 2018.\n\n\nHannon graduated from  (1963),  (1967) and  (1970). During the presidential primary season of 1976, Hannon was a panelmember for an episode of '''', discussing whether  or  was the better nominee.\n\nHe was Special Counsel to the law firm Farrell Fritz, P.C., ending the association on January 31, 2017. Hannon resides in , with his wife Bronwyn and their twin daughters, Alexandra and Madeleine.\n\nHannon served in the  from 1977 to 1989, sitting in the , , , , ,  and s. In 1989, he was elected to the  to fill the vacancy caused by the resignation of . Hannon represented the 6th State Senate District, which includes , , , , , , , , , , , , , Island Trees and .\n\nA Republican, Hannon chaired the New York State Senate Health Committee for nearly two decades.\n\nIn 2011, Hannon voted against allowing same-sex marriage in New York during a Senate roll-call vote on the Marriage Equality Act, which passed after a close 33-29 vote. On January 14, 2013, Hannon voted in favor of the NY SAFE Act (a gun control bill), which the Senate passed 43-18. On June 10, 2014, the State Senate passed medical marijuana legislation that was later signed into law by Gov. Andrew Cuomo; Hannon, along with nine other Senate Republicans, voted against the bill.\n\nOn November 6, 2018, after having served 29 years in the New York State Senate, Hannon was unexpectedly defeated in his re-election bid by Democratic challenger .\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
