    "pages": }\n'''Micah Z. Kellner''' (born December 5, 1978) is an  from the state of . A , he was formerly a member of the  from the 76th district, which includes 's  and . Kellner was elected to the Assembly in 2007 and served until 2014, when he did not stand for reelection.  In September 2013, he lost the primary election for the Democratic nomination for the  seat for the 5th District to attorney . During his Assembly tenure, Kellner was admonished twice by , then the Assembly Speaker, based on findings that he had engaged in sexual harassment.\n\n\nAn advocate for disabled people, Kellner was born with . He attended the , graduating in the class of 1997. He graduated from  in 2001 with a  in ,  and . He worked as an aide to Senator , Congresswoman  and City Comptroller  before being elected to the Assembly in 2007.\n\n\nFollowing the appointment of Assemblyman  as Commissioner of New York State's Department of Environment Conservation early in 2007, Kellner was selected as the Democratic nominee for the special election held to fill the vacancy. In that election, held on June 5, 2007, he received 64% of the vote, comfortably defeating his Republican opponent.\n\nDuring the 2013–14 term of the Legislature, Kellner became Chair of the Assembly Committee on Libraries and Education Technology.  On June 27, 2013, Kellner chaired a hearing on \"The Sale of Public Library Buildings in New York City\" at which Pulitzer-Prize-winning author Edmund Morris testified against the 's controversial Central Library Plan.\n\nIn August 2010, New York State's Governor, , signed \"Elle's Law,\" legislation introduced by Kellner that allows for the suspension of up to six months of the New York State driver's license of any driver inflicting serious physical injury on another person while committing a traffic violation. The law was named after Elle Vandenberghe, a three-year-old Upper East Side girl living in Kellner's district who was seriously injured after being struck by a motorist who was illegally backing through an intersection against a red light to find a parking space.\n\nHe also sponsored ''Oreo's Law''  in the New York State Assembly, which required the release of a shelter animal to a rescue group upon request of the rescue group prior to euthanasia of the animal. The law is named in memory of Oreo, a dog who survived abuse at the hands of her former owner, recovered from her injuries, but was then euthanized by the ASPCA in New York City, despite the offer of a No Kill sanctuary to guarantee her lifetime care.\n\n\nIn early 2013, Kellner announced his intentions to run for the New York City Council seat in District 5 being vacated by . Initially, he received significant support, being endorsed by most local elected officials. In late June, however, the ''New York Post'' reported that he had accepted a campaign contribution from a taxi manufacturer whose handicapped-accessible vehicle was being considered for adoption by New York's Taxi and Limousine Commission.\n\nOn July 23, 2013, '''' reported that in 2009 Kellner had engaged in inappropriate Internet chat with a young female staffer. Kellner apologized in a statement to the Times, saying, \"Over four years ago, for a few weeks while I was still single, I exchanged instant messages with a female member of my staff that were flirtatious. It was inappropriate. I was wrong and it was stupid. When I was told that my staffer felt the messages were unprofessional, I immediately stopped and regretted placing her in that position. I was sorry then and I am sorry now.\" The ''New York Daily News'' subsequently quoted an anonymous source identified only as a former Kellner staffer saying that Kellner had made life \"horrible\" for the other staffer after she had allegedly rebuffed his advances.\n\nFollowing the media reports, several elected officials withdrew their endorsement of Kellner in the City Council race, including Lappin, Manhattan Borough President , and two state senators (Jose Serrano and Brad Hoylman). The day after the allegations against Kellner were revealed, the New York City chapter of the  endorsed one of his two opponents in the Democratic primary for City Council, .  rescinded its support as well, and endorsed Kallos, who went on to defeat Kellner in the September 10, 2013 primary.\n\nIn August 2013, the state's ethics commission launched an investigation into sexual harassment allegations against Kellner. That December, following an investigation by the Assembly Ethics Committee, Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver publicly admonished Kellner for taking actions that created a hostile work environment; Silver also stripped Kellner of a committee chairship and banned him from hiring interns. On December 31, 2013, New York Governor Andrew Cuomo stated that Kellner should deny the sexual harassment allegations or resign.\n\nIn June 2014, Silver announced the closure of Kellner's Albany and district offices, and the elimination of Kellner's staffing budget, on the grounds that Kellner had \"engaged in additional sexual harassment beyond the matters that were the subject of the 2013 investigation,\" as well as hired an intern in spite of being explicitly told he was prohibited from doing so.\n\n\nIn 2014, two challengers announced they would run against Kellner's political club's state committee candidate. When the club's original candidate dropped out of a competitive Democratic primary, Kellner received his club's endorsement. Kellner characterized the win as a favor to his club, and not as an attempt at a political comeback. Following his victory for the obscure position, Kellner insisted it was a myth that he was not popular anymore in his district. Kellner won with nearly 57 percent of the votes in the three-way race.\n\nIn 2015, Kellner was re-nominated by his political club to run for re-election as district leader, an unpaid position he had held since 2012. Adam Roberts ultimately won the race, garnering 53% of the votes to Kellner's 47%.\n\n\nKellner is openly  and was the first openly bisexual person elected to the . February 21, 2009  His 2007 campaign won the support of the , which provided financial and strategic assistance. In 2009, he received the , which \"recognizes an individual or organization whose work on behalf of the  Community best exemplifies the vision, principles and community service of the late bisexual rights activist , and who serves as a positive and visible role model for the Bisexual Community.\" He was one of six openly  members of the , alongside Assemblymembers , ,  and , as well as Senator . His 2011 marriage to Marie Ternes, a former chief of staff to , ended after she filed for divorce in 2013.\n\n\n* '''June 2007 , NYS Assembly, 65th AD'''\n\n:\n\n* '''November 2008 , NYS Assembly, 65th AD'''\n:\n\n* '''November 2010 , NYS Assembly, 65th AD'''\n:\n\n* '''November 2012 , NYS Assembly, 76th AD'''\n:\n\n* '''September 2013 , Democratic Party, NYC Council, 5th District'''\n:\n\n* '''November 2013 , NYC Council, 5th District'''\n:\n\n* '''September 2014 , Democratic Male State Committee, 76th AD'''\n:\n\n* '''September 2015 , Democratic Male District Leader, 76th AD, Part B'''\n:\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n* \n* \n* \n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Jarett Gandolfo''' (born June 22, 1990) is an American politician who is a member of the  from the 7th district. Elected in 2020, he assumed office on January 1, 2021.\n\n\nGandolfo is of  descent. Gandolfo was raised in  and graduated from . He earned a Bachelor of Arts degree in criminology and sociology from  and a  from .\n\n\nPrior to his election to the , Gandolfo served as 's chief of staff. When Garbarino was elected to the , Gandolfo announced his candidacy to succeed him. Gandolfo defeated Democratic nominee Francis T. Genco in the November election and assumed office on January 1, 2021.\n\nOnce in office, Gandolfo became a vocal critic of Governor 's use of COVID-19 pandemic emergency powers, especially the 10pm curfew imposed on restaurants and bars. Gandolfo argued that the curfew was arbitrary, ineffective, and greatly harming the food service industry.\n\nGandolfo currently sits on the Health, Higher Education, Insurance, Mental Health, and Racing and Wagering committees.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''George A. Amedore Jr.''' (born April 2, 1969) is an American homebuilder, businessman, and  politician. Amedore formerly represented the  in the . The district encompasses all of  and  Counties and portions of , , and  Counties.\n\nFrom 2007 to 2013, Amedore represented the 105th District in the . At the time, this district included all of  and part of .\n\n\nAmedore was born and raised in Schenectady County. As of 2011, he was Vice President of Amedore Homes, a business founded in 1974 by his father, George Amedore, Sr. In 2007, Amedore and his family business were \"featured on ABC-TV's \"Extreme Makeover -- Home Edition\" when they \"brought together dozens of subcontractors to build a 3,600-square-foot home at no cost\" for a local family.\n\n\nAmedore was first elected to the State Assembly on July 31, 2007 in a special election to fill a vacancy created by 's appointment by Governor  to lead the . Amedore ran against Democrat Ed Kosiur, a Schenectady County legislator.\n\nAmedore was re-elected to the Assembly in 2008 and 2010, defeating Democrats Mark Blanchfield and Angelo Santabarbara, respectively.\n\n\nRather than seeking re-election to the Assembly in 2012, Amedore chose to run for the  in . The district was a newly drawn district stretching from Montgomery County to . Although there were more registered Democrats than Republicans in the district, Amedore was initially favored because he had represented the entire northern portion of the district for five years.\n\nAmedore trailed Democrat  on election night, but legal action by Amedore forced a judge to monitor the counting of 6,000 provisional and absentee ballots. The judge threw out 450 votes, enough to give Amedore a 37-vote lead. Amedore was certified as the winner and filed his oath of office in January. However, Tkaczyk appealed, contending that since the ballots were primarily in Democratic-leaning areas, she could potentially win if they were all counted.  Eventually, a court ordered 99 ballots in , , and  counties opened. Tkaczyk picked up enough votes in the opened ballots to take an 18-vote lead. Amedore conceded the race on January 18. At the time, according to the '''', Amedore was the shortest-tenured senator in the modern history of that chamber.\n\nAmedore ran against then-incumbent Senator Tkaczyk in the 2014 elections and won. He was re-elected in 2016, defeating challenger Sara Niccoli by a wide margin. He again won reelection in 2018.\n\nPrior to Democrats taking the majority, Amedore served as Chair of the Senate Alcoholism and Drug Abuse Committee and the Senate Technology and Innovation Task Force. He also served as Co-Chair of the Heroin Task Force.\n\nAmedore received the 2019 Oil Slick Award from Environmental Advocates for what they deemed to be his consistently-poor environmental record.\n\nIn November 2019, Amedore announced that he would not seek re-election to the Senate in 2020.\n\n\nAmedore resides in  with his wife Joelle. The Amedores have three children: George, Anthony, and Bria. Amedore is a Christian. As of 2011, Amedore was a member of Calvary Tabernacle  Church in Schenectady.\n\n\n* '''July 2007 , NYS Assembly, 105th AD'''\n:\n\n* '''November 2008 , NYS Assembly, 105th AD'''\n:\n\n* '''November 2010 , NYS Assembly, 105th AD'''\n:\n\n* '''November 2012 , NYS Senate, 46th SD'''\n:\n\n* '''November 2014 , NYS Senate, 46th SD'''\n:\n\n* '''November 2016 , NYS Senate, 46th SD'''\n:\n\n* '''November 2018 , NYS Senate, 46th SD'''\n:\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Nicole Malliotakis''' ( ; born November 11, 1980) is an American politician serving as the  for  since 2021. Her constituency covers  and southern .\n\nMalliotakis is the only  representing any part of  in Congress, and is one of five female Republican elected officials in New York City, with the other four serving on the . In 2020, she defeated incumbent Representative . She was the Republican nominee for  in the , which she lost to incumbent Democrat .\n\n\nMalliotakis was born on November 11, 1980, in the  borough of . She moved to  when she was two years old and grew up in , the daughter of  parents; her father is from  and her mother from , having  following the rise of . She was raised in the  faith.\n\nMalliotakis attended  on Staten Island, and during her senior year was elected class president. She received a  in  from  and a  (MBA) from .\n\n\nMalliotakis worked as a community liaison for former State Senator  in 2003&ndash;04 and former Governor  in 2004&ndash;06. Before her election, she also worked on state energy policy as the 's .\n\nIn November 2015, Senator  of  named Malliotakis the New York State chair of .\n\n\n\nIn 2010, Malliotakis won the election to represent the 60th District in the , defeating two-term  incumbent  by 10 percentage points. Upon her election to the Assembly, she became the first  woman elected to office in New York State, the first  woman elected to office in New York State, and the first person of  descent elected from . As of January 2018, she was one of only two Republicans from the City of New York serving in the Assembly, along with  Malliotakis was Brooklyn's only Republican lawmaker.\n\nIn October 2011, Malliotakis submitted an '''' brief in support of an  lawsuit against the  in federal court, arguing that recent toll increases were illegal. She successfully brought an Article 78 proceeding in New York State Supreme Court to get the Port Authority to disclose the results of an  on the effect the toll increases had had on business at .\n\nMalliotakis was reelected in 2012 with 61% of the vote and in 2014 with 73% of the vote in both Brooklyn and Staten Island. After U.S. Representative 's resignation in 2014, she was mentioned as a top contender for his seat, but decided against a run.\n\nShe made  a hallmark of her tenure and successfully fought to keep a  in  from being closed.\n\nMalliotakis held a series of forums on the  and its alleged negative impact on es, s, and s. The  and Governor  subsequently enacted significant s. Malliotakis fought for relief from the September 2011  increase on Port Authority bridges, calling for  of costly non-essential  and highlighting mismanaged contributions to s.\n\nDuring her first year in the Assembly, Malliotakis was named a \"rising star\" by ''Capitol News'', ''Home Reporter News'', the Hispanic Coalition of New York, and the Greek America Foundation. The Business Council of New York State named her a \"top-ranking pro-jobs supporter\".\n\n\n\n\nOn April 25, 2017, Malliotakis filed as a Republican candidate for  in the . She won the Republican nomination unopposed after businessman Paul Massey dropped out in June over money concerns. On November 7, 2017, Malliotakis lost the election to incumbent Democratic Mayor , 66–28%. She received 70% of the vote in Staten Island.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nIn 2020, Malliotakis ran as the Republican nominee for  against incumbent Democrat . Her state assembly district included much of the eastern portion of the congressional district.\n\nThe race was considered the only potentially competitive House race in New York City. The 11th has long been the most conservative district of the 12 that divide New York City; it is the only one with a  less than D+20, and since the 1990s it has been the only New York City-based district where Republicans usually do well. The GOP had held the seat for all but one term since  before Rose won the seat in an upset in the . The two engaged in a contentious race, with many attack ads on both sides.\n\nMalliotakis endorsed incumbent Republican President  in the ; in turn, Trump announced, \"Nicole has my Complete & Total Endorsement!\" She embraced Trump's backing, saying, \"I am honored by President Trump's endorsement and his words of support...I plan to defeat Max Rose and return New York's 11th Congressional District to commonsense leadership.\"\n\nMalliotakis declared victory upon taking a commanding lead in election day returns on November 3. Rose did not immediately concede, citing absentee votes yet to be counted. As it became apparent that Malliotakis's lead was too large to overcome, Rose conceded on November 12. Malliotakis took 53% of the vote to Rose's 47%.\n\n\n\n\nIn 2022, Malliotakis ran for a second term against former Democratic congressman  in a rematch of her previous race. She declared victory on election night, and Rose conceded defeat shortly afterward; Malliotakis took 62% of the vote to Rose's 38%.\n\n\n\n\nIn 2024, Nicole Malliotakis was re-elected for a third term in the United States House of Representatives, defeating Democratic challenger Andrea Morse. Nicole Malliotakis garnered 64.49% of the vote, compared to Morse's 35.12%, securing a decisive victory in New York's 11th Congressional District.\n\n\nIn January 2021, Malliotakis was appointed as the Assistant Minority Whip for the Republican Conference, the House Committees On Foreign Affairs and Transportation & Infrastructure, as well as the Select Subcommittee on the Coronavirus.\n\nOn February 4, 2021, Malliotakis joined 10 other Republican House members and all Democrats in voting to strip  of her  and  assignments in response to controversial political statements she had made. Malliotakis called Greene’s comments \"extraordinarily offensive and hurtful to thousands of 9/11 families and first responders, our Jewish community and many others in my district.\"\n\nOn November 5, 2021, Malliotakis joined 12 other Republicans in voting for the , which passed the House 228–206.\n\nIn January 2023, Malliotakis was selected to serve on the  in the 118th Congress; she is the only House member from New York City to serve on the committee this term and the first Republican from the city to serve on the committee in 30 years.\n\n\n\n* \n** Subcommittee on Tax\n** Subcommittee on Oversight\n* \n* Assistant Whip for the \n\n\n* \n* \n* \n* \n*\n* Congressional Hellenic Caucus \n* Congressional Hellenic Israel Alliance Caucus\n* Republican Israel Caucus\n* US-Lebanon Friendship Caucus\n* Congressional Zoo and Aquarium Caucus\n* Law Enforcement Caucus\n* Armenian Caucus\n* SALT Caucus\n* \n* Congressional Egypt Caucus\n* Congressional Cigar Caucus\n* Friends of Ireland Caucus\n* Congressional Hispanic Conference Caucus\n\n\nDuring her time in Congress, the , a  (PAC) supporting , gave her a 66% score for voting in line with its positions while the , a PAC associated with  and , gave her a 0% score. Upon her election to Congress, Malliotakis indicated an intent to join other freshman Republicans in forming a counterweight to oppose the so-called \"\" of progressive Democrats; the coalition is known as the Freedom Force.\n\n\nShortly after  defeated Trump in the , Malliotakis  Biden's win, echoing Trump's refusal to concede the election. In the aftermath, Malliotakis supported Trump's .\nOn January 6, 2021, Malliotakis  either Arizona's or Pennsylvania's electoral votes in the 2020 presidential election based on disproved allegations of voter fraud and unconstitutional procedures. On January 9, more than 300 protesters, including seven New York City and New York State elected officials, gathered outside her Brooklyn office to call for her to either vote to  Trump or resign. On January 13, she voted against  for inciting the storming of the Capitol.\n\n\nAs a state legislator, she received a 100% rating in 2011 from the New York State Right to Life Committee, an  PAC, and a 50% rating in 2019 from  Empire State, a  PAC, indicating how often she voted with their positions. During her run for mayor, she said, \"I am not against abortion.\" She does not support overturning '''', but has voted against taxpayer-funded abortions and against New York state's late-term abortion bill. During her run for mayor, she did not identify as pro-life or pro-choice, saying, \"it's not black or white. I think there's a lot of things that go into a decision of that magnitude.\" But in her congressional campaign, she identified as pro-life, even as she reiterated that she does not \"hold black-and-white views\" on abortion.\n\n\nMalliotakis voted against the  in 2021, but after its passage, she touted aspects of the legislation as one of her \"achievements\".\n\n\nMalliotakis voted for Trump in the  and opposes  status for undocumented immigrants in New York City. During her mayoral campaign, she said that she regretted voting for Trump and that she would \"write in Marco Rubio so that I could tell you I voted for Marco Rubio.\" In 2020, however, she endorsed and said that she voted for Trump.\n\n\nOn legislation relating to firearms and , Malliotakis received an 8% rating from the , a PAC opposing , and a \"C-\" grade from the , another PAC opposing gun control legislation.\n\n\nMalliotakis has repeatedly called for the implementation of additional security measures on the .\n\nWhile in the State Assembly, Malliotakis said she was \"against New York State extending licenses for illegal immigrants\".\n\n\nOn November 5, 2021, Malliotakis was among the 13 House Republicans who voted with a majority of Democrats to pass the , a $1.2 trillion infrastructure spending bill.\n\n\nAfter originally opposing same-sex marriage, Malliotakis said she regretted that position and voted to support adoptions by same-sex parents and to protect estate rights for married same-sex couples. She voted against a bill relating to bathroom rights for transgender people. Malliotakis also voted against the . She has been endorsed by , a Republican PAC in favor of same-sex marriage and other .\n\nOn July 19, 2022, Malliotakis and 46 other Republican Representatives voted for the , which would codify the right to same-sex marriage in federal law. She said, \"In 2017, I expressed my deep regret for voting against a bill legalizing same-sex marriage in New York State while in the state Assembly six years prior. Over the past decade, I have attended two weddings of couples who deserve equal recognition and protection under the law.\" On December 8, 2022, she and 38 other Republican representatives voted for the final passage of the Respect for Marriage Act.\n\n\nMalliotakis opposed raising fees on plastic bags in New York and supports reducing bridge tolls. She proposed a plan to cut property taxes for seniors and to limit increases on property taxes.\n\n\nIn 2022, Malliotakis was one of 39 Republicans to vote for the Merger Filing Fee Modernization Act of 2022, an antitrust package that would crack down on corporations for anti-competitive behavior.\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}} \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nMalliotakis is , speaking English and  fluently and some . She was baptized into the .\n\n\n*\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n*  official U.S. House website\n*\n*\n\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n \n|-\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Joseph R. Lentol''' (born January 15, 1943) is former representative for District 50 in the , which comprises ,  and , among other neighborhoods located in the northern portion of the   of . He is a .\n\n\nLentol was born on January 15, 1943, the son of State Senator and Supreme Court Justice  (1909–1981).\n\n\n\nLentol was first elected to the  in 1972. He has served as Chairman of the Committee on Codes since 1992, and has previously served as Chairman of the Committee on Governmental Employees and the Assembly Committee on Governmental Operations.\n\nIn 2000, he was one of two Assembly members chosen by  and Governor  to serve on the Election Modernization Task Force. The following year, he was elected by his colleagues to represent the Brooklyn Assembly Delegation and appointed to New York City's Community Action Board, of which he later became Chairman.\n\nPrior to his election, Lentol served as an Assistant  within .\n\nIn 2001, Lentol was elected by his colleagues to direct the Brooklyn Assembly Delegation, responsible for making decisions and advocating for funds and activities for all areas of the borough.\n\nAs the Chair of the Assembly Committee on Codes, between 2004 and 2005 Lentol contributed to a report regarding hearings on the . He credited the hearings with changing his mind regarding the death penalty  which he had in 2004 \"wanted to see done right.\"\n\n\n\nOn June 23, 2020, Lentol was challenged in the Democratic primary for the first time since 2010. It was the fourth primary of his career. His opponent was community activist , who he led by 1,763 votes on election night. However,  were more significant than usual due to the , and once they were counted, Gallagher was determined to have won by between 400 and 600 votes on July 21, 2020. Lentol conceded on July 22, 2020.\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n*\n*\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Carlos Menchaca''' (born September 11, 1980) is an American politician who served as a member of the  for the . He is a . His district included the  neighborhoods of , , , and portions of , , and . In October 2020, Menchaca declared his candidacy in the , but suspended his campaign in March 2021, three months before the primary.\n\n\nMenchaca was born and raised in . The first in his family to attend college, he earned a Bachelor of Arts degree from the , where he studied  and social justice.\n\n\nPrior to assuming office, Menchaca worked in the Brooklyn Borough President's Office, as ’s Capital Budget and Policy Coordinator from 2005 to 2011. From 2011 to 2013, Menchaca served as a liaison to the LGBT and HIV/AIDS community for the Office of the Speaker in the New York City Council.\n\nMenchaca, along with Councilman , was arrested in January of 2015 at a rally for carwash workers.\n\n\nIn the , Menchaca defeated incumbent  in the Democratic primary for  in the , which includes a portion of . He won the seat in the general election on November 5, 2013. Upon his election, Menchaca became the first  elected to public office in , and the first openly gay New York City Council member from Brooklyn.\n\nMenchaca has been criticized for derailing redevelopment of the . In July 2020, Menchaca said he \"strongly opposes\" plans to rezone and redevelop . Due to City Council customs, Menchaca had the power to effectively end the project.\n\nMenchaca chaired the immigration committee in the city council and serves on the following committees: Recovery & Resiliency, Small Business, Standards & Ethics, General Welfare, and Transportation. He formerly served as the chairman of the Brooklyn Council delegation.\n\n\n\nOn October 9, 2020, Menchaca registered a campaign with the  and released a statement on social media about a potential run for mayor in the . On October 22, he posted a video on his Twitter account officially announcing his candidacy for mayor. As of mid-January 2021, Menchaca had raised approximately $62,000 from donors, spent $48,000 on his campaign, and had about $14,500 left. Menchaca ended his campaign on March 24, 2021 and later endorsed  for mayor.\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n*\n* \n* \n*  by the \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n| birth_place         = , U.S.\n| death_date          = \n| death_place         = \n| spouse              = Gail Skelos\n| children            = 1\n| alma_mater          =  () ()\n| caption             = Skelos in 2012\n}}\n'''Dean George Skelos''' (born February 16, 1948) is an American former politician from Long Island, New York.\n\nA , Skelos served in the  and later represented the  in the  from 1985 through 2015. He served as Senate Majority Leader in 2008 and again from 2011 to 2015.\n\nSkelos forfeited his Senate seat when he was convicted on federal corruption charges in 2015. In 2017, his conviction was overturned following the U.S. Supreme Court decision in ''''. His retrial resulted in a second conviction on July 17, 2018. Skelos was sentenced to four years and three months in prison, and he began his prison term in January 2019. In April 2020, Skelos tested positive for  and was released from prison to serve the remainder of his sentence under .\n\n\nSkelos was born on February 16, 1948, in ,''New York Staff Directory 2007'' (CQ Press), p. 108. the oldest of four children.Yancey Roy, , ''Newsday'' (May 7, 2011). He is the grandson of a . Skelos graduated from  in  with a  in history in 1970 and earned a  from  in 1975.\n\nSkelos was  to Ruskin Moscou Faltischek, P.C., from 1994 through 2015. Skelos was automatically disbarred in 2016 following a felony conviction.\n\n\n\n\nSkelos was elected to the New York State Assembly in 1980.\n\n\n\nAfter one Assembly term, Skelos ran for State Senate in 1982, challenging incumbent Democratic-Liberal   . The reapportionment earlier that year changed the boundaries of the 9th Senate District, which previously included parts of Nassau and Queens County. The new district, drawn by Senate Republicans, was entirely within Nassau County and favored Republicans. Skelos was endorsed by the Republican and Conservative parties. Berman, running on the Democratic Party and Liberal Party lines, won the race by 6,108 votes (55,504 to 49,396). Matthew Doyle, the Right-to-Life Party candidate, received 2,520 votes in the three-way race.\n\nIn 1984, Skelos challenged Berman in a rematch. This time, Skelos, who had President  visit the district and campaign for him, narrowly defeated Berman in a two-way race, winning by 50.7% to 49.3% (67,834 to 65,875 votes). Skelos represented Senate District Nine from 1985 to 2015.\n\nIn 1986, Berman challenged Skelos in their third consecutive state senate contest. Skelos, running on the Republican and Conservative Party lines, defeated Berman, the Democratic and Liberal parties' candidate, in a three-way race, winning 53% of the vote (49,761) to 43.7% (41,005). Right-to-Life party candidate Joan McDermott received 3.2% (2,967) of the vote.\n\nFrom 1995 to 2008, Skelos was Deputy Majority Leader of the New York State Senate. In 2008, he became the Majority Leader of the New York State Senate after  stepped down from that post.\n\nOn June 24, 2011, Skelos voted against allowing same-sex marriage in New York during a senate roll-call vote on the , which narrowly passed the Senate in a 33–29 vote. In a statement made prior to the vote, he said: \"This is a very difficult issue and it will be a vote of conscience for every member of the Senate.\"\n\nIn 2013, as Senate Majority Leader, Skelos was responsible for suspending Senate rules and bringing the  (a firearm-related bill) to the Senate floor. He voted for the SAFE Act and advocated its passage.\n\nOn May 4, 2015, Skelos was arrested on federal corruption charges. On May 11, he stepped down from his position as Senate Majority Leader. Skelos was convicted on December 11, 2015; he was automatically expelled from the Senate due to his conviction.Benjamin Weisner, , ''New York Times'' (September 26, 2017).Benjamin Weiser & Vivian Yeemay, , ''New York Times'' (May 12, 2016)(''Limited access'').\n\n\nSkelos and his son, Adam Skelos, were arrested and charged with six counts of  by U.S. Attorney  on May 4, 2015. The criminal complaint included , , and  solicitation charges. Skelos was accused of taking official actions to benefit a small Arizona environmental company, AbTech Industries, and a large New York developer, , that had financial ties to AbTech. According to the complaint, Senator Skelos agreed to do so as long as the companies paid his son.\n\nOn May 28, 2015, Skelos and his son were indicted by a federal grand jury on six counts of bribery, extortion, , and conspiracy.\n\nAfter his arrest, Skelos asserted that he and his son were innocent. He stepped down from his majority leader post in the Senate on May 11, 2015; he had already begun a leave of absence from the law firm of Ruskin Moscou Faltischek. \"The criminal complaint against him said he had earned $2.6 million there since 1994, despite apparently doing no actual legal work; he was paid instead for referring clients, some of whom had business before the state.\"\n\nIn July 2015, in an expanded indictment, federal prosecutors added two new charges of soliciting bribes from a Long Island company in return for favorable legislation. The new indictment charged that Skelos procured a position for his son at a medical malpractice insurance company with business before the state, that Adam Skelos was not qualified for the position, that Adam Skelos threatened his supervisor, and that Adam Skelos asserted that \"he didn't need to show up to work because his father was the Majority Leader of the State Senate\".\n\nOn December 11, 2015, a unanimous jury convicted Dean and Adam Skelos of all eight counts of bribery, extortion, and corruption. Dean Skelos was convicted of using his position in the Senate to benefit three companiesa real estate developer, an environmental technology company, and a medical malpractice insurerin exchange for the companies' agreement to give work to his son. Prosecutors said that the three businesses provided Adam Skelos with about $300,000 and other benefits. The trial verdict automatically terminated Dean Skelos from the state legislature. On May 12, 2016, U.S. District Judge  sentenced Dean Skelos to five years in prison, and Adam Skelos to six-and-a-half years in prison. Wood allowed both to remain free on bail pending appeals based on the 's decision in '''', in which the court reversed the corruption conviction of a former Virginia Governor.\n\nOn September 26, 2017, the  vacated the convictions of the Skeloses and ordered a retrial, arguing that the district judge had given the jury improper instructions. However the panel wrote that the government's evidence appeared to be sufficient to allow a properly instructed jury to convict the Skeloses, as there was enough evidence to establish that there had been a quid pro quo arrangement in each of the schemes at issue. The retrial of Skelos and his son began on June 19, 2018. During the retrial, in contrast to the first trial, Skelos took the witness stand and testified in his own defense. On July 17, 2018, Skelos and his son were found guilty of eight felonies.\n\nOn October 23, 2018, Skelos was sentenced to four years and three months in federal prison. Judge Wood suggested that he had been unrepentant and that parts of his testimony were outright false.  Adam Skelos was sentenced to a four-year prison term. Dean Skelos reported to the , Orange County, New York to begin his prison term on January 8, 2019. Under New York State law, Skelos continued to draw his annual pension of nearly $100,000 while in prison.\n\nSkelos tested positive for  in April 2020 and was released from prison to serve the remainder of his sentence under .\n\n\n\n\n\n*  official website\n\n\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
          }

    "pages": }\n\n'''John Joseph Marchi''' (born '''Giovanni Marchi'''; May 20, 1921 – April 25, 2009) was an American politician, attorney and . A member of the  from , New York, he was a member of the  from 1957 to 2006, making him the longest-serving state legislator in New York history. He was the Republican nominee for  in  and .\n\n\nGiovanni Marchi was born in 1921, to parents to had immigrated from , Tuscany, Italy. He attended parochial schools on Staten Island before graduating with honors from  in 1942. In 1948, he married Maria Luisa Davini, an Italian immigrant also from Lucca; they had two daughters. Marchi earned a  from  in 1950 and a  from  in 1953. In , he served with the  on antisubmarine duty in the Atlantic and with the  in the  in the Pacific. Marchi also served as a Commander in the Active Reserve after the war, retiring from the service in 1982.\n\n\nOn October 19, 2006, Marchi passed out and fell from his chair at the annual  at the .\n\nMarchi died from pneumonia on April 25, 2009, while vacationing in Lucca with his wife and other family members.\n\n\nMarchi was first elected on November 6, 1956, after having served as a Senate aide. He was a member of the  from 1957 to 2006, sitting in the , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , ,  and s.\n\nMarchi was active in conservative issues, particularly of a fiscal nature, during his long Senate tenure. Marchi wrote the state laws to help New York City recover from its fiscal crisis and near bankruptcy in the 1970s.\n\nMarchi ran twice for Mayor of New York City. He won a surprise upset over Mayor  in the 1969 Republican primary. He ran in the general election against Lindsay, who was still the  nominee, and   . Marchi and Procaccino lost to Lindsay.\n\nMarchi was the Republican nominee again in 1973, but he lost to Comptroller , the Democrat that Lindsay had defeated in 1965, while he came in ahead of  and . Previously, he ran unsuccessfully as the Republican nominee for  of Staten Island in 1961.\n\nMarchi worked to improve public education in the 1980s and was appointed as Chairman of the Temporary State Commission on  Governance in 1989. This commission conducted a two-year study on the control and governance in New York City schools and provided recommendations to the  on improving administration and public participation in the school system. Senator Marchi also provided assistance to the  so that the school could obtain the land of the former  for a campus.\n\nMarchi was a longtime advocate for the . He wrote a law which backed a secession referendum in 1993. While the referendum passed, the legislature has not allowed Staten Island to become its own city. As a part of his Staten Island secession work, Marchi drafted a model charter for a new City of Staten Island. Marchi also drafted the law to close the  on Staten Island.\n\nMarchi was the only Republican member of the State Senate who opposed the death penalty.\n\nMarchi was a member of the executive committee and the Board of Governors of the . He was appointed by U.S. President  to the National Advisory Committee on Drug Abuse Prevention.\n\n\n*Chairman of the Joint Liquor Laws Committee\n*Chairman of the Senate Commerce and Navigation Committee\n*Chairman of the Joint New York City Docks Committee\n*Chairman of the Joint Alcoholic Beverage Control Law Committee\n*Chairman of the Senate Constitutional Affairs Subcommittee\n*Chairman of the Senate City of New York Committee\n*Chairman of the Joint Intergovernmental Cooperation Committee\n*Chairman of the Senate Finance Committee\n*Chairman of the Senate Corporations, Authorities and Commissions Committee\n*Vice President Pro Tempore of the Senate\n*Chairman of the Temporary State Commission on New York City School Governance\n*Chairman of the New York State Charter Commission for Staten Island\n*Chairman of the Staten Island Charter Commission\n*Deputy Majority Leader for Intergovernmental Relations\n*Chairman of the Senate Ethics Committee\n*Assistant Majority Whip\n*Assistant Majority Leader for Conference Operations\n*Chairman of the Senate Task Force on World Trade Center Recovery\n\n\n boat ''Sen. Marchi'', which shuttles passengers from the ferry terminal at the southern tip of  to the  ferry terminal in .]]A new  boat was named in Marchi's honor in 2006.\n\nJohn Marchi Hall was named in his honor on campus of the College of Staten Island in 2006. The building is located in the \"north\" side of campus; building 2N.\n\nA collection of Marchi's legislative and personal files are available at the College of Staten Island Archives and Special Collections.\n\n\n\n\n\n*   \n*\n*\n*\n*\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Sylvia M. Friedman''' was a former woman. She was elected to fill an unexpired term on February 28, 2006. Friedman was a long time community activist and a member of her local community board. Her main focus was on housing and homeless issues. She died on February 4, 2013, at the age of 74.\n\n\nShe served as Co-Director of the Center for Independence of the Disabled in New York, as Program Director of , New York's Consumer Directed Personal Assistance Program, and as liaison to the disabled community in the office of Public Advocate . She had previously lost two races for the .\n\n'''' described her in 1993 as a former teacher who subsequently was employed as a Housing policy analyst with the Department of Housing Preservation and Development. '''' described her in 1993 as a former teacher who subsequently was employed as a Housing policy analyst with the Department of Housing Preservation and Development.\n\nFollowing the resignation of former Assemblyman , Friedman was a surprise choice of the Democratic Party to run to succeed him in the special election. Friedman served for ten months of Sanders' unexpired term. She represented the East Village and Lower East Side of .\n\nIn her first week in the Assembly, she voted for , which provides parity in medical insurance for mental illness. During her tenure in the Assembly, Friedman was a member of the Alcoholism and Drug Abuse Committee, the Election Law Committee, the Housing Committee and the Social Services Committee.\n\nFriedman was defeated in the Democratic primary in September 2006 by , who assumed the seat in 2007.\n\nBefore her election to the Assembly, Friedman served as District Leader and then as  Member. On the State Committee, she was a member of the Reform Caucus and last year was elected its Chair. She served on , at various times chairing the Housing Committee, the Homeless Committee and the Parks, Recreation and Landmarks Committee. For the last twenty years, she has Chaired a shelter for twelve homeless men and women. Using a gift given to the shelter as seed money, she helped start and served on the Board of Friends House in Rosehill, a residence for fifty formerly homeless people with .\n\nA longtime member of the 504 Democratic Club Executive Board, she is their first member to be elected to public office. On May 21, 2006, she was awarded the Joan Kinzer Award by the Club during their annual event.\n\n\n* '''February 2006 , NYS Assembly, 74th AD'''\n:\n\n* '''September 2006 Democratic , NYS Assembly, 74th AD'''\n:\n\n* '''November 2006 , NYS Assembly, 74th AD'''\n:\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Laurie A. Cumbo''' (born February 4, 1975) is an American politician and Commissioner of the . A , she served in the  for the  from 2014 to 2021, which includes the Brooklyn neighborhoods of , , and , portions of , , , the , and . She is the founder and first  of the .\n\nCumbo was ineligible to run in 2021 due to s.\n\n\nCumbo was born in ,  to Wilkins and Beverly Cumbo, the latter an , and raised in  at a time when waves of people of  descent were leaving and residents of African descent were arriving. (Her father had moved to the neighborhood in the 1940s.)\n\nAfter graduating from , she was accepted into and enrolled in  in ,  in 1997, inspired by the actions of characters on '''' and ''''. After receiving a degree in  there, she received a  in  administration from  in 1999.\n\n\nBased on her 1999 NYU graduate work and a trip to , , Cumbo founded and served as the  of the . She told the '''''s Local, \"prior to [receiving her master's] I would say I was very inspired by the , Spain. This museum created a whole economy for this particular city after its  died. It made Bilbao and the museum a must destination when visiting Spain. I know that MoCADA can do that for Brooklyn as well.\"\n\nOriginally based in a building operated by the   in the  section of Brooklyn, the institution moved to its current location in the borough's   section within the BAM Cultural District with the help of the 's Local Development Corporation, which included , the  and  , on its board.\nIn 2012, the museum landed a $100,000 grant from the  to pay for a two-year program that brought monthly concerts to public spaces in nearby  Houses like , Ingersoll, and  in Fort Greene that drew crowds up to 500 or 600. The following year, MoCADA launched another art performance series, Soul of Brooklyn, \"a borough-wide celebration of the diverse arts and cultures of Brooklyn's \". From 2001 to 2011, Cumbo served as a graduate professor in the Arts and Cultural Management program at 's School of Art & Design.\n\n\nIn December 2013, one month before she was sworn in, a series of attacks took place targeting Jewish residents of , , totaling at least eight victims including children. The attacks were  to be part of a trend of \" attacks\", and  was cited by a number of community leaders, politicians and media outlets as a precipitating factor. \n\nFollowing the attacks, Cumbo publicly expressed that her African American and  constituents had expressed fear of being \"pushed out of their homes by Jewish s\", and that resentment towards the Jewish residents of Crown Heights \"offer possible  as to how young African-American/Caribbean teens could conceivably commit a '' against a community that they know very little about.\" She wrote \"I admire the Jewish community immensely.... I respect and appreciate the Jewish community's family values and unity that has led to strong political, economic and cultural gains. While I personally regard this level of tenacity, I also recognize that for others, the accomplishments of the Jewish community triggers feelings of resentment, and a sense that Jewish success is not also their success.\" Her response was covered widely on s and in the New York press.\n\nCumbo's statements raised concerns among many residents, and in addition to other local media, the story was featured in local Jewish media outlets. Cumbo later apologized to her constituents for her remarks, saying in a statement, \"I sincerely apologize to all of my constituents for any pain that I have caused by what I wrote ... and I understand now that my words did not convey what was in my heart, which is a profound desire to bring our diverse communities closer together.\" The next year she allocated thousands of dollars in district council money to a  Orthodox Jewish community group.\n\nEarlier, in April 2010, while head of MoCADA, she was quoted in the ''New York Times'''s Local with another remark regarding Jews. She said, \"I'm trying to figure out new ways to do what I want to do to grow the museum.... You have a Jewish children's museum, but you don't feel that there should be a black-centered museum?\"\n\n\n\n\nIn 2013, she moved into the  to run for its city council seat. By the end of August 2013, Cumbo's political campaign had received at least $80,000 from Jobs for New York PAC, a pro-development  unpopular in an already rapidly  area. In an -sponsored discussion a week later she claimed she received no money from the  (backers of Jobs for New York), and that they had given no contributions to her campaign. She denied it again when confronted with the issue at a Brooklyn community board committee meeting in February 2015 although she had reportedly claimed to the ''Brooklyn Paper'' (at her 2013 victory party) that she would be more developer-friendly than her predecessor and that \"[I]t would be almost malpractice to be a councilmember and to have no relationship with the developers who are building this community.\"\n\nElected in 2013 in a crowded Democratic primary race, Cumbo, unchallenged by a  candidate, succeeded . She was handpicked to run by Brooklyn Congressman . Cumbo's political leanings are in some ways more conservative than that of her predecessor, and has been the subject of other controversies. She had previously denounced the practice and encouraged voters to blow the whistle on excessive corporate support of political campaigns during her campaign. She did not appear at the public debate before the primary election for the council district seat on August 21, 2013. Despite this, she won the council seat on a platform, in part, of expanding and developing arts and cultural tourism in the district and making improved use of public spaces including parks. \n\nHer platform included \"Investing in Economic Development, Strengthening Not-for-Profits and Service Employees, Reforming Education.\" She was endorsed by Jeffries, New York State Assemblyman , and the .\n\nIn May 2014, she was fined $7,868 by the  for taking contributions above the limit from a group pushing for a ban on the horse-carriage industry.\n\n\n\n\nIn 2017, Cumbo, now an , again defeated one of her 2013 opponents, Ede Fox, in the Democratic primary, 58% to 42%. She defeated then- candidate  and Republican Christine Parker in the general election.\n\n\n\nCumbo is ineligible to run in 2021 due to .\n\n\nCumbo took office in January 2014. She was appointed chair of the Women's Issues Committee and serves on the following committees: Cultural Affairs, Libraries, and International Intergroup Relations; Finance; Higher Education; Public Housing; and Youth Services. She is a member of the Women's Caucus and the Black, Latino/a, and Asian Caucus. She is specifically passionate about women's issues such as domestic violence, workplace discrimination, girls education, and sex trafficking.\n\nIn her first six months in government, when city council members were working on the FY 2015 Budget, she and Council Member , chair of the Public Housing Committee, along with many residents advocated to stop 57 NYCHA community and senior centers from experiencing cuts in funding. As a result, the Council allocated $17 million to keep these centers open.\n\nEarly in October 2014, Cumbo, as chair of the Women's Issues Committee, and her colleague , chair of the Public Safety Issues Committee, announced the council allocated nearly $6 million to support  programs and initiatives. On October 15, 2014, Cumbo joined by Speaker , Rosemonde Pierre-Louis, commissioner for the Mayor's Office to Combat Domestic Violence and other citywide elected officials, posted at subway stations across the city in a campaign that Cumbo organized in order to raise awareness of the problem of domestic violence in honor of \"NYC Go Purple Visibility Day\". She and her office partnered with the \"Not on My Watch!\" campaign back in June 2014.\n\nShe was also in strong support of hosting the  in New York City, specifically Brooklyn, which failed. In arguing in favor of the convention coming to her borough, she argued \"We have swag on lock down,\" continuing, \"A convention anywhere else in the United States of America is just going to be 'eh.'\"  This earned her an ingratiating visit from Senator  at her first \"state of the district\" address at the .\n\nDuring 's campaign for , '''' broke the story of his 2009 arrest in a domestic dispute, the records that had been sealed, which were used by competing candidates. Cumbo, who went to high school with Williams, wrote a letter demanding to know if the law enforcement sources of the story broke city policy in doing so.\n\nIn 2021, Cumbo voted against allowing non-citizens to vote in municipal elections because she claimed it would dilute the power of black voters at the gain of Latino voters, implying Latino residents of the city were largely non-citizens.\n\n\nCumbo made local headlines again in late March 2015 when she asked why there were \"blocs\" (possibly \"blocks\") of Asians living in two Fort Greene housing projects. Colleague and Manhattan councilwoman , who is , said \"She certainly could've chosen her words a bit more carefully. The fact is that there are many Asian-American families . . . who have applied to live in public housing.\" Cumbo issued an apology, but then said she only wanted to know if the  \"uses a cultural preference priority component\" in picking tenants to which  chair  replied that it did not, saying its vacancy rate is less than 1 percent, making such an influx almost impossible. The Brooklyn councilwoman then told the '','' \"There could be some benefit to housing people by culture . . . I think it needs to be discussed.\" Queens Congresswoman , another Asian-American New York City representative, denounced Cumbo's idea, saying that it was \"thinly disguised segregation based on race, color, creed or national origin.\" City council speaker  while defending Cumbo called her comments \"unfortunate.\"\n\nIn 2016, Cumbo was in favor of proceeding with the development of the  with  via a lengthy public review process, despite community opposition, saying \"Let's just continue to negotiate, see what the final outcome is, and if it's satisfactory,\" claiming adjustments could be made along the way. After many months of push back from residents and activist, she changed her position on May 18, 2017. The new plan passed six months later and still attracted protesters with Jonathan Westin of  saying \"The entire process was fixed from the beginning so the Mayor could push through a deal to one of his favored developers.... Plainly and simply: this is planned gentrification, driven by the gentrification mayor and rubber-stamped by Laurie Cumbo.\"\n\n\nOn March 18, 2022, Mayor  appointed Cumbo as Commissioner of the .\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Elizabeth S. Crowley''' (born November 27, 1977) is an American politician. She was previously the  member for the  from 2009 to 2017, representing the neighborhoods of , , , , and parts of  and , in the borough of . Crowley is both the first woman and first  to hold the seat. Crowley was a 2021 candidate for . She is a cousin of former U.S. Congressman .\n\n\n\nCrowley was born in  to a large and civically-active family. The 14th of 15 siblings,Council Biography  She joined multiple members of her extended family who had held elected office over the years.  Her father, Walter, was a local Democratic District Leader and City Council Member during the 1980s. Crowley's mother, Mary, served on the local School Board 24 for a number of years. Following Walter's death in office in 1985, Mary was tapped to finish out the remainder of his term. This made Crowley the third member of her immediate family to serve in the City Council.Lombardi, F. (January 9, 2009). \nCrowley is the cousin of former U.S. Congressman , vice chair of the  and Democratic Party chair in Queens County.\n\nCrowley has a   in restoration and preservation from  , where she was a , and an  in city and regional planning from 's . She did historic preservation work on various landmarks through New York City, including , , and . She is a member of District Council 9 . Crowley also briefly worked as an educator.\n\n\n\n\nOn March 17, 2008,  City Council Member  resigned from office after pleading guilty to two  counts of  stemming from a 2007 incident in which an intoxicated Gallagher forced himself upon an unidentified 52-year-old woman inside his Middle Village District Office. Mayor  subsequently called a  for the following June 3 to fill Gallagher's vacant seat. On May 8, Crowley announced her candidacy, joining a crowded field that included Gallagher's predecessor , a Republican who held the seat until term-limited from office in 2001, city  Commissioner , civic leader Charles Ober, and attorney Joseph Suraci. Crowley and Como received the backing of the county Democratic and Republican parties, respectively, with Ober picking up the  line. Como eked out a victory over Crowley with a margin of just 41 votes.Hogwood, B. (October 23, 2008). \n\nFour months after Como's close victory, Como faced Crowley in the . Crowley anticipated to benefit from a higher turnout due to the historic candidacy of  in a district where Registered Democrats outnumber Republicans 2-to-1. On election day, Crowley defeated Como by 4,369 votes.\n\nFor the third time in 17 months, Crowley ran for the 30th District during the . This time, Crowley faced Ognibene, who had sat out the second 2008 race after the county Republicans passed him over by endorsing Como, despite his stated interest in running. The race quickly turned heated, with Ognibene criticizing Crowley's brief tenure in the Council as \"ineffective,\" while the Democrat in turn painted her 65-year-old challenger as \"out of touch.\" In the end, Crowley proved the stronger candidate, out-fundraising Ognibene and easily beating him in the November election.\n\nIn the ,  defeated Crowley by 137 votes. Holden, a Democrat, had previously lost to Crowley in the primary, but several other parties offered Holden their ballot line in the general and Holden ran as a Republican, Conservative, Reform and \"Dump de Blasio\" candidate.\n\n\nIn 2010, when the city faced serious budget cuts and  planned to close as many as 20 firehouses, Crowley, as Chair of the Council Committee on Fire & Criminal Justice, led a coalition of elected officials and community members to stop the planned closures. Crowley has taken both the Bloomberg and de Blasio administrations to task to improve the reliability of the city's 911 system.\n\nCrowley led a fight to preserve and expand City health services for women. Crowley has also sponsored legislation to expand access to HPV vaccinations, birth control and other women's health services. Crowley has pushed the FDNY to double the number of women serving as firefighters in her efforts to improve gender equality among the city's emergency services. In an effort to bring more women to leadership roles in corporations, Crowley sponsored legislation requiring companies receiving city contracts to report the gender and racial makeup of their board members and executives.\n\nOwing to her background in historic preservation, Crowley has worked to protect important local landmarks. In 2013, Crowley joined advocates in successfully lobbying the city's  (LPC) to confer landmark status on the century-old , one of the last works of master carver Daniel Carl Muller, culminated a 40-year battle by the Woodhaven community to secure official landmark status for the beloved carousel.(May 11, 2016). ]] That same year, Crowley oversaw the reopening of a nature preserve at the former , a decommissioned 19th Century reservoir located in  on the – border. This represented the culmination of a years-long effort by Crowley to maintain the site's natural character. The city  under Mayor  had previously announced a number of proposals that would have limited public access to the site and installed sports facilities and comfort stations in two of the reservoir's three basins. However, in response to strong local opposition and a petition garnering over 1,000 signatures, Crowley joined with fellow elected officials in writing to New York Governor  to oppose the city's plan. Crowley subsequently secured Council funding towards a $7 million renovation that preserved the site as a nature area, while installing new fencing and lighting, and repaving walkways.\nIn November 2016, Crowley presided over a ceremony to official inaugurate the , a 40-block area including nearly 1,000 historic homes and buildings. At the time of its designation, Central Ridgewood is the largest historic district in the borough of Queens, and the third largest in the city after Manhattan's  and Brooklyn's .\n\n\n\nStarting in 2015, Crowley joined preservationists and local residents in mounting a campaign to landmark historic  in Woodhaven. Considered to be the oldest bar in the city, it has been a neighborhood watering hole for more than 180 years and was prominently featured in the  film ''''.\nIn May 2016, Crowley attended a rally at the Tavern with more than 100 local residents to call on the LPC to recognize the building. Crowley criticized the body for falling to prioritize the landmarking of historic sites in the borough. The proposal was rejected by the LPC, according to the bar's owner, because \"Neir's Tavern does not rise to the level of significance to warrant landmark status\" and that landmark status would not protect the site from future development.\n\nIn August 2016, city officials announced plans to house 110 homeless adult families at a  in Maspeth. Crowley declared her opposition to the planned shelter, noting the impact on the community of two existing homeless shelters along  and pledging to \"[work] with community leaders and residents\" to halt the Maspeth proposal. The following week,  Commissioner Steve Banks held a public meeting to present the plan to the community, drawing more than 1,000 residents opposed to the plan. Crowley also addressed the crowd, reiterating her opposition to the plan.\n\n\n\n\n\nCrowley was married to Dennis O'Hara, a New York City police officer. They have two sons, Dennis and Owen. She lives in  with her sons.\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n*\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Kimberly Jean-Pierre''' is an American politician serving as a member of the  for the , which includes portions of the town of  in . A , she was first elected in 2014 and announced she would not seek reelection in 2024.\n\n\nJean-Pierre is of  descent, and graduated from  and later received a master's degree in public policy from . Prior to elected office Jean-Pierre worked for the  as a legislative aide to DuWayne Gregory. She later worked for Congressman  as a Community Outreach Coordinator, and later for the Town of Babylon's Industrial Development Agency.\n\n\nIn 2014, Assemblyman  decided to retire, leaving the district open for the first time in twenty six years. Jean-Pierre announced her run, and easily attained the nomination before going to win the election with 58% of the vote. She easily won reelection in 2016 and 2018. In the Assembly, Jean-Pierre serves as Chair of the Subcommittee on Banking in Underserved Communities.\n\nIn 2022, Jean-Pierre was narrowly reelected by under 1% against Republican. She announced that she would not run for reelection in 2024 days after the candidate filing deadline, allowing the Suffolk County Democratic Party to replace her on the ballot without a primary.\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Daniel Garodnick''' (born May 5, 1972) is an American lawyer and a former  member for the . He is currently the Chair of the . He also served as president and chief executive officer of the  Conservancy.\n\n\nGarodnick was born in  and is a graduate of  (1990). He received his  from  (1994). He earned a  from the  (2000), where he was Editor-in-Chief of the ''''.\n\nBetween college and law school, Garodnick spent time in both  and  helping to rebuild African American churches that had been burned by arson. He also spent two years working for the New York Civil Rights Coalition as the director of a program to teach New York City public school ways to combat racial discrimination, and how to use government to effect social change.\n\n\nAn attorney, Garodnick practiced as a litigator at the New York law firm of  where he focused on securities litigation and internal investigations of companies. While there, he represented the Partnership for New York City in the successful  lawsuit regarding public school funding., and same-sex couples seeking marriage equality in New York State.\n\nPrior to joining the firm, he served as a law clerk to Judge  of the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York. \n\n\nIn May 2008, Garodnick married Zoe Segal-Reichlin, senior associate general counsel and director of advocacy of . They have two children.\n\n\nGarodnick was elected to New York City Council in 2005, winning 63 percent of the vote in the general election and defeating both the Republican and Libertarian candidates. In the five-way Democratic primary that year he won 59% of the vote. He won reelection in 2009 and 2013.\n\nDuring his twelve-year tenure, '''' praised Garodnick for his “independent streak” and noted that he had “distinguished himself in the fight to preserve middle-class housing.” ''The Wall Street Journal'' has called him “smart and fair” and POLITICO New York noted that he is known as a “policy wonk” who has “bucked the establishment.\"\n\nIn 2017,  called Garodnick a “no-nonsense negotiator.” Garodnick earned this reputation for repeatedly bringing parties to an agreement in difficult negotiations. In 2007, Garodnick successfully stepped in to broker an agreement between renowned Chef  and the staff at his eponymous restaurant, who sought redress and compensation after Asian and Latino employees had been discriminated against and passed over for promotions. In 2008, when a developer proposed rezoning the largest stretch of undeveloped, privately owned land in Manhattan, Garodnick was able to adjust the plan to reduce the height of the towers, provide for acres of gardens and a school, as well as a $10 million contribution from the developer for a future pedestrian bridge over the . In 2015, when the de Blasio administration and Council Member  were at a logjam over the $115 million redevelopment of the , Garodnick helped broker an agreement between both sides.\n\nGarodnick is best known for his work fighting for his childhood home in Stuyvesant Town and Peter Cooper Village, where he spearheaded the largest housing preservation deal in New York City history in 2015, with 5,000 units for middle-class families. He wrote a book on the subject, called \"Saving Stuyvesant Town: How One Community Defeated the Worst Real Estate Deal in History,\" published by Three Hills Press, an imprint of Cornell University Press.  He also negotiated the East Midtown Rezoning in 2017, covering an 80 block area in midtown Manhattan, which almost immediately began to generate new commercial space, and to deliver significant public improvements to the area.\n\nGarodnick's last term as councilman ended on December 31, 2017, when he was succeeded by .\n\nGarodnick authored and passed over 60 laws during his tenure on the New York City Council.\n\n\nOn April 3, 2012 Garodnick announced that he would seek the Democratic nomination for . On November 28, 2012 Garodnick dropped out of the Comptroller race, and immediately endorsed , while pledging to run for re-election in District 4. Stringer had previously been running for . Garodnick was opposed in his bid for re-election by attorney Helene Jnane.\n\n\nOn February 7, 2022, Mayor Eric Adams appointed Garodnick as Director of the Department of City Planning, and Chair of the City Planning Commission. In that role he is leading the administration’s ambitious land use agenda, including proposed changes related to the impact of zoning on climate, changes to the city zoning law related to business development and housing, including for office to housing conversions. Garodnick is also focused on support for proposed changes near the new Metro-North Stations coming to the Bronx, a key stretch of Atlantic Avenue in Brooklyn, Manufacturing Districts in Midtown Manhattan, and downtown Jamaica in Queens. In July 2023, Garodnick was named in the top ten of City & State Newspaper's Real Estate Power 100.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
          }
        ]
      }

    "pages": }\n'''Errol T. Louis''' (born August 24, 1962) is a New York City journalist and television show host. He has unsuccessfully run for office several times.\n\n\nLouis was born in  and raised in , by his father, Edward J. Louis, a retired , and his mother, Tomi (Hawkins) Louis, a . He received a B.A. in government from , an M.A. in political science from , and a J.D. from .\n\n\n\nLouis co-founded the Central Brooklyn Federal Credit Union with  in the spring of 1993. The two were known as \"the hip-hop bankers\".\n\nLouis taught urban studies at .\n\n\nOn September 9, 1997, Louis ran in the Democratic primary for  District 35 against incumbent  and police officer . Louis had charged Pinkett with being absent in the community, and he was endorsed by Congressman , State Senator , and Assemblyman .\n\nLouis lost to Pinkett with 27.82% of the vote, but then ran against Pinkett again in the November 4, 1997, general election on the  line, with Davis on the  and  lines. Louis was defeated with 8.54% of the vote.\n\nLouis declared his candidacy in the 2001 Democratic primary for the same City Council seat, but he had dropped out of the race by August 2001.\n\n\nLouis was an associate editor of ''''. He later joined the New York '''' in 2004 and for many years wrote a column, \"Commerce and Community\", for '''', which is published weekly and based in the  neighborhood of Brooklyn. Louis also served on the .\n\nOn June 23, 2008, Louis became host of the ''Morning Show'', a three-hour talk program on radio station ; in 2009 he was succeeded by . In November 2010 '''' named him the city's best newspaper columnist and radio show host.\n\nLouis joined  in November 2010 as political anchor and the host of '''', a program about New York City politics that airs nightly. He is the Director of the Urban Reporting program at the 's . He is also a  contributor and has made frequent appearances on '''' and other CNN news programs.\n\nIn 1996 Louis was named by '''' as one of \"10 New Yorkers Making a Difference\", \"with energy, vision and independent thinking.\"\n\n\nLouis lives in , with his wife, Juanita Scarlett a lobbyist with the firm Bolton-St. John's, and their son.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Julissa Ferreras-Copeland''' (born November 2, 1976) is an American . She is the former  Member for the  from 2009 to 2017, which includes portions of , , , , , ,  and  in the  borough of . During her tenure, Ferreras-Copeland served as the chairman of the Finance Committee. She was the first woman, the first , and the youngest member to be elected Finance Chair. She is a .\n\n\nFerreras-Copeland grew up in ,  to mother Josefina Ferreras-Peláez, an office aide who worked at the , and father Julio Alejandro Ferreras, a subway car inspector at New York City's . Her parents are both from the  but met in New York City at  at a  concert.\n\nFerreras-Copeland graduated from  in . She attended  and .\n\n\nIn 1999, at age 19 and after graduating from high school, Ferreras-Copeland became the director of a Beacon program housed in one of the most crowded public schools in the world, Public School 19Q. She was assistant director of the Community Conciliation Network in Corona, Queens.\n\nFerreras-Copeland's political career officially commenced in 2001 when she became a  delegate appointed by Assemblyman . She then became the  and campaign manager for her then-predecessor Councilman . She served in this position from 2001 to 2008. Ferreras-Copeland briefly left the  and from 2005 to 2007 served as the New York Director of the  (NALEO), working to support the NALEO Education Fund.\n\nWhen Councilman Monserrate became involved in a scandal (in 2012, he pleaded guilty to mail fraud), Ferreras-Copeland was among those questioned and cleared. \"It was an experience I learned a great deal from,\" she said. \"It was something I overcame and was able to step into my own.\" \"This was a lesson learned,\" she said, \"especially since I worked so hard at building my name and my integrity, to have this little bit of tarnish is not something I ever want to have to face again.\"\n\nIn 2017, Ferreras-Copeland decided to leave politics and not seek re-election, returning to the private sector in order to focus on her family.\n\n\nIn February 2009, Ferreras-Copeland was elected to the  of the . Ferreras-Copeland was the first Latina elected to political office in Queens. Starting in 2010, Ferreras-Copeland served as the head of the Committee on Women's Issues. While serving on this committee, in 2010 she held the first city council hearing on .\n\nAfter being re-elected for a second term in 2014, Ferreras-Copeland was appointed by Council Speaker  to the serve as the first woman and first person of color to chair the City Council's Finance Committee. In this role, Ferreras-Copeland oversaw the city's $78.3 billion budget as well as the Department of Finance, Banking Commission, Tax Commission, Comptroller's Office, Department of Design and Construction and Independent Budget Office.\n\nFerreras-Copeland was responsible for building hundreds of school seats in Corona, Jackson Heights, and East Elmhurst. Ferreras-Copeland told '''' that she allocated funding to build five new schools in her district and all were scheduled to open in Corona in the coming years to handle increased demand.\n\nFerreras-Copeland developed and supported the creation of Corona Plaza, a former underutilized parking space which has been transformed in a public square. Corona Plaza, which is located at 103rd Street and Roosevelt Avenue, has become a meeting place since it was turned into a pedestrian zone in 2012. Ferreras-Copeland said the plaza has taken on the role of the central squares found in towns and cities in Latin America. \"If you go to many of these countries, everyone comes to a centrally located plaza at some point in the day.\"\n\nFerreras-Copeland focused on increased transparency in the budgeting process. She improved tax exemptions to build over 15,000 affordable housing developments in . She supported regulations to help small businesses that also fostered job creation. Ferreras-Copeland supported Summer Youth Employment Program (SYEP) and after school programs, HANAC Affordable Senior Housing, Beacon programs, , paid sick days, and tenants' rights. She is also an advocate against  and .\n\nFerreras-Copeland co-sponsored the paid sick leave bill, which in 2017 was expanded in 2017 to include victims of domestic violence, sexual assault, and human trafficking paid leave to attend to immediate safety needs. She advocated for expanded  and launched the creation of the Alliance for Flushing Meadows-Corona Park, a public-private partnership.\n\nIn 2016, Ferreras-Copeland sponsored menstrual equity legislation, the first laws of this type in the United States that guarantee access to feminine hygiene products in schools, prisons, and homeless shelters.\n\nFerreras-Copeland had been considered a favorite in the race to succeed  as Speaker of the . Like Mark-Viverito, she was considered an ally of then-Mayor . Her retirement shook up the race and ultimately led to a victory by , who had billed himself as the \"anti-DeBlasio.\"\n\n\n\n\nIn 2015, Ferreras-Copeland married Aaron Copeland in a ceremony officiated by Mayor  at . Copeland is an  and aerospace industry executive. They have one son, Julian, born on September 11, 2013. The family lives in , where her husband works.\n\n\n* Corona Youth Council, member\n* Corona-East Elmhurst NAACP Youth Council, president, 3 years\n* 2008: , 40 Under 40\n* 2010: Queens Dominican Culture & Heritage Month Organizing Committee, Juan Pablo Duarte Award\n* New York City Commission on Gender Equity, commissioner\n* 2014: , 40 Under 40\n* Dominican American National Roundtable, board member\n* , board member (former)\n* Neighborhood Housing Services, board member\n* Renaissance Music and Sports, board member\n* Elmcor Youth & Adult Activities, Inc., board member\n*  (NALEO), board member\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n\n\n* \n*  at the \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
