    "pages": }\n}}\n'''Ronald Tae Sok Kim''' (born May 2, 1979) is an American politician from . He serves in the  representing the 40th District, which includes portions of , , , and  in . First elected in November 2012, Kim became the first  elected in New York State. Speaker  appointed him as Vice-Chair of the Majority Conference of the New York State Assembly in January 2017 and Chair of Committee on Aging in January 2021.\n\n\nKim comes from a  family who immigrated to  when he was seven. The only child of Seo Jun Kim and Sun Hee Kim,\" .\" BBC News. N.p., 30 Mar. 2011. Web. he grew up in . He graduated from the  in  in 1997, where he was  of the  and  teams. He later earned his Bachelor of Arts from , where he continued his football career on the varsity team. He received his  from  as part of the National Urban Fellows Program.\n\n\nKim began his career in  in then- ’s office, focusing on  issues in the Flushing community. He moved on to become an aide to then-State Assemblyman . Following that, Kim joined the New York State Department of Buildings, followed by the Department of Small Business Services. In 2004, Kim was accepted into the National Urban Fellows Program, where he was placed in a fellowship advising the Chief Education Office of the , simultaneously earning his Master’s in Public Administration from .\n\nIn 2006, Kim joined the staff of then-New York City Council Speaker  as a Policy Analyst, where he focused on legislative issues relating to transportation, , and .\n\nFrom 2007 through 2010, Kim served as a Regional Director for Government and Community Affairs in the administrations of Governors  and , where he worked with state agencies, elected officials, and s.\n\nAfter leaving his position at the Governor’s office, Kim worked at the Parkside Group where he advocated on behalf of children with , , community organizations, and vulnerable New Yorkers.\n\nIn June 2012, Kim announced that he would seek the State Assembly seat being vacated by , who was running for the . Kim won the five-way Democratic  on September 13, and went on to defeat  Philip Gim in the , 68% to 32%.\n\nOn December 10, 2018, Kim announced that he would be seeking the  seat being vacated by , who had been elected for . Running on a plan to end  in what ''The Villager'' described as \"one of the most jam-packed elections in recent memory,\" he and over a dozen other candidates entered a crowded race eventually won by then-Councilmember .\n\nHe endorsed  for the . In 2021, he endorsed  for mayor of New York City. During the , Kim stated that \"[t]here were clear patterns of foreign influence trying to dictate the outcome of the election  groups with ties to mainland China and the . They were trying to steal the Flushing seat.\"\n\n\nIn his first month in office, Kim helped pass legislation (A.3354) which implemented  for New York City s; the bill was projected to encourage housing development.\n\nHe has supported bills related to education issues and services for seniors. He is also an active supporter of immigration issues and is a sponsor of the  on the state level as well as the prime sponsor on a bill to make  an allowable  in , a measure which the mayor eventually adopted. Kim has sponsored legislation inspired by events that happen in his district; in January 2013, he became a proponent of the Taxi Drivers Protection Act following a robbery and assault that occurred in .\n\nKim currently chairs the Committee on Aging and sits on the Education Committee; the Corporations, Authorities and Commissions Committee; Governmental Operations Committee; and Housing Committee. He is the co-founder of the New York State Asian Pacific American Task Force, and also a member of the Black, Puerto Rican, Hispanic and Asian Caucus.\n\nKim was the first public official to lead the opposition against Amazon HQ2. His policy stance lead to a larger discussion around corporate subsidies, economic development, and the rate of return for such investments.\n\n\nIn October 2018, he authored a  called \"Gut-Checking Democracy\" in which he outlined this thesis and presented several policy solutions. His legislative record as an Assemblyman reflects this philosophy.\n\nIn October 2018, he organized more than 20 labor groups, s and community leaders to call for a one-time cancellation of student debt and outlined the economic rationale and financial mechanisms for how it could be executed.\n\nHe was also the first elected official in New York to speak out against providing taxpayer-funded incentives to lure Amazon to New York City. On November 9, 2018 he and Professor  published an  in '''' which warned of the consequences of locating a big corporation like Amazon in New York.\n\nHe went on to lead the #PeopleOverCorporations agenda, calling for an end to  and repurposing of taxpayers' money to liberate New Yorkers from a lifetime of debt.\n\n\nKim has worked with state legislators to pass a bill expanding access to small loans and seed funding for micro-businesses, and sought to create a fund in the 2017 State Budget to help small businesses in New York struggling to comply with increasingly burdensome regulations.\n\nHe has introduced legislation to create an entity within the New York State Department of Financial Services called the \"State Office of Financial Services for Immigrants.\" The purpose of the office would be to foster financial literacy among recent immigrant communities; assist recent immigrants with navigating mainstream financial institutions as they seek to borrow, lend or invest; and help recent immigrant build their credit score and history.\n\nKim has also introduced legislation to create the first-in-the-nation Office of Financial Resilience, which would work to reverse the cycle of debt under which so many New York families are living.\n\n\nIn the summer of 2015, following an investigative report by '''', Kim helped to draft a measure to improve the conditions in the nail salon industry. The law Kim passed created a trainee nail specialist program and modified the ’s enforcement of licensing requirements. Soon after, however, Governor Andrew Cuomo called a state of emergency and unilaterally implemented other requirements, such as wage bonds for nail salons, that were not part of the new law. These additional requirements caused excessive hardships for small business owners in the industry, and many of them were forced to close their stores. Kim spoke out against the new unilateral mandates imposed by the governor, which were not part of the law their offices had worked on and agreed to. Nail Salon Regulations: A New York Assemblyman Responds|work=The New York Times|date=November 13, 2015|language=en|access-date=February 18, 2017|archive-date=November 21, 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151121182749/http://www.nytimes.com/2015/11/14/opinion/nail-salon-regulations-a-new-york-assemblyman-responds.html?_r=0|url-status=live}} He subsequently introduced and became the primary sponsor of a bill to relieve the financial and economic burdens that small business owners, including those in the nail salon industry, were facing. As a result of his efforts, the bill passed both houses of the , but the governor refused to sign it.\n\nIn November 2015, ''The New York Times'' initially published a report claiming Kim had changed positions on the nail salon issue as a result of campaign contributions, which he vigorously countered in a letter to the ''Times''. '''' and '''' each published stories examining the record and refuting the ''Times'' allegation that Kim had changed his position. In December 2015, the New York Times made a correction, stating that its report \"included incorrect information about some political donations to Mr. Kim from the industry.\"\n\nAfter the publication of ''The New York Times''' nail salon investigative report, the validity of its claims about the industry soon came into doubt. Amid increased scrutiny, the accuracy of its reporting on nail salons was challenged by several media outlets. , a former ''New York Times'' reporter, expressed serious doubts about its claims of widespread abuses and \"astonishingly low\" wages, and showed that its translation and understanding of job ads in the industry, one of its key pieces of evidence, were either inaccurate or false. In October 2015, '''' published a three part re-reporting of the story by Jim Epstein, charging that the New York Times' series was filled with misquotes and factual errors with respect to both its claims of illegally low wages and of health hazards. In November 2015, the ''Times'' public editor concluded that the ''Times''' exposé's \"findings, and the language used to express them, should have been dialed back  in some instances substantially\" and recommended that \"The ''Times'' writer further follow-up stories, including some that re-examine its original findings and that take on the criticism from salon owners and others  not defensively but with an open mind.\"\n\n\n\n\nDuring the , Kim was one of the few New York elected Democrats who questioned  ’s handling of infections in s and the reporting of deaths of nursing home residents. According to Kim, Cuomo threatened to \"destroy\" him if he did not retract or change his statements.\n\n\nKim and his wife, Alison Tan, reside with their three daughters in Flushing, Queens.\n\nOn September 17, 2015, Kim tackled an alleged purse-snatcher, Daniel Fish, to the ground while walking to his office. He broke his own glasses as he took down and held the  until police arrived to arrest him. Subsequently, Kim stated that he believed the suspect was suffering from a , and expressed hope that the individual was not simply punished but also given the help and treatment he needed. Kim said that the incident, and the efforts to understand how the would-be mugger ended up in that situation, gave him more insight into the importance of effective policies to address , mental health problems, and other long-term issues.\n\n\n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* \n*  \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Pamela A. Helming''' (born February 18, 1962) is an American politician from the state of New York. A , Helming has represented  in the  since 2017. Prior to her election to the State Senate, Helming served as the town supervisor for . She was elected to that post in 2014.\n\n\nA graduate of , Helming's career has been focused on individuals with , including those who reside in .  She and her husband, Gary Helming, have resided in the  area for over thirty years and have raised their two children there.\n\nHelming was first elected to local office in 2010 as a town councilperson.  In 2014, she was elected a Town Supervisor from Canandaigua, which elevated her to the county level of government.\n\n\nIn 2016, twenty-four year incumbent Sen.  announced his impending retirement from the State Senate due to health concerns. Sen. Nozzolio represented Senate District 54. Although competitive on paper, Senate District 54 was seen as friendly to Republicans. Five candidates sought the GOP nomination for State Senate in Senate District 54 in 2016. In a tight race with very low turnout, Helming received a plurality of 33% of the vote and won the primary by 210 votes.\n\nIn the 2016 general election, Helming faced Democrat Kenan S. Baldridge as well as Floyd G. Rayburn, who had come in second to Helming in the Republican primary but continued his candidacy on the Reform Party line. Helming prevailed with over 60% of the vote.\n\nHelming was reelected in 2018 and again in 2020 with over 60% of the vote.\n\n\n\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Robert D. \"Bob\" Barra''' (born February 1, 1960) is a  who was elected to serve the 21st district of the  in November 2000. Because of redistricting due to the census, Assemblyman Barra became the Assembly member from the newly formed 14th Assembly district.\n\nBarra received a  degree in communication and journalism from  in 1982. He has worked for the Nassau County Department of Commerce, the North Hempstead Town Board, the Nassau Board of Elections, former congressman , and the Nassau Republican Party. He was unable to win re-election due to the change of how board members were elected; up until that point, Hempstead Town Board members were elected at-large, instead of using the district system that is in place today.\n\nBarra became a member of the New York State Assembly in January 2001. He stepped down from the Assembly at the end of 2010.\n\nHe lives in , with his wife Celeste and two daughters: Alexandra and Erica.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Brian Barnwell''' is an American lawyer and politician, who served as a  member of the . Since January 2017 until December 2022, he has represented Assembly District 30 in Queens; the district includes , , , and portions of , , ,  and .\n\n\nBorn in New York City on April 24, 1986, Brian Barnwell has been a longtime  resident. He comes from a middle-class family of law enforcement officers, nurses and teachers. Barnwell graduated cum laude from  with a Bachelor of Arts degree in political science. He went on to earn his  degree from .\n\nDuring his time in law school, Barnwell worked for the Albany County District Attorney's Office and for the Albany Law School Civil Rights and Disabilities Law Clinic.\n\n\nAfter graduating from law school, Barnwell went into private practice and practiced general law. Barnwell then worked as an aide in Queens City Council Member ’s office. Barnwell first announced in July 2015 that he would seek the District 30 seat in the Assembly; at the time, he was a political newcomer. Incumbent Democratic Assemblymember  had been elected to the seat nine times.\n\nIn the September 2016 Democratic primary, Barnwell defeated Markey 1,710 votes to 1,082. One report on the election result stated that \"[this] might be one of the biggest political upsets Queens has ever seen.\" After defeating  candidate Tony Nunziato by a large margin in the November 2016 general election, Barnwell took office in January 2017.\n\nIn the summer of 2018, Barnwell was named to 's \"Albany 40 Under 40\" He joins other \"figures crafting groundbreaking legislation, shaping public opinion and driving the news cycle.\"\n\n\n\nSince his time in office, Barnwell has introduced legislation that provides tax relief for seniors and the middle class. Barnwell also drafted legislation to attempt to reform the affordable housing formula, and proposed bills that would allow for tougher sentencing on violent felons. Barnwell has also pushed a bill that would outlaw the sale of puppies by \"puppy mills.\" Barnwell has been the primary sponsor on many other pieces of legislation. He has worked to create bills that hold the government accountable and promote citizen well-being.\n \nBarnwell is the chair of the Subcommittee on Emerging Workforce within the New York State Assembly. Barnwell also serves as a member of the Committee on Aging, the Committee on Banks, the Committee on Children and Families, the Committee on Labor, the Committee on Libraries and Education Technology, the Committee on Real Property Taxation, the Asian Pacific American Task Force, and the Puerto Rican/Hispanic Task Force.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* official site\n*\n*\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Helene E. Weinstein''' (born September 6, 1952) is an American politician who represents District 41 in the , which comprises , , East Flatbush,  and , in Brookyn.\n\n\nFirst elected in 1980, Weinstein currently chairs the Assembly's Ways and Means Committee and is a member of the standing committees on Aging, Codes, Rules . She previously chaired the Assembly Committee on Governmental Employees, Election law and Judiciary. And the Assembly Task Force on Women's Issues for seven years.\n\nWeinstein chairs the Assembly Standing Committee on Judiciary. She is the first woman in New York State's history to be appointed to this position. The Judiciary Committee presides over virtually all legislation affecting the state's judicial system, Family and Domestic Relations Law, Trusts and Estates, as well as civil practice in the courts. Weinstein has sponsored major reforms in the state's jury system and is the leading proponent of ensuring civil legal services for low-income New Yorkers. Weinstein led the successful effort to increase 18B and Law Guardian rates. Weinstein is also a member of the Court Facilities Capital Review Board.\n\nShe has been involved in the drafting and passage of several key pieces of legislation, especially with respect to family law. She is the sponsor of the Family Protection and Domestic Violence Intervention Act, as well as the Child Support Standards Act.\n\nWeinstein has previously served as an appointee of former Governor  to the New York State Child Support Commission and the Governor's Commission on Domestic Violence.\n\nOver her political career since 1998, the two groups contributing the greatest amounts to her campaigns have been trial lawyers/lobbyists and public sector unions.\n\n\nWeinstein holds a B.A. in Economics from  as well as a degree from the .\n\n\nWeinstein is of counsel to her family's personal-injury law firm, Weinstein, Chase, Messinger & Peters, P.C.  She has been licensed to practice law in New York since 1977.\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n*\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Jumaane D. Williams''' ( ; born May11, 1976) is an American activist and politician who has served as the  since 2019. He is a former member of the  from the , which includes , , , , and  in .\n\nA member of the  and a self-described , Williams was a member of the New York City Council from 2010 to 2019. He served as Deputy Leader of the City Council and as chair of the Task Force on City Workforce Equity. A candidate for  in , he lost to incumbent . Williams was elected  in the  to complete the term of , who resigned to become . He was re-elected in 2021. Williams ran for  in , losing to incumbent governor Kathy Hochul in the Democratic primary.\n\n\nWilliams's parents, Greg and Patricia Williams, are from , Grenada. His father was a footballer and cricketer before moving to the U.S. to study medicine. He has a brother.\n\nWilliams is an alumnus of  and , from which he received a  in  in 2001 and a  in  and administration in 2005.\n\n\n\nWilliams was elected after defeating incumbent Councilmember Kendall Stewart in the September 2009 Democratic primary by a margin of 12 points. Williams won the general election with an endorsement from the . He was easily reelected in 2013.\n\nIn June 2013, the New York City Council passed Williams's Community Safety Act, which established an Inspector General to oversee the  (NYPD) and created an enforceable ban against bias-based profiling. The Act was passed over then-Mayor 's veto. Williams has been an outspoken opponent of the NYPD's approach to .\n\nIn July 2013, Williams introduced \"house party\" legislation requiring parties with 40 or more people in attendance to register with the police. He also wants event organizers who advertise on social media and those charging admission to pay fines.\n\nOn June 29, 2015, Mayor  signed Williams's legislation, the Fair Chance Act, commonly known as . The law prohibits public and private employers from inquiring about an applicant's criminal history until a conditional offer of employment is made.\n\nOn August 13, 2015, the  passed Intro. 700, Williams's legislation, which, along with bills sponsored by Council Speaker  and Council Member , established regulations for \"tenant relocation specialists\", people landlords employ to buy out tenants. The mayor signed the legislation into law on September 9, 2015.\n\nWilliams has cited his religious beliefs as an influence on his views on issues such as gay marriage and abortion. He expressed opposition to gay marriage and abortion as recently as 2017, but has since altered his position on these issues. As of 2019, Williams had reportedly received a 100% rating from the  of New York City Action Fund.\n\nWilliams resigned from office on March 19, 2019 to become New York City Public Advocate. He declined to back his former staffer, , to succeed him on the city council, instead endorsing , who lost to Louis in the May special election.\n\n\nIn , Williams challenged incumbent   in the , running on a platform of anti-corruption, affordable housing, and criminal justice reform. Williams and , who challenged incumbent   in the Democratic gubernatorial primary, endorsed each other. Williams lost the primary by less than seven points.\n\n\n\nWilliams ran in the 2019 special election for  when  vacated her seat to become New York . '''' endorsed him in both his 2018 campaign for lieutenant governor and his 2019 campaign for public advocate. The New York City chapter of  endorsed him in 2018, but in 2019 did not endorse anyone for Public Advocate. The '''' broke the story of his 2009 arrest in a domestic dispute, publishing records that had been sealed, which were used by rival candidates.\n\nIn a crowded field with 18 other candidates, including former council speaker  and state assemblyman , Williams won, with 33% of the vote to Mark-Viverito's 11% and Blake's 8%.  Eric Ulrich received 19%. In his post-election remarks Williams said that he would work with Mayor de Blasio. He was certified and sworn into office on March 19, 2019. \n\nIn the case that New York City mayor  resigns or is removed from office due to ongoing  into his administration, Williams will become interim mayor until a  can select a new mayor.\n\nIn 2024, Williams said he was against a proposed zoning change that would have eliminated parking mandates for new housing units. \n\n\n\nOn September 28, 2021, Williams announced the formation of an exploratory committee to seek the Democratic nomination for governor in 2022. On November 16, 2021, Williams formally announced his bid for governor. Williams finished second in the June 2022 Democratic primary, losing to Gov. Kathy Hochul by a wide margin. While Williams initially received the support of the Working Families Party, the Party dropped him from the ballot and endorsed Hochul following the June primary.\n\n\n]]\nOn September 5, 2011, during the  in Brooklyn, Williams and Kirsten John Foy, director of community relations for then- , were arrested and handcuffed for walking along a closed-off sidewalk, after having received permission to do so from other officers.\n\nWilliams was a supporter of the  movement, and in September 2012 was assaulted by a member of the  at an Occupy Wall Street event.\n\nWilliams was also arrested in 2018 for protesting the detention of immigrant-rights activist Ravi Ragbir after Ragbir was detained during one of his regular check-ins with .Anderson, Lincoln, \"Oh, maane! Williams crushes advocate race,\" ''The Villager,'' February 28, 2019\n\n\nWilliams was diagnosed with  (ADHD) and  as a child and has advocated for people with those conditions.\n\nWilliams is a .\n\nWilliams was arrested in 2009 following a domestic dispute.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n|-\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

Stern''' (born October 30, 1968) is an American politician currently serving as a  member representing the 10th district, which includes portions of the towns of  and  in . A , Stern was first elected in 2018 through a special election.\n\n\nStern is from .     "pages": }\n\n'''Scott M. Stringer''' (born April 29, 1960) is an American politician who served as the 44th . A , Stringer also previously served as a man, and as the 26th  of .\n\nIn 1983, Stringer became a legislative assistant to New York State Assemblyman and future United States Congressman . In 1992, he successfully ran for a seat in the  vacated by Nadler, covering the . Stringer served as New York State Assemblyman for 13 years and six terms, from 1992 until 2005, when he was elected the 26th borough president of Manhattan. He won the  to become New York City's 44th comptroller, and began serving on January 1, 2014.\n\nStringer was an unsuccessful candidate in the , and has formed an  to determine whether he should run for Mayor of New York City in .\n\n\nStringer is Jewish, and was born and raised in  in . His mother, , was a cousin of former U.S. Representative , and served on the  before working in the . His father, Ronald, was counsel to former  . His stepfather, Carlos Cuevas, was at one time the New York City clerk and a Deputy Borough President in .\n\nStringer attended Manhattan public schools, including PS 152, JHS 52, and  (where he was editor of the school newspaper). When Stringer was still in high school at age 16, then-Manhattan Borough President  named Stringer to the . Stringer graduated from the  with a Bachelor of Arts in Government Studies in 1986.\n\nHe has distant roots from  and , he has said, and his great-grandfather was from Poland.\n\n\nIn 1983, he became a legislative assistant to man, and future Congressman, . During these years, he supported Democratic candidate Governor .\n\n\n\nIn 1992, Stringer ran for and won Nadler's New York State Assembly seat representing the , when Nadler replaced deceased Congressman . Stringer served for 13 years and six terms in the , from 1992 until 2005. During his Assembly career, Stringer served as Chairman of the Cities Committee, Chairman of the Real Property Taxation Committee, and Chairman of the Oversight, Analysis and Investigation Committee. He led the fight to end empty seat voting and reform the State Assembly's rules of operation. He authored anti-stalking legislation and was an advocate of , and  reform.\n\nIn 1999, Stringer was arrested at a  protest outside 1 Police Plaza following the . Later that year, Stringer organized a counter-rally to a  march.\n\nOn August 28, 2001, '''' political writer  wrote a piece entitled, \"Mother Dearest & the Courthouse Cabal,\" in which he discussed Stringer's involvement in courtroom politics, specifically questioning how Stringer's parents had benefited financially from his political ties, and whether some of his campaign contributors had done unethical things. Barrett also raised questions about whether acting Supreme Court judge Louis York had attempted to gain Stringer's support in his bid for a full term on the court by appointing Stringer's mother nine times as a court evaluator and conservator. In 2001, while a member of the Assembly, Stringer explored a run for .\n\n\n\n\nIn 2005, he entered the race to succeed  as Manhattan Borough President. His candidacy was endorsed by ''The New York Times''. In September 2005, he won the Democratic primary against 9 other candidates and was later elected in the November general election. He took office as Borough President on January 1, 2006.\n\nStringer issued over 40 policy reports designed to raise awareness about local issues and improve New York City. These reports have led the charge in addressing many of Manhattan's most important challenges and issues, including: increasing community input and response to development and planning projects across the borough; introducing comprehensive reform and empowerment measures to Manhattan's Community Boards; leading the fight to maintain and create new affordable housing units and schools  across the borough; empowering parents to better participate in the public school system; investigating and recommending policy action on the city's many transportation issues; and helping working families and small businesses access resources to become and remain self-sufficient.\n\n\nIn November 2008 and December 2009 as Borough President, he hosted day-long conferences on the subject of progressive . For the second conference, attended by 1,000 New Yorkers, he joined with  and the not-for-profit Just Food to address the impact of food on the health of New York City's people and their environment. He released several policy reports on food policy, including \"Food in the Public Interest\", \"FoodStat\", and \"Red Tape, Green Vegetables\".\n\n\n\nThroughout his tenure as Borough President, Stringer supported new transportation initiatives such as bike lanes. After numerous constituent complaints, in 2010 he undertook a survey, \"Respect the Lane – Clear the Path\", a policy report analyzing bike lane safety in Manhattan. During the course of the three-day survey, a total of 1,700 infractions were witnessed. The survey found that while bike lanes have a tremendous positive impact on New York City, the lanes were being misused by all parties; pedestrians, motorists, and cyclists. Working with community leaders, elected officials, local businesses, and local residents, Stringer worked to raise awareness about bike lane safety, and recommended an \"increase in protected bicycle lanes, which are separated from traffic by a physical barrier and stepped-up patrol by traffic enforcement agents to ticket scofflaws, along with better signage,\" among other ideas.\n\n\n\nStringer led the fight in New York City against  in New York State. Stringer hosted many Manhattan Community Boards to discuss the potential problems associated with \"fracking\", such as contamination to the water supply. Stringer also released a policy report in 2009, ''Uncalculated Risk: How Plans to Drill for Gas in Upstate New York could threaten New York City's Water System'', a report highlighting the impacts of \"fracking\".\n\n\n\nOn November 6, 2008, Stringer announced his decision to seek re-election as Manhattan Borough President. His Republican opponent, David Casavis, a history professor and foreign affairs writer/commentator, got 16% of the vote on a platform to abolish the office. In an October 5, 2009 article in ''City Limits'', Stringer dismissed calls by Casavis and Mayor  to eliminate his office: \"There are people who are going to call for the elimination of the public advocate office, borough president, the City Council. There are people who believe that we should have a king system here,\" says Stringer. \"Borough presidents are part of a new era and a different kind of government. It has real responsibilities and it gives you a large footprint on the issues you get involved with. It's up to the individual to take advantage of that, that you might have an impact.\"\n\n\n\nIn Spring 2009, Stringer considered a  to   . However, he announced in May 2009 that he would not run. In his statement he said: \"In light of President Obama's clear desire to avoid a Democratic primary in New York State, I have decided to focus on my re-election race for Manhattan Borough President and to suspend my exploratory committee and fund-raising efforts for the . I firmly believe that innovative thinking on issues like education and the urban environment must be joined with bedrock Democratic values on gun control and immigration if New York's interests are to be effectively represented in Washington.\"\n\n\n\n\n\n\nStringer was the Democratic nominee for New York City Comptroller in . He defeated former New York Governor  in the Democratic primary.\n\nStringer was considered one of several contenders for the 2013 New York City Mayoral primary before he announced in mid-November 2012 that he would instead run for  in the . His campaign team included spokesperson , advertising agency GMMB, and pollster . Stringer was challenged by former New York Governor  in the Democratic party primary. Stringer, originally thought to have the lead unopposed, trailed Spitzer in the polls until late August, when he took a two-point lead. Stringer defeated Spitzer in the September 10 primary 52%–48%. In the days prior to the Democratic primary, several media outlets published a piece describing Stringer's vote against legislation that stripped  of its tax-exempt status.\n\n\n\nIn 2014, Stringer criticized the health department's response to complaints about  as \"weak\", because they failed in their oversight and their inability to follow their own procedures.\n\nIn November 2014, Comptroller Stringer announced an initiative, on behalf of the $160 billion New York City Pension Funds, to give long-term shareholders the right to nominate their own directors at 75 U.S. companies. The \"proxy access\" initiative, known as the Boardroom Accountability Project, requests that these companies change their bylaws to allow shareholders who meet a threshold of owning three percent of a company for three or more years the right to list their director candidates, representing up to 25 percent of the board, on a given company's proxy. Proxy access is the ability for shareowners to nominate directors to run against a company's chosen slate of director candidates on the corporate ballot. The 75 proposals were filed based on three priority issues: climate change, board diversity and excessive CEO pay. Stringer called proxy access \"the defining issue for the 2015 proxy season\".\n\n\nIn 2017, there was no Democratic primary for the position with Stringer defeating Republican  in the general election.\n\n\n\nOn September 8, 2020, Stringer formally announced his candidacy for Mayor of New York City. He was endorsed by a number of progressive politicians shortly after his announcement, such as , , , , , , , and others. At his announcement, he criticized incumbent mayor de Blasio saying: \"We never closed the book on a tale of two cities. If anything over the last eight years, we've written more chapters.\"\n\nIn late April 2021, a woman accused Stringer of sexual misconduct when she volunteered on his 2001 Public Advocate campaign. Despite the loss of some supporters, Stringer maintained his bid in the mayoral race. Following the accusations, Stringer lagged behind  and  in the polls. A second woman accused him of sexual misconduct in June 2021.\n\nStringer finished in fifth place with 5.0% of the vote.\n\n\nOn January 18, 2024, Stringer announced that he was forming an exploratory committee to determine whether he should run for mayor in the .\n\n\nOn September 3, 2010, Stringer married Elyse Buxbaum, an arts administrator at the time, who is the deputy director of development at . The couple chose to receive a marriage license in  as a statement of solidarity with  couples who had not yet been given the right to . They have two sons, Max and Miles.\n\n\n\n\n\n*  (2020). ''''. New York.\n\n\n\n*\n*\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Michel J. Faulkner''' (; born May 21, 1957) is a former  football player who is the pastor of New Horizon Church in . Faulkner was the 2010  nominee for  for , and was the 2017 Republican nominee for .\n\n\nFaulkner was born in , . His mother, Queenita Hairston, a , married Steve Faulkner, a  . After moving to D.C., he lived and attended  in southeast Washington, D.C. area of . His family later moved to , where Faulkner attend junior high and was graduated from  in 1975. He was awarded a  to , where he was a four-year starter and freshman . In 1980, he was graduated with a  in  and . While at Tech, Faulkner was involved in drama and  presentations where he developed his  abilities.\n\nAfter college, Faulkner signed with the  and had tryouts with the  and the . In 1981, he attended  with the  and spent the 1981–1982 season with the team as a . He was cut from the Jets in 1982 because of a leg injury.\n\nAfter leaving the Jets in June 1982, Faulkner returned to Washington, D.C., where he attended  at CBN (now ) in , . Faulkner moved to  to complete his  in education and  at Virginia Tech. After completing his Master's Degree in 1985, Faulkner met  and joined  as Assistant Dean of Students. In 1987, he was promoted to Vice President for Urban Ministry. In 1988, he moved from  to the  area of .\n\n\nIn 1988, Faulkner served as assistant pastor of Lamb's Church in . Faulkner held the position of Vice President for Community Government Relations at  from 1988 to 1992. In 1989, Faulkner joined  in  as a youth pastor. Faulkner was ordained at Calvary Baptist Church in December 1991. In 1993, Faulkner became the senior pastor of Central Baptist Church in .\n\nFrom June 2002 to February 2004, Faulkner served as ’s Director of U.S. Programs. He oversaw the distribution of over $1 million in faith-based community and   to eight local churches in New York City.\n\nIn June 2006, Faulkner founded the New Horizon Church of New York in . Faulkner describes New Horizon as a  congregation focused on \"bringing light to the darkness, and being an agent of transformation to bring the Gospel to Harlem.\"\n\n\nMayor  appointed Faulkner to the Task Force on Police Community Relations following Faulkner's work on Giuliani's campaign. Faulkner has also served as Commissioner of the City Charter Review initiative and as co-chairman for the ’s HIV/AIDS Task Force. Faulkner served as Regional Chaplain for  from November 2005 to May 2006. Faulkner is a Regional Leader for Christ Covenant Coalition (Clergy Association) and is a guest speaker for national and local radio and television broadcasts including  and \"\".\n\nIn 2005, Faulkner founded the Institute for Leadership, a  to develop leaders and  programs. The institute brings leadership principles to all areas and marketplaces such as s, business leaders, s, other s,  and ministers. Faulkner serves as President of the IFL. The IFL received a grant from New York State Health Foundation in 2009 to run a statewide  campaign for the faith-based community.\n\n\n\nIn February 2010, Faulkner announced his candidacy to run as the ,  and Jobs Now , challenging Democratic and Working Families incumbent  for . Faulkner was inspired to run for office by 's successful election to 's former Senate seat. Faulkner has stated that his reason for running for Congress is his belief that \"greed and corruption\" is ruining government. He believes that government should work to assist the \"powerless\" and the \"voiceless\".\n\nFaulkner was endorsed by , the , and . Faulkner and  Chairman  campaigned together in Harlem on October 26, 2010. Steele called Faulkner a strong representative of \"new\" Republican Party.\n\nIn the November 2, 2010, general election, Faulkner received 9,235 votes (10%) of the 102,176 total votes cast, as Rangel won with 80% of the vote.\n\n\n\nOn September 21, 2015, Faulkner, a registered Republican, announced his candidacy for the , thus becoming the first official candidate to contest incumbent mayor, .\n\nIn early 2017, Faulkner decided to run for  instead of Mayor, and endorsed rival Paul Massey for Mayor. Massey subsequently dropped out of the race as well. On November 7, 2017, Faulkner was defeated by incumbent Democratic Comptroller  by a margin of 76.72% to 19.50%.\n\n\n\nFaulkner is anti-abortion.\n\nFaulkner has been critical of the law, stating that it was enacted before legislators had read it, it increases federal regulation of health care, it did not contain a provision on tort reform, it did not deregulate insurance sales between states, and it would lead to higher costs and lost jobs.\n\nFaulkner has been critical of the  administration's handling of foreign policy, especially as it pertains to . He believes that the national security of the United States is \"inextricably tied to Israel's security\", and that the U.S. must \"ensure that Israel's security is not compromised.\" Faulkner believes that the real threat to peace in the  is not Israel, but rather the \"terrorists such as , , and other ian proxies.\" Faulkner has also stated that Obama assisted in the delegitimization of Israel and as such Obama's actions \"fuel feelings of .\"\n\nFaulkner stated that government spending was an important issue for him: \"My campaign is not just about Mr. Rangel and his recent indiscretions. It is about stopping the direction in which the government, led by his party, is going. The growing size of the federal government is unbelievable. That’s a bigger scandal than the ethics issuethe size of the debt, the unbridled spending.\"\n\nDuring his 2010 congressional campaign, Faulkner appeared on the '''' show on  and , the John Batchelor Show on , the  show on , and Soul Matters with Rabbi Shimshon Nadel on Arutz 7/Israel National Radio to promote his candidacy.\n\n\nFaulkner was married to his first wife, Virginia, for 31 years until her death in 2014. They had three children. Faulkner is currently married to Sarai Padilla, a psychologist.\n\n\n* ''Restoring The American Dream'', Camden House Books, a division of Word & Spirit Resources, (2010) .\n\n\n\n\n\n*  ''Official Comptroller campaign site''\n* \n* \n*  from \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Kathleen A. Marchione''' is an American politician from the State of New York. A , Marchione served as Town Clerk and Town Supervisor in the Town of  before becoming  . She served in that role from 1997 through 2012. In 2012, Marchione was elected to the  in ; she held that position from 2013 until 2018, when she declined to seek re-election. Marchione is notable for having unseated State Senator , a fellow Republican, following his 2011 vote to legalize .\n\n\nMarchione first entered public service at the age of 25, serving as Town Clerk in her hometown of . She subsequently served as Halfmoon Town Supervisor, and later as clerk of the Saratoga County Board of Supervisors. In 1997, Marchione won a  to be the Saratoga County Clerk following the resignation of Rosemarie Corbett. She was subsequently elected to a full term in 1998, and won re-election every four years thereafter until her election to the State Senate. Marchione served as Saratoga County Clerk from 1997 to 2012. In 2007, she was chosen as the President of the New York State Association of County Clerks.\n\nIn 2009, Marchione led a group of New York county clerks to oppose a plan to require the replacement of new  beginning in 2010. In her leadership role with the NYSACC, Marchione spoke out against Gov. Eliot Spitzer's 2007 plan to allow undocumented immigrants to obtain driver licenses; Spitzer withdrew the proposal under heavy pressure from multiple sources.\n\nMarchione is married to Frank Marchione and lives in Halfmoon, New York. She has two children and one stepchild.  She is the daughter of Hall of Fame modified stock car driver .\n\n\n\nOn April 4, 2012, Marchione announced that she would challenge Sen. Roy McDonald in a Republican primary in . Sen. McDonald had voted for the Marriage Equality Act in 2011 after having voted \"no\" on same-sex marriage legislation in 2009. Marchione criticized McDonald for his same-sex marriage vote and accused him of lacking a consistent conservative voting record. Marchione faced resistance to her primary challenge from the establishment within her own party.\n\nThe Marchione-McDonald primary was variously described as \"one of three localized referend[a] on New York's 2011 same-sex marriage law\" and as \"divisive\", \"bitter,\" and \"nasty\". Initially, the results of the race were too close to call. Marchione declared victory on September 25, 2012, while Sen. McDonald's campaign announced that the senator was considering his options. Later that week, Gov. Andrew Cuomo, a Democrat, weighed in on the race by announcing his support for Sen. McDonald to continue his re-election bid on a third party line. The ''Troy Record'' reported that McDonald spent five times what Marchione did during the Republican primary contest.\n\nUltimately, Marchione defeated McDonald by 99 votes in the 2012 Republican primary; a total of 14,579 votes were cast. Sen. McDonald opted to cease his campaign and throw his support to Marchione. The '''' called the Marchione-McDonald primary contest \"a reminder that a solid portion of the Republican base remains uncomfortable with same-sex marriage, and that grass-roots insurgents are at least an even match for the party's establishment candidates.\" Marchione won the November general election, defeating  Robin Andrews and McDonald (who received 20,929 votes on the  line despite having suspended his campaign).\n\n\nMarchione began her tenure in the Senate on January 1, 2013. She was re-elected to the Senate in 2014 and 2016. In 2018, the ''Times Union'' described Marchione as \"an outspoken opponent of gun control legislation, a critic of business regulations, a voice for conservatism and an advocate for the region’s horse racing and tourism industries\".\n\nIn April 2018, Marchione announced that she would not seek re-election to the Senate. She was succeeded by her legislative director, .\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

A member of the , he sought the party's nomination for  in the , but finished third in the primary.\n\n\nRoberts earned an  from  and Bachelor of Science from . He also holds certificates in labor studies from .\n\n\nRoberts is retired from  where he worked for 30 years and was a member of the . He was elected as recording secretary of UAW Local 465 and Chair of Local 854's Education and Civil Rights Committees.\n\nDuring his employment with General Motors, Roberts also served five terms (1990–2000) as an  legislator, representing the county's 19th district.\n\n\nRoberts is also a practitioner of , holding a sixth degree  in American  Karate.     "pages": }\n\n'''Toby Ann Stavisky''' (née '''Goldhaar''', born June 26, 1939) is an American politician serving as a member of the , having held a seat since 1999. She represents the , which comprises parts of .\n\n\nStavisky was born and raised on the  of Manhattan. She attended New York City public schools before graduating from . She attended the  at  on an academic scholarship, graduating in 1960. The Senator completed graduate courses at  and .\n\nAfter working in the actuarial department of a major insurance company, Stavisky taught Social Studies in the New York City high schools. She served as District Manager in Northeast Queens for the Census, where she directed more than 1,000 field and office staff and was cited by the Commerce Department for her outstanding work.\n\nStavisky was married to Dr.  (1925–1999), a member of the  from 1966 to 1983, and of the New York State Senate from 1983 until his death in 1999. Her son, Evan M. Stavisky, is a political consultant as well as a local district leader.\n\n\nUpon the death of her husband in 1999, Stavisky ran and easily won the special election to succeed him. She is the first woman from Queens County elected to the State Senate. When she first won election, the district was predominantly , but has shifted drastically over the past two decades to become majority Asian American. As such, Stavisky has faced primaries in recent years against Asian-American candidates, but has been successful in each challenge.\n\nFrom 2003 to 2008, Stavisky served as Assistant Minority Whip and Ranking Minority Member of the Committee on Higher Education. She currently serves as the Chairwoman of the Committee on Higher Education. In 2013, Stavisky was appointed to the subcommittee on New York City Education.\n\nIn 2022, Stavisky sponsored a bill that would give state health insurance coverage to .\n\nStavisky has claimed that New York's bail reform laws have had no clear impact on the increase in crime.\n\nIn 2023, Stavisky's Senate district  from the  to the 11th.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Douglas M. Smith''' (born August 5, 1990) is an American legislator serving as the man for the  since 2018.\n\n\nSmith was born and raised on  and graduated  in  and went on to earn degrees in Mathematics and Adolescent Education from  in . Doug Smith|website=nyassembly.gov|language=en|access-date=2018-08-24}} Smith is a former high school mathematics teacher.Assembly Member Directory  New York State Assembly|url=https://nyassembly.gov/mem/Doug-Smith/story/94701|access-date=2020-12-24|website=nyassembly.gov}} Immediately prior to his election to the , Smith served as Chief of Staff to his predecessor Assemblyman .\n\nHe is currently serving in his third term in the New York State Assembly representing the 5th Assembly District and is the top republican on the influential Assembly Education Committee.\n\nSmith resides in , with his wife Elizabeth and their daughter Sophie.\n\n\nSmith represents the  which includes portions of the towns of  and , including , , , , , , , , ,  and  in  on .\n\nIn the New York State Assembly, Smith serves as Ranking Minority Member of the Education Committee, which is responsible for overseeing educational policies and programs affecting prekindergarten, elementary, and secondary education for approximately 3 million children attending both public and nonpublic schools. Doug Smith - Legislative Committee Membership|url=http://nyassembly.gov/mem/Doug-Smith/comm/|access-date=2018-09-11|website=nyassembly.gov|language=en}} The Education Committee also participates in the process for selecting persons to serve on the New York State Board of Regents.\n\nHe also serves as a member of the New York State Assembly Committees on Higher Education, Energy, Aging, and on the Commission for the Future of the Long Island Power Authority.\n\nHe previously served as the Ranking Minority Member on the Committee on Higher Education and has served as a member of the Banks Committee, Housing Committee, and the Committee on Alcoholism and Drug Abuse.\n\n\nOn April 24, 2018, Smith was elected to the  in a special election to fill the unexpired term of Assemblyman  who resigned from the Assembly on January 1, 2018, upon election as  District Court Judge on November 7, 2017. Smith was seated as a Member of the  for the  on April 30, 2018.\n\nSmith was re-elected during the general election on November 6, 2018, to serve a full term during the . He was re-elected again on November 3, 2020, to serve a second full term during the . On November 8, 2022, Smith was again re-elected to serve a third full term for the  with a two-thirds majority vote. On November 5, 2024, Smith with again re-elected to serve a fourth term for the , with record number of votes, the highest ever received for a candidate running for Member of Assembly in the 5th District. \n\n\n\nIn December 2018, Smith introduced \"Todd's Law\" legislation that would increase the penalties on property stolen that is necessary for the performance of activities of daily living by an incompetent or physically disabled person or a vulnerable elderly person.\n\nSmith has been an outspoken opponent of  in New York. In 2018, he introduced a bill to eliminate common core state standards. Smith has also introduced a bill to establish a scholarship for students who meet certain academic criteria and attend a New York state community college.\n\nIn November 2019, it was reported that New York faced a $6 billion budget deficit for the coming year, and that the deficit was expected to jump to $8.5 billion by 2023. In December 2019, Smith introduced a bill to have the New York State Comptroller create a plan to cut government spending by 1% each year.\n\nFollowing the resignation of former Governor , Smith introduced the \"Predator Portrait Prevention Act\" to require passage of a joint resolution of the state legislature to accept any portrait of a former governor that did not complete any term for which they were elected before being included in the Hall of Governors on the second floor of the New York State Capitol.\n\nIn response to the Russian invasion of Ukraine, in May 2022, Smith introduced the \"Russia Divestment Act\" to require the divestment of public funds in the Russian energy sector, prohibit entities that invest in the Russian energy sector from receiving state contracts, and withdraw investment of public funds in companies doing business with Russia.\n\n\nRepresenting the 5th Assembly District, '''Douglas M. Smith''', Republican (2018–Present) succeeds: , Republican (2011 - 2017); , Democrat (2004 - 2010); , Democrat (2001 - 2003); , Democrat (1975 - 2000); , Republican (); , Republican (1967 - 1972); , Republican (). Prior to 1966, New York State Assembly districts were apportioned differently.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''George Elmer Pataki''' (; born June 24, 1945) is an American politician who served as the 53rd  from 1995 to 2006. He previously served in the  from 1985 to 1994, and as the mayor of  from 1981 to 1984. Pataki was the third  since 1923 to win New York's governorship, after  and , and is the most recent one to do so.\n\nPataki's most notable achievements as governor included the creation of a number of new  programs, presiding over recovery efforts following the , and for increasing the state's credit rating three times. He chose not to run for a fourth term in ; he was succeeded by Democrat . Pataki and  (his second Lt. Governor) are the last Republicans elected to statewide office in New York, although Republicans  and  each briefly served as acting Lieutenant Governor in 2008.\n\nPataki announced his candidacy for the  on May 28, 2015. He withdrew from the race shortly before the primaries began on December 29, 2015.\n\n\nPataki was born on June 24, 1945 in . Pataki's paternal grandfather was Pataki János (known in the U.S. as ''John Pataki'', 1883–1971) of , . The family name's  pronunciation is  and means \"from the creek (little river).\" János came to the United States in 1908, worked in a hat factory and had married Erzsébet (later Elizabeth; 1887–1975), also Hungarian-born, around 1904. Their son, Pataki's father, was Louis P. Pataki (1912–1996), a  and volunteer fire chief, who ran the Pataki Farm. Pataki's maternal grandfather was Matteo Laganà (born in , Italy in 1889), who married Agnes Lynch of , Ireland around 1914. Their daughter, Margaret Lagana (1915–2017), is Pataki's mother. Pataki has an older brother, Louis. Pataki speaks some  as well as Spanish, French, and German.\n\nAfter graduating from , Pataki entered  in 1963 on an academic  and graduated in 1967. While there, Pataki was  of the Conservative Party of the , where he participated in debates. He received his  from  in 1970.\n\n\n in 1987]]\nWhile practicing law at Plunkett and Jaffe, P.C. in Peekskill, Pataki became friends with , who would go on to be the architect of Pataki's ascendancy to power.Revkin, Andrew. \"\". ''''. October 2, 1997. Finnegan would go on to manage Pataki's campaigns for Mayor, , , and the governorship.\" \". ''''. Retrieved on February 29, 2008. Finnegan was then appointed chief counsel to the governor in 1995, and played the key role in developing and negotiating nearly all of Pataki's early legislative success.Hernandez, Raymond. \"\". ''''. August 15, 1997.\n\n\nPataki first won elected office in November 1981. He was elected mayor of the city of Peekskill, which is located in the northwestern part of Westchester County. Pataki defeated Democratic incumbent Fred Bianco Jr., winning 70% of the vote. In November 1983, he was re-elected mayor, winning 74% of the vote.\n\n\nIn November 1984, Pataki was elected to the New York State Assembly (91st District), by defeating one-term Democratic incumbent William J. Ryan, winning 53% of the vote. In November 1986, Pataki defeated Ryan in a rematch, capturing 63% of the vote. Pataki won a third term in November 1988, winning 74% of the vote against Democratic candidate Mark Zinna. Pataki won a fourth and final term in November 1990, winning over 90% of the vote, as he only faced a minor party candidate. He was an assemblyman in the , ,  and s.\n\n\nFrom 1983 to 1992, the 91st Assembly district included parts of Westchester, Orange, Rockland, and Putnam Counties. However, in 1992, Assembly Democrats substantially redrew the district boundaries, placing the newly renamed 90th Assembly district entirely within . Instead of running in the newly redrawn district, Pataki decided to challenge seven-term incumbent  State Senator  in a Republican primary in Senate District 37 by criticizing her for taking her grandchildren to Disney World and missing a vote in . Pataki won the primary by a 52% to 48% margin. However, Goodhue still planned to appear on the November ballot on a minor party line. In November 1992, Pataki won the general election. He served in the Senate during the  and ran for governor at the next election.\n\n\n\n\nPataki was a first-term state senator from  when he launched his bid for the Republican nomination for governor in 1994. He said he launched the campaign because of his frustration in the Senate regarding how  worked and on tax issues. Pataki's campaign received a boost when he was endorsed by U.S. Sen. . He received the party's endorsement at the spring state convention and easily defeated former State Republican Chairman Richard Rosenbaum in the September primary. Pataki was considered an underdog from the start since he was running against three-term Gov.  and because Pataki had little name recognition statewide. D'Amato reportedly backed Pataki because of a poll that showed a , fiscal conservative from the New York City suburbs could win statewide for governor. The poll also showed a female running mate for  would help the ticket.  Academic  was chosen as Pataki's running mate.\n\nThe polls had Governor Cuomo ahead by as many as ten points going into the final two weeks, but they narrowed at the end. Pataki made an issue of Cuomo seeking a fourth term as governor and pledged to serve only two terms in office. Cuomo was helped late in the race by the endorsement of New York City Mayor . Pataki narrowly defeated Cuomo in the general election. Many, including Pataki himself, believed 's endorsement of Pataki was a major reason for his win. He finished with 48.8% of the vote to Cuomo's 45.5%, and independence candidate  finished with 4.2%.\n\nPataki made up for a soft performance in New York City by running up a decisive margin outside of it, especially among upstaters disenchanted with Cuomo. Pataki won all but one county outside the Five Boroughs. Pataki became New York's first elected Republican governor since Nelson Rockefeller.\n\n\n\nPataki was considered the front-runner from the start of the 1998 campaign for governor. He was unopposed for the Republican nomination and paired with a new running mate, Judge . The Democrats faced a primary battle between New York City Council Speaker , Lt. Gov. , who had switched parties, and former Transportation Commissioner James LaRocca. Vallone captured the Democratic nomination, with  running as the Independence nominee and McCaughey Ross as the Liberal Party nominee. Pataki was easily reelected to a second term in office. He finished with 54.3% of the vote, his highest percentage finish in a gubernatorial race, to Vallone's 33.2% and Golisano's 7.7%. This is the last time a Republican has won a majority in a statewide election in New York, and the first time since , when  was re-elected.\n\n\n\nPataki was considered a strong contender for a third term, despite having pledged in 1994 to serve only two terms. He ran again on a ticket with Lt. Gov. Mary Donohue and the Democrats faced a primary battle between State Comptroller  and former HUD Secretary , Mario Cuomo's son. Pataki emphasized his previous work and the need to have continuity following Sept. 11.\n\nMcCall essentially secured the Democratic nomination when Andrew Cuomo stumbled (and ultimately withdrew before the primary at the urging of his mentor ); Cuomo was quoted in the media as saying, regarding Pataki's performance post-9/11:\n\nPataki stood behind the leader. He held the leader's coat. He was a great assistant to the leader. But he was not a leader. Cream rises to the top, and Rudy Giuliani rose to the top.\n\nPataki sought the nomination of the  in his bid for a third term as well. He faced the party's founder and 1994 and 1998 nominee, , in his bid for the nomination. Pataki ran an active primary campaign and lost to Golisano. Donohue did win the primary for lieutenant governor and was the running mate of both Pataki and Golisano in the general election.\n\nIn the general election, Pataki defeated McCall and Golisano easily. As in 1998 due to Golisano's presence on the ballot, Pataki did not win a majority, instead winning a plurality. Pataki won 49.4% of the vote, and McCall only mustered 33.5% with wins in four of the five New York City boroughs. Golisano finished with the highest vote total of his political career, and the highest vote total for any candidate of the  in any statewide election.\n\nThis was the last time a Republican was elected , and the last time a Republican has cracked over 41% in a gubernatorial election until the 2022 election in which Republican candidate Congressman  amassed 47% of the vote against incumbent Democrat .\n\n\nBy the summer of 2005, opinion polls indicated that Pataki would face an uphill battle if he sought a fourth term in 2006. Accordingly, he announced on July 27, 2005, that he would not do so, saying that New York was \"a better state than it was 10 years ago\" and that he was retiring so he could \"follow a new path, find new challenges.\" He was succeeded by Democrat .\n\n\n\n\nAs Governor of New York, Pataki was known as a moderate to Liberal Republican who cut taxes and was tough on crime, but who also supported gun control, environmental protection, gay rights, and abortion rights.\n\n\n\nUnder the Pataki Administration, New York's credit rating was increased three times by , a fact that he highlighted often before his critics. During his three terms in office, he introduced and approved more tax cuts than any of his predecessors. Following through on a campaign promise, Pataki led a push to cut both the individual and the corporate tax rates in New York. The state's infamously high income tax rates dropped by 20% on average, but an economic downturn following the attacks of September 11 and increasing state spending caused  and  to coordinate an effort to roll back a number of these cuts in 2003 over Pataki's veto power.\n\nThe STAR and STAR-Plus programs were also introduced during Pataki's governorship. The STAR program introduced tax relief for New York's homeowners and landowners on their school taxes. The STAR-Plus program was later introduced when relief was diminished by increasing school taxes, increasing spending and State Aid. In his third term Pataki challenged the Speaker of the Assembly, resulting in two Court of Appeals decisions sustaining the powers of the governor to formulate a statewide budget.\n\n\n]]\nPataki advocated for Native American casinos in upstate New York. As a part of the creation of the Seneca Niagara Casino in Niagara Falls, an agreement was reached to give a percentage of the  revenue to the City of Niagara Falls each year to spend on local tourism projects and projects relating to hosting the casino.\n\n\n\nPataki describes himself as . In 1999, he called upon the Republican Party to soften its platform language regarding opposition to abortion rights.\n\n\nPataki lobbied heavily in favor of the , a  bill that had languished in the state Senate for many years due to the opposition of Senate Leader . In late 2002, Bruno finally gave in; the bill passed the Senate and was signed into law by Pataki. He opposed  as governor.\n\n\nPolls showed that the majority of New Yorkers wanted the state's death penalty laws restored. Prior to Pataki's tenure, a bill to restore the death penalty had passed the Legislature for several years in a row only to be vetoed by . Pataki made the issue a top priority of his, and when the bill reached his desk in 1995, he signed it into law. The  later ruled the death penalty law unconstitutional in a 4–3 decision in  (2004).\n\nBeing tough on crime was a major plank of Pataki's campaign for governor. In 2011, the administration touted statistics that illustrated that crime had steadily reduced during the 12 years Pataki had been governor, bringing New York from the 6th most dangerous state in the nation to the 7th safest. During his time in office, he signed into law over 100 new bills to change New York's criminal statutes. In 2000, Pataki helped lead the legislature in passing some of the then-strictest  laws in the country. Numerous aspects of the bill had been put forward by members of the Democratic-controlled Assembly but had never made it through the Republican held Senate. With numerous mass shootings in recent public memory, he urged a number of Republican Senators to support the bill, eventually passing it in a bipartisan effort. His administration also launched programs such as SAF-T (Statewide Anti-Fugitive Teams) and the 100 Most Wanted. The initiatives were aimed at disseminating descriptions of criminals who were evading law enforcement officials to promote the ability of average citizens to help aid in their capture. Versions of  and  were integrated into New York's laws under the governor as well as a number of reforms to the . The changes to the Rockefeller laws were largely focused on inmates' ability to appeal for an early release from sentences that were passed on them under mandatory minimum sentencing statutes.\n\n\nUnder the Pataki Administration a number of new health care programs were created focusing on expanding care to the state's poorest citizens.\nIn 1999, Governor Pataki signed into law comprehensive health care legislation that provided health insurance coverage, under Family Health Plus, to lower income adults who do not have health insurance through their employers.\nChild Health plus greatly expanded coverage for poorer families with children under 19 who did not qualify for . By 2001, 530,000 children had been enrolled in the program. Family Health Plus would expand insurance coverage even further, offering free insurance to families and single adults who had too much income to be covered by Medicaid but could not afford insurance. Pataki also increased the affordability and availability of medication for seniors under New York's  program by lowering fees and expanding eligibility. New York's 2003 ban on smoking in public places was passed and signed into law under the Pataki administration in the hopes that it would promote better health in New York and reduce health care cost over time. Accessing his twelve years in office, ''The New York Times'' ran an editorial praising his work on health care.\n\n\n, September 7, 2002 (back row, left)]]\n\nIn 2005, '''' placed George Pataki among the 20 individuals it commended for their personal efforts to combat global warming, citing his Greenhouse Gas Task Force and efforts to increase New York's usage of renewable energies. In 1996, Pataki oversaw the creation and passage of the Clean Water/Clean Air Environmental Bond Act. The act put forth $1.75 billion for over 2,200 environmentally minded projects throughout the state. Projects were focused on improving drinking water quality, closing landfills, investing in recycling programs, cleaning up New York's polluted waterways, funding cleanup of  and clean-air projects. During his tenure, Pataki added over one million acres to the entirety of the protected open spaces of New York. He also worked to protect the drinking water of millions of New Yorkers through the Catskill Watershed Agreement. Through the agreement, the numerous small communities that surround the 19 reservoirs that provide drinking water for New York City received $1 billion in aid to assuage environmental issues and promote local development in return for accepting higher standards of environmental regulations to better protect the reservoirs. On Pataki's final day in office, '''' ran an editorial evaluating his twelve years as governor and praised his work on the environment.\n\n\nPataki heeded mounting desire to allow New York to join numerous other states in the growing movement for charter schools. In 1998, Pataki prevailed upon the Legislature to pass a charter school law by threatening to veto a legislative pay raise if the bill was not passed. Over the course of his terms in office, Pataki would expand the availability of charter schools in New York City and raise the state's cap on charter schools to 250.\n\nIn coordination with Mayor , Pataki pushed to begin disassembling the reputation of  system as a group of remedial schools. Starting in 1999, CUNY colleges would be required to drop their remedial courses over a 3-year period and restrict students who could not pass entry exams in an effort to deliver a higher quality college education through the city colleges. Pataki also put forth legislation that would lend mayors in New York's five largest cities greater control over their education systems. Through negotiations this authority was only awarded to the mayor of New York City as an attempt to overcome a system of school boards that many considered to be hampering efforts at reform.\n\n\nLooking over his tenure, ''The New York Times'' ran an editorial that criticized Pataki for the lack of tangible political reform and the consolidation of power under his watch.\n\n\n\n\nPataki's New York City office had moved out of the World Trade Center in the months before the , as the governor had pushed for privatization of the building.\n\nFollowing 9/11, Pataki and New York City Mayor  appointed the  to distribute nearly $10 billion in federal grants and to oversee the construction of a memorial. A symbolic cornerstone for the Freedom Tower with Pataki's name was laid on July 4, 2004, and after numerous design changes, construction commenced in May 2006. The memorial was completed in 2011.\n\n\n\n\nPataki's 1994 running mate for  was , an academic best known for her critique of the Clinton health care plan. McCaughey was selected because of her work on the Clinton health care plan. Pataki choose McCaughey over sofa bed heiress ; Castro was nominated for the U.S. Senate in 1994.\n\nIn April 1997, Pataki announced that he was dropping McCaughey from his 1998 reelection ticket. McCaughey became a Democrat and unsuccessfully sought the governorship in that party's 1998 primary. She was on the 1998 general election ballot as the nominee of the Liberal Party for governor.\n\n\n\nAfter dropping McCaughey Ross from his 1998 ticket, Pataki considered several replacement running mates. In the spring of 1998 he announced his choice of State Supreme Court Justice  for lieutenant governor. Donohue did not run to succeed Pataki in 2006. In December 2006, Pataki appointed Donohue to be a Judge of the .\n\n\n\n and Lloyd Stamy]]\nIn July 2000, Pataki's name surfaced on the short list to be the running mate for Republican presidential nominee , along with the names of Governor  of Michigan, Governor  of Pennsylvania, former Senator  of Missouri, and former U.S. Labor Secretary  of North Carolina. Bush eventually selected the man who was in charge of scouting vice presidential candidates, former Secretary of Defense . Pataki had strongly campaigned for Bush, making an unsuccessful effort to keep  off the New York primary ballot (which Bush ultimately won).\n\n\nPataki and New York  Chairman  faced controversy after naming moderate   the party's nominee for the  against Senator  over conservative , who held significant advantages in both fundraising and organization.. ''Albany Times-Union'', February 25, 2004. Benjamin publicly accused Treadwell and Pataki of trying to muscle him out of the Senate race and undermine the democratic process. Mills went on to lose the election in the largest landslide for a Senate seat in the history of New York.\n\n\nPataki was instrumental in bringing the  to  in . New York City, which normally votes overwhelmingly Democratic (the Democratic presidential nominees carried 78 percent of the city vote in both 2000 and 2004), had never hosted a Republican Convention. He introduced President . A year prior, Pataki had boasted Bush would carry the state in the 2004 elections; Bush lost New York 58–40 to . Pataki notably orated, referencing the recently deceased , \"This fall, we're going to win one for the Gipper. But our opponents, they're going to lose one with the Flipper.\"\n\n\nAfter leaving the governorship, Pataki joined the law firm  in New York joining their renewable energy practice. He continued to flirt with a possible bid for president. After ruling out a presidential campaign, Pataki retained his , which he could legally use to further his own views and other political interests. In addition, Pataki has formed an environmental consulting firm with his former chief of staff John Cahill, the Pataki-Cahill Group.\n\nPataki holds an  license.\n\n\nThe Governor George E. Pataki Leadership and Learning Center, located in , is designed to educate schoolchildren on government using Governor Pataki's public service as an example. , Pataki's former  chief, led the effort to create the center. On August 14, 2008, the '''' announced that the center's sponsors had \"filed paperwork with the State Department of Education and are trying to raise $500,000 for a start-up fund so they can open the center in the fall.\" The center held Governor Pataki's official portrait, which was moved to  at the end of 2009. As of 2008, the center had three directors: David Catalfamo, the governor's former communications chief; Kimberly Cappelleri, Libby Pataki's former chief of staff; and, Amy Holden, former executive assistant to the governor.\n\n\n\nIn February 2009, Pataki was approached by Sen. , head of the Republican Senatorial Campaign Committee, about a possible 2010 run for the U.S. Senate seat to which  had been appointed. In April 2010, Pataki said he would not run against Gillibrand.\n\n\n\n\nIn November 2009, Pataki traveled to , sparking speculation. Ending months of speculation, Pataki announced on August 26, 2011, that he would not run for the Republican presidential nomination. He endorsed Mitt Romney.\n\n\nPataki announced in April 2010 that he was creating a nonprofit organization, Revere America, that would advocate repeal of the recently enacted United States , which he said was a \"horrific\" and costly bungle. As of 2015, the organization is defunct.\n\n\n\n\nIn early 2015, Pataki started exploring a candidacy for the ; On May 28, 2015, Pataki formally announced his campaign for the 2016 Republican nomination. He had previously considered running in 2008 and in , but had decided against it.\n\nPataki's candidacy was considered a long-shot because of his age, because he had not run for office since 2002, and because of his liberal stances on abortion, gun control and environmental protection. Pataki received the endorsements of two New Hampshire State Senators:  and .\n\nPataki's run failed to gain traction. He failed to make the main stage in the candidate debates, being . His national poll numbers . Pataki did not file to be on the primary ballot in multiple states and missed the filing deadlines for Alabama, Arkansas, Idaho, Ohio, Oklahoma, Texas, Utah, and Virginia. On December 29, 2015, Pataki ended his campaign before the Republican presidential primaries had begun. He endorsed Florida Senator  on January 26, 2016 and went on to endorse Ohio Governor  after Rubio suspended his campaign.\n\nAfter video footage of eventual nominee   emerged on October 7, 2016, Pataki described the Republican nominee's candidacy as \"a poisonous mix of bigotry & ignorance.\" Pataki also called upon Trump to step down as the Republican nominee.\n\n\nIn 2020, he declined to endorse  for re-election. He stopped short of endorsing , citing disagreements with foreign policy relating to U.S.-China relations. Pataki opposed efforts to decertify the election results.\n\n\nIn September 2022, Pataki endorsed Republican candidate  for Governor of New York, against incumbent Democrat . Zeldin went on to lose the  by 6.4%, the closest margin since Pataki's  win.\n\n\nPataki married his wife, Libby, in 1973. The Patakis have four children.\n\nPataki is Catholic.\n\nPataki suffered a burst  and had an emergency  on February 16, 2006, at Hudson Valley Hospital Center. Six days later, he developed a post-surgical complication ( caused by ) and was transferred to  for a second operation. From there, he was discharged on March 6.\n\nPataki has been an intense critic of the Cuomo and Hochul administrations. In 2022, he was considered to be a contender for Governor of New York for a fourth, non-consecutive term.\n\n\n*  –  (2008)\n\n\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n* (2020). ''''. New York: Skyhorse Publishing.\n\n\n\n*\n*\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
