    "pages": }\n'''Frank Skartados''' (January 3, 1956 – April 15, 2018; ) was a  politician and businessman.\n\nSkartados was a member of the . A resident of the   of , where he ran a farm, he was the Assemblyman for the 104th district of the  in the , which includes both the  and  of Newburgh, the cities of , and , the hamlet of , and the town of . He defeated 14-year  incumbent  in  for what was then the 100th district, but narrowly lost to him  in a contest not formally decided for four months.\n\nKirwan died less than a year into his term, and Skartados won the 2012  to fill the seat, the first election held for what was now the redrawn 104th district, which excluded some areas of  that were heavily Republican. He went on to win the general election that year and re-election in 2014 and 2016. After his death from  in April 2018, Skartados was succeeded by .\n\n\nSkartados was born on the Greek island of . He grew up on a small farm which he worked with his father.\n\nAt age 14, in 1970, Skartados and his mother moved to . Skartados graduated from  in upper Manhattan. He later worked in the restaurant industry and eventually owned one. His business savvy eventually allotted him the funds to educate himself at the , where he earned a degree in political science. At the same time, he worked at the Commandant's Office of the  in .\n\nAfter college, Skartados attained a master's degree in International Studies at the . He later served an internship at the  Center Against Apartheid.\n\n\nFor the next eight years, Skartados worked back at the  as chairman of the Health Department. He also taught Environmental Studies and American History. In 2000, Skartados abdicated his seat at the military academy.\n\nSubsequently, Skartados focused on renovating properties in downtown , including building the Aegean Entertainment Center, the largest entertainment venue between  and New York City. Skartados was the founder and president of the Academy Street Business Association in Poughkeepsie. Skartados helped in the revitalization of the street's business environment, which changed the negative perception of the area.\n\nIn addition to his work with the Poughkeepsie Partnership&nbsp;– a go-between to promote the partnership of business and city government agencies&nbsp;– Skartados also served on the mayor's Promotions & Events Committee to help further promote and attract new people to the city of Poughkeepsie.\n\n\nHis political career began when he defeated 14-year incumbent  in 2008. Skartados served the 100th district of the  from 2008 to 2010. However, Kirwan narrowly recaptured the seat in 2010 but died in late 2011. On March 20, 2012, a special election was held for the vacant seat, which Skartados won with more than 60 percent of the vote. He was re-elected for a full term on November 6, 2012, and on November 4, 2014, by 60% of the vote.\n\nDuring his Assembly tenure, Skartados supported bills that focused on the environment, criminal justice reforms, consumer protection, veterans benefits, business regulation reform, family court reform, and library election reform. Skartados secured millions of dollars for struggling schools in ,  and Poughkeepsie. He also helped secure state funding to purchase fire trucks, plows, and police cars, and pursue environmental projects such as the . Skartados also helped expand non-profit grounds such as soup kitchens, Newburgh Habitat for Humanity, and Newburgh Safe Harbor's Park. He remained in the assembly until his death in April 2018.\n\n\nSkartados had one child at the time of his death.\n\nOn April 12, 2018, Skartados was hospitalized in , with a \"serious illness\" and according to his chief of staff was \"not likely going to recover\". He died in the hospital three days later, of , at age 62.\n\nIn response to Skartados' death,   praised Skartados' \"legacy as a fighter for the people he loved and a voice for many who had none\".\n\n\n\n*\n*\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n*\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Melissa Mark-Viverito''' (born April 1, 1969) is an American  politician and former speaker of the  from 2014 to 2017, as well as councilmember for the  from 2006 to 2017, representing , , , , , , , and .\n\nDescribed by '''' as \"fiercely liberal\", she was elected Speaker on January 8, 2014, succeeding .\n\n\nMark-Viverito was born in , to Anthony Mark, a physician and founder of San Pablo Hospital, and Elizabeth Viverito. She grew up in Bayamón, where her mother still resides.\n\nAt the age of eighteen, she moved to New York to attend , from which she graduated in 1991 with a bachelor of arts degree. She received her  from  in 1995.\n\n\nMark-Viverito served as a member of , coordinator of the movement Todo Nueva York con Vieques, president of Mujeres del Barrio, and strategic organizer for  of the  (SEIU), an influential  union.\n\n\nAfter running unsuccessfully against  for City Council in District 8 in 2003, Mark-Viverito was elected to the position when Reed reached his term limit in 2005. During her first four years in office, Mark-Viverito sponsored and passed several pieces of legislation regarding tenant harassment, building safety, greening buildings, and park conservancies. In January 2009, she criticized the voting record of newly appointed New York Senator  on immigration.\n\nDuring Mark-Viverito's second term in the Council, she served as chair of the Parks and Recreation Committee and as founding co-chair of the .\n\nIn November 2013, she won re-election to her third term in the Council, and her close ally  was elected mayor. Soon the '''' cited Mark-Viverito as \"the front-runner\" for \"New York City's second-most powerful political post  Speaker of the City Council.\" A grassroots effort to boost her Speaker candidacy included social media, fliers, phone banking, and volunteer recruitment.\n\nMark-Viverito was elected City Council Speaker on January 8, 2014, at age 44, becoming the first member of the Council's Black, Latino and Asian Caucus to hold this position. Her first \"State of the City\" speech emphasized reform of the criminal justice system.\n\nIn January 2016, Mark-Viverito introduced a collection of eight bills known as the \"Criminal Justice Reform Act\" to reduce the penalty for acts such as violating park rules,  and  from misdemeanors to the civil process. In addition, the Criminal Justice Reform Act also suspended enforcement for \"excessive noise,\" which resulted in a sudden spike in noise complaints around the five boroughs, according to data compiled by 311, New York City's complaint submission platform. Mark-Viverito sponsored the bills so that young people in communities of color could \"fulfill their potential\" by incentivizing officers to give verbal warnings and fines but not remove the option of making arrests.\n\nIn 2016, Mark-Viverito was alleged to have pressured the New York City Housing Authority to fire a black manager of a NYCHA housing project and replace her with a \"Spanish Manager\". As of 2018, the lawsuit is still pending and the City of New York's motion to dismiss the lawsuit was denied.\n\nIn 2017, Mark-Viverito declined to boycott the , after organizers decided to honor , a prominently incarcerated member of  (FALN).\n\n\nIn 2018, Mark-Viverito announced her intention to run for the open seat of , but lost to .\n\n\nIn August 2019, Mark-Viverito announced her candidacy to replace  as representative of , but lost in the  to , receiving 4.3% of the vote with a rank of 6th place.\n\n\nMark-Viverito campaigned in solidarity with the  movement and identified herself as part of the \"99%\" of income earners despite having a net worth in the millions. She and her family inherited an estimated $6.7 million from her father, a doctor. Prior to her inheritance, she applied for a taxpayer-subsidized loan in 1998 when her property at the time was worth $310,000. As of 2014, the multi-story condominium property was worth around $1,300,000. Mark-Viverito rents out her properties, but did not report her rental income. Her spokesman claimed it to be an honest oversight on her part.\n\nIn August 2014, Mark-Viverito publicly disclosed that she was infected with the most common , the . She said she was an \"extremely private person\" but that she what announcing it because she wanted to destigmatize and raise awareness about the disease.\n\nIn 2016, in response to the   recording, Mark-Viverito public revealed that she had been a victim of , drawing the support of many, including other elected officials.\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n*  campaign website\n* \n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

His district included the communities of , , , , , , , , , , , and . A Republican, Padavan lost his  bid for re-election to Democrat .\n\n\nPadavan attended  in .     "pages": }\n'''Robert E. Antonacci''' is an American politician and judge from . A , Antonacci served as  from 2008 to 2018. He was the Republican nominee for  in , losing to incumbent Democrat . He was elected to the  in  in 2018. In 2019, Antonacci was elected as a Justice of the a trial-level courtin the Fifth Judicial District and stepped down from his Senate seat.\n\n\nAntonacci was born and raised in , and graduated from . Following graduation, he worked with  as a . He is married with two children.\n\nFollowing his time as a CPA, Antonacci attended , graduating ''cum laude'', and later entered into a private law practice.\n\n\n\nIn 2003, Antonacci ran for  of  as a Democrat, but lost to incumbent Republican Donald F. Colon. However, in 2007, Antonacci was elected to the post as a Republican. After taking office in 2008, he won reelection in 2011 and again in 2015. Antonacci resigned his post after being elected to the New York State Senate in 2018.\n\n\n\nAntonacci unsuccessfully sought the Republican nomination for  in 2010. Four years later, after no other candidates came forward, he accepted the Republican nomination for the , anticipating that he would receive matching funds for his campaign. He failed to raise enough money to qualify for matching funds under the state's pilot program and lost to incumbent .\n\n\nIn 2018, longtime Republican Senator  announced that he would not seek re-election in Senate District 50. DeFrancisco's decision left the District 50 seat open for the first time since 1992. Soon after, Antonnaci declared his candidacy for the seat. Democrats targeted the district as a prime pickup opportunity, lining up behind the candidacy of public school teacher John Mannion. Although Democrats won control of the New York State Senate in 2018, Antonacci won his election; he defeated Mannion by a margin of 51% to 49%. He was sworn in on December 29, 2018.\n\nAntonacci stepped down from his State Senate seat on December 31, 2019 after being elected to the New York State Supreme Court.\n\n\n\nLess than a year into his State Senate term, Antonacci accepted nominations to run for a seat on the , Fifth Judicial District. Antonacci sought the judgeship vacated upon the June 2019 death of James Tormey III, one of Antonacci's prominent mentors. In November 2019, Antonacci was elected to the New York State Supreme Court. He participated in a swearing-in ceremony on December 30, 2019.\n\n\n\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Malik D. Evans''' is an American politician and banker who is the 71st and current  of . A member of the , Evans previously served on the Rochester City Council as an at-large member and on the Rochester City School Board including several years as its president.\n\n\nEvans was born to Gwendolyn Evans and Lawrance Lee Evans Sr., a minister who founded the First Community Interfaith Institute focusing on social justice and two time political candidate for the  against  and Rochester City School Board in the 1970s. Evans attended , graduating in 1998, the , graduating in 2002 with an undergraduate degree and , graduating from the School of Management. Malik Evans is a member of  fraternity.\n\n\n\nIn 1996, at age 16, Evans helped found the City/County Youth Council which later became Youth Voice, One Vision and the Mayor's Youth Advisory Council. While enrolled at the University of Rochester, Evans joined Mayor 's taskforce on city's nightclubs, studying options and code enforcement for black clubs and the Mayor's Council on Race and Ethnicity. Also while at the University of Rochester, Evans was part of a 200-student sit-in outside University President 's office in 1999 calling for the preservation of the Frederick Douglass Institute for African and African-American Studies which was facing elimination at the time. He also previously worked as a legislative aide to former councilman Wade Norwood as one of his first jobs.\n\nIn 2003, Evans was first elected to the  school board. At age 23, he was the youngest person voted onto the board in its history. He served a total of 14 years on the board and was its president for five years from 2008 to 2013.  During his tenure on the school board, the RCSD improved its graduation rates to over 50%. Evans also worked as the Prosperity Program Manager at  and at . After being elected to the city council in 2018, Evans was the Finance Committee chairman of the city council, a role which he retained until taking office as mayor.\n\n\n\nEvans declared his candidacy for mayor of Rochester on  2021. He ran with the slogans of ''\"restoring transparency\"'' and ''\"building bridges\"'', also prioritizing economic development through providing job opportunities for youths and reducing  by cracking down on illegal guns. Despite incumbent Rochester mayor 's numerous controversies, Evans refused to directly attack the mayor during his campaign and the election debate, instead focusing on promoting his platform.\n\nOn June 22, 2021, Evans handily defeated Warren in the Democratic primary, receiving 66% of the vote as opposed to Warren's 34%. Despite Evans outspending and out-raising Warren, some still expected Warren to win, given her past two election victories. Evans  in the general election, as the  also threw its support behind him and no other party filed to run. As expected, Evans won the election on November 2, 2021.\n\n\nEvans was officially sworn in as mayor on January 1, 2022. As mayor, he has attempted to end the crisis of substandard housing in the city. The majority of Rochester residents are renters, and a city commission found that half of rental properties in the city were substandard. In February 2022, a housing task force was formed to develop new programs. Based on the task force's recommendations, the city government hired a housing attorney to prosecute landlords with code violations on their properties and began subsidizing the construction of new housing stock for city residents.\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Francis Joseph \"Frank\" Scaturro''' (born July 26, 1972) is an American lawyer, historian, public advocate, and politician. As a college student, he spearheaded the restoration of  in 's , and in 1998 he published a reassessment of 's presidency. Scaturro is a constitutional law expert and served as counsel for the Constitution on the  from 2005 to 2009, and helped coordinate the nomination process to elevate  and  to the . Scaturro published other books and articles about history, constitutional law, and public policy. He ran for Congress in 2010, 2012 and 2014 in  on , but was defeated each time. As of July 2023, Scaturro is president of the Grant Monument Association.\n\n\nScaturro was born in New York City in 1972. His family moved to New Hyde Park in Nassau County on Long Island the following year. His father, Salvatore, emigrated from Italy as a boy and was self-employed in a small business fixing air conditioning and refrigeration systems. His mother, Rosanne, worked near home as a legal secretary. Scaturro attended Notre Dame Elementary School in New Hyde Park and graduated with the school's highest honor. He then attended  in  where he graduated near the top of his class. He was active in scouting and attained the rank of .\n\n\n\nScaturro attended  and graduated , magna cum laude, in 1994 with an A.B. in history and political science. He won Columbia's Albert Marion Elsberg Prize for achievement in modern history. He then attended , receiving his  in 1997, winning the Fred G. Leebron Memorial Prize for the top paper in constitutional law. He was articles editor for the ''''.\n\n\n\nScaturro worked several years at two large commercial law firms headquartered in New York City, Lane & Mittendorf LLP (now ) and later,  LLP. In 2005, he became counsel for the Constitution on the staff of the Senate Judiciary Committee assisting the Committee Chairman,  (R- PA),  (R-AL, Ranking Member), and other Republican members of the committee. Scaturro's work focused on constitutional aspects of legislation and judicial and executive nominations. Among these, he assisted committee Republicans on the nominations of , , and  to the U.S. Supreme Court, and  and  to become U.S. Attorney General.\n\nIn 2010, Scaturro returned home to Long Island and became a visiting Assistant Professor at , where he taught courses on the legislative process and constitutional law. He is currently a partner at , where he handles civil rights and commercial litigation.\n\n\n\nScaturro published several books and articles about history and law, including ''President Grant Reconsidered'' (1998) which triggered a broad scholarly reassessment of the Grant presidency; '''s Retreat from Reconstruction'' (2000), an exploration of a key chapter in the history of civil rights; ''Public Companies'' (2002), a book he co-authored about making public companies responsible following recent corporate scandals; and ''Never Give In: Battling Cancer in the Senate'' (2010), which documented Sen. Arlen Specter's cancer treatment while he was still in office. In 2023, Scaturro co-edited ''Grant at 200''. Scaturro is currently working on a book about the  dispute between the United States and Great Britain following the Civil War, and how the ensuing arbitration inspired international peacekeeping efforts in future generations.\n\n\n\nCivil War general and 18th U.S. President  died in 1885 and was interred in New York City's Riverside Park.  is the largest mausoleum in the Western Hemisphere and was once among the nation's most widely visited tourist attractions. By the 1990s, however, the site had fallen into a severe state of disrepair. The tomb was scarred by graffiti. The roof leaked, the granite was cracked, and the area was used by the homeless as a latrine and drug haven. Scaturro regarded the desecration of Grant's Tomb as a national disgrace.\n\nThe tomb was administered by the , part of the . Scaturro volunteered with the Park Service to conduct guided tours at the site while he was a  undergraduate. He alerted Park Service officials that the tomb urgently needed repair, but to no avail. Scaturro persisted with regular memoranda to Park Service bureaucrats, including a 26-page report submitted in the summer of 1992. For over two years, Park Service officials simply ignored him. Undeterred, Scaturro went public with a 325-page whistleblowing report he sent to Congress and the President. His efforts drew national media attention, including a 1994 '''' editorial entitled \"Dishonor for a Hero President\" which said, \"the tomb's lamentable condition demands more funds from Washington.\" Scaturro also sued the Interior Department and National Park Service in federal court to force it to fulfill its legal duties to the public. His efforts paid off. Congress tripled the site's operations budget, including funds for security during off hours when the site was closed, and appropriated $1.8&nbsp;million for a full restoration. Scaturro explained to reporters, \"I only did what I did because I had no other resort ... the only thing left was abandoning the site, and that was not an alternative to me.\" Restoration was completed by April 27, 1997, the 100th anniversary of the site's dedication and Grant's 175th birthday. It was re-dedicated that day. Grant's descendants, appalled by the prior condition of the tomb, hailed Scaturro as a hero.\n\n\n\nIn 2010, Scaturro made his first bid for the Republican nomination to represent  in . After Scaturro gained momentum to defeat the Democratic incumbent, , the chairman of Nassau County's notorious Republican machine, , hand-picked a machine stalwart, Nassau County legislator, , to defeat Scaturro. Nationally syndicated columnist  opined that Mondello preferred to \"boot an election in order to maintain his own personal power.\"\n\nIn a three-way primary, Becker won with 11,194 votes to Scaturro's 8,241 and Dan Maloney's 3,192. McCarthy beat Becker in the general election 94,483 votes to 81,718.\n\n\nA federal court unexpectedly ordered the primary for Congress take place on June 26, yielding a very low turnout. With only 7% of registered Republicans voting, Becker narrowly won the primary with 6,836 votes to Scaturro's 5,531. Nonetheless, Scaturro won the Conservative Party primary by a write-in votea first in the modern history of  for an electoral district that size. In the general election, Scaturro won 15,603 votes on the Conservative line, despite the absence of a get-out-the-vote drive, the effects of , and a national Democratic wave. Scaturro's success on a minor party line was greater than that of any congressional candidate in the 4th District since 1986. He also received over 40% more votes within the district on the Conservative Party line than Republican-Conservative presidential candidate, Mitt Romney, and U.S. Senate candidate, Wendy Long.\n\n\nOn October 21, 2013, Scaturro announced he would run again to challenge Congresswoman  to represent New York's 4th Congressional District. News media reported McCarthy, a nurse and lifelong smoker, was suffering from lung cancer, and on January 8, 2014, she announced that she would not seek reelection. Democrats then announced their bid to win this open \"purple\" seat. Syndicated columnist  wrote that Scaturro \"has a serious chance to win the Republican as well as Conservative nomination this year... [in what] could be a much more seriously contested seat than it was [in 2012].\"\n\nOn January 29, 2014, Democrat and Nassau County District Attorney, , announced she would run for the 4th District seat. It was reported she would face a primary contest from Nassau County legislator Kevan Abrahams. Rice was endorsed by nine-term incumbent McCarthy. As of the January 31, 2014, FEC filing deadline, Scaturro was the only Republican candidate to have raised money, with over $113,000 cash on hand.\nThe Nassau County Republican Committee and the Conservative Party both nominated  to face Rice but Scaturro primaried Blakeman and lost badly. Blakeman beat Scaturro in every town and won by over 30 points.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n* Facebook|publisher=facebook.com|access-date=March 16, 2014}}\n*\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
          }
        ]
      }
    }
  }

    "pages": }\n'''Simcha Eichenstein''' (born August 6, 1983) is an American politician from . He is a member of the .\n\n\nSimcha Eichenstein was born to a  from a prominent  rabbinical family in , where he grew up and attended s.Donn, Yochonon (April 26, 2018) , ''Hamodia''Witt, Stephen (August 20, 2018) , ''Kings County Politics''\n\nIn July 2011, Eichenstein, by then a known political operative, was at the front lines of the search for the suspect in the . His wife helped to identify Levi Aron through her job as a receptionist at the dentist's office that Aron was a patron of.\n\n\nEichenstein started his career as an aide to political consultant .\n\nFrom 2011 until 2015, Eichenstein was the senior adviser to  . Following this, he was director of political and governmental services to the , .\n \nOn April 26, 2018, Eichenstein announced his candidacy for the open  District  seat, covering most of Borough Park and part of , being vacated by . He won the seat unopposed in the , becoming the first  lawmaker from Brooklyn elected to any level of government. As Hikind's hand-picked successor, Eichenstein was considered to be the front-runner in the race, running unopposed as the  candidate in the primary election in September 2018. His candidacy was supported by  of various Hasidic sects, including , , , and , as well as by Senator , former Senator , and New York City Mayor .\n\nEichenstein has strongly opposed the government mandating secular education in Hasidic schools.\n\nIn March 2020, Eichenstein co-sponsored a bill promoted by  that sought to end driver license suspensions for drivers with unpaid fines, saying: \"Without a driver's license, a person cannot drive to work or to school, or even to court to pay their fine... Let's keep our safe and responsible drivers on the roads, instead of being embroiled in needless and wasteful court appearances... This new legislation would represent a victory for all New York drivers.\"\n\nIn October 2020, during the , Eichenstein said he was \"outraged\" with the \"draconian measures\" implemented by Governor  to curb the spread of coronavirus in various neighborhoods of New York City.\n\n\nAssembly Speaker  appointed Eichenstein to serve on a number of committees, including Aging, Cities, Housing, Real Property Taxation, and Social Services. Eichenstein serves as Chair of the Subcommittee on Outreach and Oversight of Senior Citizen Programs.\n\n\nEichenstein is married, and the father of four children. He is a life-long resident of Borough Park, Brooklyn.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Tremaine Wright''' (born November 2, 1972) is the Chairwoman of the  and a former member of the  from the 56th district, which includes parts of  in .\n\nOn September 1, 2021, Wright was selected by Governor  to chair the Cannabis Control Board of the newly created .\n\n\nWright was born and raised in , living down the block from the home she was raised in.  A graduate of  and the , Wright practiced law both in private firms and as a public defender with Brooklyn Law Services.\n\nPreviously, Wright was the chairperson of , and also formerly owned a neighborhood coffee shop. In 2009, Wright ran for the  against incumbent  but lost.\n\n\nAfter sixteen years representing the district, Assemblymember  announced that she would retire instead of seek another term in 2016. Soon after, Wright announced her intentions to run to replace her. Facing Karen Cherry in the Democratic primary, Wright won the nomination by a 59% to 41% margin.\n\nWright won the general election unopposed, and was sworn into office on January 1, 2017. Wright did not run in the Democratic primary for her Assembly seat in 2020 so that she could run for the .\n\n\n\nOn January 11, 2020, State Senator , representing , announced that she would be retiring and not running for re-election in 2020. As part of this announcement, she endorsed Wright as her successor, and Wright entered the race against schoolteacher , and former Montgomery staffer Jason Salmon.\n\nMore than a month after the Democratic primary was held on June 23, 2020, the final absentee ballots were counted, and Brisport was named the nominee with a 13-point lead over Wright. Salmon finished in third.\n\n\n\nSince September 6, 2021, Wright has been chair of the Office of Cannabis Management's Cannabis Control Board, where she is charged with deliberating regulatory and tax policies regarding medical and adult-use cannabis in New York State.\n\n\n\n\n\n* official site\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Alfred C. Graf''' (born February 13, 1958) is an American politician and attorney who served as the man for the 5th district from 2011 to 2017. A member of the , he represented portions of the towns of  and , including , , , , , , parts of , ,  and  in  on . Graf has been a Suffolk County District Court Judge since 2018.\n\n\nGraf was born and raised on Long Island and graduated from Farmingdale High School in 1976. He enlisted in the  in June 1976 and eventually rose to the rank of Operations Specialist Third Class Petty Officer. Graf received an honorable discharge in June 1980.\n\nAfter returning to civilian life, Graf joined the . He worked his way up from patrol to a plainclothes unit and was awarded numerous citations for exceptional police duty before being forced to retire due to an injury. He then worked for Wells Fargo Guard Services as an Accounts Manager.\n\nAfter moving upstate to , Graf was elected as Supervisor for the . After two terms as a town supervisor and at the age of 39, Graf went back to school. He received a bachelor's degree in elementary education from  and taught in an alternative education program for children. Graf later received a Juris Doctor from .\n\nGraf lives in . He and his wife Mary have three children: Charles, Jean Marie, and Caitlin.\n\n\nIn November 2010, he was elected to the State Assembly after defeating incumbent Assemblywoman . He was re-elected in 2012, 2014, and 2016.\n\nIn November 2017, he was elected to the Suffolk County 5th District Court.\n\n\n\nAssemblyman Alfred C. Graf served as the ranking minority member of the New York State Assembly Committee on Codes, and was also a member of the Committees on Education, Judiciary, and Housing.\n\nDuring the 2013-2014 Legislative Session, Graf was appointed to the New York State Assembly Minority Task Force on  and traveled the state holding hearings on New York State's implementation of the Common Core curriculum. During the 2015-16 Legislative Session, Graf was appointed to the New York State Assembly Minority Task Force on Heroin Addiction and Community Response and travelled the state holding hearings on the heroin epidemic.\n\nUpon his election as District Court Judge, Graf resigned his seat in the New York State Assembly effective January 1, 2018. He was succeeded by his longtime Chief of Staff, , who was overwhelmingly elected in a Special Election held on April 24, 2018.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n\n'''Marc C. Panepinto''' is an American attorney and Democratic politician from .\n\nPanepinto graduated from The University at Buffalo School of Law. He is a founding partner at the Buffalo law firm of Dolce Panepinto. Panepinto was convicted of misdemeanor election law violations in 2001.\n\nPanepinto ran for the  in the  in the 2014 elections. He won the election, receiving 34% of the vote;  nominee Kevin Stocker finished with 30%,  nominee  (the ) received 28%, and  nominee Timothy Gallagher (a  who did not campaign) received 8%.\n\nPanepinto did not seek re-election in 2016. Following Panepinto's announcement that he would not seek re-election, the Erie County District Attorney's Office opened an investigation into claims of an underage drinking party at Panepinto's home.\n\nOn June 28, 2018, Panepinto pleaded guilty to federal corruption charges arising out of an attempted cover-up of unwanted sexual advances he made to a member of his Senate staff in January 2016. On December 14, 2018, Panepinto was sentenced to two months in prison. In December 2020, Panepinto's law license was suspended for one year. Panepinto was reinstated to the practice of law in January 2022.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Thomas J. Abinanti''' (born December 28, 1946) is an American politician, lawyer, and former member of the  from , . A member of the , Abinanti was elected to the State Assembly in 2010 to replace Assemblyman , and represented central , .\n\n\nBorn in , Abinanti graduated from  in 1964. He received a  in  from  in 1968 and a  from  in 1972.\n\n\nAbinanti moved to Westchester in 1975 and lived in Greenburgh until 2011 when he moved to Pleasantville. He was legislative counsel to a Congressman and staff counsel to the Speaker of the New York State Assembly and various Assembly committees. He served as a prosecuting attorney for the villages of Ardsley and Dobbs Ferry. Abinanti has taught continuing legal education courses for   and courses in state and local government as an adjunct professor at .\n\nAbinanti served as Greenburgh Town Councilman twice (1980&ndash;1984 and 1990&ndash;1991). Abinanti was elected as Westchester County Legislator ten times. For almost twenty years (1992–2010), he represented the 12th District on the Westchester County Board of Legislators, which included the villages of Irvington, Dobbs Ferry, Hastings, Ardsley, and much of unincorporated Greenburgh, including East Irvington, Central Greenburgh, Hartsdale and Edgemont. On the County Board, he served as Majority Leader for three terms after the Democrats first assumed the majority on the Board for the first time in the history of the Westchester Legislature.\n\nHe is a practicing attorney with an office in Pleasantville.\n\n\nAbinanti was first elected as a member of the New York State Assembly in 2010 and has served six terms.\nHe represented the 92nd District of the State Assembly which included the  of Greenburgh and , including the  of Ardsley, , Dobbs Ferry, , Irvington, , Pleasantville, and , as well as parts of the . \nHe served as chair of the Assembly Committee on Libraries, the Assembly Committee on Investigations, the Assembly Committee on Banks and the Assembly Committee on People with Disabilities\n\nIn 1996 and 2000, Abinanti ran unsuccessfully for the 35th District of the  against the incumbent  State Senator .\n\n\nThree voters filed objections to the petition of Abinanti's opponent, . Out of many objections, the Westchester Board of Elections deemed one validthat Williams used the term \"New York State Assembly, District 92,\" to describe the office she was running for.  The Board of Elections struck  Williams from the ballot because of the objection.\n\nWilliams then brought the case to court claiming the description was sufficient to describe the office she was seeking. Judge Gretchen Walsh ruled in Williams' favor. Williams and Abinanti both appeared on the ballot in the June 2020 primary.\nAbinanti won the Primary and then won the General Election.\n\n\nAbinanti is married to Janet Longo-Abinanti. They have two children. Abinanti is an attorney and advocate for people with disabilities \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n*\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Walter T. Mosley III''' (born September 19, 1967) is an American politician who is currently serving as Secretary of State for New York. He previously represented the  of the , serving the neighborhoods of , , , and parts of  and . In 2020, Mosley lost his primary to nurse and political newcomer .\n\n\nMosley was born in Brooklyn, New York. His mother is Marilyn Mosley, the president of Progressive Association for Political Action (PAPA) and chief of staff to the Speaker of the House Corey Johnson. His father is Walter T. Mosley, Sr., a retired insurance broker who currently lives in Ohio.\n\nHe attended , where he obtained his  in . He received his  degree from  in 1998.\n\n\nMosley served as a district leader, senior adviser to the Deputy Speaker of New York State Assembly and  and senior consultant to the  before running to for Assembly.\n\n\nMosley ran to fill 's Assembly seat in the 57th district in 2012 when Jeffries ran for Congress. Mosley won the Democratic primary with 62.8% of the vote, beating out Olanike T. Alabi and Martine Guerrier. He handily defeated Republican challenger , who Hakeem Jeffries had beaten in 2010, in the general election with 97.6% of the vote. Mosley ran unopposed in 2014, 2016, and 2018, running on both the Democratic and Working Families Party lines in 2016 and 2018.\n\n\nHe was originally a co-sponsor of a  to place a monitor with  in the East Ramapo School District in , an -dominated school district that was diverting funds to s. Mosley took his name off after meeting with both sides, saying that the discussion about the bill has anti-Semitic overtones. He refused to meet with the sponsor of the bill, a 71-year-old former East Ramapo schoolteacher, and ultimately did not vote on the bill.\n\n\nMosley faced his first primary challenger since 2012 in the Democratic primary on June 23, 2020 against . While Mosley led Forrest by 588 votes on election night,  were more significant than usual due to the . On July 22, 2020, once absentee ballots had been counted, Forrest was declared the winner of the primary by over 2,500 votes.\n\n\nMosley was nominated by Governor  to be Secretary of State, and was confirmed the New York state Senate on May 22, 2024.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''William T. Stachowski''' (born February 14, 1949) is an American politician from .\n\n\nStachowski attended Bishop Ryan High School in Buffalo, New York. He graduated from the College of the Holy Cross in Worcester, Massachusetts, where he played Varsity Football. He was All New England and won the Davitt award as the Holy Cross best defensive player. He entered politics as a Democrat, and was a member of the Erie County Legislature (3rd D.). In November 1981, he was elected to the New York State Senate, to fill the vacancy caused by the resignation of Raymond F. Gallagher, and took his seat during a special session on December 3, 1981.\n\nHe was re-elected many times, and remained in the Senate until 2010, sitting in the , , , , , , , , , , , , ,  and s.\n\nStachowski chaired the Commerce, Economic Development and Small Business Committee. This committee works closely with the . Stachowski also sat on the  and the Legislative Commission on the Development of Rural Resources. He was also a member of the \n\nOn December 2, 2009, Stachowski was one of eight Democratic state senators to vote against legislation which would legalize same-sex marriage in New York. This legislation would fail to pass the Senate.\n\nHe worked closely with  President  to carry out the  plan. Stachowski sponsored and passed legislation in support of UB 2020 in the Senate. In 2010, he ran for re-nomination, but was defeated in the Democratic primary by Erie County Legislator . Kennedy went on to win the general election.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Inna Vernikov'''}}}} (born August 30, 1984) is an American attorney and politician serving as a member of the  for the . The  of the City Council, her district includes the neighborhoods of , West Brighton Beach, , , and parts of   and  in . Formerly a Democrat, Vernikov is a member of the .\n\n\nVernikov was born in  in ,  (now southwestern ), to  parents. She attended ORT Specialized School #41, a Ukrainian . At age 12, she immigrated with her family to the . She received a BA from  and a  from .\n\n\nVernikov served as an aide to  . Prior to running for City Council, Vernikov was an  and .\n\n\n\nPreviously a registered Democrat, Vernikov switched parties and became a  to run for office and after seeing the rise in antisemitism and what she sees as  in New York City. She is a supporter of . While campaigning, she said “Jews coming from the former Soviet Union are very familiar with communism and socialism, and many of us feel strongly that what today’s Democratic Party is promoting is exactly what we ran froma place where speech was censored, where we were not allowed to practice religion, where we didn’t have freedom or economic opportunity.”\n\nVernikov received the support of the district's former councilman Democrat  (who had been expelled from the council after pleading guilty to tax fraud), and was endorsed by  (who made a  on her behalf). She was elected to the City Council after defeating the Democratic nominee, Steve Saperstein. She became one of five Republicans in the 51-member council, and the first Republican to represent a portion of Brooklyn in the New York City Council since  in 2002.\n\n\nAs a councilwoman, Vernikov organized a rally against  in New York City outside  in Manhattan. She had also organized a march against antisemitism after two Jewish teenagers were assaulted for wearing a  with the logo of the . After the faculty at  passed a resolution supporting  against Israel, Vernikov announced she would pull $50,000 in funding for the law school and redirect it towards .\n\nShe voted against expanding New York’s  program, which issues speeding tickets when a driver exceeds the posted  by 11 or more miles per hour in a . In September 2022, it was reported that Vernikov had been caught on camera for repeatedly and recklessly speeding through school zones. She had received 23 camera-issued tickets since mid-2020. She had also received 31 other non-moving violations.\n\nIn August 2022, Vernikov withdrew her $5,000 donation to the  for allegedly banning Florida governor  from their events, though the museum denied banning anyone. In December 2022, Vernikov called for the national Republican Party leadership to condemn Trump for hosting  and  at his residence, where West supposedly made repeated  views.\n\nIn March 2023, '''' published a report revealing that Vernikov sent an email blast, using her official government email account, to constituents soliciting business for $300 martial arts classes offered by Legion Self Defense; her email also included a link for her constituents to sign up. Vernikov was the Chair of the executive board of Legion Self Defense, and her biography on the City Council website lists her as “Chair at Legion Self Defense. The  prohibits the use of public resources for financial gain. Vernikov said that her role is not paid, but New York City ethics rules also prohibit officials from using city resources for non-city purposes. Professor , a former Chairperson of the New York City Conflicts of Interest Board, said Vernikov likely violated the government's ethics law, stating: \"That’s a clear violation of  rules.\"\n\nOn October 13, 2023, Vernikov was arrested on charges of criminal possession of a firearm after bringing a gun to a pro-Palestinian rally by 's campus. Vernikov had accused the protestors of supporting  following the start of the , and claimed the rallies would make  campuses unsafe for Jewish students. The charges were later dropped by the  over a lack of proof that the gun was operable, citing a lab report that the gun was unloaded and missing its recoil spring assembly.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Rafael \"Ralph\" Salamanca Jr.''' (born July 2, 1980) is the councilmember for the  of the .  He is a . The district includes portions of , , , , , , , and  in .\n\n\nSalamanca was born and raised in  to parents from .  His father worked the docks at the  while his mother was an administrative worker in healthcare. Salamanca did not finish high school, but did receive his high school diploma equivalency certificate and subsequently earned an associate degree from .\n\nA lifelong resident of the , Salamanca began his career working as an administrative assistant for a healthcare services provider, and later went on to organize surrounding healthcare issues in both  and , including in , with future-New York City Councilmember .\n\nSalamanca was a member of , where he would advocate for issues in the  and  neighborhoods. He eventually became the District Manager for the board, and also served as the President of the 41st Precinct Council. He gained citywide attention for his work as the Community Board Manager for shutting down  in the community that were havens for criminal activity.\n\n\nIn 2015, Councilwoman  resigned from her seat on the City Council. Salamanca entered the race for the special election to replace her and won a six-way Democratic primary election, with 39% of the vote. He was sworn into office on March 8, 2016.\n\nSalamanca ran again in November 2016 to finish Arroyo's term, won his first full term in 2017, and was re-elected in 2021. Salamanca explored but ultimately did not pursue a candidacy for Bronx Borough President in 2021. \n\n\n\n\nIn September 2021, a stray bullet shattered Salamanca's office window while he was inside with constituents.     "pages": }\n| signature           = Anna Kelles Signature.png\n| website             = \n| residence           = \n}}\n\n'''Anna Kelles''' (born April 11, 1974) is an American  politician who currently represents  district 125, New York State Assembly |url=https://www.nyassembly.gov/mem/Anna-R-Kelles/bio/ |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210326071529/https://www.nyassembly.gov/mem/Anna-R-Kelles/bio/ |archive-date=2021-03-26 |access-date=2021-03-25 |website=www.assembly.state.ny.us}} which includes  and parts of .\n\n\nKelles spent her childhood in . She earned a bachelor's degree in biology and  from  in 1997 and a doctorate in  from the  in 2008.\n\nKelles worked in  between her degrees as a high school biology teacher and  ecological guide. After earning her Ph.D, she taught  at  and  before starting a private practice in nutrition and wellness.\n\n\nKelles served in the  Legislature 2015–2020, where she drafted legislation on subjects including  and .\n\nKelles was elected November 12, 2020, defeating  Matthew McIntyre in the general election race to represent New York Assembly District 125. Kelles considers herself a  democrat. Her platform includes , , economic recovery, , , , and . She also supports , having campaigned in the midst of the .\n\nKelles visited the  in February 2021 in order to \"bear witness\" to conditions at the prison, one of the oldest in the United States. She criticized the small cells and the mental health implications of extended . She and other legislators advocated for the Justice Roadmap, which includes measures to reform solitary confinement and ensure fair and timely parole. She joined several advocacy groups in this position, including .\n\nKelles was among a number of  politicians to criticize Governor  after  were published that he had  several women, first calling for him to resign if found guilty by an investigation led by State Attorney General , then calling for him to resign immediately, signing on to a letter along with 58 other Democrats in statewide elected offices. She and others also criticized Cuomo for the , as it had been found that data on COVID-19 deaths in s had been altered.\n\nKelles is proposing a Earned Time act to shorten sentences for good behavior of prisoners and a Save Journalism Act to combat monopoly practices and to promote local media and newspapers across New York.\n\nIn May 2023, after testifying in front of the  on , of which she is critical of due to environmental concerns, her  account was hacked to promote cryptocurrency.\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* \n*  \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Michael Gerard Grimm''' (born February 7, 1970) is an American former politician who represented New York in the  from 2011 to 2015, when he was convicted of tax fraud and resigned from Congress. Grimm represented  during his first term, after which he represented . Both districts consisted of  and parts of . Grimm is a member of the ; during his time in office was the sole Republican to represent a significant portion of .\n\nOn April 28, 2014, Grimm was charged by federal authorities with 20 counts of fraud, federal , and perjury. On December 23, 2014, he pleaded guilty to a single count of felony tax fraud, and \"acknowledged committing perjury, hiring illegal immigrants, and committing wire fraud\". After initially vowing to retain his seat, Grimm announced on December 30, 2014, that he would resign from Congress effective January 5, 2015. On May 5, 2015,  won the  to replace Grimm. On July 17, 2015, Grimm was sentenced to eight months in prison for tax evasion. He began his prison term on September 22, 2015, after a brief delay for medical treatments.\n\nOn October 1, 2017, Grimm launched a campaign to attempt to win back his old House seat in the 11th district. On June 26, 2018, he lost in the Republican primary.\n\n\nGrimm was raised as a Catholic in , the son of Petrina (née Castronova) and Gerard Grimm. He is of German, Irish, and Sicilian descent. He graduated from  in 1988.\n\nGrimm entered active duty with the  in 1989. He received a combat promotion to , and was awarded the , , the , among other awards.\n\nGrimm received a  in  from  in 1994. He transferred to the U.S. Marine Corps Reserve and was discharged from service in 1997. He received a  ''('') from  in 2002.\n\n\n\n\nGrimm entered the  as a clerk in 1991. In 1995, he entered the  in . He graduated as a  and was certified to become an . He transitioned into undercover agent work, eventually working in the FBI  Squad, and was assigned to the inside activities of , 's brother. Grimm worked for the FBI as an agent for nine years.\n\nIn 2011, , writing for '''', reported that Grimm had been the subject of an internal investigation into allegations that he abused his authority as an FBI agent in a nightclub in 1999. At the time of the'' New Yorker'' report, the  and U.S. Justice Department had not released documents regarding the alleged incident. Grimm stated that the incident had been fully investigated and that he had been cleared of all allegations.\n\nDuring his time with the FBI, Grimm spent two years posing as a small-cap stockbroker, uncovering white-collar criminals on . According to Grimm, the firm was involved in , making false trades, and manipulating stocks. After building a strong case for two years, he and the firm's partners were arrested together, at which point the police informed the group that they had been infiltrated by an undercover agent. Grimm stated in 2011 that he has long been aware of the possibility that people may try to take revenge on him. He left the FBI in 2006, citing his exhaustion from working long hours.\n\n\nBefore joining the FBI, Grimm worked for a year for Whale Securities, an investment banking firm. Shortly before leaving the bureau, Grimm invested in a luxury Texas development.\n\nIn 2006, Grimm founded a small  in  called Healthalicious. He co-owned and served as principal and  of Austin Refuel Transport, an -based  company. As of 2011, Grimm owned 28% of the company, although he is no longer involved in daily operations nor is he CEO. In July 2011, the '''' reported that Austin Refuel Transport had received 11 safety violations in two  checkups. Grimm's spokesman said that he now \"has no authority or managerial role in the daily activities of the company. He is simply a silent investor.\"\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nGrimm launched his campaign for the 13th New York Congressional District seat on January 23, 2010. He was endorsed by former   as well as , a former U.S. Representative and  . He was also endorsed by the . He was challenged by Michael Allegretti who was endorsed by former six-term U.S. Representative , the  Republican Party, State Senator , and State Assemblyman . Allegretti worked for the nonprofit  and cited his relationships with NYC Mayor  and former  . Grimm chose not to contest the Staten Island's party endorsement because of their \"corrupt political culture\" and \"sham convention.\"\n\nGrimm's primary win was divisive for the Republican Party leadership, which favored Allegretti. His campaign gained national attention from the Tea Party and the National Republican Congressional Committee, which contributed $90,000 to Grimm's campaign. He received endorsements from high-profile Republicans, including Giuliani, , , and former President , who applauded his service in the Gulf War.\n\nGrimm faced incumbent  in the general election. On October 12, the '''' reported that it had been receiving emails from the McMahon campaign attacking Grimm's business credentials. Grimm reportedly admitted in an interview with the ''Staten Island Advance'' that his former restaurant in Manhattan, Healthalicious, had been on the verge of bankruptcy, forcing him to sell his stake in it. A major difference between the two candidates was the issue of the U.S. economic stimulus package, which the ''Advance'' called the \"starkest contrast\" among the two candidates. Grimm stated that the stimulus was a \"huge waste\" of taxpayer money and ineffective in generating job creation and economic recovery, whereas McMahon cited improvements in the state budget and renovations on the Staten Island Expressway and the Saint George Ferry Terminal as direct successes of the stimulus.\n\nOn November 2, 2010, Grimm defeated McMahon in the race, 51% to 48%. The ''Advance'' reported that Grimm won in large part due to his political signs, which became popular among his supporters. They stated, \"McMahon raised my property taxes 18.5%\".\n\n\n\nAfter redistricting, Grimm's district was renumbered the 11th District. He was challenged by Democrat Mark Murphy, a former  to  . Grimm won reelection to a second term, 53%–46%.\n\n\n\nIn 2014 Grimm received the backing of the Staten Island Republican party and the Independence Party, who called him \"'a truly independent voice' for his constituents.\" He faced  nominee  in the general election. Grimm was endorsed by the Association of Flight Attendants-CWA, the International Union of Painters and Allied Trades, the United Transportation Union, and the Humane Society Legislative Fund.\nGrimm defeated Recchia on election night, November 5, 2014.\n\n\n\nOn October 1, 2017, Grimm launched a campaign for reelection to his old House seat in New York's 11th District. On May 30, 2018, President  endorsed incumbent Representative Dan Donovan. Donovan defeated Grimm in the June 26 Republican primary, 63.9% to 36.1%.\n\n\nDuring a Sean Hannity interview of all freshmen Republican members, Representative-Elect Grimm took exception to being asked if he was a conservative. He replied that he was \"American first\" and that \"we have become way too polarized,\" indicating a desire for compromise with Democrats. Grimm did not join the  in the House, instead joining the more moderate .\n\n\nGrimm was appointed to the , which the ''Staten Island Advance'' considered a major opportunity for Grimm to influence the debate on financial reform. Roughly 70,000 of his constituents were involved in financial services, making this a vital issue for his political profile.\n\nGrimm introduced legislation that would prohibit potential whistle-blowers from receiving a cash reward from the Securities and Exchange Commission unless they report wrongdoing to their employers before reporting it to the SEC.\n\nGrimm voted for the fiscal cliff compromise bill that permanently extended most of the Bush tax cuts.\n\n\nAfter the , Grimm voiced support for \"security-based situational awareness training\", including how to spot suspicious people, when to run for an exit, and how to keep guards at close range. Grimm also said congressmen should consider carrying firearms. House Leader  called his suggestions an \"excellent idea\" and indicated that security would be a major focus for Congress in 2011.\n\n\nGrimm voted in favor of the Pain-Capable Unborn Child Protection Act, a bill banning abortions after the 20th week of fertilization.\n\n\nGrimm voted to repeal the  in the House, as he had promised during his campaign. He was called \"hypocritical\" by several Democrats for enrolling in the congressional health-care plan.\n\n\nGrimm has expressed support for immigration reform and was one of six Republicans to vote against an amendment that would have resumed deportation of \"Dreamers\".\n\n\nGrimm was appointed to the House Republican Israel Caucus in January 2011, serving as co-chair. In February 2011, as House Republicans were pushing for deep cuts in , Grimm wrote a letter to  saying he would vote against any budget that reduced aid to Israel. Grimm was also named chair of the House Republican Policy Committee's Task Force on Foreign Policy. \n\n\nGrimm opposed a military strike on the Assad regime in Syria, stating, \"I am no longer convinced that a U.S. strike on Syria will yield a benefit to the United States that will not be greatly outweighed by the extreme cost of war.\"\n\n\nAccording to a January 27, 2012, '' ''article, several followers of Orthodox Rabbi  said Grimm's campaign had accepted questionable donations. Three of Pinto's followers reportedly said that Grimm or Ofer Biton, a top aide of Pinto's, had told them that the campaign would find a way to accept donations that were over the legal limit. Grimm stated, \"Any suggestion that I was involved in any activities that may run afoul of the campaign finance laws is categorically false and belied by my life of public service protecting and enforcing the laws of this country.\"\n\n\nIn June 2013, Grimm stated that he believed water fees should be waived for survivors of  who had been displaced from their homes. Under New York City's Department of Environmental Protection rules, all homeowners are subject to a minimum charge of $1.19 per day, even if a home uses no water during a given period. Residents who had been displaced from their homes for long periods of time received water bills over $500 for damaged, vacant properties. Grimm called the bills \"ridiculous,\" saying, \"That's $500 these people could use to replace a washer or dryer or refrigerator swept out to sea during Sandy.\"\n\n\nOn January 28, 2014, -TV political reporter Michael Scotto was interviewing Grimm in a balcony hallway of the U.S. Capitol building about the recently concluded . He then tried to question Grimm about a campaign finance investigation. Grimm said he would not discuss the investigation. As Scotto started to mention the investigation again, Grimm walked off. Scotto then turned to the camera and implied that Grimm did not want to face the issue on camera. Grimm then threatened Scotto, saying that he would \"break [Scotto] in half,\" as well as threatening to throw Scotto over the balcony.\n\nGrimm issued a statement defending his behavior, saying that he was annoyed by what he called a \"disrespectful cheap shot\" from Scotto. The next day, Grimm contacted Scotto to offer an apology for his behavior, which Scotto deemed sincere. Grimm also issued a written apology, saying, \"I shouldn't have allowed my emotions to get the better of me and lose my cool.\" An unnamed former staffer for Grimm and NY1-TV political director Bob Hardt reported that Grimm had behaved in a similar manner to other reporters on previous occasions.\n\n\nIn early 2014, Grimm and  cosponsored the Homeowner Flood Insurance Affordability Act. In March 2014, the bill was passed by the U.S. Senate and signed into law by President Obama. The law repealed exponential increases in flood-insurance rates for homeowners in flood-prone areas, preventing \"skyrocketing\" flood insurance premiums for 5.5 million Americans.\n\n\nAccording to '''', in April 2014, Grimm became \"the first sitting House Republican to stop denying the science that humans cause climate change.\" Grimm stated, \"The majority of respected scientists say that it's conclusive, the evidence is clear. So I don't think the jury is out.\"\n\n\n*''''''\n**\n**\n**\n\n\n*\n*Friends of Switzerland Caucus (Co-chair)\n*House Republican Israel Caucus (Co-chair)\n*House Oceans Caucus (Co-chair)\n*\n*Sportsmen's Caucus\n\n\nIn August 2012, the office of the  said it was investigating Grimm's 2010 campaign. In November 2012, the  decided to inquire into the campaign but agreed to \"defer consideration\" of it at the Department of Justice's request.\n\nOn January 10, 2014, the FBI arrested Grimm's former girlfriend Diana Durand on charges that she had illegally donated more than $10,000 to Grimm's 2010 campaign. Durand allegedly gave the campaign $4,800, the legal limit, but then used s to donate more than $10,000 illegally. The FBI also charged Durand with lying to federal agents about the matter. Grimm denied any wrongdoing. In September 2014, Durand pled guilty to making illegal contributions to Grimm's 2010 campaign.\n\nThe investigation, which originally focused on Grimm's 2010 fundraising, branched out to include Grimm's prior business dealings. On April 25, 2014, Grimm's attorney was advised by the U.S. Attorney's office that his client would be indicted on criminal charges related to Healthalicious. On April 28, prosecutors unsealed a 20-count indictment charging that Grimm and others concealed over $1 million  of the restaurant's sales and wages from both the U.S. federal government and the State of New York. Grimm surrendered to the FBI that morning. Grimm pled not guilty to all charges and was released on $400,000 bond. He told reporters that he not only had every intention of fighting the charges, but also of staying in office and running for a third term.\n\nOn December 23, 2014, under two months after winning reelection, Grimm pled guilty to one charge of felony tax evasion. He admitted to under-reporting Healthalicious's revenues by over $900,000 over four years and to filing false tax returns based on that under-reported income. He also admitted to using the under-reported receipts to pay restaurant expenses, as well as to make under-the-table cash payments to employees. As part of the plea bargain, the other charges were dropped, but Grimm admitted to two of the offenses in the original indictment: knowingly employing people ineligible to work in the United States and lying in a 2013 deposition. The crimes to which he pled guilty carried a prison sentence of up to 30 months.\n\nAt first Grimm admitted making mistakes, but told a reporter he would \"absolutely not\" resign. But on December 29, 2014, it was reported that after discussing the matter with House Speaker , Grimm had changed his mind and would decline to take his seat for a third term. He resigned from Congress on January 5, 2015. A  to replace him was held on May 5, 2015, and Staten Island District Attorney , a Republican, was elected to the seat.\n\nOn July 17, 2015, U.S. District Judge  suggested that Grimm's moral compass \"needs some reorientation\" and sentenced him to eight months in prison. He surrendered on September 22, 2015, after a brief delay for medical treatment. He was released on May 20, 2016, after serving seven months.\n\n\nPrior to his indictment, Grimm lived on . He is divorced with no children.\n\n\n*\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n''|years=}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Gina Sillitti''' (born April 5, 1978) is an American  politician who represents  district 16, Assembly Member Directory  New York State Assembly |url=https://www.nyassembly.gov/mem/Gina-Sillitti/bio/ |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210328021055/https://www.nyassembly.gov/mem/Gina-Sillitti/bio/ |archive-date=March 28, 2021 |access-date=March 28, 2021 |website=www.nyassembly.gov}} which includes , , , , , , , , ,  and  of  on .\n\n\n\nSillitti grew up in  and . She earned a bachelor's degree in  from the  in 2000. She moved to  in 2012. She is married to Kevin Clemency.\n\nBefore running for office, she spent nearly two decades in , starting at the .\n\n\n\nSillitti began her political career working in the office of  Dave Mejias. She then worked in the Department of Community Services for the Town of North Hempstead, being appointed as deputy commissioner in 2010. She later worked as director of legislator affairs and deputy chief of staff for Town Supervisor Jon Kaiman.\n\nFrom 2015 to 2020, Sillitti was the human resources director for the Nassau County Board of Elections.\n\nSillitti was nominated at the Nassau County Democratic Committee Convention on February 11, 2020, after Assemblyman  announced he would be retiring.\n\nSillitti ran on a platform to increase state funding for local schools and roads, reducing property taxes, and protecting  and . She also advocated for  relief from the  and emphasized she would be accessible to her constituents.\n\nIn late February 2021, after the  became public, Sillitti was among a group of assemblywomen who issued a statement calling for an independent investigator to be appointed by Attorney General . She later pushed back against calls for his immediate resignation, being among 23 Democratic assemblywomen to say the attorney general's investigation should be completed first, in a split among New York Democrats.\n\n\n\n\n\n*  \n*  \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Taylor Darling''' (née '''Raynor''') is an American psychologist and politician serving in the  representing the  since 2019. A , she represents part of .\n\n\nDarling was born to Raulston and Towana Bertley. Her father was of , , and  descent and a convert to . She graduated from  with a  in  and  with a  in .\n\n\nDarling challenged incumbent Democratic Assemblymember  in . During a candidate forum, Hooper compared the race to a  and claimed Darling was a tool for   in the majority  district. An anonymous mailer called Darling a \"\" and urged voters to \"vote against fake Democrat and fake Christian Rayner [Darling]. Jesus sees your vote.\"  She ultimately defeated Hooper in the Democratic primary with 52% of the vote.\n\n\nDarling announced her campaign for the  of the  in  after incumbent Democrat  announced his intention to run for the .\n\n\nDarling is married to Reginald Rene and is a . She has three children: Lorde-Khai, Ford-Kate, and Monroe-Day.\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''J. Raymond McGovern''' (December 22, 1898 – March 14, 1974) was an American lawyer and politician. he served in the  for three two-year terms (1946 to 1950), and as New York State Comptroller from 1951 to 1954.\n\n\nHe was born on December 22, 1898, in . McGovern graduated from  and the .\n\n\nHe was a partner in the law firm of McGovern, Connelly & Davidson in New Rochelle.\n\nHe was a member of the  from 1945 to 1950. He served as  from 1951 to 1954, elected on the  ticket at the . In , he ran for  as the running mate of , but they were narrowly defeated by the Democratic–Liberal Party nominees.\n\n\nHe died on March 14, 1974, in .\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n|office1      = Chair of the \n|term_start1  = January 3, 2009\n|term_end1    = January 3, 2011\n|predecessor1 = \n|successor1   = \n|birth_name   = Edolphus Towns Jr.\n|birth_date   = \n|birth_place  = , U.S.\n|death_date   =\n|death_place  =\n|party        = \n|spouse       = Gwen Forbes\n|children     = 2, including \n|education    =  () ()\n|allegiance   = \n|branch       = \n|serviceyears = 1956–1958\n|module       = \n}}\n'''Edolphus''' \"'''Ed'''\" '''Towns Jr.''' (born July 21, 1934) is an American educator, military veteran, and politician who served in the  from 1983 to 2013. A  from , Towns was Chairman of the  from 2009 to 2011.\n\nDuring his 30 years in Congress, Towns represented districts based in : first , from 1983 to 1993, and then the  from 1993 to 2013.\n\n\nTowns was born in , the son of Versie (née Brown) and Edolphus Towns. He graduated from West Side High School, Chadbourn, North Carolina in 1952. He earned a bachelor's degree in sociology from  in 1956 and a master's degree in social work from  in 1973. Towns is a member of  fraternity.\n\nTowns was an administrator at , a professor at New York's  and , and a public school teacher teaching orientation and mobility to  students. In 1956, he joined the  as a private and received basic combat training at , Texas with the . He served until 1958. He was also an ordained  .\n\nIn 1970, he ran for  District 38, and was defeated in the Democratic primary by John Mullally, 75%–25%. In 1972, he ran in District 40 and was defeated in the Democratic primary by , who won the primary with a plurality of 37%.\n\n\n\n\nAfter redistricting, Towns ran for the open seat in the Brooklyn-based . Towns won the Democratic primary with a plurality of 48%, and won the general election with 84% of the vote. He never won a general election campaign with less than 85% of the vote. He has won the Democratic primary with at least 60% of the vote all but three times (1998, 2000, and 2006).\n\nFrom 1996 to 1998, Towns was in a rivalry with Brooklyn Democratic Party Chairman Clarence Norman. In addition, he has received criticism for endorsing Republican  for  in . He was challenged in the 1998 primaries by Barry D. Ford, a 35-year-old lawyer with the firm of  and also faced a challenge from political activist Ken Diamondstone. Towns won the primary with 55% of the vote. In 2000, Ford ran for a rematch against Towns and lost 57%–43%.\n\nIn 2006, Towns faced Democratic primary challenges from , a member of the , and , a former member of the . Barron was a staunch ally of . Green was convicted of stealing $3,000 in taxpayer dollars. Towns defeated Barron and Green 47%–37%–15%, the worst primary performance of his career. In 2012, Towns endorsed Barron in the race for his Congressional seat, but Barron was routed by a 72–28% margin and the seat went to .\n\n, a , writer, and former cast member on the   show '''', opted out of challenging Towns for the 2006 Democratic nomination, challenging him in 2008 instead. Powell criticized Towns for supporting  over  in the Democratic presidential primaries. Towns defeated Powell 69%–31%.\n\n\nTowns served on the  and is a member of the . On January 7, 2009, his proposed legislation to require information on Presidential donors kicked off the new session of the 111th Congress. Towns' past accomplishments include, co-sponsoring or enacting several pieces of federal legislation, including the Student Right To Know Act, which mandated the reporting of the rate of graduation among student athletes, creating the Telecommunications Development Fund, which provides capital for minority business initiatives, and the development of a federal program for poison control centers.\n\nHe had been targeted by various Democratic Party constituencies, including factions led by his political rival , and national and local labor unions, who resent his support for passage of the , which passed the House of Representatives by a razor-thin margin. In addition, he has been heavily criticized for taking money from telecom s and opposing . \n\nHe put particular emphasis on arguing in behalf of underserved Brooklyn communities, and has won recognition from several organizations for his efforts. The  has honored him for his efforts in fighting to secure federal funds for the restoration of Prospect Park. Towns fought to have  testing in the aftermath of the , including neighborhoods outside of the borough of . \n\n (center)]]\nTowns delayed the investigation into 's VIP loan program when he was the House oversight panel's chairman by refusing to issue a subpoena for  records. After '''' reported that public loan documents indicated Towns had received two mortgages from the VIP program, he issued the subpoena and his office denied wrongdoing.\n\nIn December 2010, he announced that he would not seek the position of  of the Oversight Committee in the next Congress, even though his seniority and service as Chair would typically result in him filling this post. Towns reportedly withdrew due to lack of support from , who reportedly feared Towns would not be a sufficiently aggressive leader in an anticipated struggle with incoming committee chair  (R-CA). Towns's successor is , who defeated  in a vote of the House Democratic Caucus.\n\nOn April 16, 2012, Towns announced he would be retiring at the end of his 15th term. His district had been renumbered as the 8th district in redistricting and had a significant increase of white voters, though it still had a large black majority.\n\n\n* ''''''\n** \n** \n** \n* ''''''\n**  (Ranking Member)\n\n\n* \n* \n* Congressional COPD Caucus\n* \n* Congressional Arts Caucus\n\n\nAfter leaving Congress, Towns became a senior advisor for the government relations and lobbying firm Gray Global Advisors.\n\n\nTowns is married to the former Gwendolyn Forbes and they reside in the  section of . They have two children,  (who had served in the  but vacated his seat to become commissioner and chief executive of New York State Homes and Community Renewal agency when appointed by Gov. ) and Deidra, who ran in special election to replace her brother, on a self-created ticket, Community First. \n\nHe is a distant cousin of  .\n\n\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* ''official U.S. House website''\n* ''official campaign website''\n\n* at\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n''|years=}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Ingrid P. Lewis-Martin''' (born February 28, 1961) is an American  and political advisor. She has served as chief advisor to   since 2022. Sometimes called \"The Lioness of City Hall\", Lewis-Martin is a longtime ally of Adams.\n\n\nLewis-Martin was born in  and raised in the  and  neighborhoods, her father immigrated from  and her mother was born in  but grew up in . She graduated from  and attended  before transferring to , studying . She is a member of .\n\nLewis-Martin previously worked as a public school teacher and as an instructor at . She got her start in politics volunteering for  , then served as his deputy campaign manager. She would go on to serve as chief of staff in the  for Adams.\n\n\n  (center-left) and   (center background) for the pilot of a weapons detector program on the  in 2024.]]\nLewis-Martin has served as chief advisor to Adams since 2022. In 2023, she was charged with a $1,000 fine for abusing her position to financially benefit an aide who owed her money.\n\n\nOn September 27, 2024, in the midst of the , federal investigators searched Lewis-Martin's home, then seized her phones and served her with a grand jury subpoena on arrival at . Lewis-Martin was returning from a vacation in  alongside  and . A search warrant published by the  stated that they were investigating five charges, including: , , offering a false instrument for filing, and .\n\n\nLewis-Martin is married to Glenn D. Martin, a police officer who trained with Eric Adams. A , Lewis-Martin is an ordained . She lives in the  neighborhood of . Lewis-Martin is a member of the .\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Jeff L. Gallahan''' (born June 4, 1959) is an American politician serving as a member of the  from the 131st district. Elected in November 2020, he assumed office on January 6, 2021.\n\n\nGallahan is a native of .\n\n\nHe began his career a union machinist for the General Railway Signal Company before becoming a sales employee and manager. He and his wife founded CR7 Food Trailer and Catering in 2017. Gallahan served as a member of the  Town Council and as town supervisor of Manchester for 15 years. Gallahan was elected to the  in November 2020 and assumed office on January 6, 2021.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''John J. Salka''' is an American politician and respiratory therapist from the state of . A , Salka has represented the 121st district of the , based in  and , since 2019.\n\n\nSalka has worked as a  for 30 years, currently serving as the director of cardiopulmonary services at Community Memorial Hospital in .\n\n\nSalka was elected as Brookfield Town Supervisor in 2007, a position he held until 2018.\n\nIn 2014, Salka ran for the 's 121st district, challenging long-serving incumbent  . Salka lost, 53-47%. He ran again against Magee in 2016, losing by a slightly narrower margin of 52-48%.\n\nSalka announced a third run for the Assembly in 2018, this time defeating Magee 51-49%. He took office on January 9, 2019.\n\n\nSalka lives in  with his wife Erin. They have two children; Emily (born 1993), and Aleksandr (born 1994). Emily died of brain cancer in 2015.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Amanda Septimo''' is an American politician from the state of . A , Septimo is the Assemblymember for the 84th district of the , based in the ; her term began in January 2021.\n\n\nSeptimo was born and raised in the , before attending  on a full  scholarship  in 2008. With one semester left at Vanderbilt, Septimo moved back to the Bronx to work for  . She plans to complete her degree in political science in December 2020.\n\n\nIn 2018, Septimo ran for the 's 84th district, challenging incumbent  from the left. Despite receiving high-profile endorsements from  and former  Speaker , Septimo lost in the  primary, 63-37%.\n\nSeptimo announced a second run against Arroyo in 2020. Before the Democratic primary could be held, however, Arroyo was removed from the ballot for petition fraud, leaving Septimo as the de facto Democratic nominee. Although Arroyo ran in the general election on the Proven Leader Party line, Septimo defeated her easily and began her term the following January.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Michael W. Reilly Jr.''' (born January 30, 1973) is a member of the , representing the 62nd district since 2019.  He is a . The district includes portions of the South shore of .  Reilly formerly served in the  and was an officer with the . He previously served as the president of the Community Education Council (CEC) for District 31, which includes all of Staten Island. He has a  in Legal Studies from . He resides in  with his wife and family.\n\nIn 2018 Assemblyman  opted to not seek re-election in order to run for a judgeship. Reilly, in a three way primary, easily defeated his two opponents to claim the Republican nomination. He won the general election with nearly 90% of the vote.\n\n'''School Safety:''' While president of the CEC, Reilly focused on the issue of school safety. As Assemblyman, he has continued his push to see front doors of academic buildings locked and for retired police officers to serve as supplemental school security.\n\n'''Secession:''' Discussion surrounding the Staten Island Secession received renewed attention in 2019. Reilly announced his support for the Divide NY plan, indicating his desire to see Staten Island become part of the upstate New York region - New Amsterdam.\n\nReilly received the endorsement  of the Staten Island Republican Party's Executive Committee for his 2020 re-election bid. In November 2020, he won re-election unopposed.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
