    "pages": }\n'''Zohran Kwame Mamdani''' (born October 18, 1991)  is a -born American politician. He is the assembly representative for the  of the , in . Mamdani was elected after defeating incumbent Democrat  in the 2020 primary. Mamdani is a declared candidate for the November 2025 election to become .\n\n\nMamdani is the son of award-winning Indian filmmaker  and academic , a longtime  professor, the director of the  (MISR), and Chancellor of Kampala International University. Born in , Mamdani moved to  when he was seven. He is a . Mamdani graduated from  in 2014.\n\n\nMamdani worked as a  and  before running for office.\n\nAfter leading student organizing campaigns, Mamdani became formally involved in politics when he volunteered for the unsuccessful campaign of  primary candidate , a Palestinian Lutheran Democratic Socialist minister running in  in 2017, then he was the campaign manager for 's race for  in 2018, and a field organizer for Democratic Socialist 's campaign for  in 2019, before running for Assembly himself.\n\nOn January 29, 2021, Mamdani hosted a video for the progressive left wing  discussing the .\n\n\nIn 2019, Mamdani announced his campaign for  in the , which encompasses  and  in . During the campaign, Mamdani was endorsed by the  and ran on  , , and  in New York. Mamdani's narrow victory over four-term incumbent  took almost a month to call.\n\n NYC Transit President Richard Davey and MTA Construction & Development President Jamie Torres-Springer]]\n\n\n\nOn October 23, 2024,  Mamdani announced that he would be entering the upcoming race for New York city mayor  following  and . Mamdani is running on  and building housing for working families, fast and  for riders, and  for all New Yorkers.\n\n\nMamdani started to consider himself a  following the .\n\n\n\n\nIn 2023, Mamdani co-introduced a bill that would enact a weight-based vehicle-registration fee to dissuade people from owning heavier vehicles.\nIn December 2022, Mamdani introduced a series of bills for the 2023 session called \"Fix the MTA\". Mamdani proposed free bus travel over the next four years across , , , and then  and . The Formula Three Act would fill the $2.5 billion dollar shortfall of the MTA with another plank freezing fares at $2.75. Another plank would have set aside further money for more frequency such as, six minute headways for trains and for the hundred most used bus-routes, then using any additional money towards increasing service by 20%. His advocacy helped spearhead the  MTA bus pilot program. However, in April 2024, the MTA budget didn't set aside further money for a continuation of the pilot program which Zohran decried it and accused the MTA of never supporting the pilot program saying \"the MTA was opposed to this program. And they were opposed to this program because they were saying that now is not the time to create any kind of confusion around fare collection”. The new budget did set aside money to improve frequency and reliability\n\n\nIn the same year, Mamdani introduced a bill to eliminate 's and 's tax exempt status and direct those funds towards underfunded public universities.\n\n\nEarly in 2023, Mamdani introduced a bill called the \"Not on our dime!: Ending New York Funding of Israeli Settler Violence Act\" which aimed to prohibit registered charities from donating to organizations that support Israeli settlers. In November 2023, Zohran joined  in a five day hunger strike outside of Washington DC in support of an immediate ceasefire and opposition to Biden's involvement in support of Israel's offensive in Gaza. He continued local activism in 2024, holding an  for a ceasefire in Gaza during Ramadan.\n\n\nZohran Mamdani has been a vocal supporter of Congestion pricing alongside  and was quick to condemn Governor  for pausing her plan for congestion pricing.\n\n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Joseph D. Morelle''' ( ; born April 29, 1957) is an American politician serving as the  for  since 2018. A , he was formerly a member of the  representing the 136th Assembly district, which includes eastern portions of the City of  and the  suburbs of  and . Speaker  appointed him as majority leader of the New York State Assembly in January 2013 and Morelle served as acting speaker in the Speaker's absence. He was elected to the  for  in November 2018 following the death of longtime Representative .\n\n\nMorelle was born in , to Gilbert and Juliette Morelle. Gil was a Korean War veteran, a heating and cooling technician and a lifelong Plumbers and Pipefitters Union member. Joe and his three siblings grew up Catholic, on Vayo Street in , where he attended . He received a  in  from  in 1986.\n\nIn his early years, Morelle was a sales manager for a  and laundry business. He got his political start working for State Senator John D. Perry as a constituent services representative in Rochester and legislative aide in Albany.\n\n\n\nMorelle, a , made his first foray into elective politics at age 24 when he ran for a seat in the Monroe County legislature. He failed to unseat the incumbent on the first try, but prevailed in the 1983 election. He was reelected once before running for the New York State legislature.\n\n\n, , and  president Daan Braveman]]\n\n]]\nMorelle was first elected to the State Assembly in 1990. He ran uncontested in the November 2008  and won the November 2010 general election with 61% of the vote.\n\nDuring his tenure in the state legislature, Morelle authored more than 200 laws, including major reforms to the  system, laws to require  detectors in one- and two-family homes, toughen regulations governing charitable organizations, protect the elderly and infirm who live in s or receive , and raise senior citizens'  exemption. He sponsored bills to exempt veterans from certain state licensing fees, protect their grave sites, and assist them with the civil service application process.\n\nIn January 2001, Morelle was appointed chair of the Assembly Standing Committee on Tourism, Arts, and Sports Development. He worked with area leaders to develop Rochester as a center for tourism and the arts in Western New York.\n\nIn addition to the Tourism Committee, Morelle's standing committee assignments included Economic Development, Job Creation, Commerce and Industry; Higher Education; Local Governments; and Libraries and Education Technology. At his request, the Speaker created the Subcommittee on Manufacturing in order to give New York's manufacturing sector a greater voice in state government.\n\nIn 2005, Morelle issued a report, \"Creating a State of Innovation: Unleashing The Power of New York's Entrepreneurial Economy\", detailing New York's economic decline, particularly upstate, and offering numerous policy recommendations to reverse this years-long trend.\n\nIn 2005, Morelle was elected chair of the Monroe County Democratic Committee, and held this position until 2014.\n\n\nIn 1990, an acting state Supreme Court justice ruled that Morelle fraudulently obtained several signatures on nominating petitions to qualify him for an  on the 1990 ballot (New York permits  in some circumstances) during his run for the State Assembly. Morelle remained on the ballot and won the election.  He later admitted that he allowed family members to sign the petitions for the individuals whose names appeared on them and did not personally witness the signatures, both of which are illegal. In 1991 he was charged with seven misdemeanor counts of violating state election law. Morelle denied intentionally violating the law, but accepted a plea bargain in which he was found guilty of two counts of disorderly conduct. He was sentenced to 32 hours of community service and a $25 fine. Because disorderly conduct is a violation of the law, rather than a misdemeanor or felony, Morelle's plea enabled him to avoid having a permanent criminal record as a result of the incident.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nAfter the death of Representative , Morelle announced his candidacy for ; he won the Democratic Party's nomination on June 26, 2018. On November 6, he ran in two elections: a special election for the last two months of Slaughter's 16th term, and a regular election for a full two-year term. He won both, defeating Republican nominee Jim Maxwell.\n\n\n\nMorelle ran for reelection to a second full term, winning the Democratic primary against challenger and  town councilwoman Robin Wilt. He defeated the Republican nominee, businessman George Mitris, in the general election.\n\n\nMorelle was sworn in on November 13, 2018.\n\n\n* (Ranking member)\n*\n\n\n*\n* \n* \n\n\nMorrelle voted with  's stated position 100% of the time in the , according to a '''' analysis.\n\n\nOn July 7, 2024, it was reported that Morelle had expressed interest in encouraging Biden to end his . This was during a call that   held with the committee leaders.\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nMorelle lives in Irondequoit with his wife, Mary Beth. They have three children.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n* official U.S. House website\n*\n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n|years=2015}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Michael E. McMahon''' (born September 12, 1957) is an American politician and attorney serving as the  for , which is coextensive with . A member of the , McMahon is a former  for , serving from 2009 until 2011, and a former member of the .\n\n\nMcMahon is a lifelong resident of Staten Island. He is of  and Irish descent. He grew up in the  neighborhood on the North Shore and attended parochial schools. He graduated from  in 1979, later obtaining a  degree from . He then worked for Democratic  members  and . He joined the staff of City Councilman , whom he succeeded in the Council. Prior to being elected to public office, McMahon worked as a partner at O'Leary, McMahon & Spero law firm in Staten Island. Since 1981 he is member of the  .\n\n\nMcMahon served as the Chair of the 's Sanitation & Solid Waste Management Committee focusing on minimizing the use of trucks to transport garbage and also more evenly distributing the load of waste processing across the five boroughs.\n\n\n\n\n*''''''\n**\n**\n**\n*''''''\n**\n**\n**\n\n\nIn November 2009, McMahon voted along with 38 other Democrats against the  and against the  in March 2010. \nHe was the only member of the  delegation to do so, and was only one of two , the other being , to vote against it.\n\n\n\n\nOn May 28, 2008, the Staten Island Democratic Committee endorsed McMahon to run for the Congressional seat in  being vacated by retiring 12-year incumbent  . On September 9, 2008 McMahon defeated opponent Steve Harrison in the Democratic Party primary with 75% of votes to Harrison's 25%.  Earlier, on June 11, 2008, McMahon had been endorsed by the city's 12 Democratic congressmen.\n\nThe 13th had long been considered to be the most conservative district of the 13 that divided New York City. It was based in Staten Island, which is the base of the city's Republican Party. Although Democrats have a 17-point edge in registration, its voters are somewhat conservative on social issues and matters regarding , which kept Republicans in the seat for over a quarter century. However, the Republicans had considerable difficulty finding a replacement for Fossella on the ballot, eventually settling on former state assemblyman . As a result, nearly all major pundits believed McMahon was almost certain to win the seat.  \n on February 4, 2009]]\nIn the November election, McMahon won in a landslide, taking 61 percent of the vote to Straniere's 33 percent.  With his victory, New York City's congressional delegation became entirely Democratic for the first time in 76 years. This occurred despite the fact that  narrowly carried Staten Island in the presidential election; a Democratic presidential candidate has carried Staten Island only four times since 1936.\n\n\n\nMcMahon was challenged by Republican and Conservative Party nominee , a former FBI Special Agent, and Libertarian nominee Tom Vendittelli. Grimm won the election, defeating McMahon. He was one of a number of freshman  who lost reelection in the  landslide of 2010. In all, Democrats lost 63 seats in the 2010 Republican landslide.\n\n\n\nMcMahon had publicly expressed a \"serious interest\" for retaking his old seat, now numbered as the , in the  to replace his successor .  Grimm, who defeated McMahon for reelection in 2010, announced his plans to resign in January after pleading guilty to a felony tax evasion charge on December 23, 2014.  McMahon, however, declined to run, deciding to enter the race for Staten Island (Richmond County) District Attorney, and the Democratic nomination went to man , who was from the Brooklyn portion of the district.\n\nIn November, McMahon defeated Republican candidate Joan Illuzzi for Staten Island District Attorney. In April 2024, following the resignation of former  District Attorney John Flynn, McMahon was sworn in as President of the District Attorneys Association of the State of New  York.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* ''official campaign site''\n* \n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n''|years=}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
          }

    "pages": }\n\n'''P. David Soares''' (born October 26, 1969, in ) is the  . He is a .\n\n\nSoares was the youngest of the six children of Lucas and Lidia Soares. He was raised in Pawtucket, Rhode Island. Soares and his wife Stacey live in , and have two young children.  . Accessed June 17, 2008. He has two children from a previous marriage.\n\n\nSoares worked his way through  as an intern for the  Authority, and later for the  's office. He also worked with the Albany Law School  law clinic for prisoners' legal services. Upon graduation, he was hired as an assistant district attorney by then-DA Sol Greenberg.\n\n\n\nOn November 2, 2004, Soares was elected as Albany County District Attorney.Michael Cooper, \"Democrats Gain Seats, but G.O.P. Retains Senate and Most Incumbents Win,\" ''The New York Times'', November 3, 2004, found at . Retrieved January 30, 2009. He defeated incumbent District Attorney  in a Democratic primary, and in the general election he defeated Clyne () and Roger J. Cusick ().\n\n'''September 2004 Democratic  for district attorney'''\n* David Soares, 14,909 votes, or 60.5%\n* , 9,741 votes, or 39.5%\n\n'''November 2004 election for district attorney'''\n* David Soares (D), 75,610 votes, or 54.6%\n* Roger J. Cusick (R), 57,202 votes, 41.3%\n*  (I), 5,677 votes, or 4.1%\n\nPrior to the Democratic primary election for DA of Albany County, New York, Paul Clyne had been considered a \"shoo-in\" incumbent by the local political establishment. This prediction, however, failed to materialize when Soares won by a landslide. Soares' campaign received third-party support from the progressive, union-backed Working Families Party, which viewed Soares' victory as a sign of its own influence and of a mandate for reform of New York's Rockefeller drug sentencing laws (which were opposed by Soares, but supported by Clyne). Michael Slackman of The New York Times stated that the Party had \"established itself as an emerging political force statewide by getting a little-known candidate elected district attorney in Albany County.\" Soares' victory was called one of the \"most stunning upsets in New York political history.\" '''' noted the unusual nature of that upset the day that almost all s won easy re-election.\n\n\nFormer DA Clyne, who lost to current DA Soares by a landslide in the 2004 Democratic primaries, initially contemplated opposing his successor for re-election; but eventually he decided not to run. For a moment it looked as though Soares might run unopposed since no candidate from either major parties, Democratic or Republican, had filed to run for the office of District Attorney of Albany County before the deadline to file expired. However, since there was still time left for independent candidates to file, Roger Cusick, a Republican, who had opposed DA Soares in 2004 and lost, declared himself as an independent candidate on August 18, one day before the deadline to file as an independent candidate would have expired. Cusick was able to get enough signatures to put himself in the ballot list. He once again opposed DA Soares in the November 2008 election.\n\nIn November 2008, Soares won re-election by a landslide, 73% to 27%, with a 50,000 vote margin.\n\n'''November 2008 election for district attorney'''\n* P. David Soares (D), 80,441 votes, or 73%\n* Roger J. Cusick (I), 29,128 votes, or 27%\n\nAfter a , including the counting of all s, the vote was 75,857 for Soares on the Democratic line, 6,548 on the Independence Party line, and 4,882 on the  line, for a total of 87,287. . Accessed December 2, 2008. Cusick received 31,996 votes, and there were 24 \"scattered\" and \"void\", or s. There were 29,526 blank votes.\n\n\nAttorney Lee Kindlon announced his plans to challenge Soares in a Democratic Party primary in 2012. Soares was endorsed for re-election by the ''Albany Times Union''.\n\nSoares won the primary on September 13, 2012, by an unofficial count of 14,498 to 10,1432.\n\n\nSoares was defeated in a Democratic primary by criminal defense attorney Lee Kindlon, who had unsuccessfully challenged him 12 years earlier, by a margin of 55-45%.  Soares is said to be mulling a write-in campaign.\n\n\nThere was speculation in early 2007 in the local and national media that Soares might run for re-election as District Attorney, or for higher office, in 2008.\n\nSoares was featured in '''', in which interview he discussed his goals and hopes for his career. On October 26, 2007, Soares was mentioned in the largest local daily newspaper as a possible replacement for   in the 2008 race for Congress in the 21st congressional district of New York. However, Soares opted to run for re-election in 2008 instead.Robert Gavin, \"Soares unfazed by critics: Amid Troopergate probe, DA says he's not worried about re-election, '''', April 1, 2008, found at . Accessed April 1, 2008.\n\n\nSoares has faced some criticism. His  position has been disputed by at least one defense lawyer, while some members of Albany police and others consider Soares as \"soft\" on drug crimes. He has been criticized for his prosecution of defendants from  for selling steroids to residents of Albany County.\n\nSome feel the criticism is politically motivated, and his supporters and independent pundits applaud Soares's progressive approach to criminal prosecution in Albany County. In an editorial, the Times Union noted, \"Mr. Soares has rightly concluded that it would serve no purpose to seek a perjury indictment of Mr. Spitzer because the former governor did not speak with the district attorney's office under oath.\" Soares claims to be \"unfazed by critics.\"\n\nIn 2011, Soares was criticized by members of both major parties for declining to prosecute participants in the Occupy Albany demonstrations who were arrested for violating a curfew in Albany's Academy Park. During an interview with Keith Olbermann, Soares called Occupy Albany a \"wonderful protest,\" and stated that \"we would decline to prosecute any of the cases, any of the arrests, based upon the fact that unless there were injuries to police officers or damages to property, then the people should be allowed to exercise their First Amendment right.\" Albany County Republican Party Chairman Don Clarey described Soares' decision not to prosecute as being \"politically motivated,\" while attorney Lee Kindlon, who lost a challenge to Soares in a Democratic primary in 2012, accused Soares of violating his oath of office. Soares beat Kindlon handily in a primary that year, illustrating that Kindlon's argument did not negatively influence voters in the least.  In addition, the Working Families Party circulated a petition supporting Soares' decision not to prosecute the Occupy protesters.\n\nSoares received criticism from one Albany County official for arguing back vacation pay to an assistant district attorney whom he had dismissed. Michael Conners, County Comptroller, noted his supposed , since Soares had received his past due pay when Clyne had fired him. Soares distinguished the two cases, because he fired the ADA for cause, while he had been fired for running against his boss.\n\n\nSoares has received several public service awards during his tenure as District Attorney, including being named a 2015 \"America's Top 10 Animal Defender\" by the Animal Legal Defense Fund, and the Whitney M. Young Community Partner of the Year Award in 2014 for hosting HIV/AIDS testing at the office's Community Justice and Outreach Center in Albany.\n\nAs of 2016, Soares serves as the 1st Vice President of the  (DAASNY)  and is a Board of Directors at the New York State Prosecutors Training Institute. Soares served as President of DAASNY from July 2018 through July 2019.\n\n\n\nSoares' office's first big case was the murder case of Peter Porco, an attorney, in 2005. ADA Michael McDermott and ADA David Rossi secured a guilty verdict for the murder against Porco's son,  after a change of venue moved the case to Orange County, NY. Christopher Porco was sentenced to 50 years to life in prison. In October 2011, the New York Court of Appeals upheld Porco's conviction. The case was profiled by several media outlets, including the Lifetime TV Network's rendition entitled \"Romeo Killer: The Chris Porco Story.\"\n\nOther notable cases handled by Soares' office include the double murder conviction of People vs. Edward Mero  and People vs. De Von Callicutt.\n\n\nIn October 2006, Soares opened an investigation into   on allegations of defrauding the government. On December 22, 2006, Hevesi accepted a plea bargain from Soares which called for Hevesi to plead guilty to one count of defrauding the government based on his personal use of state employees to care for his ailing wife, in lieu of a grand jury indictment.\n\nOn January 3, 2007, Soares said he would open investigations into wrongdoings in the New York state departments of Education, Health, Motor Vehicles, Labor and Insurance.\n\nSoares investigated the so-called  scandal in August and September 2007, and found that Governor  and his staff broke no laws. He re-opened his investigation amid much criticism.\n\n\nThe Free Press office under Soares has prosecuted several defendants for selling illegal s to  players, and representatives of the  met at least twice with Soares over this issue. Soares secured the conviction of a  who prescribed steroids to baseball players and other persons who the doctor had never examined.\n\n\nMedia reports in February 2024 revealed that Soares is under investigation for directing state grant monies received by his office to fund nearly $24,000 in bonuses for himself. Soares, who earns a salary of $208,000 per year, insisted his actions were legal but pledged in a video to return the money \"to change the conversation.\" New York State Assemblyman , a Democrat whose district includes Albany County, has called on Soares to resign. The controversy has threatened to derail Soares' reelection campaign. The Albany County Democratic Committee has yet to endorse Soares and is interviewing other candidates for the position, including Steck himself.\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

She served as the commissioner for the  from September 2013 until April 2019 and was appointed to the post by .\n\n\nFoster holds degrees from  and .\n\n\nElected in 2001, she replaced her father, Rev. , who was forced to retire from the city council due to term limits.     "pages": }\n\n'''Daniel Rosenthal''' (born June 4, 1991) is an American politician who was a  member of the , representing District 27 from 2017 to 2023. Rosenthal represents the central and eastern Queens neighborhoods of , , , and , and parts of , , , , and . On July 14, 2023, Rosenthal resigned to take a position at .\n\n\nRosenthal is a graduate of  in Queens, where he studied . Upon graduation, he began working as a Councilmanic Aide for   for 6 years, serving as Lancman's District Director. Some of his accomplishments included pushing the city's Department of Design and Construction to finally complete the long-awaited Kew Gardens Hills Library, representing the district's interests on the Flushing Meadows Corona Park Community Advisory Board, and helping to secure increased sanitation services in Briarwood and Kew Gardens Hills.\n\n\nWhen Assemblymember , who had served since 2011, died of cancer, a special election was called by   for November 7, 2017. Rosenthal won the election unopposed, and was seated soon after. When he was sworn into office, he was the youngest serving member in the Assembly.Kadinsky, Sergey.  , ''Queens Jewish Link'', January 17, 2018. Accessed January 26, 2018. \"The youngest member of the State Assembly took his oath of office before a packed auditorium at P.S. 201 in Pomonok, sharing the stage with his family, fiancée, and local political leaders... Rosenthal's path to the Assembly began in a similar manner. Raised in Manalapan, New Jersey, he settled in Queens to study at Touro College's Lander College for Men.\"\n\n'''Legislative and Budget Achievements'''\n\nIn his first term in office, Rosenthal tackled a number of legislative issues aimed at improving the quality of life for his constituents. He introduced several bills directly taken from resident suggestions, and focused his legislative priorities on the fight to improve worker rights, affordability and access to health care.\n\nIn June 2018, Assemblymember Rosenthal passed his first bill, directing the  to conduct a feasibility study of rehabilitating the  in the heart of Kew Gardens. After years of neglect, the LIRR agreed to rehabilitation after Rosenthal's bill was passed. Working alongside Senator  and the Kew Gardens Civic Association, the bill ensured that the structure of the bridge would be saved, while maintaining the architectural integrity of the neighborhood and securing the future of a dozen small businesses.\n\nIn June 2019, Assemblymember Rosenthal passed important legislation aimed at protecting New Yorkers from hazardous drug recalls. Until this bill, there were no requirements for pharmacies to notify patients of the adverse health consequences associated with Class 1 drug recalls. The law mandated pharmacies to notify patients within 3 days of recalls.\n\nAssemblymember Rosenthal was a co-sponsor of the Religious Protection Act, which was signed into law by Governor Cuomo in early 2019. Introduced by Assemblymember , this law prohibited employment discrimination based on religious attire, clothing, or facial hair.\n\nIn March 2019, Assemblymember Rosenthal announced $250,000 in funding to provide services and programming for Holocaust survivors. This is in line with the Assemblymember's mission to support those who have been vulnerable to anti-Semitic crimes in their lifetimes. Rosenthal has also secured millions in funding for local schools, libraries, social services agencies, and municipal services.\n\n'''Committee Membership'''\n\nAssemblymember Rosenthal is Chair of the Subcommittee on Intergenerational Care, and is a member of the Committee on Aging, the Committee on Insurance, the Committee on Labor, the Committee on Real Property Taxation, and the Committee on Social Services.\n\n\n\n\n\n* official site\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Richard N. Gottfried''' (born May 16, 1947) is an American attorney and politician who served as a member of the  representing portions of Manhattan. Gottfried had been a member of the Assembly for more than 50 years, making him the longest-serving member of the body and one of the longest-serving state legislators in the United States.\n\n\nGottfried was born in New York City. He is a graduate of , where he was a classmate of  and . Gottfried earned a Bachelor of Arts degree from  in 1968 and a  from  in 1973.\n\n\nRichard Gottfried represents District 75 in the , which includes , , , portions of  and the . Gottfried is a progressive Democrat who has been endorsed by the  and  parties.\n\nElected to the Assembly in 1970, while a matriculating student at , Gottfried served as chairman of the Assembly Committee on Health and was also a member of the Committees on Higher Education and Rules. He was also a member of the Assembly  and the head of the Manhattan Assembly Delegation.\n\nSome of his pieces of legislation-bills enacted into law that he has primary or secondary responsibility for include the creation of the Prenatal Care Assistance Program  as well as the Child Health Plus and Family Health Plus programs. He is also the author of the Physician Profiling Law, which allows patients to access information about their ; the Family Health Care Decisions Act, which prioritizes who would make health care decisions for a person who does not have a health care proxy and is incapacitated; and the  Law-which allows individuals to designate a secondary party to make critical health care decisions for them if they become incapacitated-as well as the HIV Testing and Confidentiality Law.\n\nGottfried was the sponsor of the 1998  Law, which established that park, as well as the legislation to expand the . He was also instrumental in the enaction of the Omnibus Crime Act of 1978 and drafting of the 1976 Juvenile Justice Reform Act.\n\nAs chair of the Health Committee, and as a supporter of reproductive freedom, he seeks to keep New York pro-choice, and sponsored  Reproductive Health and Privacy Protection Act.\n\nGottfried introduced the first same-sex marriage bill in the Assembly in 2003. When then-Governor  submitted it as a governor's program bill in 2007, Assembly Member , one of the Assembly's openly-gay members, became the lead sponsor. Marriage equality became law in New York State in June 2011.\n\nOther bills he sponsors are: GENDA, the Gender Non-Discrimination Act which would make discrimination based on gender identity illegal; and a bill to legalize the use of medical marijuana, NY State Assembly Bill A6357E, which is now commonly referred to as the Compassionate Care Act. \n\nAs a leading advocate for patient autonomy, he has a major responsibility for New York's managed care reforms, and continues to sponsor legislation for stronger protections for consumers and health care providers, work toward public support for universal access to quality, affordable health care, and establish end-of-life and pain management protocols. Gottfried's NY Health bill, to establish universal, publicly funded health coverage, was the first of its kind to pass a legislative body (NYS Assembly, 1992).\n\nDuring his time as a member of the Assembly Gottfried has served in various leadership capacities, including as Deputy Majority Leader, Assistant Majority Leader, Chairman of the Assembly Committee on Codes, and Children and Families, as well as Chairman of the Assembly Task Force on the Homeless, Campaign Finance Reform and Crime Victims. In his 2010 re-election bid he received 82% of the vote.\n\n\nOn December 13, 2021, Gottfried, then the longest serving member of the New York State Assembly, announced he would not seek re-election in 2022 thus ending his tenure in the Assembly after (what will be) a record 18,993 days in office.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
          }
        ]
      }
    }
  }

    "pages": }\n\n'''Richard Louis Brodsky''' (May 4, 1946 – April 8, 2020) was an American lawyer and politician from .\n\n\nBrodsky was born on May 4, 1946, in , . In 1955, the family moved to . He attended . He earned a Bachelor of Arts degree in Politics from  and  from .\n\n\nA , Brodsky was a member of the  from 1983 to 2010, sitting in the , , , , , , , , , , , ,  and s. He was first elected to public office in 1975, winning a seat in the .\n\nIn 2006, Brodsky announced his intentions of running for , a campaign that he suspended in order to donate a kidney to his 14-year-old daughter. He did not ultimately donate, but later introduced legislation that would make consent to  presumptive for New York state residents. After the resignation of  , Brodsky was a frontrunner to succeed the scandal-ridden Hevesi.  was selected instead by the Legislature to serve out the rest of Hevesi's term. Brodsky later ran to succeed Attorney General  in the 2010 elections, but lost to  in the primary.\n\nBrodsky wrote a weekly column for the  up until days before his death. He served on the Board of Advisors of the . In 2010, Brodsky became a Senior Fellow at the  at . Additionally, in April 2011, Brodsky joined non-partisan public policy organization  as . He wrote regularly for Demos' \"Policy Shop\" weblog and is a columnist for ''The Capitol''.\n\nBrodsky worked as a lawyer for the  for years, notably winning a \"landmark case stemming out of the 2004 Albany County district attorney contest that let the WFP spend money in Democratic primary races, paving the way for the WFP’s future involvement in campaigns like the one run by  in the 2018 gubernatorial campaign.\" On the day that  began to put New York on lockdown in response to the  crisis, Brodsky won \"a WFP challenge against rules created by the Public Financing Commission that threatened to destroy the state’s minor parties.\"\n\n\n\n\nBrodsky sponsored the Public Authorities Reform Act, which was signed into law in December 2009.\n\nAs Chair of the Assembly Committee on Corporations, Authorities and Commissions, Brodsky investigated New York's system of public authorities, including the , the , the  and the . Brodsky sponsored the Public Authorities Accountability Act of 2005.\n\n\nDuring his career, Brodsky, was concerned with the potential safety hazards of nuclear power plants located at . He released the Interim Report on the Evacuation Plans for the Indian Point Nuclear Generating Facility in February 2002, highlighting the perceived failures of  and state authorities to develop a feasible evacuation plan in a theoretical , terrorist attack, or other catastrophic emergency. Three months later he co-signed a petition to  requesting that it deny continued approval to the Indian Point Evacuation Plans. In January 2010, he filed suit against the  \"challenging its decision to allow Entergy Inc., which operates the nuclear facilities at Indian Point in , to violate fire safety standards.\"\n\nIn May 2011, Brodsky sent a letter to the NRC formally complaining of commissions' violations of the Freedom Of Information Act (FOIA) law with respect to his FOI request earlier that year. The request had sought a complete listing of all \"exemptions\" to health and safety rules, including fire safety, at nuclear power plants across America. The \"exemptions\" in question included issues of fire safety, control of safety systems that are required for safe shutdown in cases where core meltdown is possible, safe evacuation of civilian populations and safe storage of spent fuel.\n\n\nWhen Brodsky was Chairman of the Committee on Environmental Conservation (1993–2002), he authored the legislation responsible for creating the Environmental Protection Fund, devoted to environmental protection and preservation in . Brodsky is also partially responsible for having authored the Clean Air/Clean Water Bond Act, a $1.75 billion  approved by New York state voters in 1996. In 2007, Brodsky introduced legislation which subsequently passed to phase out the use of  on State property.\n\n\nBrodsky sponsored legislation permitting New Yorkers to vote on whether a Constitutional Convention should be held in New York State in 2010. He publicly recommended that those calling for a Convention must realize that they \"have an obligation to tell us what the Constitution would look like when they are finished with it.''\"''\n\nBrodsky was one of the few prominent political figures to support a \"yes\" vote on the , which was defeated.Mahoney, Bill (November 7, 2017). . ''Politico''. Retrieved November 9, 2017.\n\n\nBrodsky was involved in the creation of the  (STAR), which was enacted into law in 1996. He also co-sponsored legislation to eliminate the state tax on clothing.\n\n\nBrodsky worked to reform New York's telecommunications and energy systems. In 2007 he authored the Omnibus Telecommunications Reform Act that would create a  authority, expand , protect the traditional telephone system, create cable competition and protect . He led an effort to make the Internet safer, authoring several Internet security bills, including the anti- act of 2006, the computer breaking and entering act, a bill to notify consumers of the limitations of 911 emergency services using s and the country's first-of-its-kind act to combat modem hijacking.\n\nBrodsky co-authored a  paper in opposition to NJ Senate Bill 2664, or the \"Market Competition and Consumer Choice Act,\" entitled \"How To Raise The Phone Bill On The Average New Jersey Family.\"\n\n\nAs Chairman of the Committee on Corporations, Authorities and Commissions, Brodsky was involved in the 2009/2010 financial issues facing the . He held hearings to investigate the authority as well as seeking to retain funding for New York City student s. As Chairman of the Committee on Corporations, Authorities and Commissions, Brodsky sought greater oversight and funding for the authority.\n\n\nIn July 2007, Brodsky became a leading opponent of New York City Mayor 's  proposal. Brodsky issued a  about the proposal. According to the , Brodsky received more  than any other state legislator. The proposal, which would have substantially reduced New York City motor vehicle traffic congestion and provided funding to mass transit, failed.\n\n\nBrodsky died on April 8, 2020, in , of a heart attack, aged 73. He also suffered symptoms consistent with .\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* \n*\n* \n*\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Elaine Phillips''' (née '''Reidman''') is an American  who currently serves as  Comptroller, with a term beginning in January 2022. She was elected to the position in a landslide victory, defeating Democrat Ryan Cronin 61%-39% to succeed retiring incumbent Jack Schnirman. Phillips previously represented the 's , and had previously served as the 18th Mayor of . She is a . Phillips was elected to the Senate in 2016 but was defeated in her 2018 re-election bid.\n\n\nPhillips was born and raised in . She is the daughter of John Reidman, a steel worker who died when she was 12, and Betty Reidman, who worked as a cook at a local  post. Phillips attended , where she earned both her bachelor's degree in political science and an M.B.A. in Finance. A former financial analyst, Phillips worked for large financial institutions for over 20 years, including  and  Securities. She later served as a vice president in Institutional Sales at .\n\nPhillips and her husband, Andy, are the parents of three daughters.\n\n\nPhillips served as the mayor of Flower Hill, New York from 2012 to 2016. During her tenure as Mayor, she cut taxes and stabilized the village's finances (which, under her predecessor's management, were criticized by the New York State Comptroller's Office).  Phillips also implemented an environmental policy to expand the number of trees in the village, an effort which led the Village to be named  by the National Arbor Day Committee.\n\nPhillips was the first female in Flower Hill's history to hold the position.\n\n\nIn 2016, State Senator  decided to run for Congress, foregoing re-election to the Senate to do so. Phillips announced that she would seek the open Senate seat and was supported by Martins.\n\nPhillips ran on a platform which included cutting taxes, combating the heroin epidemic and strengthening state ethics laws in response to corruption scandals in Albany. Phillips was unopposed for the Republican nomination. With the Seventh district being one of the most competitive districts in the state, the race was projected to be close. In the end, Phillips defeated Democrat Adam M. Haber by a 51% to 49% margin.  She was sworn in on January 1, 2017.\n\nIn 2018, Phillips lost her re-election bid to Democrat .\n\n\nIn November 2021, Phillips was elected the first woman to serve as Nassau County Comptroller with 61 percent of the vote.\n\n\n\n* '''November 2016 , New York State Senate, 7th Senate District'''\n:\n\n* '''November 2021 , Nassau County, New York, Comptroller'''\n:\n\n\n\n\n\n* ''official site''\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''John T. McDonald III''' is the Assembly member for the 108th District of the . He is a . The district includes all of  and , and parts of  and .\n\n\nMcDonald was born and raised in  where he would later serve as Mayor from 1999 to 2012. In 1985, he graduated from the  and went on to open Marra's Pharmacy which is located in Cohoes, where he and his family still reside today.\n\nFormerly, McDonald served as the President of the New York Conference of Mayors.\n\n\nIn 2012, McDonald opted to run for a newly created seat in the . In the Democratic primary, he defeated Albany City Council President Carolyn McLaughlin 55% to 45% to take the nomination. He would easily win the general election with 76% of the vote. In 2014 he was easily re-elected with 73% of the vote.\n\nIn the Assembly, McDonald serves as the Chairman of the Governmental Operations Committee.\n\n\n\n\n\n* ''official site''\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Craig M. Johnson''' (born April 21, 1971) is an American politician and former  member of the  for the .\n\n\nJohnson earned a  degree ('''') from  in 1993. He earned his  degree ('''') from  in 1996. He was admitted to the New York bar in 1997. Johnson has practiced law at the law firm of Jaspan Schlesinger Hoffman LLP in .\n\n\nJohnson was first elected to the  in May 2000, succeeding his mother Barbara Johnson who died in March 2000.\n\nOn February 6, 2007, he became the first male Democrat elected to the State Senate from  in more than a century. He represented the 7th Senatorial District, which includes all of North Hempstead and parts of  and . He chaired the Senate Investigations and Government Operations Committee.\n\nIn the November 2, 2010 general election,  Mayor , Johnson's Republican challenger (who was also backed by the Independence and Conservative Parties), defeated Johnson by 451 votes. On December 20, 2010, New York's highest court rejected Johnson's final appeal in regard to the election results.\n\n\nJohnson lives in  with his wife Elizabeth and three children.\n\n\n* '''February 2007 , NYS Senate, 7th SD'''\n:\n\n* '''November 2008 , NYS Senate, 7th SD'''\n:\n\n* '''November 2010 , NYS Senate, 7th SD'''\n:\n\n\n* \n* ''\".\"''Skyhorse Publishing.     "pages": }\n'''Wendy Elizabeth Long''' (née '''Stone'''; born June 21, 1960) is an American attorney from . A member of the , Long was the Republican and  parties’ nominee for  in  in  and , losing in landslides to incumbent   and , respectively. She was a delegate to the  in support of  in 2016.\n\nLong, a former resident of New York City, has since moved back to her home in southwestern New Hampshire. \n\n\nWendy Elizabeth Stone was born on June 21, 1960, in , to Donald W. Stone and Norma Swahnberg Stone. The family shortly thereafter returned to their native . Stone’s father was a small business entrepreneur who pioneered using recycled paper to make greeting cards in his printing company and owned a construction business that built homes in Keene. Her mother, a former elementary school teacher, served as a Selectman in Ward 5 in Keene.  Her maternal grandfather, Gunnar Swahnberg, emigrated from Sweden as a child, got an entry-level job as an engineer and became the president of Kingsbury Machine Tool Corporation in Keene.\n\nLong, the oldest of four children, grew up in Keene and graduated from Symonds School, Keene Junior High School, and Keene High School.\n\nLong and all of her three younger siblings are graduates of  in . Long was the executive editor of '''' daily newspaper and was a contributor to '''' newspaper. In 1987, Long was a Publius Fellow at the . Long graduated from  in 1995, where she had served as an editor of the ''''. During her third year, Long studied at .\n\n\nAfter college, Long returned home to Keene to work with her father.  She then served as press secretary to New Hampshire U.S. Senator  from 1986 to 1987.  She then went on to serve as press secretary for U.S. Senator  from 1987 to 1990.  Both Senators retired after two terms, declining to seek a third.  Long supports term limits for members of Congress.  Before entering law school, Long worked for Americans United for Life, a law firm that authored legislative and litigation strategy for the anti-abortion movement.\n\nFrom 1995 to 1996, Long served as a law clerk for Judge  on the  in New York. From 1997 to 1998, she clerked for Justice  on the . She was an associate in the Washington, D.C. office of  between her clerkships and joined the New York office of Kirkland & Ellis when she married and moved to New York City, becoming a litigation partner there.\n\nIn 2005, Long helped to found the  (now known as the Judicial Crisis Network), where she served as chief counsel and promoted judicial restraint through media and public speaking. She participated in discussion and debate on U.S. Circuit Court and U.S. Supreme Court nominations and led both public support and opposition to various judicial nominees., She wrote and spoke in support of President ’s nomination of Chief Justice  and Justice , but withdrew support for the nomination of .  She also played a prominent role in opposing the Supreme Court nomination of Justice . In 2007, Long became a legal advisor to 's presidential campaign.\n\nFollowing the , in a private email group communication among former clerks to Justice Thomas, Long expressed support for the  that the election was “stolen” from Trump, stating that she and others \"believe in our hearts [that it] was likely a stolen election,\" and that \"President Trump would be determined to be the legitimate winner.\" The email was leaked by an unknown source and published in ''The Washington Post''.Wendy E. Long biography at The Judicial Confirmation Network  Long, ''JCN Statement on nomination of Sonia Sotomayor to the Supreme Court''\n\n\n\n\n\n\nIn 2012, Long challenged  Senator  in the November 6, 2012 general election for . On March 16, 2012, Long received 47% of the New York State Republican convention vote, with Nassau County Comptroller  receiving 27% and Congressman  receiving 25%; all three candidates attained access to the ballot for the Republican primary. Long prevailed by a sizable margin in the June 26 Republican primary, receiving \n50.9% of the vote; Turner received 35.6% of the vote and Maragos 13.5%. Long was designated as the nominee for the , having received 91% percent of the delegate vote at the Conservative Party's state convention; thus, Long appeared on both the Republican and Conservative lines in the November 6 general election.\n\nLong lost the general election for  to  by 46 percentage points.\n\nLong's supporter and college friend from Dartmouth, , pleaded guilty and was sentenced in 2014 for violating the federal campaign election law by making illegal contributions to Long's 2012 Senate campaign in the names of others.\n\n\n\n\nIn March 2016, Long announced a challenge to  for his seat in the U.S. Senate. She launched her campaign on March 3 and lost the election on November 8 by 43 percentage points.\n\nLong endorsed  in the , although she received no endorsement in return.  She cited mosques in  as the reason for increased crime.\n\n\nIn 1998, Long married Arthur S. Long, now a partner at the law firm , in Keene, New Hampshire.  Following their marriage, they lived in New York City, where they raised their two children. \n\nLong was baptized in the First Congregational Church in Keene, New Hampshire. She was raised a  and became an evangelical  while working in the U.S. Senate. While attending , she converted to  in Boston. Long has served as a catechism teacher in several Catholic parishes, private catechism groups, and a homeschool co-op. In early 2022, Long returned to New Hampshire and became a member of the Parish of the Holy Spirit of Southwestern New Hampshire.\n\n\n* \n* \n* \n* \n* \n* \n\n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n*\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Samuel Howard Sloan''' (born September 7, 1944), also known as '''Mohammad Ismail Sloan''', is an American  and former . In 1978, he won a case '''' before the , becoming the last non-lawyer to argue a case in front of the court before it prohibited the practice in 2013. He has unsuccessfully run or attempted to run for several political offices, including .\n\n\nSloan was born in , and graduated from high school in 1962. He studied at the , where he became president of the  branch before dropping out.\n\nSloan began studying chess at age 7. In 1959, he was the youngest competitor in the National Capital Open Chess Tournament in  The 's database reports that he has played in 152 chess tournaments since 1991 and that his highest USCF rating was 2107 in 1997.\n\n\nStarting in 1968, Sloan worked for two years in the  department at the  investment banking firm  In 1970, he established Samuel H. Sloan & Company, a registered broker-dealer primarily trading over-the-counter stocks and bonds. The  (SEC) brought civil actions against Sloan & Co. starting in 1971, alleging he had failed to maintain adequate books and records, and revoked his broker-dealer registration in 1975. After years of litigation, he prevailed in a case against the SEC at the U.S. Supreme Court in 1978, arguing his case ''''. He submitted a 175-page brief that ''The New Republic'' called a \"singularly absurd and complicated document\" with \"far too many obfuscations and legal shenanigans\". The Supreme Court ruled unanimously that the \"tacking\" of 10-day summary suspension orders for an indefinite period was an abuse of the SEC's authority and a deprivation of due process. Sloan is the last non-lawyer to argue before the court, which prohibited that practice in 2013.\n\nIn the 1980s, Sloan assumed control of , a digital and print-on-demand publishing company.\n\nSloan spent four years in the  writing a chess column and running a computer store. In July 2006, he was elected to a one-year term on the executive board of the  (USCF) after finishing in second place (the first-place finisher received a three-year term). In 2007, he ran for reelection to the board but was unsuccessful, finishing ninth out of 10 candidates. He subsequently sued two officers of the board.\n\n\nSloan ran for the Libertarian nomination for governor of  against attorney  and former madam . By his own admission, he was not popular in the party and did not expect to win. He lost the nomination to Redlich in a two-way battle, 27 votes to 17, after Davis refused to show up at the convention.\n\nIn January 2012, Sloan announced his candidacy for the Libertarian Party's .  won the nomination.\n\nIn November 2013, Sloan was on the ballot for the , as an independent on the War Veterans line; he received 166 votes (0.02%).\n\nIn June 2014, Sloan ran for the Democratic nomination for  against incumbent . Serrano won, 91% to 9%. Later that summer, he attempted to submit petitions for the , one for the Democratic primary (with Nenad Bach as his running mate) and another an \"ambush\" of the Libertarian Party line similar to the one he attempted in 2010 (with  as the running mate). Both petitions were ruled invalid.\n\nIn 2016, Sloan paid $1,000 to enter the Democratic presidential primary in New Hampshire but was not nominated. He was also a candidate in the 2016 Democratic primary for Congress in . He received 197 votes (0.46%), placing eighth out of nine candidates.  won.\n\nSloan unsuccessfully ran for president again in 2020 as a Democrat. He later ran in the Democratic primary for , one of several challengers to incumbent first-term Representative , but lost with 2.2% of the vote.\n\nSloan appeared on the New Hampshire primary ballot for the Republican nomination for the , receiving the fewest votes.\n\n\nSloan has married five women. In 1976, he converted to  and changed his name to Mohammad Ismail Sloan, though he continued to also use the name Sam Sloan. In 1986, he was accused of kidnapping his daughter by the couple who had adopted her. He was convicted of attempted kidnapping in 1992 and served 18 months in a Virginia prison.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* \n* \n* \n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
          }

A , Byrnes has represented the 133rd district of the , covering  and other areas to the south of , since 2019.\n\n\nByrnes worked as an attorney for 32 years. In that time, she served variously as a judge with the , as an assistant district attorney for , and most recently as court attorney to Livingston County Court Judge Dennis Cohen.\n\nAfter her retirement from the court system in 2017, Byrnes became a Caledonia Village Trustee.\n\n\nIn 2018, Byrnes announced that she would launch a primary challenge to Republican incumbent , who had been selected by Republican leadership for the 133rd district in 2016 following 's suicide. Byrnes easily defeated Errigo, with 61% of the vote to his 39%.\n\n, Byrnes defeated  Barbara Baer with 55% of the vote. She took office on January 9, 2019.\n\n\nByrnes has lived in  for 12 years.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Stephen M. Katz''' (born August 11, 1953) is an American , business owner and politician from , . He formerly served as a member of the , representing the 94th Assembly District, including parts of  and  counties. Described by the ''Putnam Examiner'' as \"bombastic\" and known \"for his fiery rhetoric,\" he announced his retirement from the state legislature in January 2016.\n\n\nKatz was born and grew up in , a  in ,  on the  of . In 1972, Katz was involved in an incident at the , which received wide media coverage after he rescued a man who was nearly strangled to death by a 23 foot long  which had escaped from its cage.Haley, T.J. \" .\" ''''. September 2, 2010.\n\nKatz earned a  in 1984 from the  and a Bachelor of Science Degree in Animal Science from  in 1976. During his studies, he served as a field researcher for the  in  and . Katz then was the assistant director of the  in , and also lived in  for two years where he learned to speak fluent Italian.\n\nSince 1989, Katz has been a veterinarian in private practice, while maintaining a residence in the   of , with his wife and three of their four daughters. A business owner, Katz is the owner and founder of the Bronx Veterinary Center, a million dollar veterinary hospital in the  in . In 1995, he and his wife opened the Concourse Animal Hospital on the , also in the Bronx. He is also an occasional  participant.\n\nAround 2009, Katz and his family became active members of a local , which sparked his political enthusiasm and made him decide to run for office.\n\n\nA political newcomer, Katz was elected assemblyman for the 99th Assembly District on November 2, 2010, as a candidate of the , and  parties, in an open race to replace Assemblyman  who was elected to the . The businessman and veterinarian self-funded his campaign at a cost of almost $200,000. He ran with strong backing from the . He defeated a Democratic challenger, as well as a challenger on the  line whom he had previously bested in the Republican primary in September 2010.\n\nKatz staked out  positions on cutting taxes and spending, a , and anti- issues, including calling for English to be made the official language of the state of New York. Yet he also attempted to establish  bona fides by backing a moratorium on the controversial proposed  in the  region of New York, a process also known as \"hydro-fracking.\"\n\nAs one of his first official acts as an assemblyman, Katz offered to provide free veterinary care for the s of the K-9 unit in his home town of , as the town was facing a budget crisis. In addition to Yorktown, the 99th Assembly District Katz represents in the  includes the towns of  and  in , the towns of , ,  and the village of  in , and the town of  and village of  in .\n\n\nAs a member of both the Assembly's Alcoholism and Drug Abuse Committee and Higher Education Committee, in 2012 Katz voted against a bill that would have legalized medical marijuana. A year later, and 11 weeks after being ticketed for the illegal possession of marijuana (see below), he reversed positions and voted in favor of another bill to legalize medical marijuana in New York state. Katz explained his earlier vote as the result of a \"divergence between the will of his district and his core beliefs.\"\n\nIn March 2013, Katz was stopped by a state trooper on the  for speeding and was charged with possession of . The following month, as part of a plea deal, the marijuana charge was dismissed in exchange for Katz's payment of $75 fine and performance of 20 hours of .\n\nIn 2015, Katz developed the company Therabis, using his political connections to secure funding for his private business venture. Therabis aims to heal animals using marijuana-based products. No animals have been reported to be harmed by use of Therabis.\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Penny Bacchiochi''' (born ) is an American  , who served as a  in .  She was first elected to the House in 2002 and was re-elected in 2004 and 2006. She unsuccessfully sought the office of  in the .\n\nAs representative of the 52nd House District, Bacchiochi served the rural northeastern towns of  and , both of which are located in .  She maintains her residence in Stafford Springs.\n\n\n\nRaised in Stafford, Bacchiochi graduated from  in 1979 and later received degrees from , where she  in , and the , where she majored in  and .  She also completed some -level work in  at .\n\nAside from being a state representative, Bacchiochi has worked in the  field for more than 25 years.  She owns a  and  company based in Stafford.\n\nBefore becoming a state legislator, Bacchiochi served on several town committees in Stafford, including the Planning and Zoning Committee.  She was also active with the s in Stafford and Somers, including serving as chair of the Somers RTC.\n\nA , who has since remarried, Bacchiochi was a single mother to two young sons. She is also the daughter of Allen Bacchiochi, former  of Stafford.\n\n\n\nBacchiochi was the House's , or leader of the Republican delegation, on the 's Planning and Development Committee.  She was also the ranking member of the Internship Committee, which she previously chaired, and oversaw the Connecticut Legislative Internship Program for the House Republican Office.  In addition, she was a member of the Public Safety and Security Committee and participated in  for the House Republicans.\n\nShe previously served on the Select Committee for Housing and the Commerce Committee.\n\n\nBacchiochi is a fiscal conservative and has offered a viable \"No Tax Increase Budget\" each year since 2007. Regarding other conservative stances, Bacchiochi is a member of the , and voted against the state contracting reform legislation put forth by .  She continues to support a no--increase state budget plans and has cosponsored legislation to make  the official language of Connecticut.\n\nBacchiochi is active with the  (ALEC), , , and the , and served as the Connecticut State Co-Chair of the  Presidential Committee.\n\n\n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n*  - official website\n*  - campaign website\n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Christopher Marte''' (born April 26, 1989) is an American politician who is a member of the  for the 1st district, elected in November 2021. He is a member of the Democratic Party.\n\nHis district includes all or parts of , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , and the .\n\n\nMarte was born and raised on the  of . He attended  and earned a Bachelor of Arts degree in international economics and politics from .\n\n\nAfter graduating from college, Marte worked in finance for . He then joined Arena, a -affiliated  that trains candidates and campaign staffers. He later co-founded Neighbors United Below Canal, a non-profit organization.\n\n\nMarte ran for City Council in 2017, losing narrowly to incumbent . He ran again in the , which were the first New York City elections to use ranked-choice voting. In the Democratic primary, Marte won 34.9% of the votes in the first round of voting and 60.5% of the votes in the final round. Marte won 72.1% of the vote in the general election.\n\nMarte's campaign was bolstered by community organizing against Chin's ties to real-estate developers, as well as by name recognition he had gained while attempting to primary Chin in the previous council election. Marte's campaign was also unique in redefining the common ties that the different parts of District 1 have, in the Lower East Side, TriBeCa, Chinatown, and SoHo.\n\nIn 2022, Marte filed a lawsuit to prevent the construction of four tower developments in  on the basis that the luxury housing construction was \"environmental racism\" and violated people's right \"to clean air and water, and a healthful environment.\"\n \n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Robert Jackson''' (born December 18, 1950) is an American  in New York City. A member of the , he is the Senator for the 's  on the  of . He previously served in the  from 2002 to 2013, representing the  in . He is the first  New York State Senator.\n\n\nRobert Jackson was born in Harlem, the son of Zelma Jackson and Chinese immigrant Eddie Chu. He grew up in Manhattan and , attending P.S.186 in , and P.S. 146, Junior High School 120, and Benjamin Franklin High School in . As a child, he sold newspapers. Jackson graduated from the  in 1975. After college, he worked for the  and the , a . In 1986, he was elected to New York City Community School Board 6.\n\n\nIn 1992, Jackson was serving as the elected president of Community School Board 6. He sued the state, frustrated and accusing the state of under-funding New York City public schools. Jackson sought assistance from the school board's attorney, ; they founded the , and in 1993 filed suit in CFE v. State of New York. The lawsuit argued that the State of 's method of allocating funds for  did not provide adequately for children in , and therefore violated the  and the federal .\n\nOn June 26, 2003, the  (the state's highest court) ruled in favor of plaintiffs, and gave the State until July 30, 2004, to implement changes. However, lawmakers could not agree on a formula. The Court of Appeals appointed a special panel to address the problem, and in 2005, the panel proposed that NY City schools receive an extra $5.6 billion per year. Justice  accepted that solution, and in 2007, the Legislature established the Foundation Aid Formula to distribute the requisite funds, phased in over a period of four years. Because of the subsequent fiscal crisis, funding was frozen during 2009–2012. Full funding has yet to be restored, a situation Jackson protested both in Albany and New York City.\n\n\nRobert Jackson was elected to the New York City Council's 7th district in 2001 as a . Before it was redistricted in 2013, the district included portions of the neighborhoods ,  and . He served parts of his three terms as Education Committee Chair and co-chair of the Black, Latino and Asian Caucus with Council Member . Jackson was twice re-elected before being term-limited in 2013.\n\nJackson is , and was the only Muslim City Council member during his tenure.\n\n\nJackson announced in late January 2013 that he was running in the Democratic Primary for Manhattan Borough President. Jackson highlighted the  as a significant accomplishment in at least five campaigns since he initially ran, and won a seat on, the New York City Council in 2001, and his literature stated Jackson \"brought home billions of additional dollars each year to improve our public schools,\" though the Campaign for Fiscal Equity was called a failure by the .\n\nJackson, who was the only male or black candidate in the race, received the endorsement of former mayor , New York City's first Black mayor, prior to announcing. His opponents in the Democratic Primary were former city council members  and , as well as small business owner and former Chair of Community Board 1, . Jackson lost the  to Brewer, coming in third place with 19% of the vote, compared to Brewer's 40% and Lappin's 25%.\n\n\n\nIn 2014, Jackson for ran for the New York State Senate in the  against the incumbent, . In the September 2014 Democratic primary election, he lost with roughly 43% of the vote to Espaillat's 50%, and Luis Tejada's 7%, in a race described by the  as \"his second shot at a campaign in less than a year.\" Jackson's campaign manager, Michael Oliva, said that there were no specific plans moving forward, and quoted Jackson as saying he's \"not going to deal with this bullshit for another two years.\"\n\n\nIn 2016, Espaillat ran for  to replace retiring long-term Congressman  of Harlem; Jackson ran for Espaillat's seat in State Senate District 31 once again. In a tight primary race, Jackson came in 3rd place with 30% of the vote, losing to District Leader , Espaillat's chosen successor, with 33% of the vote, and Bloomberg administration alumnus Micah Lasher with 31% of the vote, while again defeating Luis Tejada with 5% of the vote.\n\n\nIn 2018, Jackson ran for State Senate District 31 for the third time. In the , he won with 56% of the vote, defeating Alcantara, the incumbent, with 39% of the vote, Tirso Pina with 4% of the vote and Thomas Leon with 1% of the vote. Jackson's victory was attributed to backlash against Alcantara, who in the State Senate had joined the , a group of Democratic senators who allied themselves with the Senate Republican Conference that controlled the chamber. Jackson had the support of 2016 rival Micah Lasher.\n\nIn November 2018, Jackson easily won the general election in the heavily Democratic district with 89% of the vote, becoming the first Muslim state senator. In the Senate, Jackson is serving as Chairman of Committee on Cities.\n\n\n\nOn February 1, 2013, a Democratic mayoral forum was held in Washington Heights. Elected officials repeatedly neglected to acknowledge City Councilman Robert Jackson, who represented the area. Finally, when black mayoral candidate  greeted State Senator A. Espaillat, Assemblywoman G. Rosa, and Councilman Y. Rodriguez, Mr. Jackson called out, \"I'm not part of the Northern Manhattan team? ... Can you see? Hello? Am I black enough for you, brother?\" Thompson responded that he had no intention of ignoring Jackson, and referred to him as a \"hero\" for his fight for NY City schools.\n\n\nIn February 2013 Jackson, and his wife Faika Jackson, sued  and New York City. The Jacksons claimed Faika tripped over a downed stop sign in front of the Harlem location of the market in April 2010.\n\n\nJackson and Senator  received criticism in March 2022 after attending a rally organized by NY Renews, where they posed with a sign that compared  to the . The sign used imagery that depicted a plane flying into the , with \"climate change\" captioned over the plane. Jackson was captured helping hold the sign up, and reading aloud from it. Jackson apologized for the incident, stating \"the artwork depicted is wrong and I fully reject it.\"\n\n\nJackson has three daughters. He met his wife, Faika Jackson, while in college. He currently lives with his family in Washington Heights.\n\n\n\n\n\n* \"Black, Blind, & In Charge: A Story of Visionary Leadership and Overcoming Adversity.\"Skyhorse Publishing. New York, New York, 2020\n\n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
          }

    "pages": }\n'''Rory Lancman''' (born March 4, 1969) is an American politician and former member of the , representing the  from 2014 until 2020. He is a .\n\nThe district includes , , , , , , , , , , ,  and  in . Formerly, Lancman served as a  member, representing the 25th Assembly District in  from 2007 to 2013.\n\n\nLancman was born and raised in Queens and is a graduate of New York City Public School 164, Parsons Junior High School, and . He received a Bachelor of Arts degree from  () in 1991 and a  degree from  in 1995, to which he had transferred after a year at the .\n\n\nLancman served in the New York's  as a lieutenant of Infantry from 1988 to 1992.\n\nLancman served on Community Board 8  for over sixteen years, chairing first the Aging Committee and then the Youth & Education Committee. He ran unsuccessfully for the  in 2000, losing to .\n\nIn September 2007, he was named one of '''''s \"40 under 40\" for being a young influential member of New York City politics. He was first elected to the State Assembly in 2006, and ran uncontested in the 2008 and 2010 general elections.\n\nIn 2012, Lancman sought the Democratic nomination for . He faced  member  and fellow Assembly member , and eventually lost to Meng. A large campaign war chest gave Lancman's campaign cause to believe they would emerge the victor, but Meng went on to take it with over 50% of the vote.\n\n\nOn November 19, 2012, Lancman declared his run for the  of the  district, seeking to succeed  in the 2013 election. Lancman won a score of endorsements, including the Queens County Democratic Party, the , the , , the ,  32BJ, and 1199 SEIU.  Lancman defeated two other candidates in the primary and went on to win the general election in November 2013.\n\nCouncil Member Lancman became the chair of a newly created committee on the New York City Council called the Committee on Courts and Legal Services. Although both are liberal, Lancman has been critical of Mayor  at times.\n\nHe resigned from the City Council on November 4, 2020 for a position under  as his Special Counsel for Ratepayer Protection.\n\n\n\nIn 2019, Lancman was a candidate in the Democratic primary for  in the .  is the Democratic incumbent who succeeded Lancman as the Assemblymember for the 25th District.\n\n\n\n\n\n* ''\".\"'' New York, New York, 2020\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Steven Pankow''' (March 29, 1908 – July 25, 1993) was an American businessman and politician. A , he was most notable for his service as  from 1954 to 1957.\n\n\nPankow was born in Buffalo on March 29, 1908, the son of Ivan Pankow and Anastasia (Kurdupel) Pankow. His mother was from Freifeld, a town in  then in the Austrian portion of the , but now of , , . His parents were of  or  descent, and the family moved to Freifeld in 1909. Pankow was educated in the parochial schools there before returning to  with his brother John in 1925, so they could live with an aunt.\n\nPankow's father later returned to Buffalo, then went back to Freifeld in 1939 intending to bring the rest of the family to Buffalo.  commenced with 's  soon afterwards, and Pankow's parents, a sister and three brothers were never heard from again. Two sisters who were living in Poland and one who resided in Germany survived the war.\n\n\nAfter leaving high school early to join the workforce, Pankow worked at local  and  plants until 1930. He then moved into car sales and traveled to  to attended the  business school for auto salesmen. His success in the car business led Pankow to start Pankow Motors, a - dealership. Pankow was a longtime member and past president of the  of Western New York and the  Automobile Dealers Association. Pankow also belonged to the , the , and the local .\n\n\n\nPankow developed an interest in politics and considered running for a seat in the , but the local  organization refused to back him, so Pankow became a . In 1948, he was the Democratic nominee for Clerk of , and he achieved an upset win. In 1949, Pankow ran for mayor, but lost the Democratic primary to Judge John Hillery. Hillery lost the general election to Republican . In 1950, Pankow was a delegate to the state Democratic Convention. In 1951, Pankow was narrowly defeated for reelection as county clerk, but his strong showing in Buffalo indicated his viability as a mayoral candidate. He was a delegate to the .\n\n\nIn 1952, Pankow announced he would be a candidate for mayor in 1953. In the Democratic primary, Pankow defeated city council president Elmer Lux and city council member Peter J. Crotty for the nomination. In the general election Pankow's Republican opponent was Harold Becker, the city fire commissioner. On November 3, 1953, Pankow defeated Becker by a vote of 93,206 to 90,490 for Becker and 4,304 for  Richard Lipsitz.\n\nDuring Pankow's term, the  was extended to erect a wider bridge over the Union Ship Canal. In addition, the , the  extension and the  were constructed.\n\nThough elected with the strong support of Buffalo's Polish-Americans, as mayor Pankow move beyond the politics of ethnic bloc voting by appointing Joseph Decillis as the city's first Italian-American police commissioner. He also began to surmount gender barriers when he named Ann Mikoll as a judge of Buffalo's City Court.\n\nPankow's additional accomplishments included creation of the city's Port Authority, the creation of a Youth Board to consider projects and programs aimed at the city's children and teenagers, and revitalization of the Police Athletic League baseball program. Pankow was also credited with starting paid medical insurance for city workers and construction of seven police and fire stations.\n\n\nMayors of Buffalo were limited at the time to one four-year term. After the end of Pankow's term in 1957, he held a number of positions with the city government, including one with the Board of Assessors. He also owned various businesses including nightclubs and a liquor store.\n\nBetween 1959 and 1963, Pankow was indicted and tried several times for federal and state charges including bribery and tax evasion. Several proceedings resulted in mistrials, and the retrials ended with acquittals. He was never convicted of any of the charges.\n\nIn later life, Pankow maintained his interest in politics, and mounted quixotic campaigns for offices including mayor and Erie County Executive. He did not exert the same political influence he had previously, and these campaigns were unsuccessful.\n\n\nPanko retired in 1977 and continued to reside in Buffalo. He died in Buffalo on July 25, 1993. Pankow was buried at Mount Calvary Cemetery in .\n\n\nIn 1930, Panko married Mary Conwall (born Konowalczuk) (1912-2002). They were married until his death and had no children.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
          }
        ]
      }
    }

    "pages": }\n'''Herman Daniel “Denny” Farrell Jr.''' (February 4, 1932 – May 26, 2018) was an American politician from . He was a  member of the  representing the  neighborhoods of ,  and  from 1975 to 2017.\n\n\nFarrell was born February 4, 1932, in Manhattan. His parents, Herman Sr. and Amy Gladys, owned a dress shop. He graduated from  in . Before working in politics, he was an auto mechanic.\n\nHe worked for Mayor , then, in 1966, began work as a confidential aide to a state Supreme Court justice.\n\n\nIn 1970, he was elected a Democratic state committeeman.  First elected to the New York Assembly in 1974, Farrell was a longtime Chairman of the powerful Assembly Ways and Means Committee, as well as a member of the Assembly Rules Committee and the Black, Puerto Rican, Hispanic and Asian Legislative Caucus. He previously served as Chairman of the Assembly Committee on Banks from 1979 to 1994.\n\nFarrell played a pivotal role in the passage of several significant pieces of legislation, including the Omnibus Consumer Protection and Banking Legislation Act, which established a toll-free number at the New York State Banking Department that dispenses information about  rates, fees and grace periods, and a mandate for banks to furnish low-cost checking accounts to its customers. He also played an important role in the passage of the Neighborhood Preservation Companies Act, whereby New York State funds community organizations that \"provide tenant advocacy.\"\n\nHowever, Farrell is most widely known for having been a prominent member of the state (and to a lesser extent, national) . He was first elected as a Democratic State Committeeman in 1970, serving a two-year term. Subsequently, he was elected as the leader of the  Democratic Party (1981–2009) and Vice-Chair of the New York State Democratic Party, in which capacity he served for a decade. He was Chairman of the New York State Democratic Committee from 2001 to 2006. He also served as a member of the .  Farrell resigned from the State Assembly in September 2017.\n\n\nFarrell entered the Democratic primary against  in the . Although Farrell's entry into the race initially created some bad blood,  credited him for paving the way for Dinkins’ victory in .\n\nFarrell's late entry into the race was a surprise to the party and caused a split between party leaders in Manhattan and the outer boroughs and between black and Latino politicians. At the time, Bronx Borough President  believed he would win the endorsement of the Coalition for a Just New York, one of the city's black political organizations, to form a coalition that could unseat Koch.\n\nHe recovered from an attempt by Council President  to remove him from the ballot but still fared poorly taking 13% of the vote and finishing third behind Bellamy and Koch.\n\nFollowing the split, black leaders from around New York City met to settle past differences and focus on uniting for future elections. David Dinkins strength with black voters helped him defeat Koch in 1989 to become mayor.\n\n\nA pedestrian bridge constructed in  in late 2017 was named after Farrell as it was located within his Assembly district.\n\nFarrell died of heart failure on May 26, 2018, at the age of 86.\n\n\n*John C. Walker,''The Harlem Fox:  at Tammany 1920:1970'', New York: State University  New York Press, 1989.\n*, ''A Mayor's Life: Governing New York's Gorgeous Mosaic'', PublicAffairs Books, 2013\n*; Wynter, Leon (2007). ''And I Haven't Had a Bad Day Since: From the Streets of Harlem to the Halls of Congress''. New York: St. Martin's Press.\n* ''''.
