    "pages": }\n\n'''Amadeo Henry''' \"'''Meade'''\" '''Esposito''' (1907 – September 3, 1993) was an American politician who was a  Democratic leader and . Esposito served as chairman of the  from 1969 to 1984. As a leader, he was known as a political fixer, and honored loyalty, running a citywide patronage system involving gratuity exchanges that ultimately resulted in multiple municipal corruption scandals. \n\nFollowing the election of  to the mayoralty in 1977 (an outcome facilitated by Esposito's support, which was obscured by mutual agreement due to Koch's political origins in the postwar, Manhattan-based \"\" movement), Esposito emerged as New York City's paramount political leader and ''de facto'' shadow mayor, with a multiracial sphere of influence that encompassed such disparate figures as  political leaders ,  and Ramon S. Velez; Brooklyn Assemblymen  (who also served as  at the peak of Esposito's influence) and ;  Borough President ; Brooklyn Borough President ; Brooklyn Representatives ,  and ;  fixer ; real estate developers  and  (the latter would ultimately serve as the  from 2017 to 2021); and  leaders  and . Critics called him a \"medieval king holding court with his barons by sections of the press\". \n\nAlthough he ensconced himself in the tradition of urban \"Regular Democrat\" , Esposito personally identified as a political  in marked contrast to many of his successors, frequently speaking of his admiration for  (whom he supported at great political risk in the ) and . He also was a vociferous supporter of New York City's first (and ultimately unsuccessful)  bill. As the apex of his power coincided with historic population declines in New York stemming from decades-long , Esposito moved beyond his  base in southeastern Brooklyn to collaborate with leaders of nascent  and  communities throughout the borough, such as City Councilman  and his successor, . \n\nBy the early 1980s, several Brooklyn-based elected officials with national ambitionsmost notably Kings County District Attorney ,  Representative  and future  had either directly repudiated or distanced themselves from Esposito's influence, although  and  reported that Schumer met publicly with Esposito for lunch on at least one occasion.\n\nIn 1983, investigations into his activities mounted; this, along with a thwarted leadership challenge from erstwhile protege Genovesi (who Esposito believed had been \"openly salivating\" for his departure) would prompt his retirement in January 1984. Three years later, he was convicted of giving an illegal gratuity in the , having given Bronx Representative  a spa vacation in . As a result of this and related scandals (including Manes' suicide and Friedman's conviction on federal corruption charges) amid the political emergence of reform-minded rivals  and , the Esposito machine effectively collapsed. During this period, several fledgling African American politicians also withdrew their support, precipitating the 1990 election of  as county chairman of what had momentarily descended into a \"largely vestigial structure\".\n\nEsposito was respected and feared for his street-style management, intimidation tactics and criminal connections. He became known for running politics similar to a junket.\n\n\nAmadeo \"Meade\" Esposito was born in the subsection of  (alternatively characterized as part of  or ) in 1907. He was the son of Giuseppe and Felicia Esposito. His grandfather came to America from  in 1885. His father followed his grandfather in 1900 and arrived in America at the age of 18. Giuseppe became a saloon owner. Meade lived with his two sisters above the saloon and claimed to have started working as a child.\n\nEsposito grew up in Brownsville (then a predominately Jewish neighborhood with smaller Irish and Italian populations) and received his nickname \"Meade\" during elementary school. He briefly attended 's Manual Training High School, now known as the , but dropped out at the age of 14. He married at the age of 18 and became a father by 19. \n\nDespite his dearth of formal education, colleagues lauded Esposito as a keen  \"who read everything from comic books to .\"\n\n\nAfter dropping out of school, Esposito found employment at an  business (a field he would return to throughout his career) operated by Jim Powers, a former  and local Democratic leader. There, Esposito met , another Brooklyn Democratic leader who went on to secure the presidential nomination for  at the party's . Although Schorenstein was , his blunt, transactional management style would profoundly influence Esposito. At the age of 18, Esposito \"got a couple of dozen of the guys together\" and started the Progressive Democratic Club on Fulton Street.\n\nDuring the  and the early postwar era, he primarily worked as a  salesman and . He met many of his future connections through the latter business. Esposito cultivated ethnic and community ties that encouraged more Italian Americans to move into politics. He launched the political career of prominent Brownsville-based haberdasher  (who served as  from 1954 to 1961 and  of Brooklyn from 1962 to 1970) and assisted in electing longtime  member , best known for co-founding the . \n\nAmid  and white flight-driven demographic shifts in Ocean Hill-Brownsville and adjacent  throughout the 1950s and 1960s, Esposito's predominantly Italian and Jewish base gradually migrated to southeastern Brooklyn's semi-suburban belt of ,  and , culminating in the formation of the  39th Assembly District to represent these constituencies in 1972. As early as 1958, Esposito ran for Democratic district leader in Canarsie on a ticket with co‐leader candidate Shirley Weiner. Although they lost by 200 votes, Esposito was ultimately elected to the post in 1960 after being endorsed by Eleanor Roosevelt and . During this period, his influence continued to grow in tandem with the Canarsie-based  Democratic Club, which served as his primary political base for the remainder of his career.\n\nThroughout the 1960s, Esposito began to personally select many judges and politicians in Brooklyn. From 1960 to 1970, he also served as assistant vice president of the Kings Lafayette Bank (which was subsumed by the -led  in 1966) for an indeterminate period of time \"despite no apparent experience\" in the profession. Jack Newfield would later report that Esposito sought the position to distance himself from his bondsman career to better ensure his political ascension, while \"the single biggest depositor in the bank\" during his incumbency \"was the [Anthony Scotto-affiliated ], which many law enforcement agencies believe is Mafia-dominated [...] It is suspected that the ILA used its influence to get Esposito the job.\"\n\nAlthough Esposito attained his longtime goal of becoming chairman of the Kings County Democratic Committee in 1969 as part of a byzantine power-sharing agreement with \"sometimes friend and often business partner\"  (who sought to consolidate his control of the 's Democratic caucus in preparation for assuming the speakership), the Jefferson Club's influence was initially overshadowed by the enduring dominance of Steingut's -based  Democratic Club, a predominantly Jewish political clearinghouse for such figures as future New York City Mayor , veteran  , prominent jurist Nat Sobel and members of the . After Beame lost the mayoralty in 1977, the balance of power in municipal politics gradually shifted to Esposito, with accelerating white flight in East Flatbush and the concomitant death of Steingut organization  Beadie Markowitz (an Esposito ally for decades because of their mutual roots in the Schorenstein machine) in early 1978 all but assuring the then-Speaker's decisive defeat by -backed primary challenger Murray Weinstein (later succeeded by his daughter, ). \n\nSome observers have asserted that Esposito's authority was functionally attenuated throughout this period due to the failed campaigns of several Esposito-Steingut endorsees, including former   (who unsuccessfully sought the 1974 Democratic gubernatorial nomination in a voluble campaign managed by ) and longstanding Washington Senator , a seminal  who ran for the 1976 Democratic presidential nomination; both were primarily favored by Steingut, with the latter retaining support from the machine for most of the 1976 primary season (mainly due to his advocacy for  and opposition to ) despite late Madison Club attorney James Harrison Cohen's efforts to campaign for , the eventual nominee. As county leader, Esposito became the main interlocutor between the bellicose eastern Brooklyn constituencies and a less visible coterie of high-ranking s in western Brooklyn, including former  administrative director and longtime //South Brooklyn district leader , who was blocked from ascending to the chairmanship of the County Committee by Esposito in 1969; fellow district leader Anthony Caracciolo, whose expansive territory included all or part of such transitional neighborhoods as , ,  and ; and Windsor Terrace-based  Majority Leader . The unanticipated election of alleged Mangano-Caracciolo proxy Bernard M. Bloom (then leader of the eastern Flatbush-based  Democratic Club) as  (a role charged with overseeing lucrative  and estate proceedings) in 1976 may have deprived the Esposito-Steingut machine of a key patronage tranche as retribution for the 1969 \"coup\", although Cohen asserted in his 2019 memoir that Esposito personally \"tapped\" Bloom to serve in the role after \"quietly [supporting]\" Hugh Carey, the Mangano-Caracciolo-Bloom faction's successful 1974 gubernatorial candidate.\n\nIn the summer of 1979, Esposito was tried for allegedly violating a state law barring New York county political leaders from engaging in business dealings with race tracks. Citing the rules of the Kings County Democratic Committee, New York Supreme Court Justice Alvin Klein ruled that Esposito had not violated the law since he was formally identified as chairman of the Committee's executive subcommittee. According to Ken Auletta, Esposito had previously characterized himself as county leader in a 1976 interview with ''''.\n\nBy the 1970s, Esposito's legitimate employment had primarily shifted to the proprietorship of at least two lower Manhattan-based s; these included the Grand Brokerage (also known as the Grand Insurance Agency)a partnership between Esposito, Steingut and prominent  reform Democratic leader Lester Zirinand Serres, Visone, & Rice, a similar venture between Esposito and former Brooklyn Heights/Fort Greene/South Brooklyn Assemblyman Joseph Martuscello that functioned as Esposito's main business for the remainder of his life. Esposito and Martuscello also co-owned several properties, including a  brownstone, a villa in a  resort and a 50-foot yacht. Esposito's involvement in the former concern appears to have faded following a 1974-75 investigation of money laundering and organized crime involvement in the city's nursing home industry; it was ultimately dissolved amid Steingut's pursuit of a Manhattan legal career in 1982. In press interviews, Esposito noted that he was \"not a broker\" at either firm, claiming that he instead served as a \"stockholder\" and \"more of an administrator.\" During the 1980s, he also owned a stake in Beaumont Offset Printing, a printing firm ran by his daughter that was contracted by various New York political campaigns.\n\nEsposito elicited a variety of perceptions from his peers. While  called him a \"new breed of party leader\", , a critic of Esposito, called him \"an old-line boss\". During his tenure as county leader, his connections to known Mafia members and associates had become common knowledge. He grew up alongside many of these figures, who continued to retain him during his years as a bail bondsman. In 1972, during a federal investigation into the , Esposito's name was frequently mentioned in a bugged junkyard trailer used as an office by Paul Vario.\n\nPoliticians traded favors and gifts with Esposito for political influence and positions, a process that greatly accelerated after he became New York City's preeminent political boss in 1978. By 1983, investigations into his increasingly conspicuous activities were growing. Despite claiming he would never retire, Esposito left his position as leader of the Kings County Democratic Committee in January 1984, unexpectedly leaving the position to incumbent Brooklyn Borough President Howard Golden amid internal conflict with former protege \"Fat Tony\" Genovesi.\n\nNevertheless, Esposito continued to retain significant surreptitious influence in New York City politics after his retirement. In the fall of 1985, during an  investigation into the , Esposito was heard speaking with lifelong friend , a  in the organization. This led to a direct wiretap of Esposito's phone. \n\nLater in 1985, Esposito was recorded speaking with Mario Biaggi, claiming to have \"\" 42 judges in Brooklyn. Biaggi was charged in 1987 with taking an unlawful gratuity, having accepted a free $3,200 vacation in Florida from Esposito. Prosecutors said it was in exchange for using his influence to help a ship-repair company that was a major client of Serres, Visone, & Rice. The defense said it was given out of friendship, and no favors were done in return. While Biaggi was acquitted of both bribery and conspiracy, he was convicted of accepting an illegal gratuity and , sentenced to two-and-a-half years in prison, and fined $500,000. Esposito received a suspended sentence. Esposito was put on probation, sentenced to community service and fined $500,000.\n\nIn 1989, Esposito faced additional charges of bribery and tax fraud; however a federal judge determined Esposito was too sick and elderly to maintain a proper defense.\n\n\nEsposito was known for his \"blunt, warm and earthy\" nature. He frequently smoked cigars and kept a baseball bat under his desk to symbolically enforce power. Donald Trump, whose family's real estate business frequently interlocked with elements of the Brooklyn Democratic machine, respected Esposito and his management style. Esposito had a daughter, Phyllis. \n\nAt the height of his power, Esposito primarily resided at 2600 National Drive, a waterfront property in Mill Basin. He also maintained a residence in . In 1987, he moved his principal residence to .\n\nWhile serving as county leader, Esposito eschewed written memoranda and held important meetings in the basement of his mother's Canarsie house to evade potential  at his  office and Mill Basin home. The elder Esposito usually prepared homemade  for her guests.\n\n\nIn the early 1990s, Esposito developed  and . He died of a blood infection at  in Manhasset on September 3, 1993.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
          }
        ]
      }
    }

Meeks is the second  to represent  in the Assembly; , his predecessor, was the first.\n\n\nAfter graduating from  and , Meeks began working as a labor organizer. He serves as an administrative organizer for , and is an active member of the . He has received additional labor-related trainings and certifications from .\n\n\nIn 2020, Assemblyman  announced that he would not seek reelection to the 137th district. Meeks announced his campaign for the seat, and won the  primary against county legislator Ernest Flagler and two other candidates. He faced no opposition in the . As Gantt had died over the summer, leaving the seat vacant, Meeks was sworn in early on November 12, 2020.\n\n\nMeeks lives in  with his wife, Cratrina, and their children.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Frank Albert Sedita''' (June 20, 1907 – May 2, 1975) was an American attorney and politician who served as the 56th and 58th  of .\n\n\nHe was born in  on June 20, 1907. His family relocated to  in 1911. When he was 10, Sedita began selling newspapers and shining shoes around the  area. He attended  and spent his summers working in canning factories and on farms in  and .\n\nSedita received a Bachelor of Arts from . In 1931, he received his  degree from the .\n\n\nIn 1950, Sedita was elected as a City Court . He resigned from his job on the City Court bench on September 6, 1957 to pursue his mayoral bid. On November 5, 1957, he was elected mayor, defeating incumbent . During this term,  was continued and the Ellicott District Project was completed. He lost his bid for re-election to mayor in the November 7, 1961 election, when  was elected mayor. In 1962, President  nominated Sedita to the post of Federal Customs ; he held that post until May 7, 1965. He was elected as mayor to a second term on November 2, 1965.\n\nAt the 1966 Democratic State Convention, held in , he was nominated to run for . He was defeated in the  by . In June 1967, during the  at the Michigan Avenue YMCA, the mayor faced an angry crowd of young African Americans during an East Side street confrontation. He was re-elected on November 4, 1969. He ran for  executive in 1971, but was defeated by  in the general election. Because of health concerns, on February 8, 1973 Sedita submitted a letter of resignation to the Buffalo Common Council, to become effective on March 5, 1973. \n\n\nHe married Sarah Vacanti on July 11, 1934.\n\nHe died on May 2, 1975, aged 67, and was buried in . On December 14, 1987, Buffalo Public School 30 was renamed Frank A. Sedita Community School.\n\nSedita's son, Frank A. Sedita, Jr., was a judge on the  Court. His grandson, Frank A. Sedita III, was twice elected District Attorney of Erie County and is now a judge on the .\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Carl L. Marcellino''' (born December 23, 1942) is an American politician who served as a member of the  from 1995 to 2018. He was first elected in a March 1995 special election following the resignation of former state senate majority leader ; he was defeated by  in 2018. Marcellino represented , which comprises parts of  and  counties on . Marcellino is a member of the .\n\n\nMarcellino attended public schools in . He received a  and  degree from . Marcellino worked as a science teacher and administrator in the  school system for 20 years. Prior to serving in the State Senate, he was Town Clerk of . Marcellino and his wife Patricia reside in  and have two children, Jean and Carl.\n\n\nIn November 1994, , who had represented the area around the Nassau-Suffolk line since 1969, was deposed from his post as Senate Majority Leader. After Marino resigned from office, a special election was called for on March 13, 1995. Marcellino was nominated by Republicans to face Mary A. McCaffery, a Democrat who worked as a fund-raiser for nonprofit agencies. He would go on to easily win that race with 60% of the vote. Marcellino would go on to win re-election eleven times, only facing serious opposition in 2016; that year, Marcellino defeated challenger  by only 1,761 votes. In 2018, Gaughran challenged Marcellino again. This time, Gaughran prevailed.\n\nIn 2011, Marcellino voted against allowing same-sex marriage in New York during a senate roll-call vote on the , which the Senate narrowly passed 33&ndash;29. He also voted in favor of the 2013 gun control law known as the NY SAFE Act.\n\n\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Carlina Rivera''' (born January 3, 1984) is an American politician who represents the  of the  since 2018. A member of the , her district includes portions of the , , , , , and  in .\n\nAfter serving as the legislative director for , Rivera launched her campaign for City Council in 2016 as a . By 2017, she was no longer a socialist, and has served as city council representative since. Rivera was a candidate in the Democratic primary for  in , but lost, coming in fourth place, behind , State Assemblywoman , and Congressman .\n\n\nRivera grew up on the , where she was raised in  housing by a single mother who moved from  to the mainland. She graduated from  in Manhattan and  in , where she majored in journalism.\n\n\nRivera worked as director of programs and services at , a local  focused on neighborhood housing and preservation, , and community revitalization. She was also a member of  and later served as the legislative director for .\n\n\n\nRivera launched her campaign for  in 2016, running for the , which encompasses the , , , , ,  and the . A first-time candidate who participated in public financing, she raised $176,000 through the City’s  program. Rivera was endorsed by the , then  , then  , Rep. , and the City Council’s Progressive Caucus.\n\nRivera and her husband, Jamie Rogers, lived in a federally subsidized, low-income  apartment with an annual income limit of $61,050 for a family of two. Rogers, a former corporate lawyer at , owns a growing coffee business, a  co-op apartment in , which he rents out, and a small family trust fund. Pictures of Rogers on a yacht owned by his father William P. Rogers Jr., a retired partner at , were deleted before the Democratic primary. Their eligibility was questioned as Rivera’s salary as a City Council staffer was $41,770, which means her husband would have had to earn less than $20,000 a year in order for the family to be under the limit. Rogers explained his financial situation in an interview with '''' and defended their eligibility due to his struggling coffee business and substantial debt.\n\nRivera won the Democratic  for  in 2017 with 60.54% of the vote (8,354 votes). She went on to win the  with 82.86% of the vote against  and   and several third-party candidates.\n\n\nIn 2019, as a co-chair of the Women’s Caucus, Rivera was involved in securing $250,000 for the  to provide abortions for women not covered by insurance or , including for those who travel from out-of-state. This funding made New York City the first to allocate money directly to abortion procedures. She has called for more aid to reach the city’s public hospital system, including funding and programs around reproductive healthcare. She also introduced a legislation to create a patient advocate’s office within the  to help New Yorkers navigate the healthcare system.\n\nIn the same year, Rivera introduced legislations to create an  and  to assess conditions for safe biking and walking in the city and make recommendations for improvements. She introduced and passed a legislation to strengthen protections for renters during periods of maintenance, renovation, and construction. She introduced a legislation to require child protective specialists to explain to parents or caretakers about their rights during initial contact of an  investigation. and passed bills to outlaw the sale of  and outlaw pigeon trafficking. In an effort to crack down on illegal hotel operators, she introduced a bill in June 2018 to require  companies such as  to report host data to the city. The bill passed the Council 45–0 and was signed into law by Mayor  on August 6, 2018.\n\nShe was listed on ''''’s 2020’s Above and Beyond for her work on strengthening abortions rights and combating sexual harassment.\n\nIn June 2022, Rivera voted for a controversial $101 billion budget that will cut funding for the  by $600 million, citing \"fundamental flaws\" in the  formula.\n\nRivera is Chair of the Council’s Committee on Hospitals and member of the Council's Women's Caucus, Progressive, and Black, Latino, and Asian Caucuses.\n\n\nRivera announced her candidacy for the  in early June 2022 to represent the newly-redistricted . She was the only candidate that currently lives outside the districtNY 10 Debate, / , August 10, 2022 but has said that she will move into it if elected. She was endorsed by Rep. , Rep. , Brooklyn  ,  , several , and unions such as  and .\n\nRivers has been a supporter of allowing more density and  in the Manhattan neighborhoods of  and . She supported a  project to build low-income senior housing in a wealthy neighborhood’s community garden, a project that other New York politicians opposed. \n\nShe has been a strong proponent of efforts to rebuild  at higher elevation to make the neighorhood less vulnerable to storms. Rivera is the only top candidate in the Democratic primary to not support allocating 100 percent of residential units in the proposed  in  as affordable housing. She has raised a large amount of money from major real estate developers and lobbyists, including  real estate developer  of Two Trees, Kirk Goodrich, Don Capoccia, Robert Levine of RAL Companies, Bruce Teitelbaum, and Daniel R. Tishman of , the firm that managed the building of . '''' reported she has reached out to at least two other executives in the real estate industry for donations as of August 2022, according to recipients of her outreach.\n\nRivera drew criticisms of treating  New Yorkers as \"political chess pieces\" when she expressed support for s that target members of the community in response to a question about her stance on the well-known  during an interview with ''''. Rivera said she has put religious exemptions in legislation in the past and is \"willing to explore that and do it on the federal level.\" She walked back her statement and clarified that she opposes giving private businesses a pass on discriminating against LGBTQ+ people.\n\nRivera was met with backlash for seemingly inviting PAC money by adding a \"red box\" to her website. She was also called out by then-rival congressional candidate  for her investments in defense contractors  and , as well as the gun company .\n\nRivera finished in fourth place in the crowded  with 10,985 votes (17%), losing to .\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n| party = Democratic Party (United States)\n| votes = 11,777\n| percentage = 18.2\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nShe and her husband, Jamie Rogers, a  and  graduate, lived on the Lower East Side until June 2021 when they moved to  for reasons they would not disclose publicly. On 's '''', on January 11, 2022, she claimed that \"the Lower East Side is my home.\"\n\nRivera and her husband are parents to a male baby as of February 2023.\n\nRivera was a member of the  as of 2017 but is no longer.\n\n\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* Councilwoman Carlina Rivera (official site)\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Michael Venditto''' (born June 30, 1981 in ) is a former , previously representing , which comprises the South Shore of Long Island beginning with Baldwin in the West and ending with West Babylon in the East. A Republican, he was first elected in 2014, he served as Chairman of the Consumer Protection Committee, and on the Codes, Higher Education, Insurance, Judiciary, Labor, Libraries, and Crime Victims, Crime and Correction committees and on the Heroin Task Force.\n\nBefore his election to the state senate, Venditto served as a  Legislator from the 12th District, replacing the deceased Presiding Officer . Venditto began his career working as an attorney for the .\n\n\n\nVenditto has spent his entire life in the South Shore communities that make up the 8th Senate District. He attended public schools and graduated from Farmingdale High School. He earned his B.A. from Hofstra University and his J.D. from . He resides in the hamlet of  with his wife Antonella and their son Andrew. His father, John Venditto, served as  Town Supervisor from 1998-2017.\n\n\nVenditto ran for the New York State Senate in 2014 to succeed former Senator , who resigned to become the head of the Alzheimer's Foundation. Michael, on the Republican, Conservative, and Independence lines, won with 56.7% of the vote.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Carl Kruger''' (born December 3, 1949) is an American convicted felon and politician from . A Democrat from Brooklyn, he represented District 27 in the . Kruger was first elected to the State Senate in 1994 and later became Chair of the Senate Social Service Committee and the Senate Finance Committee. In December 2011, he resigned from the State Senate and pleaded guilty to federal corruption charges. In 2012, Kruger was sentenced to seven years in prison.\n\n\nFirst elected to the New York State Senate in a 1994 special election, Kruger represented Senate District 27 in Brooklyn. In February 2007, then-Senate Majority Leader a Republicanappointed Kruger Chair of the Senate Social Services Committee, making him the first minority party senator to chair a committee in New York history. Kruger later chaired the powerful Senate Finance Committee.\n\nIn February 2007, Kruger presented legislation attempting to ban the use of electronic devices, such as  and , in  crosswalks.\".\" ''WashingtonPost.com.'' February 7, 2007. Retrieved on February 8, 2007.\n\nKruger, along with Sens. Rubén Díaz Sr. (Bronx), Pedro Espada, Jr. (Bronx), and Hiram Monserrate (Queens), threatened to abandon the Democratic majority that was elected to the New York State Senate on November 4, 2008. The self-named \"Gang of Four\" refused to back  of Queens as the chamber's majority leader and sought concessions. Monserrate soon rejoined the caucus after reaching an agreement with Smith that reportedly included the chairmanship of the Consumer Affairs Committee. The remaining \"\" reached an initial compromise in early December that collapsed within a week, but was ultimately resolved with Smith becoming majority leader.\n\nOn December 2, 2009, Kruger was one of eight Democrats to vote against a  bill that failed to pass the Senate. On June 13, 2011, it was announced that he,  and  had switched their intentions from \"against\" to \"for\" a pending same-sex marriage bill. Kruger voted in favor of the Marriage Equality Act in 2011; the bill passed the Senate and was signed into law by Gov. Andrew Cuomo.\n\nIn 2011, Kruger introduced a bill \"that would ban the use of , s or other electronic devices while crossing streets &mdash; runners and other exercisers included.\" January 14, 2011\n\n\nOn June 25, 2010, '''' revealed that the  and the  in Brooklyn were investigating Kruger for allegedly seeking campaign contributions in exchange for political favors. On March 9, 2011, Kruger was  on charges of bribery and profiting from a hospital merger he supported. On March 10, 2011, Kruger was among eight individuals (including , another New York State Assemblyman) who \"surrendered to face charges in a federal corruption case accusing the lawmakers of taking bribes over the course of a decade in schemes large and small.\" According to ''The New York Times'':\n\n\n\nKruger allegedly used the money to \"bankroll a lavish lifestyle, financing a four-door  and a $2 million waterfront home originally built for , a  of the .\"\n\nOn December 20, 2011, Kruger pleaded guilty to two counts of conspiracy to commit mail and wire fraud and two counts of bribery conspiracy.  He faced up to 50 years in prison. Michael Turano, a co-conspirator described as Kruger's \"secret longtime companion,\" pleaded guilty to one count of conspiracy to commit bribery and was sentenced to two years in prison.\n\nOn April 26, 2012, Judge  sentenced Kruger to seven years in federal prison.\n\n\nThe ' Inmate Locator lists Kruger as released since August 3, 2018.\n\nIn January 2019, a blog covering Brooklyn politics spotted Kruger at a meeting of Community Board 18. The District Manager of the Community Board at the time was Dorothy Turano, who is mother of Kruger's co-conspirator and partner Michael Turano.\n\nIn April 2019, a small business owner applying for a liquor license complained to  that Kruger threatened her at the Board meeting. Kruger assailed a  representative at a June 2019 Community Board meeting, in a manner one observer called \".\"\n\n\nKruger has stated that he was raised by his mother, a single parent, in a low-income environment. He has further indicated that his mother attempted to give him up for adoption as an infant, but that his potential adoptive parents changed their minds and sent him back to his mother. Kruger is .\n\nKruger is a close friend of the Turano family, which includes longtime Democratic activist Dorothy Turano and her sons, Michael and Gerard Turano. The gay marriage issue affected Kruger's personal life; Dorothy Turano has a gay nephew who cut off contact with both her and Kruger after Kruger voted against a same-sex marriage bill in 2009. Kruger voted in favor of same-sex marriage in 2011.\n\nAccording to , as they investigated Kruger for bribery, the FBI \"learned that he lived with his longtime male partner [Michael Turano] while pretending (or at least allowing people to believe) that his partner's mother [Dorothy Turano] was his girlfriend.\" Kruger has publicly denied being gay; however, the federal government produced wiretap evidence of \"nearly daily\" contact between the two men, including \"baby talk\" and a reminiscence by Turano of Kruger's declaration of love for him. Kruger and Michael Turano asked to serve their sentences at the same detention facility, but their request was denied.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* \n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''John Reagan''' (born August 5, 1946) is an American politician who served in the  from the  from 2012 to 2022. He previously served in the  from the  1 district from 2006 to 2012.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n|birth_place  = , U.S.\n|death_date   = \n|death_place  = \n|party        = \n|spouse       = Beverly Massa\n|education    =  ()\n|allegiance   = \n|branch       = \n|serviceyears = 1981–2004\n|rank         = \n}}\n'''Eric James Joseph Massa''' (born September 16, 1959) is a former American politician who served as a U.S. Representative for the . A , he served in Congress from January 2009 until his resignation in March 2010.  Massa resigned during a pending  investigation into allegations of . Massa identified his declining health and the ongoing ethics investigation as the reasons for his resignation; however, he later said that there was a conspiracy \"to oust him because he had voted against overhauling health care.\" It was reported in 2017 that Congress had paid nearly $100,000 to  the  claims made by two male staffers against Massa.\n\n\nEric James Joseph Massa was born in  on September 16, 1959. The son of a career  officer, Massa grew up in various locations, including  and . After graduating from the  Massa was on active duty in the Navy for 24 years. He served in the Persian Gulf War and also served as aide to General . Near the end of his Navy career, he was diagnosed with , from which he later recovered.\n\nUpon retirement from the military, Massa moved to  to work for the  in 2001. He lost his job due to downsizing and moved to Washington to work as a Republican staffer for the House Armed Services Committee in 2003. Massa was fired after it became known that he had written to his former boss, Democrat Wesley Clark, with advice on his presidential campaign. Thereafter, Massa joined the Democratic Party. He coordinated veterans' outreach efforts in New Hampshire and Virginia during Clark's unsuccessful .\n\n\n\n;2006\n\nIn 2006, Massa ran for Congress in New York's 29th congressional district on the strength of his military background, which it was hoped would appeal to veterans and to independents who favor a strong defense policy.  During the campaign, Massa positioned himself as strongly opposed to the Iraq war and unrestricted , favoring instead . Other issues in his platform included expanding farm aid programs, as well as bringing homeland security money to the .\n\nOn Election night, incumbent Republican Rep.  led Massa by a 52%-48% margin. Massa requested a recount and an accounting of absentee ballots because 6,000 votes separated the two and 10,000 were left to be counted. After a week of waiting, the ballots were approximately even and Congressman Kuhl was re-elected. Massa conceded the election with a telephone call to Congressman Kuhl.\n\n;2008\n\nAlmost immediately after conceding defeat in 2006, Massa prepared for a rematch against Kuhl in 2008.  The race remained tight through the campaign; however, Massa emerged victorious, defeating Kuhl 51% to 49% (a margin of approximately 4000 votes), although Kuhl did not immediately concede defeat. All voting machines were impounded at Kuhl's request (pending a re-count), with 12,000 absentee ballots to be counted. The recount yielded a margin of victory of approximately 4,000 votes for Massa, and Kuhl conceded the race on November 21. Some press reports attributed Massa's victory to the plurality he attained among voters in , which voted for Kuhl in 2004 and 2006.\n\n\nMassa was assigned a seat on the . He also inherited Kuhl's seat on the  and was given a seat the .\n\nMassa voted in favor of, and generally supported, the , but has said he finds faults with the legislation. After the act failed to generate the expected stimulus to the Southern Tier economy, Massa claimed that virtually all of the stimulus funds were funneled to the state governments and diverted to interests in New York City.\n\nIn April 2009, Massa was noted for his suggestion to close the  as a response to the , which originated in Mexico. He also was a leading critic of 's abortive plan to charge a  rate for its .\n\nThough he generally supported a health care reform plan, he opposed, and voted against, the  by the Obama administration, due to the cost, and preferred a  system instead.\n\nDuring the 2009 Netroots Nation convention held in Pittsburgh, PA, Massa told a group of activists that he \"will vote adamantly against the interests of my district if I actually think what I am doing is going to be helpful\" in regard to a single-payer health care system. Moments later Massa clarified that he meant he would vote against the \"opinions\" of his constituents if he thought it was the right thing to do. He also controversially exclaimed that Sen. 's comments describing end-of-life care as \"\" constitute \"an act of treason.\"\n\n\nOn October 10, 2009, Massa announced his plans for re-election, saying, \"I don't want to play games with people about speculation, I want to be very direct and candid.\"\n\nOn a press conference call on March 3, 2010, Massa announced that his cancer had returned and that he would not seek re-election. In his statement, Massa addressed allegations of , but claimed he would stay on for the remainder of his term.\n\nThe next day, March 4, 2010, House Majority Leader  confirmed that the  was investigating allegations against Massa of  as the result of a complaint that a senior member of Massa's staff had filed with the committee on February 8, 2010. The investigation was said to involve alleged sexual advances and harassment toward a younger male member of Massa's staff.\n\nAt a press conference, Massa described his behavior and his language as \"salty,\" claiming that he had apologized to the parties in question, did not know of the specific allegations, and did not make the decision to retire based upon such allegations.\n\n\nMassa announced on March 5, 2010, that he would resign his seat in Congress effective 5:00&nbsp;p.m. on March 8, 2010.  In a published statement on his website, Massa identified his declining health and the ongoing ethics investigation as the reasons for his departure. He apologized in response to the  complaint, saying that \"There is no doubt in my mind that I did in fact, use language in the privacy of my own home and in my inner office that, after 24 years in the navy, might make a Chief Petty Officer feel uncomfortable. In fact, there is no doubt that this ethics issue is my fault and mine alone.\"\n\nMassa later claimed that there was a conspiracy to remove him from Congress \"because he had voted against overhauling health care.\" Massa placed specific blame for his resignation on White House Chief of Staff , stating that Emanuel \"is the son of the devil's spawn...  He is an individual who would sell his mother to get a vote. He would strap his children to the front end of a steam locomotive.\" Massa also commented on the following alleged confrontation with Emanuel in the congressional gym locker room:  \"I am sitting there showering, naked as a jaybird, and here comes Rahm Emanuel, not even with a towel wrapped around his tush, poking his finger in my chest, yelling at me because I wasn't going to vote for the president's budget...  He goes there to intimidate members of Congress... He's hated me since day one, and now he wins. He'll get rid of me, and this bill will pass.\" A Democratic spokesperson denied the existence of the alleged conspiracy.\n\nOn March 10, 2010, ''The Washington Post'' reported that Massa was under investigation for allegations that he had groped multiple male staffers working in his office. The ''Post'' reported:\n\nThe freshman Democrat told  host  that \"not only did I grope [a staffer], I d him until he couldn't breathe,\" then said hours later on 's \"\" that \"it is not true\" that he groped anyone on his staff.\n\nHe told Beck that he resigned from the House because he made the mistake of \"getting too familiar with my staff\" members, but he told King that he left primarily for health reasons. Massa, 50, has survived non-Hodgkin's lymphoma, but he said he is afraid that he is facing his \"third major cancer-recurrence scare.\"\n\nIn his interview with Beck, the married Massa acknowledged that he shared a Washington residence with several unmarried male staffers as a cost-saving measure.\n\nMassa claimed that he contemplated  at least twice on his way back to his home in , following his resignation. Later campaign finance filings revealed that his campaign funds were being used to fund his wife's salary well after his resignation, as well as to pay legal fees stemming from disputes with his staffers. The payments to his wife continued until the end of 2012.\n\nIn 2017, the '''' reported that Congress had paid nearly $100,000 to  the  claims made by two male staffers against Massa.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n*''''''\n**\n**\n*''''''\n**\n**\n*''''''\n**\n**\n\n\n\n*\n*\n*\n*\n\n\n\n\nHutchinson, Laura.  .     "pages": }\n\n'''Rhoda S. Jacobs''' (born September 29, 1936) is an American politician from . A , she was until 2014 a member of the  from the 42nd Assembly District in , which primarily includes the neighborhoods of  and .\n\nA  native and a graduate of , Assemblywoman Jacobs was originally elected to the then 43rd District in 1978.  Jacobs faced a difficult re-election in 1982 after the Assembly districts were re-apportioned to increase  and  representation in the Legislature. Jacobs ended up in the new 42nd District where she prevailed and remained there until 2014, sitting in the , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , ,  and s.\n\nShe served at times as the Assistant Speaker of the , as Assistant Speaker pro tempore and Chairwoman of the Majority Program Committee as well as the Social Services Committee, which latter positions she occupied for two and twelve years respectively.\n\nIn the past, she has also served as the Chair of the Assembly Committee on Oversight, Analysis and Investigation and the Task Force on Food, Farm and Nutrition Policy. In 1997, Jacobs was appointed as Chairwoman of the Budget Conference Committee on Health and Human Services.\n\nIn addition to these positions within the Assembly, she has also served as an officer for the National Association of State Legislators and as an elected delegate to other national legislative bodies.\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Carolyn McCarthy''' ( '''Cook'''; born January 5, 1944) is an American politician who served as the  for  from 1997 to 2015. She is a member of the .\n\nOn January 8, 2014, she announced that she would not run for re-election that November, citing health; she retired in January 2015 and was replaced by fellow Democrat .\n\n\nMcCarthy was born Carolyn Cook in , New York, and was raised in , a suburban area on  about twenty miles outside . Her father was a  and her mother worked at . In her youth, she was an athlete and wanted to become a  teacher but found reading challenging and later was diagnosed with . After caring for a boyfriend who was injured in a car accident, McCarthy decided to work as a . Later she married and she and her family lived in Mineola.\n\nOn December 7, 1993, her husband, Dennis, was killed, and her son, Kevin, was severely injured on a   at the  station in the village of , when 35-year-old Colin Ferguson .  Ferguson killed six and wounded 19 others. McCarthy responded to the crime by launching a campaign for more stringent  that eventually propelled her to Congress in 1996 on the Democratic ticket. She defeated freshman Republican  by a large margin. In the biographical 1998  '''', which portrayed these events, she was played by actress .\n\n\nDuring her time in Congress, McCarthy was described as \"the  of anti-gun advocates in the House\" and \"the fiercest gun-control advocate in Congress\".  She made attempts to broaden her policy portfolio, but was never able to entirely shed the label of being a one-issue congresswoman. She acknowledged this, saying in 2009 that although she is also known for her education and district work, she is still the \"gun lady\".\nMcCarthy was a registered Republican before her first run for Congress, although she ran for office as a Democrat and \"evolved\" over the years into a reliable Democratic vote. She voted with her party 98.1 percent of the time during the .\n\n\n*'''''' \n** (Ranking Member)\n**\n*''''''\n**\n**\n\n\n*Co-chair, \n*Congressional Glaucoma Caucus\n*Financial Literacy Caucus\n*\n*U.S.-Israel Security Caucus\n*Women's Caucus\n\n\n\n\nMcCarthy's husband Dennis was murdered in the , which first prompted her to run for Congress.\n\nMcCarthy was one of the nation's most vocal gun control advocates. In 1997, she sponsored a bill requiring s on guns. After the , she introduced legislation to ban the sale of guns to tourists visiting the United States; afterwards, she received \"threats serious enough to require police protection during most public appearances\". Later that year, McCarthy unsuccessfully opposed a  bill provision that allowed the importation of weapons that had been modified in order to be compliant with the federal assault weapons ban. In the aftermath of the , McCarthy proposed a bill that would require firearms to be child-resistant, would make it more difficult for young adults to purchase guns, and would regulate gun shows.\n\nAfter the  expired in September 2004, McCarthy introduced the  to reauthorize it in February 2007.\n\nOn April 16, 2007, after the s, McCarthy issued a press release calling for \"legislation to prevent further acts of \".  Shooter  had passed a background check despite his mental health issues owing to an inconsistent sharing of records between the federal and state governments. McCarthy introduced (H.R. 2640, the NICS Improvement Amendments Act of 2007) to remedy this problem. The bill, with the support of the , was passed by the House and signed by President . McCarthy said her next priority was closing the .\n\nIn January 2012, McCarthy along with Senator  from California proposed a bill which would \"ban the sale, transfer, manufacturing of importation of 150 specific firearms including semiautomatic rifles or pistols that can be used with a detachable or fixed ammunition magazines that hold more than 10 rounds and have specific military-style features, including pistol grips, grenade launchers or rocket launchers.\" McCarthy spoke on the bill saying, \"The American people are on our side this time, and we do outnumber some of the people who are fighting against us this time.\"\n\nOn a 2007 episode of MSNBC's program , Tucker Carlson interviewed McCarthy about the  and her proposed reauthorization of the .  She said that the legislation would ban  and \"shoulder things that go up.\"\n\n\nMcCarthy voted in favor of the  in 2002. In 2006, she voted in support of a Republican resolution in support of the war.\n\n\nIn her 1996 race, McCarthy said she was against the  but added that she wouldn't support repeal because her district supported it.\n\n\nMcCarthy is one of the strongest advocates of hearing loss detection, prevention, and treatment. A former nurse, she has repeatedly championed the Hearing Aid Tax Credit Act, which is designed to help those with hearing loss to afford hearing aids.\n\n\nMcCarthy consistently supported . In 1997, McCarthy voted against a ban on late-term abortions. In 2003 she was rated 100% by NARAL, and in 2006 she was rated 0% by the NRLC; both scores indicate a strongly pro-choice stance.\n\n\nIn 2003, McCarthy introduced legislation prohibiting companies from compelling the retirement of older employees and denying them pension and benefits.\n\n\nMcCarthy, who has , testified in support of the  and co-sponsored an act to fund early detection of dyslexia.\n\n\nIn September 2007, McCarthy supported an increase of $35 billion for the  (SCHIP), the national program to provide health care for children from families who earn too much to qualify for  but cannot afford private health insurance. She said, \"No child in the 4th Congressional District, Long Island, or anywhere throughout our nation should ever go without medical care.\" The increase passed but was later ed by President .\n\n\nMcCarthy was a supporter of federally funded  but restricted to the use of embryos that would be discarded. In 2007, she supported the  which did just that. It passed both the House and Senate but was later vetoed by President Bush.\n\n\nOn November 4, 1999, McCarthy voted in favor of the .\n\n\nIn a 2011 press release, McCarthy expressed her sentiments on the , saying \"It's time to stop letting the Tea Party hold the House of Representatives hostage.\"\n\n\n\nThe Fourth District and its predecessors had been in Republican hands since 1953, even though Nassau County as a whole has supported Democrats for  since 1992. In 1996, the district's first-term  incumbent  was running for re-election at the time that McCarthy testified at a congressional hearing against an ultimately unsuccessful Republican attempt to repeal the  in a congressional hearing.\n\nAfter Frisa voted for the repeal, McCarthy, a lifelong Republican, announced she would run against him in the primary.  However, local Republican officials showed no support for her candidacy. So, with the support of the local and national Democratic parties, and the endorsement of '''', the local daily newspaper, McCarthy ran as a Democrat and defeated Frisa by seventeen points. Afterwards, some Republicans tried unsuccessfully to persuade her to run as a Republican in 1998.\n\nShe faced a close fight for reelection in 1998 against state assemblyman . In 2004, she faced  mayor .  The race was expected to be competitive, but McCarthy won easily, taking 63% of the vote.\n\nAlthough McCarthy has always served as a Democrat, she did not change her voter registration from Republican until 2003.\n\n\n\nBefore the election, it was reported that Democrats were concerned that McCarthy was in danger of losing her seat. In the end, however,  McCarthy defeated Republican challenger , by a margin of 54% to 46%.\n\nEarlier in 2010, it was widely reported that McCarthy was considering entering the  to challenge Senator , owing to the latter's support for gun rights. Gillibrand had been appointed to the seat on January 23, 2009, by Governor  to succeed , who had left the Senate to become Secretary of State in the new . McCarthy commented, saying: \"I've spent 15 years trying to prevent gun violence in this country, and if he [Paterson] does pick her [Gillibrand] and if no one goes and primaries her, I will primary her.\" She said she would not let New York be represented by someone with a 100% rating of the NRA. On Hardball, McCarthy said that she thought Gillibrand was working for the NRA.  On June 4, 2009, however, McCarthy announced that she would not mount a primary challenge to Gillibrand.\n\n\n\nIn early 2012 there was a question as to whether redistricting might eliminate McCarthy's district.  In the end, her district was left essentially intact.\n\n\nThird-party candidates omitted, so percentages may not add up to 100%.\n\n\n\n\nMcCarthy announced on June 3, 2013, that she has a treatable form of . On November 8, 2013, it was reported that McCarthy, who had smoked cigarettes for 40 years, was suing more than 70 companies claiming that she had developed lung cancer from . Her father and brother, whose clothes she washed, worked with asbestos. This was challenged by '''' columnist , who claimed McCarthy was part of a growing trend of cigarette smokers suing companies that once used asbestos, citing her nearly lifelong \"pack-a-day\" habit as evidence that she was knowingly bringing a bogus case and partaking in a widespread \"asbestos scam\".\n\n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n''|years=}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''William Scarborough''' (born March 14, 1945) is a Democrat who represented District 29 in the , which includes large portions of , including . He chaired the Assembly Committee on Children and Families and served as a member of several other standing committees.\n\nScarborough grew up in , and has also lived in  and , graduated Public School 140 June, 1957, Shimer J.H.S. 142, and . He received an  from  in 1970 and  degree in psychology and political science from  () in 1975.\n\nHe was an account executive with the  from 1979 to 1983. His initial start in politics included a stint as a member of Community Board 28 (1977–1983). Prior to his election to the Assembly, Scarborough served as District Manager of  (1984–1994), as well as in the capacity of Chairman of Area Policy Board 12 (1983–1994).\n\nScarborough was first elected to the State Assembly in 1994. He ran uncontested in the 2008 and 2010 s.  During his tenure in the State Assembly, Scarborough was the Chair of the Small Business Committee and a vocal advocate for the City and State to address the flooding occurring in his district. Flooding in Southeast Queens is primarily the result of the restored water table that developed following the closure of the Greater Jamaica Water Companies pumping operations.\n\nOn October 1, 2014, Scarborough was indicted on eleven federal charges and 23 state charges of using campaign funds for personal benefit. In May 2015 he pleaded guilty and resigned his Assembly seat.  In September, 2015, Scarborough was sentenced to 13 months in federal prison for his crime. Since his release from prison, he has found employment with the , helping the recently released connect with social services.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Anthony David Weiner''' ( born September 4, 1964) is an American former politician who served as the  for  from 1999 until his resignation in 2011. A member of the , he consistently carried the district with at least 60% of the vote. Weiner resigned from Congress in June 2011 after it was revealed he  to different women, including a minor.\n\nA two-time candidate for , Weiner finished second in the Democratic primary in . He ran again in , placing fifth in the Democratic primary.\n\nIn 2017, Weiner pled guilty to transferring obscene material to a minor and was sentenced to 21 months in prison. He was also required to permanently register as a . Weiner began serving his federal prison sentence the same year and was released in 2019.\n\n\nWeiner was born in  in New York City, the middle son of Jewish parents, Mort Weiner, a lawyer, and his wife, Frances (née Finkelstein), a public high school math teacher. The family lived for a time in the  neighborhood of Brooklyn. Weiner attended elementary school at . His older brother Seth was 39 years old when he was killed by a  in 2000. His younger brother, Jason, is a chef and co-owner of several New York restaurants.\n\nWeiner took the , an examination used to determine admission to all but one of New York City's , and was admitted to , from which he graduated in 1981. He  attended the , and spent his junior year as an exchange student at the , where he was friends with future comic and political commentator . Weiner's interests turned towards politics; he became active in student government and was named most effective student senator.\n\nAfter he received his  degree in  in 1985, Weiner joined the staff of then– and current  . He worked in Schumer's  office for three years, then transferred to the district office in Brooklyn in 1988, when Schumer encouraged him to become involved in local politics.\n\n\nAfter working for Schumer for six years, Weiner got his first chance at political office in 1991 when the  was expanded from 35 to 51 seats.  Weiner was considered a long-shot because he faced strong competition in the Democratic primary elections from two other candidates who had better local name recognition and funding. Weiner narrowly won the primary, besting  by fewer than 200 votes. Controversy ensued in the last weeks of the campaign after Weiner's campaign anonymously spread leaflets around the district that had alleged ties between Cohen and the so-called \"Jackson-Dinkins agenda\"; the leaflets referred to the  earlier in the year, after which white residents had seen , who became notorious for his earlier remarks about New York City as \"\", and then-mayor  as having been beholden to the predominantly African-American rioters and therefore endangering whites.\n\nWeiner's win in the November general election was widely considered a formality because he had no opposition in the heavily Democratic district. He was 27 years old when he became the youngest councilman in the city's history. Over the next seven years on the City Council, Weiner initiated programs to address  concerns. He also started a program to put at-risk and troubled teens to work cleaning up , and he backed development plans that helped revive the historic  area.\n\n\n\nIn 1998, Weiner ran for  from , which was the seat held by his mentor, Chuck Schumer, who had run successfully for the . Weiner won the Democratic primary election, which was  in the heavily Democratic district that included parts of  and south and central .\n\n\n, 2009.]]\nWeiner received a 100% rating from the  in 2003 and a 0% rating from  2006, which indicated a strong  voting record. He was critical of the 2009  to the , which prohibits the use of taxpayer funds for s, calling it \"unnecessary and divisive\" and saying it would prevent health insurers from offering abortion coverage regardless of whether an individual uses federal funds to purchase an insurance plan.\n\nIn April 2008, Weiner created the  Congressional Middle Class . He received an \"A\" on the 's 2005 Congressional Scorecard on middle-class issues. In June 2008, Weiner sponsored a bill to increase the number of  available to foreign fashion models, arguing that it would help boost the fashion industry in New York City. He criticized UN diplomats for failing to pay parking tickets in New York City, claiming foreign nations owed $18,000,000 to the city.\n\nDuring the health care reform debates of 2009, Weiner advocated for a bill called the , which would have expanded  to all Americans, regardless of age. He remarked that while 4% of Medicare funds go to overhead, private insurers put 30% of their customer's money into profits and overhead instead of into health care. In late July 2009, he secured a full House floor vote for  in exchange for not amending  in committee  with a single-payer plan.\n\nWhen a  was being considered as part of America's Affordable Health Choices Act of 2009, Weiner said that it would help reduce costs, and he set up a website to push for the option. He attracted widespread attention when described the  as \"a wholly owned subsidiary of the insurance industry, teaming up with a small group of Democrats to try to protect that industry\". In February 2010, he proclaimed to Congress that \"every single Republican I have ever met in my entire life is a wholly owned subsidiary of the insurance industry.\"\n\nWeiner was the chief sponsor of the  of 2009, which made the selling of tobacco in violation of any state tax law a federal , and effectively ended Internet tobacco smuggling by stopping shipments of cigarettes through the . He claimed, \"This new law will give states and localities a major revenue boost by cracking down on the illegal sale of tobacco\", and added that \"Every day we delay is another day that New York loses significant amounts of tax revenue and kids have easy access to tobacco products sold over the Internet.\"\n\nOn July 29, 2010, Weiner criticized Republicans for opposing the , which would provide for funds for sick  to the  on the . In a speech on the floor of the House, he accused Republicans of hiding behind procedural questions as an excuse to vote against the bill.\n\nIn response to pressure from Weiner,  removed some of 's inflammatory videos from its website in November 2010. Weiner voted against the . As a prominent Democratic opponent of the tax cut package passed by Congress, Weiner said Republicans had gotten the better of President  in the negotiations to reach an agreement on the $858 billion deal and said the Republicans turned out to be \"better poker players\" than Obama.\n\nIn 2002, Weiner voiced strong criticism of the removal of the  debris without investigating it for determining the causes of the collapses of Tower 1, 2 and 7.\n\n\nIn 2002, Weiner voted to give President  the authority to use military force against . In May 2006, Weiner attempted to bar the Palestinian delegation from entering the United Nations. He added that the delegation \"should start packing their little Palestinian terrorist bags\", and went on to claim that , '''', and  are all biased against .\n\nOn July 29, 2007, Weiner and Rep.  (D-N.Y.) objected to a $20-billion arms deal that the  negotiated with  because they didn't want to provide \"sophisticated weapons to a country that they believe has not done enough to stop terrorism\", noting that 15 of the 19  in the  were Saudis. Weiner made the announcement outside of the Saudi Arabian consulate in , stating, \"We need to send a crystal clear message to the Saudi Arabian government that their tacit approval of terrorism can't go unpunished.\" The two intended to use a provision of the  to review the deal and pass a Joint Resolution of Disapproval.\n\nWeiner and several other members of Congress later criticized the Obama administration's proposal to sell over $60&nbsp;billion in arms to Saudi Arabia. He said: \"Saudi Arabia is not deserving of our aid, and by arming them with advanced American weaponry we are sending the wrong message\", and described Saudi Arabia as having a \"history of financing terrorism\" and teaching \" and Jews\" to its schoolchildren.\n\n\nIn July 2008, '''' characterized Weiner as one of the most intense and demanding of bosses. The newspaper described him as a person who often worked long hours with his staff and required them to be in constant contact via . He frequently yelled at them and occasionally threw office furniture in anger. As a result of Weiner's actions, the ''Times'' reported that he had one of the highest staff turnover rates of any member of Congress; this included the departure of three chiefs of staff within an 18-month period. Weiner admitted he pushed his aides hard but said that his speaking at a high decibel level was part of his background and style, not necessarily shouting. Though some former employees were critical of his supervisory practices, others praised him for his intense involvement in constituent concerns and readiness to fight for New York City.\n\n\nA 2010 license plate check by the  newspaper '''' showed that Weiner's vehicles were among several owned by members of Congress that had unpaid tickets. Weiner's past due fines, which spanned three years and totaled more than $2,000, were among the highest uncovered by ''Roll Call'' and were paid in full shortly after publication of the article. On June 13, 2011, the '''' reported that one of Weiner's vehicles, though it had been issued valid plates, was displaying expired plates that had been issued to another one of his vehicles.\n\n\n\nOn May 27, 2011, Weiner used his public  account to send a link to a woman who was following him on the social media platform.  The link contained a sexually explicit photograph of himself. After several days of denying that he had posted the image, Weiner held a press conference at which he admitted he had \"exchanged messages and photos of an explicit nature with about six women over the last three years\" and apologized for his earlier denials. After an explicit photo was leaked through the Twitter account of a listener of '''', Weiner announced on June 16, 2011, that he would resign from Congress, and he formally did so on June 21. A special election was held on September 13, 2011, to replace him; Republican businessman  defeated Democrat  to fill Weiner's seat.\n\nA second sexting scandal began on July 23, 2013, which was several months after Weiner returned to politics in the New York City mayoral race. Weiner sent explicit photos under an alias to a 22-year-old woman with whom he had contact as late as April 2013, which was more than a year after he had left Congress. The woman was later identified as Sydney Leathers.\n\nOn August 28, 2016, the '''' reported that Weiner had  another woman, including sending a picture while he was lying in bed with his young son. ''The New York Times'' reported the next day that Weiner and his wife  intended to separate. Abedin announced her intention by stating, \"After long and painful consideration and work on my marriage, I have made the decision to separate from my husband. Anthony and I remain devoted to doing what is best for our son, who is the light of our life. During this difficult time, I ask for respect for our privacy.\"\n\nIn September 2016, claims were published that Weiner had engaged in sexting with a 15-year-old girl from North Carolina, and devices owned by Weiner were seized as part of an investigation into this incident. The report prompted a criminal investigation and Weiner's laptop was seized. Emails that were pertinent to the  were discovered on the laptop; this prompted FBI Director  to reopen that investigation eleven days before the .  said Comey's decision was one of the reasons she lost the election to .\n\nOn January 31, 2017, '''' reported that federal prosecutors were weighing whether or not to bring  charges against Weiner over the incident. On May 19, 2017, ''The New York Times'' reported in its online edition that Weiner had surrendered to the  that morning. He plead guilty to a single charge of transferring obscene material to a minor. Under the agreement, Weiner faced a sentence of 21 to 27 months in federal prison and would be required to register as a . At his sentencing hearing on September 25, 2017, presiding judge  sentenced Weiner to 21 months in prison, beginning on November 6, 2017, with an additional three years of supervision following his prison term.\n\n\nOn November 6, 2017, Weiner reported to  in  to begin his 21-month sentence. After getting about three months deducted from his sentence for good behavior, Weiner was released from prison on February 17, 2019, and sent to a halfway house. Weiner was released from a Bronx halfway house on May 14, 2019. Weiner is registered as a sex offender.\n\n\n\n\n\nWeiner sought the Democratic nomination to run for , vying against three other candidates. He had a three-part pitch to voters that included criticizing sitting Mayor  for his top-down style of management and promising a more democratic approach; against \"passivity in City Hall\" and for getting more federal money for the city; and a series of ideas on how to get the city to work better. He presented a book of 50 \"Real Solutions\" and among his policy proposals were fixes for the health care and educational systems. One idea already in play was a neighborhood scrubbing-up program he dubbed \"Weiner's Cleaners\".\n\nWeiner started out last in many polls, but gained ground in the final weeks of the campaign, coming in second. Initial election returns had  with 39.95% of the vote, just shy of the 40% required to avoid a runoff against Weiner, who had 28.82%, but Weiner conceded, citing the need for party unity and denying rumors that various high-ranking New York Democrats, such as Senator  and  , had urged him to concede.  put Ferrer over the 40% mark in the official .\n\n\nWeiner appeared to be a candidate for mayor again in 2009. However, in May 2009, after the  voted to extend term limits for Mayor Bloomberg, Weiner announced his decision not to run against the popular incumbent. By July 2010, Weiner had raised $3.9&nbsp;million for a potential campaign in the 2013 mayoral election, and was considered a leading contender in early polls. According to the  website, as of the March 2013 filing deadline Weiner had raised over $5.1&nbsp;million, the second most among registered mayoral candidates, behind only .\n\n\n\nIn an interview with '''' published online on April 10, 2013, Weiner said he would like to \"ask people to give me a second chance\" and was considering a run for mayor. He added that, \"it's now or maybe never for me.\"\n\nIn an interview on April 11, Rep.  endorsed Weiner, saying that he would love to see him become mayor of New York. Weiner announced his intent to seek candidacy on a  video on May 21, 2013.\n\nWeiner's platform for candidacy was summarized in \"Keys to the City: 64 Ideas to Keep New York City the Capital of the Middle Class\".\n\nAfter his resignation from Congress, Weiner used the alias \"Carlos Danger\" to continue to send explicit photographs. Following the second set of sexting allegations, he acknowledged on July 23, 2013, that he had sent messages to at least three women in 2012. One recipient stated that Weiner described himself to her as “an argumentative, perpetually horny middle-aged man”. Following this admission, there were calls for Weiner to drop out of the mayoral race; however, Weiner held a press conference with his wife, , in which he announced that he would continue his campaign. At the press conference, Weiner said, \"I said that other texts and photos were likely to come out and today they have... I want to again say that I am very sorry to anyone who was on the receiving end of these messages and the disruption this has caused.”\n\n\nOn July 27, 2013, Danny Kedem, Weiner's campaign chief, announced his resignation. On September 10, 2013, Weiner lost the mayoral primary, winning only 4.9% of the vote.\n\n\n\nIn November 2024, Weiner announced that he is considering running for public office again.  He is considering running against New York State Assemblyman  and two other Democrats in The New York City Council District currently occupied by term limited member .\n\n\nIn July 2011 (less than a month after he left Congress), Weiner created the consulting firm Woolf-Weiner Associates. He advised over a dozen companies that included electronic medical records providers and  firms. He worked with , an international law firm. According to 2012 public disclosures, his work helped increase his combined family income to $496,000. Weiner argued that despite contacting members of Congress on behalf of his clients, his work did not meet the legal definition of . This was based on the so-called \" Loophole\" in the , which requires only those who spend more than 20% of their time lobbying to register as lobbyists.\n\nThe  criticized Weiner for stealth lobbying and falling under the aforementioned \"Daschle Loophole\". The public never learned of his lobbying work until two years later, when his nondisclosure agreements expired.\n\nFrom July to September 2015, Weiner worked for , a  in New York City as a part-time consultant to serve on the company's board of advisors.\n\nOn August 29, 2016, the '''' said it would no longer carry Weiner's columns, which included his writings on New York City politics. On the same day, television channel  said Weiner would not be reprising his contributor role on any of its shows.\n\nWeiner served as  of IceStone, a Brooklyn-based kitchen-countertop company. He left his role as CEO in August 2021, as the company transitioned to a worker-owned cooperative.\n\nAfter leaving IceStone, he began working for  where he co-hosts a weekly live show with  and records a weekly podcast.\n\n\n in 2010]]\n\nIn 2009, Weiner became engaged to , a long-time personal aide to , and they married in July 2010, with former president  officiating. Abedin is a practicing  of  and  descent. In December 2011, Abedin gave birth to a son.\n\nIn August 2016, Abedin announced that she was separating from Weiner. In early 2017, Abedin announced her intent to file for divorce with  of their son.  On May 19, 2017, after he pleaded guilty, she filed for divorce. Abedin and Weiner withdrew their divorce case from court in January 2018, saying they decided to settle the divorce privately in order to spare their six-year-old son further embarrassment. As of November 2021, their divorce was in its final stages, although they still see each other and raise their son.\n\nWeiner is a lifelong fan of the  and .\n\n\n\n\nIn 2013, Weiner and Abedin allowed filmmakers full access to his mayoral campaign. In 2016, the resulting documentary, '''', premiered at the .\n\nIn 2013, a production called ''The Weiner Monologues'' premiered at the Access Theater. Directed by Jonathan Harper Schlieman, the show was based on media coverage of Weiner's sexting scandal.\n\nIn 2014, he had a cameo appearance in an '''' episode.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* \n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nBarbaro, Michael & David W.     "pages": }\n'''William Anson Barclay''' (born January 5, 1969) is an American politician and attorney from the State of New York. A Republican, he has served in the New York State Assembly since 2003. In January 2020, Barclay was elected to the position of Assembly Minority Leader.\n\n\nBarclay was born in . He earned his  from  in 1992 and his  from  in 1995.  After graduating from law school he served as a clerk for , a judge in the  Second Circuit, in both  and .\n\nBarclay is a partner in the law firm of Barclay Damon. His father is , a former  and a former chair of the Republican Conference in the .\n\nAs of January 2020, Barclay and his wife Margaret are the parents of two sons, Harry and George. Nine generations of Barclays have resided in Pulaski, New York.\n\n\nBarclay was first elected to the State Assembly on November 5, 2002, defeating Democrat E. Clyde Ohl by a margin of 21,848 to 14,594. He took office in 2003. Barclay won the November 2008  with 67 percent of the vote and ran uncontested in the November 2010 and 2012 general elections. A , Barclay represents the 120th District in the . As of 2020, the 120th district includes  and portions of ,  and  counties.\n\nOn December 14, 2007, Barclay announced his candidacy for  in New York's 48th Senate district. He sought to replace former Senator , who stepped down. Barclay lost the election to Democratic Assemblyman  on February 27, 2008.\n\nOn January 7, 2020, Barclay was unanimously elected to the post of Assembly Minority Leader by his Republican colleagues following the resignation of . He previously served as Deputy Minority Leader, as chair of the Republican Assembly Campaign Committee, and as ranking member of the Assembly Ways and Means Committee.\n\nOn August 31, 2020, during an interview with Susan Arbetter on  Capital Tonight, an Albany-based political insider television program, Barclay would not say if he believed in anthropogenic climate change. Barclay also claimed that natural gas \"had gotten a bad rap,\" and said that if climate change was responsible for , \"we can't say climate change is responsible for a really cold winter.\"\n\nOn October 26, 2022, the Albany-based statewide environmental 501(c)(4) non-profit Environmental Advocates Action, formed in 1969 as one of the first organizations in the nation to advocate for the future of a state's environment and the health of its citizens, released its annual Environmental Scorecard and gave Assembly Minority Leader Will Barclay its 2022 \"Oil Slick Award,\" which symbolizes his disregard for the environment (based upon his environmental votes). Environmental Advocates Action's sister organization is Environmental Advocates NY, which is the New York State affiliate of the National Wildlife Federation.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Helen Marie Marshall''' ( '''Sargent''' ; September 30, 1929 – March 4, 2017) was an American politician from . She was  of  from 2002 - 2013. She was also the first African-American Borough President of Queens.\n\n\nMarshall was born on  September 30, 1929, in , having been raised in between both  and the . Both of her parents were immigrants of African descent from  (now ).\n\nShe graduated with a  in education from . She was a teacher for eight years. In 1969, she left teaching to become the first Director of the Langston Hughes Library in Queens. She was married to Donald Edward Marshall until his death; they had two children, Donald Jr. and Agnes Marie. She entered politics as a . She was a member of the  for eight years and a member of the  for ten.\n\nShe was elected as Borough President of Queens in November 2001, to succeed the term-limited . As Borough President, Marshall made marketing Queens as a  one of her priorities. In 2005, she won a second term, defeating her Republican/Conservative challenger  with 75% of the vote to his 25%. She was inaugurated to her second term as President of the Borough of Queens on January 3, 2006, in a ceremony held at  in . Marshall outlined her plans for the next four years including health care, education, housing and new park projects. In November 2009, Marshall was re-elected to a third term.\n\nIn 2017, P.S. 330 was renamed the Helen M. Marshall School to honor her legacy.\n\n\nMarshall died on March 4, 2017, at her home in , aged 87. A widow, she was survived by her two children.\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
