    "pages": }\n\n'''Hiram Monserrate''' (born July 12, 1967) is an American politician who served in the  from 2009 until his expulsion in 2010. A , he previously served on the  from 2002 through 2008.\n\n\n\nMonserrate served on the  from 2002 to 2008, representing  in .\n\nIn June 2003, Mayor  announced an  allowing city employees to report  to federal authorities. Monserrate, then chairing the Council's Black, Latino and Asian Caucus, argued that this order would worsen relations between immigrant communities and the police. He responded by sponsoring a bill entitled \"Access Without Fear\", which would have forbidden city officials from revealing such information except as required by law. He joined director  in publicizing the immigration film '''' to raise awareness of the issue.\n\nIn late 2008, Monserrate opposed Mayor Bloomberg's planned use of  in the $4 billion  Redevelopment project in Queens. The long-term project aimed to clear the  industrial area, clear up pollution, and develop a hotel and convention center. However, it was initially opposed by a majority of the existing business owners. Monserrate changed his mind and supported the development after being assured that one-third of the housing would be \"affordable\" and that the city would offer businesses an opportunity to relocate. He told reporters the compromise showed that government \"can be fair and still do good economic development\".\n\n\nMonserrate supported the , a project co-founded by  to deliver the so-called  (an unproven \"detoxification\" procedure created by  as part of ) to rescue workers affected by the . Monserrate went through the program himself, and drafted official proclamations honoring both Cruise and Hubbard. He also attended a fund-raising dinner in New York for the project, as well as an event at the Scientology Celebrity Centre in Los Angeles. Monserrate dismissed medical authorities' criticism of the Purification Rundown, saying, \"This is the same type of thing they said about  twenty years ago.\"\n\n\nIn 2006, Monserrate ran for New York State Senate against fellow Democrat , a 16-year incumbent. Monserrate came within 200 votes of pulling off an upset in one of the closest races in Queens.\n\nIn 2008, he again ran for the State Senate with the support of organized labor. Sabini withdrew from the race following his appointment to chair the . Monserrate then ran unopposed and on November 4, 2008, was elected the New York State Senator for the 13th district.\n\nOn June 8, 2009, Monserrate and  (D-Bronx) joined Senate Republicans in an attempted parliamentary coup for the purpose of shifting control of the Senate to the Republicans; Monserrate, Espada, and all 30 Senate Republicans voted, 32-30, to replace Senate Majority Leader  with then-Senate Republican Leader  and install Espada as Temporary President of the Senate. This action resulted in the . A week later, Senate Democrats appointed Senator  as their leader. On the same day, Monserrate rejoined the Democratic caucus, leaving the Senate in a 31-31 deadlock. With the office of  vacant due to 's resignation, the tie could not be resolved, and the resulting  continued until July 9, when Espada rejoined the Democrats.\n\nOn December 2, 2009, Monserrate voted against legislation , which failed to pass the Senate.\n\n\nA bipartisan nine-member committee recommended disciplinary action against Monserrate following his 2009  domestic violence assault conviction. If Monserrate had been convicted of the  charges against him, he would have been automatically expelled from the Senate. Politicians of both parties at the national, state, and local level called for him to resign or be expelled from the State Senate.  The committee's report was released on January 14, 2010 and recommended that the full Senate expel or censure Monserrate.\n\nOn February 9, 2010, the State Senate voted to expel Monserrate. The vote was 53 to 8, with one senator not present.  In response, Monserrate sued the State Senate in federal court. Monserrate lost his case on the District Court level and in the Second Circuit Court of Appeals.\n\n\n\nThe Queens Democratic Party withdrew its support for Monserrate's 2010 re-election bid on October 29, 2009. The party leadership supported Assemblyman  for the State Senate. Following Monserrate's expulsion from the Senate,   called for a  in the 13th Senate District to be held on March 16, 2010. Peralta won the special election, outpolling Monserrate 65 percent to 27 percent.\n\n\nMonserrate filed petitions with the Board of Elections to be entered in the Democratic primary to fill the 39th Assembly District seat (-) vacated by Jose Peralta following his election to the State Senate. The Queens County Democratic Party endorsed community activist  for the seat.  On September 14, 2010, Moya defeated Monserrate in the Democratic primary, 2,711 votes to 1,358 votes.\n\n\nIn June 2016, following his release from federal prison for mail fraud and mail fraud conspiracy, Monserrate attempted his third political comeback by seeking the unpaid elected position of Democratic  for the 35th District in  and . Monserrate ran against Democratic incumbent and community volunteer George R. Dixon. Despite having struggled to meet court-ordered financial obligations, Monserrate opened a campaign office and hired paid staffers. On September 13, 2016, Monserrate lost his bid for district leader by 57 votes.\n\n\nIn 2017, Monserrate ran for New York City Council in District 21. He was defeated by Francisco Moya in the Democratic primary, 55%-44%.\n\n\nIn 2018, Monserrate again sought a district leader post in Queens. On September 13, 2018, he prevailed.\n\n\nIn November 2019, Monserrate filed to run for New York State Assembly in District 35 in 2020 against incumbent Assemblymember . Monserrate lost to Aubry in the Democratic primary, 65-35%.\n\n\nIn February 2021, the New York City Council passed a local law by a 44-1 vote, barring former lawmakers from running for municipal office if they have been convicted of corruption. The law was reportedly targeted at Monserrate, who had announced his intent to again run against Moya and other candidates in the Democratic primary for his former seat on the New York City Council and was collecting campaign donations. Monserrate filed his nominating petition signatures the following month, but was blocked from receiving matching campaign funds by the city's Campaign Finance Board and from appearing on the ballot by the New York City Board of Elections. Monserrate filed a federal lawsuit, claiming that the law did not bar him from receiving matching donations and contending that keeping him off the ballot was unconstitutional.\n\n'''2022 New York State Assembly candidacy'''\n\nMonserrate again filed to run for New York State Assembly in District 35 against incumbent Assemblymember . Monserrate lost to Aubry in the Democratic primary, 61-38%.\n\n\n\n\nMonserrate was arrested on December 19, 2008 and accused of slashing Karla Giraldo, his girlfriend, in the face with a broken drinking glass during an argument in his Jackson Heights apartment. He was  the same day and pleaded not guilty to the charges of second-degree , a  that carried a maximum sentence of seven years in prison, and fourth-degree criminal possession of a weapon.\n\nGiraldo initially made statements to hospital staff and the police that led to Monserrate's arrest. However, Giraldo later changed her account to match that of Monserrate, stated that the cuts on her face near her left eye from a broken glass were an accident, and added that she was no longer cooperating with the investigation. Sources discussed evidence with the media, including video surveillance that supported the charges of assault and the attempt to cover it up.\n\n\nOn March 23, 2009, a Queens  indicted Monserrate on three counts of felony assault on Giraldo and three counts of misdemeanor assault. Monserrate denied the charges, saying \"Listen, the reality is that from the very beginning I have said this was an accident. My girlfriend said it's an accident. This is an accident and we look forward to the dismissal of all these charges based on the truth.\"\n\nThe case proceeded to trial, and Monserrate waived his right to a jury on September 18, 2009.  As his trial started, security camera footage from Monserrate's apartment building was entered into evidence and made public. The footage showed Giraldo girlfriend screaming and clutching at doorways as Monserrate forced her out of the building. Giraldo testified in Monserrate's defense.\n\n\nOn October 15, 2009, Monserrate was acquitted of the second-degree assault felony counts, but convicted on a third-degree assault misdemeanor count which carried a maximum sentence of one year in prison. On December 4, 2009, Monserrate was sentenced to three years' probation, 250 hours of community service, a $1,000 fine, and one year of domestic abuse counseling.  He sought to vacate an order of protection preventing him from contact with Giraldo, but it was not vacated. \n\nIn an appearance before the sentencing judge, William Erlbaum, on July 7, 2010, Monserrate again petitioned to have a court order prohibiting him from contact with Giraldo vacated. The petition was granted, and according to the ''New York Post'', Monserrate and Giraldo kissed and held hands. The pair later ended their relationship.\n\n\n\nIn October 2010, Monserrate was indicted on federal corruption charges which alleged that, as a sitting member of the City Council, he had used staff members of a nonprofit organizationthe Latino Initiative for Better Resources and Empowermentto perform tasks related to his unsuccessful 2006 State Senate campaign. In 2006 and 2007, then-Councilmember Monserrate allocated $300,000 in discretionary city funding to LIBRE, and the indictment charged that approximately one-third of that funding went toward paying LIBRE staff for their campaign-related work.  After the court proceeding, he was freed after posting a $500,000 bond, secured by a home belonging to his parents. Millions of dollars in so-called discretionary member items had been allocated by members of the City Council to non-profit groups with ties to the members.  The investigation of Monserrate was part of a broad federal investigation to determine if these funds had been used for the members' personal or political expenses.\n\nMonserrate was assigned a court-appointed attorney. In May 2012, Monserrate pleaded guilty to charges of  and mail fraud conspiracy. In December 2012, he was sentenced to serve two years in prison.\n\nIn 2015, the U.S. Department of Probation informed Monserrate's judge that he had failed to make timely restitution payments.\n\nMonserrate served 21 months in federal prison.\n\n\n\n*\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n*  (shortly after the previous link was added to this Wikipedia article, the  and others noted this dormant site was still accepting comments, most of which were highly critical of Monserrate)\n*  Panel on illegal immigration, including Monserrate and his City Council colleague, Dennis Gallagher.\n* .     "pages": }\n| birth_place         = \n| death_date          = \n| death_place         = \n| party               = \n| education           =  () ()\n| website             = \n| module              = \n}}\n'''Sandra Ung''' (, born September 9, 1974) is an American attorney and politician from . She is a member of the  for the , which is based in , .\n\n\nUng was born in  to ethnically  parents. Her family fled to  soon after she was born to escape the , and immigrated to the  when Ung was seven years old.\n\nAfter growing up in , , Ung attended  for her undergraduate degree, and went on to receive her  from  in 2001.\n\n\nPrior to seeking elected office, Ung held a number of jobs in and around New York politics, among them  to Assemblyman (and father to ) , legislative assistant to   and , and most recently special assistant to Congresswoman Meng. She has also worked as a practicing attorney at the firm .\n\n\nIn July 2020, Ung announced she would run as a  for the  of the , held by term-limited incumbent , in . She received influential endorsements from the Queens Democratic Party and Congresswoman Meng, and was among the top fundraisers in City Council races across the city, cementing her as the race's frontrunner.\n\nIn an effort to overcome Ung's advantages, seven of her opponents in the race formed a coalition together in May 2021, with each candidate encouraging their voters to rank other non-Ung candidates on their  ballots. The seven ran on significantly different platforms–among them were John Choe, the race's most left-wing candidate, and Neng Wang, its most conservative–but argued that they were united against the Queens Democratic Party's influence.\n\nUng nevertheless emerged with a lead on election night in June, receiving 24 percent of first-choice votes. When s and ranked-choice votes were counted two weeks later, she defeated former Assemblywoman  55-45%; she formally declared victory on July 7. Ung easily won the November  in the strongly Democratic district.\n\n\nInaugurated in January, 2022, Ung was named as the Chair of the Committee on Government Operations for her first term in the City Council. The Committee has jurisdiction over Federal and State legislation (including Home Rule requests), municipal governmental structure and organization, and includes several important city agencies including New York City's Department of Citywide Administrative Services, Office of Administrative Trials and Hearings, Board of Elections, Board of Standards and Appeals, Campaign Finance Board, Commission on Public Information and Communication, Community Boards, Department of Records and Information Services, Financial Services Agency, and the Law Department.\n\nAs Chair, Ung held several oversight hearings on the city's elections, including on public campaign financing of elections. Ung also held hearings on New York City's Civic Engagement Commission and on NYC's Community Boards.\n\nIn her first term, Ung introduced 29 bills and resolutions, 12 of which passed during the City Council's 2022-2023 term. Ung's bills included a bill requiring the Board of Elections to redesign ballots to make it more clear for speakers of a language other than English, two bills that improved the 311 call experience for LEP (Limited English Proficiency) New Yorkers and a bill requiring the Department of Transportation to report on potential locations for the construction of a bus transit center in Flushing. Ung also passed several resolutions, including one calling for Lunar New Year to be made a federal holiday and one calling on the New York State Legislature to expand financial relief programs to assist New Yorkers struggling to pay their utility bills.\n\nIn her 2024 term, Ung was appointed to be the Chair of the Committee on Standards and Ethics. Ung was also appointed to the Leadership team of the Council, which works with the Council Speaker to steer the legislative body's priorities, and the Budget Negotiations Team, which negotiates the city's budget with the mayoral administration.\n\n\nUng lives in  where she is the primary caretaker for her mother. Ung is a marathon runner, having completed the New York City marathon.\n\n\nIn 2022, home healthcare workers organized a protest outside of Sandra Ung's City Council district office demanding that she support city legislation (called The No More 24 Act) limiting the number of hours that home healthcare aides can work in a day. They want their employers to limit their work schedule to 12 hours a day and 50 hours a week. Many of these workers provide care for 24 consecutive hours. This protest was organized by the Flushing Workers Center. The City Council Speaker's office said that the legislative efforts on the City Council level were misdirected because home health care is funded primarily through Medicaid, which is managed at the state level. Council Member Ung wants the non-profit employers to hire more home healthcare workers and wants the State of New York make adjustments to the Medicare reimbursement policy so that patients who need attentive care are not left unattended. Council Member Ung called the current system unjust and held a rally with SEIU 1199 homecare workers, union representatives and disability activists calling on the state government end 24-hour shifts and provide funding to split them into two, 12-hour shifts.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Stanley M. \"Stan\" Makowski''' (April 22, 1923 – August 5, 1981) was  of the City of , serving 1974–1977.\n\n\nHe was born in Buffalo on April 22, 1923, as the younger of two children of . He dropped out of  and served six months with the . In 1943, he joined the Army and served three years during , including an eight-month tour on . After the war, he earned his high school diploma and attended , where he received a certificate from the , and night school at .\n\n\nIn 1959, he accepted appointment to the at-large seat on the Common Council, when  was elected to Congress. In 1969, Makowski ran as the  candidate for  executive; he was defeated in the general election by . In 1972, the Common Council created the post of deputy mayor and Makowski was the first appointed, serving under Mayor . Upon Mayor Sedita's resignation of March 5, 1973, Makowski became mayor. He was elected as mayor on November 6, 1973. During his term, the Buffalo Convention Center was constructed, as was the . On January 28, 1977, a most  struck Buffalo and Western New York. He served just one term as mayor (in addition to the final 10 months of Mayor Sedita's 3rd term).\n\n\nHe married Florence Ziolo on August 7, 1954. He died on August 5, 1981, and was buried in St. Stanislaus Cemetery in .\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Barbara S. Lifton''' (born November 26, 1950) is a former  member of the  representing Assembly District 125, which includes  in its entirety, as well as the City of  and towns of  and  in .\n\nShe attended , receiving a  in English a teacher certification in 1973, and an  in English in 1985. Lifton was an English teacher in the  Central School from 1976 to 1982, then in the  public school system from 1985 to 1988. For fourteen years before entering the Assembly she served as the Chief of Staff to former Assemblyman . She also served for two years on the /Community Waste Management Committee.\n\nLifton was first elected to the State Assembly in November 2002. She ran uncontested in the November 2008  and won the November 2010 general election with 62 percent of the vote.\n\nFellow assemblyman , the chairman of the Monroe County Democratic Party, attempted to recruit Lifton, among other candidates, in an effort to run against Republican  for the  formerly held by , who resigned in disgrace from the United States Congress, although Lifton lived outside the boundaries of that district. She had stated that she considered the overture, as she had long wanted to have a say in global issues, but ultimately chose not to run.  She continued in the state Assembly until announcing she would not seek re-election in 2020.\n\nLifton resides in . She has two children and five grandchildren.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n*\n* \n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Kevin Parker''' (born March 6, 1967) is an American politician from the state of . He is a member of the  representing the , which comprises portions of the  neighborhoods of , , , , , , and . A , Parker was first elected to the Senate in 2002.\n\nHe ran unsuccessfully in 2001 in the  Democratic primary and in 2021 for  in the Democratic primary. Parker is also known for his angry outbursts, some of which have been violent. In 2010, he was convicted by a jury of two counts of  for attacking a '''' photographer, damaging their camera and car door, and breaking their finger.\n\nHe is now simultaneously running in the  and the .\n\n\nParker is the son of Sonie and Georgie Parker. He attended P.S. 193, Andries Hudde I.S. 240, and  in Brooklyn. Parker received a  degree in Public Service from .\n\nPrior to serving in elected office, Parker held a number of different public sector roles, including intergovernmental aide to New York State  H.  and New York City Urban Fellow under Manhattan  and mayoral candidate .\n\nIn 2001, Parker ran unsuccessfully in the  Democratic primary, coming in fifth with 14.95% of the vote.\n\n\n\n\nIn 2002, Parker defeated former City Councilman  in a tightly-contested Democratic primary for a newly drawn, open State Senate seat in Brooklyn. He won the 2002 general election and was elected to the Senate for the first time.\n\nIn the 2008 Democratic primary, Parker held off a strong challenge from New York City Councilmembers  and Kendall Stewart. He won the primary with less than 50% of the vote. In 2008, the district was about 60% black, 22% white, and 10% Hispanic. In 2012, Parker's district was redrawn, and remained a majority  district.\n\n\nOn June 24, 2011, the State Senate passed the .Nicholas Confessore and Michael Barbaro (June 24, 2011).   ''The New York Times'', accessed June 25, 2011 Parker voted in favor of the legislation, which was signed into law that evening. However, he stormed to the podium where Lieutenant Gov.  was presiding and then left the Senate floor in protest because he was not allowed to speak on the bill. According to Parker, Senate Democrats had previously been informed that each Senator would have two minutes to explain his or her vote. Parker added that the doors to the Senate chamber were locked on the evening of June 24 to prevent senators from leaving the chamber when the bill was voted upon.\n\nAfter Democrats won the Senate majority in the 2018 elections, Parker was named Chair of the Committee on Energy and Telecommunications. As of March 2019, Parker served as . The State Senate passed the  in 2019, with Parker voting in favor of the bill; then-Governor  signed the bill into law. In May 2019, the State Senate passed a Parker-sponsored bill that would ban undetectable firearms.\n\nA Parker-sponsored bill that barred utility companies from shutting off customers' service during the  and other states of emergency was signed into law on June 17, 2020. On October 14, 2020, a Parker-sponsored bill recognizing  (June 19) as an official  was enacted, commemorating the day when the news of liberation came to Texas more than two years after President ’s  went into effect. Also in 2020, he sponsored a bill that would have recognized racism as a public health crisis.\n\nIn 2021, Parker re-introduced legislation to require members of the  to live in the five boroughs.\n\n\n\n\nParker announced his candidacy in the . He ran in the Democratic primary against (among others) NYS Senator , entrepreneur and former US Marine , NYC Council member , and NYS Assemblymember . Through January 15, 2021, he was fifth in fundraising among all candidates, behind Lander, Iscol, Benjamin, and Weprin. He had raised approximately $122,000  and finished sixth in the Democratic primary, which was won by Lander.\n\n\nParker is notable for what '''' referred to in 2019 as his \"long history of making explosive remarks and getting involved in scuffles\".\n\n\nIn 2004, businessman and politician Wellington Sharpe, who once ran against Parker, said that Parker had assaulted him in an argument. Sharpe did not file any charges. Parker defeated Sharpe in the 2004 election.\n\nIn January 2005, Parker was arrested, taken to the 67th Precinct station, and charged with third degree  for punching a New York City traffic agent in the face after Parker saw the traffic agent writing his car a  for . The charges were dropped as part of a  after he agreed to take  classes.\n\nIn 2005, a female staffer alleged that Parker had hit and shoved her while she was working for him as an office manager. She further alleged that after she made these accusations public, Parker had threatened her at a restaurant.\n\nA 32-year-old female special assistant to Parker filed charges with the police at the 70th Precinct against him in 2008. She alleged that he pushed her during an argument, choked her, knocked her eyeglasses off her face, and then intentionally smashed her glasses by stomping on them.\n\n\nParker was convicted of misdemeanor charges of criminal mischief in 2010. On May 8, 2009, he was arrested and charged with  , assault, and menacing in Brooklyn for chasing and attacking a '''' photographer, damaging the photographer's camera and car door, and breaking his finger.  Parker was taken to the 67th Police Precinct station, booked, charged with a felony due to the value of damage to the camera and car door, and released without . As a result, he was stripped of his leadership positions as  and chair of the Energy Committee, and payment of his $22,000 leadership stipend was suspended. Parker was convicted by a jury of two misdemeanor charges of criminal mischief on December 6, 2010. On March 21, 2011, Parker was sentenced to three years' , fined $1,000, and ordered to pay compensation to the newspaper. He was ordered again to attend  classes; the judge also issued an  against Parker on behalf of the photographer. Meanwhile, Parker told reporters: \"I don't think I have an anger issue.\"\n\nParker was restrained by colleagues during a profane tirade against Senator  in February 2010, in which he referred to her as a \"bitch\". He then offered to fight her boyfriend, Senator , who intervened.\n\nIn April 2010, Parker launched into a tirade while white colleague,  Senator  of , was questioning a Black nominee for the  at a confirmation hearing. He objected to DeFrancisco's questions and asserted that he had never seen a white nominee treated in similar fashion. \"Amid the nearly two-minute tirade, committee chairman  told Parker he would be removed from the hearing room if he didn't settle down\". Parker responded: \"Well, you better bring people\". During the tirade, Parker accused his colleagues of . He followed up in a radio interview by accusing DeFrancisco and Parker's Republican \"enemies\" of being s, but later apologized for the \"white supremacists\" accusation. His fellow Democrat, then-Senator , himself a member of a racial minority group, opined that Parker \"needs help\". '''' , writing that Parker was \"known as the man with frightening rages that could erupt at any time and on almost any subject,\" opined that \"Mr. Parker should be d, and voters in central Brooklyn should start recruiting a qualified replacement.\"\n\nIn December 2018, a car bearing Parker's official Senate parking placard was parked illegally in a New York City , blocking bicycle traffic. When questioned by a female staffer about the vehicle on , Parker replied, \"Kill yourself!\" Incoming Senate Majority Leader  expressed her \"disappointment\" at Parker's action, and then-lieutenant governor  said it was \"wildly inappropriate\". Parker said: \"I don't know why this is a temper issue. Did I touch her?\" He also said: \"I’m sure people in my district don’t care.\" As of January 27, 2019, no formal disciplinary action had been taken against him in regard to the \"Kill yourself!\" tweet.\n\nIn an April 2019 closed-door meeting of Senate Democrats, an argument between Parker and then-freshman senator  occurred. Parker reportedly \"ripped off his tie and threw it down in a rage\".\n\nIn November 2023, Parker was sued by a woman accusing him of raping her in 2004 during his first term in office.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n* Official website.\n*\n* , ''Courier Life Newspapers''.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n \n'''Erik Martin Dilan''' (born May 11, 1974) is an American politician. A , Dilan represents the 54th district of the  which comprises the  neighborhoods of , , , , and . Formerly, he represented the  of the  from 2002 to 2014.\n\n\nDilan graduated from , , and . He later graduated from , earning an  in .\n\nHe was a member of .\n\n\n\n\nIn 2001, incumbent Democrat NYC Councilman (and Dilan's father)  of the  decided to retire in order to run for the . Dilan decided to run for his father's seat. He won the Democratic primary with a plurality of 33% of the vote. In the general election, Dilan won the seat with 87% and defeated three third party candidates. In 2003, he was challenged in the Democratic primary by just one candidate, State Senator , and defeated her 65%–35%. He won re-election to second term with 92% of the vote. In 2005, he was unopposed in the primary and won re-election to a third term with 84% of the vote. In 2007, he wasn't challenged at all to win a fourth term. In 2009, won re-election to a fifth term with 87% of the vote.\n\n\nHe was chair of the Council's Housing & Buildings Committee, while also serving on the Rules, Privileges & Elections, Zoning & Franchises, and Rules committees.  While there, he refused to allow a bill to count all vacant properties in the city out of committee.  This was met with a sleep-out outside his office by activists with \n\nHe illegally acquired an \"affordable housing\" unit for which he exceeded the allowable income to qualify because of his connections in the real estate industry.  He was punished with a $9,000 fine in January 2015.\n\n\n\nAfter redistricting, he decided to challenge incumbent Democratic U.S. Congresswoman  (D-) for . He said \"We've had an incumbent who has been there for 20 years and she's done little with the post. She's going to have to justify after 20 years of nothing, why she should remain in office.\" Dilan took second place in the Democratic primary with 35% of the vote.\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n|signature=Stefani Zinerman Signature.png\n| website             = \n| residence           = , , \n}}\n\n'''Stefani Zinerman''' is an  politician. A member of the , she currently represents district 56, which includes  and  in , in the . Assembly Member Directory  New York State Assembly |url=https://www.nyassembly.gov/mem/Stefani-Zinerman/bio/ |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210326133204/https://www.nyassembly.gov/mem/Stefani-Zinerman/bio/ |archive-date=26 March 2021 |access-date=2021-03-26 |website=www.nyassembly.gov}}\n\n\nZinerman grew up in  in  . Her parents were from Bedford-Stuyvesant, and lived in  until they were able to move to Gowanus through the . She credits her parents for encouraging her interest in politics.\n\nZinerman studied  at the . She worked in the banking industry and beverage distribution, and later was senior manager for a New York City  program.\n\nZinerman also served as a pastor and was involved in community organizations including the Brooklyn  and Age-Friendly, a program she chaired that helps local leaders improve their communities for the elderly.\n\n\n\n\nZinerman entered local politics after New York City Mayor  defunded the Begin Education/Employment Gain Independence Now (BEGIN) program; she volunteered with the , becoming the Bedford-Stuyvesant neighborhood volunteer leader.\n\nZinerman served as 's petition and  starting in 2012 and became his  once he was elected. As a staffer, she focused on serving the  community of  and , being a member of the  with Cornegy, which worked on issues such as  and classifying the  as a .\n\n\nWhen  announced she would not be seeking reelection in the 56th Assembly District in order to instead run for , Zinerman announced her candidacy at the , with the support of Wright. After winning the Democratic primary, she ran unopposed in November 2020 to take the seat.\n\nZinerman is a member of the Black, Puerto Rican, Hispanic & Asian Legislative Caucus. Committees  New York State Assembly |url=https://nyassembly.gov/comm/?id=58&sec=mem |access-date=2021-03-26 |website=nyassembly.gov}}\n\nZinerman ran for the Assembly on a platform focusing on local concerns and constituent engagement, particularly  and education equity. She advocates for several community-based health initiatives, including for , , ,  care, more , and safe staffing standards for nurses. From the , she wants state aid for basic school funding. She advocates for lessened police contact and a  model with investment in education and social service programs, citing the  and the .\n\n\nIn 2024, Zinerman faced a primary challenge from  candidate, Eon Tyrell Huntley. The race was called \"one of the most closely contested state races this primary cycle\" and \"an existential fight for the political soul of Bed-Stuy Brooklyn\".\n\nA key issue in the race was housing, with Zinerman supporters saying that Huntley represented young, white,  and highlighting his address outside of the district. Zinerman's campaign spokesperson stated that Huntley: \"doesn’t have his hands in the sand with the rest of us. His hands aren’t in the mud because he doesn’t live in this district.\" Huntley said that Zinerman represents \"the real estate, charter school and Israel lobbies\" and that he would fight for voters to \"stay in their homes\". Additionally, Zinerman opposed  legislation, while Huntley supported it.\n\nZinerman was endorsed by  and . '''' reported that Zinerman received support from Solidarity PAC, a Pro-Israel group that \"resembles\" . s funded by  and real estate developers spent about half a million dollars in support of her campaign.\n\nOn May 17, the Huntley campaign filed a complaint with the  against Zinerman alleging campaign finance violations.\n\nZinerman won the primary race, receiving 479 more votes than Huntley.\n\n\n\n\n\n*  \n*  \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Brian Michael Higgins''' (born October 6, 1959) is an American former politician who was the  for , from 2005 until 2024. The district, numbered as the 27th district from 2005 to 2013 and as the 26th from 2013 to 2024, included  and , along with some surrounding urban and suburban areas. Higgins is a member of the , and of several congressional committees and caucuses. He was born and raised Buffalo, New York, before obtaining a bachelor's and master's from  and an MPA from .\n\n\nBrian Higgins was born on October 6, 1959, in . A native of , Higgins served on the  (city council) from 1988 to 1993, representing the South District.}} Higgins's grandparents were from .\n\nIn 1993, during his final year on the Council, Higgins was rated \"Buffalo's Best Lawmaker\" in a 1993 '''' Survey of Western New York business and community leaders.}} Responding to the survey were 158 business, community, and government leaders in Western New York. Higgins earned the highest rating of any political leader, with a 3.81 out of a possible score of 5. The ''Buffalo News'' wrote of Higgins: \"During his 5 1/2 years on the Council, he has earned a reputation as a thoughtful, soft-spoken lawmaker who has paid attention to both district and citywide concerns.\" One community leader said, \"Brian is a very bright, responsible public official\", while a government leader said of Higgins, \"The best Councilman in Buffalo. Has great vision.\"\n\nHiggins graduated from  with a BA in political science in 1984 and an MA in history in 1985. He received an  from 's  in 1996. Higgins has taught courses on state and local government, and the economic history of Buffalo and Western New York, in Buffalo State College's history and economics departments. He served as the 145th district representative to the  from 1999 to 2004.\n\n\n\n\n, a moderate  who had represented the heavily Democratic 27th since 1993, unexpectedly announced his retirement in 2004. In April 2004, Higgins entered the race, and narrowly defeated then- Comptroller . After the 2000 redistricting, the district was made slightly friendlier for Quinn (in part, by adding mostly rural ), but was still at the time the most Democratic district in the country represented by a Republican. Since Higgins's initial election, the district has since reverted to form, and Higgins was reelected without serious difficulty, never receiving less than 60% of the vote. He easily dispatched his 2008 and 2010 opponents even after they posted six-figure fundraising numbers. In 2006 and 2008, Higgins garnered more than 70% of the vote.\n\nFor his first four terms, Higgins represented the southern two-thirds of Buffalo, as well as Chautauqua County. After the 2010 census, his district was renumbered as the 26th, and a special master redrew it to be much more compact and Democratic. He picked up the rest of Buffalo, as well as several inner-ring suburbs that used to be in the territory of , while losing Chautauqua County to its traditional  district. He also picked up a large portion of , including all of  and 99% of .\n\nHiggins has received financial contributions for his campaigns from many business executives in Western New York throughout his tenure in Congress.Brian Higgins for congress, ''FindTheBest'', Summerland, CA: FindTheBest, 2014. In 2012, his reelection committee raised more than $1,000,000, with approximately 2/3 coming from individual donors, representing major businesses in Western New York.\n\n\nHiggins has positioned himself as a , although his voting record in the House has placed him close to the center of his party. In 1998, he ran for the Assembly on the Democratic and Conservative party lines, and in 2000 and 2004 he ran with both parties' endorsements, as well as that of the Working Families Party.\n\nHiggins describes himself as a pro- moderate who wants to spur job growth. He has said he supports allowing seniors to buy prescription drugs from , and one of his priorities in Congress is legislation allowing the government to negotiate for volume discounts on drugs. He has also said he wants Congress to repeal President 's tax cuts for the wealthiest individuals.\n\nHiggins procured $279 million over 50 years for 's various governments and agencies from the  as part of the Niagara Power Project 50-year relicensing agreement. He is an advocate for economic development and job creation, and played a pivotal role through his membership on the House's Transportation and Infrastructure Committee in securing approval for the construction of a new federal courthouse in downtown Buffalo.\n\nHiggins strongly advocates for increased federal funding for cancer research, as Buffalo is home to , the nation's first major medical facility devoted exclusively to treating cancer, with cancer research as its main mission.\n\nIn 2006, Higgins and Representatives  and  met with several government leaders in  and announced confirmation of the  (IRA) weapons decommissioning. Government leaders with whom the three met included Irish Foreign Minister , Secretary of State for Northern Ireland , US Ambassador to Ireland , US Ambassador to the United Kingdom , and the leadership of each of the main political parties involved in the process for peace.\n\n\n\nHiggins has also supported efforts for peace in  and , and the , including , , and .\n\nHiggins received an \"A+\" on the 2007 Congressional Scorecard on middle-class issues from the , which describes itself as \"providing the ideas that fuel the progressive movement.\"\n\nSeveral media outlets named Higgins as one of the leading candidates to succeed  in the  after she became  in an Obama administration. He was one of six candidates on New York Governor 's \"short list\" for the position; a  poll showed 75% of respondents on the station's website would support Higgins's nomination. In the end, Paterson appointed Representative . On January 31, 2009, Higgins led a delegation of Western New York elected leaders in welcoming Gillibrand to the region, moderating an economic roundtable discussion held at the Bioinformatics Center of Excellence, on the .\n\nIn December 2008, after only two terms in the House, Higgins secured a spot on the , considered one of the most important and powerful committees in Congress due to its wide jurisdiction. Higgins was subsequently appointed to serve on the Ways and Means Committee's subcommittee on Select Revenue Measures and its subcommittee on Oversight. After the GOP takeover of the House following the 2010 elections, Higgins left the Ways and Means Committee and became a member of the  and the . On the latter, Higgins quickly rose to the position of Ranking Member of the .\n\nOn February 2, 2024, Higgins resigned from Congress, having announced the plan three months prior on November 12. He cited his impatience with \"growing dysfunction\" in Congress as the reason.\n\n\n*''''''\n*''''''\n\n\n*Co-chair, member, House Cancer Caucus\n*Co-chair, Revitalizing Older Cities Task Force\n*Former co-chair, member, Great Lakes Task Force\n*Former co-chair, member, House Cancer Caucus\n*Former co-chair, Historic Preservation Caucus\n*Former co-chair, member, Northeast-Midwest Congressional Coalition\n*Former co-chair, Northern Border Caucus\n*Member, House Steel Caucus\n*Member, China Caucus\n*Member, Arts Caucus\n*\n*\n*\n*\n\n\nHiggins voted with President Joe Biden's stated position 100% of the time in the , according to a '''' analysis.\n\nSelf-described as an independent, Higgins is considered to be in the center of his party. He supports the strengthening of , and has been a proponent for a public option of health insurance. He further supports national and regional economic development. Higgins supports  rights. He has also supported efforts for peace in many areas of the world, and has been actively involved in the .\n\n\nOn a previous policy position from his website, Higgins said: \"For too long, the  has under-funded and under-staffed hearing offices in  ... Citizens who have contributed to the  system throughout their lives should have proper customer service when their benefits come due.\"\n\nIn 2010, Higgins and many other congressional members sent President  a letter, encouraging him to keep Social Security and make it stronger, saying: \"We write today to express our strong support for Social Security and our view that it should be strengthened. We oppose any cuts to Social Security benefits, including raising the retirement age. We also oppose any effort to privatize Social Security, in whole or in part ... Cutting Social Security benefits beyond the already scheduled increase in the retirement age from 65 to 67 would create even more needless hardship for millions of vulnerable Americans.\" This was in response to Obama giving the task of cutting government spending to the  on October 15, 2010. The letter also stressed that Social Security is \"prohibited by law from adding to the national budget deficit\".\n\nHiggins opposes privatizing Social Security. He \"support[s] full funding for the Social Security Administration to process checks on time; fight against waste, fraud, and abuse; and combat unacceptable claims backlogs\". His district includes nearly 150,000 senior citizens. Higgins introduced related legislation, House Resolution (HR) 3997, in February 2014. The bill aims requires the Social Security Commissioner to submit an estimated annual budget, and to submit the estimated budget to Congress before submitting it to the President; prohibits the closing or limitation of field offices and hearing offices without justification; and mandates particular procedures related to closings, consolidations, and/or public limitations.\n\n\nIn the  from 1999 to 2002, Higgins supported certain  measures, but since 2003, he has identified himself as . In 2006, Higgins was given a rating of 9% by the NRLC, which indicates a pro-choice stance. Higgins received a score of 100% (a perfect score) from  in 2012, and from  in 2011.\n\n\nHiggins voted for the , also known as \"ObamaCare\". In June 2012, Higgins said he believed that health care providers will have to embrace \"Accountable Care Organizations, comparative effectiveness research  which studies various treatments to determine what works best  and other changes\". He believed that this should have been done decades ago.\n\nOn his congressional website, Higgins has stated that \"there is no question that [the Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act] was needed\". He added that it is a beginning of health care reform in the United States.\n\nHiggins strongly believes in a national health care program, with a \"public option\", whereby the government provides health insurance that would compete with other businesses' plans. A letter Higgins signed from a group of representatives to Senator , then the Senate Majority Leader, stated: \"As the Senate continues to work on health reform legislation, we strongly urge you to consider including a public option.\" The  gave Higgins a perfect rating of 100% in 2009.\n\n\nIt was reported that Higgins was \"proposing something unprecedented in this era of $1.3 trillion annual deficits: a $1.25 trillion, five-year plan to rebuild the nation's roads, bridges, railroads, ports, and airports\".}} Higgins's website gives the cost of these endeavors as $1.2 trillion. The bill, the Nation Building Here at Home Act, based on research by the , would cost significantly more than Obama's $787 billion . Higgins said that he wants to rebuild the US, \"as we've rebuilt other countries  Iraq and Afghanistan  in recent years\". He also said that it is not a stimulus bill, but a \"nation-building bill\".\n\n\nHiggins is a supporter of education, including early education through higher education. He has said, \"Every child has a right to a quality education.\" Ensuring that young people have a quality early education, and that legislators are supportive of education for individuals in primary, elementary, secondary, and higher educational institutions, are among Higgins's aims. He is a proponent of congressional support for measures that increase student achievement, but that also reward success, rather than punish failure, as the No Child Left Behind Act has done. Higgins further believes that financial barriers to education should not hinder anyone from pursuing higher education.\n\n\nHiggins supports maintaining lower interest rates on loans incurred by college and university students. He co-sponsored two bills  H.R. 3826, and H.R. 4816  in efforts to extend the period of time in maintaining the reduced 3.4% interest rate on student loans. In 2007, Higgins supported The College Cost Reduction and Access Act, a bill passed into law that included the reduced 3.4% interest rate on subsidized Stafford student loans through the end of the 2012 academic year.\n\n\nIn 2023, Higgins was among 56 Democrats to vote in favor of H.Con.Res. 21, which directed President  to remove U.S. troops from  within 180 days.\n\n\nHiggins resides in . He has two adult children, John and Maeve.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* official U.S. House website\n*\n\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n|-\n\n|-\n\n\n''|years=}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Erik Bottcher''' (born May 9, 1979) is an  politician from . He is a  member of the  of the , which includes the neighborhoods of , , and .\n\n\nBottcher was raised in , a small town in the  located outside of . His parents owned and operated a fly fishing motel called, “The Hungry Trout.”\n\nAs an adolescent, Bottcher suffered from depression and struggled to come to terms with his sexual orientation. At the age of 15 and following a number of suicide attempts, he was admitted to Four Winds Hospital, a mental health facility in .\n\nAfter graduating from , Bottcher wrote an open letter to the school board sharing his experiences with bullying he endured at the school and why the district needed to do more to protect its students. Shortly thereafter, the school district added “Sexual Orientation” to its non-discrimination policy. These early experiences are often credited by Bottcher as the beginning of his political activism.\n\nHe received his  degree from .\n\n\nAfter college, Bottcher moved to  and held a number of jobs in various industries throughout his 20s, including a traffic coordinator at an advertising firm, a  in the packaging design department of , and as a  at the .\n\nBottcher began his formal politics work in 2009, when he joined the staff of the  as the body's  and  community liaison. At the Council, he worked on issues including , , , and the fight for  in .\n\nBottcher soon joined the governor's office as the LGBTQ liaison and in that role he assisted the successful 2011 effort to pass . In 2015, Bottcher re-entered city politics as chief of staff to Council member (and soon-to-be City Council Speaker) , where he remained until his own City Council campaign.\n\n\nIn February 2020, Bottcher announced he would run to succeed the term-limited Johnson for the  of the City Council in . Running with Johnson's support, Bottcher quickly became the district's frontrunner, raising more money than all but four other candidates across the city and accruing endorsements from nearly every major union and local elected official.\n\nDuring the campaign, Bottcher released an extensive policy platform to address the crisis of serious mental illness, New York City's sanitation concerns, and increasing employment opportunities for residents of public housing and those living in poverty.\n\nOn election night on June 22, Bottcher resoundingly led the field with 47 percent of first-choice votes, and declared victory that night; when absentee ballots and ranked-choice votes were counted two weeks later, Bottcher officially defeated runner-up Arthur Schwartz 71-29%. He faced no opposition in the November general election.\n\n\n\nOn December 17, Bottcher attended a  event that was targeted by about 20 anti-LGBT protestors. On December 19, two protestors associated with , were arrested for entering Bottcher's building and refusing to leave before eventually doing so. The protestors also defaced the sidewalk outside of his apartment with graffiti calling him a pedophile and using slurs such as \"\". The group also entered and vandalized his nearby office building. David Nieves, a leading member of Guardians of Divinity, was arrested for assaulting Bottcher's neighbor, a 52-year-old man who had been walking his dog, who he harassed, struck in the face causing him to bleed, and then pushed into a car.\n\nBottcher is a member of the Vote Blue Coalition, a progressive group and  created to support Democrats in New York, New Jersey, and Pennsylvania through voter outreach and mobilization efforts.\n\n\nBottcher lives in . He is , and has been open about his struggles with suicide when he was a closeted high schooler.\n\n\n* \n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Kenneth P. LaValle''' (born May 22, 1939 in ) is a former American politician. He represented  in the . The district comprises the five East End towns of , as well as the central and eastern portions of the Town of . A , LaValle was first elected in 1976. He was the longest-serving member of the Senate and has served more terms in office than any other current state senator in the United States.\n\n\nBorn in , LaValle graduated from . He received a B.S degree from  in 1961 and an M.S. in Education from the  (SUNY New Paltz) in 1964. He also received a  from the  in 1987. LaValle is an attorney; he was admitted to the New York bar in 1993.\n\nLaValle is the father of two grown children. He resides in , with his wife, Penny.\n\n\nLaValle first ran for the  in 1976 to succeed retiring Senator . He defeated Democratic nominee Barry McCoy, a physicist, winning 51% of the vote. Since then, he has faced very few serious challenges in his re-election campaigns.\n\nIn 2007, Gov. Eliot Spitzer appointed LaValle to the New York State Commission on Higher Education, which was charged with identifying ways of improving the quality of higher education in the State. LaValle also served on the National Council of State Legislatures’ Blue Ribbon Commission on Higher Education. He played a key role in the development of the School Tax Relief (STAR) program. He also authored the 1993 Pine Barrens Preservation Act.\n\nIn 2011, LaValle voted against allowing  in New York during roll-call for the , which legalized same-sex marriage in the state.\n\nThe  at  bears his name.\n\nOn January 10, 2020, LaValle announced that he would not seek re-election to the Senate in 2020. He was succeeded by , and his term ended on December 31, 2020.\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

Waldon became the first elected African-American member of Congress from .\n\nIn September 1986, Waldon ran for a full term, but was defeated in the Democratic primarythe real contest in this heavily Democratic, majority-black districtby . The original advertisement had included footage of the , and references to climate change.\n\n\nPatel describes himself as a \"practical and progressive\" Democrat. His platform for the 2022 US congressional election has included a  focus on reducing housing and transit regulation, along with support for rezoning initiatives. A self-described \"\", Patel supports the theory of  that encourages large-scale infrastructure and zoning reforms to address high housing costs. Patel has advocated for increased road safety standards and reforming street design.\n\nPatel is a proponent of “The Abundant Society” plan, a  policy targeted at reducing inflation through a combination of tariff reductions, suspending the  and , and expanding domestic manufacturing through passing federal spending bills like the .\n\nPatel has previously advocated for increased competition from challengers in congressional primary races. Patel supports .\n\n\nPatel was born in Mississippi to parents of  Indian origin, and grew up in Indianapolis. He speaks English and Gujarati.     "pages": }\n\n'''Shirley L. Huntley''' (born June 29, 1938) is an American politician who is formerly a , serving from 2007 to 2012. Huntley represented  in , which included , , , , , , , and . She pleaded guilty to mail fraud in 2013.\n\n\n\nHuntley was elected to Community School Board 28 in 1993 and served as its president until the dissolution of the School Board in 2004. She was appointed to the Community Education Council for District 28 in June 2004 and was elected as its president in July 2004.\n\nA , Huntley defeated then-State Senator  in a Democratic primary in 2006. She won the general election that year and took office in 2007.\n\nOn December 2, 2009, Huntley was one of eight Democratic state senators to vote against  legislation, which failed to pass the Senate. In June 2011, Huntley came out in support of gay marriage and voted for the .\n\n\n\nIn May 2011, the '''' revealed that Huntley was being investigated by the office of the state New York State Attorney General  for allegedly running a taxpayer-funded fraudulent charity.\n\nHuntley called an emergency press conference at her home in  on August 25, 2012. She revealed that she expected to be arrested on Monday August 27 in the state’s continuing investigation into the use of  grants by legislators. Huntley founded a nonprofit social service and education group that was investigated by the Attorney General Schneiderman, and she funded it in part with state grants. Huntley turned herself in to the Nassau County District Attorney's office in  at 7:45&nbsp;a.m. on August 27, 2012.\n\nOn January 30, 2013, Huntley appeared in federal court in Brooklyn and pleaded guilty to one count of conspiracy to commit  for embezzling $87,000 in state grant funding from the Parent Information Network, a  non-profit organization. Huntley later pleaded guilty in state court to a charge of falsifying evidence. She was sentenced to a year and a day in prison on the federal charge.\n\nIn May 2013, ''The New York Times'' reported that Huntley's \"secret recordings of some of New York’s most prominent politicians heightened concerns about widespread corruption in Albany\".\n\n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n* , official website\n* \n\n\n\t\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Benjamin J. Kallos''' (born February 5, 1981) is an American attorney and politician who represented the  of the  from 2014 to 2021, and now serves in the Executive Office of the President in the . He is a . The district includes , , ,  and the  of . Kallos is also a  who ran his office on , and has office hours at green markets.\n\n\nKallos was born in Florida. He attended . He then attended ,  as an undergraduate, and .\n\n\nKallos has served as a  public member and statewide coordination committee chair for the New York Democratic Lawyers Council from 2005 to 2013. He was also chief of staff for New York State Assemblymember  from 2007 to 2009, director of policy for then   in 2009, and executive director of New Roosevelt from 2010 to 2013.\n\n\nOn September 10, 2013, Kallos won the  for the 5th New York City Council District, receiving 46% of the vote to 's 39% and Ed Hartzog's 15%. He won the general election on November 5, 2013, and assumed office on January 1, 2014. On November 5, 2017, Kallos won reelection to another term with 81% of the vote.\n\nKallos has been ranked one of the best lawmakers on the New York City Council, with '''' giving him fifth place in 2017 and seventh in 2020. He was named one of the most powerful politicians in New York City in 2018, 2019, CSNY |url=https://www.cityandstateny.com/articles/special-list/power-100/2019-manhattan-power-100-66-100.html/ |access-date=2022-09-28 |archive-date=2019-07-16 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190716161142/https://www.cityandstateny.com/articles/special-list/power-100/2019-manhattan-power-100-66-100.html/ |url-status=bot: unknown }} and 2021.\n\nHe is well known as an advocate for student loans, affordable housing and government transparency, as well as for keeping \"big money\" out of government. In 2018, '''' named him as one of the \"Officials Who Call the Shots on Real Estate.\" Kallos was endorsed by the editorial board of '''', who praised his \"fresh ideas\", including proposals to forgive , incentivize the construction of more affordable housing, reform  and expand access to .\n\nHe chaired the Committee on Contracts and was a member of the committees on Education, Governmental Operations, Oversight and Investigations, and Women and Gender Equity.\n\nIn 2015, Kallos proposed legislation to allow low-income residents on the Upper East Side to automatically receive  and other government social safety benefits. In 2016, Kallos worked with  to release their Benefits Assist software as free and open-source software. Later that year, Kallos proposed legislation to get scaffolding down in a timely manner. He introduced a law in 2017 to lower the noise allowed from construction during the evenings and weekend.\n\nIn 2016, Kallos, who is an  attorney, authored legislation with Public Advocate  and Mayor  for the city to automatically enroll employees in individual retirement accounts at no cost to employers who did not offer a retirement plan themselves. The law passed in 2021 and was then extended statewide.\n\n\nIn 2014, Kallos refused $64,000 in additional income, and authored legislature to ban outside income and make the job of Council Member full-time. In 2016, Kallos wrote a law to make New York City's budget available online, which he worked with Mayor de Blasio to implement.\n\nOn March 22, 2018, Kallos authored the law that raised the cap on public funds received by participating candidates to establish a full public matching system that matches every small dollar donated by New York City residents at a rate of 8 to 1. The new public matching system worked to elect the first majority women City Council.\n\n\nIn 2015, Kallos worked with  and a whistle blower on an investigation that found 50,000 affordable apartments that were not registered by landlords who were receiving tax breaks, and might have been charging tenants too much rent. Kallos authored legislation to force landlords receiving tax benefits for affordable housing to register every unit and allow anyone to apply for them online. The law passed in 2017, requiring most landlords in New York City to register their affordable housing. In 2020, as part of the legislation, the city began to add back hundreds of thousands of existing affordable apartments and launched an affordable housing portal, Housing Connect.\n\nKallos has advocated against the construction of new luxury tower developments in New York City. In 2015, Kallos organized a community initiative to fight a proposed 950-foot \"supertower\" that would expand the neighborhood known as . In 2016, Kallos joined a grass roots rezoning effort to prevent the construction of more supertowers to protect existing affordable housing. This rezoning effort successfully halted the construction of another luxury skyscraper in 2017. Kallos led a rezoning that banned the use of mechanical voids as a loophole for luxury housing developments to exceed height limitations by \"give billionaires better views\".\n\nHe opposed legislation that would weaken the city's landmarks law in 2015. In 2017, Kallos authored laws to reform a zoning relief board and force developers to honor commitments for promised public spaces. In 2019, Kallos opened supportive housing for homeless women and children in the Upper East Side. He advocated for opening a new safe haven shelter in his district in 2021.\n\n\nKallos wrote legislature to force transparency around how the city determines need for school seats. As a result of these laws, the city agreed to add hundreds of new school seats to the neighborhood Kallos represents. He began advocating for free pre-kindergarten for all four-year-olds in 2014. After this proposal won, he advocated for the addition of 400 new pre-kindergarten seats for his district in 2018, which had not been granted enough seats. Kallos advocated for extending free pre-kindergarten to all three-year-olds, which had a citywide rollout in 2021.\n\nAs a public student, Kallos was too ashamed to stand on the free and reduced school lunch line and went hungry instead. He authored a law to mandate reporting on the number of meals served to students to help extend breakfast after the bell and free lunch to every public school student in 2015. In 2021, Kallos proposed offering free supper at every public school to end youth hunger.\n\nIn 2015, Kallos joined Letitia James in advocating for cable companies to offer low-cost high-speed Internet to low-income New Yorkers, as a way of bridging the . In 2017, Kallos and James won low-cost high-speed Internet for one million students on free and reduced lunch as well as seniors on . Kallos then proposed legislation to force landlords to offer basic internet as a utility.\n\n\nKallos authored a law to create the Offices of Food Policy and Urban Agriculture. Kallos passed a law in 2019 to require that only healthy drinks are offered with children's meals in New York City.\n\nIn 2019, Kallos authored a declaration of climate emergency and passed it making New York City the largest city in the United States to do so. In 2018, Kallos introduced legislation to ban the sale of plastic water bottles in city parks and purchase by city agencies that Mayor de Blasio implemented by executive order in 2020.\n\nHe authored the law to ban toxic pesticides from being used in New York City parks in 2021.\n\n\nKallos ran in the primary for the Democratic nomination in the , finishing fourth. In the first round, Kallos received 13% of votes, putting him in third place. He was eliminated in the sixth round of the ranked-choice voting process.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* \n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
          }
        ]
      }

    "pages": }\n\n'''James F. Brennan''' (born April 17, 1952) is an American . He is a former  member of the , representing the  ().\n\n\nBrennan was elected to the Assembly in 1984, from the 51st Assembly District, which included the neighborhoods of  and . In 1992, due to redistricting, Brennan’s district radically changed. He subsequently ran and defeated fellow incumbent  in the new 44th Assembly District, which includes the neighborhoods of , , Park Slope and .\n\nHe  chaired four s during his career: six years as Chair of the Assembly Standing Committee on Mental Health and Developmental Disabilities, one year as Chair of the Assembly Committee on Oversight, Analysis, and Investigation, and Chair of the Assembly Committee on Cities. He most recently was the Chair of the Committee on Corporations, Authorities and Commissions.\n\nBrennan has won three national s as a . The first, in 1996, was given by the  for Brennan’s leadership in the fight for parity in mental and physical health benefits. The second was given by the  in 2007, for an investigative report directed by Brennan as Chair of the Committee on Investigation. The report concerned how the  administration undermined services for the severely disabled as a result of the closure of a  office serving those clients in the fall of 2004.\n\nIn 1998 and 1999, Brennan helped win funding for 5,000 new units of housing for the mentally ill in . As Chair of the Cities Committee, Brennan authored two new laws in 2007, to improve  and safety in  and development in one cracking down on the filing of fraudulent building plans to the , and the other compelling the acquisition of  for excavations that might damage adjacent properties.\n\nBrennan also helped create the Restore New York program, a statewide effort to help distressed areas in cities by having the State pay to clear abandoned or vacant  or  with $300 million in funding.\n\nBrennan also authored the Expansion of the Real Property Partial Tax Exemption to low and moderate-income s in  and .\n\nHe is an , a graduate of  and .\n\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n*\n*\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Fernando James Ferrer''' (born April 30, 1950) is an American politician who was the  of  from 1987 to 2001. Ferrer was a candidate for  in 1997 and 2001 and was the  nominee for mayor in 2005, when he was defeated by . Ferrer served on the New York City Council in the 1980s and has served as chairman and vice chairman of the .\n\n\nFerrer grew up in the  section of the . He graduated from s in the Bronx: St. Anselm Elementary School and . Ferrer earned his  degree from the  of New York University and his  from .\n\n\n\nFerrer represented the former 13 City Council district in the Bronx from 1982 to 1987. Ferrer authored legislation requiring interpreters in city emergency rooms. Ferrer went on to chair the Health Committee, fight for anti-discrimination laws on behalf of gays and lesbians, and lead the fight for a  for the .\n\n\nFerrer was appointed Bronx Borough President as the result of incumbent 's resignation in connection with the . In 1987, Simon, aware that he had been under investigation and that charges against him were pending, resigned from his post. Ferrer began his 14-year tenure as Bronx borough president when the borough was a symbol of  and neglect. National attention led to a federal commitment to rebuild. During the Ferrer administration housing was created for about 66,000 families. The borough saw a significant drop in crime, particularly in the  neighborhood, and a steady rise in  and  .\n\n\n\n\nIn 1997, Ferrer launched a campaign for Mayor of New York. Trailing in the polls and under increased pressure from party insiders for a unified Democratic Party, he abruptly dropped out and endorsed the eventual Democratic nominee, Manhattan Borough President .\n\n\n\nIn the , Ferrer ran for the   for . He won the first  with 34%, but failed to win the necessary 40% to secure the nomination and ultimately lost a divisive  to  following the September 11th terrorist attack on the World Trade Center towers. Ferrer, who is of  descent, received a high level of support from  s but not from African-Americans.\n\n\n\nFerrer was the Democratic candidate for mayor in 2005.\n\nFerrer's campaign was hurt by remarks he made in March 2005 concerning the  shooting. Ferrer, who'd marched in protest against the shooting when it occurred and had gotten arrested, expressed his belief to the   that the incident was a \"tragedy,\" but \"not a crime.\"  He was strongly criticized by Diallo's family and others for these remarks, and he slid in popularity polls, especially among .\n\nFerrer prevailed in the primary election held on September 13, 2005. The first tally indicated that Ferrer garnered 39.95% of the final vote. He needed 40% to avoid a runoff, but , the second-place finisher, conceded, thus ensuring that Ferrer would advance to the general election. A final count indicated that Ferrer actually received 40.15% of the votes.\n\nPolitical analyst  summarized Ferrer's campaign as follows:\n:If anyone doubted the hapless nature of Ferrer's campaign they had only to watch his ads featuring the rotund Reverend Al Sharpton . In Fernando Ferrer's losing bid for mayor, that was about as innovative as things got.  The campaign was also plagued by revenue problems as the ads they wished to use were too long and hence too expensive and these \"salsa\" ads were done to save money but also to hopefully get the campaign some needed attention. Sadly, the focus became Al Sharpton and the others used in these ads rather than the message they tried to convey.\n\nFerrer's campaign was hurt when the ''New York Times'' and other big newspapers endorsed Mike Bloomberg. Also, Ferrer's campaign relied mainly on small contributions, compared to Bloomberg's $96 million from his personal billion dollar fortune.\n\nBloomberg defeated Ferrer, 58.4%-39.0%, on Election Day. Polls taken just days before had indicated that Ferrer would lose by between 30 and 35 percent.\n\n\n appointed Ferrer to run the MTA as interim Chairman on three separate occasions.\n\n\nAs of 2005, Ferrer resided in the  section of the Bronx.\n\n\n\n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''L. Dean Murray''' (born July 22, 1964) is an American politician and former  member of the , representing the assembly's third district from 2010 to 2013 and again from 2015 to 2019. The district includes portions of the town of , including  and  in  on . Dean Murray was recently elected to serve in the  after the 2022 elections. \t\n\t \t\nMurray had described himself as being the first  activist to be elected to office.\n\n\nMurray is a  native who graduated from the . He started his career by spending ten years in the radio and television news industry, during which he covered the  and served on the board of directors of the Pennsylvania Associated Press. He was later a regional sales manager and advertising sales representative for . Murray has been the owner of -based D & S Advertising Inc. since 1997.\n\nMurray resides in ; he previously lived in  for 15 years. He is divorced and has one son, Anthony.\n\n\nIn 2009, Murray ran for Suffolk County Legislature in Suffolk County's 7th Legislative District. He was defeated by incumbent .\n\nOn February 9, 2010, Murray won a special election, winning the New York State Assembly seat previously held by Assemblywoman . Murray defeated Lauren Thoden by 160 votes. Murray was re-elected in the 2010 general election. After serving one full term, he was defeated by Edward J. Hennessey, a Democrat, by 226 votes in the General Election on November 6, 2012.\n\nIn a re-match in 2014, it was revealed during the campaign that Dean Murray's campaign committee surreptitiously planted a GPS device on New York State Assemblyman Edward Hennessey's car and secretly tracked him for two months. A witness also testified that he personally performed surveillance on Hennessey's home and family, tracking cars and their movements in an effort to continuously ascertain Hennessey's whereabouts. Dean Murray used this information to file a petition to disprove Assemblyman Hennessey's residency and knock him off the ballot. The petition was dismissed by State Supreme Court Justice Arthur Pitt In a tight race, Murray defeated Hennessey by 526 votes. Murray was re-elected in 2016.\n\nIn 2018, Murray opted not to run for re–election. Instead, he ran for state senate, and was defeated by .\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Robert E. Cornegy Jr.''' (born September 24, 1965) is an American politician. He is a former  Member for the , representing  and northern  in .\n\nA , he was an unsuccessful candidate for  in 2021.\n\n\nCornegy is a native of New York City. He is the son of the late Dr. Robert E. Cornegy Sr., pastor of Mount Calvary Baptist Church in Bedford-Stuyvesant, and Ellen J. Cornegy, the First Lady of Mount Calvary Baptist Church.\n\nHe played center for Andrew Jackson High School and was recruited by both  and  before playing backup center for 's 1984-85  team. Cornegy would later graduate from  in , with a bachelor's degree in Organizational Management. He played professional basketball in both  and .\n\nFollowing his basketball career, he earned a master's degree in Organizational Management from Mercy College. He returned to Bedford-Stuyvesant and with an increased awareness of the mental health issues and drug use in the community became a Credentialed Alcoholism and Substance Abuse Counselor (CASAC). He later opened the Cornegy Residence treatment center for chemically dependent men in Bedford-Stuyvesant.\n\n\nIn 2009, Cornegy made his first run at the , but lost the primary election to incumbent . Four years later, he was elected to the same district after defeating Kirsten John Foy for the Democratic nomination in a close race. He won the general election easily on November 5, 2013.\n\nIn 2017, Cornegy was reelected to his Council seat. He is Chair of the Council's Committee on Housing and Buildings, Chair of the Minority- and Women-Owned Business Enterprise Task Force (M/WBEs), and a member of the Budget Negotiating Team (BNT). He is also a member of the Committees on Economic Development; Education; Finance; State & Federal Legislation; and Rules, Privileges, and Elections.\n\nIn 2017, Cornegy also ran to become the first black Speaker of the New York City Council and was named Democratic Conference Chair of the New York City Council in 2018.\n\n\nIn his first term, Cornegy was among the top 10 percent of sponsored legislation. Bills and initiatives of which he has led, sponsored or authored include:\n\n* A lactation bill, mandating there be dedicated rooms for nursing and breast-feeding mothers in public buildings throughout the five boroughs\n* The  Bill, calling for the Department of Corrections to provide vocational and educational programming, therapy and services to those detained or incarcerated on Rikers Island for longer than 10 days\n* Commercial tenant anti-harassment and neglect legislation, offering protection against criminal landlords by creating a private right of action for commercial tenants facing harassment, and allocating $3.6 million to cover the legal costs associated with fighting unscrupulous property owners\n* Senior Citizen Rent Increase Exemption (SCRIE) and the Disabled Rent Increase Exemption (DRIE), which is part of the Rent Freeze Program, an effort to increase affordable housing in NYC\n* Workforce Disclosure Bill that requires certain contractors working on city-funded projects to disclose records on the nature of their workforce, including the certification of the contractor as a minority-owned or women-owned business enterprise\n\nCornegy also sponsored the bill to co-name the block of Stuyvesant Avenue between Lexington Avenue and Quincy Street, \" Way\" after the iconic 1989 movie  directed and shot on that block. It was the first time a New York City street was named for a work of art, rather than a person or institution. Lee contributed to Cornegy's run for Brooklyn Borough President.\n\n\nIn 2012, Cornegy served as a delegate to  at the . That same year, he also became District Leader / State Committeeman for the 56th Assembly District and was part of the Taskforce to Combat Gun Violence, delivering recommendations to reduce gun violence in NYC to the NYC Council Speaker.\n\nIn 2013, he partnered with Attorney General  to invest $20 million in funding the Homeowner Protection Program (HOPP) and launch the Foreclosure Rescue Scam Protection Initiative.\n\nIn 2014, Cornegy developed the Chamber on the Go program in partnership with the Brooklyn Chamber of Commerce to provide mobile support services to small businesses.\n\nCornegy supported the establishment of The Age Friendly Neighborhood (AFN) Initiative to improve the quality of life of older adults through advocacy, programming and access to essential resources.\n\nWhile Chair of the Committee on Small Business, Cornegy co-led research on the state of the retail economy in NYC and delivered strategies to address retail challenges faced in underserved neighborhoods.\n\nCornegy was selected as a 2017-18 MIT CoLab  Community Fellow alongside other social justice leaders.\n\n\n\n\n\nCornegy and his wife, Michelle, have a blended family of six children and live in . A member of , he has been noted for his seven-foot frame and long locs that are wrapped into a bun.\n\nAt 6&nbsp;ft 10 in (2.08m), Cornegy was the tallest member of the . From March 2019 to October 2019, Cornegy was the  holder for the World's Tallest Politician, but this title has since been conferred upon  , who is just over one centimeter taller.\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n*\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
