    "pages": }\n'''Tali Farimah Farhadian Weinstein''' (born in 1975 or 1976), is an American attorney, professor, and politician. She is a former federal and state prosecutor and was a candidate in the . She is an announced nominee to serve as a  of the \n\nBorn in Iran to a Jewish family, Farhadian Weinstein came to the United States as a refugee in 1979. Her family became eligible for citizenship through President 's . After graduating from  and , she earned her  degree from . She then became a law clerk for Judge  at the  and then for Justice , during O'Connor's last two years at the .\n\nFarhadian Weinstein worked at the  from 2009 to 2017, first as counsel to , the  during the , and then as an  in the . She later served as  to   from 2018 to 2020. In 2021, Farhadian Weinstein was a candidate in the Democratic primary for . Since 2017, she has also taught at the  where she continues to serve as an adjunct professor. In late 2021, she became legal analyst for .\n\n\nA , Farhadian was born in , to Farah Farhadian, then a  and now a math teacher, and Nasser Dan Farhadian, a . Her paternal grandfather was a cloth peddler. She has a younger brother, Leeor.\n\nAfter fleeing  and the  in Iran, and spending 10 months in Israel (where her parents attended university), Farhadian arrived in the United States with her family at four years old on Christmas Eve in 1979.  She reminisced, while explaining her desire to help others have opportunity and safety in their lives: \"I know what it's like to be given an opportunity.\" The  (HIAS), a nonprofit devoted to helping refugees, which represented the family pro bono, helped them apply for asylum. The family then became eligible for US citizenship through President 's  policies.\n\nThe family lived first in , New York, and then in . She attended day school at the  and the . She studied in Israel in 1992 pursuant to a .\n\nIn 1997, Farhadian graduated from  where she majored in Humanities. She edited the ''Yale Women's '', a feminist interpretation of the Jewish  text. She wrote her senior essay on the Spanish Jewish poet and philosopher .  She received Yale's .\n\nAs a , she attended  in England where she earned a  in  ( Studies) in 1999, writing her thesis on the literature of  in Israel.\n\nShe then earned a  from  in 2003, where Farhadian received the . She passed the  in July 2003.\n\n\nAt the outset of her legal career, in 2003–04, Farhadian Weinstein was a law clerk to Judge  of the . New York State Bar Association. From 2004 to 2006, she clerked for  Justice . From 2006 to 2007, she was a litigation associate at  in New York City. From 2007 to 2008, she was an adjunct Professor of Law at .\n\nIn 2009, Farhadian Weinstein joined the . Through June 2010, she served with the Department as Counsel to the  , helping create guidelines on prosecutorial discretion on indictments and sentencing recommendations. Farhadian Weinstein joined the  in 2011 as an  in the , where she investigated and prosecuted s including s, , , and national security matters, serving through 2017.\n\nFrom 2018 to 2020, she was the  for  . During this period, she created a post-conviction justice bureau to reevaluate possible wrongful convictions in collaboration with the . Besides the post-conviction justice bureau, she oversaw the Brooklyn District Attorney office's appeals bureau, civil litigation bureau, and law enforcement accountability bureau. She has also been an adjunct professor at  since 2017.\n\nFarhadian Weinstein stepped down from her position at the Brooklyn District Attorney's office in July 2020 to become a candidate in the  primary for the  to replace  and oversee more than 500 lawyers in Manhattan. She and fellow candidate  were the top fundraisers in the race, which included $8.2 million of her own money. Farhadian Weinstein was the only candidate who had worked in a New York City 's office and been a . An April 21, 2021, poll by Benenson Strategy Group found her leading with 16% of those polled. She was endorsed by the '''' and the ''''. She was also endorsed by former attorney general Eric Holder, , and , as well as Representatives , , and . She was also endorsed by New York City branch of the  and  who co-founded the .\n\nFarhadian Weinstein had the most votes in several neighborhoods including ,  and . She earned 30.7% of the total vote, second to Bragg's 34.3%, in a primary with eight candidates. On July 2, 2021, Farhadian Weinstein conceded the primary to Bragg. In late 2021, she became legal analyst for .\n\n\n\nOn November 8, 2024, President  announced his intent to nominate Farhadian Weinstein to serve as a  of the .   President Biden will nominate Farhadian Weinstein to the seat being vacated by Judge , who will assume  on December 31, 2024.\n\n\nFarhadian Weinstein views as priorities:  (which she would seek to stem by addressing  and s) and  (such as  and ). During the 2021 campaign, she proposed creating a new Bureau of Gender-Based Violence, composed of a Sex Crimes Unit and a Domestic Violence Unit, in the district attorney's office. Other top priorities of hers are: ensuring fairness in the legal system, protecting immigrants, addressing traffic violence, and preventing s. She supports giving judges discretion to jail defendants who they believe pose a danger and supports abolishing cash  entirely.\n\nFarhadian Weinstein does not support , calling the phrase \"inflammatory\". At a forum with the eight candidates for the Manhattan DA's office, she was one of only two who said they would not \"defund the police,\" something that the DA's office has no authority over. She has indicated support for police reform. She was in favor of the repeal of a rule that kept personnel files for police officers confidential. This rule was repealed in 2020 by the .\n\n\nFarhadian Weinstein was appointed to the board of trustees of the  in May 2018 and serves on the board of directors of . She previously served on the Reform Leadership Council of the .\n\n\nIn November 2010, Farhadian married hedge-fund manager , whom she had met while attending a book party at the , at the  in Manhattan. In 2012, they purchased a $25.5 million property on Manhattan's , from the estate of . In May 2020, they gave $2 million to s helping  victims. The couple have three daughters.\n\n\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Brooke Mackenzie Ellison''' (October 20, 1978 – February 4, 2024) was an American academic, disability advocate, and the first quadriplegic to graduate from .\n\n\nEllison was born in , on October 20, 1978, to Edward and Jean (née Derenze) Ellison. On September 4, 1990, at age 11, she was hit by a car while walking home from school, resulting in  from the neck down. Although her injuries left her completely dependent on other people, she graduated from  in 1996 with high honors, and was accepted to Harvard. She graduated '''' from Harvard with a bachelor of science in  in 2000 and a master's degree in public policy from Harvard's , making her the first  to graduate from Harvard. In 2014,  awarded Ellison an honorary doctorate in humane letters. She completed her Ph.D. in 2012 from .\n\nIn 2002, Ellison's memoir ''Miracles Happen: One Mother, One Daughter, One Journey'', which she co-wrote with her mother following her graduation from Harvard, was published.\n\n\n''The Brooke Ellison Story'' premiered in 2004, based on Ellison's 2002 memoir ''Miracles Happen: One Mother, One Daughter, One Journey''. The television film was directed by fellow quadriplegic , the star of ''''. Ellison was portrayed by  as a child and  as a teenager. It is also notable for being Reeve's final directing project. The film aired on the  network on October 25, 2004.\n\n\nEllison ran for  as a  in 2006 but was defeated by the  incumbent, . One of Ellison's principal issues was her support for . She served on the advisory board of the Genetics Policy Institute.\n\n\nEllison was a professor in the School of Health Technology and Management at  and a motivational speaker.\n\nIn November 2015, Ellison teamed up with director  to create the award-winning documentary \"Hope Deferred\", which aims to educate the general public about .\n\nEllison was an advocate for accessible technology. She served as Vice President of Tech Access for  beginning in January 2023 following her 2022 appointment to their board.\n\nTwo decades following the publication of ''Miracles Happen'', Ellison wrote and published her second book, ''Look Both Ways'' in 2021.\n\nEllison died at  on February 4, 2024, at age 45, of complications from quadriplegia. \n\n\n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
          }

    "pages": }\n'''José Rafael Peralta''' (November 10, 1971 – November 21, 2018) was an American politician who served in the  and . A member of the , he last represented  in the , which includes the Queens neighborhoods of , , , , and . He previously represented District 39 in the , which is located in  and includes ,  and . He was elected to the  in a landslide on March 16, 2010. Peralta was a member of the  (IDC), a group of Democratic senators who allied themselves with Senate Republicans. He was re-elected in 2012, 2014 and 2016, but was defeated in the 2018 Democratic primary.\n\nPeralta died of  at the age of 47 on November 21, 2018.\n\n\nBorn in New York City on November 10, 1971, Peralta was a first-generation . After immigrating to the  from the , Peralta's father was employed as a bank teller. His mother, Rose Hernandez, worked as a seamstress. At the age of 8, Peralta moved with his family from  to Queens. Peralta attended  and graduated from  in 1989. He enrolled at  and became the first Latino Student Body President at the college. Peralta graduated from Queens College in 1996, with a degree in .\n\nAfter graduating from Queens College, Peralta was a community liaison in the New York State Assembly. Peralta represented the interests of immigrants on the New York City Central Labor Council, serving in the position of Director of the Commission on the Dignity for Immigrants.\n\nPeralta was a political staffer on campaigns in New York including 's campaign for , 's campaign for ,  election bid for  and 's . Peralta was married to Evelyn, and had two sons, Myles and Matthew.\n\n\n\nIn the November 5, 2002 election, Peralta won a seat in the  representing District 39. He ran as a  and beat candidate Charles Gonzales, a . Peralta received 76 percent of the votes cast. He was the first  from  to win an election to serve in the New York state Assembly. The 39th Assembly District in New York was created in 2002 as a result of the significant increase in immigrant population in the region. Peralta was sworn in as a member of the Assembly by Civil Court Judge Diccia Pineda, also of Dominican heritage. Peralta took the  in  at the . In attendance at Peralta's swearing-in ceremony were  ,   and Assemblyman .\n\nIn March 2004, Peralta requested that state  leadership pass legislation which proposed to increase the state's  to $7.15 per hour. In April 2007, Peralta introduced anti-gang legislation in the Assembly that focused on creating Gang Free School Zones surrounding schools in New York. In June 2007, Peralta was among a majority of the Assembly that voted to support passage of a  bill in New York. In January 2008, Peralta co-signed legislation with ,  and  which put forth a proposal of $150 million in funding for families that had the possibility of their homes being  upon.\n\nPeralta worked with fellow Assemblyman  to change the . Peralta served in the Assembly as Chair of the Subcommittee on Banking in Underserved Communities. He worked to encourage banks to move into underserved regions through his Banking Development District legislation.\n\n\nIn October 2009, Peralta stated his intention to run for the  for a seat representing . The Queens Democratic Party lent support to Peralta in his campaign for the Senate seat. An article in '''' in October 2009 described Peralta as \"one of the party’s rising stars\". Politician  was expelled from the Senate on February 9, 2010 by a 53–8 vote of his former colleagues after being convicted of   on his girlfriend Karla Giraldo. Peralta became a candidate for the March 16, 2010  to fill the Senate seat left vacant due to Monserrate's expulsion.\n\nThe  of the  endorsed Peralta on February 26, 2010.  activist  endorsed Peralta in February 2010. On March 2, 2010, Peralta received an endorsement from  member . Peralta received the endorsement of the  (ESPA) due to his support for . Peralta also received endorsements from groups including the New York chapter of the , building services workers union the  (SEIU) sector 32BJ and Fight Back New York. On March 16, 2010, Peralta was elected to the . He was sworn in on March 17.\n\nIn January 2017, Peralta joined the  (IDC), a group of Democratic senators that caucused with the Senate Republicans, allowing the Republicans to control the chamber. After joining the majority coalition, he was named vice chair of the Senate Committee on Energy and Telecommunications. Peralta received a $12,500 stipend (known as a \"lulu\") for his position as vice chair, although state law designates these stipends for committee chairs only. The Republican conference submitted falsified payroll information listing Peralta as committee chair so that he could receive the stipend, although the IDC argued that Peralta was legally entitled to the stipends for his position as vice chair.\n\nIn April 2018, Peralta and his IDC colleagues rejoined the Senate Democratic Conference.\n\nIn the September 2018 Democratic Party primary, Peralta was defeated by , a board member of the Jackson Heights Beautification Group. Peralta's nine-point loss was attributed to long-simmering anger with the former members of the IDC. Due to New York State's  laws allowing candidates to run on multiple ballot lines in an election, Peralta appeared in the November 6, 2018 general election as the third-party candidate for the , the  and the ; however, Peralta conceded the race to Ramos and promised to support her campaign.\n\n\n* '''November 2002 , NYS Assembly, 39th AD'''\n:\n\n* '''November 2004 , NYS Assembly, 39th AD'''\n:\n\n* '''November 2006 , NYS Assembly, 39th AD'''\n:\n\n* '''November 2008 , NYS Assembly, 39th AD'''\n:\n\n* '''March 2010 , NYS Senate, 13th SD'''\n:\n\n* '''November 2010 , NYS Senate, 13th SD'''\n:\n\n* '''November 2012 , NYS Senate, 13th SD'''\n:\n\n* '''November 2014 , NYS Senate, 13th SD'''\n:\n\n* '''November 2016 , NYS Senate, 13th SD'''\n:\n\n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n*  \n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Kevin Thomas''' is an American attorney and politician from the  of . A , Thomas has represented the  in the  since 2019. In July 2023, he announced his candidacy in the 2024 election for .\n\n\n\nThomas is an  of  descent. He was born in , , , to a family originating from . He has an older sister. Thomas attended  in Dubai before he immigrated to the United States as a ten-year-old boy. He earned his  from  and his  from 's .\n\nThomas worked for the  as an attorney and was an appointee of the US Commission on Civil Rights to the New York State Advisory Committee, a federal agency tasked with civil rights oversight.\n\n\nIn an upset victory, Thomas defeated incumbent Senator  50.8%–49.1% in the 6th Senate District in the .\n\nThomas was sworn in for his first term on January 1, 2019, and is serving as Chair of the Consumer Protection committee. He is the first South Asian American and the first Indian-American to serve in the New York State Senate.\n\nIn 2020, Thomas worked on a data bill entitled the New York Privacy Act, which would require companies to allow consumers to obtain the names of all entities with whom their information is shared and give those consumers the power to stop the company from sharing that data if they do not want it distributed.\n\nIn October 2020, Thomas secured a second term after defeating Republican challenger Dennis Dunne.\n\n\nThomas and his wife, Rincy, have a daughter.\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''James G. Van Bramer''' (born August 19, 1969) is an American politician. A , who served in the  and represented the  from 2010 to 2021, which includes , , , and  in . Van Bramer is a  who was one of the few members of the City Council to endorse 's campaign in the .\n\n\nVan Bramer was born and grew up in the  borough of , the son of retired active  members. His father, William Van Bramer, was a lifelong member of Printers' and Pressman's Union Local 2. His mother, Elizabeth, helped support the family by taking a variety of jobs in their neighborhood. She was a member of Local 1893 of the International Brotherhood of Painters.\n\nVan Bramer graduated from . In 1994, he graduated from .\n\n\nBefore joining the City Council, Van Bramer served as the Chief External Affairs Officer of the Queens Public Library. In this capacity, he was the library's link between community members and government.\n\nHe worked as a reporter for Lesbian and Gay New York (now '''') a community newspaper, where he brought attention to the AIDS epidemic and bias/hate crimes. He represents his neighborhood and the 37th Assembly District on the New York State Democratic Committee.\n\nIn September 2007, he was named one of '''''s \"40 under 40\" for being a young influential member of New York City politics. Van Bramer currently lives in  with his husband, Dan Hendrick. They married on July 28, 2012. Van Bramer is one of four openly LGBTQ+ members of the New York City Council, alongside ,  and .\n\n\n\nVan Bramer was first elected to the  to represent the  on November 3, 2009. He was re-elected in 2013. On January 22, 2014, Van Bramer was chosen to be the New York City Council's , the second-most powerful position in the body. He was also named to serve as co-chair of a budget negotiating team set up by Speaker .\n\nHe was elected to a third 4-year term on November 7, 2017 and reappointed to the budget negotiating team by Speaker . Van Bramer was appointed to chair the Council’s Cultural Affairs, Libraries and International Relations Committee. He has served as chair of this committee throughout his tenure as a council member.\n\n\n\n* \n* \n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n*  \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Roger L. Green''' (born June 23, 1949) is an American legislator who served in the  for 26 years, from 1981 to 2007 (with a brief interruption in 2004), representing District 57 which, allowing for  adjustments, has primarily comprised the   of  s , , ,  and . He was the first  member of the Assembly.\n\n\nA native of Brooklyn, Roger L. Green was raised in a family with a long history of participation in the struggles to advance human rights and economic justice. He was educated in the  and graduated from , where he attained a triple major in ,  and Government.  After graduation and return to Brooklyn, he became involved in local politics, joining several civil rights groups and community organizations concerned with the elimination of racism and social injustice. He was raised  but  to  in the early 1970s.  \n\n\nAfter a historic election that required him to win an unprecedented three primary runoffs, Roger Green was elected to the  in November 1980. He was a member of the State Assembly (57th D.) from 1981 to 2006 (with an interruption in 2004), sitting in the , , , , , , , , , , , , and s. During his tenure in public office, he distinguished himself as an architect of laws, policies and institutions that defined his commitment to civil and human rights within New York State, the nation, and the world community. Beginning in 1981, he participated in numerous mass mobilizations and legislative mobilizations dedicated to the abolition of police brutality. In response to the deaths of Luis Baez,  and , Green authored legislation creating the Center for Law and Social Justice at . This social justice advocacy organization has become a renowned transformative vehicle for the abolition of racial injustice. The center worked with the  to author the disparity study, which quantified discriminatory practices within the construction industry.\n\nIn 1983,  and labor leader  asked Green to serve as the New York State political coordinator for the Memorial March on . It was during this period that Green authored the bill that established the New York State Martin Luther King Holiday Commission and the bill establishing the New York State Martin Luther King Institute. In 1985 and 1986, in conjunction with the founding of the federal ,  signed these bills into law.\n\nFrom 1986 to 1988, Green served his first tenure as chair of the New York State Black and Puerto Rican Legislative Caucus. During his term, the caucus was viewed as the preeminent voice in support of laws designed to reduce and prosecute racial violence. Following the racial killing of  in the  section of Brooklyn, Green joined the Reverend , Reverend Timothy Mitchell and Reverend Herbert Daughtry in citywide protests entitled the Day of Outrage. After his arrest for civil disobedience, Green returned to  and worked with Assemblyman  in the co-authorship of the New York State Anti-Bias Bill. This bill was the first comprehensive legislation to include prosecution for violence against members of the gay community. In 1994, , the N.Y. senate majority leader of the Republican Caucus, presented Green and Eve with an opportunity to pass their bill if they would agree to drop \"gay rights\" language from their proposal. Green, Eve, and other members of the Caucus considered this an unprincipled compromise. During a debate within the Assembly, Green quoted 's admonition that  \"an injustice anywhere is a threat to justice everywhere\"… Six years later, following a major \"March for Justice\" and lobbying effort, the anti-bias bill, authored by Green and Eve, was signed into law. From 1986 to 1991, the New York State Martin Luther King Institute trained more than 1,000 high school and college students through its  Academy. Students participating in this program learned the theory and practice of non-violent conflict resolution. Students were also provided with an opportunity to study civil rights and human rights social history.\n\n  \nFrom 1982 to 1992, Green was actively involved in the global struggle to dismantle  and to establish a free democratic . Green served as co-sponsor of the State Divestiture Bill, which was authored by . Green also served as political coordinator for the June 14 March Against Apartheid. It was the largest anti-apartheid demonstration in the history of the U.S. After the march, the U.N. Special Commission on Human Rights appointed Green as one of eight U.S. delegates to the World Conference Against Apartheid in , which was organized to develop strategies to eliminate this injustice. After  was released, Green worked directly with the leadership of the , , and labor leaders Cleveland Robinson and Jim Bell to formulate the Nelson Mandela Welcoming Committee involved in Mandela’s historic visit to the U.S.\n\nFrom 1989 to 2005, Green served with distinction as the chair of the Standing Committee on Children and Families in the New York State Legislature. During his tenure, Green authored numerous groundbreaking laws dedicated to protecting the rights of children. During the height of the , Dr. Vera Makonde, representing survivors of this tragedy who lived in the U.S., urged Green to serve as the chair of the Rwanda Children's Aid Committee. He accepted this responsibility.  As chair of the Committee, he raised moral and material support for the children who were orphaned or made refugees as a result of this crisis.\n\n\nGreen resigned his seat on June 1, 2004, after pleading guilty to petty larceny in connection with $3,000 in false travel reimbursement claims. As part of a plea deal, he served three years' probation, was fined $2,000, and had to pay $3,000 in restitution.\n\nLater that year, he ran for the Assembly and was re-elected to the same seat he had held.\n\n\nIn 2006, Green campaigned to unseat  Representative  On September 12, 2006, Green came in third, losing to both incumbent Ed Towns and City Councilman . On the same day, , Green's long-time political opponent, was elected to succeed him in the Assembly district which he had retired from to launch his unsuccessful bid for Congress.\n\n\nIn 2007, shortly after the end of Green's term in the State Legislature, the chancellor of the  and the president of Medgar Evers College, appointed him as a distinguished lecturer. Green taught a course exploring the historical significance of the freedom amendments  the U.S. Constitution’s 13th, 14th, 15th and 19th  and their influence on state and local government. Green is also the director of the , a think tank dedicated to advancing best practices in law, policy, and community covenants for urban justice within the U.S. and throughout the .\n\n\nRoger Green is married to labor rights and human rights advocate, Coraminita Mahr; is the father of three children, Corlita, Khalid and Imani; and has one grandchild, Belle. He spends time writing poetry and essays that explore, among other things, the commonalities between diverse people and cultures and the physical, mental, and spiritual well being of the world's children.\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n*\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
          }
        ]

    "pages": }\n'''Daniel Dromm''' (born November 27, 1955) is an American politician who served on the  from the  from 2010 to 2021. He is a . The district includes ,  and  in .\n\n\nDromm was born in , but his family moved to  on  when he was 5, and to  when he was 9. He attended Catholic schools. Dromm graduated from  and earned his master's degree at .\n\nA resident of , Dromm began his first career as a public school teacher in 1984 at P.S. 199 in . As an educator, he promoted teaching acceptance of LGBT individuals through the  and publicly  in 1992. Heavily involved in the Queens County Democratic Party, he served as Democratic District Leader in the 39th assembly district.\n\nHe is one of the first two openly gay City Council members from outside Manhattan.\n\nDromm was featured in the 2015  documentary .\n\n\nAs a , Dromm was elected to the City Council in 2009, representing the  in Queens. He defeated Councilwoman  by 10 points, 49% to 39%, in the Democratic primary. Dromm was reelected in 2013 and served as Chairperson of the Council's influential Committee on Education from 2014 to 2017.\n\nIn 2014, Dromm co-sponsored New York City Council bill Intro 253 to create the city's first government-issued photo identification card, later named \".\" The bill was passed overwhelmingly by the Council and signed into law by Mayor . IDNYC aides the homeless, youth, the elderly, undocumented immigrants, the formerly incarcerated and others who may have difficulty obtaining other government-issued ID. IDNYC is recognized ID for interacting with NYPD and allows cardholders to gain access to all City buildings that provide public services. It is an accepted form of identification for accessing numerous City programs and services such as the Brooklyn Public Library, the Queens Library, and the New York City Public Library, the three library systems serving the City of New York. Several NYC cultural institutions grant cardholders free one-year memberships; these include museums, zoos, concert halls, and botanical gardens.\n\nIn 2015, Dromm said he opposed a bill sponsored by New York City Council Member David Greenfield to allow non-public schools (including religious and charter schools) to request that safety agents from the New York Police Department be posted inside the schools and be funded by the Board of Education. Dromm argued that more NYPD officers or safety agents in the schools would not solve the problem of increasing hate crimes citywide and would be counterproductive.\n\nOn December 19, 2017, the New York City Council unanimously passed Dromm's resolution establishing January 30 annually as Fred T. Korematsu Day of Civil Liberties and the Constitution in honor of the late civil rights activist who objected to the internment of Japanese Americans during World War II.\n\nIn January 2018, Dromm was unanimously elected to serve as the chairperson of the NYC Council Committee on Finance.\n\n\n\n\n* \n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n* \n*  \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
          }
        ]

    "pages": }\n| module              = \n}}\n'''Thomas Richard Suozzi''' ( ; born August 31, 1962) is an American politician, attorney, and accountant serving as the  for  since 2024 and previously from 2017 to 2023. A member of the , he was the  of  on  from 2002 to 2009, when he was unseated by Republican . Before that, Suozzi served eight years as the mayor of  in Nassau County.\n\nIn , he ran unsuccessfully against  for the Democratic nomination for . Suozzi was elected to the  in  and reelected in  and . He retired from Congress to run again for the Democratic gubernatorial nomination in , losing to incumbent governor .\n\nIn October 2023, Suozzi announced that he would run for his old congressional seat in . After Congress   that December, a  to fill the remainder of the term was scheduled for February 13, 2024. Suozzi was selected as the Democratic nominee, and then won the special election, reclaiming the seat for Democrats.\n\n\n\nThe youngest of five siblings, Suozzi was born on August 31, 1962, in . His father, , who was born in , Italy, was an attorney and served as Glen Cove mayor from 1956 to 1960. His mother, Marguerite (née Holmes), of Irish and English descent, was an operating room nurse at .\n\nSuozzi graduated from  in 1980. He attended , graduating in 1984 with a Bachelor of Science degree in accounting. He became a  two years later. He then earned a  degree from  in 1989.\n\n\nBefore entering politics, Suozzi worked as an accountant at  from 1984 to 1986, a law clerk to  of the  from 1989 to 1990, and a commercial litigator at  from 1990 to 1993.\n\nSuozzi returned to the private sector from 2010 to 2016, working as an attorney  at , and as a consultant for  and . After initially leaving Congress, he became co-chair of Actum LLC, a global consulting firm.\n\n\n\nIn 1993, Suozzi was elected mayor of . He served as mayor for four terms. His father and his uncle, Vincent Suozzi, were mayors of Glen Cove before him.\n\nAs mayor, Suozzi focused on environmental cleanup of commercial and industrial sites, and redeveloping brownfield and  sites. In 1994, the Glen Cove incinerator was permanently closed and dismantled. In 1998, the city demolished and redeveloped the defunct Li Tungsten Refinery grounds, a federal superfund site.\n\n\n]]\n\nSuozzi was elected  Executive in 2001, becoming the first Democrat elected to the position in traditionally Republican Nassau in 30 years. He assumed office amid a fiscal crisis. By 1999, Nassau was on the brink of financial collapse: the county faced a $300 million annual deficit, was billions of dollars in debt, and its credit rating had sunk to one level above junk status. According to '''', he \"earned high marks from independent institutions for his signature achievement, the resuscitation of Nassau's finances.\"\n\nWhile in office, Suozzi cut spending and reduced borrowing and debt. He also oversaw 11 county bond upgrades over two years, eliminated deficits in Nassau, and accumulated surpluses. In 2005, '''' named him one of its Public Officials of the Year, calling him \"the man who spearheaded Nassau County, New York's, remarkable turnaround from the brink of fiscal disaster.\" According to ''The New York Times'', he garnered praise for social services like his \"no wrong door\" program, which centralized access to social services.\n\nSuozzi narrowly lost the 2009 county executive election to Ed Mangano. After working in the private sector as an attorney, he announced that he would seek a rematch against Mangano in 2013. He attacked Mangano for \"presiding over a decline in the county\" while also emphasizing eight years of balanced budgets and reduced crime while he was county executive. In November 2013, Mangano defeated Suozzi by a much wider margin of 59% to 41%.\n\n \n\n\nSuozzi declared his candidacy for  in the Democratic primary against  on February 25, 2006. Few prominent Democrats apart from Nassau County Democratic Party Chairman Jay Jacobs supported his bid; most of New York's Democratic legislators and mayors campaigned for Spitzer. One of Suozzi's biggest supporters was Victor Rodriguez, founder of the now disbanded Voter Rights Party. Rodriguez eventually became the lead field organizer for his Albany campaign office. The campaign was funded in part by  co-founder , former NYSE CEO , vice chairman of the MTA , and many people on  whom Spitzer had investigated and prosecuted.\n\nOn June 13, 2006, Suozzi spoke before the New York State Conference of Mayors along with Spitzer and . He received a standing ovation from the crowd of mayors. On July 6, he announced to his followers that he had collected enough petitions to place himself on the primary ballot. During a debate, he said he had presidential aspirations. On August 7, after much speculation, he announced that he would not seek an independent line were he to lose the primary.\n\nSpitzer defeated Suozzi in the Democratic primary with 81% of the vote to Suozzi's 19%.\n\n\n\nOn November 29, 2021, Suozzi announced his candidacy for governor of New York in . He strongly opposed a proposal by Governor  to permit homeowners to add an accessory dwelling unit (such as an extra apartment and backyard cottage) on lots zoned for single-family housing. The proposal was intended to alleviate New York's housing shortage and make housing more affordable. He said that he supported efforts to tackle housing problems, but that he was against \"ending single-family housing\".\n\nSuozzi placed third in the Democratic primary with 12% of the vote, behind Hochul and .\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nIn June 2016, Suozzi won a five-way Democratic primary in . He was endorsed by ''The New York Times'', ''Newsday'', and ''The Island Now''. He defeated Republican State Senator  in the general election on November 8, 53% to 47% and began representing  in the  in January 2017.\n\n\n\nIn June 2018, Suozzi won the Democratic primary unopposed. In the general election, He defeated Republican nominee Dan DeBono 59% to 41%.\n\n\n\nIn June 2020, Suozzi won a three-way Democratic primary in  with 66.5% of the votes. In the general election, he defeated Republican nominee  56% to 43%.\n\n\n\n\nSuozzi announced his candidacy for  in the November 2024 election. After Congress expelled Representative , Suozzi also declared his candidacy for the . He was selected as the Democratic nominee on December 7, 2023, and defeated Republican nominee , a member of the  representing the 10th district, in the special election on February 13, 2024 by a margin of 54% to 46%.}}\n\nAs the winner of the special election, Suozzi will serve out the remainder of Santos's term in the House, which expires in January 2025. According to a December 2023 '''' article, solidarity with  in response to the October  was a top priority for the district, and both Suozzi and Pilip were \"staunch supporters of Israel\". Suozzi and Pilip primarily campaigned on the issue of an influx of migrants into the United States.\n\n\n and  in 2021]]\n  \t\t  \t\nSuozzi was vice-chair of the , which comprises 22 Democrats and 22 Republicans. He also co-chaired the Long Island Sound Caucus, co-chaired the Quiet Skies Caucus, and chaired the 's Board of Visitors. Suozzi was a member of the , the  and the .\n\nIn Congress, Suozzi authored legislation to restore the , which was capped at $10,000 in 2017. He orchestrated a call from the New York congressional delegation for the repeal of the SALT cap. The effort was not successful, and the SALT cap remained at $10,000.\n\nSuozzi voted in favor of three military aid package supplementals for , , and  respectively in April 2024, along with most Democrats.\n\n\nIn 2021, the nonpartisan  filed a formal ethics complaint with the  alleging that Suozzi had failed to file the reports required by the  on approximately 300 different stock transactions with a value of $3.2 million to $11 million. \n\nIn March 2022, it was reported that Suozzi failed to properly disclose another 31 stock transactions, worth as much as $885,000. Two months later, it was reported for a third time that he had failed to properly disclose stock transactions he had made, this time 10 stock trades that in aggregate were between $171,000 and $515,000.\n\nWhen Suozzi came before congressional investigators to explain in a deposition why he had not disclosed hundreds of stock trades in a timely manner, he told investigators: \"Quite frankly, we have a lot going on in Congress. I have a lot of other stuff going on. And it's just notethics is a big priority for me. But...the...some of the formalities are not necessarily something I make a priority of.\" In July 2022, the U.S. House Ethics Committee said it had decided not to charge Suozzi for failing to file required reports on stock transactions on time because it was not a \"knowing or willful\" act. The committee said its five Democratic and five Republican members unanimously voted to dismiss the referral from the independent federal Office of Congressional Ethics. \n\nIn December 2022, Suozzi disclosed dozens of additional stock trades that were reported up to three years past the federal deadline.\n\n\n\n* \n** Subcommittee on Border Security and Enforcement\n** Subcommittee on Counterterrorism, Law Enforcement and Intelligence\n\n*  Congressman Thomas Suozzi |url=http://suozzi.house.gov/about/committees-and-caucuses |access-date=2024-08-11 |website=suozzi.house.gov |language=en}}\n\n\n\n* Animal Protection Caucus\n* Bipartisan Offshore Wind Caucus\n* \n* Congressional Caucus on India and Indian Americans\n* Congressional Caucus on Korea\n* Congressional Fire Services Caucus\n* Congressional Friends of Ireland Caucus\n* Congressional High Speed and Passenger Rail Modernization Caucus\n* \n* Congressional Long Island Sound Caucus\n* Congressional Pakistan Caucus\n* Congressional Uyghur Caucus (Co-Founder and Co-Chair)\n* Democrats for Border Security Task Force (Co-Chair)\n* Diabetes Caucus\n* Disaster Equity and Building Resilience Caucus\n* Friends of Kazakhstan Caucus\n* International Conservation Caucus\n* Italian American Congressional Delegation\n* Labor Caucus\n* \n* Quiet Skies Caucus (Vice Chair)\n* SALT Caucus (Co-Chair)\n* \n* Ukraine Caucus\n\n\n in 2024|262x262px]]\nSuozzi and his wife Helene (née Wrotniak) married in 1993. They live in Glen Cove and have three children. His son Joe is a minor league baseball player who plays in the  organization. Suozzi is .\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n*  official U.S. House website\n*  campaign website\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Adrienne Eadie Adams''' (born December 9, 1960) is an American politician serving as Speaker of the . A Democrat, Adams represents the , and is the first woman elected to the district.\n\nAdams was elected in 2017 to fill out the remainder of the term of her expelled predecessor, . \n\nHer district includes the  borough neighborhoods of , ,  and .\n\n\nAdams was raised in . She attended St. Pascal Baylon Elementary School, , and received a bachelor's degree in Psychology from .\n\n\nShe was a three-term chairperson of . Previously, Adams has been an appointed member of the  Board of Trustees, and appointed to Governor 's Local Planning Committee (LPC) for the . She once served as co-chair of the Jamaica NOW Leadership Council.\n\nAdams previously ran for  against \n\n\nAdams won her 2017 primary with 39.17% of the vote (3,499 votes). Her opponent, Richard David, got 31.59% of the vote (2,822 votes) and her other opponent Hettie Powell received 28.98% of the vote. (2,589 votes). Adams went on to win the general election with 85.97% of the vote. During her first term she was elected by her colleagues in the  to serve as co-chair of the body, and at various points also served as chair of the Subcommittee on Landmarks, Public Sitings, and Dispositions, and later chair of the Committee on Public Safety.\n\nAdams was elected Speaker of the New York City Council in January 2022.  She is the second politician from the borough of Queens to serve as Speaker ( was the first City Council Speaker of New York City).  She is the third woman to serve as Speaker and the first Black person to serve as Speaker. Her election was a defeat for newly elected mayor  (no relation), who had privately been trying to win support for rival Speaker candidate .\n\nCouncil Speaker Adams declined to take up legislation that would prevent New York City public service retirees from being forced into a  plan. The proposed change has been challenged by the New York City Organization of Public Service Retirees and unions such as the , the  professors union. Until 2023, most municipal retirees have been enrolled in traditional Medicare. Council Speaker Adams however, has not helped the retirees protect their health benefits from being stripped from them in retirement and has blocked their proposed legislation from being introduced. \n\nIn 2023, Councilman  drafted a bill, Intro 1099 that was simply two sentences long requiring the City to offer a  plan like retirees are currently in and stating nothing in this bill would interfere with a unions' collective bargaining - an excuse given not to help them.  Retirees are no longer in unions once retired. Speaker Adams not only blocked the bill from being introduced the traditional way, she also intimidated other councilmembers from signing onto it, and prevented Councilwoman  from calling the bill to a hearing in the Civil Service and Labor Committee, letting it die in committee.\n\nRetirees have had to continue to fight in court because the very council that legislated their Medicare benefits over the decades from Mayor  to Councilwoman  of District 28, and former Speaker Peter Vallone, this council has been more loyal to the unions that fund their campaigns than the vulnerable retirees who they should have been helping.  Speaker Adams's First Deputy Chief of Staff is Jeremy John, the former Political Action Director of the  union.\n\n\nAdams is a longtime member of the  and the . She is also an active member of the  sorority. Her family includes her husband Joseph, four adult children, and eleven grandchildren.\n\n\n\n\n\n* ''official site''\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Donald R. Manes''' (, ; January 18, 1934 – March 13, 1986) was a  politician from . He served as  of the  of  from 1971 until just before his  while under suspicion of corruption in 1986.Meislin, Richard J. , '''', March 15, 1986. Accessed December 11, 2007.\n\n\nManes was born in Brooklyn, where he graduated from . He briefly attended  before earning a degree in  from . In 1957, he received his  from . He moved to Queens with his family as a teenager. \n\nFollowing his admission to the New York bar, Manes was employed as a  under the aegis of , later serving as an associate counsel to  member  during his successful battle to become the legislative body's majority leader in 1965. That same year, he was elected to the , becoming the youngest member of its Queens delegation from a -based district. He ultimately ascended to the chair of the Council's Housing Committee and emerged as a protégé of influential Councilman , a strident opponent of then-Mayor  who became chair of the Queens Democratic Party in 1971.\n\nElected to his final role at the behest of Troy when he was 37, Manes was the youngest borough president in Queens history. During his tenure, Manes transformed his position from a mid-level policymaking role (although the borough presidents held influential seats on the now-defunct , incumbents generally served as proxies for county party leaders) into a more proactive political job, capitalizing on Queens's historic lack of a robust Democratic political machine in the mold of Manhattan's  or the storied clubhouse scenes in Brooklyn and the Bronx. In 1974, Mayor  worked with Manes to arrange Troy’s ouster as Queens Democratic leader, with Manes assuming the role for the remainder of his life. Troy had angered Manes when he supported  against eventual incumbent  in the 1974 Democratic gubernatorial primary. Manes was re-elected four more times through the turn of the decade, also serving as a delegate to the  during this period.\n\nHis popularity plummeted in late 1985, when he was criticized over two of his pet projects. He wanted to build a  auto racetrack in Queens's largest public park, , where the  and the  had been held. Community leaders denigrated the idea, and it became the first major project of his that was opposed. Also that year, Manes worked to build a domed football-baseball stadium in the park, but it was opposed by local businessmen in the  area. When Queens couldn't secure a football franchise, the plan died.\n\nOne of his biggest controversies came in late 1985, when Manes wanted to wire the borough for cable television. Manes rejected a proposal by the Queens-based Orth-O-Vision company to place cable lines in the borough, and instead awarded contracts to mega-companies  and , as well as a cable firm owned by former  borough president . Local residents were outraged that he passed over a local firm for large national companies.\n\n\nShortly after his inauguration for a fifth term, Manes attended a dinner party for the new i consul at Borough Hall in  on January 9, 1986. He left in his own car and was followed by his chauffeur up . He was later found in his car in the early morning hours of January 10; his wrists were slit and he was bleeding profusely. He initially claimed that two men had carjacked and attacked him, but later recanted the statement, saying he had attempted .\n\nIn the following weeks, it was alleged that Manes had used political appointments and favors as the source of large  schemes involving personal bureaucratic s, most notably the New York City Parking Violations Bureau. In 1978, Manes installed a friend, Geoffrey Lindenauer, who later cooperated with prosecutors, as the deputy head of the Parking Violations Bureau. With Manes’ help, Lindenauer steered collections of parking fines to a company that paid the two bribes of up to $2,500 per month by 1982. Later in 1982, Manes, Lindenauer and Bronx Democratic Party leader  each received shares in a company called Citisource, which won a city contract to develop a handheld parking ticket computer. Manes also accepted bribes from SRS, a company also involved in parking ticket collections, whose owner also cooperated with authorities. Columnist  published a story on January 23, 1986 in which the head of a third parking collections company confessed to paying $36,000 in bribes to Manes.\n\nZoning and cable TV franchises were being investigated, and some of Manes' appointees and associates were  or forced to resign. Manes' deputy  was installed as acting Borough President on January 28 and he formally resigned on February 11.\n\nThe scandal became nationwide news and a continuing top story in New York City. Manes, now facing the prospect of indictment on corruption charges, stayed in seclusion until March. On the night of March 13, he took a phone call from his psychiatrist, who discussed additional care with Manes (and his wife on an extension phone upstairs). Shortly before 10 p.m. the psychiatrist was called away from the phone and, while on hold, Manes reached into a kitchen drawer, pulled out a large kitchen knife and plunged the eight-inch blade into his heart. His daughter screamed for her mother, who came down to find Manes on the floor in a pool of blood. Marlene Manes pulled the knife from his heart as their daughter frantically called 911. Donald Manes was pronounced dead at the scene.\n\nLess than three years later, on November 17, 1988, Morton Manes, Donald Manes' twin brother, attempted suicide in the same manner. He died of a heart attack at the age of 70 in May 2004.\n\nManes was buried at Mt. Ararat Cemetery in .  Manes' successor, , served as Borough President until 2002.\n\n\n* A loosely fictionalized version of the scandal served as the basis for the film '''' (1996).                   \n* The   of the television series '''', \"\", was based on the scandal.\n*Manes' suicide and dealings with attorney Michael Dowd are both referenced on a news broadcast in the opening of the 2023 film ''''.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
          }
        ]

    "pages": }\n\n'''Melissa \"Missy\" Miller''' (born March 3, 1964) is an American politician from the state of New York. A , Miller represents the Third Councilmanic District on the Hempstead Town Board. She represented the 20th Assembly District in the  from 2017 to 2022; the district included the city of  and portions of the town of .\n\n\nMiller was born and raised in .  A mother of three, Miller lost her oldest daughter to a rare disease. She has two other children, one of whom is chronically disabled. As a result, Miller is an advocate for disabled children.  For many years, she has been a leader with Compassionate Care New York. Miller has worked professionally to train pediatric care professionals on how to properly care for chronically disabled children.\n\nIn 2016, Miller decided to make her first foray into public office by running for the . While the 20th district had long been represented by Democrats, the district had lacked representation for nearly seven months after  was elected to the . Facing no opposition for the Republican nomination, Miller went on to defeat Democrat Anthony Eramo, a Long Beach councilmember, in an upset on Election Day. In 2018, Miller was re-elected, defeating Democrat Juan C. Vides. Miller was again re-elected in 2020, defeating Democrat Gregory Marks.\n\nOn February 7, 2022, Miller announced that she was resigning from the Assembly to fill a vacancy on the Hempstead Town Board. Miller's decision was influenced by a family medical situation. Miller was appointed to the  Town Board on February 15, 2022; she represents the Third Councilmanic District.\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Edward L. Gibbs''' (born October 28, 1968) is an   who is currently representing the 68th district in the  since 2022. He is the first formerly incarcerated  member.\n\n\nBorn the second-eldest of four, Gibbs was raised in public housing in  by a single mother. His family lived off of . As a teenager, Gibbs sold crack cocaine to support his family.\n\nAt 17 years old, Gibbs was stabbed in the leg in an attempted robbery. In an act of self defense, Gibbs shot and killed his attacker before turning himself in at a local police station. He spent 17 months on  before accepting a plea deal. Gibbs then served time at the , , and  Correctional Facilities. In prison, he received his  and .\n\n\nOn October 3, 2024, Gibbs was arrested and taken into custody following a confrontation with police which occurred after his brother was pulled over after having an unregistered vehicle. The incident, which started out as a heated conversation before escalating, would later result in a dozen police cars responding. Gibbs was not immediately released and still remained in custody during the afternoon. Though the reason for the arrest was not immediately specified, it was not believed to be connected to the ongoing criminal investigation against New York Mayor Eric Adams, who Gibbs is an ally of. Later in the day, while speaking outside his precinct office, Gibbs apologized to \"officer Fibbs\" and \"officer Peter,\" stating that the arrest was justified and that he had interferred with a police investigation. Despite this, the exact charges he is facing remain unknown.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Leroy George Comrie Jr.''' (born August 10, 1958) is an American politician from . He represents  in the , which comprises , , , , , , ,  and other neighborhoods within the borough of .\n\n\nComrie, Jr is the son of the late Ruby Frith-Comrie and the late Leroy Comrie Sr., both of whom immigrated to the United States from . He has one brother. He attended P.S. 116, I.S. 8,  and the , where he developed his passion for politics and government.\n\n\nEarly in his political career, he made much of his living as a photographer for local weddings and community events.\n\nPrior to his election to the NYC Council, Comrie served seven years in the office of  Member , moving from an aide to  during his tenure. He has also served as a member and eventually president of Community School Board 29.\n\n\nLeroy Comrie was elected to represent the  in the 2001 elections, succeeding Spigner. After a close election, Comrie won his election for the 27th District by less than 200 votes over his next opponent, local lawyer Helen Cooper-Gregory, in this six-way race. After his first re-election in 2005, Comrie was elected Deputy Majority Leader, also known as , by his  colleagues on the council, as well as head of the Queens delegation, chair of the council's Consumer Affairs Committee, and later chair of the powerful Land Use Committee.\n\nAs Deputy Majority Leader, Comrie had access to some of the largest member items, also known as discretionary funding, in the legislative body. These funds went to local organizations throughout Southeast Queens, such as the Black Spectrum Theatre and his local Precinct Community Councils. Comrie also oversaw a sizable capital budget during his tenure allowing him to finance major construction projects in his district, such as the $19 million construction of P.S.36Q. As chair of the Queens Delegation, Comrie worked closely with Borough President  to increase investment into  allotting tens of millions of dollars annually to the library system through their terms. In 2007, then-Councilman Comrie helped pass a resolution in the NYC Council calling for an end to the use of the n-word in the New York. The resolution was largely symbolic but the unanimous vote by the council was the first clear statement on their position on the issue.\n\nIn 2009, Leroy Comrie won re-election to the New York City Council to serve his third-term. He defeated his Democratic opponent, local attorney and future-Assembly Member , 62%-38%. Comrie was a supporter of Mayor 's push to temporarily extend office terms to a third term, due to the economic recession, which allowed him run for office again.\n\nAs chair of the Consumer Protection Committee, in 2011, then-Councilman Leroy Comrie attempted to address the issue of child obesity by introducing legislation that would have forbidden toy giveaways in fast food restaurants with unhealthy meals. Although the bill was not passed, it is believed to have influenced McDonald's and later others in the Southeast Queens area and across the country to add healthy food items to their happy meals. This same year, Comrie held high-profile hearings about gang merchandising. The hearings focused on Buffalo-based  who he accused of imitating gang styles to bolster profits. As chair of the Land-Use Committee, in 2013, Comrie helped lead the opposition to the proposed soccer stadium eyeing a home in . The proposal ultimately failed after an outpouring of opposition from the surrounding community.\n\n\nIn 2013, Comrie launched a campaign to succeed  as  of Queens. His campaign promised to push for major investment in Queens infrastructure, particularly adding a new subway for Queens. Early on, Comrie struggled to keep up with his competitors in fundraising and failed to receive the endorsement of the powerful Queens County Democratic Party who chose to support Melinda Katz instead. Comrie would eventually drop out and endorse current Queens Borough President  in the Democratic primary. Comrie would later serve as Deputy Borough President under Katz during her first year in office.\n\n\nAccepting a sizable pay cut, in 2014, Comrie challenged  for the  after his corruption charges and questionable loyalty to the Democratic Party began calls for his replacement. He defeated Smith in the   by a landslide. Following his election to the NYS Senate, Comrie helped lead the search to appoint his replacement as Deputy Borough President eventually selecting Melva Miller, the Queens Borough President's director of economic development and Southeast Queens resident, to the post.\n\nUpon taking office, Comrie was appointed  on the Elections Committee and Consumer Protection Committee.\n\n\nComrie was also selected to be a delegate at the 2016 Democratic National Convention for the New York State 5th Congressional District. Following the election of President Trump, Comrie joined Democrats across the State of New York to call for the Independent Democratic Conference of 8 State Senators to stop supporting the Republican Conference. He even began to vocally protest the institution by participating in town halls organized by their opponents. At one of these town halls, Comrie called his colleague, the Northeast Queens Senator Tony Avella, \"the single most selfish person that I've ever met on a lot of different levels ... He has not reached out to me at all in any type of collegial fashion.\"\n\n\n\nDuring his first legislative session in the New York State Senate, Leroy Comrie also passed a bill that expanded access to  for the disabled.\n\nAs state senator, Comrie has helped lead the community on multiple initiatives such as preventing a state-run juvenile prison from being built on a closed elementary school in Queens Village, fighting the development of a multi-story religious dormitory on the controversial  Lubavitch Jewish synagogue in Cambria Heights/Laurelton, and stopping the closure of the  facility in Cambria Heights which provides medical education and programming to the surrounding community. Comrie also took several high-profile stances against legislation considered by the NYC Council such as working with other Queens elected officials in opposing the congestion pricing proposal, and, in the NYS Senate, repealing the plastic bag fee passed by the NYC Council\n\n\nAs Ranking Member on the Elections Committee, he has pushed for the Vote Better NY legislation package to address \"the catastrophe known as New York's election law\" by establishing early voting, simplifying ballots, and streamlining voter registration. The bills, among others, stalled in the  due to opposition by the Republican leadership in control of the chamber at the time.\n\nComrie introduced legislation that would allow absentee ballot voting without an excuse. It would require amending the .\n\n\nIn 2007, Leroy Comrie was tangentially associated with a controversy regarding the dismissal of Council Member 's chief of staff, Viola Plummer. Following a heated committee meeting on a bill co-naming a street in Brooklyn after , Plummer exited city hall and spoke to a small group in the plaza that included reporters. Plummer, a resident of Comrie's district, threatened to end Comrie's career and politically \"assassinate\" Comrie. These statements, taken in the light of the 2003 assassination of Council Member , led City Council Speaker  to arrange for an  escort for Comrie and to dismiss Plummer. Plummer filed suit in federal court for violation of her  right to free speech but the claims were dismissed. During this trial Comrie testified that he felt \"physically threatened\" but took no personal actions to protect himself.\n\nIn 2011, Comrie made headlines when he chose not to renew the membership of the Chairperson of . Adjoa Gzifa, chairperson of the board for three years, speculated that the decision came when she declared her opposition to numerous high-profile street renaming proposals supported by then-Councilman Comrie, including slain officer John Scarangella and Sean Bell. Since her removal, Ms. Gzifa has reconciled with Comrie and even partnered with him on numerous initiatives.\n\n\nComrie has been married to Marcia Moxam since 1990. They have two children. He is a lifelong member of Saint Alban the Martyr Episcopal Church, where he served as a layperson, vestryman and chalice administrator.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n*\n*\n*\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
          }

    "pages": }\n\n'''Patrick M. Gallivan''' (born November 18, 1960) is a member of the  and the former . Gallivan's district, the , comprises portions of Erie County, the entirety of , the northern half of  and the towns of  and  in .\n\n\nGallivan was elected Sheriff of Erie County in 1998 and served through 2005.  Prior to being elected Sheriff, Patrick Gallivan served 15 years in the , rising through the ranks from  to . Between his time as Sheriff and as a New York State Senator, Gallivan served as a commissioner on the .\n\nAfter the retirement of incumbent senator , Gallivan defeated former Erie County Republican Party chairman James Domagalski and David DiPietro in a three-way Republican primary in September 2010, going on to defeat Democrat Cynthia Appleton and DiPietro (who continued to run on a line labeled \"\") in the general election in November of the same year. In 2011, Gallivan voted against allowing same-sex marriage in New York during the senate roll-call vote on the , which legally recognized same-sex marriages performed in the state, in a closely divided Senate vote of 33-29.\n\n\nGallivan lives in , with his wife, Mary Pat, and their two children, Jenna and Conor.\n\nGallivan's cousin, Pete Gallivan, is a reporter and anchor for Buffalo television station .\n\n\nPatrick Gallivan holds a master's degree in  from the  and is a graduate of  in Buffalo.  He is a graduate of both the FBI National Executive Institute and the , and is a past member of the New York State Executive Committee on Counter-Terrorism.\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''James E. Davis''' (April 3, 1962 – July 23, 2003) was an American politician who served on the  from 2002 until his .\n\n\nDavis was born and raised in , the son of a  and a . He was raised with his brother Geoffrey A. Davis. He spent his early childhood in  before his family moved to .\n\nHe earned a bachelor's degree at  in  and youth agency administration. He became a corrections officer at  after being beaten by two white police officers, and then became a police officer himself in 1991. In 1990, Davis had started an organization called \"Love Yourself Stop the Violence\" dedicated to stopping violence in urban America. The  soon assigned Davis to the  as an instructor, and he became a frequent guest on local radio and television programs.\n\n\n]]\nDavis eventually qualified as a  at Holy Trinity Baptist Church of Brooklyn  and became a district leader and then a  for 's  in November 2001.\n\nThe template for his successful City Council bid had been established by previous races against  and Democratic  Chairman , who narrowly defeated him in 1998. The campaign against the politically powerful Normanand Davis's high-profile generallyruffled feathers within the NYPD, and Davis was fired for violating a rule that prohibits paid city employees from engaging in electoral politics. In that November's election, his name was on the ballot on the old  line, for which Davis was fired from the NYPD.  After pursuing litigation against the police department, Davis's claim that he never formally accepted the Liberal Party nomination was upheld and he was allowed to reclaim his job. He was not, however, permitted to return to his former detail at the police academy, instead being assigned to a night shift at a Brooklyn precinct.\n\nHis next campaign in 2001 was successful but would later be a factor in his murder. Othniel Askew had raised funds to run against him, but had failed to file the proper papers on time, which led to accusations of political chicanery and caused Askew to harbor a grudge against Davis.\n\n\n\nOn July 23, 2003, Davis brought Askew to attend a council meeting at the council chambers in , with the intention of honoring him by introducing him from the balcony. The councilman and Askew were able to bypass the metal detectors, a courtesy offered to elected officials and their guests. Once in the balcony, and as the full council and dozens of attendees gathered into the chamber for the meeting, at 2:08&nbsp;p.m., Askew fired a silver .40 caliber weapon at Davis, striking him several times in the torso. Davis, a retired police officer, was carrying a weapon, but it remained holstered. A plainclothes policeman, Richard Burt, on duty as bodyguard to ,  of the City Council, then fired at Askew from the floor of the chamber, striking Askew five times. s arrived quickly, and attempted to revive both Davis and Askew before taking them to , where both men died. Askew had a history of violence. It was discovered after the murder that Askew had asked Davis to sign papers naming him as Davis's replacement in case anything happened to Davis.\n\n\nDavis's brother Geoffrey announced that he would run for the seat formerly held by his brother. He was defeated by fellow  , running on the  line.\n\n\n\nDavis was buried in  in Brooklyn. Upon learning his killer's ashes were also in Green-Wood, Davis's family had his body exhumed and reinterred in the .\n\n\nThe murder incident would be used as the basis for \"City Hall\", an episode of '''' which aired on February 11, 2004. However, in the adaptation, the dead councilman was an innocent bystander, with the second victim, a low-level bureaucrat who survived with a shoulder wound, as the true target.\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
          }
        ]
      }
    }

    "pages": }\n\n'''Guillermo Linares''' is a former  member of the  who had represented the 72nd Assembly District in  from 2015 to 2016, and previously from 2011 to 2012. He is a former  Council Member and a former New York City Commissioner of Immigrant Affairs.\n\n\nGuillermo Linares was born on August 30, 1951, in the town of Cabrera in the Dominican Republic; he was the oldest of nine children. He shares the experiences and aspirations of immigrant New Yorkers, having left his native Dominican Republic in 1966 and joining his parents who gained residency through the 1965 immigration reform, he arrived in the East Tremont section of the Bronx, at just 14 years old.  He began to learn the English language as he finished high school, gaining a General Equivalency Diploma from Theodore Roosevelt High School. Although initially discouraged from going to college by his high school guidance counselor, Linares was encouraged by his parents, who noted that as the eldest child, he had a responsibility to obtain a college degree. Taking on jobs, such as taxi driving, in order to pay for his college education, he became an American citizen during his sophomore year of college. He is currently married to Evelyn Linares, a public school principal. They have two children, Mayra and Guillermo, as well as a granddaughter, Ava and grandson, Dylan. He has often credited his family with being critical to his successes in community activism, public office, and academia.\n\n\n\nIn 1991, Linares became the first  elected to public office in  and tied for first in the United States with . He served from 1992 to 2001 in the . Linares also served as a member of the , when President  appointed him in 1999 as a commission chair. Linares was later appointed the NYC Commissioner of Immigrant Affairs in 2004.\n\nIn 2010 Linares was elected State Assemblyman for the 72nd District, replacing  who was elected to the State Senate. In 2012 he challenged Senator Espaillat in the Democratic Primary for New York's 31st State Senate district and lost 62-38%, after Senator Espaillat was defeated by longtime Congressman  in the Democratic Primary for  months earlier. He was replaced by former Assembly Member .\n\nIn 2014, after Assembly Member Rosa pleaded guilty to marriage fraud and resigned, Linares announced he would run for his old seat in the . He won a four-way Democratic Primary with 44.7% of the vote, and went on to win the general election with 91.5% of the vote. Linares was defeated for re-election in 2016 by  after unsuccessfully running for Congress earlier in the year.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Daniel J. O'Donnell''' (born November 17, 1960) is an American politician from the state of New York. A , he is a member of the . O'Donnell represents the  district in Manhattan, made up of the neighborhoods of , , and portions of the  and West Harlem.\n\nO'Donnell was the legislative sponsor of the  during its successful passage and signature into law on June 24, 2011. In 2010, he ushered in the passage of the anti-bullying Dignity for All Students Act. More recently, he led the charge to repeal 50-A and the gay panic defense and authored legislation making all public, single-occupancy bathrooms gender-neutral.\n\n\nBorn in , O'Donnell is one of five siblings. He is the brother of entertainer . Raised in  on , he attended  before transferring to  for his Bachelor of Arts. O'Donnell received a  from the  at .\n\n\nAfter graduating law school in 1984, O'Donnell worked for seven years as a public defender in the criminal defense division of Brooklyn's Legal Aid Society before opening his own law firm on the Upper West Side. His community practice helped clients with tenant representation, as well as civil rights litigation ranging from employee discrimination to First Amendment rights. Since 2002, he has represented the 69th District in the New York Assembly.\n\nO'Donnell first ran for the legislature in 1998, making an unsuccessful bid for the  in the 30th district; he lost the Democratic primary to .\n\nWhen Assemblyman  announced his retirement in 2002, O'Donnell was one of eight Democrats who entered the race to succeed him. In the crowded primary election held on September 10, 2002, O'Donnell won 34 percent of the vote, twice as much as his nearest competitor. In the  that followed, he prevailed with 82 percent of the vote.\n\nO'Donnell is the first openly gay man elected to the New York State Assembly.\n\nO'Donnell ran uncontested in the 2008 and 2010 s. He was opposed in the September 13, 2016 Democratic Primary by Steven M. Appel, but won over 73% of the vote.\n\nIn 2008, O'Donnell was considered by New York Governor  to fill the Senate vacancy created by the appointment of  as President Obama's Secretary of State. Paterson ultimately appointed upstate Congresswoman  to the seat.\n\nIn 2019, O'Donnell sought the New York City Public Advocate seat being vacated by , who had been elected for New York State attorney general. He was defeated in the Democratic primary by .\n\n\n\nAs of 2017, O'Donnell serves as Chair of the Assembly Committee on Tourism, Parks, Arts and Sports Development and Chair of the Subcommittee on Criminal Procedure. Previously, O'Donnell served as Chair of the Assembly Committee Corrections, Assembly Committee on Ethics and Guidance, as well as Chair of the Subcommittee on Criminal Procedure of the Assembly Judiciary Committee. He also serves on a number of full committees, namely:\n*Committee on Codes\n*Committee on Education\n*Committee on Environmental Conservation\n*Committee on Puerto Rican/Hispanic Task Force\n\n\nOn June 19, 2007, O'Donnell ushered the , a bill that would have legalized , to passage by a vote of 85–61. Although the bill passed the Assembly and had the support of then-Governor , the Republican-controlled  did not take up the measure. O'Donnell once again led the fight for a same-sex marriage bill in 2009, shepherding it to passage twice more, by a vote of 89–52 in May, and by a vote of 88–51 in December. O'Donnell introduced the Marriage Equality bill in the Assembly for the 2011–2012 legislative session on May 10, 2011. The Marriage Equality Act was passed by the NYS Assembly on June 15, 2011, and passed the NYS Senate and was signed into law by Governor  slightly before midnight on Friday, June 24, 2011.\n\nO'Donnell was the prime sponsor of the Dignity for All Students Act, one of the first laws in New York history to explicitly include protections based on gender identity and expression. In 2019, New York enacted his legislation to ban the so-called , which asks a jury to find that a victim's sexual orientation or gender identity is to blame for a defendant's violent reaction, including even murder. One year later, the legislature passed O'Donnell's bill requiring single-occupancy bathrooms to be gender-neutral with overwhelming bi-partisan support.\n\nBeginning in 2017, O'Donnell introduced legislation to repeal 50-a, which prevents the public disclosure of police records. The legislation languished until 2020, when the  renewed campaigns for repeal. On June 10, the New York State Legislature voted to repeal 50-a and on June 12, Governor Andrew Cuomo signed to repeal the law. The law repeals 50-a in its entiretyallowing individuals, lawyers, and the press to request police disciplinary files that have long been held in secret.\n\nAdditional legislative victories include: successfully lowering NYC speed limits to 25&nbsp;mph; expanding sexual harassment protections to unpaid interns; mandating mental health discharge plans for incarcerated individuals; and passing the Domestic Violence Escalation Prevention Act, which bans individuals convicted of domestic violence from owning any type of firearm.\n\nAssemblyman O'Donnell announced that he will not seek reelection to the New York State Assembly in November 2023 and will retire from election politics in January 2025.\n\n\nOn May 23, 2023, Assemblyman Daniel O'Donnell made a comment to Assemblymember Catalina Cruz that offended her as the Assemblyman walked out of the committee meeting on codes chaired by Assemblymember .  The bill (sponsored by Assemblymember ) being debated was regarding police officers seizing guns owned by suspects during domestic violence situations.  The members of the codes committee were also debating how many votes it needed to forward the bill out of committee onto the assembly floor for a vote. Cruz voted differently than O'Donnell. O'Donnell was sanctioned by Speaker  for his actions.\n\n\nIn 2011, O'Donnell was featured in '''''s \"Out 100,\" the magazine's list of the year's 100 most inspiring individuals.\n\nOn January 29, 2012, O'Donnell married his partner of 31 years, John Banta. The ceremony and reception were attended by over 400 people including Governor , Assembly Speaker , Comptroller , Attorney General , New York City Council Speaker , many of his colleagues from the Assembly and State Senate, family, and friends. The couple were married by , the former chief justice of the .\n\nHe has been interviewed in periodicals for the .\n\n\n* \n* \n* \n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n*\n*\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
