    "pages": }\n\n'''Noah Nickolas Perry''' (born August 1, 1950) is an American politician and diplomat who has served as the  since 2022. He served as a member of the  for the 58th district from 1993 to 2022. His former district included the neighborhood of , as well as portions of  and , among other neighborhoods located in the borough of .\n\n\nBorn and raised in , Noah Nickolas Perry graduated from  in Kingston, Jamaica. Perry graduated from  with a  degree in . He later returned to Brooklyn College to study for an  in public policy and administration.\n\n\nHe worked at the Bustamante Industrial Trade Union before immigrating to the United States in 1971. The following year he volunteered for the , from which he was honorably discharged at the rank of  in 1978 after having served as an active-duty serviceman for two years and inactive reserve for four years.\n\n\nIn 1983, Perry was appointed as a member of . He later served as chairman of that board and the following year he ran as a candidate for District Leader in the 42nd Assembly District. He would later serve as a member of the Executive Board of the 67th Police Precinct and as a director of Flatbush East Community Development Corporation.\n\nIn 1992, following the 1990 Census, a new assembly district was added in Brooklyn, located in . Perry won new 58th district seat in the November 1992 election.\n\nSince 2001, Perry has been the vice-chair of the Assembly Majority Conference and majority whip. He also serves on the New York State Assembly Committees on Ways & Means, Rules, Codes, Labor, Transportation and Banks.\n\nIn 2006, Perry declared his candidacy for , which was being vacated by retiring Congressman . In May 2006, he withdrew from the congressional race and endorsed eventual leader .\n\nPerry ran uncontested in his 2008, 2010 and 2012 s for State Assembly.\n\n\nIn November 2021, Perry was nominated to serve as . Hearings on his nomination were held before the  on February 8, 2022. On March 8, 2022, the committee favorably reported Perry's nomination to the Senate floor. Perry was confirmed by the entire Senate on March 10, 2022, via . On May 13, 2022, he presented his credentials to  .\n\n\nHe and his wife Joyce reside in the  neighborhood of Brooklyn. Perry's granddaughter is , a  recording artist.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n* Criticism of David Yassky by his former primary opponent.\n*\n*\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Roxanne Persaud''' (born March 1, 1966) is a Guyanese-American politician. She is a  and a member of the  for the , which includes portions of , , , , , , , ,  and  in .\n\n\nA native of , Persaud immigrated with her family to  as a young person. She is of  ( and ) heritage. She graduated from  with both a  and  in Education Administration before entering a career in education.\n\nPersaud previously served as a school administrator with Pace University and , Brooklyn, and also was involved with her  in , and has served on numerous boards and commissions for the community. In 2015, Persaud won the Democratic nomination to succeed  in the , and served from January to November 2015.\n\n\nIn 2015, Senator  was found guilty of corruption and forced to resign. Persaud, then a first-term Assemblywoman, was chosen by the Kings County Democratic Party to succeed him, and easily won election that November to finish his term. In 2016, Persaud faced a primary challenge from , who was backed by Assemblyman  and Councilwoman . Persaud easily defeated Narcisse with over 75% of the vote. Persaud easily won re-election in 2016, 2018, and 2020.\n\nPersaud was sworn in as state Senator on November 4, 2015. In 2019, with Democrats gaining the majority in the Senate, Persaud was named Chair of the Social Services Committee.\n\n\n\n\n\n* ''official site''\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Julie Menin''' (born October 6, 1967) is a member of the  from . Before she was elected to this position, she served as an American attorney, civil servant, non-profit executive, professor and small business owner. In January 2019, she was appointed Director of the Census for NYC and Executive Assistant Corporation Counsel for Strategic Advocacy. Previously, she had worked as the Commissioner of the New York City Mayor's Office of Media and Entertainment and Commissioner of .\n\n\nMenin is the daughter of Agnes and Robert Jacobs. Her mother was a painter and her father a radiologist. Menin earned a  Degree magna cum laude from  and received her  from . Ms. Menin lived in the  and was a resident at the time of the infamous  Break-In. “People talk about the break-in as if I could have seen it,” said Ms. Menin.\n\n\n\nMenin began her career in 1992 as a regulatory attorney at  in , where she represented clients in matters involving federal and state enforcement agencies. She later became Senior Regulatory Attorney at Colgate-Palmolive in New York City, where she played a lead role in numerous agency cases involving the Department of Justice, the Environmental Protection Agency, and the Federal Trade Commission, and also litigated disputes in state and federal courts. In 1999, she opened and operated Vine, a restaurant, market, and catering operation in  with more than 75 employees.\n\n\nFollowing 9/11, Menin founded and was the president of the nonprofit Wall Street Rising, which worked for the recovery of the downtown neighborhood. She helped small businesses access grants, insurance, and other monetary aid; grew the organization to 30,000 members; and created a variety of programs, including the Retail Attraction Program, which helped more than 600 small businesses stay in lower Manhattan.\n\nUnder her leadership, the organization launched the \"Music Downtown\" and \"Art Downtown\" series, which provided cultural and entertainment amenities to local residents in an effort to revitalize Lower Manhattan. Menin worked with artists including Mikhail Baryshnikov on these programs.\n\n\nBeginning in 2005, Menin served as Chairperson for , where she was unanimously elected for three consecutive terms totaling seven years.\n\nAs chair of CB1, Menin worked on numerous  and  issues, led a successful campaign to build New York City's first \"green\" school and other initiatives to revitalize Lower Manhattan. Menin has been recognized for her \"solution-based\" approach to controversial issues in the wake of 9/11 and as chair of CB1.\n\nShe successfully pushed to move the trial of 9-11 mastermind Khalid Sheik Mohammed out of Lower Manhattan, while maintaining the importance of a federal trial. resulting in the Obama Administration backing out of New York City \n\nOn May 25, 2010, Menin presided over the Community Board's 29-1 vote in favor of a proposed Islamic cultural center and mosque, where she urged that an interfaith center (where all different religions can worship) be part of the plans.\n\nIn 2011, Menin was praised for her efforts to balance the rights of Occupy Wall Street protesters with quality-of-life concerns of residents.\n\n\nMenin ran in the Democratic primary for Manhattan Borough President in September 2013, and finished fourth behind New York City Council Members ,  and .\n\nIn 2017, Menin returned $201,000 to the  to cover funds that had remained in her campaign finance account from the 2013 election since she had raised additional funds and by law had to be returned to the Board since they had not been spent.\n\n\nUnder Menin's leadership, the  has launched initiatives to protect consumers from fraud, scams, and predatory conduct, and expanded the Agency's role in areas such as financial empowerment and investigative legal enforcement. DCA has increased its consumer restitution by 72 percent over the prior year, returning money to consumers who have been victims of fraud, scams and predatory conduct. At DCA she also implemented New York City's paid sick leave law and launched a new Earned Income Tax Credit initiative that resulted in over $250 million being returned to low-income New Yorkers.\n\n\n\nIn February 2016, Menin was appointed Commissioner of The Mayor's Office of Media and Entertainment, an agency that comprises the  and . The Office of Film, Theatre and Broadcasting serves as a one-stop shop for the entertainment industry, a sector that contributes nearly $9 billion to the City of New York's economy and employs over 130,000 New Yorkers. NYC Media is responsible for managing and programming all of the media assets for the City of New York, which includes a television broadcast network reaching over 18 million people, a radio station and four local cable stations. The agency has seen record growth in both film projects and television series produced in the city. She negotiated the deal to bring the Grammy Awards back to New York after a 15 year absence, resulting in a $200 million benefit to New York City.\n\nIn 2016, the office launched a five-part initiative to support women both behind and in-front of the camera in film and television and in theater, the first of its kind for a U.S. city. That same year, Menin launched Made in NY Writers Room, a diversity initiative that awards fellowships and mentorship opportunities to traditionally under-represented television writers, and #NominateNYC, a campaign to increase diversity among the voting members of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences. In an effort to reduce the carbon footprint of the film and television industry, Menin created NYC Film Green, an environmental initiative that promotes and recognizes sustainable practices on the sets of film and television productions.\n\n\nIn January 2019, Menin was announced as Director of the Census for NYC and Executive Assistant Corporation Counsel for Strategic Advocacy by Mayor . Menin is responsible for organizing New York City's efforts to have every resident to participate in the upcoming 2020 Census. Menin successfully advocated against the Trump administration's attempt to add a citizenship question to the 2020 census.\n\nThe Census results captured a gain of 629,000 residents for New York City as the City grew more in total population than any other city in America.\n\n\nMenin is an adjunct professor at the . She served on the board of trustees of Columbia University.\n\n\nIn 2021, Menin was elected to represent the  of the , which encompasses the Upper East Side, East Harlem, Yorkville, Midtown East, Carnegie Hill, Sutton Place, Roosevelt Island, and Lenox Hill neighborhoods of Manhattan. In the 2021 Democratic primary, she garnered 56% of the vote in the final round of ranked choice voting. She defeated Republican Mark Foley in the general election, winning over 75% of the vote.\n\nMenin serves as Chair of the Council’s Small Business Committee. As Chair, she introduced and passed legislation that created a “One Stop Shop” to streamline small business interactions for all city agency permits and fines into one portal and ease regulatory burdens small businesses face.\n\nMenin also introduced five of the bills as part of the historic package the Council passed to make New York City the first in the country to have Universal Childcare. In March 2023, Mayor  moved forward with the implementation of Universal Childcare launching the first phase of MyCity Portal, which provided an eligibility screening tool and streamlined childcare application processes.\n\nMenin also introduced the Healthcare Accountability and Consumer Protection Act, legislation that would create the nation’s first ever municipal Office of Healthcare Accountability. The bill has garnered support from over 40 other Council Members and leading labor unions in New York City.\n\nMenin has announced that she is running for re-election in 2023.\n\nMenin is a member of the Vote Blue Coalition, a progressive group and  created to support Democrats in New York, New Jersey, and Pennsylvania through voter outreach and mobilization efforts.\n\n\nIn 1999, she married  in a Jewish ceremony at the . She resides in Manhattan with her husband and four children.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n|birth_place = , , U.S.\n|death_date  = \n|death_place = New York City, U.S.\n|party       = \n|education   =  \n}}\n'''Howard Joseph Samuels''' (December 3, 1919 – October 26, 1984) was an American statesman, industrialist, civil rights activist and philanthropist who served as  and Director of the  under President Johnson, special advisor to the campaign for president by  and the administration of President .\n\nA graduate of the , Samuels served as a colonel in the  under General . Upon conclusion of service, Samuels co-founded the . Following the principles he set on his senior thesis, Kordite was the first to produce synthetic products for household consumerism and introduced a number of mainstays including the , wax paper, plastic wrap, disposable kitchenware, and a sturdy trash bag that became the  brand. The success of the company made Samuels one of the wealthiest , and financially able to enter politics.\n\nThe  nominee for  in 1966 on a ticket headed by , Samuels also contended unsuccessfully for the nomination for Governor three times from 1962 to 1974. He lost the 1970 primary to  and the 1974 primary to . He also served as special aide to New York City Mayor  prior to his appointment as the first Chairman of the . Samuels is credited with alerting voters to the need for a , forming the non-partisan group Citizens Committee for Constitutional Convention. Members included Secretaries of the Health, Education & Welfare and Commerce departments in the , numerous Commissioners and administrators to  and City agencies, and Senators  and . Governor  would later sign the bill.\n\nSamuels' foray into national politics was met with resistance and criticism among the traditional political guards of both parties. His resurrection and renewed interpretation of the defunct wartime program  spearheaded the SBA into the forefront of the . The agency's  program was the first institutionalized  and  policy which he dubbed , or black capitalism. Though hailed by many civil rights activist and minorities alike, the program faced mounting criticism and disapproval from within the Democratic controlled , members of President Johnson's own cabinet and threats of censorship and dismissal from  Senators who cited the program as  As the  continued into the 1970s, Samuels became the principal financial backer to numerous war marches including  Veterans for Vietnam . Samuels became a vocal advocate for  and  in  and State policy following the arrest of his son, , and revelation of his  to heroin.\n\nHis pioneering methods in the  and success in the then niche household  market translated into posts as Vice President of the , Commissioner of the , and Chairman to Elms Capital Management, , and . In 1988, the  opened the Howard Samuels State Management and Policy Center.\n\n\nHe graduated from  with an  in Management, and then joined the . He served as a  in the  under General . He was present during the liberation of the   in  in 1945.\n\n\n\n\nAfter the war, he and his brother Richard founded the Kordite Company, a firm that manufactured plastic clotheslines, brooms, plastic bags and packaging, and other plastic products such as  and  garbage bags.\n\n\nIn , Samuels was among the contenders for the  nomination for , but  was chosen by the state convention delegates. In , the party rank and file revolted against the wishes of state party leaders and nominated him over Orin D. Lehman for . The ticket, headed by gubernatorial candidate , was defeated by the  nominees, Gov.  and Lt. Gov. . In 1970, Samuels lost the Democratic primary for governor to former  .\n\n\nIn , Samuels was the Democratic State Committee designee for Governor. He was challenged in the  by Congressman , and despite an early lead, Samuels lost again, and Carey was subsequently elected Governor.\n\n\nIn 1971, Mayor Lindsay chose Samuels to be the first chairman of the , a position which earned him the nickname \"Howie the Horse.\"\n\n\nSamuels served as U.S. Under Secretary of Commerce in the administration of President , and in 1968 was named Director of the . In 1969, he irritated many in his own party when he supported a liberal Republican, , in his successful bid for re-election as . In , he challenged , the Democratic designee for Governor, but lost narrowly in the . That year his political work was interrupted when his son, Howard Samuels, was arrested for  possession in . The son was later arrested for possession of  and reported to have developed a heroin addiction. In 1971, Howard J. Samuels was elected to the  National Governing Board.\n\n\nHe married Barbara J. Christie, and they had eight children: William, Carey, Catherine, Victoria, Howard, Barbara, Jacqui and Janine. He later married , daughter of a Prime Minister of France, . They had two children, Camille and Dominique.\n\n\nOn October 26, 1984, Samuels died of a heart attack at his home in New York City.  His funeral was attended by many leading political figures. He received eulogies from Governor  of New York, Senator  of , Senator  of , Senator  of  and his best friend Ed R. Downe. Mr. Downe has led annual prayer services with Howard's family for 25 years (2009) in the Southampton, New York cemetery. Former New York governor , once an opponent, remembered him as \"a highly principled gentleman with a well-developed civic and social conscience.\" Cuomo said that Samuels was \"a gentle, compassionate man ... (who) had the instincts, talents, and compassion to have been a great governor.\" \"He was a better man and a visionary than a politician,\" stated journalist , formerly Samuels' campaign manager.\n\n\n* \n* \n* \n* \n* \n* \n* \n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Robert Rolison''' is a politician currently serving in the  and a retired American law enforcement officer.\n\n\n\nIn 1982, Rolison joined the 's police department and served for 12 years in the patrol division and 14 additional years as a detective.\n\n\nFrom 2003 to 2015, Rolison served on the  Legislature as a county legislator, serving as chairman of the legislature from 2010 to 2015.\n\nFrom 2016 to 2022 he served as mayor of the city of  .\n\nIn 2022, Rolison announced a bid for State Senate District 39, and flipped the seat to red after a victory margin of 6,738 votes.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Eric Dinowitz''' (born November 21, 1985) is an American teacher and politician. Dinowitz represents the  of the . Dinowitz is a registered . Dinowitz was elected in a  held on March 23, 2021, after the resignation of , who was elected to the New York Supreme Court. Dinowitz assumed office on April 15, 2021 after weeks of the  counting  ballots which were instituted for municipal elections beginning in 2021.\n\nThe 11th district includes , , , , , , and  in .\n\n\nDinowitz was born in 1985 to New York State Assemblyman  and Sylvia Gottlieb in the Northwestern . He graduated from the  and received his  from , as well as a  in education from  Dinowitz spent fifteen years as a special education classroom teacher in the New York City Public Schools. As an active member of his union, the , he served as a chapter leader. Eric was the Democratic District Leader for New York's 81st Assembly District and has also served as the Aging Committee Chair of the .\n\nIn 2021, Dinowitz was named to the  Labor 40 Under 40 list.\n\n\n\n* In 2021, Dinowitz was appointed to the following  committees:\n** Chair of the Committee on Veterans\n** Committee on Aging\n** Committee on Civil Service and Labor\n** Committee on Education\n** Committee on Mental Health, Disabilities, and Addictions\n** Committee on Oversight and Investigations\n** Committee on Parks and Recreation\n** Committee on Small Business\nDinowitz was also appointed Chairman of the New York City Council Jewish Caucus.\n\n\nCalls were made for Dinowitz to  as head of the Jewish caucus following revelations an Anti-Israel activist was named as director of the progressive caucus of which Dinowitz is also a member. Hank Sheinkopf, a former advisor to President Clinton and prominent NYC democrat advisor said \"If Dinowitz remains a member of the City Council Progressive Caucus headed by an Israel-hater, he cannot head the Jewish Caucus.\" Meyer is against aid to Israel and opposes AIPAC.\n\n\nDinowitz is a member of New York-based Jewish  group , who have performed worldwide, as well as making an appearance at the  Hanukkah Party in 2016, hosted by President .\n\n\nEric is married to Tamar Dinowitz. They have twin sons, Alex and Jesse.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Deborah J. Glick''' (born December 24, 1950) is a member of the  representing the 66th Assembly District in , including the neighborhoods of , , , SoHo, the , the , , and . She is a .\n\n\n\nGlick is a lifelong resident of  and has lived in Greenwich Village for over 40 years. A graduate of the City University of New York's , she received a  degree from . Glick owned and managed a small printing business in TriBeCa before becoming deputy director of general services at the New York City Department of Housing, Preservation, and Development, where she worked until May 1990.\n\nGlick's political activism began in college, and she is still strongly involved in grassroots organizing. Glick first ran for the State Assembly in 1990 and won, becoming the first openly gay state legislator in New York State She has served in the legislature for 30 years, championing a number of progressive legislative causes as well as key local issues. She is Jewish.\n\n\n\nGlick serves as the Chair of the Assembly's Higher Education Committee, which oversees all private and public higher education institutions, financial assistance for students, and professional licensing, a position she has held since 2007. Additionally, Glick serves on the Ways and Means, Rules, Governmental Operations, and Environmental Conservation Committees. She also serves as the Chair of the Assembly's Intern Program, overseeing the Assembly's student interns.\n\nAs an Assembly member, her legislative priorities have focused on women's rights, including expanding access to reproductive healthcare; LGBTQ rights; environmental preservation and protection; the protection of animals, especially those in shelters; higher education; tenants' rights; increasing pedestrian and traffic safety; maintaining and expanding open space; and support for the arts.\n\nGlick is a member of the Vote Blue Coalition, a progressive group and  created to support Democrats in New York, New Jersey, and Pennsylvania through voter outreach and mobilization efforts. \n\n\n\nGlick's legislative victories include the passage of the Sexual Orientation Non-Discrimination Act (SONDA), which was finally signed into law in December 2002. Glick's Hospital Visitation Bill became law in 2004, providing domestic partners the same rights that spouses and next-of-kin have when caring for a loved one in a hospital or nursing facility.\n\nShe has worked on issues of concern to women for over thirty years, including advocating for reproductive freedom, a change in the rape statutes, and women's health concerns. The Women's Health and Wellness Act, a bill that promotes early detection and prevention of certain medical conditions affecting women, including breast cancer and osteoporosis, and provides coverage for contraceptives, became law on January 1, 2003. Glick was the lead sponsor of the Reproductive Health Act, to codify and expand protections granted in Roe v. Wade in New York State, which was signed into law in January 2019.\n\nDeborah Glick supported the legalization of  in the State of New York with some minor adjustments and changes to the bill to protect the surrogate and the parties involved in regards to monetary compensation.\nThe bill was first introduced in the New York State Assembly in 2012 by . Governor Andrew Cuomo signed it into law in 2021, effectively repealing the ban on the medical procedure with monetary compensation for the pregnant women involved. Glick believes in family planning methods and stated on Twitter in October 2021 that there is a problem called overpopulation of people on the planet, causing damage to the Earth.\n\n\n\nGlick is an animal lover and has sponsored and helped pass a number of bills to improve animal welfare. These include the Veterinary Emergency Response and Mobility Act, which allows out-of-state veterinarians and veterinary technicians to provide assistance in New York during declared disasters and high-volume animal cruelty investigations; an act to prohibit the importation, possession, sale, or release of Eurasian boars in New York State; and a law prohibiting the online shooting of animals or targets. She has also fought for increased funding for animal shelters and was twice successful in allocating a $5 million capital matching grant to humane societies across the state.\n\n\n\nIn her role as Chair of the Higher Education Committee, Glick has championed the SUNY and CUNY systems and the rights of students. Among her legislative achievements, Glick was the primary sponsor of the Student Lending Accountability, Transparency, and Enforcement Act, which established protections for students and parents to protect them from exploitative student loans and became law in 2007. She also sponsored and championed legislation to implement the Enough is Enough Program, which requires New York State higher education institutions to adopt a state-wide uniform definition of affirmative consent and a number of policies protecting the rights of sexual assault victims and those who report assaults. Glick has also been an ardent supporter of the rights of student workers, such as graduate teaching and research assistants, to collectively bargain through establishing union chapters.\n\n\n\nDuring her tenure, Glick has been a strong advocate for tenants' rights and has sponsored and won renewal of the Loft Law. This law brings formerly commercial buildings up to residential code and protects current tenants, many of them artists, from eviction. This law became permanent in 2010. Deborah has always been a strong proponent of the arts and has consistently advocated for increases in funding state-wide because of her conviction that the arts play a crucial role in the economic and cultural life of New York City and New York State. Currently, she is the sponsor of several measures to protect the rights of tenants, as well as legislation to provide a tax credit to renters.\n\n\n\nGlick has been a champion for pedestrian safety. She was the lead Assembly sponsor of a bill establishing a pilot program to install speed cameras in school zones in 2013, which studies show has demonstrably reduced dangerous driving in those zones. Glick has championed legislation to expand that program, which has been blocked by the New York State Senate; however, after the pilot program expired in 2018, it was renewed and expanded by the New York City Council.\n\nGlick was also the primary sponsor of bills allowing cities to set speed limits below 25 miles per hour, requiring motorists to yield to pedestrians in crosswalks uncontrolled by traffic signals, and requiring those under 16 to use seat belts when riding in the backseat.\n\n\n\nGlick has long fought against efforts to privatize open space in her district and has been a strong proponent of maintaining and increasing park space in her district and in New York City. Glick was active in the fight against developing the Westside piers into , and since the park's creation, he has fought at the state and city level for adequate funding for the park's maintenance and against efforts to privatize parts of the park.\n\nGlick has also been involved in grassroots community activism to preserve open space, including the preservation of the . She was the lead sponsor on a bill that aided in the creation of the , the first national monument honoring the history of the LGBT rights movement.\n\n\n\nGlick was the lead sponsor of legislation requiring the MTA to make 100 key stations fully accessible. While the MTA has not completed this work, Glick has advocated for its completion and for expanding accessibility to additional stations.\n\n\n\nOn Tuesday, September 14, 2016, Deborah Glick defeated Jim Fourratt in the Democratic Party primary.  She won 3151 out of the 3928 votes cast.  Jim received 777 votes.\n\n\nOn Election Day in 2014, Glick defeated two opponents in the general election.  The Assemblywoman won 16817 votes out of the 21089 votes cast.  Progressive Party candidate Alexander R. Meadows received 1545 votes, and Republican Party nominee Nekeshia Woods received 2727 votes.\n\n \n* \n* \n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* \n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Roy J. McDonald''' (born April 12, 1947) is a   and former member of the New York State Legislature who represented the  in the New York State Senate and Districts 100 and 112 in the New York State Assembly. McDonald served as Town and County Supervisor for the Town of  for 23 years. Following his tenure as Supervisor, McDonald served in the Assembly from 2002 to 2008 and served in the Senate from 2009 to 2012.\n\nMcDonald is notable as one of four Republican members of the New York State Senate that voted in favor of the  in 2011. In 2012, he was defeated in a Republican primary by his eventual successor, .\n\n\n\nFor 23 years, McDonald was Town and County Supervisor for the Town of  and in 1986, served a term as Chairman of the Saratoga County Board of Supervisors. His two grandsons have , and McDonald has been a leader regarding autism awareness, creating the Saratoga County Autism Council and sponsoring legislation. Before being elected to the New York State Senate in District 43 on November 4, 2008, McDonald had served in the  since 2002, representing the 100th and 112th Districts, respectively. During McDonald's tenure, Senate District 43 included all of  and part of .\n\nSen. McDonald lost his bid for re-election to the Senate in 2012; he was defeated by Kathleen Marchione in a Republican primary.\n\n\n\nOn June 16, 2011, McDonald spoke to the press on his intended support for New York State's upcoming vote on .  In response to the pressure he was receiving from other Republicans to vote against the measure, he is quoted as saying:\nYou get to the point where you evolve in your life where everything isn't black and white, good and bad, and you try to do the right thing. You might not like that. You might be very cynical about that. Well, fuck it, I don't care what you think. I'm trying to do the right thing. I'm tired of Republican-Democrat politics. They can take the job and shove it. I come from a blue-collar background. I'm trying to do the right thing, and that's where I'm going with this.\n\nWhen same-sex marriage legislation was passed by the Senate on June 24, 2011, Senator McDonald voted \"yes.\"  McDonald had previously voted \"no\" on same-sex marriage legislation in 2009. McDonald was one of four Republican state senators to vote in favor of the bill.\n\nFollowing his vote in favor of same-sex marriage, McDonald and the three other Republican senators who voted in favor of the bill saw a massive increase in fundraising, which included money generated from an event hosted by New York City Mayor Michael Bloomberg.\n\n\n\nOn March 18, 2012, the   County Committee declined to renominate Senator McDonald for re-election. McDonald did receive the support of the .\n\nOn April 4, 2012, Saratoga County Clerk Kathleen Marchione announced that she would challenge McDonald in a Republican primary in .  One writer commented that the McDonald-Marchione primary contest \"could prove to be one of the state's most hotly contested races because of McDonald's recent voting pattern, notably his votes to enact same-sex marriage and Gov. Andrew Cuomo's tax plan.\"\n\nAfter a primary contest that was variously described as \"divisive\", \"bitter,\" and \"nasty,\" the results of the McDonald-Marchione race were initially too close to call.  Marchione declared victory on September 25, 2012, while McDonald's campaign announced that the senator was considering his options. Marchione defeated McDonald by 99 votes. Later that week, Gov. Andrew Cuomo, a Democrat, weighed in on the race by announcing his support for McDonald to continue his re-election bid on a third-party line. Following his primary defeat, McDonald opted to cease his campaign and throw his support to Marchione, stating that he was \"very proud of [his] time in public service\" and that \"[s]tanding up for the communities [he] represented was always [his] first priority\". Marchione went on to win the general election on November 6, 2012, defeating Democrat Robin Andrews and McDonald (who received 20,929 votes on the  line despite having suspended his campaign).\n\nFollowing McDonald's loss in his 2012 primary, a  headline described the senator as \"a political casualty of same-sex marriage.\"\n\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n*\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
          }

    "pages": }\n\n'''Daniel L. Squadron''' (born November 9, 1979) is an American politician and former member of the  for the .\n\nA , Squadron was elected a , and was a candidate in the  for . In August 2017, he resigned from the NY State Senate to work with entrepreneur  and  of  to launch Future Now, a national initiative to promote \"policies focused on creating a better, healthier, fairer future.\"\n\n\nDaniel Squadron was born in 1979. His mother is Anne Strickland Squadron, and his father was  of the law firm  and Chairman of the Conference of Presidents of Major American Jewish Organizations. His brother, Bill Squadron, was the head of .\n\nSquadron attended the private  and graduated from  in 2003. During his junior year, he cofounded and managed What Bar, a bar near .\n\n\n\n\nSquadron served as a consultant to New York City's Department of Education and worked as a staffer on Congressman 's 2005 mayoral campaign. He served as an aide to  , helping the New York senator with his book '''' (2007).''\n\n\nSquadron ran for the 25th district of the New York State Senate in 2008. He received the endorsements of Schumer, Congressman ,  , and  . Assisted by family friends, Schumer supporters, and an aggressive campaign strategy, Squadron defeated incumbent state senator  and took 54% of the vote. On November 6, 2012, Squadron was elected to the state senate again, this time to represent the 26th district. He beat his Republican opponent, J. Haro, 86% to 14%. Squadron won reelection in 2014 in a landslide over Republican candidate Wave Chan; and he ran unopposed in 2016, running on both the Democratic and  lines.\n\nSquadron's platform included opposition to luxury development in . He negotiated a deal that reduced and delayed housing in the park, and has been credited with returning $11 million in capital funding that had been cut from the park's budget. Squadron also secured millions for a waterfront park project on the Lower East Side at Pier 42, along with , and also helped secure the future of . Squadron's proposal to link New York's wealthiest parks conservancies with under-resourced neighborhood parks resulted in hundreds of millions in new funding for community parks.\n\nIn 2010, Squadron sponsored the law that brought billions in federal dollars to  Squadron also passed legislation expanding middle class eligibility for the .\n\nSquadron's tenure included a noted focus on ethics and campaign finance reform. He passed the law prohibiting public officers from using government resources for their own for-profit business. Squadron also unsuccessfully pushed to close the \"LLC Loophole,\" which allows nearly unlimited, often anonymous campaign contributions to flood the political process.\n\nOn August 9, 2017, Squadron announced his resignation from the Senate in an opinion piece published in the ''Daily News.'' He cited \"heavily invested special interests\" and \"cynical political deals,\" adding: \"And the status quo has proven extraordinarily durable: It barely shuddered when the leaders of both legislative chambers [Senate Majority Leader  and  Speaker ] were convicted of corruption.\"\n\n\n\nIn the race for Public Advocate, Squadron had the endorsements of mentor Senator Chuck Schumer, and former   and . Squadron placed second in the primary and advanced to an October 2013 , which he lost to , by 59% to 41%.\n\n\nIn August 2017, Squadron announced he would be working with entrepreneur  and  of  on a national initiative focused on \"stronger candidates, a sharpened approach and better policies at the state level\", emphasizing \"policies focused on creating a better, healthier, fairer future\". In October 2017, that initiative was launched as . The initiative is now known as The States Project.\n\n\nSquadron is married to Elizabeth Weinstein, a former director in Mayor Bloomberg's Office of Operations. The couple were set up by Schumer and his wife, , for whom Weinstein worked as chief of staff at the . Squadron lives in  with his wife and two sons.\n\nAccording to Squadron, a  established for him and 18 other family members was lost in the  .\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* \n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

She was elected in November 2021 to represent the , which includes all or parts of the  neighborhoods of , , , and . Her term began on January 1, 2022.\n\n\n\nSchulman was born in Queens, New York, and raised in the neighborhood of Forest Hills. She was educated in the , and her mother worked as a substitute teacher. The Brian Lehrer Show |url=https://www.wnyc.org/story/51-council-members-52-weeks-district-29-lynn-schulman/ |access-date=2023-02-07 |website=WNYC |language=en}} She went on to graduate from  with a  degree in journalism and political science, and later from  with a  degree.\n\nSchulman first became involved in politics when she campaigned for , a member of the  from  seeking election to the .\n\n\n\nSchulman, an attorney, worked in various government and healthcare nonprofit roles prior to her election to the City Council. In , she served in the  administration of  and the offices of New York City Councilwomen  and . Schulman also worked in  as an aide to New York State Assemblyman . Schulman was then employed at the  services nonprofit , before she managed business affairs at the  for over a decade. Afterward, Schulman returned to New York City government, where she worked in the Office of the New York City Council Speaker until her inauguration.\n\nSchulman also held multiple volunteer public service roles in Forest Hills. She served as vice chair of  and as a member of the 112th Precinct Council, District 28 Community Education Council, and the Board of Directors of the Forest Hills Chamber of Commerce. Schulman gained local notoriety for her healthcare advocacy, which she said \"was born out of the HIV/AIDS movement\" and later influenced by her breast cancer diagnosis during her 2021 City Council campaign.\n\nSchulman ran unsuccessfully for the City Council in 2001 and 2009 in the same district that she now represents.  editorial board endorsed Schulman during her 2009 campaign, writing, \"Ms. Schulman argues more powerfully for better access to schools and more affordable housing and health care.\"\n\n\nDuring Schulman's 2021 primary campaign for the vacant  seat, she received influential endorsements from the , , U.S. Representative , and labor unions including , the , the , and the .\n\nSchulman defeated eight other candidates in a June 2021  primary, the first  in which  was implemented in New York City. She received 60.0 percent of the vote in the final round, and the results were certified the following month by the . Schulman then advanced to the November 2021 general election, in which she defeated one candidate running on the  and  lines to win the position.\n\n\nSchulman took office as a member of the New York City Council on January 1, 2022. She was named chair of the committee on health by Speaker  soon after. Schulman also sits on the committees on aging, criminal justice, education, fire and emergency management, and governmental operations, as well as the subcommittee on zoning and franchises.\n\nSchulman's primary legislative focuses have included increasing hospital capacity, protecting maternal rights, investing in green space, and improving government responses to public health crises, including the  and the .\n\nSchulman, who is Jewish and gay, is a member of the , , and .\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Carmen E. Arroyo''' (born June 2, 1933) is an American politician and a native of  who is the first  woman elected to the . She served the 84th Assembly District, which covers the , , , , , Concourse, and  sections of the .\n\n\nArroyo was born and raised in the town of in  where she received both her primary and secondary education. She graduated from Corozal High School and then attended the Sixto Febus Business School where she took Secretarial and Bookkeeping courses and earned a diploma. She married Pablo Arroyo and together they had seven children; she was eventually abandoned by her husband and she then decided to move to the .\n\nIn 1964, Arroyo moved to  with her children and settled down in the borough of the . While the idea of the move to the United States was a search for a better way of life she was soon faced with racial discrimination and other hardships. Arroyo became dependent on the welfare and public assistance systems of the state.\n\nArroyo took classes in  and attended Eugenio María de Hostos Community College, of the  (CUNY) where in 1978 she earned her Associate of Arts degree. Arroyo studied at night and worked during the day while she attended the . She earned her Bachelor of Arts degree from said educational institution in 1980.\n\n\nArroyo organized a group of welfare mothers and formed the  Action Group in 1966. She became the group's executive director and with the federal funds which the group received she was able to provide the community with services in employment, health and adult education. In 1978 Arroyo became the Executive Director of the South Bronx Community Corporation where she worked to develop private homes in the South Bronx that were sold to families and residents of the South Bronx Community. She was also instrumental in the construction of 194 housing units for senior citizens becoming the first Puerto Rican woman housing developer in .\n\n\nIn a special election held in February, 1994, Arroyo ran and was elected to the , representing the 84th District which includes the Bronx and thus became the first Puerto Rican woman elected to the Assembly and the first Puerto Rican woman elected to any state assembly in the United States. Among the committees which she has been assigned to are those on:\n*Alcoholism and Drug Abuse;\n*Children and Families; and\n*Education and Aging committees.\n\nArroyo has also been involved with:\n*The Assembly/Senate Puerto Rican/Hispanic Task Force,\n*The Black and Puerto Rican Caucus,\n*The Women's Caucus,\n*The National Order of Women Legislators, and\n*The New York City Commission on the Status of Women\n\nArroyo's daughter,  has followed in her mother's footsteps and ran for a seat in New Yorks City Council and was sworn in on March 21, 2005, representing District 17 of the Bronx. On April 23, 2004, New York State Governor  presented Arroyo with the Champions of Housing Award in a reception held in .\n\nNY State Assemblywoman Carmen Arroyo has been sued by the state Board of Elections 21 times since 2006-for a total of $12,700- for failing to file campaign finance disclosures. The nondisclosure is a violation of state election laws that often results in heavy fines, but little else. Arroyo has an established record of ignoring the deadlines.\n\nBoard of Elections Officer Risa Sugarman referred Arroyo to the state attorney general in 2015 due to numerous financial irregularities. Including a number of 'loans' allegedly made in 2014\" by the campaign committee to Arroyo. At least one of the loans appeared to have been paid directly to Empire City Casino in Yonkers, Sugarman wrote.'''', Bronx, 2 MAY 2016. Retrieved on 30 AUGUST 2018.\n\nIn total, $3,322 in campaign funds were either withdrawn from an ATM located at the casino or used to make at least one direct purchase at the facility, Sugarman found.\n\nAccording to a footnote in the letter, a January 2015 bank statement from Chase indicates that a \"loan\" of $518 made on Jan. 2 of that year was a \"card purchase\" made to Empire City Casino.\n\nIn addition in 2013, it was found that individuals who worked on Arroyo's daughters campaign in 2013 had forged petition signatures for ballot access in her reelection to council. She also came under fire for paying her son over $55,000 from her campaign account for a part-time advisory role.\n\n\nCarmen Arroyo currently continues to hold her political position and has published her autobiography titled \"''Carmen Arroyo: Puertorriqueña en Nueva York, mujer de armas tomadas''\" (Carmen Arroyo: Puerto Rican Female in New York). She also published a book of poems titled \"''Mis Poemas''\" (My Poems). Assemblywoman Arroyo currently serves as Chair of the Sub-Committee on the Effective Treatment of Alcoholism and Drug Addiction, Chair of the Sub-Committee on Bilingual Education, Chair of the Assembly Office of State and Federal Affairs, and Chair of the Assembly and Senate Puerto Rican/Hispanic Task Force.\n\n\n\n*\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
          }

    "pages": }\n\n'''Robert L. Turner''' (born May 2, 1941) is an American businessman and politician who served as the  for  (containing parts of  and ) from 2011 to 2013. He is a member of the .\n\nTurner is a retired media executive known for his success in the television talk show segment of the industry. Six years after retiring from his business career, he entered politics to run against Democratic Rep.  in November 2010. He lost the race, receiving 39 percent of the vote. Less than one year later, following Weiner's resignation due to a , Turner defeated Democrat , 52%–47%, in a  battle for Weiner's seat; Turner became the first Republican to represent the area since 1923. In , after his congressional district was eliminated in redistricting, Turner ran for the  but was defeated in the primaries. Turner later served as chairman of the Queens County chapter of the Republican Party from 2015 to 2017.\n\n\nBorn in 1941, Turner grew up in the  and  neighborhoods of Queens, the eldest of three sons. His father was a taxi driver, and ; his mother a homemaker. Turner has described his parents as \" who began splitting their tickets in the post- years.\" He attended St. Thomas The Apostle School in  and . He served in the Army at the rank of , then graduated from  with a  in history, after working his way through college. As a college student, he took part in the conservative activist group .\n\n\n President and CEO  for his support of pro-business issues.]]\nTurner worked in the advertising and television industries for more than four decades. In 1984, he co-founded and ran Orbis Communications, a distributor of . He then headed the North American operations of Pearson LLC, where he exported the television  format to Europe, launching six shows in two years. In addition, Turner reorganized and redirected the successful program '''' and launched new versions of the game shows '''' and ''''.\n\nTurner's most notable position was president of , a division of media conglomerate Multimedia, Inc., from 1991 to 1995. He created '''', he oversaw the production of '''' and '''', and launched the  show on television.  recalled that he and Turner had a friendly, businesslike relationship though their politics differed. Turner shelved several Springer show episodes as inappropriate but kept the show on the air despite heavy criticism and calls from Congress to regulate the show's raunchy content. Limbaugh recalled of Turner: \"it was Bob Turner that chased Roger Ailes and me down one night at  with the idea of doing a show. He was a great guy. He is a great guy. And he has the perfect temperament(...) and he was as loyal as the day is long.\" Multimedia Entertainment was sold to Gannett Corporation for $2.1 billion in 1995 with Turner helping to orchestrate the sale. Gannett ended Rush Limbaugh's television show and Turner's 24-hour news talk station, the All-Talk Channel. In 1996, Multimedia Entertainment was sold to /\n\nHe has also been President of LBS Communications, a division of , where he created a daytime \"barter network\" for the distribution and syndication of the series '''' and ''''. He served as Director of Advertising for  Company, where he began the production of the Leonard Nimoy series, '''', and was the first General Manager of .\nDuring his active business career, Turner founded and served as the president of the Association of Syndicated Television Advertisers and was on the boards of the National Association of Television Programming Executives and the Advertising Research Council. He served on the television committee of the .\n\nWhile in his early 60s, Turner retired from full-time business activities but continued to manage his own investments including a hotel business in Orlando, Florida. He sat on several Boards of Directors, including Readspeak Inc., Liberty Imaging Inc., the Achilles Track Club and Family Focus Adoption Services.\n\n\nTurner first ran for Congress in  in New York's ninth congressional district, losing in a 60–40 split. During the 2010 campaign, he ran on a platform favoring minimal regulation of business and signed the  /  pledge of \"no new taxes under any circumstances\".\n\n\nFollowing the resignation of Anthony Weiner, Turner ran for the vacant seat in  held on September 13, 2011beating his Democratic opponent, , by a margin of more than 4,000 votes. His campaign consultant was strategist . Turner's campaign ran ads showing images of the  in flames, accusing Weprin of commemorating the attack by defending the right of Sufi Muslims to build the Islamic community center . Turner also said that Weprin would merely toe the Democratic Party line if elected and emphasized that Weprin had said the national debt was $4 trillion when the correct number was $14 trillion. Turner, according to the ''New York Times'', \"aggressively courted observant Jewish voters\", and painted Weprin as a puppet of President Obama, who would not stand up for Israel. Turner won strong support from Orthodox Jewish leaders, and won crossover endorsements, two key ones being New York Assemblyman , and former New York Mayor , both Democrats and Jews.\n\nTurner began the campaign with a disadvantage in fundraising because the national and state Republican parties had spent heavily in previous special elections in New York state. Turner turned down  support and offers to help during his special election campaign. Regardless, Turner rose in the polls from an underdog to an eight-point advantage days before the election. The Democratic Party contributed heavily to Weprin in the last weeks of the race, as Turner's odds of winning increased. Turner's win was publicized as a large upset victory, and made national headlines because Democrats outnumbered Republicans by 3-to-1 in the district. His win was also unexpected because his district had a large Jewish constituency (up to one quarter of registered voters are Jewish), and Turner beat Weprin, an Orthodox Jew, with a majority of the Jewish vote.\n\nTurner's campaign manager, E. O'Brien Murray, was later named 2012 GOP campaign manager of the year, by the  for his role in the win. The district is Democratic leaning with a  (CPVI) of D+5. In ''Salon'', which called Turner's win \"unremarkable\", it was argued that the district had been leaning rightward, as it was one of the few districts in the nation in which  performed one point worse than  in 2004 and 12 points worse than  in 2000. However, ''Salon''s claims were questioned by some as Obama had won the district in 2008 by 11 points and Kerry by 12 in 2004, which did not seem to imply a strong conservative swing. Furthermore, the local city council seat was easily won by a Democrat in the most recent election, along with the local State Senate and Assembly seats. This included a special election for  on the same day as Turner's election, within his congressional district, where the Democratic candidate won with 76% of the vote. Additionally,  easily won the district during his run for Governor of New York.\n\n\nOne of Turner's campaign themes was fiscal recovery through cuts in federal spending. He opposed what Democrats said were Republican plans to privatize Medicare and Social Security and turn Medicaid into a block-grant program, reportedly at the request of former New York mayor , who supported him. In endorsing Turner's opponent, ''The New York Times'' said that Turner's economic plan to reduce taxes without reducing benefits for current Medicare and Social Security recipients was unrealistic. \"That would take a magician, not a businessman\", said the Times. One month before the election, Turner admitted that an op-ed he written for the '''' calling for a one third reduction in federal spending and \"an end to government dependencies\" was \"blatant pandering\" to \"a particular audience\".\n\nDuring his 2011 campaign, Turner stated he came out of retirement to run for Congress \"to fix what's broken and go home. End subsidies. End government dependencies. Dramatically cut the budget by 30 or 35 percent. Slash capital-gains taxes down to zero. Cut taxes across the board. The rest of America's economic healing will happen naturally as a consequence\", he said.  In 2011 he chose not to sign \"the pledge,\" citing the need to compromise in the critical area of reducing the debt. In his 2011 campaign he cited illegal immigration as a major cause of U.S. unemployment. To resolve the U.S. debt, he proposed eliminating the U.S Department of Agriculture and the Environmental Protection Agency and reducing the size of the Department of Education.\n\n\n, where he argued for the elimination of its tolls]]\nTurner was sworn in on September 15, 2011. He was mentored by Homeland Security Committee chair  (R-NY) in his transition to his new job. Turner met with his former rival, Anthony Weiner, discussing open constituent files and issues facing the district, including noise pollution and eroding beaches. He had a cordial and businesslike meeting with Weiner, though the two men have been described as polar opposites.\n\nWithin weeks of taking office, Turner was attacked by the  (DCCC) for his no new tax pledge, and painted by the DCCC as representing wealthy individuals and corporations rather than the average district voter. Turner expressed support for  in upstate New York, and would allow states to opt out of . Remarking on the tenth anniversary of the war in Afghanistan, Turner said he would \"leave our military commitment in Afghanistan up to the generals in the field,\" adding that, \"If they believe the sacrifice of our soldiers continues to be necessary to prevent attacks on U.S. soil, then we have no choice but to let them finish the task.\" Turner was an advocate for removing the tolls on the , and applauded Gov. Cuomo for his motions towards changing the policy.\n\nIn November 2011, a protester affiliated with the  movement shouted during Turner's ceremonial swearing-in. Turner then criticized the OWS demonstrators as socialist and praised America's capitalist system as a \"beacon to the world\". Turner voted for Paul Ryan's revised  in 2012, despite reluctance that it would privatize . Turner promised during his campaign to protect Social Security, and explicitly said he would vote no to the Ryan plan. Turner's spokesman defended his vote for the bill, saying Turner was opposed to many of its provisions, but believed it was a good starting point for negotiations because it would not be finalized without compromise with the Democratic-controlled Senate. However, Turner did suggest raising the minimum age from 65.\n\nTurner introduced The TEACH Act of 2012, which would provide a  of up to $5,000 per year to families who send their children to non-public K-12 schools. Congressman Turner has said his goal with the TEACH Act is to ameliorate the “double taxation” burdening on parents paying for local school taxes and private schooling tuition. His proposal received wide support from the , Yeshiva congregations in Queens, and the . The Act is currently in .\n\n\n. On foreign affairs, he supported Israel and voted to restrict the threat of a nuclear Iran]]\nThe House Republican Steering Committee assigned Turner to three committees in the House, including '''''', '''''', and ''''''. When asked about the news, Turner said he was \"very excited to be appointed to three important House committees.\" Rep.  commended Turner's involvement in homeland security, saying Turner knew that \"New York is the number one target.\" Turner sided with the , and supported more funding for defense. Upon being chosen to serve on the House Committee on Foreign Affairs, he stated, \"I intend to forward my beliefs that it is in our national interest to defend our Middle East ally, Israel, and I will oppose further attempts by the U.N. to recognize a Palestinian state.\" He co-sponsored H.R. Bill 556, which condemned Iran for human rights abuses, and urged Pres. Obama to challenge Iran for its nuclear armament policies Turner pushed for strict economic sanctions on the , and criticized Sen.  for stalling H.R. 1905, which would have allowed the U.S. to restrict Iran's trade internationally and bar U.S.-Iran diplomacy.\n\n''Brooklyn Daily'' opined that the assignments would not allow Turner to make use of his business experience and offered little opportunity for him to deliver on his promises of bringing \"fiscal sanity\" to Washington. His predecessor, Anthony Weiner, had served in the '''''', which had the broadest jurisdiction of the committees.\n\n\nFollowing the 2010 Census, New York State lost two congressmen in its delegation, and Turner's district was split. ''Crain's New York Business'' said that Turner's win would make the New York Republican Party more likely to push for a \"super Jewish\" congressional district, extending the influence of Brooklyn's Orthodox Jewish community.  Under the new congressional district lines, he would possibly have faced  in a more African-American and heavily Democratic constituency; Turner was not optimistic about his chances, telling reporters, \"That’s a district that really can’t be moved. That’s not a legitimate shot.\"\n\n\n\nIn March 2012, he announced he would challenge Democratic incumbent U.S. Senator . Turner faced attorney  and Nassau County Comptroller  in a primary election to face Gillibrand.  The 2012 New York State Republican convention split the endorsement among the three candidates, with enough support for each candidate to automatically appear on the ballot.  Turner lost the primary election to Long on June 26, 2012. He additionally sought the endorsement of New York's , which he also lost to Long.\n\n\nOn March 12, 2015, Turner was named chairman of the  borough Republican Party. He was endorsed for the position by New York state Republican chairman , and voted in unanimously. On September 27, 2017, he was ousted as chairman by Joann Ariola.\n\n\nTurner is married to Peggy Turner, a foster care nurse for special needs children. The couple has five adult children and 13 grandchildren and resides in . In August 2011, Turner revealed the couple's 1994 adoption of C.J. Holmstrom, an orphan boy whose parents had died from AIDS. C.J.'s mother, Rosemary Holmstrom, had been on daytime talk shows in the 1980s discussing the death of her husband from AIDS and her own HIV-positive status. The Turners helped her and C.J. from that time on, adopting C.J. after her death. Turner's home was flooded and subsequently burned to the ground during .\n\n\nState of New York, June 26, 2012\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n72197\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n -->\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n*  ''official U.S. House website''\n* \n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n''|years=}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''La'Ron Singletary''' (born 1979/1980) is an American law enforcement official who was active in the , serving as the chief of the department from July 2019 to September 2020. He resigned after disputes with then    in the aftermath of the . Formerly a Democrat, he ran for congress to represent  district in  as a , losing to Democratic incumbent .\n\n\nSingletary grew up in the 19th Ward neighborhood of , and wanted to become a police officer from a young age. He became a  at 14 and graduated from John Marshall High School. He then went on to attend , graduated from , and then received a  from .\n\n\nSingletary joined the Rochester police force in 2000, and was sworn in by . He became deputy chief of the department in January 2018, and became chief in July 2019.\n\nWhile Singletary was police chief,  in 2020. Prude was under the influence of  and was walking the city streets naked before being physically restrained by the police. The incident gained nationwide attention, and after public pressure and a city council investigation that determined that Mayor  and Singletary concealed critical details about Prude's death from the public and lied about their knowledge of the case, Singletary and all other members of the Rochester Police Department command staff resigned. Later, a jury would not indict any of the officers involved.\n\nIn December 2020, Singletary accused Rochester mayor Lovely Warren of pressuring him to lie about the series of events following the death of Daniel Prude and firing him after he refused. Warren subsequently argued that Singletary downplayed the circumstances surrounding Prude's death. He later filed a successful lawsuit against the city asking for medical benefits promised to employees who work in the department for more than 20 years.\n\n\nFormerly a , Singletary joined the  in 2021.\n\nIn November 2021, Singletary announced that he was running for the  to represent  in . He was encouraged to run by former  .\n\n\nSingletary lives in .\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Anthony Joseph Brindisi''' (born November 22, 1978) is an American lawyer and politician from the state of New York. As a , Brindisi served as the  from  from 2019 to 2021. He represented New York's 119th Assembly District from 2011 to 2019. He is a nominee to serve as a  the .\n\nBefore his election to the , Brindisi served on the   and practiced as an attorney. He was first elected to the New York State Assembly in a September 2011 special election. Brindisi narrowly defeated  U.S. Representative  in the  in New York's 22nd congressional district. Tenney challenged Brindisi in . Initially, the 2020 election was too close to call, and its results were challenged in court. On February 5, 2021, a state trial court judge declared Tenney the winner.\n\n\nBrindisi was born in 1978 in , to Louis and Jacqueline Brindisi. He has five siblings. His great grandparents were from  (present-day Turkey) and fled to , Syria during the . His mother died of cancer when he was four years old, on the same day that a murder took place at Louis's law firm. Louis gave up the practice of  after the murder.\n\nBrindisi graduated from  and attended Mohawk Valley Community College before graduating from  in 2000. He has said that the  inspired him to become a lawyer. Like his father, he attended  of  and received his  degree in 2004. He joined the law firm his father founded and later won a seat on the .\n\n\nFollowing the appointment of Assemblywoman  as Commissioner of the New York State Office of General Services, Brindisi won a  to replace her to represent the 119th Assembly district, beating Republican Gregory Johnson in a September 13, 2011, special election. He was unopposed in the 2012 general election, running on the Democratic, , and  . He was also unchallenged in 2014 and 2016.\n\nBrindisi voted against the , a 2013 gun control law written in response to the . He was endorsed by the  in 2016, and the NRA also gave him a 100% rating in 2017. The NRA downgraded his rating to an F during his 2018 campaign for Congress.\n\n\n\n\n\nBrindisi ran for Congress in , which was held by one-term Republican  of nearby . Tenney had served alongside Brindisi in the State Assembly from 2011 to 2017. Brindisi ran unopposed in the Democratic primary. He was endorsed by former Republican congressmen  and . The brand of Republicanism in central New York has traditionally been a moderate one, and Tenney was considered a staunch conservative and an outspoken supporter of President Trump.\n\nOn November 19, 2018, Brindisi declared victory., ''''. Vaughn, Natasha. November 19, 2018. Retrieved November 19, 2018. By November 20, his lead grew to over 3,900 votes, and there were not enough remaining absentee ballots for Tenney to close the gap. Tenney conceded on November 28. The 22nd voted for  by a 15% margin over  in 2016, the largest margin in any House district to change hands from a Republican to a Democrat in 2018.\n\n\nUpon his swearing-in on January 3, 2019, Brindisi became only the second Democrat to represent the district in 68 years, and the third in 119 years. The last Democrat to represent this district was , who represented what was then the 24th district from 2007 to 2011. Arcuri won with 54% of the vote, becoming only the second Democrat to represent this district and its predecessors in 106 years, and the first since 1951.\n\n\n\nBrindisi sought reelection to Congress in 2020. In October 2019, Tenney announced that she would challenge him. The initial election results were too close to call, and a court challenge ensued. On December 8, a New York state judge ordered a district-wide recanvass of all ballots, including provisional ballots and disputed ballots not included in the original count. By January 29, 2021, Tenney had a 122-vote lead over Brindisi based on unofficial tallies. On February 5, 2021,  Judge Scott DelConte ruled in Tenney's favor, allowing her to be declared the winner of the election by 109 votes.\n\n\nOn December 18, 2019, Brindisi voted to impeach President  for abuse of power and obstruction of Congress.\n\n\n\n* \n** \n** \n* \n** \n** \n* \n** \n** \n\n\n\n*  (Co-Chair for Whip)\n* \n\n\nIn July 2021, Brindisi announced his candidacy for . He lost the 2021 race for the 5th Supreme Court District to Republican Danielle Fogel.\n\n\nIn May 2022, Governor  appointed Brindisi to the .\n\n\n\nOn July 31, 2024, President  nominated Brindisi to serve as a  the .  President Biden nominated Brindisi to a seat being vacated by Judge , who announced his intent to assume  upon confirmation of a successor. On September 25, 2024, a hearing on his nomination was held before the . During his confirmation hearing, he was questioned by Senator  on the constitutional limits of the  and by Senator  over his past congressional co-sponsorship of the . His nomination is pending before the .\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nBrindisi lives with his wife, Erica, and their two children in Utica.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n\n\n\n\nfrom the 119th district|years=2011–2019}}\n\n|-\n\n\nfrom |years=2019–2021}}\n\n|-\n\n\n''|years=}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Kevin Christopher Riley''' (born November 16, 1987) is an American politician. A , he serves as the member for the . The district includes , , , , , ,  in .\n\n\nRiley grew up and lives in Baychester, The Bronx. He graduated from Mount Saint Michael Academy in Wakefield before attending State University of New York at Old Westbury where he received a B.A. and an M.P.A. from . He has two daughters and one son.\n\n\nPrior to running for office, Riley was an aide to Assembly Speaker  for ten years. He was also a Democratic Male District Leader for the 83rd Assembly District.\n\n\nOn December 22, 2020, Riley won a special election in the 12th district following the expulsion of Council Member . He was sworn in on January 6, 2021, and named chair of the Subcommittee on Landmarks, Public Sitings, and Dispositions.\n\nOn the proposed City of Yes plan to increase housing supply in New York City, Riley said, \"Some of these reforms make a lot of sense. The problem is that the proposal doesn’t identify the specific housing needs that different types of neighborhoods have.\"\n\n\nRiley outraised his opponents and received a significant amount of endorsements from high-ranking elected official and unions, which some attributed to his close relationship to Assembly Speaker Carl Heastie, one of the most powerful politicians in the State.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Ruth Wyler Messinger''' (born November 6, 1940) is a former American political leader in  and a member of the . She was the Democratic nominee for  in , losing to incumbent mayor .\n\n\n\n\nBorn and raised in New York, Messinger attended the . She graduated from  of  in 1962, and received a Master of Social Work from the  in 1964. She is married to Andrew Lachman, her second husband, and has three children. She was formerly the President and CEO of , an international development agency.\n\n\nMessinger was a delegate to the  and served on the  from 1978 to 1989, representing the  of Manhattan. In the City Council, she proposed extending  from individuals to businesses. From 1990 to 1998, she served as Manhattan borough president, an office she gave up to unsuccessfully run for mayor in the 1997 election. Her candidacy made her the city's first female Democratic mayoral candidate.\n\nA political , Messinger was known for her advocacy on behalf of public schools, efforts to achieve compromise between developers and neighborhood activists, and her aggressive media work. She is pro-choice and opposes the death penalty. During her 1997 campaign, she was nearly forced into a Democratic primary runoff with Reverend , but avoided it by receiving 40% of the vote during a recount. She ultimately lost to Giuliani but received more than 500,000 votes.\n\nIn 2005, Messinger endorsed  for mayor in the . Ferrer had briefly run against her for mayor in 1997, before dropping out to endorse her and then run for reelection as Bronx .\n\n\nFrom 1998 until 2016 she was President and CEO of  before transitioning to an Ambassador role with the organization. \n\nIn late 2005, following a high-profile year that included the Asian tsunami and , '''', a Jewish newspaper based in New York City, named her to the top of its annual \"Forward Fifty\" list of the most influential . Messinger is also a board member of  and a trustee emerita of the . In 2015 she was named as one of '''' 50.\n\nMessinger serves as the inaugural Social Justice Fellow at the  and the Social Justice Activist-in-Residence at the .\n\nIn 2020, she served on incoming  ' transition team.\n\n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n*\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

Gunther earned a national certification in infection control, a Nursing Degree from Orange County Community College and attended State University of New York, New Paltz for a degree in Liberal Arts.\n\nShe is a  with 29 years experience.\nGunther is an  counselor. Gunther III. She ran uncontested in the 2004, 2006, 2008, and 2010 s.     "pages": }\n\n'''Charles D. Lavine''' (born August 14, 1947) is a member of the , representing the 13th district, which includes portions of the towns of  and  in . First elected in 2004, Lavine is a .\n\n\nLavine was born in . He graduated from  in 1965 and received a  degree in  from the  in 1969. After coming to New York, he earned a  from  in June 1972.\n\nLavine has been a  resident since 1980. He and his wife Ronnie have two grown children, Gregory and Andria.\n\n\nFrom 1972 to 1976 worked as a staff attorney for the  of New York. From 1977 to 1995 he served as a partner in the law firm of Grossman, Lavine & Rinaldo in . Since 1996, he has been a sole practitioner specializing in criminal defense work.\n\nIn 2000  Executive and  Mayor  appointed Lavine to the Glen Cove Planning Board. In May 2003 Lavine was appointed to fill a vacancy on the Glen Cove City Council, a position to which he was subsequently elected.\nIn 2004 he successfully ran in the   for an Assembly seat against six-term incumbent  and later that year won the seat at the , taking office in 2005.\n\nIn 2016 Lavine had announced that he would run for Nassau County Executive in 2017, saying he would want to weed out corruption and strengthen government ethics in Nassau as he has sought to do in the state Legislature. In May 2017, Lavine dropped out of the race for Country Executive and endorsed  for the position.\n\nIn January 2021, Assembly Speaker Carl E. Heastie appointed Assemblymember Lavine as Chair of the Judiciary Committee. Lavine is also a member of the Committee on Codes, Ethics and Guidance, Rules and Insurance. Lavine previously served as Chair of the Election Law Committee, Chair of the Committee on Ethics and Guidance, co-Chair of the New York State Legislative Ethics Commission and as Chair of the bipartisan Taskforce that produced the Assembly Speaker's Policy on Sexual Harassment, Retaliation and Discrimination.  Lavine also serves as President of the New York Chapter of the National Association of Jewish Legislators and as a member of its national board of directors.\n\n\n\nAs chair of the Committee on Ethics, Lavine led the investigation into former Assemblyman  for sexual harassment of female staffers, eventually imposing a $330,000 fine in 2013.\n\nLavine voted on March 11, 2014, to re-appoint three members (James Cottrell, Wade Norwood, and Christine Cea) to the Board of Regents, the body responsible for overseeing state education policy and implementation of the .\n\nIn 2009, he was one of 17 Democrats to cosponsor A8180, which increased several transportation-related fees to fund the operation of the  (including rental car fees, DMV fees and the MTA fee on self-employed workers).\n\nLavine supports LGBT rights including same-sex marriage as well as opposing gender discrimination. In 2009, he sponsored A7732 that would allow \"same-sex couples the same opportunity to enter into civil marriages as opposite-sex couples\". Lavine sponsored A5710, a bill that would prohibit \"discrimination based on gender identity or expression.\" In 2011, Lavine renewed his support for this legislation.\n\nIn 2011, Lavine supported an extension of the temporary New York State  surcharge on individuals earning over $200,000 annually.  This temporary surcharge was enacted in January 2009 to balance the .\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Audrey I. Pheffer''' (born August 13, 1941) is an American  politician from . She is currently serving as  . Previously, she represented District 23 in the  from 1987 to 2011, which comprised ,  and , among other neighborhoods found within the   of .\n\n\nPheffer worked from 1973 to 1977 at the Rockaway Occupational Training Center and agency of the Queens Association of ARC, where she worked with the developmentally disabled. In 1977, she was a member of the New York City Commission of Human Rights.\n\nDespite her long separation from education and having only a high school diploma, she successfully combined being a working mom and a full-time student at , where she received a  degree () in 1982.\n\nShe was a Special Assistant to former New York City Council President  and Executive Assistant to State Senator .\n\nPheffer resides in Far Rockaway and has two children, Mitchell and . She and her life partner Glenn Riddell have six grandchildren.\n\n\nOn April 28, 1987, she elected to the , to fill the vacancy caused by the resignation of . Pheffer was re-elected many times, and remained in the Assembly until 2011, sitting in the , , , , , , , , , , ,  and s. She was Chairwoman of the Committee on Consumer Affairs and Protection from 1995 to 2011. In the past she has chaired the Assembly's Election Law Committee and the Subcommittee on Outreach and Oversight of Senior Citizen Programs, and served as President of the National Order of Women Legislators from 1995 to 1996.\n\nIn 2001 Pheffer launched a run for Queens  before ultimately withdrawing from the race.\n\nIn 2011, she resigned from the State Assembly after being appointed to the position of County Clerk of Queens County. She is ''ex officio'' a clerk of the  and Commissioner of Jurors of Queens. In 2016, her daughter  was elected to her mother's old Assembly seat, becoming the first such same-seat mother-daughter combination in the Assembly's history.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n*\n*\n*\n*\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
