    "pages": }\n\n'''Marcela Mitaynes''' is a  politician and tenant . She is a member of the , representing the 51st district as a Democrat. Mitaynes is a member of the .\n\n\nAfter spending her early life in the , , Mitaynes moved to  as a child and was raised in . Mitaynes has an  in Accounting from .\n\n\n\nMitaynes ran for elected office for the first time in the June 23, 2020  primary for the 51st district of the . On election night, she trailed longtime incumbent  by 464 votes. After absentee ballots had been counted, Mitaynes led Ortiz by 240 votes, and on July 16, 2020, Ortiz conceded defeat to Mitaynes. Given that the district skews heavily Democratic, Mitaynes ran unopposed in the November 3 general election and won her race. She was sworn in on January 1, 2021.\n\nDuring the campaign, Mitaynes was endorsed by the New York City , the , the ,  ,  , and actress and  .\n\n\nMitaynes first became politically active as a member of the tenants' rights movements in New York City, after she and her family were  from their apartment in 2006.  She was active in the successful 2019 effort to lobby the  to pass stronger tenant protections.  Mitaynes made housing issues central to her 2020 campaign.  She supports cancelling rent for residential and commercial tenants, and cancelling mortgage payments for small landlords.  On August 19, 2021, she was arrested in an act of  to oppose the end of New York's .  The moratorium was extended later that month.  Mitaynes also participated in a  in March and April 2021 in support of an \"excluded workers fund\" that was established to support undocumented workers who did not qualify for .\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Christopher Louis Jacobs''' (born November 28, 1966) is an American politician who represented  in the  from 2020 to 2023. Jacobs served as the 62nd  from April 2006 to January 2007. Beginning in 2012, he held the post of  clerk, and he was a  member of the  for the  from 2017 to 2020. On June 23, 2020, he won  to fill a congressional vacancy in the 27th district. He was reelected to a full term in November 2020.\n\nJacobs did not seek reelection in 2022, after receiving what '''' described as \"rising backlash\" from Republicans for supporting some gun control measures following the  and the .\n\n\nJacobs was born in , as one of 5 siblings. His family has long owned the  Companies and the  hockey team. Jacobs earned his undergraduate degree from , a master's degree from  and a  from the . He is married to Martina Jacobs.\n\n\n\nBefore holding elected office, Jacobs served as deputy commissioner of environment and planning in the administration of Erie County Executive . He also worked at the  under then-HUD Secretary .\n\nJacobs served on the  board. He was elected in 2004 and reelected in 2009.\n\nJacobs serves on the Boards of Buffalo Place and the Freedom Station Coalition and was previously a board member at the Catholic Academy of West Buffalo and the Olmsted Parks Conservancy.\n\nOn April 19, 2006, Governor  appointed Jacobs .\n\n\nIn 2011, Jacobs was elected Erie County clerk. He was reelected to the post in 2014.\n\n\n]]\nIn February 2006, Jacobs was the Republican nominee in a special election for a  seat representing Buffalo and . He lost to Democratic nominee .\n\nOn November 8, 2016, Jacobs defeated Democratic nominee Amber Small for the 60th district seat. The district was formerly represented by Democrat . The campaigns were rare for their lack of rancor on the part of either candidate.\n\nJacobs was reelected in 2018. He resigned on July 20, 2020, after being elected to Congress. Democrat  was later elected to succeed him.\n\n\n\n\n\n\nIn May 2019, Jacobs announced that he would run for  in the . He initially planned to challenge incumbent  in the Republican primary, but Collins resigned in October 2019 and pleaded guilty to insider trading charges.\n\nJacobs defeated Nate McMurray, 50.7%-45.6%, in a  on June 23, 2020, for the balance of Collins's term and was sworn in as a member of Congress on July 21, 2020.\n\n\n\nOn the day of the special election, he also won a three-way Republican primary for the general election on November 3, in which he went on to win a full term by defeating McMurray a second time.\n\n\nIn January 2021, Jacobs objected to the certification of the  results in Congress, basing his decision on what '''' called \"spurious allegations of widespread voter fraud\". Jacobs's vote came shortly after the . On January 10, seven members of the New York State legislature signed an open letter calling on Jacobs to resign.\n\nOn January 13, Jacobs voted against both articles of impeachment in the  of President . On February 4, he joined 10 other Republican House members voting with all voting Democrats to strip Representative  of her , and  assignments in response to controversial political statements she had made.\n\nOn May 19, 2021, Jacobs was one of 35 Republicans who joined all Democrats in voting to approve legislation to establish the  meant to investigate the storming of the U.S. Capitol.\n\nIn September 2021, '''' reported that Jacobs had violated the , a federal transparency and conflict-of-interest law, by failing to properly disclose 13 securities trades worth more than $356,000. In September 2022, '''' reported that Jacobs had again violated the STOCK Act when he failed to properly disclose 43 additional securities trades worth between $456,043 and $1.415 million.\n\nOn May 22, 2022, as a result of  imposed by the United States in response to the , Jacobs was one of 963 Americans permanently banned from entering Russia.\n\nOn May 28, 2022, during a press conference on the  and the , Jacobs said he would vote for bills banning s and \"raising the minimum age for some gun purchases to 21\", explaining that the Buffalo shooting had \"been a profoundly impactful event for me\" and that he had rethought his stance on guns. Jacobs was endorsed by the  during his 2020 congressional run, at the time saying he was honored to receive the endorsement and vowing to serve as an \"ally and fighter\" for gun owners in western New York. Subsequently, Jacobs was admonished by some Republican politicians for his remarks, and , the Republican nominee for governor in , said he would consider challenging Jacobs for reelection in the Republican primary. On June 3, 2022, Jacobs ended his reelection campaign.\n\nOn July 19, 2022, Jacobs and 46 other Republican Representatives voted for the , which would codify the right to same-sex marriage in federal law.\n\nOn July 29, 2022, Jacobs and one other Republican,  of Pennsylvania, joined the Democrats in voting for a bill banning assault weapons.\n\nIn 2022, Jacobs was one of 39 Republicans to vote for the Merger Filing Fee Modernization Act of 2022, an antitrust package that would crack down on corporations for anti-competitive behavior.\n\n\n\n* \n* \n* \n\n\nSource:\n* \n* \n*\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n*\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n''|years=}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''William J. Larkin Jr.''' (February 5, 1928 – August 31, 2019) was an American politician and retired U.S. Army officer from the state of New York.\n\nLarkin was a decorated veteran of World War II and the Korean War. In 1967, he retired from the Army as a lieutenant colonel.\n\nFollowing his retirement from the Army, Larkin served as  town supervisor. A , Larkin sat in the  for 40 years, representing various districts in the . Larkin was a member of the  between 1979 and 1990, representing first the 97th and then the 95th Districts. He then sat in the  from 1991 until his retirement in 2018, representing the .\n\n\nBorn in , Larkin was raised by his aunt and uncle. He graduated from  in Troy and later attended the  and .\n\n\nBelieving himself to be 18 years of age, Larkin enlisted in the  as a private in 1944 at age 16. (Larkin later stated that he did not learn until 1965 that his actual birth year was 1928, not 1926.)\n\nLarkin fought in the  in  and saw combat in the . He subsequently entered  and was sent to fight in the . Larkin led an all-black unit during a period when the Armed Forces remained segregated. He was evacuated from the Korean War in 1951 due to severe frostbite to his feet. When Larkin retired from politics in 2018, he was the last serving New York state legislator to have fought in World War II.\n\nDuring his career in the Army, Larkin helped protect President  on a visit to Berlin and met  when escorting one of the  in  during the . Larkin retired from the U.S. Army in 1967 as a ; he also received the Legion of Merit and seven Army Commendation Medals.\n\n\nFollowing his retirement from the Army, Larkin was hired as an  in the  and served a term as New Windsor town supervisor before being elected to the  in 1978. Larkin served in the Assembly from 1979 to 1990. He was elected to the State Senate in 1990, defeating incumbent  state senator . Larkin would go on to win 13 more two-year State Senate terms. In the Senate, Larkin represented portions of Orange, Rockland, and Ulster Counties.\n\nKnown for his advocacy for veterans, Larkin helped to create the National Purple Heart Hall of Honor in Orange County, New York in 2006. Larkin successfully urged the U.S. Postal Service to issue a stamp depicting the Purple Heart, and to later make it a \"forever\" stamp which continues to be in circulation despite price changes. In October 2018, a Larkin-sponsored bill renaming the Bear Mountain Bridge was signed into law; the bridge was renamed the Purple Heart Veterans Memorial Bridge. According to the Albany '''', Larkin \"often shared anecdotes from his life experiences on the Senate floor\".\n\nLarkin sponsored legislation that required Pulse Oximetry testing for all newborns. He voted against same-sex marriage legislation in 2009 when the bill was defeated in the State Senate, and again in 2011 he voted against allowing same-sex marriage in New York in a close 33-29 vote on the act, which passed. In 2013, he voted against the gun control law known as the . Larkin voted in favor of medical marijuana legalization in 2014.\n\nIn May 2018, at the age of 90, Larkin announced that he would retire at year-end instead of seeking re-election. At the time of his announcement, Larkin was the only World War II veteran remaining in the New York State Legislature. In June 2018, ''U.S. News & World Report'' reported that Larkin was believed to be one of only two World War II veterans still serving in a U.S. state legislature; the other was State Senator  of .\n\n\nLarkin lived in the town of . He was married to Patricia Kurucz Larkin. He died on August 31, 2019, and was survived by his wife and their eight children, 17 grandchildren, and two great-grandchildren.\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
          }
        ]
      }
    }
  }
}

    "pages": }\n\n'''Ellen C. Jaffee''' (born May 20, 1944) is an American politician who served as a  member of the , representing the 97th Assembly District in .\n\nA native of , Jaffee earned her  in Education from  and her  in  from . She was previously a teacher at Pomona Middle School before becoming an elected official of the Rockland County Legislature in 1998.\n\nJaffee was first elected to the State Assembly in 2006 for a two-year term (2007&ndash;2009). She ran uncontested in the 2008  and won the 2010 general election with 61 percent of the vote.\n\nJaffee has lived in  since 1978, where she and her late husband, Steve, raised two children, Marc and Allison. Steve Jaffee, who was also the Chairman of the Suffern Democratic Committee, died on January 19, 2016.\n\nJaffee was defeated in  by Republican .\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n*\n*\n*, \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Kathleen Maura Rice''' (born February 15, 1965) is an American lawyer and politician who served as the United States representative for  from 2015 to 2023. She is a member of the . Before serving in Congress, Rice served as the  district attorney, and, before that, she served as a federal prosecutor in the U.S. Attorney's Office in  and as an assistant district attorney in the  District Attorney's Office in .\n\nOn January 29, 2014, Rice announced that she would run for Congress in New York's 4th congressional district to replace retiring Democratic incumbent . Rice defeated Republican nominee  on November 4, 2014, and took office in January 2015.\n\nOn February 15, 2022, Rice announced that she would retire at the end of her term.\n\n\nRice was born in , , to Laurence and Christine Rice. She grew up in , on , as one of 10 siblings. Rice graduated from . She received a B.A. degree from the  in 1987 and a J.D. degree from the  in 1991.\n\nIn 1992 Rice began her career as an assistant district attorney in the  District Attorney's Office, under District Attorney . She prosecuted cases involving burglaries, robberies and sexual assaults and was the first member of her class to be promoted to the  bureau.\n\nIn 1999, Rice was appointed assistant  in  by then- . As a federal prosecutor, she prosecuted white-collar crimes, corporate fraud, gun and drug cases, and public corruption.\n\n\n in 2010]]\nRice was elected Nassau County District Attorney in 2005, winning by 7,500 votes to become the first woman to hold the position. She defeated 30-year incumbent , who had generally won reelection easily, even after switching his affiliation from Democratic to Republican in 1989. Rice was the first serious opponent Dillon had faced since his first run in 1974. Rice was reelected in 2009 and 2013.\n\n\n\n\n\nIn 2006, Rice declared her first major policy initiative to be an \"assault on the drunk driving epidemic\". She lowered the blood-alcohol level at which plea bargains were offered, supported , and charged a man with murder after a 2005 accident that killed a limo driver and a child.\n\n\n\nIn September 2011, Rice's office arrested seven students after uncovering an  cheating ring on Long Island. When this case led to the discovery of a wider-spread cheating scandal, Rice worked with the , which administers the test, to update security standards to halt cheating in the future. This effort sparked other test administrators, like that which gives the , to update their standards as well.\n\nRice has also received credit for teen education programs geared toward , drug use, texting and dangerous driving.\n\nIn 2007, Rice's office, Nassau County and  police led a counter-assault on Terrace Avenue, a major drug haven and crime-ridden street in 's Hempstead Village. Through a combination of zero-tolerance enforcement for repeat and violent offenders, and social-service based jail diversion for nonviolent and first time offenders, crime was reduced in the area.\n\nIn 2008, following the trampling death of a  employee at one of its Black Friday sales events, Rice encouraged Walmart to upgrade its security protocols at its nearly 100 New York stores.\n\nIn 2012, Rice came out in favor of decriminalizing small amounts of \"plain view\" marijuana. She has also supported efforts to allow some citizens to seal prior low-level, non-violent convictions in the hopes of improving their chances of obtaining employment.\n\nIn the same year, then-Governor  chose Rice to be a member of the Moreland Commission on Utility Storm Preparation and Response, a panel tasked with investigating the failures of the  (LIPA) after . The panel recommended that LIPA be replaced by a private, investor-owned company and that the Public Service Commission, which has regulation authority, be given more power to penalize and fine poor-performing utility companies.\n\nRice supports the \"Raise the Age NY\" initiative to treat nonviolent teen offenders as juveniles in the criminal justice system.\n\n\n\nRice implemented gun buyback programs in some of the county's most crime-plagued areas, which removed more than 2,000 guns from the streets. She also spoke out in favor of then-Governor Cuomo's gun control legislation and created the office's first ever gun prosecution unit.\n\nIn 2011 Rice announced a major prosecution of nine gun dealers and gun store employees police arrested in an undercover operation investigating alleged illegal assault weapons. This was the second arrest for Martin Tretola, one of the gun shop owners. He was previously arrested on firearms-related violations in 2007. In 2012, a federal jury delivered a verdict rejecting Nassau County's and Rice's charges for the 2007 arrest and awarded Tretola $3 million in compensatory damages and $2 million in punitive damages. This judgment was reduced to $1.3 million in total upon appeal.\n\n\n\nThe Kings County district attorney's prosecution of Antowine Butts for double homicide imploded and ended in an acquittal in 2000, but not before Butts spent two years in a  jail cell. After the case unraveled, Butts alleged that he was a victim of prosecutorial misconduct in a civil rights lawsuit that was settled with New York City.\n\nRice was among those named in that suit, but has largely escaped attention for starting her career in an office in which prosecutors are alleged to have put some innocent people behind bars with coerced confessions, bogus witness statements, coached lineup identifications and other tactics.\n\nIn April 2013, Rice announced the arrest of 18 members of the \"Rollin' 60's\" gang, an \"ultra-violent\" subset of the Crips. Rice charged these defendants with crimes ranging from attempted murder of a police officer to assault and robbery to gun and drug sales.\n\n\nAmong those Rice has charged and convicted of corruption include a deputy police commissioner, a  City Council member, former  legislators, and several town building department employees.\n\n\nIn July 2013, Cuomo appointed Rice to be one of three co-chairs of the Moreland Commission on Public Corruption. The commission's work is ongoing.\n\nRice formed Nassau's first-ever  and public assistance fraud unit, which has since secured millions of dollars in restitution for Nassau taxpayers.\n\n\nIn 2010, Rice ordered the review of a 1987 case in which Arnold Friedman and his son, Jesse, pleaded guilty to sexually abusing young boys in their Great Neck, Long Island home. Rice formed a panel of outside expertsincluding the 's  (who spoke out against the review)to examine whether Jesse Friedman had wrongfully confessed. In a 172-page report released in July 2013, investigators found that Friedman had not been wrongfully convicted.\n\n\nIn July 2013, Rice was inducted as president of the  (DAASNY).\n\n\n  in May 2015]]\n , , , and  in 2021]]\n\n\nIn an August 2017 tweet, Rice referred to both the  and its spokeswoman,   and author , as national security threats under President . Loesch reacted to Rice's tweet by calling for her resignation.\n\nAs of September 2021, Rice had voted in line with 's stated position 100% of the time.\n\nRice was one of three House Democrats on the Energy Committee to vote against a provision that would lower prescription drug prices.\n\nIn 2022, Rice criticized Democratic groups aiding  GOP primary candidates to make for easier opponents .\n\n\n\n*\n**\n** (Chair)\n*\n**\n**\n\n\n\n*\n*\n\n\n\n\nIn 2005, Rice returned to Nassau County and declared her candidacy for  on the Democratic line. She challenged 30-year incumbent . Throughout the campaign, Rice provided an alternative to Dillon, pledging to cut plea bargaining and touting her would-be zero tolerance policy for drunk driving. She also committed herself to modernizing the office's approach to domestic violence and crimes of sexual abuse. Rice edged out Dillon, 51%–49%.\n\n}}\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\nIn 2009, Rice was challenged by law clerk Joy Watson. She defeated Watson, 54%–46%.\n\n}}\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\nIn May 2010, Rice announced that she would seek the Democratic nomination for . The race pitted Rice against four Democratic opponents: then-State Senator , former prosecutor , former State Assemblyman , and former insurance commissioner . Though originally considered a long shot, she lost the five-way primary to Schneiderman by just two points, 34% to 32%.\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nIn 2013, Rice was challenged by Law Secretary Howard Sturim. Rice defeated Sturim, 59%–41%.\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\nIn June 2014, Rice won the Democratic primary election for the U.S. House of Representatives in New York's 4th congressional district, defeating Nassau County Legislator Kevan Abrahams, 56%–44%. In November, she was elected, defeating Republican nominee , 53%–47%.\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\nRice was reelected, defeating Republican nominee , 59.6%–40.4%, a margin of about 60,000 votes.\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\nRice was reelected, defeating Republican nominee Ameer Benno, 61.3%–38.7%. US House of Representatives: History, Art & Archives|url=https://history.house.gov/Institution/Election-Statistics/|access-date=February 15, 2022|website=history.house.gov|language=en}}\n\n}}\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\nRice was reelected, defeating Republican nominee Douglas L. Tuman and  nominee Joseph R. Naham 56.1% to Tuman's 43.0% and Naham's 0.8%.\n}}\n\n}}\n\n\n\nRice has never married and has no children.     "pages": }\n\n'''Janet L. Duprey''' (born November 27, 1945) is a former  member of the , representing Assembly District 115, which includes all of  and  Counties, as well as part of . She is originally from .\n\nDuprey was first elected to the Assembly on November 7, 2006. She ran uncontested in the November 2008 \n\nShe was the 2010 Republican nominee when a potential primary challenger’s petitions were thrown out in New York State Appellate Court based on case-law regarding sufficiency of verbiage describing office being sought. \nShe then faced Rudy Johnson, a former energy analyst and small businessman, in the , which she won with 59 percent of the vote. Duprey did not seek re-election in 2016.\n\n\nDuprey supports gay and lesbian rights and voted in favor of a bill to introduce same sex marriage in New York State.\n\nDuprey sponsored a resolution to create a day of awareness for individuals diagnosed with .\n\nDuprey was a vocal supporter of  during the 2009 special election in .\n\nIn 2013, Duprey was a signatory to an amicus curiae brief submitted to the Supreme Court in support of same-sex marriage during the  case.\n\n\nDuprey and her husband Elmer have two grown children, John and Michelle.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n*, campaign website\n*, campaign website\n*, campaign website\n\n\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Roy Matz Goodman''' (March 5, 1930 &ndash; June 3, 2014) was an American politician and businessman who served as a member of the  from 1969 to 2002. He was the Republican nominee in the , receiving 4.08% of the vote.\n\n\nGoodman was born in New York City on March 5, 1930. He was the grandson of , the founder of the  company. As a child, he attended . Goodman received an undergraduate degree from  in 1951 and an M.B.A. from  in 1953.\n\n\nPrior to serving in the Senate, Goodman was the New York City Director of Finance under Mayor  in 1966 and 1967. He served as chairman of the New York County Republican Committee from 1981 to 2001.\n\n\nIn 1968, Goodman was elected to the New York State Senate for District 26 on Manhattan's East Side (later District 28). He would serve for 34 years, in the 178th through 194th New York legislatures, until his retirement in 2002.\n\nHe served as Chairman of the Senate Committee on Investigations, Taxation and Government Operations. He was considered a leader of the  of the . Goodman's supporters would sometimes refer to him as \"The Statesman of the State Senate.\"\n\n, Goodman ran for . He defeated , a talk radio host in the Republican primary. In the general election, Goodman finished third behind Democratic Congressman  and New York Secretary of State , a Democrat who ran on the  ticket.\n\nGoodman was nearly defeated in 2000 by . At first, Krueger was leading Goodman by several hundred votes. After a recount and the counting of the absentee ballots, Goodman was declared the winner in late December. In 2020, the ''New York Times'' reported that months after the election, in 2001, election workers discovered \"hundreds of ballots\" from a Krueger-leaning area in an air conditioning duct.\n\nGoodman resigned from the State Senate in early 2002. As of , he remains the last Republican elected to office in Manhattan.\n\n\nIn 1981, Goodman became chairman of the New York County (Manhattan) Republican Party. In Goodman's first decade as county chairman, the only other Republican elected official in Manhattan was liberal U.S. Representative , who represented the Upper East Side.\n\nGoodman's tenure in the 1990s witnessed the expansion and then the contraction of the Republican Party in Manhattan. In 1990, Republican  was elected to the . In 1991,  was elected to the . In 1993,  also won election to the Council. In 1992, Bill Green was ousted by , who served in congress until her defeat in the  in 2022 to . Millard attempted to win back the seat for Republicans in 1994, but he was soundly defeated. Both Millard and Eristoff eventually left the City Council, and their seats were won by Democrats. Ravitz remained in office until 2002, when he lost the special election to succeed Goodman in the Senate to . He did not seek re-election to the Assembly.\n\n\n\nGoodman is notorious among New York Republicans for his role in picking  as the Republican candidate for  in 1990. Republicans had difficulty finding anyone to run against incumbent Democrat , who was considered unbeatable. Goodman checked his  and found Rinfret, whom he knew socially. Goodman picked Rinfret because he was  on abortion and, as a millionaire economist, could spend some of his own money on the campaign.\n\nOn election Day, Rinfret received about 21 percent of the vote and barely outpolled , the candidate of the .\n\n\nGoodman was a Fellow For Life of the , a patron of the , a Patron of the , president of the Goodman Family Foundation, and a member of the . He served on the  from 1985 to 1989.\n\n\nGoodman married Barbara Furrer in 1955; they had three children and were married until her death in 2006. \n\nGoodman died from respiratory failure at a hospital in , on June 3, 2014, aged 84. He had fallen ill while traveling home to New York from Harvard Business School in Massachusetts, where he had attended graduation ceremonies for one of his grandchildren.\n\n\n\n\n\t\n\t\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Albert A. Stirpe Jr.''' (born June 16, 1953) is a politician who serves as a member of the  representing the 127th Assembly district first elected in 2006. He is a . Stirpe's district comprises the towns of Cicero, Clay, Manlius, Pompey and Tully in Onondaga County, Central New York.\n\n\nStirpe was born and raised in  where his family owned and operated Albert's Restaurant for more than 26 years. After graduating from high school with honors in 1971, he attended the  and graduated in 1975 with a degree in economics. At Notre Dame, Stirpe was a place kicker and punter on the football team. He lives in North Syracuse with his wife, Chele, and their daughter, Alexandra. He is involved with Casey's Place in Syracuse, NY.\n\n\nStirpe ran for the New York Assembly in 2006 when his Republican predecessor decided to run for the 49th District Senate seat against the incumbent. Though he was not the Onondaga County Democrats designated candidate, he won the September primary and went on to win the seat in November. His Republican opponent was William Meyer of Cicero, NY.\n\nAl Stirpe was opposed by Republican David Knapp in 2008, but won reelection in what was one of the most hotly contested races in New York State - 59% to Knapp's 41%. In 2010, Stirpe lost to  by 953 votes.\n\nIn a hotly contested rematch in 2012, costing over $800,000, Stirpe won the election with almost 6,000 more votes than Miller according to unofficial results. Stirpe carried Manlius, Cicero (his hometown) and Clay (Miller's home town). Miller carried Tully, Pompey and Fabius. This was the most expensive state assembly race in this election year. In another hotly contested election in 2014, Stirpe won the election with over 2,000 more votes than his opponent, Rob DeMarco.\n\nThe 2020 campaign was unique in the large number of absentee ballots cast, with Stirpe initially behind in the vote count, but he pulled ahead when absentee votes were counted. Stirpe then went on to declare victory on December 1, 2020, after an extended time for counting ballots.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n| serviceyears        = 2001&ndash;2009\n| rank                = \n}}\n\n'''Gregory R. Ball''' (born September 16, 1977) is a former American politician from 2006 to 2014 (now a business executive), former active duty  officer and member of the  and the . He is a resident of .\n\n\n.]]\nBall was born on September 16, 1977 in , and grew up on Quaker Hill. In 1996, he was awarded the Falcon Foundation Scholarship and attended the  before receiving an appointment to the . While at the United States Air Force Academy, Ball interned in the  .  Retrieved on September 25, 2012.\n\nAt the Air Force Academy, Ball received a  in Government in 2001. He started a Masters in  at  in 2004 and was a  at the Center for the Study of the Presidency from 2002 to 2003.\n\n\nBall was commissioned as a Lieutenant in the United States Air Force and requested an assignment with the Air Force Academy's , and was posted in  for a one-year tour working as a . Ball was then assigned to the   at  in , as . The Ceremonies & Protocol office was responsible for planning, organizing and developing projects for the  and the , as well as coordinating  burial services at .\"I was honored to serve as Greg Ball's mentor while he was in the U.S. Air Force. ... As Greg excelled through the ranks and was promoted to Captain, I was honored to watch Greg perform as an outstanding young officer. Greg Ball graduated from the Air Force Academy, served in the White House Drug Policy Office, lived on Capitol Hill, and served in the 11th Wing in our Nation's capital working directly for four-star generals in the Pentagon and throughout the National Capitol Region. Few Lieutenants are chosen for such a demanding position.\"&ndash; Joseph P. Green, , . June 6, 2006.\n\nDuring his time in the Ceremonies & Protocol Office, Ball was a Project Officer for numerous events. The largest may have been the 2003 Global Air Chief's Conference, the first since 1997, for which he rented a cruise ship for a welcome reception in Washington, D.C., for dignitaries attending the Global Air Chiefs Conference.\n\nAs a lieutenant, Ball was charged with directing  in 2002, 2003, and 2004. He organized exhibits and demonstrations to recognize the contributions made by Hispanic countries and cultures, and hosted , then , in 2003. In 2003, Ball was nominated as \"Military Volunteer of the Year\" for the 11th Wing. He was awarded an  for outstanding service by   and was honorably discharged from active duty in January 2005, with the rank of captain.\n\n\nUpon his separation from active duty, Ball was recruited by the , based Exceed International, a commercial development corporation with a presence in India,  and .Chandramouly, Anjana. \"\". ''''. March 17, 2006. Placed in charge of the marketing department, he served as a team member with the Company President on a 38-company executive mission to an economic summit in , which included representatives from companies such as , , , , , , and . Later, Exceed invested $11.1 million in India to expand operations. Construction began on six projects in , which included the , and the , which helped Exceed establish a foothold in India. The company also invested as a joint venture partner in mixed use residential projects such as a water treatment facility.\n\nEventually, Ball was elevated to Vice President of Exceed's Northeastern United States division and returned to New York.\"\". ''''. Retrieved on February 24, 2008. The  based developer employs nearly 400 people in various fields such as project management, development, architecture, engineering, construction, government relations, finance, and technology. In 2006, Exceed proposed a $75 million urban renewal project for the village of  which would generate some $2 million a year in tax revenue for the town.\" \". ''''. March 24, 2006. The village's Mayor noted that \"All of the infrastructure work recently completed by defining our identity within the watershed has paid off. Brewster finds itself in a situation where people are eagerly interested in working with the village in partnership to see our village revitalized\".\n\n\nIn early 2005, Ball announced his candidacy for State Assembly as a  and stated he would attempt to unseat the incumbent Assemblyman  in a primary. Stephens' family had held the seat nearly continuously for eighty years: his grandfather, , represented the district from 1926 to 1952; his father, Willis Stephens Sr., held the seat from 1952 to 1982; and Stephens himself served from 1994 to 2006. Ball received over $110,000 in campaign contributions for the race. He was placed on the primary ballot by the signature of over 1800 petitioners.\n\nIn 2004, while living in D.C., Ball created a charity polo event for underprivileged youth known as the , which presented $10,000 to charities in 2005. The Courage Cup was also investigated by the '''' after allegations that Ball was diverting funds from the charity to his political campaigns. The ''Poughkeepsie Journal'' noted that Ball's political action committee made a donation to the Courage Cup charity for the use of the tent at the event. The group then solicited funds for Ball in the tent, an activity the assemblyman said was \"perfectly legal and above-board.\".\n\nAt times Ball's campaign was noted for its unorthodoxy.  Ball himself dressed up in a chicken suit and followed around Stephens after the incumbent refused to debate him.Risinit, Mike. \" \". ''''. May 31, 2006.\nOn September 12, 2006, in the Republican Primary for New York's 99th District, Ball defeated Stephens in a landslide with 70.4% (5,165 votes) to 29.6% (2,176 votes) for Stephens, the lowest vote total for any incumbent running for reelection to the State Assembly that day. Stephens drew criticism when he refused to repudiate a letter about challenger Greg Ball which falsely claimed Mr. Ball had received a dishonorable discharge from the United States Air Force.\n\nAccording to a 2006 interview, Ball's ultimate political ambition is to become the Governor of New York State.\n\n\n.]]Ball has stated that \"since my election victory, we have made extraordinary progress by elevating the debate on tough issues like taxes, illegal immigration and dysfunction in Albany.\" He was sworn into office on January 8, 2007. The first time Ball rose to speak in the Assembly chamber, he called the legislature \"dysfunctional\", and withstood boos from his colleagues. The next day, Governor Spitzer called Ball to express support for his sentiments.Risinit, Mike. \" \". ''''. February 9, 2007.\n\nBall stated that \"It was not easy getting up as the new guy and standing up to tell a group of people what they don't want to hear\" but his speech became so popular that soon dozens of reporters began calling, he appeared on , excerpts from the floor speech popped up on numerous political blogs, his campaign web site received so many visits that its server crashed, and, a  video of his remarks was ranked 80th among new videos the day it was uploaded.Confessore, Nicholas. \"\". ''''. February 10, 2007. Although the remarks were contentious, they echoed a fifty-six page study from the nonpartisan   , which referred to the legislature as \"the least deliberative and most dysfunctional in the nation\".\n\nAs ranking member of the Veterans Affairs Committee, Ball announced legislation expanding the eligibility for veterans to receive tax exemption benefits, including the exemption of real property owned by certain disabled veterans from property taxation. Ball authored the bill that created the tuition remission program for veterans, offering them free tuition at both  and  undergraduate and graduate institutions. Governor Eliot Spitzer included the measure in his 2008 executive  proposal, and the measure was kept funded in Governor David Paterson's version.\n\nAccording to '''', one key to Ball's success was that his campaign identified the concern local voters cared most about: illegal immigration.West, Debra. \"\". ''''. August 12, 2007. The '''' reported that Ball, who has called for some local prison and police officials to be trained by Immigration and Customs Enforcement to help deport illegal immigrants, defines himself as a moderate on the immigration issue. Ball made illegal immigration a focal point of his bid for office.Klein, Benjamin. \"\". ''''. January 16, 2007. In October 2007, he strongly criticized . He was at the forefront of the opposition to the plan, and his Statewide petition to stop it led to the Assembly Minority Conference's decision to sue the Governor to stop the plan.\n\n and Assemblyman Ball disagreed on a number of issues, but worked together on several reform packages.]]Ball has worked to promote businesses that hire legal immigrant laborers, and has begun to create a database for usage on his campaign website.Risinit, Mike. \" \". ''''. April 25, 2007. His campaign headquarters in   may have been targeted over the contentious issue, and was vandalized with  in October 2006, although the person or persons responsible misspelled the word \"Fascist\" twice. An oft-quoted line from his campaign literature was that \"Illegal Immigration is Illegal\".\n\n\nBall was referred to as \"one of the rising stars in the Republican Party\" during speculation that he would run against freshman Congressman  in 2008, although he later ruled out a challenge against Hall.Risinit, Mike. \"\". ''''. December 31, 2007. In early May 2008, John Degnan, the former Mayor of , announced he would be mounting a challenge to the freshman Assemblyman. In the September 9th, 2008 primary, Ball won the primary by a 3 to 1 margin amongst Republicans. He again faced Degnan, who had the Democratic nomination, in the general election, and was re-elected with 60% of the vote.\n\n\nIn July 2010, State Senator  blamed Ball for a raid of the Senator's home which was conducted by the . The Senator was later arrested, tried, and convicted on several counts of Federal corruption charges. Ball had often accused the Senator of using the office as his \"personal piggy bank.\"  The feud between Leibell and Ball dated back to the 2008 election, when Ball first accused the Senator of orchestrating a \"smear campaign\" against him.  \n\nOn August 26, 2008, a local newspaper known as ''The Putnam Times'' published court documents surrounding the breakup between Ball and a Washington, D.C., woman in 2003. Ball blamed Leibell for hiring private investigators for the newspaper article, and for funding the campaign of his Democratic challenger, John Degnan. Ball stated both he and the woman both filed for orders of protection following the end of their relationship. In November 2003, both Ball and the woman asked the court to dismiss their complaints against each other, which was done. Ball told ''The Daily News'' that \"It was just a heartfelt breakup where both parties jointly requested a 'cooling off' period, and the entire matter was mutually dismissed. My life is an open book, and always has been.\"\n\nWhile ''The Putnam Times'', a local paper incorrectly reported that Ball violated the order of protection by following the woman to Israel on July 20, ''News Channel 12'', a regional network, pointed out that order of protection was filed six days earlier on July 14, and court records state Ball traveled to Israel on June 20. ''The Poughkeepsie Journal'' also later pointed out that there was never a criminal restraining order, and the documents printed by the ''Times'' was actually a , which anyone can request.\n\nFollowing the revelations that Ball's ex-girlfriend filed for an order of protection against him in 2003, on September 3, 2008, the ''Journal News'' reported that a former member of Ball's staff had accused him of sexually harassing her in a letter sent to Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver detailing the incident. Perrault's accusations were later found to be fabrications and Ball was exonerated.\n\nInitially, ''News 12'' analyst Mike Edelman called the report \"not credible,\" and many questioned the timing of the complaint, as the former staff member waited a year to write the letter until a few days before the primary election. The previous day, Ball had released e-mails from his former Chief of Staff, which stated that Perreault was ready to \"go forward with a lawsuit and 'embellish' some of the details,\" calling the letter to Silver into question. Ball said the letter was part of a \"smear campaign\", and that the ex-Chief of Staff was a \"mole\" for State Senator Vincent Leibell, who was backing his primary opponent. Ball released a taped phone conversation between the ex-Chief of Staff and a local political candidate, where his former deputy stated he was working for \"the senate\" to \"neuter\" Ball. Although at first, the ex-Chief of Staff denied working for the senate to ''The Journal News'', the next day, he admitted it in another article, but Senator Leibell denied any conspiracy.Risinit, Michael. \"\". ''''. September 7, 2008.\n\nThe Assembly Ethics committee met in October 2008, reaching a 'not guilty' verdict and ruling that no harassment ever occurred, and unanimously voted to throw out the charges against Assemblyman Ball. The accuser, the 60-year-old Perrault, had been the target of numerous sexual harassment allegations at a prior job, where she was a supervisor. It was noted that Ball's accuser had herself settled four lawsuits for an undisclosed sum, at least three of which accused her of sexual harassment.\n\n\nIn May 2009, Ball announced he was a candidate for Congress in New York's 19th congressional district. Ball drew some attention by raising more money than incumbent Congressman John Hall in the second quarter of 2009. On November 21, 2009, Ball abandoned his Congressional run and decided to run for State Senate in District 40, the seat formerly held by .  In a letter to his supporters, Ball stated that the job of reforming Albany had not been completed, saying, \"From property tax reform to corruption in government, the job I set to do in 2006 is still incomplete, and it can only be accomplished by continuing to tackle our nation's most dysfunctional legislature.\"  Ball, who was opposed by the Republican Party operatives, defeated endorsed Republican candidate and  town supervisor Mary Beth Murphy in a primary election in September 2010. On November 2, 2010, Ball won election to the New York Senate from the  by a 52%-48% margin over , also from Somers.\n\n\nOn June 24, 2011, Ball voted against allowing same-sex marriage in New York during a senate roll-call vote on the Marriage Equality Act, which narrowly passed 33-29 and legalized marriages performed in the state regardless of the genders involved in the union. In a , Ball said he did not think the bill went far enough in extending religious protections for \"individuals and businesses with religious objections\" to marriage equality for same-sex couples.\n\nBall opposes drilling in the  and in particular the use of  in the process.Campbell, Jon (December 21, 2011).  . ''Gannett News Service''. Retrieved December 21, 2011. He has taken several tours of Pennsylvania with , the director of ''''.\n\nBall supported the temporary two-month extension of the Social Security payroll tax relief, calling out incumbent Representative Nan Hayworth for voting against the bill using class-related rhetoric, accusing Hayworth of being out of touch with her constituents.\n\nIn 2012, Ball has expressed strong support for the use of public funds to transport private school students and is currently trying to increase the distance for these children that the public schools would be responsible for.\n\nBall spoke out against publishing the names and addresses of handgun permit holders, insulting the editors of , and accusing them of privacy violation.\n\nGregory Ball has taken a strong, public stance against medical marijuana since bills regarding the topic have come before the NYS senate after passing through the Assembly. After Just Say Now activists contacted their representatives during the week of April 1, 2013, Senator Gregory Ball tweeted  , \"Receiving emails, calls on \"Medical\" Marijuana...let me be clear: Marijuana is NOT medicine. Period. Next topic...\"\n\nIn April 2013, Ball argued on  that , one of the perpetrators of the , should be tortured in order to obtain information on any possible attacks in the future. He subsequently got into a heated on-air exchange with  host  when asked to defend his Twitter post.\n\n\nIn May 2014, Ball announced that he would not seek reelection, opting instead to return to the private sector. He was replaced by  town councilman  on January 1, 2015.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Latoya Joyner''' (born September 13, 1986) is a New York politician who served as the Assembly member for the  of the  from 2015 to 2024. The district includes portions of , , ,  and  in . She is a .\n\n\nJoyner was born and raised in  and graduated from the Richard R. Green High School for Teaching. She later attended  for her undergraduate degree and later the  for law school. At Stony Brook, Joyner was a member of Chi Alpha Epsilon Honor Society and .\n\nPreviously, she served as a member of the  and with the . She was a community liaison in the district office of former Assemblywoman , and later was a member of .\n\n\nAssemblywoman  resigned from her seat after being elected to the  in 2013, and following her resignation, the seat remained vacant for a year. Joyner entered the race to succeed her, and in a four-way primary, easily won the election. She would win the general election with nearly 95% of the vote.\n\nJoyner was sworn in for her first term on January 1, 2015. She served on the Subcommittee on Diversity in Law as its Chairwoman. Joyner announced her resignation effective January 8, 2024, to pursue a new opportunity. She was succeeded by attorney and fellow Democrat .\n\n\n\n\n\n* ''official site''\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Harvey Weisenberg''' (born December 31, 1933) is an American politician from .\n\n\nWeisenberg was born on December 31, 1933, and has been a lifelong resident of . He graduated from  in 1952. After attending  on a basketball scholarship, he earned a  degree from  in 1958. He holds a  degree from  (1962), along with a professional diploma in administration from the  (1981). He served as a police officer for the City of Long Beach, then spent over 20 years (1967–1989) working for the  School District, starting as a teacher and eventually becoming an administrator. He and his wife Ellen have five children.\n\nWeisenberg also entered politics as a , and was a member of the Long Beach City Council. He was President of the Long Beach City Council in 1977 and 1980.\n\nOn February 14, 1989, he was elected to the State Assembly, to fill the vacancy caused by the resignation of . He was re-elected many times, and remained in the Assembly until 2014, sitting in the , , , , , , , , , , ,  and s. He represented the 20th assembly district which comprised , , , , , , the , and parts of  and . He rose to the position of Assistant . In 2007, he sponsored .     "pages": }\n'''William Colridge Thompson Jr.''' (born July 10, 1953), ''The Brooklyn Rail'', Apr-May 2003, '''', July 9, 1996, ''New York Times'', Aug. 25, 2001 is an American politician who served as the 42nd ; sworn into office on January 1, 2002, he was reelected to serve a second term that began on January 1, 2006. He did not seek re-election in 2009. Instead he ran for mayor, and he was succeeded as comptroller by . On June 15, 2016, Thompson was appointed by New York State Governor  as chairman of the board of trustees of The ; his term ended in June 2022.\n\nThompson ran unsuccessfully in the  for  as the nominee of the  and  parties, and he unsuccessfully sought the Democratic nomination in the .\n\n\nThompson was born and raised in the  neighborhood of .  He is the son of Elaine Thompson, a New York City public-school teacher, and , formerly a prominent Brooklyn  leader, ,  and judge on ., ''New York Times'', July 9, 1996 His grandparents immigrated to New York City from  in the Caribbean.  Thompson attended , a public school in Brooklyn, and graduated from  in 1974.\n\n\nUpon his graduation from Tufts University in 1974, until 1982, Thompson served as the special assistant and chief of staff to former Brooklyn Democratic Rep. , who pleaded guilty to income tax evasion, marijuana possession and making an illegal payment to a government employee and who resigned his seat pursuant to a plea agreement in 1982. Later, Thompson became the youngest Brooklyn Deputy . As deputy to Borough President , Thompson was Golden's designee to the . Following the , Thompson worked to fix the racial divide that had paralyzed Brooklyn. In 1993, Thompson moved to the private sector for one year, taking a position as senior vice president of the investment firm George K. Baum & Co.\n\nAs a member of the , from 1994 to 2001, and a five-term president, from 1996 until 2001, Thompson worked for centralized management of the public school system., ''Education Update Online'', Feb. 2006 Thompson also fought for better after-school programs, improved teacher quality, and an expanded arts curriculum.\n\nWhile serving the board of education, Thompson also worked as a political consultant, the director of  (now ), and director of a financial firm headed by Michael. W. Geffrard, a former deputy city comptroller. Thompson resigned from the board of education in March 2001 to run for the office of Comptroller.\n\nThompson has also served on the boards of the , , , New York  and each New York City .\n\n\n\n\nIn the role of City of New York's chief financial officer, Thompson led a team of 720 employees, managed a $66 million annual operating budget and the country's 5th largest pension fund, a multibillion-dollar fund that was rated among the top 20 in the world. As New York City Comptroller, Thompson was the custodian and investment advisor to the five boards of trustees of the Five New York City Pension Funds, which included the New York City Employee's Retirement System; the Teachers' Retirement System of the City of New York; the New York City Police Pension Fund; the New York City Fire Department Pension Fund; and the New York City Board of Education Retirement System.  Thompson worked to diversify the pension portfolio from primarily public equities into private equity, real estate and other asset classes, and since 2003, the funds grew at a pace of 12.33 percent a year, outperforming its actuarial return assumption of 8 percent. In addition, during Thompson's tenure, assets managed by minority-and-women-owned firms increased from less than $2 billion to over $6 billion.\n\nThompson called on American firms in the pension portfolio – including  and  – to document the impact of their businesses on the environment. He advocated that companies doing business in  embrace the goal of equal opportunity employment and supported efforts to prohibit workplace discrimination based upon sexual orientation. Since, funds reinvested in New York City, leading to the creation and rehabilitation of more than 20,000 units of affordable housing, the development of thousands of square feet of commercial space, and investments related to creating clean and renewable sources of energy.\n\nIn 2003, Thompson led the effort to deposit $200 million in city funds to establish new bank branches in traditionally underserved neighborhoods, enabling more New Yorkers to open checking accounts and apply for business loans and mortgages. Thompson has developed a number of community service and education programs to help New Yorkers deal with the challenges of the economic crisis. These programs include consumer banking days (regular events that take place in every borough and feature workshops addressing savings and credit issues), predatory lending reforms and general investment strategies.\n\nIn an analysis of Thompson's use of the comptroller's office to audit city government, the on-line journal ''City Limits'' opined that \"Thompson has not been a ferocious antagonist to Mayor Michael Bloomberg. Instead, he has mostly praised the mayor's budgets, smiled on his economic policies and hailed Bloomberg's accomplishments with the city's schools.\" , ''City Limits Weekly'', No. 693, July 13, 2009 However, ''City Limits'' reported the Comptroller's office and the Bloomberg administration in fact engaged in hundreds of \"low-level skirmishes\" over the Comptroller's audits of city agencies and programs, although Thompson did not audited the mayor's office and mayoral agencies as often as his predecessor, , under Mayor . ''City Limits'' concluded \"the jury is still out on the impact Thompson's audits on city services.\"\n\n\n\n\nThompson was opposed by , a man from Queens, for the Democratic nomination to run in November 2009 against incumbent mayor . On September 15, 2009, Thompson overwhelmingly won the Democratic nomination, defeating Avella by 70 points.\n\nOn July 9, 2009, Thompson was endorsed by the Working Families Party.\n\nOn July 21, 2009, the Comptroller's office released a report suggesting the Bloomberg administration had falsely inflated graduation rates in city schools. Thompson's report did not demonstrate any conclusive evidence of manipulation, \"saying only that a lack of oversight, coupled with intense pressure to push up the graduation rate, created the potential for abuse.\", ''New York Times'', July 21, 2009 Thompson also criticized Bloomberg's managerial style as creating incentives for schools to graduate unqualified students. The  released a 38-page rebuttal to Thompson's allegations.  In addition on July 21, 2009, Thompson said on  that School's Chancellor  should be fired, referring to his Department of Education as \"The Enron of American education. Showing the gains and hiding the losses.\". It was reported that on October 29, 2009, the principal of Lehman High School was being investigated for granting students credits inappropriately and graduating students without them having completed the required course work. Thompson reiterated once again that the  breeds abuse.\n\nThompson's 2009 mayoral candidacy received endorsements from President , both of New York's U.S. Senators ( and ), Governor , Attorney General , U.S. Congressmen  and , , , , Rev. , ,  and former mayor , among others.\n\n after losing the mayoral election.]]\n, the city's largest union, endorsed Thompson on August 13, 2009, giving Thompson \"crucial labor support\" according to the ''New York Times''. The union, representing 125,000 workers and 50,000 retirees, endorsed Bloomberg in 2005.  On June 19, 2013, the  delegates voted to support Thompson. Other unions that endorsed Thompson include the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers Local Union #3, FDNY-EMS Emergency Medical Technicians, Paramedics and Fire Inspectors Union Local 2507, the FDNY-EMS Officers Union Local 3621, the Retail, Wholesale and Department Store Union (RWDSU, UFCW), Allied International Union, Amalgamated Transit Union Local 1056/1181, Local 891, International Union of Operating Engineers, Civil Service Employees Association Local 1000, Communications Workers of America (CWA) District 1, International Association of Machinists District 15, International Brotherhood of Teamsters, Local 808, Local 94 of the International Union of Operating Engineers, The Associated Musicians of Greater New York, Local 802 AFM, and Transport Workers Union (TWU) Local 100.\n\nAs of October 6, 2009, Mayor Bloomberg's lead over Thompson had shrunk to 8%.\n\nThompson's mayoral campaign against Bloomberg in 2009 was close, but on November 3, 2009, Bloomberg won a third term by edging out Thompson by 4.6 percent.\n\n\nIn 2010, Thompson joined Siebert Brandford Shank & Co., L.L.C. – the largest African-American, woman and Latino owned investment banking firm in the country, handling more than $2 trillion in infrastructure financing. He became a partner in 2015.\n\nIn 2010, New York State Governor  appointed Thompson chairman of the Board of The Hugh L. Carey  Authority (BPCA) – a Class A public-benefit corporation created by  in 1968 to redevelop outmoded and deteriorated piers, a project that has involved reclaiming the land and facilitating new construction of mixed commercial and residential community uses. Thompson held the position until 2012, previously serving on the New York State Gaming Facility Location Board, and, since 2011, he has chaired Governor Andrew Cuomo's  Task Force.\n\n\n\nThompson announced his intention to run again for mayor as a Democrat in 2013, when the seat will next be up for election.  Unlike his 2009 campaign, there was no incumbent in the race in 2013, as New York's term-limits law prohibited Mayor Bloomberg from running for a fourth term.  Chancellor  joined his campaign in April, as campaign chairwoman.\n\nAccording to the 's website, as of the March 2013 filing deadline Thompson had raised over $2.7 million in private funds, fourth among registered Democratic contenders, and fifth overall. According to a report in the New York ''Times'', former New York Republican   was Thompson's largest financial backer as of May 2013.\n\nThompson lost the Democratic  for mayoral candidate to , coming in second place with 26.2% of the vote.\n\nSince 2015, Thompson has served as chairman of the , chairman of the , and since 2016, chairman of the  board of trustees. He is trustee emeritus of Tufts University (2003–2008) and KeySpan/Brooklyn Union Gas Company. Thompson was selected by the NYS Governor to head NYC's .\n\n\nA lifelong Brooklyn resident, Thompson moved to  in 2008 after marrying Elsie McCabe Thompson, a Harvard-trained lawyer and the former president of the  as well as former chief of staff to Mayor .\n\n\n\n* \n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Malcolm Anthony Smith''' (born August 9, 1956) is an American politician from New York who was convicted of public corruption. A , Smith was a member of the State Senate, representing   the  in the  from 2000 to 2002 and  from 2003 to 2014. Smith served as  in 2009 and served as Temporary President of the New York State Senate from 2009 to 2010; he is the first African-American to hold those leadership positions.\n\nOn April 2, 2013, Smith was arrested by the  on federal  charges. The  and the  alleged that Smith attempted to secure a spot on the Republican ballot in the 2013 New York City mayoral election through  of New York City Councilman  and two other Republican officials. In September 2014, Smith's Democratic primary challenger, former New York City Councilman , defeated Smith in a landslide. The following year, Smith was convicted of all charges against him and sentenced to seven years in federal prison.\n\n\nA  native, Malcolm Smith earned a bachelor's degree in  from  and went on to earn an  from . At Adelphi, he was inducted into , an  for business administration. He has also completed  from  and .\n\nPrior to his political career, Smith worked in . In 1985, he was named president of Neighborhood Housing Services of . In 1991, he founded Smith Development Corporation, and subsequently built over 100 housing units in southeastern Queens,  and . He was also responsible for several notable commercial projects such as the Pathmark Plaza-Springfield Gardens, the interior of the  building, and the s at  in Jamaica.\n\n\n in 2009.]]\nSmith began his political career as a senior aide and political protégé to Congressman  from 1986 to 1991. Smith also served as a chief aide to  , who was an assistant to Mayor , and a member of the advance staff for vice presidential candidate  in 1984.\n\nSmith was first elected to the New York State Senate in a 2000 . He was elected  in January 2007, succeeding . After the , Democrats gained a majority of seats in the State Senate for the first time in 40 years, and Smith was subsequently chosen as  of the body in January 2009. He was the first African American to hold this position. However, on June 8 of that year, Sens.  and  joined with the thirty  in voting to replace Smith as Senate Majority Leader, triggering the . The crisis concluded the following month when Espada and Monserrate abandoned their alliance with the Republicans and rejoined the Senate Democratic Conference. As a compromise, Smith retained only the title of Temporary President of the Senate, with the title of Majority Leader going to Espada.\n\nSmith's legislative achievements included securing funding for a  in , a  cleanup project in Jamaica, and a three-bill package to combat . He also helped launch a series of forums statewide for prevention of .\n\nSmith also sought to curb . In the wake of the , Smith created and chaired the Tri-Level Legislative Task Force, which released a report on increasing public confidence in law enforcement and the criminal justice system. Some of its recommendations were passed by the state legislature.\n\nSmith was re-elected to his State Senate seat without opposition in 2012. Following his reelection, he joined forces with the  to form a \"bipartisan governing coalition\" with Senate Republicans. He expressed interest in running for  as a Republican in the . He would have needed a  certification in order to do so. His attempts to obtain that certification led to his April 2, 2013 arrest by the FBI for allegedly attempting to bribe Republican leaders whose permission he needed to run for mayor on the Republican ticket despite being a registered Democrat. Following Smith's arrest, he was expelled from the Independent Democratic Conference. In September 2014, Smith's Democratic primary challenger, former New York City Councilman , defeated him in a landslide.\n\n\nIn 2010, a federal  investigated Smith's involvement in various nonprofit groups.\n\nIn 2010, Smith stated that if the Democrats retained control of the State Senate in the , he would direct his caucus to use  and \"draw the lines so that Republicans will be in oblivion for the next twenty years.\" The Democrats lost control of the chamber in that election and his threat would not be fulfilled.\n\n\nOn April 2, 2013, Smith was arrested by the  on federal  charges.\n\nSmith's trial, along with the trial of co-defendants , , Vincent Tabone, and Joseph Desmaret, began in the , New York, on June 1, 2014. Shortly after the trial started, it became known that some conversations that had been secretly recorded and could be used as evidence were in , and that prosecutors had not given those recordings to the defense. The Yiddish amounted to more than 28 hours on the recordings, which would have taken weeks to translate, transcribe, and analyze. This would have pushed what would have been a two-week trial well into July. After four of the jurors contended a longer trial would interfere with work and child care, aSmith and some of the defendants were granted a mistrial on June 17, 2014. Halloran did not request a mistrial, and was convicted of the charges against him.\n\nAt Smith's second trial, he was convicted on February 5, 2015, of all the corruption charges he faced. Those charges included conspiracy, wire fraud, travel act bribery, and extortion. The jury deliberated only briefly before returning with the guilty verdict. On July 1, 2015, Judge  sentenced Smith to seven years in prison.\n\nAs of July 2019, Smith was incarcerated at the , Pennsylvania. The Bureau of Prisons' Inmate Locator lists Smith's status as \"Released\" as of October 22, 2021.\n\n\nSmith is a member of the . He is married to Michele Lisby-Smith. They have three children, Tracey, Julian and Amanda. In 2006, a former aide of Smith's filed a  against him, and he eventually acknowledged paternity of the aide's child and began paying .\n\n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n*\n* at \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

Miller''' (born December 12, 1960) is an American politician and a  former member of the , representing the 38th Assembly District, which includes the  neighborhoods of , , ,  and .\n\nHe has lived in Glendale for 40 years. Miller is a graduate of  and attended  and the  Management School at the . He was branch manager of the Tiger Federal Credit Union. He also served as member of .\n\nMiller has been a member of the  since 2009, when he won a  held after the resignation of former Assemblyman . Miller won the subsequent 2010 general election with 69 percent of the vote. Miller was defeated by  in the .\n\n\nMiller was born to an Italian mother and German father, both first generation immigrants.\n\n\n\n\nOn December 2, 2009, Miller sided with the conservative minority, by voting against a bill legalizing same-sex marriage.  Miller voted against a similar bill that became the  in 2011.\n\n\n\n\nIn New York, candidates for special election are nominated by the party's county executive's selection. Miller's party nomination was met with a lawsuit filed by fellow Democrats. His nomination was seen by some as a back room deal. Al Baldeo, who claims he was promised the nomination by Congressman , State Senators  and , argued that the selection process was undemocratic. Farouk Samaroo argued that the selection process was to prevent an  on the ballot.\n\n\nThe New York Daily News reported that Miller was among the  that refuse to disclose his outside income.  This came 14 weeks after the state legislature publicly supported and approved a bill requiring them to disclose their outside income.  The bill that was vetoed by Governor .\n\n\n\nMiller became the subject of a 2019 internal investigation by the Assembly Ethics Committee stemming from a harassment complaint filed by a female staffer. The committee found evidence of inappropriate and unprofessional conduct, though the review did not \"support a finding that Miller engaged in harassment and/or discrimination.\" The investigation came to light in June 2020 when it was revealed that the committee's investigator uncovered multiple instances in which Miller discussed the case with outside parties in breach of confidentiality and with what the committee determined as having the \"effect of intimidating potential witnesses.\" In August 2020, Assembly Speaker  announced that he would formally sanction Miller for these actions, following the committee's recommendation.\n\n\n* '''September 2009 , NYS Assembly, 38th AD'''\n:\n\n* '''November 2010 general election, NYS Assembly, 38th AD'''\n:\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Michael Jon Bragman''' (August 11, 1940 – October 13, 2023) was an American politician from . A member of the , he served in the  from 1981 to 2001, and was the assembly's majority leader from 1993 to 2000. He left politics after unsuccessfully attempting to remove then-Speaker of the Assembly  from his post in 2000.\n\n\nMichael Jon Bragman was born on August 11, 1940, in . He graduated from  in 1963, and worked as a schoolteacher.\n\n\nBragman entered politics as a , and was elected to the  Town Council in 1965, and to the Onondaga County Legislature in 1969. He was a member of the  from 1981 to 2001, sitting in the , , , , , , , , ,  and s. During his first term, he was indicted on charges stemming from his time in the county legislature; he was accused of seeking $1.6 million in bribe money from a company selling an incineration plant, though he was acquitted. \n\n'''' said that Bragman \"exerted a profound influence in the Assembly. He was credited with successfully sponsoring more than 300 bills and pumping some $200 million in  for local projects in his Central New York State district, which was centered in Syracuse\".\n\n\n\nA centrist Democrat, he served as Majority Leader from 1993 to 2000, when he lost his position after leading an attempted coup against Speaker . The move came amid criticism from some Democrats in the assembly that Silver's leadership style was too aloof. However, Bragman's attempt failed: after he announced his intent to overthrow Silver, the speaker demoted two high-ranking legislators who openly supported Bragman and made clear he would punish others who voted against him. In the floor vote on May 23, 2000, Silver prevailed by a vote of 85 to 63. \n\nBragman's political career was destroyed by his efforts to overthrow Silver. He lost his leadership position and resigned his seat in December 2001, where he was succeeded by Republican  in a special election.\n\n\nIn 1986, Bragman married Suzanne Collier, and they had three children. He died in Syracuse on October 13, 2023, at the age of 83.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Kevin A. Cahill''' (born November 5, 1955) is an American politician who was a member of the . Cahill is a  and represented parts of  from 1993-1994, then again from 1999-2022. He currently serves as an appointed member of the New York Tax Appeals Tribunal.\n\nCahill graduated from the  in 1977 with a BA in , and from  in 1980. From 1981 to 1990, Cahill worked as an attorney, while also serving on the Ulster County Democratic Committee. He was an Ulster County legislator from 1986 through 1992, when he served as minority leader of the Ulster County Legislature. From 1993 to 1994 he served as the Assemblyman from the 101st district. \n\nAfter 1994, Cahill served as the director of a  health care plan under contract with the . Cahill was elected again to the Assembly in 1998, and began his term in 1999.\n\nHe won each subsequent election for the Assembly until 2022, when he lost against Sarahana Shrestha in the Democratic Primary election on June 28, 2022 by less than 600 votes.\n\nHe was the chairman of the Standing Committee on Insurance.  He previously served as chairman of the Standing Committee on Energy. He also serves on the Health, Higher Education, Ways and Means and Commerce and Industry Committees, among others. He served as the chairman of the Assembly Committee on Ethics and Guidance, co-chair of the Joint Legislative Ethics Commission, the Assembly Science and Technology Commission, Assembly spokesman for Community Corrections, part of the task force on Local Government Finance Reform and the chairman of the Legislative Task Force on People with Disabilities in the past.  His term concluded in 2022.\n\n  appointed Cahill to the New York Tax Appeals Tribunal in 2023.\n\n\nCahill has two adult children and lives in .\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''John W. Mannion''' (born July 8, 1968) is an American politician who has served as the  from the  since . He was elected defeating  Angi Renna and became the first  to hold the seat in more than 50 years. Prior to becoming a state senator, Mannion was a high school biology teacher.\n\nMannion is the winner in  election for , defeating incumbent U.S. Representative .\n\n\nMannion was born and raised in  and is the grandson of Irish immigrants. His mother worked for  and his father was employed by  .\n\nMannion attended  and later graduated from  with a 's degree in biology. He went on to earn a  in secondary science education from . \n\n\nAfter completing his studies, Mannion became a high school biology teacher. He taught in the , where he also served as president of the West Genesee Teachers' Association.\n\n\nIn 2018, Mannion ran for the  in the  but narrowly lost to the incumbent, Republican  . He ran again in 2020 and won the seat with 52.57% of the vote, defeating Republican Angi Renna.\n\nMannion's 2022 re-election campaign was closely contested. On election night, Republican candidate Rebecca Shiroff led by 396 votes before absentee ballots were counted. A recount ultimately declared Mannion the winner, with a margin of 10 votes, making it the closest race in the 2022 New York State Senate elections.\n\nIn 2023, Mannion announced his candidacy for  in the 2024 election, choosing not to seek re-election to the Senate. In June 2024, three individuals, claiming to be former staffers, accused Mannion and his wife of creating a hostile work environment. After an investigation, he was cleared of any misconduct.\n\n\nMannion is the chairperson of the Committee on Disabilities. He also serves as a member of the following committees:\n* The Committee on Children and Families\n* The Committee on Civil Service and Pensions\n* The Committee on Education\n* The Committee on Environmental Conservation\n* The Committee on Housing, Construction and Community Development\n* The Committee on Internet and Technology\n\n\nMannion won the 2024 Democratic primary for the U.S. House of Representatives in . He defeated Sarah Klee Hood and went on to face incumbent Republican Representative .\n\n\nMannion is married to his wife, Jennifer. They have three children.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Colin J. Schmitt''' (born June 20, 1990) is an American businessman and politician who served two terms as a member of the  from the , which covers parts of  and . He is a member of the .\n\nHe ran for  in the , losing to incumbent Democrat .\n\n\nSchmitt was born on  and raised in . He graduated from  in .\n\nHe earned a Bachelor of Arts degree in politics with minors in theology and religious studies from the .\n\n\nHe started his political career in the office of then-Assemblywoman . After graduating from the  in 2012, Schmitt joined the staff of State Senator , and later worked as the chief of staff for the town supervisor of .\n\nSchmitt is also a commercial real estate agent and a Sergeant in the .\n\n\nSchmitt first ran for office in 2012, campaigning for the 's . He lost in the primary to   Kyle Roddey, who in turn lost in the general election to  .\n\nSchmitt ran for the same seat again in 2016. He won the primary uncontested but lost to Skoufis in the general election, 53% to 47%.\n\nIn , after Skoufis had declared his campaign for the  of the , Schmitt announced he would run for the 99th district for a third time. He defeated Democrat Matthew Rettig with 53% of the vote, and was sworn into the Assembly on January 9, 2019.\n\nIn 2020, Schmitt defeated Democratic challenger Sarita Bhandarkar to hold his seat winning all ten towns of that district that year.\n\nOver the course of his four years in the NY Assembly, Schmitt passed 9 prime sponsored bills through the chamber and co-sponsored over 75 other’s that passed the Assembly. Several of his bills that did not become law were more controversial, including an attempted ban on  and classroom lessons that made students feel discomfort about racism, and a prohibition on mask guidance or mandates from New York state.\n\n\n\nFollowing the 2020 election, Schmitt announced his candidacy for  in the 2022 election. Schmitt was defeated in the general election by incumbent Democrat  in a close race. Schmitt was supported by local and national small business groups including NFIB. In addition to advocating for small businesses, Schmitt campaigned on support for police, tighter border security and tackling the fentanyl crisis.\n\n\nPrior to announcing his run for Congress, Schmitt delivered send-off remarks to members of the Orange County Right to Life non-profit before they headed to the Washington, DC on January 6, 2021. The disclosure of this news resulted in immediate calls for Schmitt's resignation, which he resisted. Schmitt was not present in Washington, D.C. on January 6, 2021.\n\n\nFollowing Election Day, numerous media outlets reported on the attempt by a firm connected to the DCCC to illegally access the military records of Republican elected officials and candidates for congress. Schmitt was one of the Republican candidates targeted by opposition research groups attempting to illegally access private military records. During the campaign some of Schmitt’s records were used in a report by the Intercept questioning the use of the term \"veteran\" to describe Schmitt by certain political supporters.\n\n\nSchmitt up not running but was appointed by  (NY) Supervisor George Hoehmann to be the new Director of Finance for the Hudson Valley municipality effective March 13.Jeff Lewis, This position serves as the pleasure of the Town Supervisor, still garned opposition from the sole Democrat on the Town Board, Patrick Carroll who stated \"Supervisor Hoehmann made representations that Schmitt was qualified and experienced for a financial job...this type of job shouldn't be a patronage job. The hardworking taxpayers deserve better for a steward of their money.\" Schmitt previously served on the local governments committee in the State Legislature and represented parts of Rockland County.\n\n\nIn April 2023, Schmitt announced he would run for New Windsor Town Supervisor, setting up a primary against fellow Republican Steve Bedetti (a town councilman). Schmitt held a narrow three-vote lead over Bedetti following election night. Still, after counting all absentee and affidavit ballots, Bedetti was declared the winner of the Republican primary by a five-vote margin (765 to 760). Schmitt was the  general election nominee.\n\n\nSchmitt is an active member of the , currently serving for over nine years. At the onset of , Schmitt was activated with his unit, 1569th Transportation Company, for the COVID-19 Relief Mission to distribute  throughout the state. Between Christmas and New Year 2022, Schmitt was activated for the Buffalo Blizzard Mission.\n\n\nSchmitt lives with his wife, Nikki Pagano-Schmitt, in .\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
