    "pages": }\n'''Joseph J. Lhota''' (; born October 7, 1954) is an American public servant and a former politician who served as the chairman of the  and was also a former deputy mayor of . He was the  nominee in an unsuccessful bid for  for . In January 2014, he became senior vice president, vice dean, and chief of staff at . In 2017, he returned to the chairmanship of the MTA, but would not run the authority day-to-day. He resigned from that position in 2018.\n\n\nJoe Lhota was born in , New York, the son of Jackie and Joseph \"Joe\" Lhota, a . Lhota was raised Catholic, and self-identifies as a Christian. The family later moved to . He was the first member of his family to attend college, graduating with honors from 's  with a degree in  in 1976. He received an  degree from  in 1980.\n\n\nUpon graduating from Georgetown University, Lhota joined Arthur Andersen & Co. in Washington, D.C. and specialized in health care finance. He worked there for two years before entering the Harvard Business School. Following Harvard, Lhota returned to New York City and began a fourteen-year career as an investment banker at  and . He specialized in public finance, serving state and local governments throughout the United States.\n\nIn 2002, Lhota became executive vice president of , as well as president of Lightpath, a fiber-based telecommunications company that offered telephone and high speed data services to businesses throughout the New York area. In 2010, he joined  as executive vice president as a member of the senior management team and chief administrative officer.\n\n\nIn early 2014, after his mayoral run, Lhota was appointed as senior vice president, vice dean, and  at , in charge of \"government outreach\", , and ning.\n\nFrom 2002 to 2015, Lhota served as a member of the board of directors of First Aviation Services, Inc. In 2015, FAVS became a private company. In 2014, Lhota became a board member of  Systems Corporation and was chairman of its audit committee until the company was sold in June 2016 to .\n\nIn 2016, Lhota became an independent member of the board of directors and chairman of the audit committee of .\n\n\n\n\nIn 1994, Lhota joined the administration of Mayor , where he held several positions over Giuliani's two terms. He first served as chief of staff to the deputy mayor for finance and economic development and that year was quickly promoted to New York City finance commissioner. In 1995, he was selected as director of the . In 1998, Giuliani appointed Lhota to deputy mayor for operations. As the head of the mayor's rat abatement task force, he was humorously known as \"\".\n\nLhota served as Mayor Giuliani's liaison to the , , ,  and . Additionally, he was responsible for oversight of the city's relationships with the public employee unions and development of collective bargaining agreement strategies.\n\n\nOn October 20, 2011,  Governor  nominated Lhota to serve as chairman of the , the largest mass transit provider in the United States (servicing 8.5 million customers daily). While awaiting confirmation by the , Lhota began serving as interim CEO. He was unanimously confirmed on January 9, 2012.\n\n]]\n with  and federal, state and city officials.]]\nLhota was responsible for ’s Fastrack program, which saw more than $16 million in productivity gains in 2012, by concentrating and targeting subway station maintenance efforts. In July 2012, Lhota announced a $30 million service enhancement package that restored transportation services that the MTA had previously eliminated in 2010, and added new transit services in underserved areas, including , the  and all New York City neighborhoods that had seen significant residential and commercial development since 2005. Lhota headed efforts to make information about the MTA and its services more accessible to its customers through its website and apps. He granted pay raises to managers at the MTA.\n\nWhen  devastated much of the New York metropolitan area in October 2012, Lhota shut down the MTA in advance of the storm and moved the system's trains to high ground to avoid damage from the storm surge. His other notable hurricane recovery measure was the rapid deployment of a free  to service the worst damaged line in . \nLhota also directed the MTA to provide regular details and updates to the public on the recovery efforts via social media and local news channels.\n\n\n rally across the  along with parents from low income neighborhoods in 2013]]\n\n\nLhota resigned as head of the MTA on December 31, 2012, to explore running for . On January 17, 2013, he filed paperwork with the  and the  to formally launch his mayoral campaign.\n\nLhota won the endorsements of all three major daily New York City newspapers for the Republican primary, with '''' stating, \"few people know better than Mr. Lhota how city government works.\" He won the primary on September 10, 2013, with 52.5% of the vote, defeating , who garnered 40.7%, and George T. McDonald, who captured 6.8%.\n\nIn the general election campaign, Lhota received the endorsements of Crain's New York Business, , Newsday, and The .\n\nLhota's economic plan focused on job creation primarily through municipal tax cuts. He said he wanted to lower the General Corporation Tax, phase out the Commercial Rent Tax, reform the Unincorporated Business Tax, and lower the hotel tax.\n\nLhota also proposed a tax incentive program to allow private sector developers to build  to incorporate affordable units. He planned to improve education in New York City by doubling the number of public s, particularly in low-income neighborhoods. He participated in a  Rally organized by  to protest Democratic candidate 's proposed rent requirement for the city's charter schools that were operating in public school buildings and ban on further co-location in public school buildings. He also proposed universal pre-kindergarten without raising taxes.\n\nLhota lost the general election to de Blasio, garnering 249,121 votes, or 24.3% of the voter turnout.\n\n\nIn January 2017, Governor Cuomo appointed Lhota to the committee charged with conducting a nationwide search for a new chair and chief executive officer of the MTA. In June 2017, Lhota was nominated by Cuomo to return to Chairman of the MTA. Lhota remained at NYU Langone, as he would not be the day-to-day executive of the MTA; that role was instead filled by Veronique Hakim.\n\nLhota's return to the MTA occurred in the middle of the . In summer 2017, the subway system was officially put in a state of emergency after a series of derailments, track fires, and overcrowding incidents. Cuomo ordered Lhota to come up with a reorganization plan for the subway within 30 days. Lhota's plan involved removing seats from subway cars, consolidating the subway's scattered operations, managing escalators and elevators, and repairing damaged and critically important signals and tracks. Press Release  MTA Headquarters  MTA Chairman Joseph Lhota Unveils New York City Subway Action Plan|website=www.mta.info|access-date=July 25, 2017|archive-date=April 24, 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210424164852/https://www.mta.info/press-release/mta-headquarters/mta-chairman-joseph-lhota-unveils-new-york-city-subway-action-plan|url-status=dead}}\n* See also:  The MTA had been criticized for implementing relatively cosmetic improvements, rather than performing needed repairs and upgrades to signals, power, tracks, station accessibility, and infrastructure. In response, Lhota said that the MTA was improving passenger experience not only on the trains, but also in the stations.\n\nOn November 9, 2018, Lhota resigned his position as chairman of the MTA, effective immediately, without having taken his $1-a-year salary. A ''Wall Street Journal'' article in October 2018 had speculated that Lhota was considering retiring because of potential conflicts of interest with his other roles as NYU Langone Health chief of staff, and as a lobbyist, though Lhota repudiated these claims. In July 2019, it was revealed that Lhota did resign in a letter to Cuomo due to a state ethics committee decision that he had too strong a potential conflict of interest.\n\n\nLhota is married to Tamra Roberts Lhota. The couple met while she was working in  They have one child.\n\nWhile he was raised  and identifies as , Lhota's maternal grandmother was . When asked why he didn't capitalize on his grandmother’s religious heritage to garner the city's Jewish voters, he responded, \"I think that would be patronizing.\"\n\n\nLhota defended his support for  and  as not only being in sync with New York City's  outlook but consistent with  and its intellectual premise in . Lhota called for expulsion of  from the  after Trump's remarks about banning Muslims from entering the United States. He later left the party in protest of Trump's policies. Lhota endorsed  in the .\n\nLhota revealed in 2021 that he was now a registered . He endorsed  for first preference in the , with  and  as his second and third picks, respectively.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Randy Daniels''' (born 1950) is an American businessman, politician, and journalist who served as  from 2001 to 2005.\n\nDaniels was appointed to the board of trustees of the  in 1997 and currently serves as vice chairman. He was previously the senior vice president for economic revitalization at the . He was nominated for both positions by former  . Daniels launched an unsuccessful   bid for  in 2006.\n\nDaniels served as the director of communications for the  President's Office from 1986 to 1988, and was appointed  to the  of the  in 1988. In 1992, he briefly became  of  under . Prior to his career in public service, Daniels worked as a correspondent for  and  of journalism.\n\n\nDaniels grew up in  in a housing project with nine siblings. The family later moved to suburban . He holds a bachelor's degree in government and journalism from . He is a former journalist and public relations professional.\n\nDaniel's wife, , was appointed as New York State Judge by Governor  in 2009.\n\n\n\nHe began his journalism career in Chicago, as a reporter for  radio. He was then employed with , first as a war correspondent for throughout the 1970s, and later as their Africa Bureau Chief in 1977. He became a familiar face on the evening news, covering eight wars and the . During this time he also worked adjunct Journalism professor at both the  and  Graduate School of Journalism.\n\n\nIn 1986 he became communications director for , president of the . He later became press secretary for the  of the  in 1988.\n\nDaniels began his career as a Democrat, but changed his party registration to Republican in 2002. He was briefly the  of New York City under former mayor . He was appointed as Pataki's secretary of state in 2001 and served in that capacity until 2005. He was considered a possible running mate for Pataki in 2002 for .\n\nDaniels was a candidate for the Republican nomination for Governor of New York in 2006. He was considered the most articulate speaker in the race, and gained support from party leaders in Central New York, particularly in . Daniels also won support from leaders of the state's Conservative Party.\n\nOn April 9, 2006 it was reported that Daniels would end his campaign the next day and endorse former Assembly Minority Leader  for governor. He denied that he was seeking to be Faso's  for lieutenant governor. Faso later choose Rockland County Executive C. Scott Vanderhoef as his running mate.\n\nDaniels was considered a possible future candidate for  or chairman of the , though he has said he does not have plans to run for office again, and would rather support Republicans from the private sector.\n\n\nDaniels served as vice chairman of Gilford Securities Incorporated from 2007 to 2015, and now serves as managing director of Pickwick Capital Partners, LLC, an investment banking firm based in .\n\n\n\n\n\n* ''\".\"'' New York, New York, 2020\n\n\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Nettie Mayersohn''' (May 30, 1924 – August 13, 2020) was a member of the , representing the 27th District in , . Her district extended from , to  and the northern edge of .\n\n\nShe was born on May 30, 1924. She graduated  from  in 1978. She was a resident of the   complex in . She was married Ronald Mayersohn until his death in 2005. The couple had two children, including Lee, a judge.\n\nMayersohn spent 30 years as a community activist, and was Executive Director of the New York State Crime Victims Board. She is a . She was a member of the  from 1983 to 2011, sitting in the , , , , , , , , , , , , , , and s, where she was a prime sponsor of the Baby AIDS Bill, which requires all newborns to be tested for that disease. The \"Black And Latino AIDS Coalition\" (BLAC) strongly supported Mayersohn's \"Baby AIDS Bill\" and the \"HIV Surveillance Bill\". , the HIV+ African American President of the community-based \"BLAC\", was criticized by New York City AIDS advocates for supporting Mayersohn but the two became close friends. She resigned her seat on April 1, 2011, reportedly to spend more time with her grandchildren.\n\nShe died on August 13, 2020, in , ,  at age 96.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Miriam Elizabeth \"Mimi\" Rocah''' (born July 28, 1970) is an American attorney currently serving as District Attorney for Westchester County, New York. In 2020, Rocah defeated incumbent Democrat Anthony Scarpino in a primary challenge and went on to win in the General election.\n\nSince taking office, Rocah has been particularly vocal in combating public corruption, governmental misconduct, substance abuse, and gun violence. Rocah has also promised to pursue criminal justice reform in .\n\nIn October 2023, Rocah announced that she would not seek re-election for Westchester County District Attorney in , but that she would serve out the rest of her term.\n\n\nRocah graduated  from  with a  degree in American history in 1992. She later obtained a Juris Doctor from , where she joined the  honors society.\n\nRocah started her legal career as a clerk for United States Eastern District Judge  and later, , United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit. She later took a position as a litigation associate at  law firm.\n\nIn February 2001, Rocah became an  for the  under U.S. Attorney . From 2012 to 2017, Rocah led the  division for Westchester County after being promoted by U.S. Attorney . In 2016, Rocah received the 2016 Women In Federal Law Enforcement Leadership Award from the Department of Justice. Rocah worked as an Assistant U.S. Attorney for the Southern District of New York for over sixteen years, leaving in 2017.\n\nRocah was also a Distinguished Fellow in Criminal Justice and professor at the .\n\nRocah was also a legal analyst for both  and , where she frequently criticized former President . She made her campaign announcement for Westchester County District Attorney on a segment for the show '''' on MSNBC News.\n\n\nIn December 2019, Rocah announced she would launch a primary challenge against incumbent Westchester County District Attorney Anthony Scarpino, a fellow Democrat. She won the primary election and was endorsed by Scarpino against  candidate Bruce Bendish.\n\nSix weeks before the General election was held, Bendish suspended his campaign for district attorney citing 'certain realities' in the race, clearing the way for Rocah to win the election. Rocah won the 2020 election for Westchester County District Attorney and was sworn in by her former employer, Preet Bharara, in January 2021.\n\nSince taking office, Rocah has launched numerous campaigns and policies aimed at combating government impunity and criminal justice reform. In July 2021, Rocah announced her office would dismiss all open cannabis possession cases and limited their prosecution going forward. She also garnered national press after requesting evidence on New York State Governor , following a state attorney general's report indicating he committed multiple acts of sexual harassment.\n\n\nRocah lives in , New York with her husband David Brian Anders, an attorney and partner at . Rocah’s father is a  and she is a proud .\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Joseph H. Holland''' is an American businessman, real estate developer, attorney, public servant, author, and civic leader. Holland was selected by Governor  to serve as Commissioner of the  Department of Housing and Community Renewal, a position he held from 1995 until his resignation in October 1996. Holland ran for Attorney General of New York in 1994 and 2018 and ran for Governor of New York in 2018; he has also run for New York State Senate.\n\n\nOne of ten children, Holland is the son of Laura Mitchell Holland and , who served as the  under  . He received a B.A. and an M.A. from . Holland played on the  squad. He became a member of the Academic Hall of Fame and was president of the  Society. Holland attended , graduating in 1983.\n\n\nA Republican, Holland served as co-chair of  successful 1994 gubernatorial campaign. Following his , Gov. Pataki appointed Holland Commissioner of the  Department of Housing and Community Renewal. Holland held this position from 1995 until October 1996, when he resigned to \"'focus on resolving outstanding personal business matters'\" following \"threats by creditors to [garnish] his state salary in a bid to enforce court judgments.\" At the time, a spokesperson for Gov. Pataki stated that the Governor \"accepted Holland's resignation 'regretfully'\" and added that \"'Commissioner Holland [had] served the state exceptionally well.'\"\n\nHolland has run for ; he also ran for  in the 1994 Republican primary, but \"dropped out of the race under pressure from GOP leaders to clear the way for , who won in November.\"\n\nIn early 2018, Holland announced that he was running for . Holland withdrew from the race on May 22, 2018 to instead run for . At the 2018 New York State Republican Party Convention, Holland gained enough votes to force a primary for the attorney general post; however, he threw his support to the first-place finisher, Keith Wofford.\n\n\nAccording to , Holland moved to Harlem in 1982; in the following decade, he opened a law office, \"started and ran a 15-bed homeless shelter in a church basement, founded a drug rehabilitation program and acquired a travel agency. He also opened the first Ben & Jerry's store in Harlem and a soul food restaurant, staffing both with homeless-shelter residents\". During the mid-1980s, Holland worked in Albany as Counsel to the New York State Senate Housing Committee.\n\nFollowing his stint as Commissioner of the New York Department of Housing and Community Renewal, Holland was a partner at the law firm of Wilson, Elser, Moskowitz, Edelman & Dicker. Holland left that post to form Uptown Partners, a real estate development company that focused on housing in Harlem; he reportedly sought to \"aid churches and nonprofit organizations by developing their underused properties, and encourage successful African-Americans to invest in blighted neighborhoods\". One of his projects, the Uptown Grand restaurant, enmeshed him in a flood of accusations and counter-accusations with regard to the financing of the enterprise and conflicts with his partner Thomas Lopez-Pierre., '''', Cyril Josh Barker, January 17, 2013. Retrieved October 10, 2018.\n\nAn author, Holland has published a spiritual memoir entitled ''From Harlem With Love:'' ''An Ivy'' ''Leaguer’s'' ''Inner-City Odyssey''; he has also published two plays (''Cast Me Down'', an Off-Broadway play that received six AUDELCO nominations, and ''Homegrown'', \"which experienced two extended runs at Harlem’s landmark National Black Theatre\") and a self-help book entitled ''The Touchstone Tools: Building Your Way To An Inspired Life''.\n\nHolland is an ordained minister.\n\n\nHolland married '''' correspondent Alisa White in 1995. The couple produced three children.  He has remarried since then.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
          }
        ]

    "pages": }\n\n'''Thomas K. Duane''' (born January 30, 1955) is an American politician from New York, who served in the  from 1999 to 2012, and in the  from 1992 to 1998.\n\nDuane was the first openly gay member of the New York State Senate, and the only such member during his tenure there. He was also the body's only openly HIV-positive member. He represented the , which stretched along 's  from  to , and includes the following neighborhoods: , , , , and part of the East Side, including the , ,  and .\n\n\nDuane holds a degree in American and Urban Studies from . Born at the old French Hospital on West 30th Street in , he was raised in , where he attended St. Andrew Avellino School and . After beginning a career as a Wall Street stockbroker, he moved into public service by volunteering for his community board and working for then-city comptroller Elizabeth Holtzman. In 2004, Duane completed Harvard University's  program for Senior Executives in State and Local Government as a  LGBTQ Victory Institute Leadership Fellow.\n\nHis brother, John F. Duane, served in the  in 1983–84 representing the 26th Assembly District in Queens. Duane's partner of 25 years is Louis Webre.\n\n\nDuane was first elected to the  in 1991 for the . Duane and , first elected in the same year, were the first two openly gay city council members in New York. For part of that time,  worked as his chief of staff. When he resigned his council seat on being sworn into the Senate, she successfully ran to succeed him.\n\nIn 1994, Duane ran for the  against incumbent , losing the primary election by a margin of two to one.\n\nDuane has also served as a member of his local Community Board, and four terms as Male Democratic District Leader in the .\n\nFirst elected to the New York State Senate in 1998, Duane took office the following January and won re-election every two years thereafter until leaving office in 2012.\n\nOnly the second openly  member of the , he later became one of six, alongside Assemblymembers , , ,  and .\n\nDuane was the lead sponsor of  in the . Following the failed 2009 Senate vote on the bill, New York City Council Speaker  thanked Duane and the State Senate leadership for bringing the bill to a vote and saying \"I applaud them for their dogged leadership on this issue.\" Same-sex marriage was legalized in New York in 2011, and the '''' described Duane as a \"leader\" in that legislative effort.\n\nDuane's signature legislative accomplishments in the New York State legislature included the passage of the  (SONDA) (2002) and , which requires mental health parity for patients by insurance companies (2006) which were subsequently signed into law by Governor .\n\nDuane was the prime Senate sponsor of the state's  (GENDA), which became law in 2019 after he had left office.\n\nDuane was also instrumental in the ultimate passage of the Hate Crimes Protection Act of 2000, which stipulates longer penalties for those convicted of alleged  and mandates that New York State keep an  of these crimes. Duane's advocacy of this cause was personal as well as principled; in 1983, he was hospitalized after being assaulted by two men shouting anti-gay epithets, yet the perpetrators were charged only with a misdemeanor. He also took the lead on \"Manny's Law\", which requires hospitals to disclose to indigent patients the availability of state-sponsored funds for health care costs, and worked to enact a rental cap of 30 percent of income for people who are living with AIDS and eligible for government financial assistance.\n\nHe was also a leader in bipartisan moves to require health insurers to cover  treatment, to improve health care for prisoners, and to make it harder for people to avoid paying child and spousal support.\n\nDuane has also fought overdevelopment in historic districts. In 2003, he was honored with a Village Award from the .\n\nAt one time he was Chairman of the Senate Committee on Health, and he later served as that committee's Ranking Minority Member.\n\nIn June 2012, Duane announced that he would be leaving the Senate, citing weariness with commuting between New York City and Albany and in general being ready for \"another chapter in my life.\"\n\nSince retiring from the State Senate, he has continued his advocacy work on behalf of the  community, disadvantaged children, people with , and others. He established Tom Duane Strategies, Inc., dedicated to working with organizations that improve the quality of life for New Yorkers. He has been an outspoken critic of Republican Party agendas, including the , and an ongoing supporter of LGBTQ rights. He has done philanthropic work with New York City's Anti-Violence Project, which coordinates the , and has served on its board of directors.\n\nDuane has received a number of honors, from organizations including , Congregation  (where he was the  speaker in December 2015), and The Alpha Workshops, which will be honoring him on May 15, 2017. In 2012 he received a Legends of the Village award from VillageCare, a nonprofit serving people with chronic, continuing, and rehabilitative care needs, which cited his championing of \"civil rights, including gay rights in particular, HIV treatment and outreach needs, health care initiatives that reach out to those who are underserved or not served at all, tenant rights and much more.\" In 2016 he received an Impact Award from ''''.\n\nIn January 2022, Tom Duane endorsed New York State Assembly candidate Tony Simone for the June 28, 2022 Democratic Party Primary.\n\n\n* \n* \n* \n* \n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n*\n* Video of NYS Senate speech, June 24, 2011\n*  Interview taped for PBS documentary.\n*\n*\n*\n* News article and video of NY Senate speech July 17, 2009\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''George D. Maziarz''' (born May 25, 1953) is a  politician from New York State.  From 1995 to 2015, Maziarz represented the  in the , which included all of , all of , and the towns of Sweden and Ogden in . In March 2018, Maziarz pleaded guilty to a misdemeanor to avoid trial on five felony charges arising out of the alleged filing of false campaign finance reports.\n\n\nMaziarz is a native of , where he was educated in local schools, first at Ascension Academy and then at , graduating in 1972. Four years later, he earned a Bachelor of Arts degree in history from . Senator George D. Maziarz's biography\n\nHe was appointed  in his hometown of North Tonawanda in 1978 at the age of 25 and he became  Clerk in 1989.  Six years later, State Senator  resigned his seat to become Commissioner of the , and Maziarz entered the State Senate after winning a special election.\n\nHe has served as President of the Chamber of Commerce of the Tonawandas, member of the Board of Directors of the United Way of the Tonawandas, member of the Corporate Advisory Board of  and Chairman of the popular Canal Festival of the Tonawandas. , Canal Fest of the Tonawandas.  He is also a past officer and long-time member of Live Hose Co. #4, member of the Niagara County Volunteer Firemen’s Association, Knights of Columbus Council 2535, S.C.O.P.E. and the Niagara University Booster Club.\n\nDuring the 2012 presidential election, Republican Mitt Romney chose George Maziarz as a Polish-American representative to support his campaign.\n\n\n\n\nMaziarz was first elected to the New York State Senate in 1995 and was a \"power-broker\" in  Republican circles during his term in office.Nick Reisman,  , ''NY State of Politics'' (July 13, 2014). In January 1997, Maziarz was named Chairman of the Senate Aging Committee, a post which he held through the 2001-2002 session. At various points Maziarz served as chairman of the Tourism, Recreation, and Sports Development Committee, Labor Committee, and Energy and Telecommunications Committee; he was also a member of the Rules; Higher Education; Crime, Crime Victims, and Corrections; Environmental Conservation; and Transportation committees. He voted against same-sex marriage legislation on December 2, 2009; the bill was defeated. In 2011, Maziarz voted against a similar bill allowing same-sex marriage in New York, the , which narrowly passed the Senate in a close 33-29 vote.\n\nIn July 2014, \"amid reports that his office [was] under investigation by a federal prosecutor,\" Maziarz announced that he would not seek re-election to the Senate that fall.\n\n\nIn 2014, a team of investigators of the  issued s that showed that \"Maziarz's campaign had failed to disclose $147,000 in contributions and $325,000 in spending.\"Thomas Kaplan, William K. Rashbaum & Susanne Craig, , ''New York Times'' (December 8, 2014). A review of Maziarz's bank records showed \"personal, nonpolitical expenditures\" made from campaign accounts; from 2007 through 2013, investigators found that credit and debit cards associated with Maziarz's campaign funds were used to pay \"$28,000 at stores like  and Michaels; $7,500 at , the photo-printing site; and $7,850 for reading material, including a stop at a Borders store at Kennedy Airport.\"\n\nIn March 2017, Maziarz was charged with five felony counts of filing false campaign expenditure reports. The 's Office charged that Maziarz had made the reports to illegally conceal $100,000 in payments to a former aide who had departed from his position amid accusations of sexual harassment.Jesse McKinley, , ''New York Times'' (March 23, 2017). Maziarz pleaded not guilty.\n\nOn March 20, 2018, Maziarz pleaded guilty to a misdemeanor as part of a deal allowing him to avoid trial for five felony counts. Maziarz was fined $1,000 \"after admitting to one count of offering a false instrument for filing as part of a scheme to cover up payments from his political campaign. \"\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

Seward''' (August 11, 1951 – July 27, 2024) was an American politician who was a Republican  from 1987 to 2020. Seward was first elected to represent the  in 1986. In his final term he represented the , which consists of , , and , as well as parts of , , , , , and .\n\n\nSeward was born in , and attended Oneonta public schools. He went on to  in Oneonta and graduated with a  in political science. He also studied at the Nelson Rockefeller Institute of SUNY Albany.\n\nSeward served as a Milford town justice and as chairman of the Otsego County Republican Committee. He was a delegate to the Republican National Convention in 1976, 1980, and 1988, and was also an alternate delegate in 1996. Seward and his wife Cynthia (née Milavec) resided in Milford, New York. The Sewards had two grown children, Ryan and Lauren.\n\n\nSeward was elected to the state senate in 1986 and was appointed chairman of the Senate Energy and Telecommunications Committee. In 1999, Seward became chairman of the Senate Standing Committee on Insurance.\n\nIn 2007, Seward was asked by former Senate Majority Leader  to assume a post in the senate leadership team as majority whip. In 2011, Senator Republican Leader  asked him to assume the position of assistant majority leader on conference operations.\n\nSeward voted against a same-sex marriage bill on December 2, 2009; the bill was defeated. He voted against legislation allowing  in New York again in 2011, but the bill was passed in a narrow 33–29 vote.\n\nIn November 2019, Seward announced that he was being treated for a recurrence of . In January 2020, he announced that he would not seek re-election.\n\n\nSeward died from cancer on July 27, 2024, at the age of 72.\n\n\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n*  Seward's New York State Senate site\n*  Sewards's personal senate site\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Joseph A. Errigo''' (November 30, 1938 – April 27, 2020) was an American politician who represented New York's 133rd Assembly District in the  from 2001 to 2010 and 2016 to 2018.\n\n\nErrigo was born in  in 1938 and graduated from the  in 1956. He served in the .\n\n\nErrigo then worked as a draftsman for the . From 1965 to 1995, Errigo worked as a court reporter. He then established his own business, the Tiro Reporter Service, in 1978. He started a second business, Errigo Sand & Gravel, in 1995.\n\nErrigo was elected as the representative for the 136th Assembly District in 2000. After redistricting, he represented the 130th Assembly District. He was a . He did not seek re-election in 2010.\n\nOn September 14, 2016, Errigo was selected by a  to replace  on the general election ballot for the 133rd Assembly District. Nojay, the incumbent, had committed suicide several days before the primary election while under investigation for fraud. In the general election campaign, Errigo defeated Democratic candidate Barbara Baer.\n\nIn 2018, Errigo was defeated in a Republican primary, 61%-39%, by . Byrnes went on to defeat  Barbara Baer in the general election.\n\nOn October 10, 2018, Errigo was charged with fraud and other crimes.\n\n\nErrigo died on April 27, 2020, from complications of a fall suffered earlier in the year. He was 81. He had been in hospice care for dementia.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Kurt Lidell Schmoke''' (born December 1, 1949) is an American politician and lawyer who was the 47th mayor of , , from 1987 to 1999, the first  to be elected to the post. He is a former dean of the  and, on July 7, 2014, he was appointed as president of the .\n\n\nSchmoke was born and raised in Baltimore to Murray Schmoke, a civilian chemist for the , and Irene B. Reid, a social worker. He attended the public schools of Baltimore.\n\nSchmoke attended the , the third oldest high school in the United States, and graduated in 1967. Schmoke excelled in both football and lacrosse and he was a star quarterback. As the varsity quarterback, he led the  to two undefeated seasons and successive  A-conference championships in 1965 and 1966.\n\nAs a student, Schmoke was a member of the Baltimore City College \"A-course\", a college preparatory curriculum that required him to take Latin and other advanced studies not offered to the average Baltimore high school student. Schmoke was elected president of the school's student government in his senior year but also worked in the Baltimore community with disadvantaged youth. Compulsory community service had not yet been mandated for Baltimore high school students, yet he tutored and mentored young men from the inner city as a member of the .\n\nSchmoke entered  in the fall of 1967. He played quarterback on the freshman team that year. Schmoke played in one of college football's most famous games in 1968. Harvard and Yale battled to a   in a battle of unbeaten teams. While at Yale, Schmoke and his classmates started a day care center on campus for the children of the university's janitors and cafeteria workers who lived in New Haven. The center was named after , a former Yale football star who became a star running back for the , and it still stands today.\n\nSchmoke has been acknowledged as the undergraduate student leader who helped quell the possibility of riot on the Yale campus in the wake of the  in the spring of 1970.  As New Haven filled with radical protesters, Yale students demanded the suspension of classes.  A bitterly divided faculty met to discuss strategy, and invited a student leader to address the gathering.  Schmoke, who was Secretary of the Class of 1971 and a leader of the Black Student Alliance at Yale, was selected to represent the students. He spoke only a few sentences: \"The students on this campus are confused, they're frightened. They don't know what to think. You are older than we are, and are more experienced. We want guidance from you, moral leadership. On behalf of my fellow students, I beg you to give it to us.\" This moment is credited with helping to dispel the growing tensions: the university voted to bend its rules, making classes \"voluntarily optional\" to the end of the term, and despite small outbreaks of violence, no campus-wide unrest resulted.\n\nAfter graduating from Yale with a degree in history in 1971, Schmoke studied  as a  at , and graduated from  in 1976.\n\nSchmoke was selected with five other distinguished former collegiate s for a  by the  in 1996.\n\n\nAfter graduating from Harvard Law School, Schmoke joined the Baltimore law firm of . In 1977, he was selected to be part of the  Domestic Policy Staff during the  to work in the Department of Transportation. After one year working in President Carter's administration, Schmoke returned to Baltimore as the Assistant United States Attorney, a position he held from 1978 to 1981.\n\n\n in 1982 as they both launch their political careers]]\nIn 1982, Schmoke ran for his first elected office. He challenged incumbent Baltimore City State's Attorney William A. Swisher in a citywide contest. Schmoke ran an energetic, grassroots and race-neutral campaign and upset Swisher in a landslide.\n\nOn November 3, 1987, he was  mayor of Baltimore. As mayor, he became known for his opposition to the \"\" and his stance in favor of . He made his position on drug decriminalization known during a speech at the . Schmoke rewrote his speech the night before the conference, adding a harsh criticism of drug criminalization without showing his staff or the organizers of the conference. After newspapers published accounts of the speech, Schmoke faced widespread, bipartisan condemnation. Baltimore's two congressmen came out against Schmoke's idea of decriminalization, as well as Reagan administration officials. One of his most notable critics was Democratic Congressman , who called Schmoke \"the most dangerous man in America.\"\n\nSchmoke initiated programs in housing, education, public health and economic development.\n\nIn 1992, President  awarded him the National Literacy Award for his efforts to promote adult literacy and, in 1994, President  cited Baltimore's programs to improve public housing and enhance community economic development and named Baltimore one of six cities to receive Empowerment Zone designation. In 1995, Schmoke spoke at the . In 1997, Schmoke was a committee member for the . After serving three terms as city mayor, Schmoke opted not to run for reelection in .\n\n\nIn 1999, Schmoke delivered some remarks on the subject of school choice and school vouchers at a  luncheon in New York.  An edited version of a transcript of that speech entitled, \"Why School Vouchers Can Help Inner-City Children\", is available online and in that brief web page, Schmoke explains why he believes [that] school choice and vouchers will improve the quality of public education for America's youth, particularly inner-city minority children. Schmoke first spoke in support of school choice in a speech at  in March 1996.\n\n\n\nAfter leaving office in December 1999, Schmoke practiced law at the firm of  in Baltimore. In 2003, Schmoke was appointed the dean of the  in Washington, D.C. In 2004, Schmoke was appointed an honorary fellow of .  He is also on the board of , and a member of the . In 2008, Schmoke delivered the keynote lecture, \"A New Hundred Years War? The Compelling Need to Reform National Drug Control Policy\" for the  Conference on Diversity in Graduate Education at Yale University.\n\nHe also appeared in two 2004 episodes of the acclaimed HBO series ''''. The episodes, entitled \"\" and \"\", featured Schmoke in a bit part as a health commissioner. He acts as an advisor to the fictional mayor after a rogue police major has legalized drugs in a portion of the city. This is a reference to his own feelings on the drug war.\n\nIn July 2008, Schmoke became the acting senior vice president for academic affairs at . Schmoke continued as dean of the . He also taught election law as a seminar class every fall semester to third-year law students.\n\nIn January 2009, Schmoke was seen holding an umbrella for Illinois Senate designee  during an outdoor press conference concerning . Schmoke was part of the legal team advising Burris during the controversy. Schmoke was appointed vice president and general counsel of Howard University in July 2012. On May 14, 2014, the University of Baltimore announced that Schmoke would become its new president. On September 8, 2017, President Schmoke made the decision to have Department of Education Secretary  as the Fall 2017 commencement speaker.\n\nIn January 2024,  reached a $1.725 billion deal to sell the  to a group led by . The group included Schmoke, , New York investment manager Michael Arougheti, businessman  and NBA hall of famer .\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n*  at the  \n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n''' Martin Malavé Dilan''' (born September 12, 1950) is a former member of the  representing the  and . The 18th Senate District encompasses the northern Brooklyn communities of , , , , , ,  and .\n\nA Democrat, Dilan was a member of the  for 10 years. In 1994, Dilan voted for vacancy decontrol legislation; he later stated that he regretted his vote.\n\nIn November 2002, Dilan was elected to the New York State Senate. He served a total of eight terms in the Senate. Dilan voted in favor of the  in 2011 and voted for the gun control law known as the NY SAFE Act in 2013. On September 13, 2018, Dilan was defeated by , a 27-year-old  who ran an insurgent Democratic primary campaign against him.\n\nDilan's parents came to the United States from Puerto Rico. He resides in Bushwick. Dilan's son, , is a Democratic politician; as of January 2019, Erik Dilan represents the 54th District in the .\n\n\n*\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Zephyr Rain Teachout''' (, born October 24, 1971) is an American attorney, author, political candidate, and professor of law specializing in democracy and antitrust at .\n\nIn 2014, Teachout ran for the  nomination for  and lost to incumbent governor , receiving 34% of the primary vote. In 2016, Teachout was a candidate for the  in . Teachout won the Democratic primary before losing to Republican . In 2018, Teachout was a candidate for New York State  in the  but lost the Democratic nomination to . Her candidacy was endorsed by ''''.\n\nOn November 15, 2021, Teachout again announced her  for the Democratic nomination for New York State attorney general, but suspended her campaign after the incumbent, James, who had been running for , instead ran for reelection. Teachout endorsed James when she announced the suspension of her campaign.\n\nOn January 24, 2022, the New York State attorney general's office appointed Teachout as a special advisor and senior counsel for economic justice.\n\n\nTeachout was born in , , the second of five children to Peter Teachout and Mary Miles Teachout. Peter, who served in the  as a  during the  and has a law degree from , was a professor at the  at the time. The family relocated to Vermont, where Peter became a constitutional law professor at , and Mary has served as a trial judge and founded the .\n\nRaised on a farm outside , Teachout attended  in , where she was a champion cross-country runner and acted in school plays.\n\nIn 1993, Teachout received a  degree from . In 1999, she earned two simultaneous degrees from : a , ''summa cum laude'', and a  degree in . She was also editor-in-chief of the ''Duke Law Journal''.\n\n\nAfter graduating from law school, Teachout clerked for Chief Judge  of the . She served as the director of Internet organizing for the 2004  presidential campaign. In 2009 she helped found the Antitrust League. She was the first national director of the , which promotes transparency and accountability in government.\n\nShe has been a professor at  since 2009. She was a visiting professor of law at  in 2007 and a lecturer at the .\n\n\nTeachout is also an actor who has performed in many plays at the Unadilla Theatre in , directed by Bill Blachly, appearing as Katherine in Shakespeare's ''Love's Labour's Lost'' in 1994 and as Imogen in Shakespeare's ''Cymbeline'' in 1995. She played Winnie in Samuel Beckett's ''Happy Days'' in 2012 and 2019. In 2013, Teachout was Lady Utterwood in George Bernard Shaw's ''Heartbreak House''. In 2019, she played Anne in Florian Zeller's 2012 play ''The Father''.\n\n\nIn August 2015, Teachout became CEO and board chair of the –oriented organization , replacing . She stepped down from this position in December 2015 to run for the  in .\n\nTeachout volunteered at , where she encouraged the movement to focus on the importance of decentralized power, citing the ideas of , and worked to educate activists in corporate law and policy.\n\nIn January 2017, Teachout joined the 's  against President , alleging violations of the Constitution's .\n\nAs of May 2018, she served on the board of advisors of , an organization founded by former   that aims to end . In October of that year she was appointed to the editorial board of ''''.\n\n\n (UAW Local 1981) president Larry Goldbetter at the \"We Will Not Go Back\" march and rally held on August 23, 2014.]]\n\nTeachout faced off against incumbent  and comedian  in the Democratic primary election on September 9, 2014. In July 2014, the Board of Elections received objections from Harris Weiss and Austin Sternlicht challenging Teachout's New York residency. She first ran for the  nomination, but lost to Cuomo. His margin of victory was much smaller than expected, especially since the Working Families Party traditionally cross-endorses the Democratic Party candidate.\n\nTeachout then announced that she would run for the Democratic nomination. Her running mate was , a  professor who coined the phrase \"\". Their platform called for a rollback of Cuomo's tax cuts for the wealthy, investment in transportation and broadband infrastructure, a statewide fracking ban, an end to high-stakes testing and fair funding for schools in both under-resourced and affluent school districts, restoring voting rights to convicted felons, and support for the NY DREAM Act and anti-corruption measures, including public financing of elections to reduce the power of corporate donors and affluent political insiders.\n\nTheir campaign raised $800,000, a small amount for New York state politics. Four days before the primary, polls showed their likely voter share at 26%, in line with the predictions of political professionals.\n\nTeachout and Wu lost to Cuomo and his running mate, former  , in the primary on September 9, 2014. Although Teachout was only expected to receive 26% of the vote (based on polling days before the election), she received 33%.\n\n\nIn March 2015, Teachout moved from Brooklyn to . Ten months later she announced her candidacy in 's 2016 Democratic congressional primary. She ran to replace Republican , who was retiring. In the June 28 primary Teachout won the nomination. She was endorsed by U.S. Senators , , and , New York Governor , the , , , the , , and the . She lost to Republican  in the November 8 general election by nine percentage points.\n\n\nTeachout served as treasurer for 's campaign for  until May 2018, when she announced she was running for  in the . At the time Teachout was pregnant, expecting a child in October, one month after the primary and one month before the general election. On August 19, 2018, ''The New York Times'' endorsed Teachout for state attorney general. Its editorial board members argued that she would be the ideal candidate to hold both President Trump as well as the state government to account.\n\nOn September 13, 2018, Teachout lost the Democratic primary for attorney general to , receiving 31% of the vote to James's 40.6%.\n\n\nOn October 29, 2021, New York Attorney General Letitia James announced her candidacy for governor in 2022. Teachout had previously announced that if James ran for governor, she would run again for attorney general in the Democratic primary. On November 15, Teachout announced her candidacy on her Twitter account and at a press conference in Downtown . Her campaign was supported by  Attorney General  and  Professor . James ended her campaign for governor, and decided to run for reelection for New York Attorney General; on December 12 Teachout suspended her campaign for attorney general and endorsed James.\n\n\nOn January 24, 2022, the New York State attorney general's office appointed Teachout as a special advisor and senior counsel for economic justice. In a tweet, she wrote that she would take a leave of absence from her position at Fordham Law School.\n\n\nTeachout was among the minority of Democratic congressional candidates who endorsed  during the . She was also among the first candidates Sanders endorsed. He subsequently endorsed her for  in 2018, and Teachout endorsed him in the . In a January 2020 opinion column in '''', Teachout wrote that Sanders's Democratic presidential rival  had \"a big corruption problem\" arising from his relationships with donors over the course of his Senate career. Sanders apologized to Biden for the article, saying: \"It is absolutely not my view that Joe is corrupt in any way.\"\n\nTeachout's platform for her House campaign included a higher , increased spending on public infrastructure, a ban on fracking, an increase in manufacturing jobs,  cuts, increased investment in rural infrastructure, an end to  and high-stakes testing, and  (specifically working to overturn '''').\n\nWhile running for , Teachout pledged that she would use the power of the office to sue Trump for violating anti-corruption laws and to force him to  from his businesses.\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nTeachout is married to Nicholas S. Juliusburger, a software company executive. They live in East Harlem, Manhattan.\n\nIn October 2018, Teachout and Juliusburger were expecting their first child. Teachout used footage of her receiving an  in a campaign advertisement.\n\nIn 2020, Teachout enrolled in the  program at . For her field education, she served at .\n\n\n\n* \n* \n* \n\n\n* \n* \n*  \n*  \n* \n* \n* \n* \n* \n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n* \n\n\n\n*  at \n*  at  – Publications & abstracts\n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''India B. Walton''' (born June 14, 1982) is an American political activist and nurse. She defeated incumbent Mayor  in the  primary for the  for  of , before losing to Brown in the general election, where he ran as a .\n\n\nWalton was born on the east side of , New York to Doris Siddiq and Louis Kelly. She was raised by her mother, who was a pharmacy technician, with five siblings. She attended Lorraine Elementary and . Walton gave birth to her first child when she was fourteen, dropped out of high school, worked at  and , and lived in a  for young mothers. She married Vernon Walton Jr. and left high school after giving birth to twin sons at the age of nineteen. Walton later earned a  certificate and graduated with a nursing degree from . She has said she decided to pursue a career in nursing after her experience following the birth of her twins, who were born premature and required months of intensive care. She later gave birth to another son.\n\nAfter she completed her nursing degree, she began work at . In 2014, she was arrested on a charge of harassment, and the case was dismissed by the court. In 2014, she also moved out of her home due to what she has described as abuse and physical violence by her husband, and later divorced her husband after an attempt to reconcile in 2015 was unsuccessful.\n\n\n\nWalton became active in politics at the age of twelve when she protested  with her mother as part of the activist group . While working as a nurse, she served as a representative for . In 2016, after participating in meetings held by the Community First Alliance, a local organization focused on advocacy for residents in the majority-Black Fruit Belt neighborhood, she held a protest against parking practices in the neighborhood. She left her nursing career after being hired by Open Buffalo as a community organizer with a focus on criminal justice and policing reforms. In 2017, she became executive director of  .\n\nShe was also a leader in local , and advocated for Mayor  to sign . She has said  was one of her inspirations to run for political office.\n\n\nWalton announced her campaign for the  of Buffalo in the  on December 13, 2020. During the primary campaign, Byron Brown, who had served as mayor for four terms, refused to debate Walton. The  endorsed and supported Walton during her campaign, after having previously endorsed Brown in his past campaigns. She was also endorsed by the  and the Buffalo Teachers Federation, a union with 3800 members. Walton defeated Brown and Le'Candice Durham in the primary election on June 22, 2021, 52 to 45 percent. After her primary win, '''' reported, \"observers saw Walton's win as yet another signal that a dynamic candidate can knock off a complacent incumbent anytime, anywhere – which might just encourage more challengers to take on long-serving elected officials elsewhere in New York and beyond.\"\n\nDuring the course of her campaign, Walton was endorsed by  , Senator , and New York City public advocate , and supported by Senator , Senator , and Representative . She was also endorsed by the Erie County Democratic Committee. Her campaign raised $150,000 compared to Brown, who raised over $500,000 and received support from the Police Benevolent Association and Republicans. On October 23, 2021, '''' reported the mayoral election \"escalated over the summer and into the fall as a proxy fight between the city and state's growing progressive movement and more business-friendly, establishment Democrats determined to block Walton's ascent\".\n\nWalton is a , and a member of the . In an interview with '''', published in July 2021, she stated, \"It's my responsibility to explain to folks that being a democratic socialist does not mean that I'm interested in seizing people’s private property.\" During a mayoral election debate in late October 2021, in response to Brown stating, \"I don't see Ms. Walton as a Democrat,\" she replied, \"I won the Democratic primary. Secondly, I am a self-avowed democratic socialist. The first word in that is 'Democrat.'\"\n\nIf elected in the general election, she would have been the first socialist mayor of a large city since  left office as  in 1960, and she would have been the first socialist mayor in New York since  was elected mayor of Lackawanna in 1919. She would have also been the first woman to serve as mayor of Buffalo.\n\nAfter his primary election defeat to Walton, Brown announced a , after his lawsuit that sought to add his name to the ballot was unsuccessful. On November 3, 2021, Walton publicly acknowledged that she did not appear to be the winner of the election, while votes were still being counted, but did not officially concede. According to '''' on November 6, 2021, despite her apparent loss, \"Walton may have awakened a potent progressive force in Buffalo politics.\" On November 8, 2021, '''' reported she joined advocacy for Brown to be removed from his position in the . Walton received a letter of support from  following her election loss. In an interview with '''', Walton stated that Obama's letter to her, \"sort of put the final stamp of approval that I was doing the right thing.\"\n\n\nFollowing the mayoral election, the Working Families Party announced Walton's new role with them as a Senior Advisor for Special Projects. In an article by , Walton spoke about the role, stating, \"I’m so excited to work with the WFP to build power for the multiracial working class and elect a new generation of progressive leaders in this state.\"\n\n\nOn February 1, 2023, Walton announced she would run for a seat on the . On February 11, Democratic incumbent Ulysses Wingo, Sr. announced he would not seek re-election. In response, Walton said, \"I think that it's a good decision, and there's time to make way for new ideas.\"\n\nIn April, two community activists filed a complaint with the Erie County Board of Elections claiming Walton was not eligible to run based on not meeting residency requirements. The board ruled they did not have the authority to disqualify Walton from the race for residency reasons, and ruled they could not certify her for the Working Families Party ballot line in the November general election because her nomination petitions did not state she is a .\n\nWalton was endorsed by the Working Families Party and competed in the Democratic primary in June 2023. Her opponents were Murray Holman, the executive director of the Stop the Violence Coalition in Buffalo, and Zeneta Everhart, a staffer for state senator , who was endorsed by the  Democratic Committee. Everhart won the June 27 Democratic primary, while Walton indicated that she would appear on the general election ballot as the nominee of the Working Families Party.\n\n\nDuring her mayoral campaign, she supported the creation of a publicly-run bank, neighborhood-owned grocery stores, a municipal broadband network, and support for homeowners with delinquent property taxes due to job loss or medical emergency. She supported increased funding for public schools and a moratorium on the creation of new , and said she would make Buffalo a . She also expressed support for small business owners and landlords, including financing to small landlords for building maintenance including lead removal, as well as strengthening Buffalo tenant protections. In October 2021, after Walton revealed the impoundment of her car due to unpaid parking tickets and an expired inspection, she described the experience as indicating a need for the city government to focus on how to support residents with the management of fines and fees. \nIn 2021, Walton said she would decrease the budget of the  by $7.5 million by having unarmed first responders, rather than police, answer mental health calls or enforce minor traffic violations.  She also supports establishing a civilian police oversight board.\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Shekar Krishnan''' (born June 5, 1985) is an American attorney and politician who is a member of the  for the , which covers the northwestern  neighborhoods of , , parts of , and a small piece of .\n\n\nKrishnan was born to immigrant parents from , .\n\nHe received a  in engineering from  and a  from the .\n\n\nKrishnan worked as an associate for law firms  and . He was also an attorney at Brooklyn Legal Services Corporation A, directing the organization’s  and tenant advocacy divisions. He is the co-founder of Communities Resist, a legal services organization that represents tenants and neighborhood coalitions in fair housing litigation and anti-displacement advocacy in  neighborhoods.\n\n\n\nKrishnan announced his candidacy in the  Democratic primary for the  of the  on November 17, 2020. Incumbent Councilmember  was  and could not run for reelection. He was endorsed by Dromm,  , and   and . He centered his campaign on immigrant rights, the  crisis, , and .\n\nKrishnan won the  primary with 53.4% of all votes cast. He won the general election with 60% of the vote. Along with , Krishnan is one of the first  to serve in the .     "pages": }\n'''Bruce Arthur Blakeman''' (born October 2, 1955) is an American attorney and politician currently serving as the 10th County Executive of , . He was elected in the 2021 election, defeating  incumbent . He previously served as a commissioner for the  as well as a Nassau County legislator and  .\n\n\nBlakeman was born in . Blakeman's father was Assemblyman . His mother, Betty, served in the  and his father was a  and later  officer. His brother, , was on the staff of President .\n\nBlakeman attended . He earned a Bachelor of Arts degree in political science and government from  and a  from the . During school, he worked on Republican political campaigns and, for a time, was a driver for former First Lady . After , he worked as a partner at his father's law firm. Blakeman also holds a certificate in Homeland Security management from .\n\n\nBruce Blakeman was first elected to the Hempstead Town Council in 1993.\n\nIn 1993, federal district court judge  ruled Nassau County's Board of Supervisors to be in violation of . The Board of Supervisors authorized the creation of the  as a successor to their body. Elections were held in November 1995, and Blakeman, at the time a Hempstead town Councilman, was elected to the first legislative class to represent the 7th district. He was also elected the body's first presiding officer. The body took their seats on January 1, 1996.\n\nIn , Blakeman was the Republican nominee for . He lost in the general election to incumbent Democrat .\n\nDuring a particularly bad election year for Nassau County Republicans, Blakeman lost his seat in the Legislature in the election of November 1999 to Jeff Toback, and the Republicans lost the majority.\n\nIn June 2001, Blakeman was appointed by Governor  as a commissioner of the . He held that position until 2009. He was a commissioner during the .\n\nIn 2007, as a member of the New York law firm Abrams, Fensterman, Fensterman, Eisman, Greenberg, Formato & Einige, Blakeman brokered the purchase of 52 acres of land in  by  for the construction of new headquarters. About 1,200 people worked at their old  offices at the time. Previous attempts to move their headquarters to  and  were unsuccessful, and Canon was expected to move out of state if the deal fell through. '''' reported that Blakeman received a \"multimillion-dollar\" commission for the sale.\n\nIn the , Blakeman ran for , but lost the Republican primary to former  . In , Blakeman ran for the , after incumbent  announced her retirement. He won the Republican nomination, but was defeated 53% to 47% in the general election by  .\n\n\nIn January 2015, Blakeman was appointed to the  Town Council, replacing James Darcy after previously serving on the Hempstead Town Council from 1993 to 1995.\n\nIn 2017, Blakeman joined fellow Republican councilwoman Erin King-Sweeney in endorsing Democratic challenger Laura Gillen in the race for Hempstead Town Supervisor. Gillen, who ran against incumbent Town Supervisor Republican Anthony Santino, went on to win the election, becoming the first Democratic Hempstead Town Supervisor in over 100 years.  Gillen named Blakeman Deputy Town Supervisor.\n\nIn 2019, Blakeman and King-Sweeney endorsed Republican Receiver of Taxes Donald X. Clavin Jr. against Democratic Town Supervisor Laura Gillen for Town Supervisor. Clavin went on to win against Gillen.\n\nBlakeman was succeeded on the Hempstead town council by Republican Assemblywoman .\n\n\nIn March 2021, Blakeman was chosen by Nassau Republicans to run against incumbent Democratic Nassau County Executive Laura Curran. In the  he squeaked by with 50.35% of the vote, which was considered surprising in a county with 100,000 more registered Democrats than Republicans.\n\nDuring his campaign, Blakeman promised to fight the state's  and  intended to address the . Upon taking office, he signed an  making masks optional, contravening the state mandate. On January 24 a  justice in Nassau County declared the mandate unconstitutional under the state constitution, but a  justice  the ruling the next day. In February the mask mandate was lifted in most circumstances, rendering the case moot.\n\nBlakeman opposes the  and has called for its repeal. Shortly after taking office, he issued an executive order permitting the  to disclose when a person released without bail is rearrested.\n\nDuring the  in February, Blakeman helped conduct a rifle  which resulted in the collection of 60 rifles for Ukraine at a Nassau County gun shop. At the time it was unclear how the rifles would be sent to Ukraine: a  said that a weapons shipment would have to be approved by the . A couple weeks later, the Florida gun manufacturer  agreed to deliver the donated guns to Ukraine as part of a larger shipment of 400 weapons.\n\nOn September 19, 2022, Blakeman introduced his annual budget proposal for the 2023 fiscal year. This proposal kept tax rates the same and added nearly 100 additional law enforcement positions.\n\nOn January 11, 2023, Blakeman joined Nassau Republican Chairman Joseph Cairo and other elected officials to call for the resignation of Congressman . Blakeman pledged not to work with Santos, criticizing him for lying about his resume, and falsely claiming his grandparents were Holocaust survivors.\n\nIn March 2023, preceding , , , and a campaign visit from then-presidential candidate , Blakeman created a patrol unit within the Nassau County Police Department modeled on the 's \"Hercules\"  unit.\n\nOn May 24, 2023, Blakeman held a rally and press conference in  in support of  resident . Penny, a former , was arrested by the NYPD on a charge of fatally choking , a homeless man who was allegedly acting in a threatening manner, aboard a New York City subway train on May 1 in Chinatown. Over the course of the rally, 3 counter-demonstrators were arrested.\n\nWhile walking in the 2023  4 July parade, a 10-year-old girl from  threw a water balloon at Blakeman from 100 feet away, striking him in the head. It is a long-standing tradition to throw water balloons at fire engines and politicians at this parade. Video of the incident went viral, having been viewed 40 million times as of August 2, 2023. Many viewers mistook Blakeman for . Blakeman located the girl and her family, and worked with  President  to bring her to a Yankee game and watch batting practice from the field.\n\nIn August 2023, during the , Queens Borough President  suggested that migrants could be housed at the . Blakeman responded that Nassau County had no plans for \"any migrant program\". Soon after, Governor Hochul said the state could not and would not force migrants to move within the state, nor could it force counties to shelter them.\n\nFollowing the , on October 11, Blakeman held a rally in support of Israel at the  Lakeside Theater in . 6,000 people were reported to have attended. Aid for  soldiers was collected at the rally. On November 28, 2023, Blakeman called for the resignation of , president of , over a letter she sent to the Hofstra community about the Hamas attacks in Israel. Blakeman accused Poser, who is Jewish, of anti-semitism.\n\nIn July 2024, the  reported that Blakeman had recruited 75 people for a force of \"special deputies\" to deploy during emergencies. Many of them were former police officers. Critics described it as a  force answering only to him.\n\nOn August 14, 2024, Blakeman signed into law the Mask Transparency Act, an act introduced by county legislator . It was voted on and passed by the legislature on August 5, 2024. The Mask Transparency Act prohibits the usage of a mask or facial covering to conceal one's identity within Nassau County. Exceptions to the bill are granted for individuals with health concerns or religious obligations. The bill seeks to eliminate anti-Semitism and hate crimes in the county that occur during protests. Violation of the act results in a misdemeanor charge of up to $1,000 USD, imprisonment for up to a year, or both.\n\nBlakeman's salary in 2022 and 2023 was $211,821. In 2024, a  increased that to $227,959.\n\n\nOn September 16, 2024, Nassau County Executive Bruce Blakeman has signed the county’s 2025 budget plan, totaling $4.2 billion. The budget maintains property taxes at the same level as the previous year, ensuring no increase for both 2024 and 2025. It includes provisions for 206 new hires, such as two police cadet classes and two correction officer classes. An additional $22 million has been allocated for early intervention and preschool services for children. The budget assumes no growth in sales tax revenue, which constitutes 45% of the county’s total revenue. \n\nBlakeman emphasized that keeping property taxes flat is a key strategy, which he believes is crucial for attracting new businesses to the area. He also highlighted the need for a careful approach to fiscal management, particularly given the county’s reliance on sales tax revenue. This marks the second consecutive year without a property tax increase under Blakeman’s administration. \n\n\nBlakeman is a proponent of a lease from Nassau County to the  entertainment company to redevelop the site of the , including the construction of a . The deal passed the  with a vote of 17-1 with one recusal to transfer the Coliseum lease to the Sands.  filed suit against the deal, claiming that the county violated the state open meetings law by not adequately providing enough transparent, public hearings for the project. Hofstra had also been critical of the project due to possible increases in ,  and . On November 10, 2023, a state judge ruled in Hofstra's favor and struck down the deal. In May 2024, Blakeman announced that the county would resubmit the lease-transfer application.\n\nOn January 17, 2024, Blakeman and Nassau Legislative Presiding Officer Howard Kopel announced the issuance of subpoenas to  President . Blakeman and Kopel accused Poser of colluding with , a direct competitor for the casino license. Hard Rock and Hofstra stated that neither had been in touch with the other. Hofstra described the subpoenas as retaliatory and an \"attempt to distract and impede a fair and open process.\"\n\nOn September 18, 2024, Former President Donald Trump held a rally at the Nassau Veterans Memorial Coliseum in Uniondale in Nassau County, NY at the invitation of Nassau County Executive Blakeman and Nassau County Republican Chairman Joseph Cairo. The Rally drew over 60k supporters. The event took place on a Wednesday night, with Trump addressing a packed crowd inside the arena. Most attendees, unable to get inside, watched from large screens outside.\n\n\nOn February 22, 2024, Blakeman issued an executive order banning women's sports teams that include  from using county facilities. The ban applies to youth, college, and professional sports. Sports teams including  were not targeted. In a press conference beforehand, Blakeman repeatedly referred to transgender women as \"bullies\" and \"biological males,\" and recommended that they join men's or co-ed teams instead. State Democratic leadership and Long Island LGBTQ advocates condemned the order as discriminatory and illegal under state law, and accused Blakeman of using the controversy over  for self-promotion. \n\nState attorney general  issued a  letter to Blakeman; he sued the attorney general in response. In March the , represented by the , filed suit against Blakeman over the order. Later that month  made an appearance with Blakeman in support of the ban. In April,  judge  denied a request from Blakeman for a restraining order against James preventing her from blocking the executive order. Later that month, Choudhury dismissed his suit against James.\n\nOn May 11th, a state judge struck down the order on the grounds that the county executive lacked the authority to impose the ban. The county legislature passed a similar ban the next month, voting along party lines.\n\n\nIn August 2024, Nassau County, New York, enacted a law prohibiting the wearing of face masks in public to conceal one’s identity, with exceptions for health or religious reasons. The first arrest under this law involved a teenager, Wesslin Omar Ramirez Castillo, who was found carrying a knife and wearing a ski mask. The law, known as the Mask Transparency Act, makes such an offense a misdemeanor, punishable by up to one year in jail or a $1,000 fine. A lawsuit challenging the law was dismissed last night, upholding the ban’s enforcement.\n\n\nIn March 2024, Blakeman attended the wake of NYPD officer  alongside  in .\n\nBlakeman held and attended a rally for Trump at  in  during September 2024, prior to the  \n\nOn Monday, October 7, 2024, Blakeman and Trump visited the Ohel, gravesite of the  at the  in  for the first anniversary of the  in .\n\n\nBlakeman married Segal Magori Blakeman in 2015. He was previously married to , who is now married to  of . He has one son, Arlen, and two step children, Ariel and Avi. Blakeman is the first  Nassau County Executive. He is a member of the , a  synagogue.\n\nHis nephew, NYS Court Officer Tommy Jurgens, was killed in the line of duty on 9/11 while assisting in the evacuation of Tower 2 of the World Trade Center. Blakeman provided a DNA sample to identify his nephew's remains.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

DeStefano is a .\n\nSince 1980, he has served as an active member of the Medford Fire Department, and in 1996, DeStefano was first elected commissioner of the Medford Fire District.
