    "pages": }\n\n'''Yuh-Line Niou''' ( , born July 15, 1983) is an American politician who served as a member of the  for the 65th district. The  district, which is heavily Democratic and over 40% Asian American, includes , the , , and the . Niou is the first  elected to the State Assembly for the district. She was a candidate for Congress in New York's newly redrawn  in .\n\n\nNiou was born in , , the eldest of three children, and emigrated to the U.S. with her parents when she was six months old. She went to school in . Her mother worked as a registered nurse and hospital administrator while her father worked as a materials science engineer. They were both from . Her father received a  in materials science and engineering from  and worked as a senior research scientist at the  and senior engineer at  in  for over a decade. From 2001 to 2010, her father worked as a senior director at , a Chinese-state owned company, in . Her mother also worked as an assistant director of environment, safety, and health at the company during this time. She lived in , and , before her parents settled in . She attended and graduated from .\n\nNiou earned her  in social policy from  and worked as a legislative assistant to   and   of the . She was diagnosed with  at 22. She moved to New York City in 2010 to obtain a  (MPA) from , and served as  to , a member of the . In a 2016 interview, Niou said that she first publicly discussed her autism diagnosis with a group of parents representing  who visited Kim's office. Niou also worked as a lobbyist in Washington state.\n\n\n\nAfter a corruption scandal involving  forced his resignation, a  was held to fill the vacancy in April 2016. , an ally of Silver and a local Democratic District leader, ran as the nominee of the Democratic Party, while Niou, with the encouragement of former State Senator , ran as the  candidate. Cancel won the special election.\n\nNiou ran for the seat again in the 2016 Democratic primary and won the Democratic nomination in August 2016. She then won the general election in November 2016 with 76% of the vote.\n\nIn 2018 Niou was uncontested in the primary and general elections. In 2020,  ran against Niou in the Democratic primary, receiving 35.7% of the vote to Niou's 64%. Niou was uncontested in the 2020 general election.\n\n\nSince her election to the , Niou has prioritized legislation related to consumer protection and tenants rights as well as advocating for increased funding for the  (NYCHA). She has also worked to prevent a new housing and office building from being developed on community supported green space, the . Eventually, the garden's nonprofit lost the battle to save the space, which had begun in 2012, prior to Niou's election.\n\nIn January 2019, during an assembly hearing regarding the Child Victims Act, Niou recounted her own sexual assault. The act passed in the state Assembly that day with a vote of 130–3. In the same year, she voted to ban the possession of firearms on school campuses with the exception of school's police officers and security guards, prohibit the manufacturing, sale, or ownership of untraceable , and establish a  in New York. All bills passed the State Assembly and  and were signed into law by New York's governor .\n\nIn 2022, she voted to expand legal protections for  in New York, prohibit arrests for lawful abortions, and prohibit extradition of abortion providers to other states. Both bills passed the State Assembly and State Senate and were signed into law by Governor  in June 2022.\n\nAs a member of the State Assembly, Niou served as the Chair of the Subcommittee on Catastrophic Natural Disasters that focuses on combating climate change and building a safer New York when disaster strikes, and co-chair of the Asian Pacific American Task Force that focuses on fighting anti-Asian bigotry and hate crimes in the wake of the coronavirus pandemic.\n\n\nIn December 2021, Niou stated her intention to issue a primary challenge against state Senator  of . In May 2022, Niou announced she was instead running for Congress in . She was endorsed by the , , , New York City Public Advocate , State Sen. , State Assemblymember , Mayor of Boston , former gubernatorial candidate , former candidate for Manhattan District Attorney , and dozens of other elected officials, activists, and organizations.\n\nNiou garnered about 1,300 fewer votes than  in the crowded  from in-person ballots according to the . While the race was not certified by the  until September 14, she conceded the primary on September 6 after most of the remaining absentee ballots had been counted. She decided against a third-party challenge to Goldman using the Working Families Party ballot line in the , citing her priority of defending democracy in other competitive races and lack of resources needed to mount a serious challenge against the Democratic nominee.\n\nGoldman won the general election with 84% of the vote.\n\n\n\nNiou has a 100% rating from  for her support of abortion rights. She has voted to expand legal protections for  in New York and prohibit extradition of abortion providers to other states. She said codifying abortion rights is one of her first priorities if she were to be elected to Congress in an interview with .\n\n\nIn 2019, Niou voted in favor of a  that prohibits the use of cash bail for misdemeanors and non-violent felonies, requires both defendants and prosecutors to share all evidence in their possession in advance of trials, and mandates all misdemeanor and felony cases in the state of New York to be resolved within 90 and 180 days, respectively. It passed both the  and  and was signed into law by New York's governor  in April 2019. Under the reform, judges retain the ability to set bail in, for example, cases that involve a violent felony, a defendant who is charged while on probation, or are considered high-risk.\n\nDuring a series of  in 2020, Niou criticized the police for \"escalating tensions or resorting to violence\" and called for creating a culture of accountability and fairness within law enforcement. She also supports efforts to  in order to redirect the funds toward social services, education, and housing.\n\n\nNiou has a \"F\" rating from the  (NRA-PVF). She has voted to expand , require license for possession of a , prohibit the sale of , and authorize the State of New York to sue gun manufactures for damage caused by their guns. She is in favor of banning assault rifles and assault weapons.\n\n\nNiou supports a nationwide  system and has been a supporter of the New York Health Act introduced by fellow assemblymember , which would establish a statewide single-payer health plan if passed.\n\nIn 2021, Niou co-introduced and cosponsored legislation to expand the practice of  in New York State. It was signed into law on Dec. 30, 2021 and took effect June 30, 2023.\n\n\nIn 2019, Niou supported a controversial lawsuit to stop a  affordable housing development for seniors in  in . Niou has expressed doubts about proposals to allow for more dense housing, including affordable housing, in  and .\n\nNiou supports allocating 100 percent of residential units in the proposed  in  as affordable housing.\n\n\nNiou supports expanding the  and implementing term limits on Justices. In the wake of the  that overturned '''', she again advocated for expanding the court, citing concern over further erosion of constitutional rights to privacy with respect to intimate practices as established by ''''.\n\n\nNiou supports the .  She has been endorsed by  for her campaign for  in 2022.\n\n\n\nPreviously Niou supported a negotiated solution to the conflict between Israel and the Palestinians. She also supported providing Israel with defensive military equipment to ensure the country's ability to protect itself and believes the people of Israel deserve to \"live in safety and security.\" However, she approves including restrictions on United States foreign aid to Israel that would prevent the use of tax dollars for harm or violations against human rights. It has also been alleged that Niou supports the , which calls for boycotts, divestment and sanctions against Israel; Niou has consistently stated that she's never personally boycotted Israel and believes the Middle Eastern country has the right to exist, but she opposes  on  grounds.  More recently, Niou expressed support for pro-Palestinian protestors at Columbia University, decrying the involvement of the NYPD by University administration and the removal of protestors from Columbia University grounds.\n\n\nNiou is a cousin of , an American voice actor known for his roles in anime dubs.\n\n\n* \n* \n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n* official site\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Mike Martucci''' is an American politician from the state of . A , Martucci represented the  of the , based in the western , from January 1, 2021 to December 31, 2022.\n\n\nAt age 22, Martucci founded Quality Bus Service, a school bus business which provided service to the Greenwood Lake Union Free School District. The company eventually grew to include over 550 employees and 350 buses, and currently operates in school districts across  and . Quality Bus Service was sold in April 2018.\n\nIn each of the ten years Martucci owned Quality Bus, the company consistently earned over a 90% New York State Bus Net Safety Score, the safety score goal established by the Department of Transportation.\n\nIn November 2015, Martucci was voted President of the New York School Bus Contractors Association. As association president, he worked on several pieces of school bus safety legislation, including a law passed by Gov. Andrew Cuomo (D-NY) in May 2019, which allows school districts to cooperate with police in ticketing and enforcing Stop-Arm (bus-passing) driving violations. Accompanying this initiative, Martucci hosted two statewide \"Operation Safe Stop\" Events during his presidency, which brought awareness to the issue of passing stopped school buses outside of the legislative chambers.\n\n\nIn , Martucci announced he would run for the  of the  against freshman  . After winning the  primary unopposed, Martucci narrowly defeated Metzger 50.5-49.5% in the general election. He took office in January 2021.\n\nIn 2022, Martucci led an effort to put forward an amendment that would end school mask mandates. The bill failed, with unanimous Republican support and unanimous Democratic dissent, a vote of 20-43.\n\nIn May 2022, Martucci announced he would not seek re-election to a second term.\n\n\nMartucci lives in  with his wife, Erin, and their three children.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Joseph S. Saladino''' (born March 28, 1961) is an American politician. He is the current Supervisor of the  in , . Saladino previously served as a member of the . He is a .\n\n\nSaladino was born in  in the year 1961, and he graduated from  in 1979. His mother, Jessie Saladino, was a teacher, and his father was the late Joseph J. Saladino, a former  Justice. He attended  and the ; he received a masters degree in  from the latter. He graduated .\n\nAfter graduating, he worked in journalism for six years. Some places he worked at included  and . He also had a brief stint working for the Town of Hempstead and Town of Oyster Bay as an assistant.\n\n\nAfter  was elected  of Oyster Bay, on March 14, 2004, Saladino was elected defeating his  candidate William R. Funk. He won later that year in the general election with about the same percentage, against the same person. He won every election since with at least 2/3 of the vote.  After representing Assembly District 12, he was redistricted into District 9 in 2012 and was elected to represent that district.\n\nIn the State Assembly, he was a strong advocate for the passing of  in New York, and introduced bills related to drug abuse prevention.\n\n\nAfter John Venditto resigned because he was facing federal corruption charges, the Town Board voted near-unanimously to appoint Saladino as Town Supervisor. He was sworn in by State Supreme Court Judge Stephen Bucaria on January 31, 2017, and he immediately changed leadership around the executive. Within the first month of being appointed, he merged the sanitation, recycling, engineering, highway, vehicle maintenance departments to form the Department of Public Works, reorganized the building department to increase efficiency, and created a Board of Ethics. In the 2018 budget, he lowered spending, slashed the debt, and cut property taxes, something he has wanted done in the state government as well.\n\nSaladino won his first election as Supervisor in November 2017 with just under 52% of the vote in a five-way election, and in 2019 he received 58% of the vote, against his Town Clerk, James Altadonna, Jr. He was re-elected in November 2023 against Democrat Jared Behr.\n\n\nSaladino appeared on the April 5, 2023 episode of  to present a key to the city to  world champion .\n\n\nSaladino is married, with three daughters. Saladino has lived in Massapequa his entire life.\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Steven A. Levy''' (pronounced ''LEE-vee''; born August 25, 1959) is an American politician and lawyer who served as the seventh  of , , elected on November 4, 2003. Originally a fiscally conservative , Levy joined the  in an unsuccessful bid for the Republican nomination for .\n\n\n\nSteve Levy was born in .\n\n Along with his brother and sister, he was raised in  by his father Andrew Levy, who owned a Brooklyn appliance store, and his mother, Marie Cavalcante Levy.\n \n His father was Jewish, descended from immigrants from , and his mother was Italian-American and Catholic (Levy was reared as a Catholic). He is a graduate of  in Holbrook (1977), the  (1981, ) and  (1984). Levy married Colleen West on December 2, 1994, at St. Ann's Episcopal Church in . They live in  with her children from a previous marriage.\n\n\nIn 1984, Levy was elected to the   where he served for 15 years (1985–2000). In 2000, he was elected to the , where he represented the 5th Assembly District from 2001 to 2003.\n\nLevy, then a Democrat who identified as fiscally conservative, ran for the office of Suffolk County Executive in 2003, winning the election against Republican opponent Edward Romaine. Levy entered office in 2004. On November 6, 2007, he was overwhelmingly re-elected to a second term with cross-endorsement and receiving 96% of the vote.\n\nAs County Executive, Levy invested $15 million in affordable housing and infrastructure aid. Levy directed increased funding for solar energy projects, clean-fuel cars, and sewer construction. The county spent $42 million to double the sewer capacity for the Hauppauge industrial area, and $8 million in aid for sewer improvements and affordable housing for more than 500 new apartments. These investments sparked downtown revitalization in Patchogue.\n\nLevy transformed Suffolk's long-dormant  in  into a business park that is projected to create as many as 1,000 jobs. In addition, he helped resolve a land dispute that cleared the way for  US headquarters to relocate its North American headquarters to Melville, creating over 2,000 new jobs for the county.\n\nUnder Levy’s tenure, Suffolk County experienced a double-digit decrease in murders, burglaries and other violent crimes, which Levy attributed to an increased police presence on the street.\n\nThe Levy Administration kept general fund taxes flat and lowered the county's share of the overall property tax bill from 13 percent to 10 percent. Throughout his tenure, Suffolk County’s bond rating rose seven times, to record levels.\n\nLevy advocated for preserving open space to secure Suffolk’s clean drinking water. In support of Suffolk County’s tourism industry, he invested in conserving the county’s rustic nature and preserved over 70 of its farms.\n\nReflecting concerns of many residents in the county about rising numbers of undocumented immigrants, Levy has promoted policies to enforce immigration laws, including employer verification of worker status and restrictions on drivers’ licenses for undocumented immigrants.\n\n\nOn March 19, 2010, Levy announced that he would switch political parties, seeking the 's nomination for New York Governor, competing with former New York Congressman  and Buffalo developer  for the party nomination. Though he changed his voter registration to the Republican Party, this change came after the deadline for making such a change. For legal purposes, Levy remained a Democrat until November 2010, with the registration change taking effect after Election Day.\n\nLevy's platform focused on getting the state's financial house in order and reining in spending, while decreasing property taxes. He also called for the creation of an independent control board, much like the ones formed by the state for counties who are in financial crisis, to help address the state of New York's fiscal woes.\n\nDespite the support of state Republican chairman , Levy failed to gain the necessary support at the New York State Republican Convention for a \",\" the document necessary for non-party members to seek a party's nomination. Authorizing such a document requires a majority weighted vote of the attending members of the party; Levy received 42 percent, which barred him from entering the Republican primary, either by nomination or by petition. As a result, Levy was eliminated from the race.\n\n\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* \n*\n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
          }
        ]
      }
    }

He is the first openly-gay assembly member to represent .\n\nSimone is a member of the Vote Blue Coalition, a progressive group and  created to support Democrats in New York, New Jersey, and Pennsylvania through voter outreach and mobilization efforts.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Sal F. Albanese''' (born August 29, 1949) is a politician from . He served as a  member, and ran unsuccessfully for several other public offices including , , and .\n\n\nAlbanese was born in , , . He came to New York City when he was eight years old and attended Our Lady of Peace Grammar School and John Jay High School. He received his Bachelor of Arts in Education from  in 1972. After graduating from York, he taught in the New York Public School system at his alma mater, John Jay High School, for eleven years. Concurrently, he earned a Master of Arts in Health from  in 1976.\n\nAlbanese was elected to the New York City Council in 1982. During his tenure, he earned a J.D. from  in 1990 and became a member of the . After leaving public office in 1998, he became Marketing Director for INVESCO and then Managing Director of Institutional Sales & Marketing for Mesirow Financial. He currently holds Series 7 and 63 Financial services licenses.\n\nAlbanese and his wife Lorraine lived in , before moving to  in 2017. The couple has two adult daughters, Danielle and Laura.\n\nFollowing a failed bid for Mayor in 2013, Albanese returned to practicing law as Of Counsel at  .\n\n\n]]\nIn 1978, Albanese ran for  in the , losing 44.25% to 55.75% to Republican Florence Sullivan. Four years later, he ran for City Council and defeated  51.44% to 48.57%. Arculeo was a 21-year incumbent and Republican-Conservative Minority Leader. Albanese won reelection four times and represented the  in the City Council until 1997, when he became a candidate for . He received 21% in the Democratic primary in 1997, coming in third place.\n\nIn 1992, Albanese ran for  in the . He was defeated by , who won 56.13% of the vote to Albanese's 38.24%. He returned to his work in the City Council thereafter.\n\nAs a Council Member, Albanese was a member of the Council’s Public Safety, Education, and Transportation committees. He drafted laws requiring mandatory ing for  drivers and overhauled the previously-failing .\n\nHe supported increasing police presence in under-patrolled neighborhoods through community policing. He also initiated legislation requiring police to publish response times to emergency calls and led a successful effort to update the City's antiquated  system.\nDespite objections from Mayor , Albanese passed the New York City Living Wage Bill in 1996, which \"required some city contractors to pay higher minimum wages to their employees.\" He was also the original sponsor of a Campaign Finance Reform Bill, stating that \"If the present system stays in place, you will continue to have a city run for a few wealthy interests and by big business.\" He famously voted against the proposed 1995 and 1996 budgets, arguing that they \"balanced [the budget] on the backs of the middle class, poor, elderly and the youth of this city.\"\n\nIn the , Albanese ran for , placing third in the Democratic Party . He earned 21.02% of the vote compared to 's 32.05% and winner 's 40.19%. In 2000, he briefly entered the Mayoral race for a second time before bowing out early, citing the high cost of fundraising.\n\nIn 2008, he was part of then-Senator 's New York delegation to the .\n\nOn December 14, 2012, Albanese opened a campaign for mayor in the . He placed eighth out of nine candidates in the Democratic Party primary, receiving 0.9% of the vote.\n\nAlbanese again ran for mayor in the . He finished second in the Democratic primary with approximately 15% of the vote, but secured the 's nomination and appeared on the general election ballot where he placed third behind incumbent  and eventual Republican Congresswoman .\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n \n\n\nAlbanese became the Democratic candidate for a City Council seat representing Staten Island in 2021, but conceded defeat to Republican .\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n*\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Percy Ellis Sutton''' (November 24, 1920&nbsp;– December 26, 2009) was an American political and business leader. An activist in the  and lawyer, he was also a  and the legal representative for . He was the highest-ranking African-American elected official in New York City when he was   from 1966 to 1977, the longest tenure at that position. He later became an entrepreneur whose investments included the '''' and the  in .Salazar, Cristian (December 27, 2009).  .  '''' (''via'' '''').  Accessed December 27, 2009.\n\n\n\nSutton was born in , , the youngest of fifteen children born to Samuel Johnson (\"S.J.\") Sutton and his wife, Lillian.\n\nHis father, an early civil-rights activist, was one of the first black civil servants a teacher and school administrator in , Texas, and used the initials \"S.J.\" for fear his first name, Samuel, would be shortened to . In addition to being a full-time educator, S.J. farmed, sold real estate and owned a mattress factory, funeral home and skating rink., ''The New York Times'', December 28, 2009.\n\nSutton's siblings included , who became the first black elected official in San Antonio, and , a judge on the .\n\nAt age twelve, Percy stowed away on a passenger train to New York City, where he slept under a sign on  in the  neighborhood of the   of the city. His oldest sister, Lillian Sutton Taylor, who was 20 years his senior, was attending Columbia Teacher's College at the time.  His oldest brother, John Sutton, a food scientist who had studied under , and also in , was living in New York at the time Percy arrived there. \n\nHis family was committed to civil rights, and he bristled at racism. At age thirteen, while passing out leaflets in an all-white neighborhood for the  (NAACP), he was beaten by a policeman. \n\nHe joined the  and attained the rank of  in 1936 and was recognized with the  as an adult. Sutton stated that  was a key factor in shaping his life. Percy and Leatrice Sutton married in 1943. He later took up  on the  circuit, but gave it up after a friend crashed.\n\nDuring World War II, he served as an  with the  – the popular name of a group of African American pilots who flew with distinction during World War II as the  of the . He won  in the  and .\n\nSutton attended   in , ; the  in , Alabama; and the  in , Virginia without receiving a degree. He went on to attend  and , ultimately receiving his  from the latter institution in 1950. Shortly thereafter, he was admitted to the New York bar.\n\n\nDuring the 1950s and 1960s, Sutton became one of America's best-known lawyers. He represented many controversial figures, such as . After the murder of Malcolm X in 1965, Sutton and his brother Oliver helped to cover the expenses of his widow, .  \n\nSutton's civil-rights advocacy took him even further in the minds of many.  Being jailed with  and other activists endeared him to the Harlem community and showed many that he was willing to place himself in harm's way for his client's sake.\n\n\n\nSutton was a longtime leader in Harlem politics, and was a leader of the , also known as the \"\".  The Clubhouse has dominated  politics in Harlem since the 1960s.  His allies in running the Clubhouse were  ,  , and   – whose son, , became  in 2008. Sutton was the one who told David Paterson he should run for the State Senate. He also was a life member of the  fraternity.\n\n\nHe was a member of the  in  and . On September 13, 1966, he was elected  of , to fill the vacancy caused by the appointment of  to the federal bench. He served in that post until 1977, when he  for New York City Mayor against , a former U.S. Representative; U.S. Representative ; incumbent  Mayor ;  Secretary of State ; and U.S. Representative ; Koch won the nomination and the .\n\nIn his race for mayor, Sutton surprised his  political base when he turned temporarily to the right. He assailed the rising crime rate, as he termed the situation \"a city turned sick with the fear of crime\". He attacked criminals for \"cheating, stealing, and driving away our families and our jobs.\" His candidacy was fatally injured by racial backlash that followed the looting and arson during the , directly precipitating his retrenchment from politics:\"It was an especially cruel fate for ... Sutton, a master builder of color-blind alliances, who had long been tapped most likely to become New York's first black mayor. (''New York'' magazine titled a May 1974 Sutton profile 'Guess Who's Coming to ?'\")\n\n\nIn 1971, Sutton cofounded the  which purchased New York City's -AM, and WBLS FM the city's first African-American-owned .\n\nSutton served in the  during the late 1970s.\n\nSutton produced '''', a , music television show first broadcast on September 12, 1987.\n\n\nIn 1987, Sutton was awarded the , an award presented annually by the NAACP for outstanding achievement by an African American. In 1992, he received a  from the .\n\n\n\n* ''''\n* \n* \n* \n* \n* \n* \n* \n* \n* \n\n\n*John C.     "pages": }\n\n\n|term_start   = May 5, 2015\n|term_end     = January 3, 2019\n|predecessor  = \n|successor    = \n|office1      = \n|term_start1  = January 1, 2004\n|term_end1    = May 5, 2015\n|predecessor1 = \n|successor1   = Daniel Master (Acting)\n|office2      =  of \n|president2   = \n|term_start2  = January 1, 2002\n|term_end2    = December 31, 2003\n|predecessor2 = \n|successor2   = Daniel Master (Acting)\n|birth_name   = Daniel Michael Donovan Jr.\n|birth_date   = \n|birth_place  = , , U.S.\n|death_date   = \n|death_place  = \n|party        = \n|residence    = , U.S.\n|education    =  () ()\n|signature    = Daniel Donovan signature.png\n}}\n'''Daniel Michael Donovan Jr.''' (born November 6, 1956) is an American attorney, former prosecutor and politician. A member of the , he served as the  for  from 2015 to 2019. Donovan served as  from 2004 to 2015. He was first elected to Congress in a  following the resignation of . The district includes all of , as well as portions of southwest . Donovan was defeated for reelection in  by  .\n\n\nDonovan was born into a   family in , in 1956. His  father, Daniel Michael Donovan, was a  and lifelong Democrat; his  mother, Katherine Bolewicz Donovan, was a .\n\nHe was raised in the  section of the borough. He attended , an all-boys Catholic school, graduating in 1974. He went on to study criminal justice at . After graduating from there he attended , earning his  in 1988.\n\nIn 1989, Donovan became an Assistant District Attorney in the office of . He served in the office of the  under Morgenthau until 1996. Later that year Donovan became chief of staff to then Staten Island  . He remained in that position until 2002, when he was sworn in as Deputy Borough President of Staten Island; he had been appointed by his immediate predecessor and the then-new Borough President .\n\nDonovan is .\n\n\nIn 2003, 20-year incumbent Democrat  decided not to seek reelection. Donovan announced his intention to run to succeed him. In the election he faced Chief Assistant District Attorney David Lehr and won with over 53% of the vote. A key part of his platform was to start the county's first witness protection program; his office led the city's prosecutors with the highest felony conviction rate in many of the years since he took office.\n\n announce their support for federal legislation to prosecute cold cases, September 2005]]\nDonovan was reelected in 2007 with over 68% of the vote, defeating local Democratic attorney Michael Ryan despite a last-minute endorsement of his rival by longtime friend and mentor   ; Molinaro was angered that Donovan had referred his grandson's case to a special prosecutor.\n\nDonovan's tenure as DA has seen several high-profile cases, including the second conviction of , long suspected in a string of kidnappings on Staten Island. In 2010, famed rapper  pleaded guilty to attempted tax evasion and was forced to pay about $106,000 in restitution and penalties.\n\n\nDonovan became the focus of a national controversy surrounding the death of  in 2014, when a  grand jury declined to indict Daniel Pantaleo, the officer whose chokehold the medical examiner determined was instrumental in Garner's death, on any charges. The medical examiner had ruled Garner's death a homicide. After considering the medical examiner's findings that Garner was killed by \"compression of neck (choke hold), compression of chest and prone positioning during physical restraint by police\", Donovan's office declared, \"it is appropriate to present evidence regarding circumstances of his death to a Richmond County Grand Jury.\"\n\nDonovan asked the grand jury to consider whether there was \"probable cause\" for manslaughter and criminally negligent homicide, but did not bring reckless endangerment charges. After two months, the grand jury returned no indictment. Donovan's office strenuously opposed releasing the trial proceedings, citing New York confidentiality laws, despite being pressured by activists and lawmakers to release them.\n\n\n\nOn May 17, 2010, Donovan, a registered Republican, announced his candidacy for the New York Attorney General, becoming the front-runner for his party's nomination. ,  , also ran for the nomination.\n\nAntonacci stepped aside and endorsed Donovan after earning 40% of the vote at the 2010 Republican State Convention. With 60% of the delegates at the convention and no primary opponent, Donovan became the presumptive nominee.\n\nOne week earlier, Donovan received the endorsement of the , but he was defeated on November 2 by Democrat .\n\n\n\n\n\n\nDonovan was selected as the Republican candidate for  after the resignation of . He defeated Democratic City Councilman  and Green Party candidate James Lane in the Shapiro, Rachel (May 5, 2015). . ''Staten Island Advance''; retrieved May 5, 2015. and was sworn into office on May 12, 2015.\n\n\n\nIn 2016, Donovan faced Democrat  in his first reelection bid. He was reelected with 56.8% of the vote.\n\n\n\nIn 2018, Grimm challenged Donovan in the Republican primary. During the campaign, Grimm accused Donovan of having tried to entice Grimm to drop out of the race by offering to lobby Trump to pardon Grimm. Grimm pleaded guilty to federal tax evasion charges in 2014 and spent several months in prison. Both candidates emphasized their loyalty to Trump, seeking to \"out-Trump each other,\" according to the ''Washington Post.'' Donovan defeated Grimm, 64%-36%, but lost to Democrat  in the general election.\n\n\n*''''''\n**\n**\n*''''''\n** (Chairman)\n**\n\nDonovan is a member of the moderate , the  and the .\n\n\nDonovan has faced a number of protests from constituents seeking town hall meetings. After being heckled at public events, he has instead held telephone phone halls over \"fears that any large-scale town hall will devolve into mayhem.\"\n\nConstituents have organized a variety of town halls to which Donovan has been invited. He has not attended, saying that to avoid disruptions, he only holds town halls over the phone.\n\n\nAs of January 2018, Donovan had voted with his party in 91.6% of votes in the  and voted in line with President Trump's position in 81.4% of votes. He was ranked as the 15th most bipartisan member of the U.S. House of Representatives during the  in the Bipartisan Index created by  and the .\n\nDonovan has been characterized as a \"moderate Republican\". In his  2018 primary election, he ran with an emphasis on conservatism and loyalty to Trump. In the first session of the , Donovan's Bipartisan Index rank fell to 50th.\n\n\n, a nonprofit, nonpartisan research organization that collects and distributes information on candidates for public office in the United States, \"researched presidential and congressional candidates' public records to determine candidates' likely responses on certain key issues.\" According to Vote Smart's 2016 analysis, Donovan generally supports pro-choice legislation, opposes federal spending and supports lowering taxes as a means of promoting economic growth, supports the building of the , opposes government funding for the development of renewable energy, opposes the federal regulation of greenhouse gas emissions, supports gun-control legislation, opposes repealing the , supports requiring immigrants who are unlawfully present to return to their country of origin before they are eligible for citizenship, opposes same-sex marriage, supports increased American intervention in  and  beyond air support, and opposes allowing individuals to divert a portion of their  taxes into personal retirement accounts.\n\n\nDonovan endorsed Trump in the 2016 presidential election. He has called Trump a \"personal friend\". Trump endorsed Donovan's 2018 reelection bid, but in the announcement of his endorsement mistakenly claimed that Donovan had voted for the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act of 2017. Donovan introduced legislation that would require post offices to display Trump's portrait.\n\n\nIn January 2016, Donovan voted to repeal the  (Obamacare). In May 2017, he voted against the  (the GOP's bill repealing Obamacare).\n\n\nNew York City's sole Republican member of Congress, Donovan supported Trump's 2017  to impose a ban on immigration from seven Muslim-majority countries. He said, \"President Trump's decision is in America's best interest, and I support exploring safe zones in the region to protect innocent life.\" Protesters disrupted a Brooklyn Chamber of Commerce event in February 2017, repeatedly shouting down Donovan due to his support of Trump's immigration ban.\n\nIn June 2017, Donovan voted in favor of Kate's Law, which would increase penalties for undocumented immigrants who return to the United States after being deported.\n\nDonovan opposes  (jurisdictions that have policies in place to limit cooperation with federal immigration enforcement). In March 2017, Donovan said that he opposed efforts to reduce funding for jurisdictions with sanctuary policies in place. In April 2018, he introduced legislation that would reduce federal funding to jurisdictions with sanctuary policies in place, such as New York City. In June 2018, Donovan defended ICE's decision to arrest an undocumented immigrant who was delivering a pizza to a Brooklyn Army base. During his 2018 primary campaign, Donovan came out in favor of Trump's wall on the Mexican border, saying, \"Build that wall! Build that damn wall!\"\n\n\nIn September 2018, Donovan co-sponsored, together with  and , the \"Cyber Ready Workforce Act\" advanced by . The legislation would create a grant program within the  to \"create, implement and expand registered apprenticeships\" in . It aims to offer certifications and connect participants with businesses in order to \"boost the number\" of federal jobs in said trade.\n\n\nDonovan was endorsed by the  in 2010. He has been criticized by the Democratic Party for his opposition to same-sex marriage. Donovan has a 64% rating from the  based on his LGBT rights voting record.\n\n\nDonovan has a \"C\" rating from  regarding his voting record on -related matters. He has voted against allowing veterans access to , if legal in their state, per their Veterans Health Administration doctor's recommendation.\n\n\nDonovan voted against the , one of five New York Republican representatives to do so. He said he opposed the bill because it would raise taxes for his constituents and exacerbate the \"already unaffordable housing market in my district\". With the  scheduled to consider legislation in September 2018 that would make permanent individual tax changes in Trump's 2017 tax law, Donovan said he would be \"forced to oppose\" legislation that included a provision \"permanently extending the $10,000 cap on the state and local tax (SALT) deduction\".\n\n\nIn 2018, Donovan introduced a bill that would penalize anyone who causes \"injury, opposes, threatens or intimidates any person\" while wearing a mask, with the maximum penalty a 15-year sentence. The legislation, which made reference to the far-left group , was given media attention after being promoted by  activist . Professor Mark Bray of Dartmouth said, \"It's a law that threatens to clamp down on direct action politics. More broadly, I think it sets a disturbing precedent.\"\n\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n|-\n\n\n''|years=}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Joseph Michael Sempolinski''' (born February 10, 1983) is an American politician who is a member-elect to the  from the . He previously served as the  for  from 2022 to 2023. A , he was first elected in a  held on August 23, 2022.\n\n\nBorn in , Sempolinski graduated from Corning-Painted Post West High School in . He earned a  degree from  and a  and  from .\n\n\nBetween 2010 and 2015, Sempolinski worked in the office of  , including as District Director. A member of the , he also serves as the Chairman of the  Republican Committee. At the time he was selected to run for Congress in , he was serving as Chief of Staff in the office of man .\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nOn May 10, 2022, Reed resigned from the seat representing , a seat to which he had already stated he would not stand for re-election past 2022, leaving a vacancy in the  . The boundaries of the district were to be redrawn according to the . Though two Republican candidates emerged for the newly redrawn district, former   member  and eventual primary winner , both lived outside the bounds of the 23rd district as drawn at the time and decided not to seek the seat in the special election; the Republican county chairmen from the district selected Sempolinski to run for the seat in the special election.\n\nSempolinski defeated Max Della Pia, the Democratic nominee by a 53.1%–46.6% margin. He won 10 out of the 11 counties in the district, while Della Pia overwhelmingly won .\n\n\nSempolinski had pledged not to seek re-election in the November general election. He was sworn in immediately before Congress reconvened on September 13.\n\n\nOn September 13, 2022, Sempolinski was assigned to the following :\n*\n*\n\n\n\nIn February 2024, Sempolinski announced that he would  in the  in 2024, seeking to succeed state assemblyman Joseph Giglio, who employed Sempolinski as his chief of staff.     "pages": }\n\n'''Warren Mattice Anderson''' (October 16, 1915 – June 1, 2007) was an American lawyer and politician from . He was Temporary President and Majority Leader of the  from 1973 to 1988.\n\n\nHe was born on October 16, 1915, in , , the son of  (1891–1976), later a State Senator and Supreme Court Justice, and Edna Madeline (Mattice) Anderson (born 1889).\n\nAnderson graduated from  in 1937, and from  where he was an associate editor of the .  He served in the  during , attaining the rank of  in the .\n\nFollowing the war he served as Assistant County Attorney for Broome County, and then joined the Binghamton law firm of Hinman, Howard & Kattell.\n\nA , Anderson was a member of the  from 1953 to 1989, sitting in the , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , ,  and s. He was Chairman of the Committee on Finance from 1966 to 1972. In this capacity he was the unofficial deputy to Temporary President . After Brydges retired, Anderson succeeded him as Temporary President and Majority Leader. Anderson worked with Governor  and Assembly Speaker  to put together a package to rescue  from  in 1975.\n\nAnderson served in the Senate's top post until 1989, when he re-joined the law firm of  in . In May 2006, Anderson announced his endorsement of former Assembly Minority Leader  for the Republican nomination for governor.\n\nIn his role as Temporary President of the Senate, Anderson twice performed the duties of the . The first was from December 18, 1973, to December 31, 1974, after the resignation of Gov.  elevated Lt. Gov.  to the governorship. The second was from February 1, 1985, to December 31, 1986, after Lt. Gov.  resigned.\n\nIn 1978, Anderson was a candidate for the Republican nomination for Governor of New York, but lost the nomination to .\n\nHe died on June 1, 2007.\n\n, which runs from the  to the Capital District, was named in his honor.\n\n\n\n\n\n* Warren M.     "pages": }\n'''Clara A. L. Virginia Fields''', better known as '''C. Virginia Fields''' (née '''Clark'''; born August 6, 1945), is an American politician who served as  of . She was served two terms, elected in 1997 and reelected in 2001, with her second term expiring at the end of 2005.\n\n\n\nClara Virginia Clark was born in  to Peter and Lucille Clark. She received a  in sociology from  in  in 1967 and an  from  in 1969. She married Henry Fields in 1971; they divorced in 1985. In 1971, she moved to  and became a social worker. In the late 1970s and 1980s she worked in a variety of administrative positions in the social services field, while also becoming involved in community politics.\n\nFields was known for her activism during the height of the  in which she participated in a number of protests and marches, thus beginning her foray into social and political advocacy. She is a member of .\n\n\n\nIn 1989, Fields was elected to the New York City Council. In 1997, Fields was elected Manhattan Borough President, after  served the maximum two terms.  Fields supported cultural organizations such as the New York Shakespeare Festival and the West Side Arts Coalition. She was in office during the .\n\nIn 2005, Fields was a  candidate for mayor of .  In early polls, she placed second to Bronx Borough President .  She received criticism for her campaign's perceived lack of policy-based motivation, with some critics pointing to the term limits of her position at the time as the real impetus for her campaign.  It was discovered that her campaign literature included photographs doctored to create the impression of diversity in support.  Fields never found traction and in the primary she finished third with 15.92% of the vote. Fields finished behind former Bronx Borough President  and Congressman , but ahead of City Council Speaker .\n\nIn March 2006 it was reported that Fields would run for the  seat representing Harlem and parts of Upper Manhattan, being vacated by Senate Minority Leader .  (Paterson ran for  on a ticket headed by State Attorney General  who was running for governor.) On June 1, 2006, Fields announced that she was ending her Senate campaign, explaining that it was not the right time for her to run.\n\n\nFields became President and CEO of the non-profit organization, National Black Leadership Commission on AIDS (NBLCA) in 2008. During her tenure the organization rebranded itself as the National Black Leadership Commission on Health (\"Black Health\") and broadened its focus to include other diseases that disproportionately affect Black Americans. She retired as President and CEO of Black Health in June 2024. New York City Mayor Eric Adams designated June 19, 2024 as C. Virginia Fields Day, which coincided with the National Juneteenth Holiday.\n\n\n*\n\n\n* ''''. New York, New York, 2020\n*John C. Walker,''The Harlem Fox: J. Raymond Jones at Tammany 1920:1970'', New York: State University  New York Press, 1989.\n*, ''A Mayor's Life: Governing New York's Gorgeous Mosaic'', PublicAffairs Books, 2013\n*; Wynter, Leon (2007).     "pages": }\n\n'''Arthur Levitt Sr.''' (June 28, 1900 &ndash; May 6, 1980) was an American lawyer and politician who served as the 50th  from 1955 to 1978.\n\n\nLevitt was born in  in 1900. He served in the  in  and , finishing the latter as a . After leaving the military, he earned degrees from  and . While attending Columbia College, Levitt was initiated into the Alpha Chapter of  which later merged into  Fraternity.\n\n\nLevitt served on the New York State Board of Education from 1952 to 1954.\n\nLevitt was  from 1955 to 1978, elected on the  and  tickets in , , , ,  and , the longest-serving person in this office. He was a delegate to the ,  and s.\n\nIn 1961, he was the  regular candidate for the Democratic nomination for , but was defeated in the  by incumbent Mayor  who had broken with Tammany's leader, .\n\nLevitt was granted an honorary degree from  in 1979. The Arthur Levitt Public Affairs Center on the  is named in his honor.\n\n\nLevitt married Dorothy Wolff. They had a son, , who was chairman of the  from 1993 to 2001.\n\nAfter retiring as comptroller, Levitt became an investment advisor with Lincoln Savings Bank, headquartered at the . He suffered a fatal heart attack at his office there on May 6, 1980, aged 79.\n\n\n\n\n\n* in ''Time'' magazine on May 19, 1980\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Christopher W. Burdick''' is an American politician and attorney, currently serving as a member of the , representing the 93rd district. In the s, Burdick was elected to succeed . The 93rd Assembly District includes the towns of , , , , , , ,  and . Before joining the New York State Assembly, Burdick served as Town Supervisor for the Town of Bedford.\n\n\nBurdick graduated from the , where he received a B.A. in economics and history. He later obtained a master's degree in international studies from the . Finally, Burdick earned a Juris Doctor from , in .\n\nBefore being elected as Bedford Town Supervisor, Burdick held a senior counsel position at Stewart Title Insurance Company of New York.\n\n\nBurdick's personal political career first started in 1977 when he ran as a Democratic candidate for New Jersey's 40th State Assembly District, at age 26. Burdick gained the most votes in the Democratic Primary but lost to Republican Party candidates  and  in the General election. Burdick had previously been a legislative aid to New Jersey State Assemblymember .\n\nBurdick was first elected to public office in 2007, when he won a seat on the Bedford Town Board, running as a . Burdick was re-elected to his position on the town board in 2011. In 2013, Burdick was elected as the Bedford Town Supervisor.\n\nIn 2020, Democratic incumbent Assemblyman David Buchwald announced he would not seek re-election for the 93rd Assembly District, to pursue a bid for the . Burdick won the Democratic primary for the 93rd Assembly race, and went on to win in the General election, defeating Republican candidate John Nuculovic.\n\nBurdick took office as a member of the New York State Assembly on January 1, 2021, leaving his position as Bedford Town Supervisor to Bedford Town Board Member and Deputy Supervisor MaryAnn Carr.\n\nIn 2022, Burdick faced a challenge from Gary Lipson, a local attorney based out of White Plains, but won reelection with more than 63 per cent of the vote. Burdick's campaign focused on protecting abortion rights in New York State and environmental policy.\n\nBurdick is a member of the New York State Assembly committees on Correction, Environmental Conservation, Housing, People with Disabilities, Veterans' Affairs and Banks. Burdick is also Chair of the New York State Assembly Subcommittee on Employment Opportunities for People with Disabilities.\n\n\nAlong with his political offices, Burdick has served as Vice President of the East of Hudson Watershed Corporation, an environmental and development corporation, founded by local leaders in Northern Westchester, Putnam, and Dutchess Counties. Burdick also served as Vice Chairman of the Northern Westchester Watershed Committee, an organ within the Westchester County government.\n\nBurdick has lived in Bedford since he moved from New Jersey in 1992. He lives with his wife, Illyria, and has three children and a granddaughter.\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n\n'''Felix James Grucci Jr.''' (born November 25, 1951) is an American politician from New York who served in the  from  as a member of the .\n\n\n\nGrucci was born on November 25, 1951, in Brookhaven, New York, to Felix James Grucci Sr. and Concetta DiDio. In 1970, he graduated from . After graduating from high school he started working for his family's business, .\n\n\n\n\nFrom 1988 to 1991, Grucci served on the  planning commission.\n\nIn 1990, he received the Republican nomination to run in a special election for a seat in the  to replace John Powell, who had resigned after winning election to the Brookhaven Town Board. In the election he was defeated by former Assemblyman William Bianchi.\n\nFrom 1991 to 1993, Grucci served as the chairman of Brookhaven's Zoning Board of Appeals. On January 5, 1993, he was appointed to the Brookhaven Town Board to fill the vacancy created by John Powell after he accepted a position on the Suffolk County Board of Elections. In 1995, he defeated Democratic nominee Thomas Oberle to win election as Brookhaven Town Supervisor.\n\n\n\n\nOn March 20, 2000, Grucci announced that he would run for the Republican nomination in . Incumbent Representative , who had switched his political affiliation from  to , was defeated in the Democratic primary by Regina Seltzer. In the general election Grucci defeated Seltzer with 133,020 votes to her 97,299.\n\nDuring the election Grucci was endorsed by Arizona Senator , Suffolk County Republican Chairman Tony Apollaro, Suffolk County Clerk Ed Romaine, Assembly-member Pat Accampora, Brookhaven Town Councilor John LaValle, Southold Town Councilor Bill Moore, and Southampton Village trustee Bill Manger.\n\n\n\nDuring the 2002 congressional  Grucci released a radio advertisement which stated that  had \"turned his back\" on rape victims at . Grucci was criticized for the advertisement and Bishop filed a lawsuit to prevent the advertisement from being played.  stated that the advertisement was \"a big turning point in this contest\" as it was initially predicted that Grucci would easily win reelection.\n\nIn the general election Bishop narrowly defeated Grucci with 84,276 votes to 81,524.\n\n\n\nIn 2013, Grucci and his sister, Donna Grucci Butler, stepped down as presidents of Fireworks by Grucci and were succeeded by their nephew, Felix Grucci III.\n\n\n\nOn October 10, 2002, Grucci voted in favor of the .\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n''|years=}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Barry Grodenchik''' (born February 12, 1960) is an American politician who served in the  for the  from 2015 to 2021. He is a . The district includes portions of , , , , , , , , , , ,  and  in .\n\n\nGrodenchik was born in .  He grew up in , a  public housing neighborhood, and attended , graduating from  in 1977.     "pages": }\n'''Zellnor Myrie''' (born November 3, 1986) is an American politician. A member of the , he has served in the  since 2019, representing the , which includes parts of . In 2024, Myrie formed an exploratory committee to run for  in the .\n\n\nMyrie was born in ,  to n-born immigrant parents and raised in the  neighborhood. He graduated from  and attended , earning his undergraduate and s in . After graduate school, he earned his  from  where he served as , prison law instructor, and  scholar.\n\n\nBefore law school, Myrie worked for the  as a  where he helped draft the Tenant Bill of Rights. After law school, he joined . As an associate at the firm, Myrie worked more than 600 pro bono hours in one year. His pro bono work included cases brought by victims of ,  students seeking services from the , domestic violence victims, and s.\n\n\nIn the , Myrie ran for  in the . He challenged , a former member of the , in the  . Myrie defeated Hamilton in the September primary, earning 54% of the vote. Hamilton remained on the ballot in the November general election under the  and  ballot lines, where Myrie defeated him again, earning over 92% of the vote.\n\n\nMyrie chairs the Elections Committee in the state senate. He is also a member of the Senate's consumer protection committee. Myrie supported the . He also sponsored legislation to ban most evictions during New York's .\n\nOn May 30, 2020, Myrie was  and handcuffed while taking part in . On October 29, 2021, six New York City firefighters were suspended for threatening the staff of Myrie in regards to his support of firing certain city employees who were unwilling to be .\n\nMyrie supports financial institutions having the right to deny lending capital to ammunition and gun industries. Myrie has advocated for requiring food regulators to target corporations that advertise unhealthy foods. In 2021, Myrie was one of two members of the New York State Senate to vote against a bill designating  as the official state sport of New York.\n\nIn 2021, Myrie authored the Community Violence Intervention Act, which declared gun violence a public health crisis and which provides millions of dollars to local hospital- and community-based violence intervention programs. Myrie also authored a first-in-the-nation law that classifies illegal gun sales as a nuisance, which could open gun manufacturers to liability.\n\n\n\nOn May 9, 2024, Myrie announced that he was forming an  to prepare for a potential campaign for  in the 2025 mayoral election.\n\n\nHe is married to former politician .\n\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''George M. Borrello''' (born May 27, 1967) is an American businessman and politician. He is currently a  representing  since 2019. Previously, he served as County Executive for  from 2018 to 2019. He first entered politics when he served as a Chautauqua County Legislator from 2010 to 2017. In 2019, he ran for  for District 57 against Austin Morgan to fill the vacancy left by the resignation of . On November 5, 2019, he defeated Morgan with 67.29% of the vote. On November 26, 2019, he took office as State Senator.\n\n\nBorrello was born and raised in  and . He graduated from  in 1985 and  in 1989. He founded Top-Shelf Marketing, a supplier in the hospitality industry. Later, he merged the company with Progressive Specialty Glass Company and was Vice President of Marketing until 2017, when he retired to run for County Executive.\n\n\nBorrello was elected to the Chautauqua County Legislature in 2009, where he served four terms from January 1, 2010 to December 31, 2017. As a Legislator, he served as Vice Chair of Audit and Control Committee and Chair of the Planning and Economic Development Committee. In 2017, he was elected County Executive, succeeding Vince Horrigan, who decided not to seek another term.\n\n\nAfter the resignation of State Senator  in March 2019, Borrello announced his candidacy for . In June 2019, he defeated Allegany County Legislator Curt Crandall in the Republican Primary. He defeated Democratic nominee Austin Morgan in the general election. Borrello was also endorsed by the Conservative, Independence, and Libertarian Parties. Borrello went on to defeat Morgan in the 2019 general election.\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Keith L. T. Wright''' (born January 3, 1955) is an American politician and a former member of the . He was first elected to the assembly in 1992 and was re-elected eleven times. In early 2007, he proposed a bill limiting retail sale of violent  for individuals below 18 years of age. This proposed law stirred up controversy and protest amongst gamer communities. Wright is also the author of the bill to apologize for African slavery in New York, which was second only to South Carolina in the American slave trade, the first Northern State make such an apology. Wright is also credited with coining the term \"\" in response to the shifting of New York's election primary date to the 5th of February. This is now the common terminology for the change of dates nationwide.\n\n\nUpon graduating from the , Wright attended , where he made the Dean's Honor List. He received his Bachelor of Arts degree in 1977 and continued his educational career, obtaining a  from .\n\nPrior to his election to the assembly, Wright was an associate in the Law Office of Ruffin E. Cotton Jr., specializing in corporate and securities law.\n\nIn 1983, he joined the staff of the Human Resources Administration (HRA) as Special Assistant to the General Counsel. He served in this capacity until 1986, leaving the HRA to assume a key position, Director of the Uptown Office, on the staff of then-Manhattan Borough President .\n\nFollowing Dinkins' successful bid for office of Mayor for the City of New York, Wright left city government for the position of Assistant Director of Government Relations at the New York City Transit Authority.\n\nWright's father was also politically active.  He was New York State Supreme Court Justice .  Wright is married to the former Susan I. Gayles and they have two sons, Keith \"Jared\" and Jordan.\n\n\nAssemblyman Wright was a leader in the State Democratic party and chair of the New York State Assembly Housing Committee. During his tenure in the Assembly he also chaired key committees in the Assembly including; election law, social services and labor.\n\nAssemblyman Wright's priorities cover a wide variety of issues, among them: the DREAM Act; improving access to historically underrepresented industries for women and minorities, raising the age of criminal responsibility so that 16- and 17-year-olds will no longer be inappropriately prosecuted as adults in New York State and expanding access to quality education for all children. As member of the Correction Committee and the Task Force on Criminal Justice Reform, Wright is a strong opponent of the death penalty and the Rockefeller Drug Laws. He is a strong advocate for criminal justice reform and following the Alberta Spruill incident, a case of mistaken identity that led to death when police stormed the wrong apartment, Wright introduced legislation that attempted reform \"no knock\" search warrants. Assemblyman Wright is a lifelong resident of Harlem and an active community member.\n\n\nWright has served as Chair of the New York County Democratic Committee since September 2009 as well as the New York County Leader for Democratic Party, when he took over from 28-year incumbent .\n\nWright supported the eventual winner of the Democratic Primary for the Harlem City Council seat in 2023, . Salaam was opposed by two members of the NY State Legislature  and .\n\n\n*John C. Walker,''The Harlem Fox: J. Raymond Jones at Tammany 1920:1970'', New York: State University  New York Press, 1989.\n*, ''A Mayor's Life: Governing New York's Gorgeous Mosaic'', PublicAffairs Books, 2013\n*; Wynter, Leon (2007). ''And I Haven't Had a Bad Day Since: From the Streets of Harlem to the Halls of Congress''. New York: St. Martin's Press.\n* ''''.     "pages": }\n\n'''Michele R. Titus''' is an American politician and jurist from Queens, New York who has served as a New York City Civil Court Judge since January 2020. A Democrat, Titus previously represented District 31 in the New York State Assembly from 2002 to 2020.\n\n\nTitus is a lifelong resident of Queens and graduated from .\n She received a  degree in political science from  () in 1990. Titus earned her  from the  in 1993 and was admitted to the  in 1994.\n\nBefore her election to the Assembly, Titus served as Chief of Staff to Senator  and an executive director for the New York State Black and Puerto Rican Legislative Caucus. She had previously been an attorney for the . She has also been, at various times, a member of the staff of the Consumer Frauds Bureau of the New York State Attorney General's Office as well as the Integrity Bureau for the  District Attorney's office.\n\nA Democrat, Titus was first elected to the State Assembly in a special election held on April 16, 2002 to replace Assembly member Pauline Rhodd-Cummings, who died while in office. Titus also won the  that November with 86 percent of the vote. She ran uncontested in the 2008 and 2010 s. The district comprised , , , ,  and South Richmond Hill. She served on several standing committees, including Children and Families, Codes, Judiciary, Small Business and Local Governments, among others. In 2017, Titus made headlines when she and her husband, Eric DeBerry, sued the state's Unified Court System. The suit alleged that DeBerry had been wrongfully terminated from his job as a court officer; it included a claim that the defendant's actions had affected the couple's sex life.\n\nOn November 5, 2019, Titus was elected as a New York City Civil Court Judge. She took office in January 2020, stepping down from her Assembly seat.\n\n\n\n\n\n*\n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Andrea Alice Stewart-Cousins''' ( '''Stewart'''; born September 2, 1950) is an American politician and educator from . A member of the , Stewart-Cousins has represented  in the  since 2007 and has served as  and Temporary President of that body since 2019. She has previously served twice as acting  under Governor ,  for 16 days in 2021 and between April and May 2022. Stewart-Cousins is the first  to serve as the New York lieutenant governor, although in an acting capacity. She is the first woman in the history of New York State to lead a conference in the  and is also the first female Senate Majority Leader in New York history.\n\nStewart-Cousins was first elected to the  in 2006. She previously served as a  from 1996 to 2006. In 2012, she was chosen by her colleagues to lead the Senate Democratic Conference. After the Democratic Party won an outright Senate majority in the , Stewart-Cousins became Majority Leader in January 2019. She became acting lieutenant governor on August 24, 2021, when Governor  resigned and Lieutenant Governor  ascended to the governorship. Hochul announced she would be appointing a lieutenant governor, following the precedent set in 2009 by Governor 's appointment of Lieutenant Governor . Hochul selected , who took office on September 9, 2021. However, Benjamin resigned less than a year later on April 12, 2022, after being arrested in a corruption scandal. This caused Stewart-Cousins to once again assume the role of acting Lieutenant Governor.\n\n\n\nAndrea Alice Stewart was born on September 2, 1950, in . She is the daughter of Bob Stewart, a decorated  veteran and repairman, and Beryl Stewart, a stenographer and community activist. The Stewart family resided in public housing in  and , and Andrea suffered from .\n\nStewart-Cousins spent twenty years in the private sector, including thirteen years in sales and marketing with  (later known as ). After New York Telephone was acquired through a merger with , she received a buyout and pursued a college degree while working for . She earned her  Degree from  and her teaching credentials in Business Education from . She received her  from Pace University in May 2008 and is a member of , the public administration honor society. She also pursued careers in journalism and teaching before entering public service.\n\n\n\n\nStewart-Cousins's public service career began in 1992 when she was appointed Director of Community Affairs in the City of Yonkers. In that role, she created an internship program for the hearing-impaired and for children in working families. She also advocated for and contributed to the revitalization of the City of Yonkers and was a founder of the original \"Art on Main Street\". Stewart-Cousins was a co-creator of \"River Fest\", a widely attended multi-cultural citywide celebration on the Hudson River in Yonkers.\n\n\nPrior to her election to the New York State Senate in 2006, Stewart-Cousins served as a Westchester County Legislator representing Yonkers. First elected in 1995, she served from 1996 to 2006. During her tenure, she was elected Majority Whip and vice-chair. Stewart-Cousins authored living wage laws, smoke-free workplace laws, tougher gun laws, laws that prosecute predatory lenders, tax cuts for seniors and veterans, and Westchester County's first human rights laws.\n\n\nStewart-Cousins first ran for New York State Senate in 2004, but incumbent Republican Sen. Nicholas Spano defeated her by a margin of 18 votes. In 2006, she challenged Spano again and defeated him. As of 2019, Senate District 35 includes all of the Towns of  and , and portions of .\n\nStewart-Cousins voted in favor of same-sex marriage legislation on December 2, 2009, but the bill was defeated. A  was eventually passed in 2011. Stewart-Cousins is a vocal supporter of abortion rights, and has pushed for legislation to expand abortion access in the State of New York.\n\nOn April 17, 2010, it was reported that Stewart-Cousins was under consideration by then-gubernatorial candidate Andrew Cuomo to be his running mate. Cuomo ultimately chose   instead.\n\n\nOn December 17, 2012, Stewart-Cousins was elected Senate Democratic Leader. Stewart-Cousins is the first woman in history to lead a conference in the .\n\n\nThe Democratic Party won a Senate majority in the 2018 elections. On January 9, 2019, Stewart-Cousins was elected . She serves as the body's  and Temporary President, and is the first female Senate Majority Leader in New York history. In 2019, Stewart-Cousins sponsored the , which overhauled the rules affecting rent-controlled apartments in New York City. During Stewart-Cousins's first year as Senate Majority Leader, New York passed a variety of progressive laws on issues like climate change, voting rights, abortion rights, criminal justice reform, gender equality, gun control, marijuana decriminalization, LGBT rights, and immigration. According to City & State New York, Stewart-Cousins employs a \"consensus-driven approach\" to leading the Senate Democratic Conference that sets her \"apart from her predecessors\".\n\nFollowing the resignation of   due to multiple allegations of ,   succeeded him as governor. Per state law, as state Senate Majority Leader, Stewart-Cousins became the state's Acting Lieutenant Governor until Hochul appointed a full-time replacement. She was the first Black woman to serve in this role. This was also the first time New York was governed by both a female governor and lieutenant governor.\n\n\nIn 2019, Stewart-Cousins was named to ''''  list of the \"Most Powerful Women in New York\".\n\nIn February 2021, she was presented with the  Award for 2020.\n\nOn September 14, 2021, Stewart-Cousins received the  award for distinguished civic leadership. She was honored at  in her hometown of .\n\n\nIn 1979, Stewart married Thomas Cousins, and the couple moved to Yonkers. Stewart-Cousins has three children and four grandchildren. Thomas Cousins died on November 26, 2007.\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n New York State Board of Elections|url=https://www.elections.ny.gov/2018ElectionResults.html|access-date=2020-11-30|website=www.elections.ny.gov}}}}\n\n\n\n\n\n}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n New York State Board of Elections|url=https://www.elections.ny.gov/2020ElectionResults.html|access-date=2020-12-04|website=www.elections.ny.gov}}}}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n* \n\n\n\n\n\n\n* \n*\n\n\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n|-\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"

    "pages": }\n'''Alfred E. Taylor''' (born August 12, 1957) is an American politician serving as a member of the  for the 71st district. A , Taylor's district includes portions of , , , and .\n\n\nA lifelong resident of , Taylor was a troubled youth who was able to turn to judge , who mentored him and gave him an interest in community service. Taylor then served in the  while earning his GED, then graduated from . He later earned a Master of Divinity, with a concentration in church development, from the .\n\n\nTaylor served for many years as the chief of staff for his predecessor, , while also serving as a Democratic district leader and as the pastor of Infinity Mennonite Church.\n\n\nFarrell, first elected in 1974, decided to step down midterm in 2017 at the age of 85.  Taylor, his chief of staff, had long been seen as the heir apparent for the seat. With Farrell vacating the seat midterm, New York state law allowed for the Democratic District committee for the Assembly district to select the candidate for the general election, bypassing a primary for seat. Taylor, being the district leader, who ultimately leads the district committee, easily was chosen as the candidate.\n\nTaylor won the seat unopposed, and was sworn in soon after. Taylor was re-elected in 2018 after running unopposed.\n\nA new purportedly  , \"New York 4 Harlem\", that actively solicited donations of $500 to $5,000 was reported in 2018 to allegedly have been a front for Taylor and three other Harlem elected officials. In addition, a flyer organizing a free bus trip to Albany for a conference organized by  Legislators with New York 4 Harlem's name on it featured a picture of Taylor and the three other officials. Nonprofit organizations are not allowed to take part in campaign activity. The contact person for the event was a staffer working in the office of one of the other three legislators.\n\n\nTaylor has received scrutiny from pro-choice and LGBT groups over his stances on abortion and gay rights. In 2019, he was one of seven Democrats in the State Assembly to vote against the , and he voted against the Equal Rights Amendment prior to voting for it in 2023 in the lead-up to a competitive primary for the .\n\nHe has also faced criticism over his refusal to perform same-sex marriages in his capacity as pastor of Harlem's Infinity Mennonite Church.\n\n\n\n\n\n* official site\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n"
